Title: Poll Shows Bernie Sanders Supporters' Willingness to Pay for Campaign Promises

Article:

A poll conducted by Vox and Morning Consult during the first week of April revealed that supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders express strong support for initiatives like free college tuition and universal health care, with over 70% in favor of both. However, when it comes to funding these proposals, support drops significantly, particularly among those unwilling to pay more than $1,000 for a single-payer health care system.

The poll found that about 66% of Sanders supporters would not be willing to pay an additional $1,000 in taxes for universal health care, with 8% unwilling to pay anything at all. When asked about the percentage of their income they would pay, voters seemed more generous, with half stating they would not pay or would pay less than 5% of their income, and a quarter stating they would pay between 5 and 10%.

Sanders supporters also showed strong support for free public college tuition, but 14% said they would not pay additional taxes for it, and another half said they would only pay up to $1,000 a year.

Sanders' plan would impose an additional $5,000 of federal tax liability on households earning $50,000, with the aim of nationalizing vital services currently in the private sector. However, the poll data suggests that the majority of Sanders supporters, and potentially a majority of voters, are not willing to pay enough to support these nationalized services.

The poll results echo a common theme in top-down, controlled economic experiments, where costs are too great and the system collapses due to lack of funding. The economy where vital services are completely in the hands of government has been a disaster for other countries, such as Greece.

The poll data challenges the narrative pushed by Sanders on the campaign trail, which positions him as a leader of a political revolution seeking to make America fairer by destroying the job-creating and investing class and usurping a corrupt campaign finance system. The poll data shows that Sanders' most ardent backers are not willing to pay for what he is promising; they just want it.

The poll also raises questions about the sustainability of Sanders' platform, particularly in light of the fact that his base is primarily young, college-educated whites, a demographic that has been a consistent voting bloc for the Democratic Party since the 1960s.

Title: Film Director Dinesh D'Souza Indicted for Alleged Federal Campaign Law Violations

Article:

Conservative filmmaker Dinesh D'Souza, known for his anti-Obama documentary "2016: Obama's America," was indicted Thursday on charges of violating federal campaign laws. The indictment alleges that D'Souza illegally donated to a Senate campaign and made false statements in connection with the contributions.

D'Souza, who is 52 and a best-selling author and activist, is scheduled to appear in U.S. District Court in New York on Friday. The indictment states that D'Souza will be charged with one count of illegally donating to Republican Wendy Long's Senate campaign and one count of causing false statements to be made to authorities in connection with the contributions.

According to FoxNews.com, the donation in question was made to Long, who lost a 2012 Senate bid against New York Democratic Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand. D'Souza is accused of directing various donors to give contributions to Long's campaign totaling $20,000, and then reimbursing them. Individuals are only allowed to donate a maximum of $5,000 to a candidate per election cycle.

George Venizelos, the assistant director in charge of the New York FBI office, stated, "Trying to influence elections through bogus campaign contributions is a serious crime. Today, Mr. D'Souza finds himself on the wrong side of the law."

D'Souza's co-producer in "2016," Gerald Molen, told FoxNews.com that he believes D'Souza is being singled out by federal authorities. The 2012 film, which examined President Obama's past and early influences that may have shaped his political ideology, was a surprise hit, making over $33 million at the box office.

Molen stated, "Neither the filmmakers nor the American public can allow this prosecution to deter us from the film's release." He added, "I am calling upon the American people to show their elected officials that this kind of selective prosecution will not stand, by joining us at the box office."

Molen, who won an Oscar as a co-producer for "Schindler's List," said the charges against D'Souza deeply disappoint him, as D'Souza is a "great American."

The alleged illegal contributions came to light during the FBI's routine examination of campaign contributions filed with the FEC during the 2012 election year. D'Souza faces a maximum of two years in prison for the illegal contributions charge and a maximum of five years in prison for the false statements charge. The indictment was announced by Venizelos and U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara, who was appointed by President Obama in 2009.

Title: Trump Faces Growing Threat from Mueller Investigation as Legal Filings Raise New Questions

Article:

President Donald Trump has taken steps to divert attention from the ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, but the relentless focus on Trump's conduct in the 2016 campaign and subsequent events has increased the President's vulnerability.

Over the past week, a series of legal filings related to the Russia investigation has brought new questions about potential cooperation between Trump's campaign and Russian election meddling efforts. The President, however, maintains that he is being vindicated and cleared, arguing that there is no collusion.

On Saturday, Trump announced the departure of his chief of staff, John Kelly, and dismissed new revelations from the Russia probe. He also promoted violent demonstrations against French President Emmanuel Macron, a former ally, and tweeted about the ongoing investigation, stating, "This is collusion illusion, there is no smoking gun here."

The President has a history of disregarding evidence that contradicts his preferred version of events and has mounted a long campaign to discredit the special counsel. However, the deepening record of the Mueller investigation is raising the possibility that Trump's talent in creating alternative realities is facing its stiffest test yet.

New and damaging information for the White House comes at a time when Mueller's investigation appears to be delving deeper into the White House and Trump's inner circle, expanding well beyond the 2016 campaign. The special counsel is reportedly looking not just at allegations of possible cooperation between Trump associates and Russia's efforts to interfere in the 2016 election, but also at possible obstruction of justice.

Trump's former lawyer, Michael Cohen, and former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, have reportedly provided substantial cooperation to Mueller, and there is documentary evidence in addition to testimony from witnesses. The depth of the President's legal and political difficulties will only become clear when Mueller files a final report, and Trump's team will have the chance to challenge his findings and make their defense.

However, it's increasingly looking like the President's denials and distractions are failing to keep up with the special counsel's accelerating pace. The future course of the investigation remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the Mueller investigation continues to cast a long and growing shadow over the Trump administration.

Title: Trump Frustrated Over Sessions Recusal Overshadowing Congress Address

Article:

President Donald Trump is reportedly frustrated with his senior staff and communications team for allowing the controversy surrounding Attorney General Jeff Sessions to overshadow his address to Congress. According to sources, Trump feels that the Sessions news, which the administration deemed a nonstory, has taken the spotlight away from his speech to Congress.

On Thursday, Sessions recused himself from any current or future investigations into ties between Russia and the Trump campaign after it was reported he had met with the Russian ambassador to the US, something he had previously failed to disclose. The renewed focus on Russia is seen as a major letdown after Tuesday when top officials were riding high, congratulating one another on Trump's speech to Congress.

Trump reportedly expressed his frustration to his inner circle in the Oval Office on Friday, stating that he feels attacked by the media, former Obama administration officials, and others, and frustrated that things are not going more smoothly. The President is reportedly upset because he does not believe he is getting the credit he thinks he deserves for his time in office so far because of self-inflicted wounds and missteps.

White House spokesman Sean Spicer said in response to CNN's reporting that "The President had a fantastic week advancing his agenda to lift up all Americans and keep the nation safe. His joint session speech will go down in history as one of the best."

Trump's mood is reportedly adding to tremendous pressure inside the West Wing, and aides have been seen in tears in recent days at multiple meetings. With so much on the administration's plate - leaks, the Russia story, pending executive order, and Obamacare repeal and replacement - White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus reportedly decided not to travel to Florida with the President this weekend as had been previously planned.

White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon, who initially decided to also stay in Washington on Friday, ended up traveling to Florida on Saturday and is joining Trump, Sessions, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly, and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross at dinner at Mar-a-Lago. The White House has not confirmed these reports.

Title: Conservative Defenses of Chris Christie Amid Bridge Scandal: A Closer Look

Article:

In the aftermath of the George Washington Bridge scandal, leading conservative figures have been defending former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie by drawing comparisons with other political controversies, such as the Benghazi and IRS scandals during the Obama administration.

On Fox News Sunday, political strategist Karl Rove questioned the lack of attention from the Clinton camp regarding the bridge scandal and compared it to the coverage of the Benghazi and IRS controversies. He suggested that it would be challenging for Democrats to turn the bridge scandal into an issue due to the significant attention given to Christie.

Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani made a similar argument on ABC's "This Week," stating that administrative issues can occur during campaign mode, and that the Obama administration may have missed some things during that time, citing Benghazi as an example.

The defense of Christie by ad hominem attacks on President Obama and Hillary Clinton implies that the George Washington Bridge scandal is real. If the scandal were a phony one, conservatives would be labeling it as such.

However, for the conservative argument to hold up under scrutiny, the Obama "scandals" would need to be genuine. But, as other writers have pointed out, the Benghazi and IRS controversies are not real scandals, and the public is divided over these stories due to the lack of merit in the accusations.

Conservatives can argue that media bias played a role in the coverage of the bridge scandal, but the scientific term for this argument is "bullshit." The media scrutinized both stories intensely, and the only reason they've moved on is that after months of reporting, they found no evidence of scandal.

Attacking journalists investigating the bridge scandal for not succumbing to politically motivated efforts to scandalize the Obama administration is not likely to retrain their focus on Benghazi and the IRS. Instead, it will make them suspect ulterior motives.

Second, meta whining like this is seen as superficial and unproductive. Liberals spent a significant amount of time during the Bush years complaining about how Democrats would be treated differently if they engaged in similar actions. However, complaining about the media or implying that Democrats would handle a political issue less responsibly might make conservatives feel better, but it also smacks of sour grapes.

The biggest drawback is that the bridge scandal is still unfolding, and new developments could make the situation much worse for Christie. If the lane closures were orchestrated by Christie's subordinates without his knowledge, then conservatives could potentially neutralize charges of incompetence by invoking the Healthcare.gov fiasco. However, if the traffic in Fort Lee scandal is a story of hapless operatives acting out revenge fantasies, then the defense is likely to fall apart.

Title: Hillary Clinton Acknowledges "In-artful" Comment on Financial Status, Maintains Accuracy

Article:

In an interview with Fusion TV's Jorge Ramos, published Monday night, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton admitted that her comment about being "dead broke" when she and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, left the White House in 2001 was "in-artful." However, she maintained the statement's accuracy.

When asked, "Do you regret telling Diana Sawyer that you were once 'dead broke'?", Clinton responded, "Well, I regret it. It was in-artful." She continued, "It was accurate — but we are so successful and we're so blessed by the success we've had and my husband has worked incredibly hard."

Clinton then attempted to shift the conversation towards her concern for working families, stating, "What I worry about is not my family. I worry about other families in our country who feel like they’re running in place, they’re not getting ahead or maybe they're falling backwards. What I want to do—and this is what Bill has always done since the very beginning of his public life—is to try to create more ladders of opportunity for more Americans so that they can have the same opportunities that Bill and I have had."

Ramos persisted with his line of questioning, asking, "Do you know your net worth? Do you know how much money you have?" Clinton answered, "Um, you know, within a range," before mentioning their two homes. When pressed about the value of their wealth, Clinton responded, "Yes, indeed," without providing specific figures.

According to CNN, former President Bill Clinton earned $106 million between 2001 and early 2013. Hillary Clinton has reportedly earned an estimated $12 million since leaving the State Department in 2013. In a June 9 interview with ABC's Diane Sawyer, Clinton stated, "We came out of the White House not only dead broke, but in debt."

Title: Trump Plans Rebuttal to Clinton's Foreign Policy Criticism, Defends Iraq War Stance

Article:

Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, has announced plans to deliver a rebuttal to Hillary Clinton's harsh criticism of his foreign policy in a speech last week. In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, Trump suggested he might deliver his response as early as Monday, before the election in California and four other states.

Trump mocked Clinton for working with speechwriters on her San Diego remarks and dismissed her criticisms, including her characterization of him as "temperamentally unfit" for the presidency and driven by personal feuds, by insisting he has "very strong, very thick skin."

Regarding Clinton's assertion that he supported the Iraq War, Trump stated, "I was against it from before it started." However, it's clear that Trump opposed the war by 2004, but there's not yet any public evidence that he opposed it before the war began in 2003. In a 2002 interview on Howard Stern's show, Trump said, "Yeah, I guess so" when asked about then-President George W. Bush's push to go to war. Trump later characterized his comments as moving toward opposing the war.

Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, countered Trump's Iraq War claim during a separate interview on "State of the Union," stating, "We have evidence and audio of him supporting it, so I think that's another example of him trying to rewrite history."

Trump also criticized protesters who have been involved in violent clashes outside his campaign events, labeling them "thugs" planted by Democrats. Asked for evidence to back his claim that the protesters are being sent by Democrats, Trump said, "Well, they have Bernie signs." Anti-Trump protesters clashed with his supporters outside a rally last week in San Jose, and there have been instances of violence at Trump events in Albuquerque, New Mexico, and Chicago.

Trump suggested that police should be "very strong" with protesters at his events but said he's not criticizing police for how they've handled the protests so far. Trump also defended his claims that a judge overseeing a lawsuit against Trump University is biased because of his Mexican heritage, pushing back against criticism that his objections are racist. Trump stated, "He's a Mexican. We're building a wall between here and Mexico." Trump first broached these issues in an interview with The Wall Street Journal published Thursday.

Title: Missouri State Trooper Accuses "Violent Agitators" of Using Peaceful Protests as Cover for Criminal Acts

Article:

Missouri Highway Patrol Captain Ron Johnson, in charge of the law enforcement response to protests in the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, accused "violent agitators" of using largely peaceful protests as a cover for criminal acts. Johnson made the statement during a press conference early Tuesday, following a night of unrest that resulted in 31 arrests.

As Johnson spoke, two handguns and a Molotov cocktail, confiscated during the night by authorities, lay on a table in front of him. The majority-black town of approximately 21,000 has been in turmoil since the death of 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was fatally shot by a white police officer following a confrontation on August 9. Local authorities have used tear gas and smoke canisters almost daily against protesters upset with the response to the shootings by Ferguson Police.

Johnson stated that officers had come under heavy gunfire from protesters, and at least two people had been shot. He did not provide the condition of the shooting victims. Four officers had been injured when they were struck by rocks or bottles, though Johnson claimed that police had not fired a single shot.

Citing a "dangerous dynamic in the night," Johnson requested that protests take place during daylight hours, allowing officers to effectively isolate any troublemakers. However, Johnson said that his forces could not make protesters leave the streets after sunset if they did not want to.

"This nation is watching each and every one of us," said Johnson. "I am not going to let the criminals that have come here from across this country, or live in this neighborhood, define this community." Johnson added that some of those arrested overnight had come from as far afield as New York and California. The trooper also directed his wrath at the assembled media, saying they had put themselves and officers in danger by failing to clear areas when asked before imploring them to "not glamorize the acts of criminals."

"We do not want to lose another life in this community," Johnson added.

Shortly before midnight local time, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported that police fired tear gas at a group of protesters who had reportedly defied orders to leave the parking lot of a burned-out QuikTrip convenience store that has been near the center of demonstrations over the past eight days. St. Louis County Police Chief Sam Dotson told reporters that shots had been fired in the area and media members were told to go to a designated area about a quarter of a mile away.

Late Monday, reporters estimated that the number of protesters had dropped to around 100, far fewer than the number of media members who were covering them. A photographer for the Getty photo agency was arrested while covering the demonstrations and later released. Two German reporters were arrested and detained for three hours. Conservative German daily Die Welt said correspondent Ansgar Graw and reporter Frank Herrmann, who write for German regional papers, were arrested after allegedly failing to follow police instructions to vacate an empty street. They said they followed police orders.

At his news conference, Johnson said in some cases it was not immediately clear who was a reporter, but that once it was established, police acted properly.

As darkness fell, National Guard units with armored vehicles were waiting at a staging area about a half-mile from the portion of West Florissant Avenue that has been the scene of the largest protests. Closer to the protest site, a crowd of demonstrators was marching and growing in size. Sheriff's deputies in body armor and state troopers carrying wooden bats and gas masks stood watch over the group.

The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported that some protesters began throwing bottles at police shortly after 10 p.m. local time. Authorities responded by ordering protesters to clear the streets and firing high-pitched sound cannons.

Another group of protesters marched toward the police lines and stopped, defying orders that demonstrators could not assemble in a single spot, but had to keep moving instead. The Post-Dispatch reported that an armored vehicle moved down the street trying to clear the crowd and a group of pastors locked arms and helped to move protesters away from the police line.

In federal court earlier Monday, a judge denied a request from the American Civil Liberties Union for a restraining order that would have prevented authorities from enforcing the no-stopping rule.

A grand jury could begin hearing evidence Wednesday to determine whether the officer, Darren Wilson, should be charged in Brown's death, said Ed Magee, spokesman for St. Louis County's prosecuting attorney.

The St. Louis County medical examiner's autopsy found that Brown was shot six to eight times in the head and chest, office administrator Suzanne McCune said Monday. However, she declined further comment, stating that the full findings were not expected for about two weeks.

Lawyers for Brown's family and hired pathologists said an independent autopsy determined that Brown was shot six times, including twice in the head.

Forensic pathologist Shawn Parcells, who assisted former New York City chief medical examiner Dr. Michael Baden during the private autopsy, said a bullet grazed Brown's right arm. He said the wound indicates Brown may have had his back to the shooter, or he could have been facing the shooter with his hands above his head or in a defensive position across his chest or face.

"We don't know," Parcells said. "We still have to look at the other (elements) of this investigation before we start piecing things together."

A third and final autopsy was performed Monday for the Justice Department by one of the military's most experienced medical examiners, Attorney General Eric Holder said. Holder was scheduled to travel to Ferguson later this week to meet with FBI and other officials carrying out an independent federal investigation into Brown's death.

Due to the unrest, the Ferguson-Florissant School District announced late Monday that classes would be canceled for the remainder of the week. Students were due to return from summer vacation last week, but were held out due to the unrest.

Title: Trump Criticizes RNC, RNC Chairman Over Nominating Process

Article:

In an exclusive interview with ███ at Trump Tower, Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump criticized the Republican National Committee (RNC) and its chairman, Reince Priebus, over the party's nominating process. Trump described the process as a "disgrace" and a "scam."

Trump expressed his displeasure with several aspects of the Republican nominating process, including the allocation of delegates in states like Colorado, where Sen. Ted Cruz was awarded all 34 delegates without a primary or a caucus. Trump disagrees with the practice of some delegates not being bound to vote for their state or district winner at this summer's GOP convention in Cleveland.

"It should go to a vote in Colorado like other places... The delegate situation is a very unjust way of doing things," Trump said. He suggested that the best way to determine the allocation of delegates would be through a vote of the people.

When asked if he would call for Priebus to step down should he become the nominee, Trump responded, "I have not given that any thought."

In an emailed statement, Sean Spicer, the RNC's chief strategist and communications director, defended the current system, stating that each state and territory submitted a plan on how to allocate and select their delegates last year.

Trump hinted at the possibility of a lawsuit after winning Louisiana, stating the party did not give him enough delegates. However, his campaign later downplayed the legal threat.

On Sunday, Trump aide Paul Manafort accused the Cruz campaign of not playing by the rules in its attempt to woo delegates. The Trump campaign has also threatened to "file several protests" to the RNC.

Priebus defended the RNC nominating system on Monday, stating that the rules have not changed and there's "nothing mysterious" about what Colorado Republicans did. Last summer, the Colorado GOP opted to select unbound delegates to the Republican convention.

It is unusual for the Republican presidential front-runner and the head of the RNC to be at odds, especially less than 100 days before the convention begins. Last year, after Trump threatened to run as a third-party candidate, Priebus convinced Trump and other GOP rivals to sign a pledge backing the party nominee. Earlier this month, Trump and Priebus met privately at the RNC headquarters on Capitol Hill.

Trump's tone was sharply different during the interview, stating, "I would have won Colorado... The Republican system is unfair, unjust, and they should create a fair system based on votes—not a system like they have now that is based on politics as usual."

Trump also compared the Democratic National Committee's process to the Republican one, stating, "I tell you, it's unfair even from the Democrats' side... It's corrupt there, and it's more corrupt on the Republican side."

More of ███'s interview with Trump will run Wednesday morning.

Title: Late Release of Kavanaugh Documents Causes Controversy at Confirmation Hearing

Article:

On Monday night, the White House released 42,000 pages of documents related to Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's time working in the George W. Bush White House. This late release, just one day before his confirmation hearing, sparked criticism from Democrats who argue that it does not provide enough time for senators to review the records before the hearing.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) expressed his displeasure on Twitter, stating, "Not a single senator will be able to review these records before tomorrow." He also referred to the Trump White House as the "least transparent" in history.

The heated start of Tuesday's hearing saw Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) attempting to begin the proceedings, only to be interrupted by Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA). Harris objected, stating, "We have not had time to read or analyze" the documents, and thus, "We can not possibly move forward."

Senators Harris, Amy Klobuchar (D-MN), and Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) immediately objected to the late release of documents and requested a postponement of the hearing. Chairman Grassley, however, continued with his introduction, talking over the objecting senators.

Other Democratic senators, including Richard Blumenthal and Cory Booker (D-NJ), agreed that the process was unfair and turned the hearing into a mockery. Booker asked Grassley, "What is the rush?" and "What are they trying to hide?"

During the Democrats' protest, a group of protesters erupted and chanted about "obstruction of justice."

In response to the Democrats' objections, Chairman Grassley first addressed Sen. Booker, expressing displeasure with Booker's questioning of his integrity. Grassley then explained that the committee has already read 483,000 documents of Kavanaugh's executive branch service, making it more pages than the last five Supreme Court nominees combined. He also noted that this is "more materials than we have had on any Supreme Court nominee in history."

The late release of documents has not only been criticized by Democrats but also by some Republicans, as Judge Andrew Napolitano stated on Fox News that the White House's release of documents was "exquisitely unfair" because it hardly gives Democrats time to sift through all the information to prepare their questions.

Title: Pro-Gun Organizations and Politicians Remain Silent Following Connecticut Massacre, Marking a Pause in the Ongoing Gun Control Debate

Article:

In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre in Newtown, Connecticut, on Friday, pro-gun organizations and politicians have remained largely silent, marking a pause in the ongoing gun control debate.

The tragedy unfolded when a 20-year-old resident of Newtown, Adam Lanza, took a high-powered rifle from his mother's arsenal, killed her, and then drove to the school. Upon arrival, Lanza, a socially awkward individual described as being on the autism spectrum, forced his way into the school and killed 20 first-graders at close range and six school staff attempting to shield the children.

Conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh criticized gun control proponents as early as Friday for trying to exploit the tragedy for political gain. This approach seemed to strike an awkward note in a country where even pro-gun rights Americans paused to consider the implications of America's long-running affinity for guns.

When David Gregory, host of NBC’s “Meet the Press,” sent out 31 invitations to pro-gun Senators in the new Congress to discuss the issue on Sunday, no takers emerged. The Shooting Sports Foundation, a pro-gun rights group headquartered just a few miles from where the shootings took place, also remained silent, as did the National Rifle Association (NRA).

In the absence of pro-gun rights voices, some conservative bloggers reminded readers of several instances in recent years when legal gun carriers thwarted gunmen intent on killing many people. In Portland, Oregon, one concealed weapons owner claims he brandished his gun after alleged mall shooter Jacob Roberts opened fire. According to the man, Roberts, whose rifle was jamming, fled the scene after seeing the gun and minutes later shot himself.

Even on the blog of Eugene Volokh, a Russian-born UCLA law professor whose article “The Commonplace Second Amendment” has been cited in recent court rulings favoring gun rights, commenters sounded less partisan than thoughtful in response to a blog entry where Mr. Volokh acknowledged no one knows if arming more Americans in anticipation of mass shootings would ultimately save lives.

After Friday’s massacre in Connecticut became the 7th major mass shooting in the US this year, police later Friday arrested a Cedar Lake, Indiana, man who owned 47 guns, after he threatened to go to a local elementary school and open fire.

On Sunday, a man in Newport Beach, California, fired 50 shots in a mall parking lot, hurting no one. In July, a college dropout proclaiming he was “The Joker” opened fire on a midnight screening of a “Batman” movie in Aurora, Colorado, killing 12 people and injuring 58, many of them seriously.

Previous massacres, including the Aurora shootings, have barely budged American support for the Second Amendment, which the Supreme Court in recent years has ruled applies to Americans armed to defend themselves and their homes. However, some polls suggest a majority of Americans do support some gradual restrictions on gun ownership.

Sensing a pause from pro-gun rights groups and individuals, pro-gun control advocates like Huffington Post columnist Robert Cavnar, a licensed gun owner, noted that “the conversation has finally begun.”

“The age and innocence of the victims in this massacre, coming right on the heels of the Oregon shootings and the Jovan Belcher murder-suicide, have finally caused the self-imposed discussion moratorium, enforced by the millions of dollars invested by the NRA and gun manufacturers, to be ended,” he writes. As proof, he says, “The NRA has uncharacteristically gone subterranean since the shooting, and its website is completely silent on the matter.”

Rep. Louie Gohmert (R) of Texas became the only national voice to wave the Second Amendment banner in the wake of the shootings. He told Fox News' Chris Wallace on Sunday that the massacre could have been averted had the principal been heavily armed.

After saying mass killers tend to choose gun-free zones as places to attack, he noted, “Chris, I wish to God [slain principal Dawn Hochsprung] had had an M-4 in her office, locked up so when she heard gunfire, she pulls it out…and takes him out…before he can kill those precious kids.”

Title: Obama Administration Halts Arctic Oil Drilling Lease Sales Through 2017

Article:

The Obama administration has announced the cancellation of plans to sell oil drilling rights in the Arctic Sea through 2017, marking a significant change in policy following the approval of new drilling permits for Shell Oil earlier this year. This decision comes in response to Royal Dutch Shell's decision last month to suspend its oil exploration in offshore Alaskan waters due to disappointing results from a well in the Chukchi Sea.

Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell stated, "In light of Shell's announcement, the amount of acreage already under lease and current market conditions, it does not make sense to prepare for lease sales in the Arctic in the next year and a half."

Environmental groups, who criticized the administration for approving permits for Shell to drill while President Obama was highlighting the effects of climate change in Alaska, have applauded this move. The Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) called it "an essential reprieve" for Arctic Waters. NRDC's Franz Matzner stated, "The next step should be to take Arctic and Atlantic waters off the table to oil and gas drilling for good."

In addition, the department also denied requests by Shell and the Norwegian company Statoil to extend their existing leases beyond 10 years. Both companies had asked for five-year extensions, arguing that they should have more time due to regulations preventing them from exploring for oil. Without those extensions, the leases will expire by 2020.

Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) criticized the decision, stating it was "absurd." She argued that the Interior Department is creating regulatory roadblocks to prevent drilling and then using the lack of drilling to justify canceling the lease sales. Murkowski, who chairs the Senate Energy Committee, said, "This is a stunning, short-sighted move that betrays the Interior Department’s commitments to Alaska and the best interests of our nation’s long-term energy security." She further stated that the decision is part of a destructive pattern of hostility toward energy production in Alaska that began the first day this administration took office.

Title: Bipartisan Praise for Obama Administration's Diplomatic Post Closures in Response to Terror Threat

Article:

The Obama administration's decision to close diplomatic posts across Central Asia, the Middle East, and North Africa over the weekend has received praise from lawmakers in both political parties. The Washington Post reports that this response is being hailed as a smart move in light of the most serious intelligence since the September 11, 2001, attacks, suggesting potential terrorist strikes in the affected regions or elsewhere.

House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Michael McCaul (R-Texas) commended the administration's decision on CBS-TV's Face the Nation, stating, "The administration's call to close these embassies... was actually a very smart call." Representative Dutch Ruppersberger (D-Md.) echoed this sentiment on ABC-TV's This Week, saying, "What we have to do now is the most important issue, is protect Americans throughout the world."

Initially, 19 locations were affected by the closures, including Abu Dhabi, Amman, Cairo, Riyadh, Dhahran, Jeddah, Doha, Dubai, Kuwait, Manama, Muscat, Sanaa, Tripoli, Antanarivo, Bujumbura, Djibouti, Khartoum, Kigali, and Port Louis. Posts in nine locations were set to reopen on Monday: Dhaka, Algiers, Nouakchott, Kabul, Herat, Mazar el Sharif, Baghdad, Basrah, and Erbil.

The terror threat has not only brought together some lawmakers but has also influenced the ongoing discussion about National Security Agency (NSA) surveillance programs. As reported by NPR's Dina Temple-Raston, the subject has shifted from debating whether to curb these programs—a debate sparked by the revelations of Edward Snowden, the so-called "NSA leaker"—to a discussion of the programs' effectiveness in uncovering potential terrorist attacks.

According to The Hill, the "weekend terror threat... has opened up a new front in the debate over the NSA's surveillance programs." A handful of lawmakers, primarily national security hawks, have used the Sunday news shows to declare the NSA programs a success and credit the controversial surveillance methods for uncovering a potential terrorist attack.

Title: Biden Secures Victory in Maine, Leads Democratic Presidential Race with 10 Super Tuesday Wins

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden has emerged victorious in the Democratic presidential primary in Maine, making it the last state to be called in the Super Tuesday contests. Biden's win in Maine adds to his 10 victories, leaving him ahead of Senator Bernie Sanders, who has secured four wins.

Biden's Super Tuesday victories include primaries in Texas, Arkansas, Alabama, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Minnesota, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Virginia, and Maine. Sanders, an Independent from Vermont, won his home state, as well as Colorado and Utah. He also claimed victory in California, the delegate-rich state of the Super Tuesday contests.

Biden, who was the unrivaled front-runner before the early primary contests, faced a setback with lackluster fourth- and fifth-place showings in Iowa and New Hampshire. A slight rebound in Nevada's caucuses last month, where he came in a distant second to Sanders, and a landslide victory in South Carolina last week, gave him momentum going into the Super Tuesday contests.

The waning field of rivals, with moderate candidates like former South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., suspending their campaigns and endorsing Biden, consolidated the moderate vote in states that voted Tuesday. Former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg also suspended his campaign and endorsed Biden on Wednesday, making the race, essentially, a two-candidate contest. Senator Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., who had a poor showing on Super Tuesday, is still in the race.

In his victory speech, Biden told supporters, "To those who've been knocked down, counted out, left behind, this is your campaign." He added, "It may be over for the other guy."

Sanders, despite finishing behind Biden Tuesday night, expressed excitement about his campaign's position. "I am excited about where we are. We have come a long, long way," Sanders said Tuesday night.

The next tests for the candidates will come on Tuesday, when voters in Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, North Dakota, and Washington state head to the polls, and on St. Patrick's Day, March 17, when Arizona, Florida, Illinois, and Ohio have their chance to vote. Georgia will hold its primary on March 24. As of 2 p.m. ET Wednesday, Biden had 566 delegates to Sanders' 501. A candidate must reach 1,991 delegates to clinch the Democratic nomination for president.

Title: The Rise of Donald Trump and the Shift in Republican Economic Messaging

Article:

For the past several decades, the Republican party has been advocating an economic message that positions the prosperity of the wealthy as beneficial for the general public. However, the recent rise of Donald Trump, a candidate who has been described as a demagogue, indicates a shift in the party's base's acceptance of this message.

The Republican establishment has faced significant challenges in the 2016 election, with their candidates being not only defeated but also humiliated by Trump, whose rhetoric has been compared to that of Benito Mussolini and George Wallace. This shift can be attributed to the growing disillusionment among the Republican voter base, who feel they have been misled by the party's economic narrative.

The economic narrative the right wing of the Republican party, often referred to as the Money Party, has been promoting for the past 40 years is based on the idea that the economy flourished in the decades following World War II, but has since been hindered by excessive government regulation, high taxes, and an overly generous welfare system. This narrative suggests that the American dream has been stifled due to these factors, leading to the economic struggles experienced by ordinary Americans.

However, an examination of the actual economic history of America since 1945 reveals a different story. Inflation-adjusted per capita GDP in the U.S. grew from $17,490 in 1945 to $27,837 in 1974, and then increased to $55,185 in 2014, nearly doubling since 1974. This indicates that the country is twice as rich per person now as it was then.

Despite this wealth increase, the average household income of the bottom 50% of American households was $25,475 in 1974 and $26,520 in 2014. This means that half the population has not benefited from the additional $10 trillion of national wealth generated over the past 40 years. This group includes half of the nation's middle class.

Meanwhile, the average household income of the top 5% of American households has increased from $187,729 to $332,347 over the same period. The income of the top 0.01% of households, approximately the nation's 13,000 wealthiest households, has increased by about seven-fold, from less than $5 million to more than $30 million per year.

Trump's appeal to voters extends beyond his exploitation of racism and xenophobia, as he taps into the economic anxieties of white middle and working-class voters. His message, albeit crude and bombastic, resonates with many people who feel they have been losers in the contemporary economy, despite the party's promises of a thriving economy.

The Republican party's focus on issues such as cutting capital gains taxes, eliminating the estate tax, and reducing Social Security and Medicare may not align with the economic interests of middle- and working-class Americans, even if they are culturally conservative. These voters are angry about the empty promises of a Republican party that caters to the economic interests of the rich.

In conclusion, the rise of Donald Trump and the shift in the Republican base's acceptance of the party's economic message can be attributed to the growing disillusionment among the working and middle classes. The party's narrative, which positions the prosperity of the wealthy as beneficial for all, has been exposed as a myth, as the majority of Americans have not experienced the economic benefits of the past four decades.

Title: Grand Jury Decision in Ferguson Shooting Case: Latest Developments

Article:

In the aftermath of the grand jury's decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson for the shooting of Michael Brown, several developments have unfolded in Ferguson, Missouri, and beyond.

1. Darren Wilson Speaks: Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson, who shot and killed Michael Brown on August 9, spoke publicly for the first time on Tuesday with ABC News. Wilson described the altercation, stating that Brown did not have his hands up when he was fatally shot.

2. President Obama's Remarks: President Obama, speaking from Chicago at a scheduled immigration event, condemned the "destructive" behavior that caused fires, gunfire, and property damage. He also acknowledged the many peaceful protests throughout the country, expressing his support for them.

3. Governor Nixon's Press Conference: Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, in a press conference alongside National Guard and law enforcement leaders, promised to deploy more than 2,200 troops to maintain peace in Ferguson.

4. Ferguson Mayor's Criticism: Ferguson Mayor James Knowles criticized the National Guard for a slow response, stating that they did not deploy quickly enough to prevent violence and arson in the wake of the grand jury's decision.

5. Wilson's Public Appearance: Officer Darren Wilson will speak with ABC's George Stephanopoulos on World News Tonight at 6:30 p.m. ET, marking his first public appearance since the shooting.

6. Family's Response: Benjamin Crump, a lawyer representing Michael Brown's family, criticized the prosecutor who handled the grand jury, stating, "We object as publicly and loudly as we can on behalf of Michael Brown Jr.'s family that this process is broken. The process should be indicted."

7. Grand Jury Testimony: The grand jury documents, which are detailed, include Wilson's account of the altercation, describing Brown as looking like a "demon" and the encounter as "fighting Hulk Hogan."

8. Arrests and Violence: At a Tuesday news conference, authorities reported 61 arrests, with 59 of those arrested being local residents. St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar stated that it took "10,000 policemen" to control the chaos, and that the situation on Tuesday night was worse than the worst night in August.

9. Social Media Activity: Twitter reported over 3.5 million tweets sent by midnight ET after the decision was announced at about 9 p.m.

10. Overnight in Ferguson: The streets of Ferguson were calmer on Tuesday morning. Police reported 29 arrests, two police cars set on fire, at least a dozen buildings burning, looting, and rioting. One officer was shot (not seriously), and police used tear gas to disperse crowds. However, no deaths or serious injuries have been reported. Flight restrictions out of Lambert-St. Louis International Airport have expired.

11. Gunshots and Building Fires: St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar reported at a 1:30 a.m. CT news conference that at least a dozen buildings were burning and at least 150 gunshots had been fired, none by police.

12. Police Officer Shot and Woman Killed: In a burglary that may have been timed to take advantage of law-enforcement focus elsewhere, a police officer was shot, and a woman was killed in a St. Louis suburb south of Ferguson, Missouri. The suspect remains at large.

13. FAA No-Fly Zone: The Federal Aviation Administration issued a no-fly zone at 11:15 p.m. ET to "provide a safe environment for law enforcement activities."

14. Protests Turn Violent: Despite efforts by Brown's family and civil rights activists, minutes after the ruling, violent protests erupted in Ferguson. Demonstrators taunted police, shattered windows, and set fire to two St. Louis County police cars. Scores of police officers, armed with riot gear, dispersed a crowd of about 300 with volley after volley of smoke bombs, pepper spray, and bean bags. Looters plundered a Walgreens and Autozone store, while a Little Caesars pizza restaurant and local beauty shop were set ablaze.

15. Peaceful Protests in Other Cities: Demonstrators reacted more peacefully in several other cities, including New York, Oakland, Philadelphia, Detroit, and Washington, D.C. In New York, hundreds marched to Times Square chanting, "No justice, no peace, no racist police," and carrying signs that read, "Jail Killing Cops" and "Resistance Is Justified." Protesters in Oakland, California, laid in the middle of an intersection in silent protest, then marched down Broadway shouting, "Hands up, don't shoot," and "Black lives matter—all lives matter."

16. President Obama's Call for Calm: In a nearly 10-minute statement in the White House press room after the ruling, President Obama said, "We are a nation built on the rule of law." He urged, "We need to accept this decision was the grand jury's to make." He later added, "We need to recognize that the situation in Ferguson speaks to the broader problems that we still face as a nation."

Title: Mueller's Indictment of Gates and Manafort Deepens Legal Peril for Key Figures in Russia Investigation

Article:

Special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russia's interference in the 2016 presidential election has resulted in new criminal charges against former Trump campaign aide Richard Gates and President Trump's former campaign chairman Paul Manafort. The charges, unveiled on Thursday, accuse the pair of tax evasion, bank fraud, and money laundering.

Observers had anticipated that Gates, a key figure in Mueller's investigation due to his close relationship with Manafort, might strike an agreement with Mueller to avoid trial. The superseding indictment released Thursday deepens the legal peril for Gates, potentially aiming to maximize pressure on him should he be wavering on cooperating with the investigation.

Seth Waxman, a former federal prosecutor, stated that the timing of the filing is intended to continue ratcheting up the pressure on Manafort and Gates to cooperate with the investigation. Waxman suggested that the new filings signal to Gates that Mueller is not "messing around."

Gates' testimony at trial could prove especially damaging for Manafort, as they worked hand-in-hand for over a decade, including on lobbying work for a pro-Russia political party in Ukraine. Steven Cash, a lawyer at Day Pitney who specializes in criminal litigation and national security-related matters, noted that Gates' testimony would be like having the second-in-command of a company testify against the CEO.

A plea agreement with Gates would put heavy pressure on Manafort to cut a deal of his own. If he flipped, it's possible he could give Mueller inside information about any contact between the Trump campaign and Moscow during the summer of 2016, a key period when Russia began orchestrating the release of hacked Democratic emails.

Trump has denied any collusion between his campaign and Russia, describing the allegations as a "hoax." Mueller's team first unveiled an indictment against Manafort and Gates in late October, which included bank transactions and accused them of money laundering, bank fraud, and other financial crimes stemming from work overseas that pre-dated their involvement in Trump's presidential campaign.

Former prosecutors suggest that Gates' testimony, should he choose to cooperate, could help prosecutors sort through their evidence against Manafort. He could also fill in holes in timelines and help walk prosecutors through some of the complex financial transactions that he and Manafort are accused of carrying out.

The possibility of Gates on the witness stand could be enough to get Manafort to cooperate with Mueller's prosecutors, which is likely their main goal. Manafort worked for Trump's campaign for six months before resigning under pressure in August 2016 over reports of his dealings with a pro-Russia oligarch in Ukraine. He was in the room for a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower with a Russian lawyer who had promised Donald Trump Jr. damaging information on Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign, and could provide inside information about any contact between the campaign and Russia.

If Gates were to strike a plea deal, he would be the fourth known witness to cooperate with Mueller's investigation, in addition to former national security adviser Michael Flynn, former Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos, and a California man ensnared in the probe for selling bank account numbers to foreigners committing identity fraud.

"I think the question is not are there going to be more indictments and guilty pleas. I think there will be," said Jack Sharman, a former Whitewater special counsel. "The larger question is ultimately what is the relation of any of those offenses to the original core mission of the special counsel, who was appointed because of concerns over presidential campaign involvement."

Title: Monsanto Ordered to Pay $289 Million in Damages in Glyphosate Cancer Case

Article:

A California jury has ordered chemical giant Monsanto to pay $289 million in damages to Dewayne Johnson, a man who claimed that the company's Roundup and RangerPro herbicides, containing glyphosate, caused his non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. This is the first lawsuit to go to trial alleging a glyphosate link to cancer.

The jury found that Monsanto knew its weedkillers were dangerous and failed to warn consumers. The company denies that glyphosate causes cancer and intends to appeal against the ruling.

Dewayne Johnson, a groundskeeper, was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 2014. He regularly used a form of RangerPro while working at a school in Benicia, California. The implications of this verdict will be felt far beyond Monsanto's headquarters in Missouri.

Glyphosate is the world's most common weedkiller, and the science about its safety is still far from settled. In 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the World Health Organization's cancer agency, concluded that it was "probably carcinogenic to humans." However, the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) continues to insist that glyphosate is safe when used carefully.

The EPA's assessment has been questioned, with campaigners citing evidence of what they say was inappropriate industry involvement in the decision. Some Democrats have even called for a Department of Justice investigation into alleged collusion between government officials and Monsanto.

In California, where a judge recently ruled that coffee must carry a cancer warning, the agriculture industry sued to prevent such a label for glyphosate. In Europe, the battle over glyphosate has been fierce. French President Emmanuel Macron is trying to ban it despite the resistance of some French lawmakers and the fact that the European Commission recently granted the weedkiller another five-year license.

The jury found that Monsanto had acted with "malice" and that its weedkillers contributed "substantially" to Johnson's terminal illness. The jury ordered the agricultural multi-national to pay $250 million in punitive damages, together with other costs that brought the total figure to almost $290 million.

Johnson's lawyer, Brent Wisner, said the jury's verdict showed that the evidence against the product was "overwhelming." "When you are right, it is really easy to win," he said, adding that the ruling was just "the tip of the spear" of future legal cases.

In a statement after the ruling, Monsanto said it was "sympathetic to Mr. Johnson and his family" but would "continue to vigorously defend this product, which has a 40-year history of safe use." The company added, "Today's decision does not change the fact that more than 800 scientific studies and reviews - and conclusions by the US Environmental Protection Agency, the US National Institutes of Health, and regulatory authorities around the world - support the fact that glyphosate does not cause cancer, and did not cause Mr. Johnson's cancer."

Title: Investigation Intensifies Following Boston Marathon Explosions; Suspicious Incidents Reported Across U.S.

Article:

Investigators are diligently examining remnants of the explosive devices used in the Boston Marathon bombings, which occurred on Monday. The remains include parts of one or two kitchen pressure cookers packed with nails, ball bearings, and black powder; a torn dark nylon backpack or duffel bag; and a circuit board, wires, and other parts from timing devices. The aim is to trace these items back to their point of sale and compile a list of potential buyers.

A piece of a pressure cooker lid was found on a rooftop near the blast site, indicating the immense force of the explosion, according to a law enforcement official. The investigation involves scrutinizing numerous videos and photographs from surveillance cameras near businesses, as well as from marathon spectators' smartphones and television crews. As of yet, no one has claimed responsibility for the explosions.

The investigation entered its third day, and there were signs of national apprehension. In New York City, officials reported an increase in reports of suspicious packages. Similarly, in Oklahoma City, the scene of a devastating bombing in 1995, City Hall was briefly evacuated Wednesday morning due to a stolen rental truck parked outside. However, officials there confirmed that no bomb was present.

In Washington, D.C., parts of two Senate office buildings were temporarily closed as authorities investigated reports of suspicious letters or packages. The Secret Service also reported that a letter addressed to President Obama contained a suspicious substance and was intercepted at a screening facility outside the White House. A suspect was arrested Wednesday evening.

In New York, the police department received 143 reports of suspicious packages between Monday afternoon and midnight on Tuesday, marking an increase of over 300% compared to a similar time period last year, according to Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

Furthermore, the John Joseph Moakley United States Court House in Boston was evacuated in the afternoon as officials called out "code red" and bomb-sniffing dogs were deployed inside.

Title: Media's Portrayal of Hillary Clinton and the Benghazi Report: A Closer Look

Article:

The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence's report on the 2012 terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, has sparked a media frenzy, with headlines suggesting a negative impact on former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, despite the report not directly implicating Clinton in the incident.

The Washington Post, for instance, stated that the report "is likely to provide fodder" for Clinton's political opponents, acknowledging that the only references to Clinton came from partisan Republicans in an addendum, not from the review itself. CNN's Wolf Blitzer described the report as "fueling heated debate, partisan debate, about her leadership," while correspondent Elise Labbott suggested Clinton would "have to address Benghazi during" any 2016 campaign.

Jennifer Rubin, a Washington Post blogger, accused the media of being too "incurious" when it comes to Clinton, labeling Benghazi as Clinton's "drip, drip, drip problem." Partisan Republicans, such as Sen. Marco Rubio, have used the report to call for further investigations into Clinton.

However, it is important to note that Clinton's name does not appear in the bipartisan portions of the Senate review. The question of "leadership" has been a lopsided one, with media outlets using the Senate report as an indictment of Clinton's leadership, while overlooking significant aspects of Clinton's actions following the tragedy.

One such overlooked aspect is Clinton's acceptance and implementation of the findings of the Accountability Review Board (ARB), an independent, nonpartisan review panel that looked into what went wrong and how to prevent a similar tragedy in the future. The ARB report, like the Senate report, also singled out bureaucrats, not the Secretary of State, for scrutiny over diplomatic security failures.

Clinton has acknowledged ultimate responsibility for any bureaucratic shortcomings that played a role in the Benghazi tragedy. "I do feel responsible," she said under questioning by Sen. Bob Corker (R-TN). "I feel responsible for the nearly 70,000 people who work for the State Department. I take it very seriously."

The Accountability Review Board's recommendations, largely in line with those contained in the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence report, are being implemented. Leaving out this fact from discussions of leadership is problematic.

It is crucial to consider the full context of Clinton's actions following the Benghazi attack, rather than focusing solely on a single question during her Congressional testimony. The media's portrayal of Clinton and the Benghazi report should reflect the entirety of the situation, not just the parts that fit a particular narrative.

Title: Trump's Trade War with China: A Look at the Current State of Affairs

Article:

In March 2018, President Donald Trump declared that "trade wars are good and easy to win." However, over a year later, it appears that Trump is losing the trade war he initiated with China.

The tariffs imposed by Trump on Chinese goods may have slowed China's economic growth, with most data sources indicating a slight dip in 2018. This slowdown could be due to government efforts to control credit growth, but many believe that Trump's tariffs negatively impacted business confidence and slowed investment.

The U.S., on the other hand, has also been affected by the trade war. The imposition of tariffs on Chinese-made products increased prices for American consumers and factories. Two studies by trade economists suggest that the losses to the U.S. economy are in the tens of billions of dollars annually.

China's retaliation has particularly impacted American farmers, with the country halting most imports of soybeans from the U.S. Inventories have piled up, agricultural exports have decreased, and farm incomes have declined. Desperate farmers have appealed to Trump for help, to which he responded with direct payments. However, relying on government aid is not a sustainable business model, and a wave of farm bankruptcies has begun.

China's autocratic regime and its residents' tolerance for economic hardship may have given it an advantage in a trade war with the U.S. A trade truce between the two countries, enacted in late 2018, left most of the U.S.'s significant goals, such as intellectual property theft, currency manipulation, forced technology transfer, and access to the Chinese market, unfulfilled.

Meanwhile, the struggle to control the future of high technology is arguably even more important to the balance of economic power between the U.S. and China. The U.S. has been putting pressure on Huawei Technologies Co., China's leading telecommunications manufacturer, but Germany recently announced it would not exclude Huawei.

Furthermore, the U.S. has implemented export controls on many technology products. This could hurt Chinese tech in the short term, but in the long term, it could push China to accelerate its efforts to replicate and surpass U.S. technology.

In conclusion, Trump's trade war with China appears to be losing ground on multiple fronts. The ferocious attacks have inflicted some damage, but China seems to be coping with the losses effectively. It appears that trade wars may not be as easy to win as Trump believed.

Title: Court's Ruling on Trump's Twitter Account: A Closer Look at the Second Circuit's Decision

Article:

Earlier today, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals ruled unanimously that former President Donald Trump cannot block Twitter users from following his @realDonaldTrump account. The decision, made by an ideologically diverse judicial panel, appears to be a straightforward application of conventional First Amendment law. However, this article will argue that the court's reasoning contains a crucial error, reflecting a fundamental misunderstanding of speech on private social-media platforms.

Boiled down to its essence, the court's reasoning contained two key elements. First, it ruled that Trump's Twitter account represents an outlet for official communications and interactions that is controlled by President Trump. Second, it found that under these circumstances, Trump's decision to block users represents impermissible state action undertaken to suppress dissent.

The first element is fundamentally mistaken. By no traditional legal measure of "control," Trump does not control his Twitter account. Twitter owns and controls his account, and he has no legal right to wrest control of it from Twitter. The court's misunderstanding of the platform is made evident by this deeply flawed analysis.

The fact that government control over property is temporary, or that the government does not "own" the property in the sense that it holds title to the property, is not determinative of whether the property is, in fact, sufficiently controlled by the government to make it a forum for First Amendment purposes. See Seattle Promotions, Ltd. v. Conrad (1975) (holding privately-owned theater leased to and operated by city was a public forum). Temporary control by the government can still be control for First Amendment purposes.

There is no "control" at all, temporary or otherwise. When a politician rents a theater or other private venue, there is typically an exchange of money and a rental agreement that explicitly grants enforceable legal rights to access the property and control others' access to the property, and—critically—limits the landlord's power during the course of the rental.

Compare that level of control to the absolute lack of rights the user has under Twitter's terms of service:

We may suspend or terminate your account or cease providing you with all or part of the Services at any time for any or no reason, including, but not limited to, if we reasonably believe: (i) you have violated these Terms or the Twitter Rules or Periscope Community Guidelines, (ii) you create risk or possible legal exposure for us; (iii) your account should be removed due to prolonged inactivity; or (iv) our provision of the Services to you is no longer commercially viable.

There is no exchange of money, the user has no right to the platform, and Twitter can not only eliminate your access entirely but censor any single tweet. If it chooses, it can even remove Trump's ability to block, mute, or take any other action. And that's not all—when you use Twitter, your speech isn't even purely "your" speech anymore. Twitter grants itself the right to your communications, too:

By submitting, posting, or displaying Content on or through the Services, you grant us a worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free license (with the right to sublicense) to use, copy, reproduce, process, adapt, modify, publish, transmit, display, and distribute such Content in any and all media or distribution methods (now known or later developed).

Writing in response to the trial court's ruling against Trump last year, law professor Greg Dolin compared Twitter to a radio call-in show that is hosting a government official as a guest. The politician has no right to be on the show, the host can send the politician packing at any time, and the host has ultimate control over not only the politician's presence but also any callers' speech. In other words, Trump remains on Twitter entirely at Twitter's discretion.

In that circumstance, there is no "public forum." There is instead a public official using a private platform to attempt to amplify his specific message, with the permission of the entity that controls the platform. The court's ruling, in this circumstance, represents government intervention in Twitter's control of its own service. The court is overriding the permissions Twitter gave its own user.

Moreover, the court gives short shrift to Trump's own free-speech rights under the government-speech doctrine. Again, to borrow one of Professor Dolin's analogies, "If a politician is holding a rally in a park (a traditional public forum), it doesn't follow that he must permit critics to share the stage with him." The Twitter thread beneath any tweet can undermine or amplify the president's chosen message. So long as Twitter grants the user the ability to regulate his or her Twitter replies, then that regulation is an integral part of the user's expression.

If, say, Vice President Kamala Harris wins the White House and Twitter permits her to use its services to announce that she's forming a committee to study the feasibility of reparations for slavery, does she then have to allow that thread to be hijacked by white nationalists and other vile alt-right voices? I say no. The Second Circuit says yes.

It's common for social-media users to use phrases like "my Facebook page" or "my Twitter feed." Yes, it is "my" speech on social media, but it is not my page or my feed. A private company is allowing a public official to use the private company's services to amplify his message. The private company is in legal control, not the public official, and if members of the public don't want to be blocked on a Twitter feed, they should take their objections to Twitter, not to federal court.

Title: Local Woman Establishes Classroom Cafe to Empower Homeless and Refugees

Article:

In an interview with our news outlet, Ms. Brodie, a 27-year-old resident of Park Slope, Brooklyn, shared her journey towards entrepreneurship and the establishment of a unique classroom cafe. The cafe, which serves as a platform for empowering the homeless and refugees, is part of a series of articles featuring local philanthropists and their inspirations.

Ms. Brodie's family has a history of food and service, with her grandmother publishing a well-known cookbook in South Africa in the 1960s to raise funds for the Union of Jewish Women. Her father taught her how to drive while transporting leftover food from local restaurants to shelters, and she often spent her Sunday afternoons giving cooking lessons to friends and delivering extra meals to shelters.

After college, Ms. Brodie volunteered at a homeless shelter before working at the Human Rights Campaign in Washington. It was during this time that she developed the idea for a different approach to food distribution and service for the homeless and refugees. With no background in the food industry, she enrolled at the Institute of Culinary Education in Lower Manhattan and attended a food business boot camp in Harlem, also taking up shifts at restaurants.

After discussing her idea with friends, meeting with philanthropists, and sending "millions of emails," Ms. Brodie set up her classroom cafe in June. Nearly half of her students received job offers before they had completed the program.

Ms. Brodie's cafe offers a unique approach to empowering the homeless and refugees by providing them with culinary skills and job opportunities. The specific number of emails sent and the identities of the philanthropists she met with were not disclosed in the interview.

Title: California Farmers Frustrated Over Delayed Payment for Land Seized for High-Speed Rail Project

Article:

Farmers in California's Central Valley are expressing frustration over the state's seizure of their land for the construction of the high-speed railway and the delayed payment of hundreds of thousands of dollars owed for years. The California High-Speed Rail Authority, tasked with the project, has been criticized for offering farmers multiple excuses for the delayed payments and the constant changes in the project's plans, delays, and shifting costs.

John Diepersloot, a fruit farmer who cleared a large parcel of his peach orchard for the train, told The Los Angeles Times that he is out-of-pocket a quarter-million dollars for infrastructure costs and has not received any payment for over a year. Mark Wasser, a Sacramento-based attorney representing more than 70 farmers and businesses affected by the project, stated that the authority has come back four times to change the land they want to take.

Rail authority officials acknowledge they have not yet paid numerous landowners, but have not provided a reason for the delay. Don Odell, the authority's chief of real property, said in a statement to Fox News that they strive to work closely with affected property owners and ensure they receive fair market value for their land and other expenses incurred due to the construction of the high-speed rail system.

California's high-speed rail project has been plagued with delays, shifting plans, and questions over the cost and funding almost since its inception. The projected $79 billion project is years behind schedule, with the latest estimate for completion set for 2033. The bullet train planners have been under increasing pressure to make progress on the system that many believe had no plausible way of living up to its goal of getting riders across the state in three hours or less.

In February, California Governor Gavin Newsom announced he is putting the plan for a rail line between Los Angeles and San Francisco on hold in favor of a much-shorter line between the cities of Bakersfield and Merced. This move had Republican lawmakers in the Golden State calling for a referendum vote on the project. In his State of the State address in February, Newsom argued against the frequent complaint that the Merced-Bakersfield line would be a "train to nowhere" and said that a high-speed railway would "form the backbone of a reinvigorated Central Valley economy."

President Trump labeled the entire high-speed rail project a "disaster" and called for Sacramento to return the funds given to the state by the federal government. In March, the head of the state's rail authority fired back at Trump's effort to block more federal dollars from going to the California project. At that point, the Federal Railroad Administration had given California $2.5 billion to construct a Los Angeles-to-San Francisco link, with another $929 million pledged. However, federal authorities and the president claimed the terms of the federal grant had not been met and threatened to withhold any future payments while demanding repayment for the funds already doled out to California.

Title: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo Faces Challenges as Democratic Party Shifts Left

Article:

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, who is heavily favored to win a third term as the state's governor, may face challenges as the Democratic Party nationwide increasingly aligns with progressive priorities. The incumbent Democrat spent $18 million to fend off an aggressive challenge from political novice Cynthia Nixon in the primary election.

During the campaign, Cuomo agreed to restore voting rights for parolees and moved closer to marijuana legalization. However, some remain skeptical of Cuomo's recent shift towards more progressive policies.

"If he wants to have a chance in a Democratic primary, as Democratic voters really turn to the left, he’s going to have to lay out some progressive credentials," said Patrick Egan, a politics professor at New York University. Cuomo has denied he will run for president in 2020.

While Cuomo won easily against Nixon, the active challenge to his left nearly cost him his lieutenant governor, Kathy Hochul, who held off an unexpectedly strong challenge from an insurgent candidate. The primary election also resulted in losses for several Democrats in the state Senate who for years had caucused with Republicans, giving that party control of the state's upper chamber.

"Everything 'left' that he’s done is basically because Cynthia pushed him to do it," said Mindy Rosier, a 43-year-old public school special education teacher from Manhattan and a Nixon supporter.

The election of President Donald Trump has sparked a call to action for voters on the party's left flank. Voters in more liberal states like Florida and Georgia have nominated more liberal candidates for governor's races, but the movement has also been seen in more conservative states.

Teachers went on strike in Oklahoma and West Virginia earlier this year in efforts to secure higher pay, and voters later defeated some lawmakers who voted against those efforts in Oklahoma's state contests.

"One of the things I’ve been most struck by is how the reaction to Trump has so deeply affected state-level contests, even at the district level," said Grant Reeher, professor of political science at Syracuse University's Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs.

In New York, progressive anger was centered in the challenges to Democratic state senators who had handed the state's senate majority to Republicans. Several of those incumbents lost on Thursday. It was part of an effort by Democrats to regain power at the state level after suffering dramatic losses in states during the Obama Administration.

"Senate Republicans have held New York back for too long, and the oncoming blue wave will elect a functional Democratic majority in November," said Andrea Stewart-Cousins, the senate minority leader, who supported the Democratic challengers.

Having a more liberal senate may help Cuomo, experts said. The governor said that "nobody has stood up to Donald Trump like I have" at a debate last month, and New York was not immune to the surge in voter turnout among Democrats seen across special elections and nominating contests in the last year.

Nearly 1.5 million Democrats voted in Thursday's nominating contest, compared with less than 600,000 in 2014. "He was able to effectively run against Washington and the Trump administration, messaging that may have helped draw energy from Democrats eager to participate in elections this year to check the President," said Daniel Lewis, associate professor at Siena College.

Title: Obama Names Susan Rice as National Security Advisor Amidst Ongoing Controversy over Benghazi

 Article:

 President Barack Obama announced the appointment of Susan Rice as his national security adviser on Wednesday, a move that has been met with criticism from Republicans over her initial account of the 2012 Benghazi terror attack.

 Speaking in the Rose Garden, Obama described Rice as a "tireless advocate" for advancing America's interests. Rice will replace Tom Donilon, who is stepping down from the post. Rice, the current U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, does not require Senate confirmation for the job.

 The ambassador was initially considered for the secretary of State position, which does require Senate confirmation, but withdrew from consideration amid the ongoing fallout over her role following the Benghazi attack. Rice appeared on five Sunday shows after the attack, stating that it was triggered by protests over an anti-Islam film, an explanation many lawmakers said at the time was inaccurate.

 The administration later acknowledged that there were no protests on the ground in Benghazi, though they have not officially ruled out that protests elsewhere may have played a role. Republicans have criticized Rice for her statements, with Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) accusing her of "misleading" the public on Benghazi.

 The administration, under pressure from the media and Republicans, recently released the so-called "talking points" that showed officials drafting and re-drafting their storyline in advance of Rice's appearances. The intelligence community did cite demonstrations, but references to militant and Islamic extremist groups, and to prior security warnings and incidents, were ultimately removed after objections from various administration officials.

 It is unclear to what extent Rice was involved in this process. Officials, speaking in her defense, have stated that she was merely citing the assessment she was given on Sept. 16.

 Former Obama aide Samantha Power has been nominated to succeed Rice as U.S. ambassador to the U.N. Power was an aide to the Obama campaign in 2008 but resigned after a report was published in which she called then-candidate Hillary Clinton a "monster."
