Donilon is leaving the security adviser post after his wife took a job that involves a lot of foreign travel. He has been in the administration since the start, first as deputy national security adviser.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Memo Alleges FISA Abuse and Raises Questions About FBI and DOJ

Article:

A classified report compiled by the House Intelligence Committee, which has been described as "shocking" and "explosive" by Republican lawmakers who have read it, alleges extensive Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) abuse. The report, which is classified as Top Secret, has raised serious questions about the upper echelon of the Obama Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), as well as the infamous Trump-Russia dossier.

According to National security journalist and Fox News contributor Sara Carter, the memo contains information about the DOJ, FBI, and the Trump-Russia dossier. Carter also reports that sources told her "they would not be surprised if it leads to the end of Robert Mueller's Special Counsel investigation into President Trump and his associates."

Texas Rep. Louie Gohmert and Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz, among other Republican lawmakers, have spoken out about the contents of the classified intelligence memo. Gohmert tweeted a link to Carter's story, stating, "Read the CLASSIFIED @ HouseIntelComm memo on repeated FISA warrant abuses. The truth may not set the guilty free but it needs to come out."

Gaetz also issued a statement on his congressional website, calling for the document to be released to the public. He wrote, "The House must immediately make public the memo prepared by the Intelligence Committee regarding the FBI and the Department of Justice. The facts contained in this memo are jaw-dropping and demand full transparency. There is no higher priority than the release of this information to preserve our democracy."

Pennsylvania Rep. Scott Perry told Fox News, "You think about, 'is this happening in America or is this the KGB?' That's how alarming it is." Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz said, "I believe the consequence of its release will be major changes in people currently working at the FBI and the Department of Justice."

North Carolina Rep. Mark Meadows told Fox News, "It's troubling. It is shocking. Part of me wishes that I didn't read it because I don't want to believe that those kinds of things could be happening in this country that I call home and love so much."

The release of the memo and its potential impact on the ongoing Special Counsel investigation remains to be seen. However, the contents of the classified report have sparked concern and calls for transparency among Republican lawmakers.

Title: Ryan's Focus Shifts from White House to Congressional Leadership

Article:

Ryan, the current House Budget Committee Chairman, has reportedly shown little interest in pursuing a presidential bid, according to his associates. Instead, he appears to be more focused on amassing power within Congress and promoting his signature Medicare plan and spending cuts.

Ryan's growing influence among House Republicans since his failed vice presidential run in 2012 is evident. He played a significant role in formulating the GOP's new debt ceiling strategy and is crafting a budget plan that will guide the GOP caucus on key issues.

With his growing power as Speaker John Boehner's unofficial wingman, Ryan seems to view national ambitions as potentially diluting his influence. Instead, he is considering a run for House GOP leader or even speaker, a possibility his associates suggest he has warmed to since the election.

Ryan is also cultivating a national political and financial network that could support him in any role. He recently met with Spencer Zwick, Mitt Romney's fundraising guru, who indicated that much of the 2012 donor base is ready to back him if he were to reconsider a White House run. Ryan also made a fundraising trip to Texas last month for his Prosperity PAC, meeting with top Romney donors who encouraged him to run.

While some conservatives suggested Ryan challenge Boehner immediately after the election, he has no intention of doing so. However, in conversations with longtime associates, a subtle but significant change in Ryan's mood has been observed. He seems open to ultimately running for leadership, suggesting to two friends that this is the best and safest way to advance Medicare and budget cuts.

Ryan would not challenge Boehner or his No. 2, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, for their current positions. However, many Republicans believe Boehner may leave office in a few years, potentially after the 2014 election, to make way for the next generation of leaders. Ryan's current trajectory, running the Budget Committee until 2014 and then taking over the Ways and Means Committee, could provide the safest path to leadership.

Title: Graham Calls for Special Counsel to Investigate FBI, DOJ Actions During 2016 Election

Article:

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) has called for Congress to establish a special counsel to investigate the FBI and Department of Justice (DOJ) over allegations of bias during the 2016 election. Graham's call comes as newly released documents reveal anti-Trump sentiment among FBI employees who handled the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server and the Russia investigation that became Special Counsel Robert Mueller's probe.

The documents, which include transcripts of interviews with fired FBI agent Peter Strzok and former FBI lawyer Lisa Page, show they were determined to prevent Donald Trump from becoming president and had discussed impeachment once he took office.

Graham took to the Senate floor, stating that Mueller has had his chance to investigate Trump, and it's now time to scrutinize the other side. He plans to introduce legislation to create another special counsel for this purpose.

"There's more than smoking guns here. There's overwhelming evidence that somebody outside the political system should look into," Graham said.

The Mueller investigation appears to be winding down, and Democrats are pushing for the release of Mueller's final report. The Democrat-led House approved a resolution Thursday morning urging Attorney General William P. Barr to release Mueller's final report. The resolution passed unanimously.

However, when Senate Democrats attempted to bring the issue to the upper chamber, Graham objected. He stated he would have allowed it if Democrats agreed to support the special counsel Graham wants, but Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-NY) refused.

Graham also announced that his committee will hold hearings on bias at the FBI and DOJ. He plans to investigate whether the FBI misled judges when it obtained a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant to spy on Trump campaign advisor Carter Page.

The hearings will focus on how the FBI obtained the warrant using a salacious, unverified dossier written by former British spy Christopher Steele. The dossier contains unsubstantiated claims about Trump's ties to Russia.

The FBI used the dossier as part of its argument to the court to obtain the surveillance warrant on Page, and used it in subsequent renewals of the warrant. The dossier claims Page met with Russian officials with ties to Kremlin strongman Vladimir Putin during the 2016 campaign. Page has vehemently denied the claim. It also claims longtime Trump fixer Michael Cohen met with Russians in the Czech Republic to coordinate plans—a charge he has also denied.

Republicans have claimed the FBI has failed to disclose that the dossier's author was being funded by the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign as opposition research. The dossier, along with texts between Strzok and Page, are among the Republicans' top evidence for alleged misconduct at the FBI and DOJ.

The House Judiciary and Oversight and Government Reform committees, when they were controlled by Republicans last year, called in Strzok and Page to testify about their behavior. Those transcripts were secret until this week, when Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, now the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, inserted them into the Congressional Record.

In a transcript released Thursday, Strzok stated his favorable opinion of Clinton did not influence the investigation into her use of her home server to send classified emails. However, he acknowledged that Clinton was not a target, subject, or suspect during the investigation. Instead, investigators viewed her as "a critical player."

Strzok also disputed assertions that his texts to Page showed animus toward Trump—though his memory didn't align with that of Page, with whom he was having an extramarital affair at the time. She testified that a text she sent to Strzok telling him the Trump investigation would save the country from a "menace" referred to Trump. Strzok told the committee that he thought the menace was Russia.

Strzok also disputed the meaning of the now-famous text in which Page fretted Trump would win the election. Strzok responded, "No. No he won't. We'll stop it." This has been widely taken to mean the FBI would do what it had to do to prevent a Trump victory. While Strzok said in his testimony that he didn't recall writing the text, he did add that he believes the "we" he meant was the American voters.

"My answer 'No' was my personal belief that I did not think he would be," the fired agent said, adding later, "My best sense looking at this text that I didn't recall until I read it very recently was that 'we' is my belief that the American people—there is no way that they're going to elect him."

"What it is not is any statement that I would ever consider, let alone take any official action, to impact the presidency of the United States," he said.

Title: Government Shutdown: A Familiar Specter in U.S. Politics

Article:

The specter of a federal government shutdown has returned to the United States capital, reemerging after a four-year absence. The news swept through the halls of Congress like a cold desert wind, stirring up memories of past political standoffs and bureaucratic chaos.

The catalyst for this latest drama, according to President Donald Trump, is $1.6 billion for a border wall. This, as you may recall, was the wall that Mexico was supposed to pay for. However, given the numerous assurances during the campaign that Mexico would fund the wall approximately 6,256,765 times, some confusion may arise as to why a government shutdown is being considered, and why not simply call Mexico?

If a government shutdown were to occur, it would be a unique event, as many politicians have expressed concern over the potential chaos and disorder that may ensue. Government shutdowns, we are told, will result in mass chaos, disorder, and tragedy. However, in most shutdowns, the majority of the government continues to function.

Senator Jeff Flake, for example, stated, "We don't need a government shutdown. That never ends well." This sentiment is shared by many politicians who were asked about the potential shutdown this week.

Looking back to the last federal government shutdown in 2013, there was a record amount of media panic, coupled with an abundance of inside-the-Beltway weeping and gnashing of teeth. The assumption was that Republicans would never recover from the political capital they squandered while fighting over Obamacare funding, and that the 16-day shutdown would result in widespread misery.

However, America survived the shutdown, and Republicans ultimately recovered from their post-shutdown poll dip and went on to take back the Senate. The nation, it seems, managed to dodge mass tragedy. Washington D.C. returned to its usual business of self-importance, back-slapping, business-card swapping, and squandering money.

Perhaps, just perhaps, more than a few Americans realized that many government officials are full of hot air, and that expansive government bureaucracies aren't as important as they'd like you to think.

Unfortunately, when the government winds don't blow their way, many people call for...wait for it...more government. The assumption being that as long as their team is in charge, everything will be okay. News flash: That's a bad strategy. Nevertheless, in today's combative political arena, so it goes. You can see it in the sudden rash of calls to "rethink" free speech. You can see it in the bizarre paeans to communism that keep popping up at the New York Times. (No, those headlines are not made up.)

As for the latest episode in the grand historic saga of government shutdowns, we'll have to wait and see. In the meantime, take heart: Here in Texas, the legislature is shut down every other year—and that's by design. Somehow, we all manage to survive.

Title: Senate Democrats Seek to Delay or Repeal Parts of ObamaCare, Particularly the Medical Device Tax

Article:

Senate Democrats who voted in favor of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, are now expressing concerns about the tax increases included in the legislation, particularly the medical device tax set to increase on January 1.

With influential constituent groups facing onerous tax increases, senators such as Al Franken (D-MN), Dick Durbin (D-IL), Charles Schumer (D-NY), Patty Murray (D-WA), John Kerry (D-MA), Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Debbie Stabenow (D-MI), Richard Blumenthal (D-CT), and others are aiming to delay or repeal parts of ObamaCare.

One of the first provisions to be repealed was the Community Living Assistance Services and Supports (CLASS) Act, a long-term care insurance measure that was initially booked as reducing the deficit. After the bill passed, Democrats realized it was a disaster and repealed the provision.

Another contentious provision was the "1099 provision," which would have required small businesses to file additional paperwork for various transactions. This provision was also repealed.

Now, health-care industry lobbies that supported the subsidy-and-mandate-laden bill are lobbying to kill the cost-control measures that offset the costs of its subsidies. The Independent Payment Advisory Board is a target for many providers, and the medical-device industry has convinced two Democratic Obamacare-backing Senators to try to kill the medical device tax.

David Bowen, who helped to craft the legislation, stated that Senate Democrats had planned to provide insurance coverage first, "knowing that that would bring on a cost battle second." The mandates and subsidies in RomneyCare, the Massachusetts health care reform law, caused health care costs to dramatically increase, leading to never-before-seen controls on insurers and health care providers as they also raised taxes.

As Senate Democrats have gotten a look at what is in ObamaCare, the parts of the law that were intended to control costs have gradually been stripped from the legislation. The medical device tax, in particular, has been a point of contention. The tax is a tax on gross receipts instead of a tax on profits, and the tax will be imposed even if a company sells its products at a loss.

A recent study found that investment in medical research and development will fall by $2 billion per year because of the device tax—and that is a cautious estimate. The tax's adverse effect on investment will keep expensive medical devices from becoming affordable and widely available in the future.

More immediately, the device tax will increase the prices of essential medical products for consumers. The actuary for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services made it plain that Obamacare's "fees and the [device] tax would generally be passed through to health consumers in the form of higher drug and device prices and higher insurance premiums."

Whatever costs cannot be passed along to patients will be absorbed by the medical device companies, which will lead to job losses. One study found that, depending on the elasticity of the tax, the medical device industry will be forced to fire between 14,500 and 47,100 workers—up to 10% of the workforce.

While Democrats wanting to repeal the medical device tax is a step forward, the legislation still needs to be paid for to remain the law of the land.

Title: Mitt Romney Announces Senate Bid in Utah, Faces Challenges Over Perception of Allegiance to Utah and Trump

Article:

Mitt Romney, the former Governor of Massachusetts, has announced his candidacy for the Senate in Utah, addressing concerns about being labeled a "carpetbagger." In a video shared on social media on Friday, Romney emphasized Utah's unique qualities and the state's people's character, aiming to demonstrate his focus on the state rather than on the presidency or past aspirations.

Though Romney is well-known in Utah and faces little competition from the Democratic party, two prominent Republicans have raised questions about Romney's alignment with Utah issues and his criticism of President Donald Trump. State Auditor John Dougall, one of these Republicans, suggested that voters are concerned about electing a senator who may not fully understand Utah-specific issues.

Dougall, who has expressed interest in challenging Romney, said in a telephone interview on Friday that Utah issues are distinct from those in Massachusetts. He added that Romney had contacted him to inform him of his impending announcement. Dougall declined to disclose who is encouraging him to run but implied that support would come from those opposed to aligning with Trump.

Earlier this week, Utah Republican Party Chair Rob Anderson criticized Romney's criticism of Trump and questioned Romney's Utah credentials in an interview with the Salt Lake Tribune. Anderson later stated on Twitter that Romney satisfies all qualifications to run for Senate and would treat all candidates equally to ensure a fair nomination process.

In response to Dougall's comments, Romney's spokesperson did not immediately provide a comment. Dougall also noted in an email that Utahans have a favorable view of Romney and that the odds are in his favor.

In recent weeks, Dougall has been vocal on his Facebook page against a "coronation" of Romney, arguing that voters need to know Romney's stance on issues. Dougall stated, "What we need is not somebody who doesn't like the president. I think the key thing right now is folks need to know what he stands for."

Title: Romney's Foreign Policy Tour Aims to Highlight Differences with Obama, but Domestic Focus Remains

Article:

Former one-term Governor Mitt Romney embarks on a foreign tour, a trip that allows him to discuss his foreign policy positions, which may be more challenging to address in the United States where the focus is primarily on jobs and the economy. The tour includes stops in Israel, Poland, and London.

The visit to Israel, a region where President Obama has not made significant progress in the peace process, serves to highlight the anxiety surrounding the Arab Spring. Poland offers an opportunity to discuss the American relationship with Russia, an issue on which Romney has been critical of Obama.

Romney's advisers are aware of the political risks of criticizing a sitting president abroad, but they believe he can make his points without explicit attacks. The trip also provides an opportunity to tap into the deep pockets of wealthy Americans living abroad, similar to John McCain and Obama's fundraising efforts during their campaigns.

Romney may face questions about his foreign policy positions during the trip, which can be challenging for a candidate who is not well-versed in national security issues. His earlier claim that Russia is the nation's "No. 1 geopolitical foe" drew criticism from foreign policy experts and some Republicans.

The contrast with Obama is not entirely beneficial for Romney. The raid to kill Osama bin Laden and Obama's decisions to wind down the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have been widely popular. Romney's overseas trip could draw attention to these successes. Unlike Obama, who visited Afghanistan and Iraq as a candidate, Romney is avoiding both. However, this may not entirely insulate him from the need to address how his views differ from the president's on troop withdrawals.

Shifting the conversation to foreign policy goes against one of Romney's campaign imperatives—to focus on the domestic economy. By traveling abroad, he is essentially taking his eye off the ball for a week. Romney will discuss economic issues, such as trade policy and the global banking system, but Americans who are struggling with job loss or mortgage payments may not find his comments relevant to their lives while he is abroad.

In contrast, President Obama will have the campaign trail to himself during Romney's foreign tour. Obama is making a West Coast swing across Nevada, California, Oregon, and Washington this week, and he will also stop in Louisiana before returning to the White House. Both candidates will speak early in the week at the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Reno, Nevada, but once Romney leaves for Europe on Tuesday, Obama will be the only one out on the trail.

Title: Post-Election Lunch Meeting Between President Obama and Congressional Leaders at the White House

Article:

President Barack Obama is hosting a lunch meeting with congressional leaders at the White House on Friday. This post-election gathering, following the power shift away from the president's party, has become a Washington tradition, albeit an often awkward one.

The details of the discussions between President Obama and congressional Republicans may remain undisclosed, but historical precedent suggests that the leaders will describe the meeting using diplomatic terms. For instance, former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich once described a similar meeting as "a very positive meeting." Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi referred to it as "an extension of friendship," and former President George W. Bush called it "a very constructive and very friendly conversation."

Sheila Burke, who was chief of staff to Bob Dole during his tenure as Senate majority leader, describes these meetings as "Kumbaya with an edge." She notes that while there may be some awkwardness due to opposition or bitterness, the participants are professionals who ultimately want to legislate.

These meetings occur behind closed doors and can be frank, as the president does not want to concede defeat on his agenda, but the new majority has its own agenda and a mandate from voters. After his meeting with Clinton in 1994, Bob Dole stated, "I think the president understands that we're going to hit the ground running."

In 2006, when Nancy Pelosi visited the White House after becoming the first female speaker of the House, President Bush congratulated her and acknowledged the challenges that remained. Pelosi, in response, spoke of the need to make progress and highlighted the Democratic Congress's plans to raise the minimum wage.

The relationship between Pelosi and Bush was solidified during the 2008 financial crisis, when Pelosi, at Bush's request, pushed through the financial industry rescue known as TARP. John Lawrence, Pelosi's former chief of staff, attributes the strength of their relationship to the level of trust and collaboration that was built, despite policy differences.

President Obama's lunch meeting with GOP leaders on Friday will likely cover a range of policy issues, including Obamacare and immigration. In an interview with NPR's All Things Considered, White House Chief of Staff Denis McDonough expressed optimism about the meeting, stating, "Judging from the conversations that he, the president, has been having and many of us have been having with our colleagues up on the Hill, I think it should be a productive conversation."

No information is available regarding the menu for the lunch meeting.

Title: Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) Kicks Off with "America vs. Socialism" Theme

Article:

The Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) commenced on Wednesday, adopting an "America vs. Socialism" theme to emphasize the perceived leftward shift within the Democratic Party, particularly its presidential candidates. The annual conservative gathering, held near Washington D.C., will feature speeches from President Trump, various conservative figures, and White House officials, with the aim of arguing against socialist policies.

Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union (ACU), which organizes the event, stated in an exclusive interview that the theme is intended to highlight the question of whether the United States is a capitalist or socialist country. The conference, which runs through Saturday, aims to capitalize on the Democrats' internal divisions over big-government policies, as demonstrated during Tuesday's primary debate in South Carolina.

Front-runner Bernie Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, faced criticism over his praise of Cuba's Fidel Castro and the high costs of his proposed policies. As the Democrats grapple with these internal divisions, Republicans are seeking to portray Sanders as the face of the opposition.

Schlapp expressed concern that Democrats, such as Sanders, aim to "transform America." He explained, "Transform is an important word in that, they’re not saying make America kinder and gentler, they’re saying transform it—keep some of the parts we like, but change everything else."

Schlapp emphasized that the conference will focus on the relevance of conservatism in the current political climate, stating, "We will focus at this conference on how conservatism is more relevant now than ever, because the belief values the individual human being and tries to undergird each one of our God-given rights—the right to life, the right to private property, the right to chart the course for our own individual life."

In addition to socialism, the conference will address the impeachment effort against President Trump and what Schlapp described as a "disgusting path from 2015 forward to stop Trump, lie about Trump, and eventually attempt a coup against Trump." The conference will feature presentations and speeches from Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, Republican lawmakers, White House officials, and others from Trump's reelection campaign.

As per tradition, the conference will include a straw poll, allowing attendees to assess the president's performance. CPAC 2020 will conclude on the day of the South Carolina primary, the last early-state contest before Super Tuesday.

Title: Midterm Elections: A Look at the Stakes and the State of the Parties

Article:

The upcoming midterm elections on Tuesday will determine the balance of power in the U.S. Congress, with the Republican Party and the Democratic Party vying for legislative control. This article provides an analysis of the performance of both parties, focusing on their legislative accomplishments, economic growth, and handling of cultural issues.

On the Republican side, the party has two major legislative accomplishments under President Donald Trump's administration: the repeal of the individual mandate, the least popular element of Obamacare, and the tax overhaul that reduced the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%. The tax cut, combined with Trump's deregulation efforts, has led to strong economic growth, with consumer spending, capital investment, and exports all on the rise. Unemployment has plummeted below 4%, and job openings outnumber the unemployed for the first time on record. Wages and salaries have risen 3.1% in the third quarter, the highest jump in a decade.

On the Democratic side, after the 2016 election, the party could have re-examined its agenda, but instead, it focused on undoing the outcome of the election. The party has been embroiled in a series of conspiracy theories and scandals, with figures such as Christopher Steele, Michael Wolff, Michael Avenatti, and Stormy Daniels making headlines. The Democrats have also been criticized for their handling of cultural issues, with some members promoting controversial figures and ideologies, such as the pussy-hat resistance's association with anti-Semitic figures, the promotion of the violent thugs of Antifa by DNC deputy chairman Keith Ellison, and Elizabeth Warren's claims of Native heritage.

The Democratic Party has also been criticized for its response to the migrant caravan, with some members remaining silent on the issue. This silence has been interpreted as a reflection of a party beholden to a borderless ideology that has little support among broad swaths of the country.

In conclusion, the Republican Party has earned the right to retain its majority in Congress, with two major legislative accomplishments and strong economic growth under President Trump's administration. The Democratic Party, on the other hand, has been criticized for its focus on undoing the 2016 election results, its handling of cultural issues, and its response to the migrant caravan. The midterm elections will determine the balance of power in Congress, and the performance of both parties will play a significant role in the outcome.

Title: Democrats' Focus on Removing President Trump vs. Checks and Balances on Executive Power

Article:

In the aftermath of the Democrats' failed attempt to remove President Donald Trump from office, a question arises: why have they not seriously considered the reverse - removing power from the president?

Over the past 33 months, numerous behavior-specific explanations have been proposed for Trump's removal, including coordinating with the Kremlin, obstructing the Russia investigation, making "racist comments" about four congresswomen, accepting "dirt" from foreign governments, and the two impeachment articles: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

However, there has been a lack of a structural critique of the ever-accumulating executive branch power itself. Democrats may dislike Trump's use of authority, but they do not seem to want less of it in the White House, especially when they regain power.

During his response to Trump's State of the Union address, leading presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) criticized the tariff-happy president for not being punitive enough toward American companies. In her official Democratic Party response, Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer focused on the executive actions taken by Democratic governors in defiance of their legislatures, rather than Trump's monarchical gestures during the speech.

The Democratic presidential field, with the notable exception of faltering front-runner Joe Biden, has been engaging in a race to see who can make the most elaborate promises of immediate executive action. Forget 100 days; we're now talking 100 hours to see what that magical Oval Office pen and phone can do.

On Day One, President Elizabeth Warren would wipe out student loans for 42 million people, ban fracking "everywhere" and block any future fossil fuel leases on public lands and offshore. A future President Sanders' Day One list is yet to be released, but it includes an executive order to "legalize marijuana in every state in this country."

While legalizing marijuana is a wonderful and long-overdue idea, Sanders' method of achieving it is not. Federal law, including the Controlled Substances Act, is constitutionally required to originate from or be struck down by either Congress or constitutional amendment. A presidency with enough power to legalize Activity X irrespective of Congress or the desires of states is a presidency with enough power to criminalize that same activity when the other team wins. It's a seesaw of authoritarianism, and we should all want to get off.

Compared with the structural reaction against President Nixon's actions during the Watergate scandal, the personal response to Trump's imperial actions is remarkably different. After Watergate, Democrats (and some Republicans) went on a spree of pruning back the runaway executive branch. The 1973 War Powers Resolution, the 1974 Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, the 1974 upgrade of the Freedom of Information Act, and the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act were all enacted to reassert the legislative branch's authority and prevent governments from hiding their activities.

However, presidents of both major parties, particularly during this century, have fought doggedly to break free from their institutional shackles. George W. Bush, with his high-ranking veterans from the Nixon administration, made rolling back the Watergate reforms a key philosophical aim. Barack Obama, after campaigning as a constitutionalist, made a mockery of war powers in Libya.

As Congress has become more partisan, it has been more willing to forfeit anything like the consistent application of constitutional prerogatives, particularly concerning the wielding of life-and-death military power. For anyone who would like to once again see an independent legislature, the 99% partisan impeachment process in both chambers of Congress is cause for despair. As is the Democratic presidential field's will to executive power. If ever America is to get off the populist seesaw, we're going to need to root less for politicians, and more for the rules and mores that can restrain them.

Title: Bipartisan Discussions on Immigration Reform: Schumer, Ryan, and Gowdy Hold Private Talks

Article:

Democratic Senator Chuck Schumer has engaged in private talks on immigration with Republican Representatives Paul Ryan and Trey Gowdy. These discussions, which have not been disclosed until now, are part of an ongoing effort by key House Republicans to reach a deal with Democrats on immigration reform.

The talks, while not leading to any agreement on contentious issues like a pathway to citizenship for the estimated 11.7 million undocumented immigrants in the United States, provide insight into the urgency and high stakes surrounding the immigration reform debate. These discussions are informal, serving as a means for Capitol power players to exchange private information.

Sen. Schumer and Rep. Ryan have met four times since 2013, discussing various issues, but immigration reform was a significant topic. Rep. Gowdy, a respected figure on the right who chairs the House Subcommittee on Immigration and Border Security, has also met with Schumer.

In response to inquiries about his discussions with Schumer, Rep. Gowdy's spokeswoman, Amanda Infield Duvall, stated, "Congressman Gowdy has met with people of all political persuasions on immigration. He meets with people all the time on the issue."

Schumer's office declined to comment on the talks with Ryan and Gowdy. A source close to the issue stated that Schumer and Ryan "did not negotiate any specifics of House legislation at all in these meetings."

The White House is also monitoring the situation, with administration officials quietly trying to gauge the stance of House Republicans on immigration. Katie Beirne Fallon, the president's new legislative affairs director, discussed immigration with top aides and lawmakers in Republican leadership during her first rounds on Capitol Hill.

Despite the ongoing discussions, there are no substantive, across-the-aisle talks as of yet. Even immigration reform's biggest advocates express doubts about a bill passing in 2014. Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) stated, "The biggest impediment to making progress on immigration that I've seen over the last year... is a complete lack of confidence that the law will be applied, that the enforcement measures will happen."

Title: Protests Over George Floyd's Death Lead to Destruction of Confederate Monuments and Debate Over Property Rights

Article:

Demonstrators protesting the death of George Floyd have resulted in the defacement and toppling of several Confederate monuments across various southern states in the past week. The latest incident occurred on Sunday evening in Birmingham, Alabama, where a statue of Confederate officer Charles Linn was destroyed in a public park.

The destruction of Confederate monuments is part of a series of vandalisms that have swept the nation. Other affected sites include the Confederate Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Birmingham, which was defaced before authorities disassembled and relocated it; a Confederate monument on the University of Mississippi campus; a statue of General Robert E. Lee in Richmond, Virginia; Confederate statues in North and South Carolina; a 131-year-old statue of a Confederate soldier in Alexandria, Virginia, which was removed before any harm could come to it; and statues of Thomas Jefferson in Birmingham and Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia, which were vandalized.

The debate over the removal of these monuments centers on the perceived impact they have on civil unrest. Those advocating for their removal argue that their presence causes racial tensions, while those who support their preservation view them as symbols of state heritage. Protesters claim that the statues' removal will alleviate some racial tensions, while others are skeptical that the mere relocation of marble and bronze will solve underlying social problems.

However, the deliberate destruction of public property is not an appropriate mode of protest, besides being illegal. The vandalism of Confederate statues is doing a far worse injustice than the states may have done by erecting them. Property, both private and public, is sacred, and nothing—not anger, not resentment, not unrest—can justify its violation. To vandalize property is to scorn a sacred principle of the American system and to reject one of the premises upon which our nation was founded.

In a republic, citizens are free to use their vote to change the way government makes its decisions. But one of the things that enables a civil society to function is that its citizens agree to submit to the state's judgment, even when they believe said judgment to be in error. It is this general agreement that keeps our civilization from descending once again into a Hobbesian nightmare.

However, by vandalizing these statues, some protesters have shown that they will not abide by the government's decisions and are willing to break the law to prove it. This spurning of the rule of law is toxic to the health of any republic and, if it carries on unpunished or is even encouraged by officials, will continue to grow until bronze statues are not the only things getting hurt.

History is rife with examples of revolutions that have disregarded basic rights to life and property. Such chaos has been commonplace since the French Revolution and the subsequent Reign of Terror. The events then and in many revolutions since serve as grim reminders that no matter how righteous one's cause may be, going beyond the law to address one's grievances can easily upset a nation's social and political order and lead to devastating and deadly unforeseen consequences.

Whether in Birmingham or anywhere else, property, public and private, must be protected. If these Confederate statues truly are stirring up the discord accredited to them, then they should be removed in a manner to be determined by law—the citizens of any of these states are free to change their laws and their representatives. And, if this is what citizens decide to do, then, regardless of whatever social value is lost or gained, there is nothing criminal in it. But the wanton defacement and destruction of public property witnessed this week is as inexcusable as it is unlawful and unethical, and such vandalism must not be permitted to continue.

Title: Journalist Calls for Condemnation of Antifa and Prosecution of Its Members

Article:

In 2017, the political culture of the United States experienced a significant shift, with reasonable individuals allegedly surrendering to unreason and political tribalism overtaking human decency. This is according to an opinion piece by an unnamed journalist.

The primary tragedy of the events in Charlottesville was the loss of a young woman's life. The secondary tragedy, as the author sees it, was the distortion of the political culture. The President of the United States reportedly declared some portion of neo-Nazis, white supremacists, and alt-right white nationalists as "very fine people."

The author criticizes a portion of the left-wing intelligentsia for allegedly embracing their own thugs and supporting Antifa, a far-left-leaning anti-fascist movement. They are compared to the American heroes who stormed Omaha Beach, a comparison that, according to the author, did not age well.

The author, Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor-in-chief of The Atlantic, expresses his disapproval of Antifa, stating that their actions are not resistance or anti-fascism, but lawlessness and violent repression. He questions if authorities have ceded control of the streets in key American towns to a Marxist/anarchist mob.

The author calls for the condemnation of Antifa and the prosecution of its members, stating that their actions are evil and they do not occupy the moral high ground. He warns that if the basic truths of the evil nature of both violent Marxists and violent fascists are not understood simultaneously, the country may continue to tear itself apart.

The author also mentions David French, a senior writer for an unspecified publication, senior fellow at the ███ Institute, and an attorney, who has similar views on Antifa and the alt-right.

Title: President Trump to Attend March for Life, First President to Do So

Article:

President Donald Trump will attend the March for Life, an annual anti-abortion event in Washington, as announced on Twitter on Wednesday. The event, themed "Life Empowers: Pro-Life is Pro-Woman," is scheduled for Friday.

Trump will be the first president to attend the march, according to Jeanne Mancini, president of March for Life. In 2018, Trump became the first president to speak at the march via video feed. The administration has consistently worked to regulate or restrict abortion access since Trump assumed office.

Mancini stated in a Wednesday statement that March for Life is "deeply honored" to welcome Trump to the group's 47th annual march. "He will be the first president in history to attend and we are so excited for him to experience in person how passionate our marchers are about life and protecting the unborn," she said. A press release for the march indicates that Trump will speak at the event.

House Minority Whip Steve Scalise, a Louisiana Republican, and GOP Rep. Chris Smith of New Jersey are also scheduled to speak at the march. Marjorie Dannenfelser, the president of the anti-abortion group Susan B. Anthony List, described Trump's presence at the March for Life as a "watershed moment" for the Pro-life Movement.

Abortion rights activists criticized Trump's announcement as a ploy to appeal to a minority of supporters on the issue. NARAL Pro-Choice America President Ilyse Hogue called Trump's move "an act of desperation," accusing him of "turning to deception and disinformation about abortion to gin up a vocal and extreme minority as he faces the escalating reality that his presidency is crumbling around him."

Planned Parenthood Action Fund, the political arm of the nonprofit reproductive health care organization, tweeted that "since day one, the Trump-Pence administration has sought to undermine our access to health care, including safe, legal abortion." The group added, "But the 77% of us who support that access will have our say in November. Let's make sure that next year, he's there as a private citizen."

Title: House Considering Vote on Short-Term Spending Bill and Obamacare Defunding; Senate Unlikely to Follow

Article:

House Republican leaders are reportedly planning to vote this week on a short-term spending bill to fund the government and defund the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. This move increases the possibility of a government shutdown, as the Senate is unlikely to support any proposal that does not fund the health care law.

The proposed strategy, aimed at avoiding a showdown over the health care law, has faced resistance from hard-line conservatives who insist the spending bill prohibit all Obamacare funding. House Speaker John Boehner and other top House GOP leaders have been grappling with this issue, as they seek to avoid a government shutdown before the end of the fiscal year on September 30.

No decisions have been made, according to House Republican spokesman Michael Steel, who told CNN that discussions will continue among House GOP members tomorrow. House Republicans are scheduled to discuss the next steps on a vote on the "continuing resolution" Wednesday morning, with a potential Friday vote on a measure to fund the government through mid-December.

However, the measure is unlikely to gain traction in the Senate, as majority Democrats have made it clear that any attempt to defund the new health care law is a non-starter. A senior House GOP aide expects Senate Democrats to strip the Obamacare defunding language and potentially send the spending bill back to the House with other changes.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has criticized House Republicans, invoking Albert Einstein's definition of insanity in reference to their repeated attempts to defund Obamacare. Another idea gaining traction is attaching a one-year delay of Obamacare to legislation that would raise the nation's borrowing authority.

President Barack Obama has also weighed in on the issue, stating that some House Republicans are threatening to shut down the government if they cannot shut down the Affordable Care Act. He also noted that if this strategy does not work, some House Republicans have suggested they would not pay the bills that Congress has run up, which could potentially cause America to default on its debt for the first time in its history.

Louisiana Republican Rep John Fleming stated that he is still awaiting details on the end game from GOP leaders on how this plays out as they near the deadline for the end of the fiscal year. Another Louisiana Republican, Rep Steve Scalise, said the battle to defund Obamacare should be waged on both the spending bill and the bill extending the debt limit.

Title: North Korea Shifts Focus to Economy Amidst Regional Tensions

Article:

North Korea commenced its annual spring parliamentary session on Monday amidst escalating tensions in the region involving Pyongyang, Seoul, and Washington. In a surprising turn of events, the ruling party prioritized a stronger economy as a top national goal, alongside the expansion of its nuclear arsenal.

Recent weeks have seen North Korea issuing a series of threats against the United States and South Korea, including plans to sever communication hotlines with the South and to launch military strikes against the U.S. mainland. The regime has also reaffirmed its commitment to retaining its nuclear weapons under any circumstances. However, the parliamentary focus on economic reform suggests that North Korea may not be as consumed by its own paranoia as its propaganda suggests.

The Associated Press reports a noticeable shift in North Korea's rhetoric towards a message that balances economic development with nuclear advancements. John Delury, a North Korea analyst at Seoul's Yonsei University, stated, "There was a danger that this was getting to the point... of a permanent war footing. In the midst of this tension and militant rhetoric and posturing, Kim Jong-un is saying, 'Look, we're still focused on the economy, but we're doing it with our nuclear deterrent intact.'"

Despite North Korea's threat to close the Kaesong Industrial Complex, a site inside North Korea where South Korean companies and managers oversee manufacturing performed by North Korean workers, the complex remains open. South Korea's Chosun Ilbo newspaper reports that the site was operational on Monday, defying Pyongyang's Saturday threat to "mercilessly shut down" the complex unless South Korea ceased actions perceived as damaging to North Korea's dignity.

The Kaesong Industrial Complex is a critical economic lifeline for North Korea, generating approximately $87 million annually from the wages of 54,000 North Korean workers. A worker earns an average of $134 per month, but most of the earnings go directly to the regime's coffers. The closure of the complex would significantly impact the livelihoods of North Korean workers and their families, as well as the residents of Kaesong and surrounding areas.

Meanwhile, both the U.S. and South Korea have been demonstrating increased shows of strength in the region. South Korean President Park Geun-hye has stated that the country will respond powerfully to any provocation without political considerations, and that the military should be prepared for sudden and surprise provocations by North Korea. The U.S. has also sent a squadron of F-22 fighters to the region, and has flown various generations of bombers over the Korean Peninsula during ongoing Seoul-Washington war games, which have prompted strong protests from the North.

Reuters reports that the South has updated its rules of engagement to allow local units to respond immediately to attacks, rather than waiting for permission from Seoul. The U.S. has also deployed advanced aerial military technology to the region, including B-52s, B-2s, and F-22s, in what appears to be a display of military might amidst ongoing tensions.

Title: ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson Emerges as Favorite for U.S. Secretary of State

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump is reportedly zeroing in on ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson as his nominee for the position of U.S. Secretary of State. Tillerson had a second interview with Trump on Saturday at Trump Tower, and has emerged as the favorite in the long-running competition to lead the State Department, according to a person familiar with the transition deliberations who spoke on condition of anonymity because Trump has yet to announce his pick.

In an interview with Fox News, Trump praised Tillerson, stating, "He's in charge of an oil company that's pretty much double the size of his next nearest competitor. It’s been a company that's been unbelievably managed." Tillerson's deals in Russia, particularly, are likely to draw scrutiny, given his personal relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The nomination of an oil executive like Tillerson would signal a departure from the global consensus on greenhouse gas emissions, as Trump has promised to cancel the Paris climate agreement negotiated by President Obama. Tillerson's Senate confirmation hearings would likely focus on his $2.2 billion investment in Russian oil exploration in the Arctic Ocean, which he negotiated in 2011.

Tillerson has worked for Exxon since graduating from college with an engineering degree in 1975, and has no previous governmental or diplomatic experience. However, as CEO of ExxonMobil, Tillerson has negotiated with countries all over the world for oil exploration rights, particularly in the Middle East and Russia.

Environmental groups are expected to oppose Tillerson's Senate confirmation if he is nominated. The New York Attorney General is investigating whether ExxonMobil lied to investors and consumers about the risks of climate change from burning fossil fuels. Additionally, Tillerson's stance on human rights may also face scrutiny, as he was president of the Boy Scouts of America at the time when it began allowing gay scouts, and in 2015 ExxonMobil changed its anti-discrimination policy to include gays and lesbians. However, the Human Rights Campaign remains skeptical of the company's policy, stating it was prompted by Obama's 2014 executive order targeting federal contractors, not a change in corporate values.

Title: New Survey Reveals Divergent Views on American Identity Among Democrats and Republicans

Article:

A new survey from The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research has found that there is a significant divide between Democrats and Republicans regarding what constitutes the American identity. The survey reveals that while both parties share some common ground, they differ significantly on various aspects of American identity.

One of the key differences lies in the interpretation of American identity. Republicans are more likely to view it as rooted in Christian beliefs and the traditions of early European immigrants, while Democrats tend to emphasize the country's history of cultural diversity and offering refuge to the persecuted.

Despite these differences, a significant majority of respondents, regardless of party, believe that the U.S. is losing its identity. Lynele Jones, a 65-year-old accountant from Boulder, Colorado, who identifies as a Democrat, expressed this sentiment, stating, "There's so much turmoil in the American political situation right now. People's ideas of what is America's place in the world are so different from one end of the spectrum to the other."

There are some areas of agreement among Democrats, Republicans, and independents about the American identity. These include a fair judicial system and rule of law, the freedoms enshrined in the Constitution, and the ability to get good jobs and achieve the American dream.

However, significant gaps emerged in other aspects considered inherent to American identity. For instance, about 65 percent of Democrats considered a mix of global cultures as extremely or very important to American identity, compared to 35 percent of Republicans. Conversely, 29 percent of Democrats saw Christianity as that important, compared to 57 percent of Republicans.

Regarding the issue of immigration, Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to view the ability of people to come to the U.S. to escape violence and persecution as very important. This contrasts with the views of 55 percent of Republicans who hold this perspective.

Reggie Lawrence, a 44-year-old Republican from Midland, Texas, who runs a business servicing oil fields, expressed his view that the country and its Constitution were shaped by Christian values. He believes that as these values wane, so does the structure of families and ultimately, the country's identity.

Patrick Miller, a political science professor at the University of Kansas who studies partisanship and polling, attributes these findings to long-standing differences in the U.S. between one camp's desire for openness and diversity and another's vision of the country grounded in the white, English-speaking, Protestant traditions of its early settlers.

The poll also found that Democrats were nearly three times as likely as Republicans to view the U.S. as a country made up of many cultures and values that change as new people arrive, with more Republicans favoring an essential American culture that immigrants adopt.

The survey also revealed that Republicans overwhelmingly viewed immigrants who arrived in the past decade as having retained their own cultures and values rather than adopting American ones.

The areas seen as the greatest threats to the American way of life varied between Democrats and Republicans. Democrats coalesce around a fear of political leaders, political polarization, and economic inequality, while most Republicans point instead to illegal immigration as a top concern.

Interestingly, fear of influence from foreign governments was roughly the same on the left and right, with about 4 in 10 Democrats and Republicans alike viewing this issue as extremely or very threatening.

The poll, which was conducted between February 16-20, surveyed 1,004 adults using a sample drawn from NORC's probability-based AmeriSpeak panel, designed to be representative of the U.S. population. The margin of sampling error for all respondents is plus or minus 3.9 percentage points.

Title: U.S. Cuba Policy: Criticism of Obama Administration's Approach from U.S. Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen

Article:

In a statement, U.S. Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Florida and chairman of the Subcommittee on the Middle East and North Africa, criticized the Obama administration's approach to U.S.-Cuba policy.

Ros-Lehtinen argued that President Obama's argument for unilaterally reversing U.S.-Cuba policy is based on a false premise, stating that engagement with dictators and terrorists will not lead to changes in their behavior. She claimed that the Castro regime, which has made no commitments to expand democratic principles on the island, can continue its dictatorial ways without making any concessions while the White House granted all the concessions the regime wanted.

Ros-Lehtinen also criticized the administration's handling of the case of Alan Gross, an American citizen who was arrested in Cuba and later released in a swap for three convicted Cuban spies. She argued that Gross should never have been in jail in the first place and that the administration's false equivalency in the swap failed to acknowledge that Gross was, in essence, a hostage while the Cuban Five spies, who endangered American national security, received full due process, including trial by jury.

The representative also criticized the administration's deal with Cuba for not including a voice for the freedom-loving people of Cuba. She quoted Jorge Luis Garcia Perez "Antunez," a leader of the largest resistance coalition in Cuba, who stated that the deal was a betrayal that left the democratic opposition defenseless.

Ros-Lehtinen also highlighted the increase in political arrests in Cuba, with more than 8,400 arrests in 2014 at the hands of Mr. Castro's security forces. She also noted the administration's travel advisory for Cuba, which states that U.S. citizens traveling to Cuba should be aware that the Cuban government may detain anyone at any time for any purpose and that the Cuban state security or judicial systems will not carry out their responsibilities according to international norms.

The representative also criticized the administration's claim that the Cuban regime's engagement with the International Committee of the Red Cross is a success, stating that the Red Cross will not have access to Mr. Castro's gulags and will not be able to monitor prison conditions. She also pointed out that the administration's claim of the release of 53 political prisoners is misleading, as the Castro regime continues to arrest more people, as evidenced by the recent crackdown of more than 200 arrests on the island on International Human Rights Day on Dec. 10.

Ros-Lehtinen concluded by stating that the Castro regime will not change their oppressive tactics and will not loosen their grip on the island. She argued that the Obama administration's policy of dictator engagement has undermined the national security of the United States and sets a dangerous precedent that emboldens other desperate, sanctioned regimes. She called on the legislative branch to oppose this overreach of executive action and reaffirm the need to continue defending freedom and democracy everywhere in the world.

Title: Jared Kushner's Unannounced Trip to Saudi Arabia Raises Questions Over Classified Information Sharing

Article:

In October 2017, Jared Kushner, senior advisor to then-President Donald Trump, made an unannounced trip to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to meet with Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman (MBS). The meeting, which reportedly lasted until 4 a.m. on several nights, has raised questions about the nature of their discussions and potential sharing of classified information.

According to reports by The Washington Post and The Intercept, Kushner and MBS discussed various topics during their late-night meetings. However, the specific details of their conversations remain unclear. After the meeting, MBS reportedly told confidants that Kushner had discussed the names of Saudis disloyal to the crown prince, according to three sources who have been in contact with members of the Saudi and Emirati royal families since the crackdown. Kushner's attorney's spokesperson has denied these allegations.

Following the meeting, MBS launched an anti-corruption crackdown on November 4, 2017, arresting dozens of members of the Saudi royal family and imprisoning them in the Ritz-Carlton Riyadh. Several figures named in the President's Daily Brief were among those rounded up, with at least one reportedly being tortured.

Now, Congressional Democrats have asked FBI Director Christopher Wray to investigate whether Jared Kushner leaked classified information from the Presidential Daily Brief to MBS. In a letter to Wray, Democratic Reps. Ted Lieu, Gerald Connolly, Donald Beyer, Pramila Jayapal, Peter Welch, and Ruben Gallego requested an immediate investigation to determine the accuracy of the reports and to explore the extent to which information and sources may have been compromised.

The letter notes that the "integrity of classified information" falls within the purview of the FBI, but that "while the President has the authority to declassify and share information, the President's advisers do not." If Kushner discussed names with MBS as an approved tactic of U.S. foreign policy, the move would be a striking intervention by the U.S. into an unfolding power struggle at the top levels of an allied nation. If Kushner discussed the names with the Saudi prince without presidential authorization, however, he may have violated federal laws around the sharing of classified intelligence.

It is worth noting that, only months before the meeting, Jared Kushner sought a $500 million loan from officials in Qatar for a troubled New York City real estate project. The FBI's investigation into Kushner's actions could potentially shed light on whether he was trading classified information for financial benefits. Over the past two years, Kushner has reportedly sought substantial overseas investment from various sources, including South Korea's sovereign-wealth fund, France's richest man, Israeli banks and insurance companies, and a Saudi developer, among others.

The FBI's investigation into Jared Kushner's actions is crucial in determining the accuracy of the allegations and the potential implications of his actions on U.S. foreign policy and national security.

Title: Texas Governor Abbott Clarifies New Sanctuary City Law, Rejects Constitutionality Claims

Article:

Texas Governor Greg Abbott has clarified the implications of the recently signed bill that outlaws sanctuary jurisdictions in the state, addressing concerns about its constitutionality and its impact on American citizens.

During an exclusive interview with Breitbart Texas, Abbott emphasized that the law creates civil and criminal penalties for those who refuse to cooperate with immigration officials, including jail time for sheriffs or police chiefs who release criminal aliens subject to an immigration detainer.

Abbott countered claims by Democrat legislators and left-of-center Texas news outlets that the law is unconstitutional due to states being pre-empted by federal law in the area of immigration. In response to an article published in the Dallas Morning News, Abbott stated that the article "directly misstated what the legal status of this law was out of the U.S. Supreme Court – in the Arizona decision."

Abbott explained that the controversial "show me your papers" component, which some label as the law's most contentious aspect, is not as strict as the Arizona law. While the Arizona law required law enforcement to ask for papers, the Texas law does not require it, but allows it. Abbott emphasized that the "controversial part of this law has been ruled on by the U.S. Supreme Court and upheld."

The governor reassured American citizens living in Texas that the bill has no impact on their daily lives, stating, "For American citizens, this bill has no impact on them whatsoever." He clarified that the law targets only people who are in the country illegally, have committed violent crimes, and are subject to an ICE detainer request.

The law's author, Senator Charles Perry (R-Lubbock), confirmed that police can already inquire about the immigration status of a person they detain, and this bill does not change that. He also stated that citizens and legal residents do not need to carry papers to prove they are in the country legally.

The new law poses penalties for law enforcement officials who ignore detainer requests on illegal immigrants in their jails from immigration officials. Abbott stated, "All law enforcement officers are going to be required to follow this law. If they refuse to follow this law, or if they adopt sanctuary city policies, they are subject now to the stiffest penalties in America for adopting sanctuary city policies."

Referring to Travis County Sheriff Sally Hernandez and Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez, who have either ignored or threatened to ignore immigration detainers, Abbott said they must come into compliance with the law. If they do not change their policies, they will be in violation of the law and subject to its penalties.

Governor Abbott believes this law will make Texas a safer place and help avoid tragedies like the murder of Kate Steinle by a previously deported illegal alien released from the local jail in the sanctuary city of San Francisco. He stated, "This law makes Texans safer because it prevents the types of policies that California has that lead to the tragic murder of Kate Steinle."

The new sanctuary city law goes into effect on September 1, 2017.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Balances Parental Concerns and Vaccination Requirements in Measles Outbreak Discussion

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, currently on a trip to the United Kingdom, has emphasized the need for a balanced approach when considering parental concerns over vaccinations amidst the recent spread of measles in the U.S.

When asked if he would urge Americans to vaccinate their children, Mr. Christie stated, "We vaccinate ours, and so, you know that's the best expression I can give you of my opinion." He further clarified, "You know it's much more important what you think as a parent than what you think as a public official. That's what we do. But I also understand that parents need to have some measure of choice in things as well, so that's the balance that the government has to decide."

Regarding the question of whether he thinks some vaccines are dangerous, Mr. Christie clarified that he did not make such a statement. "I said different disease types can be more lethal, so that the concern would be measuring whatever the perceived danger is by vaccine and we've had plenty of that over a period of time versus what the risk to public health is. You have to have that balance, and that's exactly what I mean by what I said," he explained.

His office later issued a clarification on the remarks, stating that Mr. Christie believes vaccines are an important public health protection. Regarding measles, there is "no question" children should be vaccinated, according to the clarification. However, different states have varying requirements on vaccinations, which is why Mr. Christie called for a balance in determining which ones should be mandated by the government.

In a separate interview with NBC's Savannah Guthrie, President Obama advised parents to get their kids vaccinated, stating that measles is "preventable" and that the science is "pretty indisputable."

Title: Bipartisan Support for Intelligence Community Amidst Allegations of Russian Election Interference

Article:

In a stark contrast to President-elect Donald Trump's criticism of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) following reports of Russian election interference, the two top Republicans in Congress have offered strong support for the intelligence community. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan have praised the intelligence agencies for their work and warned against using the issue for partisan gain or casting doubt on the outcome of the election.

McConnell, in a statement to reporters, expressed his "highest confidence" in the intelligence agencies, while praising the Central Intelligence Agency specifically. He stated that the Senate Intelligence and Armed Services panels will investigate findings by intelligence agencies that Russia hacked into emails and computers used in the presidential campaign.

House Speaker Paul Ryan, in a statement, praised the intelligence agencies for "working diligently" to take on cyber threats from foreign governments. He also emphasized the need to protect the democracy from foreign influence and avoid casting doubt on the election results.

The Washington Post reported on Friday that the CIA has told senators that Russian President Vladimir Putin's government was actively seeking to help Trump win the election, a step beyond an earlier finding that the goal was to undermine the credibility of the U.S. political process.

President Barack Obama, in an appearance on Comedy Central's "The Daily Show With Trevor Noah," explained his reasons for ordering a full review of the evidence of Russian hacking. He stated that the review aims to gather all the threads of the investigations and put them in a single document that can be shared with members of Congress, relevant intelligence agencies, and the transition team.

Trump's team has attacked the CIA for its findings and questioned the credibility of the agency. Trump's spokesman, Jason Miller, didn't comment directly on McConnell's remarks when asked by reporters on a conference call, but criticized the reports about the CIA's findings, stating that it is an attempt to de-legitimize President-elect Trump's win.

The White House defended the intelligence community, with press secretary Josh Earnest stating that spy agencies are staffed by "patriots." He added that President Obama has benefited enormously from their work, expertise, advice, and service to the country.

Senate Armed Services Chairman John McCain and the incoming Senate Democratic leader, Chuck Schumer of New York, have stated that the Senate will investigate Russia's interference in the presidential election. A small group of Electoral College members, including Christine Pelosi, the daughter of House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, has requested a briefing from the intelligence community on the possible scope of Russian interference in the U.S. election.

The allegations concerning Russia have taken on new significance now that Trump is considering Exxon Mobil Corp. chief Rex Tillerson for secretary of state. Tillerson is known for having ties to Putin, and the oil chief was awarded Russia's Order of Friendship, a high civilian honor given to distinguished foreign nationals. If Trump does nominate Tillerson, the Russian allegations could pose problems for his Senate confirmation, even for some Republicans.

Title: Obama Prepares for Fiscal Cliff Negotiations with Historical Perspective

Article:

President Barack Obama is set to engage in a series of challenging negotiations regarding the debt ceiling and the impending fiscal cliff. Lawmakers have until December 31 to reach a deal to prevent $700 billion in federal budget cuts, which could potentially lead to a recession and set the tone for the beginning of Obama's second term.

According to NPR's Mara Liasson, Obama is approaching these talks with clear bottom lines and is not making initial concessions as he did during the stimulus package negotiations in 2011. Liasson suggests that the president is using lessons learned from the failed debt ceiling talks in 2011 in these new negotiations.

The fiscal cliff discussions will contribute to Obama's legacy, a topic that presidents often consider. During his first three years in office, Obama hosted small dinners at the White House with noted presidential historians, including Doris Kearns Goodwin, Robert Caro, Michael Beschloss, and Robert Dallek. The purpose of these dinners was not just for historical discussion, but to provide the president with historical perspective on his predecessors.

Jodi Kantor, who reported on the dinners for The New York Times, stated that the conversations were not idle, but aimed at giving the president strategic advice and learning from the mistakes and triumphs of his predecessors. The historians primarily focused on transformative presidents such as Abraham Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Ronald Reagan.

During the third dinner, historian H.W. Brands suggested that President Obama might find a better model for his presidency in Theodore Roosevelt. Brands noted that Roosevelt was able to push the country and the government in a progressive direction while presiding over 7 1/2 years of peace and prosperity. Roosevelt also dealt with a hostile Congress and, despite being a Republican, supported universal health care.

The historians were honest with Obama, telling him that there was one quality they wished he shared more with Theodore Roosevelt: forging a day-to-day relationship with the American people. The president took this advice to heart, as evidenced by his quotation of Theodore Roosevelt during his vision for a second term in Osawatomie, Kansas.

The upcoming fiscal cliff negotiations may present another opportunity for Obama to channel some of that inner Roosevelt as he negotiates with the same members of Congress as in 2011. The difference this time is the legacy that both Obama and those involved in the debt talks will leave behind.

Title: AOC Defends Campaign Activities Amidst Debate Cancellation and Alleged Election Law Violation

Article:

New York Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has defended her campaign activities amidst criticism over her decision to cancel an in-person debate and allegations of election law violation. Ocasio-Cortez, who is facing primary challenger Michelle Caruso-Cabrera, stated that she is not skipping debates, in contrast to her predecessor, Joe Crowley, who infamously skipped debates in 2018.

However, Ocasio-Cortez has cancelled an in-person debate scheduled for Wednesday, citing social distancing rules. The representative explained that the debate might violate the phase one and phase two reopening guidelines set by New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, who has allowed gatherings of up to 10 people since mid-May.

Ocasio-Cortez has participated in two online virtual debates with her primary challengers, including one on May 18. The Parkchester Times-sponsored debate, which was the same one Crowley shirked in 2018, was cancelled due to the social distancing concerns.

In recent weeks, Ocasio-Cortez has been active in George Floyd protests and hosted a socially distanced graduation party in a church parking lot on Sunday. The event, which included free burgers, balloon animals, and a DJ, was held next to an early voting site, leading to allegations of election law violation from Ocasio-Cortez's challenger.

Caruso-Cabrera's spokesman, Hank Sheinkopf, accused Ocasio-Cortez of violating the election law, stating, "AOC directly violated the election law. She doesn’t pay her taxes. She said yes to a salary increase. Who wants this type of person in Congress when we’re all in trouble?"

In response to the allegations, a representative for Ocasio-Cortez did not return a request for comment. After the allegations, Ocasio-Cortez moved the party a block away from the early voting site. The specifics of the alleged election law violation remain unclear.

Title: Google Employees Call for Cancellation of Military AI Project, Citing Ethical Concerns

Article:

Thousands of Google employees have signed an open letter urging the internet giant to cease work on a military project known as Project Maven. The project involves the use of artificial intelligence to enhance the precision of military drone strikes. The letter, addressed to Google CEO Sundar Pichai, states, "We believe that Google should not be in the business of war." The letter further requests that Project Maven be terminated and that Google establish, publicize, and enforce a clear policy prohibiting the development of warfare technology.

The letter, which has been signed by 3,100 employees, including "dozens of senior engineers," according to the New York Times, claims that staff have already raised concerns with senior management internally. Google employs over 88,000 individuals worldwide.

In response to the concerns, Diane Greene, head of Google's cloud business, assured employees that the technology would not be used to launch weapons or operate or fly drones. However, the employees who signed the letter argue that Google is putting users' trust at risk and disregarding its "moral and ethical responsibility."

"We cannot outsource the moral responsibility of our technologies to third parties," the letter states. "Google's stated values make this clear: every one of our users is trusting us. Never jeopardize that. Ever."

The letter continues, "Building this technology to assist the US government in military surveillance - and potentially lethal outcomes - is not acceptable."

Google confirmed in March, following an investigative report by tech news site Gizmodo, that it is allowing the Pentagon to use some of its image recognition technologies as part of a military project. A Google spokesperson told the BBC, "Maven is a well-publicized Department of Defense project and Google is working on one part of it - specifically scoped to be for non-offensive purposes and using open-source object recognition software available to any Google Cloud customer."

The spokesperson further explained, "The models are based on unclassified data only. The technology is used to flag images for human review and is intended to save lives and save people from having to do highly tedious work."

The spokesperson added, "Any military use of machine learning naturally raises valid concerns. We're actively engaged across the company in a comprehensive discussion of this important topic and also with outside experts, as we continue to develop our policies around the development and use of our machine learning technologies."

Google is currently working on establishing policies for the use of its artificial intelligence technologies.

Title: Senate Approves McConnell's Impeachment Trial Plan, Setting Stage for Trump's Trial

Article:

The United States Senate, in a party-line vote of 53 to 47, ratified Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's impeachment trial plan early on Wednesday, paving the way for the trial against President Donald Trump to commence as early as Wednesday. The Senate rejected ten other amendments proposed by Democrats by the same margin. An 11th amendment, which aimed to extend the timetable for the prosecution and defense to file trial motions, received the support of one Republican, Susan Collins of Maine, but still failed.

The trial centers around charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, which were approved by the Democratic-led House last month. The charges allege that President Trump used the power of his office to pressure Ukraine to announce investigations into his political rivals, withholding military aid and a White House meeting as leverage. The president then sought to conceal his actions from Congress by blocking witness testimony and documents, according to the charges.

President Trump's legal team argues that the charges are baseless and that they criminalize a president's prerogative to make foreign policy as they see fit. The team also claims that the impeachment is unconstitutional because the articles of impeachment do not outline a specific violation of a law.
