On Tuesday, the debate focused primarily on what would constitute a fair trial. "This initial step will offer an early signal to our country," Mr. McConnell said before the debate began. "Can the Senate still serve our founding purpose?"

Senator McConnell also received a reminder about the limits of his power to control an inherently unpredictable proceeding. Under pressure from Republican moderates, he was forced to make some last-minute changes to the rules he unveiled on Monday, which would have compressed opening arguments by both sides into two 12-hour marathon days. Mr. McConnell's rules also would have refused to admit the findings of the House impeachment inquiry as evidence without a separate vote later in the trial.

Title: Graduate Student Workers at Harvard End Strike Despite Lack of Contract Agreement

Article:

Graduate student workers at Harvard University have ended their 29-day strike, returning to work on Wednesday, despite not reaching an agreement with the university on a new contract. The union representing the school's graduate student employees, the Harvard Grad Students Union-UAW, has hailed the strike as a victory, citing agreements in negotiations and a statement from Harvard that named the end of January as a possibility for finalizing a contract.

The strike, which began on December 3, involved thousands of graduate student workers, including teacher assistants, teaching fellows, tutors, and researchers. The work stoppage marked the first strike of graduate students on the Ivy League campus since 1973 and threatened some of the university's educational operations during a critical moment of the school calendar.

In an email to supporters on Monday, members of the bargaining committee of the Harvard Grad Students Union-UAW vowed to "hold them accountable to this stated goal." The move to call off the strike came after the union agreed with Harvard to let federal mediators assist in negotiations. The school's spring semester begins this month.

The union's demands include a $25-an-hour minimum wage, expanded health care benefits, and stronger protections against sexual harassment and discrimination with a new third-party arbitration process for complaints. Talks with Harvard officials had lasted more than a year prior to the strike.

During the strike, union leaders said Harvard threatened student workers instead of agreeing to protections against workplace abuse, spent money on police details instead of health care, and canceled exams and moved to Scantron tests instead of agreeing to fair pay.

The university has proposed compensation changes that would include 8.2% raises over three years for research assistants and 7.2% for teaching fellows, in addition to a $17 per hour minimum wage for instructional work. The current rate is $12 per hour. Harvard has also proposed a new financial assistance fund totaling $100,000 per year for reimbursement under Harvard's insurance plan, which includes co-pays for mental health visits. The graduate student union has drawn support from Democratic politicians, including presidential candidates Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.

Title: White House Releases Transcript of First Trump-Zelensky Call, Preceding Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

The White House has released a transcript of President Donald Trump's first phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, a brief congratulatory conversation that took place on April 21, 2019, and lacks the controversy of their later call that led to an impeachment inquiry.

The initial phone call, which took place aboard Air Force One, began with President Trump congratulating President Zelensky on a "job well done" and on "a fantastic election." In response, President Zelensky expressed gratitude and acknowledged the U.S. as a great example.

During the six-minute conversation, President Trump expressed confidence in President Zelensky's ability to do a great job, mentioning that he has many friends in Ukraine who expect him to win. The second call, on July 25, included President Trump asking President Zelensky to investigate a company tied to the 2016 Democratic National Committee hacking and Democrat Joe Biden and his son Hunter.

White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham stated that the president "took the unprecedented steps to declassify and release the transcripts of both of his phone calls with President Zelensky so that every American can see he did nothing wrong." The transcript was read in full by Devin Nunes, the ranking Republican on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, during the second public impeachment hearing on Friday.

Committee Chairman Adam B. Schiff expressed gratitude for the transcript's release but quickly turned to demand the Trump administration release the rest of the documents Congress requested throughout the inquiry. In the April call, President Trump extended an invitation to President Zelensky to visit the White House, which was accepted. President Zelensky also invited President Trump to attend his inauguration. President Trump responded that he would consider it, but said "at a very minimum, we’ll have a great representative."

The full transcript of the April call can be found in the article's source.

Title: FBI Takes Possession of Hillary Clinton's Email Server, Server Reportedly Found to be Blank

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has taken possession of the personal email server used by Hillary Clinton during her tenure as Secretary of State, according to a report by The Washington Post. Barbara Wells, an attorney for Denver-based computer services firm Platte River Networks, confirmed that federal agents picked up the server from a private data center in New Jersey on Wednesday afternoon.

In a statement to The Washington Post, Wells revealed that the server "was blank" and no longer contained useful information. She explained that the information had been migrated over to a different server for purposes of transition. According to Wells, the data on the old server is not available on any servers or devices in Platte River Network's control.

The Justice Department is reportedly investigating whether classified information was improperly stored on or passed through the server, which Clinton used for all her correspondence during her time as Secretary of State. In March, Clinton declared that the private server would never be turned over, citing personal emails between herself and her husband Bill Clinton, as well as details about her daughter's wedding.

It is important to note that the server was not secure, and it is illegal to send or receive classified information on a private email account or server. Earlier this week, it was reported that Clinton had at least two classified, top-secret emails hosted on her server. The FBI's investigation into the matter is ongoing.

Title: House GOP Report Questions Hillary Clinton's Awareness of Security Issues in Benghazi

Article:

House Republicans have released a new report that alleges former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was aware of security problems in Libya prior to the 2012 terrorist attack on the U.S. diplomatic outpost in Benghazi. The report also questions the validity of the State Department's own internal review, known as the Accountability Review Board (ARB), stating it had serious deficiencies.

The report suggests that Clinton should have been held accountable for security breaches that led to the deaths of four Americans, including the U.S. ambassador to Libya. The report concludes, "Systemic failures at the State Department during Secretary Clinton's tenure resulted in a grossly inadequate security posture in Benghazi, which contributed to the deaths of four Americans, including the first U.S. ambassador killed in the line of duty since 1979."

The report points to Clinton's own testimony that she was aware of the security concerns in Benghazi, though other reviews have stated she was never made aware of the specifics, including some of the requests for additional security or military protection that were denied.

House Republicans are determined to keep Benghazi as a political issue in 2014, with House Speaker John A. Boehner announcing a new website, www.gop.gov/benghazi, designed to catalog various Benghazi reports and highlight questions the Republicans believe are still unanswered.

A review released last month by the Senate intelligence committee, run by Democrats, also found that the State Department should have done more to boost security. However, that review laid more blame on Ambassador Christopher Stevens, who the report said failed to ask for stiffer security in the immediate run-up to the attack. Stevens was killed in the initial assault.

The report appears to be aimed at raising questions about Clinton in particular, as she is considering another run for the White House in 2016. The report contrasts the State Department's performance with that of the Defense Department, which the investigators said "held military commanders accountable for what happened on their watch in Afghanistan." The specifics of Clinton's involvement and the extent of her knowledge remain a matter of debate.

Title: Aftermath of Minneapolis Riots: A Look at the Destruction and Community Impact

Article:

The aftermath of the Minneapolis riots, which occurred in response to the death of George Floyd, has left a significant impact on the city. Journalist Michael Tracey, who has been covering the events, has provided a firsthand account of the destruction and its effects on the community.

In a series of tweets, Tracey shared images and videos of the devastation in Minneapolis, including boarded-up businesses, looted stores, and the remains of the Minneapolis Third Police Precinct building. He noted that many businesses, such as a grocery store owned by an Iranian individual, a Halal market, and a wig shop, were targeted and had their entire inventory stolen.

Tracey also spoke with local business owners, including the Somali owner of a small deli who shared that his security fired shots to fend off the rioters. The deli owner noted that the instigators were primarily white, while the blacks hung back. He also mentioned that he had not seen a single police officer or patrol car during his five-day stay in the Minneapolis/Saint Paul area.

In addition to the physical destruction, Tracey also documented the emotional toll the riots have taken on the community. He shared images of a former dental office that provided care to underprivileged children and the uninsured, which was completely destroyed.

Tracey suggested that the extensive damage caused by the riots may not be receiving adequate coverage in the media due to potential political implications. He stated that the scope of the violence and destruction might be seen as helping President Trump, who has promised to maintain law and order during the chaos.

The riots in Minneapolis have led to a resurgence of Black Lives Matter protests and have been accompanied by looting and historical revisionism. The events have resulted in charges being filed against the officers involved in George Floyd's death, with Derek Chauvin being charged with second-degree murder and the three other officers being charged with aiding and abetting second-degree murder.

Title: Organizations Urge Commemoration of Sandy Hook Anniversary, Push for Gun Control Measures

Article:

In the aftermath of the Sandy Hook Elementary School tragedy last year, the nation mourned together. As the anniversary of the tragic event approaches on December 14, organizations such as Organizing for Action (OFA) and the White House are encouraging communities to come together in remembrance and reflection.

OFA, a non-profit organization founded by former President Barack Obama, has been reaching out to supporters, urging them to host remembrance events in their communities. The events aim to commemorate the 26 lives lost at Sandy Hook and call for action to prevent future gun violence.

OFA's email to supporters states, "By hosting a Newtown Anniversary event, you are joining thousands of Americans across the country as we remember the tragic events that took place at Sandy Hook Elementary School one year ago." The organization promises to provide resources and support for these events.

Similarly, an email from Vice President Joe Biden, sent through WhiteHouse.gov, focuses on President Obama's gun control executive orders and the need for further gun control measures. The email highlights the progress made in implementing the 23 executive actions announced by President Obama in January, which aim to keep guns out of dangerous hands, provide support for school resource officers, and reduce the stigma around mental illness.

However, it is important to note that none of the gun control measures mentioned in the emails would have prevented the Sandy Hook tragedy or other similar incidents. These incidents were not related to gun trafficking or the lack of universal background checks, as Vice President Biden suggests. Furthermore, under President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder's leadership, prosecutions of gun-related crimes have decreased by 45 percent.

In conclusion, organizations such as OFA and the White House are urging communities to commemorate the Sandy Hook anniversary and push for gun control measures. While the intentions behind these efforts are clear, it is crucial to consider the context and effectiveness of the proposed measures in preventing future tragedies.

Title: White House Addresses Allegations of Clinton Foundation Donations During Hillary Clinton's Tenure as Secretary of State

Article:

The White House faced a barrage of questions on Thursday regarding foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, including reports of donations linked to a deal that helped Russia nearly monopolize the global uranium market with State Department approval.

The Clinton campaign has grappled with similar questions, but neither the campaign nor the White House has provided sufficient answers to quell the growing controversy. The scrutiny of foreign money surrounding Hillary Clinton, including significant speaking fees paid to her husband, former President Bill Clinton, and megadonations to their charitable foundation after she became America's top diplomat, will likely intensify and follow her on the campaign trail.

White House press secretary Josh Earnest insisted that President Obama is not troubled by reports that the Clinton Foundation accepted $2.35 million from a businessman involved in Russia's uranium deals that required approval from the U.S. State Department, as well as other countries.

"At this point, there has not been any evidence presented that would prompt the president or anybody at the White House to be unsettled by Secretary Clinton's conduct as secretary of state," said Mr. Earnest. "In fact, everyone here at the White House, including the president, continues to be very proud of her service to this country."

The contributions were not publicly disclosed by the Clintons, despite a memorandum of understanding between Mrs. Clinton and the Obama administration that required donations to the foundation to be disclosed to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest, according to The New York Times.

The deal gave Russia's atomic energy agency, Rosatom, control of uranium mines spanning from Asia to the Western U.S., including half of America's uranium supply. Shortly after the Russians announced plans to buy mining giant Uranium One, a Russian investment bank with ties to the Kremlin and the deal paid Mr. Clinton $500,000 for a speech in Moscow, according to the newspaper. That was about five times Mr. Clinton's typical speaking fee.

Mr. Earnest said he was not familiar with the details of the Russian case. Asked whether the administration is concerned that examples continue to emerge about questionable donations from foreign governments or foreign entities to the Clinton Foundation, he said no.

"The president and the administration continue to have a strong confidence in the decision-making of Secretary Clinton," he said.

However, Mr. Earnest declined to answer a reporter's question on whether it is now "clear" that Mrs. Clinton did not abide by an agreement she signed with the administration before becoming secretary of state in 2009 to disclose donations to the foundation and the speaking fees paid to her husband.

"I'm not sure that that's clear, but you should go ask Secretary Clinton's team about that," Mr. Earnest said.

The Clinton campaign did not respond to questions about violating the memorandum of understanding.

Mrs. Clinton, who is the odds-on favorite to win the Democratic presidential nomination, also came under fire from her potential Republican rivals.

"It's the Clinton way: raking in millions from foreign governments behind closed doors while making promises about transparency that they never intended to keep. Now they're scrambling to refile their taxes and account for her decisions as Secretary of State," Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard who plans to announce her Republican presidential run May 4, wrote on her Facebook page.

She continued: "The American people will have a choice. Are we going to demand trust and transparency from our leaders? Have we had enough of a ruling political class that doles out favors to the wealthy and well-connected few?"

The Clinton campaign has tried to tamp down the controversy since it emerged this week in previews of the book "Clinton Cash: The Untold Story of How and Why Foreign Governments and Businesses Helped Make Bill and Hillary Rich."

The book, by conservative political adviser Peter Schweizer, argues that the Clintons got rich from speaking fees and donations in return for favors from Mrs. Clinton to various foreign interests while running the State Department. Other dealings include a free trade agreement in Colombia that benefited a major foundation donor's investments in the South American nation, development projects in Haiti after a devastating earthquake in 2010, and more than $1 million in payments to Mr. Clinton by a Canadian bank and major shareholder in the Keystone XL oil pipeline that occurred while the project was under State Department review, according to reports.

The Clinton campaign tried to dismiss the accusations as a right-wing "smear project," but that becomes increasingly difficult as mainstream news outlets pick up the story. Clinton campaign spokesman Brian Fallon sent a memo Thursday to supporters and donors in an attempt to beat back the accusations.

"The bottom line remains that the book fails to produce a shred of evidence supporting the theory that Hillary Clinton ever took action as Secretary of State for the purposes of supporting the interests of donors to the Clinton foundation," he wrote.

At a campaign stop in New Hampshire this week, Mrs. Clinton brushed aside reporters' questions about connections between contributions from foreign entities and her actions as secretary of state, calling them merely "distractions and attacks."

"I know that that comes, unfortunately, with the territory," she told The Associated Press.

Title: Federal Response to Malheur National Wildlife Refuge Occupation Proves More Effective Than Expected

Article:

The takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge by a self-appointed militia, led by the sons of right-wing radical Cliven Bundy, sparked concerns among liberals that the group would not be held accountable for their actions. The militia demanded that federal lands be turned over to private interests, including farmers, miners, and other private entities, without payment.

Initially, the federal government appeared to take a passive approach, allowing the militia to remain at the refuge for several weeks, during which time they were able to go back and forth for grocery shopping, media events, and other activities. Only one occupier was arrested for using a stolen vehicle to drive to the store.

Criticism from liberal commentators arose, with some arguing that the federal government's inaction was a double standard, suggesting that the response would have been more immediate if the occupiers were people of color. However, the solution to this double standard is not more shootouts, but rather a call for law enforcement to exercise restraint and patience when dealing with non-white suspects.

The occupation was eventually ended on Tuesday, when law enforcement confronted the militia on the open highway, resulting in a shootout and one fatality. Eight arrests have been made, and the leaders of the occupation are in custody. The federal government has since closed in on the refuge, closing roads and access, and it is expected that the remaining militia members will soon give up due to the lack of leadership and access to the outside world.

The federal strategy of patience and waiting proved to be a more effective approach than attempting to raid the refuge, which would have given the militia the martyrdom they desired and potentially resulted in further loss of life and property damage. The federal government's approach also minimized the propaganda value of the occupation, as the militia members were able to show their true colors and were ultimately apprehended in a less dramatic and less damaging manner.

The federal strategy of patience and waiting is not yet over, as some militia members remain at the refuge. However, with the leaders in custody, it is likely that the federal approach will continue to pay off. This incident serves as a reminder of the importance of smarter, less aggressive policing, and the dangers of the "shoot first" philosophy of policing. It is a more effective way to apprehend suspects and minimize harm to innocent people.

Title: International Relief Efforts Underway as Typhoon Haiyan Death Toll Expected to Reach 10,000 in the Philippines

Article:

The aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, also known as Yolanda in the Philippines, continues to unfold as hundreds of thousands of people struggle to survive and authorities grapple with delivering aid to affected areas. Richard Gordon, head of the Philippine Red Cross, described the situation to the BBC as "absolute bedlam."

According to the BBC, a massive international relief effort is underway, but rescue workers have faced challenges reaching some towns and villages cut off since the storm. "There's an awful lot of casualties, a lot of people dead all over the place, a lot of destruction," Gordon said.

Lynette Lim of Save the Children described the scene in Tacloban, one of the hardest-hit cities, after visiting over the weekend. "Complete areas have been totally flattened," Lim said. "It was truly catastrophic."

Freelance journalist Aurora Almendral spoke to NPR from the town of Hilongos en route to Tacloban City. She reported that some people who had managed to secure food, water, and medicine were worried about looters who might try to take it. Almendral also shared the story of a young woman who has not heard from her family since before the storm, including her father, mother, brother, and four-year-old daughter.

In updates, it was announced that Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has ordered the USS George Washington (CVN 73) and other U.S. Navy ships to the Philippines to assist in typhoon relief efforts. The U.S. Marine Corps is also moving "surface maritime search and rescue, airborne maritime SAR, medium-heavy helicopter lift support, fixed-wing lift support, and logistics enablers" into the region. Approximately 215 U.S. military personnel are currently deployed in the Philippines to help in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan.

United Nations officials report that about 9.5 million people in the Philippines have been affected by the typhoon and its aftermath, with around 620,000 forced from their homes. The number of confirmed deaths, which was just over 200 on Sunday, is now estimated to be around 1,000. However, officials are warning that the death toll could reach 10,000.

The U.S. military is bringing in water, generators, and trucks as part of the relief effort. Foreign governments and aid groups have begun shipping food, medicine, and supplies to the hard-hit Visayas region on the Philippines' eastern seaboard. Meanwhile, Typhoon Haiyan has moved out into the South China Sea and hit Vietnam on Monday, causing damage but no reported deaths.

Title: Synthetic Grass Advocates Push for Mandate in Drought-Stricken California

Article:

The Synthetic Grass Warehouse, the nation's largest distributor of artificial grass, has proposed a law to make synthetic grass a viable option in California, a state currently experiencing a severe drought. The company, based in Anaheim, suggests that Governor Jerry Brown consider a law allowing and encouraging the use of synthetic grass in residential and commercial areas, including front and backyards, businesses, and dog runs.

Victor Lanfranco, co-founder of the Synthetic Grass Warehouse, argues that if every Californian switched to synthetic grass, the state would no longer be in a drought. He points out that synthetic grass requires no water for maintenance, and its appearance and feel closely resemble real grass.

The company's synthetic grass is richly textured and colored, with a dozen varieties available for home use. The grass part is non-absorbent and anti-bacterial, requiring grooming with a brush instead of a mower. The Synthetic Turf Council, based in Atlanta, estimates that replacing a typical 1,800 square-foot lawn with artificial grass could save 99,000 gallons of water per year, per lawn, and eliminate pesticide and fertilizer run-off.

Governor Brown has already proposed fines of up to $10,000 for excessive water use and ordered a 25% reduction in statewide water usage. City and county agencies, as well as retail and wholesale water agencies, will be able to issue penalties and enforce restrictions.

However, Mr. Lanfranco argues that homeowners are in a difficult position due to homeowners associations requiring watered lawns and the state's water usage reduction. He believes that the governor should intervene to allow homeowners to install synthetic grass where it is currently not permitted.

The Synthetic Grass Warehouse's proposal aims to save water and alleviate the state's drought situation. The company's poster proclaims, "Imagine a California where water was no longer wasted on grass!" The future of synthetic grass in California remains to be seen, as the proposal is yet to be officially presented to Governor Brown.

Title: President Trump Responds to Jay-Z's Comments on Black Unemployment Rate

Article:

President Donald Trump responded to rapper Jay-Z's comments about the black unemployment rate in a Sunday morning tweet. Trump asked someone to "please inform Jay-Z" that the black unemployment rate is at the "lowest rate ever recorded" after the rapper suggested money does not equate to happiness during an interview with CNN host Van Jones.

"Somebody please inform Jay-Z that because of my policies, Black Unemployment has just been reported to be at the LOWEST RATE EVER RECORDED!" Trump tweeted Sunday, before declaring the overall economy has been doing well.

The comments from the president appear to be triggered by an appearance the rapper made on Van Jones' new show Saturday night. During the interview, Jay-Z said that while the black unemployment rate has decreased, it does not mean Trump is a good leader.

"It’s not about money at the end of the day. Money does not equate to happiness," Jay-Z said. "You’re missing the whole point. You treat people like human beings. That’s the main point. You can’t treat someone like: you’re going to treat me bad but pay me really well."

The black unemployment rate has reached its lowest levels since the 1970s, when the Bureau of Labor Statistics first began recording the unemployment rate in America.

The Moore Charitable Foundation, the non-profit organization behind ███ News Foundation, is working to balance out biased American media. For as little as $3, readers can support the quality, independent journalism of TheDCNF. The organization does not accept commercial, political, or government funding.

Title: Texas, Arizona Deploy National Guard to Mexico Border; Trump Seeks Up to 4,000 Troops

Article:

The U.S. state of Texas is deploying 250 National Guard members to the border with Mexico following a request from President Donald Trump. According to a Guard spokesman, these personnel will be dispatched to patrol the area within the next 72 hours. Arizona is also planning to deploy 150 troops to the same region next week.

President Trump has expressed his intention to send up to 4,000 National Guard members to secure the border with Mexico, pending the construction of his proposed border wall. New Mexico and California have been asked to take similar action to Texas and Arizona.

On Friday, President Trump outlined plans to end a practice known as "catch and release," as part of his stricter anti-immigration policies. Under this policy, illegal immigrants are released while awaiting deportation hearings. Instead, Trump wants illegal immigrants to be held in detention until their cases are resolved. He has requested a detailed list of military and other facilities from the U.S. Department of Defense that could perform this function.

In recent tweets, Trump has criticized illegal immigration, accusing Democrats of allowing "open borders, drugs, and crime." He has also threatened to use the "nuclear option" to pass tougher immigration laws and has implied that the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) could be at risk if Mexico does not stop the movement of migrants over the border.

Mexico's President Enrique Pena Nieto has condemned what he calls "threatening or disrespectful attitudes" from Trump. The deployment of troops to the Mexico border has been described by Trump as a "big step," but both his predecessors, Barack Obama and George W. Bush, also dispatched the National Guard to the same area.

The U.S. Department of Defense has approved funding for up to 4,000 National Guard troops from the Pentagon budget until the end of September, according to the Associated Press. The construction of a "big, beautiful wall" along the Mexican border was a key campaign promise for Trump, but the plan to erect a new physical barrier has been hindered by lawmakers and appears to have stalled.

A major government spending bill Trump signed last month included $1.6 billion (£1.1 billion) for the border wall - significantly less than the $25 billion the White House sought. Most of the funding can only be used to repair existing sections of the border where there is already a wall, not to build new segments.

Last month, the Pentagon confirmed that Trump had held "initial" talks with his defense secretary about using some of the Pentagon's budget to build a wall. However, two Democratic senators wrote to the defense secretary on Monday, stating that his department has "no legal authority" to use its funds for such a purpose. They warned that such a move could result in cutting funds from other priorities for U.S. service members.

In December, U.S. Border Patrol announced that arrests at the southern border had fallen to their lowest level since 1971, suggesting that fewer people were attempting the crossing.

Title: New Mexico's Quay County Declares Itself a "Second Amendment Sanctuary County" in Protest of Gun Laws

Article:

In response to pending legislation that expands background check requirements for gun purchases, Quay County, New Mexico, has declared itself a "Second Amendment Sanctuary County," according to Fox News. The two contested laws in question are House Bill (HB) 8 and HB 83.

HB 8 proposes requiring background checks for gun purchases between private citizens, a measure that the New Mexico Sheriff's Association has deemed unenforceable. HB 83, on the other hand, would establish an "Extreme Risk Protection Order" that would allow for the seizure of guns and ammunition from individuals deemed to be a danger to themselves or others.

New Mexico House Republicans have expressed support for Quay County's decision to pass a resolution in protest of the laws. State Rep. Rod Montoya (R-Farmington) stated, "We see counties starting to fight back against the over-reach of House Democrats. New Mexicans who are not even accused of a crime can lose their 2nd Amendment rights under this bill, and that's beyond wrong."

Under HB 8, it would be a misdemeanor to buy or sell a gun privately without a federal background check. The National Rifle Association (NRA) has come out against both HB 8 and HB 83. The NRA Institute for Legislative Action issued a statement regarding HB 83, stating, "Unchallenged statements made by a petitioner before a judge, alleging that someone is a danger to themselves or others in an ex parte proceeding — prior to any formal court hearing at which the respondent can be represented by counsel and present counter-evidence — would be sufficient for law enforcement to enter that person's home and confiscate their private property."

The NRA further stated, "It violates due process and puts law enforcement in a more dangerous situation and does nothing to protect citizens." New Mexico Sheriff's Association also expressed concerns about HB 83, stating, "I agree with our sheriffs and our county commissions, both of which are telling us these bills only harm law-abiding New Mexicans."

Title: Senate Democrats Alter Filibuster Rule to Advance Judicial and Executive Nominations

Article:

In a significant shift, the United States Senate, led by the majority leader, Harry Reid, has altered the filibuster rule to advance judicial and executive nominations. The move comes in response to the Republican party's refusal to confirm appointments to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and their previous obstruction of the National Labor Relations Board and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

The rule change, which was enacted due to the Republicans' refusal to confirm judges to the D.C. appellate court, lowers the threshold for confirming judicial and executive nominations from a supermajority to a simple majority. This change, according to Reid, was necessary given the unprecedented level of obstruction by the Republican party during the Obama administration.

The Constitution grants presidents the right to nominate top officials in their administration and name judges, and it does not specify the ability of a Senate minority to block these nominations. The practice of filibustering nominations, which barely existed before the 1970s, has seen a dramatic increase during the Obama administration.

According to Reid, half of all filibusters waged against nominations in Senate history have occurred since President Obama was elected. Twenty of his district court nominees were filibustered, while only three such filibusters took place before he took office. There has also been a record-setting amount of delay in approving the president's choices for cabinet positions and federal agency posts, even when no objections have been raised about a nominee's qualifications.

The rule change does not affect the 60-vote threshold for blocking legislation, a practice that the article notes is worth preserving. However, the rule change may lead to broader filibuster changes, such as a proposal by several younger Democratic senators to require "talking filibusters," which would force objecting lawmakers to stand up at length and make their cases. This could potentially end logjams that have prevented important legislation from reaching votes.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Denies Attempting to Flee Scene of 1998 Drunken Car Crash

Article:

In a debate against U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz at Southern Methodist University, U.S. Rep. Beto O'Rourke, the Texas Democrat vying to replace Sen. Ted Cruz, contradicted police reports from 1998 by denying he tried to flee the scene of a drunken car crash.

O'Rourke stated, "I did not try to leave the scene of the accident, though driving drunk, which I did, is a terrible mistake for which there is no excuse or justification or defense." He further added, "I can only tell you that I was able to have a second chance in my life."

However, O'Rourke's comments appear to contradict the police reports published by the Houston Chronicle last month, which claimed O'Rourke "attempted to leave the accident" after he lost control of his car and hit another vehicle in 1998. The police report stated, "The driver attempted to leave the accident but was stopped by the [witness]."

The witness, who also called 911, reportedly "turned on his overhead lights to warn oncoming traffic and to try to get [O'Rourke] to stop," the report continued. This was the first time O'Rourke has challenged reports of the incident. Last month, he acknowledged that he "drove drunk and was arrested for DWI in 1998." He didn't deny he tried to flee the scene.

The police report also stated that O'Rourke was visibly intoxicated and "unable to be understood due to slurred speech." O'Rourke recorded 0.136 and 0.134 blood alcohol levels on Breathalyzer tests, the records said. The state legal limit at the time was 0.10. The charges of DWI were later dismissed after he completed a court-approved diversion program, the Chronicle reported.

Title: EU Members Rush to Address Future After UK's Brexit Vote

Article:

In the aftermath of the United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union (EU), the EU's founding nations convened in an emergency meeting on Saturday to discuss the potential implications and future of the alliance. According to a German government-run newspaper, Die Welt, the German government fears that the UK could be the first of several nations to exit the EU. The paper called for keeping the UK as an "associated partner country."

Nigel Farage, leader of the UK Independence Party, celebrated the Brexit vote results, describing the EU as "doomed" and "dying." Far-right leaders in France and the Netherlands have also called for their own referendums on EU membership, according to Sky News.

Foreign ministers from Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, and Luxembourg met in Berlin on Saturday and issued a statement expressing their desire for Britain to quickly invoke the article in the EU charter that allows it to initiate negotiations for departure. Regarding other members, they stated, "We have to find better ways of dealing with these different levels" of commitment to closer European unity. Founding nations aim to increase political and economic cooperation, but some newer nations are hesitant to relinquish more sovereignty.

An online petition seeking a second Brexit referendum drew over 1 million signatures, reflecting the divisiveness of Thursday's vote to leave the 28-nation bloc. The petition site hosted by the House of Commons website experienced unprecedented activity, causing it to crash on Friday.

Scotland plans to initiate talks with EU nations and institutions to explore ways to remain in the bloc despite Britain's vote to leave, according to Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon. She also indicated that a new referendum on Scottish independence from the United Kingdom is "very much on the table."

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and Danish Prime Minister Lars Loekke Rasmussen both reacted to the Brexit vote. Orban stated, "Brussels must hear the voice of the people, this is the biggest lesson from this decision." Rasmussen said, "Britain's exit will echo for years to come and change the Europe as we know it."

German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that it "shouldn't take forever" for Britain to deliver formal notification of its intent to leave the EU, but acknowledged that the matter is in London's hands. Merkel also expressed a desire for an "objective, good" climate in the negotiations, stating, "there is no need to be particularly nasty in any way in the negotiations; they must be conducted properly."

French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault suggested that Britain should name a new prime minister in the coming days to expedite its departure. However, it is likely to take months to name a replacement for outgoing Prime Minister David Cameron, who is resigning and wants his successor to handle the departure negotiations. Ayrault stated, "they must designate a new prime minister, which would certainly require several days."

Title: Voting Irregularities: Long Lines in Florida, Confusion in New Jersey

Article:

As the voting day progresses, reports of irregularities have emerged, with long lines and confusion being the most significant issues in several states. This article will track significant irregularities throughout the day.

In Florida, voters have faced long wait times, with some waiting up to three hours to cast their ballots. The Miami Herald reported that some voters have refused to leave the line despite fainting, and in one case, a man suffered a seizure while filling out his ballot. In Miami-Dade, a woman was seen in line holding a catheter bag.

The long lines in Florida are attributed to the length of the ballot. The proposed amendments, backed by Republican state lawmakers, are lengthy, with one amendment coming in at 640 words. Voters who have not done their homework must read their way through a ballot that, in some counties, is 12 pages long.

In Virginia, long lines were also a problem, causing some voters to be late for work. In New Hampshire, voters struggled to find parking spaces and anticipated long wait times in lines.

New York City has experienced long lines, confusion, frustration, and anger due to Superstorm Sandy. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie authorized the use of fax and email voting, but some voters who requested ballots through those methods never received them. The Newark Star-Ledger reported that when the state announced the new provisions, they did not mention that those people voting by email or fax also need to send a hardcopy via mail.

In the case of email voting, voters still need to print, sign, and scan a physical ballot, then send it to their county clerk via email. However, hackers can forge ballots or signatures, send in fraudulent votes, and erase their tracks online, according to Andrew Appel, a computer science professor at Princeton University.

In Pinellas County, Florida, the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections Office mistakenly made robocalls that told voters they had until 7 p.m. "tomorrow" to turn in mail-in ballots. However, polls close at 7 p.m. on Tuesday, and any ballots turned in after that time will not be accepted. The calls went out between 8 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. due to a glitch with the SOE's phone system. About 12,000 calls did not get through, according to SOE spokeswoman Nancy Whitlock. The "tomorrow" in the message meant for Monday was incorrect when it was delivered. The SOE stopped sending out calls as soon as they noticed the problem.

Title: Analysis: Jane Mayer's "The Making of the Fox News White House" Sparks Debate on Media-Political Relationships

Article:

In a recent article titled "The Making of the Fox News White House," published in The New Yorker magazine, journalist Jane Mayer argues that there is a close alignment between Fox News and the Trump administration. The article has sparked debate, with some finding the relationship between the two unprecedented, while others argue that similar relationships between media and political entities have existed in the past.

Mayer's article, which was discussed on CNN and MSNBC, suggests that the relationship between Fox News and the White House is particularly close due to the involvement of Bill Shine, a former Fox News executive who now serves as the White House communications director. Mayer's piece has been met with criticism for its portrayal of this relationship as unique, with some pointing out instances of media-political relationships in the past, such as the coverage of Franklin D. Roosevelt's disability, John F. Kennedy's debauchery, and the creation of an "echo chamber" by Obama strategist Ben Rhodes.

Critics of Mayer's article have also pointed out the irony in her allegations of media collusion, given her own network's history of close relationships with political figures, such as Chris Matthews's public support for President Obama and Lyin' Brian Williams's adoring interactions with the Obama administration. Mayer also suggests that Fox News and Trump's relationship is characterized by a "rage-based model" that spins the country in an increasingly inflamed direction. However, some have argued that similar partisan and emotionally charged narratives can be found in other media outlets, particularly those with a liberal slant.

The article has sparked a larger conversation about the role of the media in politics and the potential for media outlets to shape public opinion. Some argue that Mayer's piece is an example of hypocrisy, given The New Yorker's own history of close relationships with political figures and the publication of sympathetic interviews and books about political leaders. Others argue that the article is a fair analysis of the relationship between Fox News and the Trump administration, and that it is important to examine the potential for media outlets to influence political outcomes.

In conclusion, Jane Mayer's article "The Making of the Fox News White House" has sparked debate and discussion about the relationship between media and politics. While some argue that the article is an example of media collusion, others see it as a fair analysis of the close relationship between Fox News and the Trump administration. The article has also brought attention to the larger issue of the role of the media in shaping public opinion and the potential for media outlets to influence political outcomes.

Title: Justice Department Threatens Lawsuit Against Harvard Over Affirmative Action Policies

Article:

The U.S. Justice Department has issued a letter to Harvard University, threatening to sue the Ivy League institution if it does not hand over documents regarding its admission policies. The department is investigating whether Harvard's policies violate civil rights laws by discriminating against Asian-American applicants.

The investigation stems from a 2015 lawsuit that alleges Harvard's affirmative action policies discriminate against Asian-American applicants. The Justice Department is examining the school's compliance with Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which prohibits institutions receiving federal funding from discriminating based on race, color, or national origin.

The letter, dated Friday and obtained by ███, sets a Dec. 1 deadline for Harvard to provide the requested documents. The Justice Department's probe follows reports of an investigation into whether university affirmative action admission policies broadly discriminate against white applicants.

In a response letter dated Oct. 6, attorneys for Harvard questioned the timing of the probe, stating it was unusual for the department to resurrect a complaint filed nearly 2-1/2 years earlier. Harvard maintains that its admissions policies are compliant with U.S. laws and has worked to increase financial aid to ensure diversity in its classes.

Harvard stated earlier this year that just over half of the freshmen admitted in 2017 were women, more than one in five was Asian, and almost 15 percent were African-American. In a statement on Tuesday, Harvard spokeswoman Anna Cowenhoven said, "The university will certainly comply with its obligations under Title VI. We have an obligation to protect the confidentiality of student and applicant files and other highly sensitive records."

Affirmative action programs in higher education were designed to address racial discrimination. The Supreme Court has ruled that universities may use affirmative action with the aim of helping minority applicants gain admission to colleges. However, U.S. conservatives argue that affirmative action can hurt white people and Asian-Americans by giving preference to other minority groups.

In response to the investigation, a Justice Department spokesperson, Devin O' Malley, said, "The Department of Justice takes seriously any potential violation of an individual's civil and constitutional rights."

Title: Clinton's Wall Street Ties Remain a Contentious Issue in 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

In the recent Democratic debate, Hillary Clinton defended her ties to Wall Street, a topic that has become a significant vulnerability in states with early nomination contests. John Wittneben, the Democratic chairman in Emmet County, Iowa, endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders after losing 40 percent of his savings in individual retirement accounts during the Great Recession. He believes that Wall Street executives, whom he believes should be in jail, were responsible for his losses.

Clinton's financial ties to Wall Street banks and other financial services firms, totaling $3 million in paid speeches and $17 million in campaign contributions over the years, have contributed to this image problem. Some undecided Democrats view her as overly cozy with big banks and other special interests. In a time when liberals are gaining influence within the party, many Democrats believe her past representation of Wall Street as a senator from New York is problematic.

Clinton has criticized the American economy as being "rigged" for the rich, but some party members question her commitment to regulating Wall Street excess if elected. Despite promising greater regulation of hedge funds and private equity firms, liberals criticize her for refusing to support the reinstatement of the Glass-Steagall Act, a law that separated commercial and investment banks until its repeal under President Bill Clinton. Senator Bernie Sanders, a presidential candidate, favors its restoration.

Furthermore, some Democrats view Clinton's strong support from wealthy donors and a big-money "super PAC" as contradicting her increasingly progressive rhetoric on free trade and other economic issues. This image problem persists despite Clinton's efforts to address concerns about her ties to Wall Street.

Title: FBI Launched Investigation into President Trump After Firing of James Comey in 2017, According to Report

Article:

A report published by The New York Times on Friday night revealed that the FBI launched an investigation of President Donald Trump in May 2017, immediately following his dismissal of FBI Director James Comey. The investigation reportedly focused on whether the president was working on behalf of Russia against American interests, with part of the probe being of a criminal nature, looking at whether the president obstructed justice.

The report, citing former officials and others familiar with the probe, stated that law enforcement officials became concerned by the president's behavior and initiated the investigation. The special counsel, Robert Mueller, took over the probe several days later upon his appointment by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

President Trump responded to the report via Twitter, stating, "Wow, just learned in the Failing New York Times that the corrupt former leaders of the FBI, almost all fired or forced to leave the agency for some very bad reasons, opened up an investigation on me, for no reason & with no proof, after I fired Lyin' James Comey, a total sleaze!"

The president also tweeted, "At the same time, & as I have often said, getting along with Russia is a good thing, not a bad thing. I fully expect that someday we will have good relations with Russia again!"

Regarding James Comey, the president tweeted, "My firing of James Comey was a great day for America. He was a Crooked Cop." He also stated, "He was a Crooked Cop who is being totally protected by his best friend, Bob Mueller, & the 13 Angry Democrats - leaking machines who have NO interest in going after the Real Collusion (and much more) by Crooked Hillary Clinton, her Campaign, and the Democratic National Committee."

White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders called the development "absurd." She stated, unlike former President Barack Obama, President Trump "has actually been tough on Russia." Sanders also said that Comey was fired for being a "partisan hack" and that former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe was "a known liar" who was also fired.

Rep. Devin Nunes of California, the ranking Republican on the House Intelligence Committee, said the Times' report is "yet more evidence that FBI leaders actually had no real evidence against the Trump team." Nunes indicated that the investigation was an attempt to undermine the president and avenge Comey's firing.

House Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler, a New York Democrat, indicated that he plans to look into the development. Nadler stated, "In the coming weeks, the Judiciary Committee will take steps to better understand both the president's actions and the FBI's response to that behavior, and to make certain that these career investigators are protected from President Trump's increasingly unhinged attacks."

Title: Obama Acknowledges U.S. Torture of al Qaida Detainees Post-9/11

Article:

President Barack Obama admitted on Friday that the United States tortured al Qaida detainees captured following the 9/11 attacks, marking some of his most extensive comments to date on a contentious set of CIA practices he prohibited upon taking office.

"We tortured some folks," Obama stated during a televised news conference at the White House. "We did some things that were contrary to our values."

Addressing the forthcoming release of a Senate report that criticizes the CIA's treatment of detainees, Obama attributed the mistreatment to the pressure national security officials felt to prevent further attacks. He urged Americans not to be overly "sanctimonious" when judging the actions through the lens of a seemingly safer present day.

This stance, which Obama expressed as a presidential candidate in 2008 and early in his presidency, explains why he did not push for criminal charges against Bush-era officials who implemented the CIA program. To this day, many of those officials maintain that their actions were not torture, which is a felony under U.S. law.

Obama's remarks on Friday were more emphatic than his previous comments on the subject, including a 2009 speech in which he announced his ban on "so-called enhanced interrogation techniques" and "brutal methods," but did not explicitly state that the U.S. had engaged in torture.

"I believe that waterboarding was torture, and whatever legal rationales were used, it was a mistake," he said in April 2009.

The administration of President George W. Bush authorized the use of harsh interrogation techniques on militant detainees in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, after deciding they did not constitute torture.

Obama told reporters the techniques were employed due to the fear of imminent further attacks.

"It's important for us not to feel too sanctimonious in retrospect about the tough job that those folks had," he said. "A lot of those folks were working hard under enormous pressure and are real patriots."

On Friday, Obama did not address two other central arguments of the soon-to-be-released Senate report: that the brutal interrogations did not yield life-saving intelligence, and that the CIA deceived other elements of the U.S. government about exactly what it was doing.

The president also expressed confidence in his CIA director, John Brennan, in the face of an internal CIA report documenting that the spy agency improperly accessed Senate computers. There have been calls for his resignation on Capitol Hill.

Title: Iran Nuclear Negotiations: Ongoing Talks Offer Uncertainty and Potential Risks

Article:

The deadline for Iran's nuclear negotiations extended once again on Thursday, as Secretary of State John Kerry warned that failure to reach a deal could potentially end the process. The ongoing talks, involving Iran, Russia, China, Britain, France, Germany, and the United States, are not aimed at eliminating Iran's nuclear weapons program but rather at determining the extent of Iran's nuclear infrastructure, the level of inspections, and the compensation provided for the privileges granted.

Inspections are crucial to any agreement focused on reducing the threat of Iran's nuclear weapons programs. The negotiations aim to increase the "breakout time," or the length of time it would take Iran to construct a nuclear bomb using known equipment and materials, from its currently estimated 2-3 months to a year.

However, Iran's reluctance to accept several proposed deals suggests that the negotiations may serve as a satisfactory outcome for the Iranian government, providing them with some sanctions relief, international recognition, and regional enemies questioning the U.S.'s commitment to their security.

It is essential to note that the extent of Iran's nuclear weapons work and the number of its facilities remain largely unknown, despite efforts by intelligence services. The Congress has been instrumental in imposing sanctions, with Senators Corker and Cardin ensuring that any agreement reached in Vienna will be subject to a 60-day review by the Congress.

An agreement would ease sanctions on Iran, with the Iranian economy primarily benefiting the Revolutionary Guards and citizen militia, as they control much of the economy. The lifting of nuclear-related sanctions would result in approximately $100 billion in revenue for Iran.

While an agreement would alleviate President Obama's political dilemma of preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon without resorting to military force, it has already created security concerns as regional allies reassess their alliances. A prolonged negotiation, free from deadlines, might mitigate some of the insecurity, providing exposure to Iranian leaders and potentially intelligence on their nuclear infrastructure.

In conclusion, Iran does not appear to have made the fundamental choice to abandon its nuclear weapons programs. Until Iran makes this choice, continuing negotiations may offer a better outcome than an agreement, as it maintains sanctions, exposes Iranian leaders, and aligns the U.S. with key European allies.

Title: Poll Analysis Suggests Trump's White Identity Politics May Be Less Effective in 2020 Election

Article:

A new analysis of public opinion over the past four years indicates that U.S. President Donald Trump's brand of white identity politics may be less effective in the 2020 election campaign. The analysis comes amid widespread criticism of Trump's racially charged comments about four minority women lawmakers and the fallout from a mass shooting of Hispanics in El Paso, Texas, that many Democratic presidential candidates swiftly blamed on the president's rhetoric.

According to a ███/Ipsos poll of 4,436 U.S. adults in July, people who rejected racial stereotypes were more interested in voting in the 2020 general election than those who expressed stronger levels of anti-black or anti-Hispanic biases. In 2016, the reverse was true. The analysis shows that Trump's narrow win came at a time when Americans with strong anti-black opinions were the more politically engaged group.

The July poll found that among Americans who feel that blacks and whites are equal, or that blacks are superior to whites, 82% expressed a strong interest in voting in 2020. That was 7 percentage points higher than people who feel strongly that whites are superior to blacks.

University of Michigan political scientist Vincent Hutchings, who reviewed ███'s findings, said, "There is some indication that racial liberals are more energized than the racially intolerant. That would seem to be good news for the Democrats and bad news for the Republicans."

The July poll did have a silver lining for Trump. Most white Republicans approve of his performance in office, and over the past four years, they have become increasingly supportive of his signature issue: expanding the wall along the U.S.-Mexico border. Some 82% now support it compared to 75% last year.

Trump is still as popular as ever with conservatives who dominate the predominantly white, working-class communities that helped him win in 2016, said Duke University political scientist Ashley Jardina, who also reviewed the poll findings. In his 2016 campaign, Trump focused on the grievances of white voters who feared the global economy was leaving them behind and who wanted more restrictions on immigration. He employed put-downs of Latino immigrants and inner-city, typically black, residents.

Trump has asserted repeatedly that his words are not meant to be racially divisive. "I think my rhetoric... brings people together," he said earlier this month. Responding to the ███ polling analysis, a spokesman for Trump's reelection campaign, Daniel Bucheli, said the president "enjoys broad support from diverse groups of Americans, and this coalition of supporters, to include minorities and first-time voters, continues to grow daily."

The White House did not respond to a request for comment on the poll findings. The ███ analysis also found that Americans were less likely to express feelings of racial anxiety this year, and they were more likely to empathize with African Americans. This was also true for white Americans and whites without a college degree, who largely backed Trump in 2016.

White Americans are also 19 percentage points more supportive of a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants and 4 points less supportive of increased deportations, when their responses from the July poll were compared with a ███/Ipsos poll in January 2015. The July 17-22 poll also found that 29% of whites agreed that "America must protect and preserve its White European heritage," down 7 points from a ███/Ipsos poll conducted in August 2017 and 9 points down from another ███/Ipsos poll in August 2018. The poll also found that 17% of whites and 26% of white Republicans said they strongly agree that "white people are currently under attack in this country," a drop of about 6 points and 8 points respectively from 2017.

Paula Ioanide, an expert in American race relations at Ithaca College, said the poll findings were consistent with her research that racial anxieties among whites peaked during the presidency of Barack Obama. Some white Americans "are not feeling as under attack as they did in 2016," Ioanide said. With Trump in the White House, "they've seen a kind of endorsement of the kinds of things that they wanted: A restoration of a white identity that they previously had felt was under attack."

███ and its polling partner, Ipsos, developed its race poll with political scientists at the University of Michigan and Duke University, asking a series of questions that measured respondents' perceptions of people from different racial backgrounds, the treatment of blacks and whites in America, and their interest in voting in 2020.

Title: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan's Potential 2020 Presidential Bid: A Complicated Prospect

Article:

Maryland Governor Larry Hogan, who won re-election in 2018 with record-breaking approval ratings, has sparked speculation within the Republican Party about a potential challenge to President Donald Trump in the 2020 primary elections. Hogan, a two-term governor and former businessman, has gained a reputation for his no-nonsense demeanor and bipartisan approach to governance.

During the recent government shutdown, Hogan publicly criticized Trump, advocating for a solution to Washington's political dysfunction by highlighting Maryland's ability to work across party lines. In a notable instance, Hogan toured Baltimore-Washington International Airport in January to emphasize the impact of the shutdown on TSA workers, and he criticized Trump's approach to the shutdown.

Hogan's moderate, centrist approach to governance has earned him praise from some Republican insiders, who have publicly urged him to run for president. Jerry Taylor, head of the libertarian-leaning think tank Niskanen Center, has been one of Hogan's most vocal supporters, advocating for Hogan to consider running for "higher office." Taylor has even gifted Hogan a book about the history of New Hampshire, a state that hosts one of the first primary battles in the path to the Republican nomination.

However, challenging an incumbent president in the primaries is a daunting task. The last time a sitting president lost his party's re-nomination battle was in 1856. Melissa Deckman, a political science professor at Washington College in Maryland, expressed skepticism about Hogan's chances, stating that Trump remains popular with the Republican base. Deckman also noted that Hogan's moderate stance on social issues may not resonate with conservative voters in early primary states like Iowa or South Carolina.

Despite the challenges, Hogan has not ruled out a potential 2020 run. In a recent interview on CNN, Hogan stated that he would only run if he believed he could win. Hogan's second inauguration earlier this month hinted at broader political aspirations, as he invited former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, a well-known Trump critic, to introduce him, and hired Mark Salter, a former speechwriter for the late Sen. John McCain and a vocal detractor of Trump, to help craft his address.

While Hogan's address did not mention Trump by name, he criticized the "debilitating politics of Washington" and referenced his father, former Maryland Representative Lawrence Hogan Sr., who famously called for Richard Nixon's impeachment. Hogan is expected to visit the early caucus state of Iowa in March.

Four years ago, few would have predicted Maryland's little-known governor would be discussed as a potential presidential candidate. However, Trump's challenges—including apparent ceilings in his job approval numbers, ongoing concerns about the outcome of special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation, and questions about his business empire and potential conflicts of interest—may have created an opening for a Republican challenger.

Title: Worship Pastor's Song Criticizing Evangelical Trump Supporters Garners Attention

Article:

Daniel Deitrich, the arts and worship pastor at South Bend City Church in South Bend, Indiana, has gained attention for a song he wrote titled "Hymn for the 81%," a reference to white evangelical Christian voters who helped secure President Trump's victory in 2016. The song serves as a "plea... to come home to the way of Jesus," according to Deitrich.

The anti-Trump pastor's song has garnered over 400,000 views on YouTube. The lyrics of the song accuse Trump evangelicals of "putting kids in cages, ripping mothers from their babies" and "weaponiz[ing] religion."

Deitrich told Religion News Service that he originally wrote the song's bridge as "an angry middle finger to the listener" and found it "cathartic," but he toned it down and plans on releasing more songs.

"There’s so much work to do to combat white supremacy, homophobia, transphobia, sexism — all the ways in which people are treated as less than the children of God that they are," he told RNS.

Although Deitrich has received praise from many on the left, Faithwire editor Tré Goins-Phillips said it is not exactly a worship song.

"Deitrich’s words are not elevating or edifying; they are divisive," Goins-Phillips writes. "Our worship and discipleship should be challenging, but it should be challenging in ways that call us back to Scripture, not to our anger at one another."

Anti-Trump evangelicals have been vocal in the last few weeks in opposition to the president and his supporters. Former editor-in-chief Mark Galli wrote an op-ed in Christianity Today called "Trump Should be Removed from Office," and a group of "Never Trump" Republicans released an attack ad called "The MAGA Church," mocking Trump's character and evangelicals' support of him.

The two events surrounded the Trump 2020 campaign's launch of "Evangelicals for Trump," where more than 70 prominent pastors came out in support of Trump's re-election bid.

Title: Democrats Call for Full Release of Mueller Report and Testimony from Attorney General Barr

Article:

Democrats have shown no signs of letting up in their pursuit of further investigations into President Trump, despite Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report finding no evidence of collusion between Trump campaign associates and Russia during the 2016 election. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, in a joint statement, called for the full release of the Mueller report and underlying documents, challenging Attorney General Bill Barr's impartiality and claiming he is not in a position to make objective determinations about the report.

Barr, in a four-page summary released on Sunday, noted that while Mueller found no evidence of collusion, the special counsel did not come to a conclusion on whether President Trump obstructed justice. Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who oversaw the majority of the Russia investigation after former Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself, concluded that the evidence was "not sufficient to establish that the President committed an obstruction-of-justice offense."

Democrats have questioned Barr's impartiality and called for a sweeping amount of documentation from the Mueller investigation. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer stated, "The fact that Special Counsel Mueller's report does not exonerate the president on a charge as serious as obstruction of justice demonstrates how urgent it is that the full report and underlying documentation be made public without any further delay."

House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has vowed to have Barr testify before the committee "in the near future," and has called for "full transparency" on what Mueller uncovered "to not exonerate the President from wrongdoing." Nadler, House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff, and House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings have also called for the release of the Special Counsel's full and complete report and all underlying documents.

The comments from Democrats underscore that they have no intention of accepting Barr's summary report as-is or putting the collusion and obstruction issues to rest, as they continue to pursue their own congressional investigations. The House Judiciary Committee is already leading an investigation into "alleged obstruction of justice, public corruption, and other abuses of power by President Trump," which Chairman Jerrold Nadler announced earlier this month. Other House Democrats have also aggressively ramped up their own Trump-related investigations, which are likely to include a network of committee probes and high-profile hearings that are likely to last well into the 2020 election year.

Title: Republican Party's Shift in Strategy: Focus on Asian-American Candidates and Elections

Article:

In the 2014 midterm elections, Asian-American voters showed a significant shift in their political preferences, with nearly half backing the Republican candidate for the House of Representatives. This marked a 46-point swing in Asian support from the 2012 elections, where they voted predominantly for President Obama's re-election.

This shift has led some pundits to question the sudden change in party allegiance, but the eye-popping exit poll data may not accurately reflect long-term success. The Republican Party's previous outreach strategies, such as nominating minority candidates in long-shot districts and last-minute ads in other languages, have not proven successful.

However, the 2014 elections saw a shift in the Republican Party's strategy, with a focus on building a bench of Asian-American candidates. Over three dozen Asian-American Republican candidates won elections at the state and local levels, in races such as school board, state senate, and city council.

Lanhee Chen, a research fellow at the Hoover Institution, noted in his post-election analysis that the Republican Party finally devoted time, attention, and resources to cultivating Asian voters.

In American Samoa, Aumua Amata Radewagen, a member of the Republican National Committee, will become the territory's first female representative to Congress. State Sen. Kimberly Yee, the first Asian-American elected to the Arizona legislature, cruised to re-election by 18 points. Even in traditionally Democratic strongholds like California, the Republican Party backed four successful Asian-American women running for the state legislature and county board of supervisors.

The election of these Asian-American candidates has a compounding effect, as argued by Tim Nguyen, chair of the Asian Pacific American Coalition. The election of prominent Asian-American leaders can inspire others with similar backgrounds to run for office.

Newly elected California State Sen. Janet Nguyen, the highest-ranking Vietnamese-American in the country, can recruit candidates from Little Saigon to run as Republican candidates for school board and city council. Connecticut State Sen. Tony Hwang can raise money from the Taiwanese-American community that would otherwise not contribute to Republican coffers. San Diego City Council Chris Cate, the first Asian-American in half a century to be elected to the San Diego City Council, has the charisma to introduce GOP presidential candidates to Filipino-American voters in swing states such as Nevada, Florida, and Virginia.

One of these rising stars, Oklahoma State Sen.-elect Ervin Yen, a first-generation Taiwanese-American immigrant, is rock-solid on gun rights. Yen, who immigrated to the United States after the Communist takeover of China, is a strong believer in the principles that America was built on and the importance of defending the Second Amendment.

For the next two years, Republicans like Mr. Yen will be featured in Asian-language newspapers, sharing a conservative message with communities that have been historically neglected by the Democrats.

The Republican Party has elected a bench of bilingual stars who have real political power. Their influence is expected to increase significantly when the 2016 presidential candidates start campaigning.

Shawn Steel, a former chairman of the California Republican Party and the state's national committeeman on the Republican National Committee, will play a key role in this effort.

Title: The Militarization of U.S. Police Forces: A Look at the Rise of SWAT Teams and the Impact on Civil Liberties

Article:

The use of police SWAT teams, originally established for handling violent situations such as hostage-takings, has expanded significantly over the past few decades, leading to concerns about the militarization of law enforcement and potential infringements on civil liberties.

Radley Balko, in his book "Rise of the Warrior Cop," details the transformation of SWAT teams, which stand for Special Weapons And Tactics, from rarely used specialized units to a near-daily occurrence. While SWAT raids initially began in the 1970s at around 300 per year, Balko notes that, as of 2005, there were approximately 100 to 150 SWAT raids per day.

The shift began during the Nixon era, with politicians seeking to appear tough on crime, even if it meant exaggerating the threat posed by illegal drugs. As the war on drugs escalated, police stopped announcing themselves when entering homes due to concerns that drug users would destroy evidence. This change marked a departure from the centuries-old rule that treated citizens' homes as their castles, requiring a warrant for police entry.

The increased use of SWAT teams has led to incidents where innocent individuals have been killed during raids. Balko cites over 50 such cases, often resulting from homeowners not recognizing the intruders in the middle of the night. One such case is that of Iraq War veteran Jose Guerena, who was shot and killed by police during a raid on his home. Guerena's home was suspected of containing drugs, but no drugs or evidence of drug dealing were found after his death. Guerena's brother was arrested on drug charges, and Balko notes that Guerena's crime seemed to be his association with someone.

The War on Terror has further contributed to the militarization of police forces, with the Pentagon and the Department of Homeland Security offering armored vehicles, including tanks and troop transports, body armor, and stun grenades, to police departments, large or small. Local police have eagerly accepted these resources, expanding the circumstances under which such equipment is used.

In a case from Concord, New Hampshire, the police chief, citing libertarians who moved to the state seeking increased individual freedom, requested and received an armored vehicle from the Department of Homeland Security. This raises concerns about the potential misuse of such equipment against peaceful, law-abiding citizens.

While the police, courts, and military are generally considered legitimate functions of government, the ability to sleep securely in one's home without fear of armored intrusions is a fundamental freedom. As the public begins to question the effectiveness and morality of the war on drugs, it is crucial to consider the impact of the War on Terror and the continued militarization of police forces on civil liberties.

Title: Education Department Revising Title IX Standards for Sexual Harassment Cases on College Campuses

Article:

The Education Department is reportedly revising Title IX standards for addressing cases of sexual harassment and assault on college campuses. The revisions, which have not yet been finalized, will allegedly bolster the rights of accused students, narrow the definition of sexual harassment, and hold schools accountable only for formal complaints filed through proper authorities and for conduct said to have occurred on their campuses.

According to a draft obtained by The New York Times, the Department recognizes that sexual harassment and assault continue to present serious problems across the nation's campuses despite well-intentioned efforts by school districts, colleges, universities, advocacy organizations, and the Department itself. The lack of clear regulatory standards has contributed to processes that have not been fair to all parties involved, lacked appropriate procedural protections, and undermined confidence in the reliability of the outcomes of investigations of sexual harassment allegations.

The draft rule also states that the Department aims to ensure fairness and due process for all parties involved in Title IX investigations. However, some critics argue that the revisions may not be operating in good faith. For instance, the Department's Office for Civil Rights, which investigates Title IX complaints, is headed by Candice Jackson, who once asserted to The Times that "90 percent" of assault complaints "fall into the category of 'we were both drunk,' 'we broke up,' and six months later I found myself under a Title IX investigation because she just decided that our last sleeping together was not quite right."

In 2017, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos reached out to several men's rights groups to discuss the issue of rape on campus.
