The secretary met with members of Families Advocating for Campus Equality and Stop Abusive and Violent Environments, which advocate for students accused of sexual misconduct, and the National Coalition for Men, which refers to itself as "the oldest Men's Rights organization in America." The latter group recently filed its own Title IX complaint against the University of Pennsylvania because the school has "over 20 women programs... but nothing similar for men."

The finalized revisions to Title IX standards are yet to be announced. The Education Department has not provided further details on the specific changes to the regulations.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Reports Increase in Terrorist Chatter Ahead of 9/11 Anniversary

Article:

The U.S. intelligence community has observed a significant increase in chatter among terrorist organizations as the 13th anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks approaches. A U.S. government official, speaking anonymously, informed The Blaze that there has been an increase in chatter among Islamic terrorist organizations, both online and over phone lines.

While the intelligence community cannot definitively confirm whether an attack is imminent, the official stated that agencies have seen similar increases in chatter before the September 11 attacks. The rise in chatter is more challenging to decipher due to the emergence of the Islamic State group, which poses a threat to al Qaeda as it asserts dominance in Iraq and Syria.

The Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, has openly declared its intent to bring terror to American interests worldwide, similar to al Qaeda. Former CIA case officer Brian Fairchild told The Blaze that the threat is two-fold, as ISIS and al Qaeda are in conflict, with ISIS having captured the imagination of young Muslims from around the world and depriving al Qaeda of its own fighters. Al Qaeda is reportedly split, and the approaching 9/11 anniversary may benefit both groups if a significant attack occurs in the United States.

The Islamic State executed American photojournalist James Foley on Aug. 19, and has used social media platforms to threaten terror attacks on American soil. Recently, Chicago's WGN network reported a tweet from the terror group on June 20, which includes a picture taken on Michigan Ave. The tweet reads "Soldiers of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria will pass from here soon," and an Arabic message held up in the picture was translated as "We are in your streets." The specifics of any planned attacks or the intentions of the terrorist organizations are not available.

Title: "Economy Advances: Profits Soar as U.S. Economy Remains Robust Amidst Global Economic Challenges"

Article:

The Wall Street Journal's front-page headline on Monday, "Profits Soar as Economy Advances," highlights the robust state of the U.S. economy. This economic growth, despite global economic challenges, such as those faced by China, underscores the country's unusual health.

The article suggests that the policies and appointments made by President Donald Trump have contributed to this economic growth. The piece also discusses the ongoing investigations and controversies surrounding the Trump family, but emphasizes that these stories have not been as damaging as portrayed by the media.

The article further discusses the historical context of the Clinton family's involvement in two of the three Constitutional crises in the author's lifetime. It mentions the impeachment of President Bill Clinton and the ongoing investigation into potential Russian collusion with the Trump campaign, led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller.

The article also references a book, "Shattered: Inside Hillary Clinton's Doomed Campaign," which suggests that Hillary Clinton's team began to engineer the narrative of Russian hacking and election interference shortly after her 2016 election loss. The article suggests that this narrative is a key part of the ongoing Constitutional crisis surrounding the Trump administration.

The article concludes by stating that the origin of the current Constitutional crisis is more complex than the passage from "Shattered" suggests, but provides a starting point for understanding the ongoing investigation and the role of the Clinton family in the political landscape.

Title: Pope Francis Criticizes Unfettered Capitalism, but Supporters Argue for Its Benefits

Article:

Pope Francis, in his apostolic exhortation, has criticized free market capitalism, stating that economic growth, encouraged by a free market, does not inherently lead to greater justice and inclusiveness in the world. He further concluded that this opinion has never been confirmed by the facts and labeled unfettered capitalism as "a new tyranny."

In response, this article will examine the benefits of capitalism as seen by its proponents. It is important to note that while capitalism may have its flaws, it is a system that has significantly improved the lives of many people in the real world.

Capitalism, relatively new in human history, has allowed individuals to amass great wealth by serving and pleasing their fellow man. Examples of this can be seen in the success stories of entrepreneurs like J.D. Rockefeller and Henry Ford. Rockefeller's marketing of kerosene led to a significant decrease in its price, while Ford's production of cars made transportation more affordable for the common man.

The question posed is whether those who, through their actions, have created unprecedented convenience, longer life expectancy, and a more pleasant life for the ordinary person, while becoming wealthy in the process, deserve the scorn and ridicule they receive from intellectuals, politicians, and now the pope.

Profits, a key aspect of capitalism, guide resources to their highest-valued uses and satisfy people's needs and desires. A survey of people's satisfaction with various services would likely show a higher level of satisfaction with profit-making enterprises such as supermarkets, theaters, clothing stores, and computer stores, compared to services provided by nonprofit government organizations like public schools, post offices, and departments of motor vehicles.

Profits force entrepreneurs to find ways to please people in the most efficient ways or go out of business. In contrast, nonprofits have an easier time of it, as they continue to operate regardless of their effectiveness or level of satisfaction they provide.

Arthur C. Brooks, president at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Who Really Cares," has shown that Americans are the most generous people on earth. Furthermore, generosity is found to be more prevalent in countries that are closer to the free market end of the economic spectrum than they are to the socialist or communist end. Given Pope Francis' emphasis on charity as a key part of godliness, it is suggested that he reconsider his criticism of capitalism.

Title: The New York Times Faces Criticism Over James Hodgkinson's Motives in Congressional Shooting

Article:

The New York Times has faced criticism over the weekend for a story that seemingly attempted to redefine the motives of James Hodgkinson, the lone gunman responsible for the ambush shooting on congressional Republicans last week. While the exact motive behind the attack remains unclear, most believe hyper-partisan politics are to blame.

After the shooting, authorities confirmed that Hodgkinson, a 66-year-old, was the shooter. His social media postings were heavily scrutinized, revealing that Hodgkinson was a stalwart supporter of socialist politics and had a deep hatred for President Donald Trump and Republicans.

However, on Saturday, the Times attempted to paint a different picture, suggesting that Hodgkinson's attack was not politically motivated but rather the result of an unstable individual. The story's headline emphasized this idea: "Before the Gunfire in Virginia, a Volatile Home Life in Illinois."

The story delved into Hodgkinson's personal life, describing his troubled home life, including instances of domestic abuse and the suicide of one foster child. The Times also reported that Hodgkinson likely suffered from some form of mental illness, and his political beliefs had "little" to do with his desire to target only congressional Republicans.

Critics argue that the Times' story ignores the political context of the shooting, with some tweets accusing the paper of playing to its base or trying to cover up the shooter's actual motive. However, the Times has defended its journalism, stating that it is not playing to a base to publish news stories that are deeply reported in the days after a news event.

It is worth noting that the Times does not always whitewash the ideological beliefs of people who commit atrocities. Last month, when a racist man killed two people on a Portland commuter train, the Times emphasized the fact that the perpetrator was racist and had anti-Muslim views.

The full context of Hodgkinson's motives may never be known, but the debate over the Times' coverage highlights the role of the media in shaping public perception and the importance of accurate and unbiased reporting.

Title: FBI Documents Reveal Hillary Clinton's Alleged False Statement Regarding Email Advice from Colin Powell

Article:

FBI documents handed over to Congress this week indicate that during a three-and-a-half-hour interview in early July, Hillary Clinton told FBI agents that former Secretary of State Colin Powell advised her to use a personal email account. However, Powell soon issued a statement that he could not recall such a conversation.

According to The New York Times, the alleged false statement by Clinton occurred during a dinner conversation at a small gathering hosted by Madeleine Albright, another former Secretary of State, at her home in Washington. Henry Kissinger and Condoleezza Rice also attended. Joe Conason, a journalist, describes the conversation in his upcoming book, "Man of the World: The Further Endeavors of Bill Clinton," which The Times obtained an advanced copy of.

Conason writes that the conversation took place during the early months of Clinton's tenure at the State Department. He notes that Powell suggested using a personal email account for unclassified communications, a decision Clinton reportedly made months earlier to keep her personal account and use it for most messages.

The Times reports that Clinton has not publicly claimed that Powell advised her to use private email. The FBI's production of documents to Congress has been criticized by Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA), who said the Bureau has "improperly" limited access to its files.

Powell's office released a statement on Thursday night, stating that he had no recollection of the dinner conversation. The statement also mentioned that Powell may have written a memo about his personal email use, which could exist in the FBI files. In his memoir, "It Worked for Me," Powell writes about his personal email use and takes pride in having tried to advance the antiquated technology practices at the State Department. However, Powell's use of personal email and Clinton's aren't entirely parallel, as Powell did not have a server at his house or rely on outside contractors, as Clinton did at her home in Chappaqua, NY.

The FBI's decision to not prosecute Clinton for her email practices has been criticized, with Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) stating that the Bureau has "improperly" limited access to its files. Clinton campaign communications director Jennifer Palmieri scolded that the material is classified, and any leaking of such material is illegal. However, the Clinton campaign has been accused of not taking the safeguarding of classified information seriously, as Clinton used a private server for her emails, which housed classified information.

Title: Trump's Executive Order on Family Separation Draws Mixed Reactions from Liberals and Conservatives

Article:

President Donald Trump's executive order ending the process of separating families at the U.S.-Mexico border has received mixed reactions from both liberals and conservatives. The Homeland Security Secretary briefed House Republicans on the executive order, but it appears that neither the order nor the GOP immigration bills have enough support.

Liberals have been critical of the policy, which they describe as "cruel and inhumane." They argue that the executive order merely swaps family separation for the detention of children. Some conservatives have also criticized Trump's policy and his handling of the controversy, but they have also accused Democrats of refusing to compromise on immigration.

CNN's Chris Cillizza described Trump's decision as a "fundamental miscalculation." He stated that being "tough" on immigration is not a political positive when it leads to images of children being separated from their parents. Rush Limbaugh, a conservative radio host, suggested that the media and Democrats would react to Trump's executive order by triumphantly claiming they forced Trump to "cave" on the issue while also backing legal challenges to keep the issue alive.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo wrote in a New York Times op-ed that the Trump administration's treatment of immigrant children has left a "dark stain" on the history of the nation. He argued that the executive order does not solve the problem, as it still allows for the long-term detention of immigrant children and has potentially caused irreparable harm to those children used as pawns in the president's political agenda.

The Federalist's David Harsanyi conceded that family separation is "callous and ineffective," but he argued that it does not excuse "ginned-up moral panic, pious grandstanding, and comparisons to Nazi death camps." He accused Democrats of defending a policy that incentivizes more migrants to bring children (sometimes their own, but sometimes not) and of being unwilling to make any compromise on the issue.

With this executive order, the policy of separating families appears to cease. However, child internment will continue, with families together as prisoners in federal custody. Young children will still be locked in "tender age" camps, asylum-seekers will still be criminalized as dangers and threats to national integrity, and there is still the matter of those children already separated from their parents.

Title: U.S. Military Involvement in Afghanistan: A Twenty-Year Perspective

Article:

The United States' military engagement in Afghanistan, which began in 2001, may be viewed by future historians as a prolonged and costly endeavor, similar to other great powers that attempted to exert control over the country. The British, for instance, retreated in 1842 after suffering approximately 4,500 casualties, including those from massacres that preceded the invention of the roadside bomb. They relinquished their sovereignty over Afghanistan in 1919, marking the beginning of the unwinding of their empire.

The Soviet Union also ended its decade-long attempt to control Afghanistan in 1989, months before the fall of the Berlin Wall signaled the collapse of the Communist superpower. This withdrawal led to the chaos and power vacuums that Osama bin Laden exploited, a situation the United States vowed it would never allow to persist.

The American-led attack, named "Operation Enduring Freedom," commenced on October 7, 2001, following the attacks on the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and a plane crash in Pennsylvania. In his address to the nation from the Treaty Room of the White House, President George W. Bush pledged to "win this conflict by the patient accumulation of successes, by meeting a series of challenges with determination and will and purpose."

In the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, the country rallied behind Bush. While a few warned of the dangers of entering what was dubbed the "graveyard of empires," the war was more perceived as a retaliatory and justice-seeking mission rather than a nation-building effort.

After bin Laden was killed in Pakistan in May 2011, and with Al Qaeda significantly weakened, politicians found it challenging to articulate the purpose of American troops' continued presence. Over 2,400 service members have died in combat since the invasion, according to the website icasualties.org. Neither President Barack Obama nor President Donald Trump could convincingly argue that, after nearly two decades, the United States had a significant role to play other than propping up a fragile democracy.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Delivers Fiery Speech in Support of Hillary Clinton, Criticizes Donald Trump's Actions Toward Women

Article:

During a campaign event for Hillary Clinton on Monday, Senator Elizabeth Warren delivered a passionate speech, referring to women as "nasty" in a nod to a phrase used by Donald Trump during the third presidential debate. Warren's speech focused on Trump's alleged disrespectful behavior towards women.

Warren criticized Trump for his behavior, stating, "Donald Trump aggressively disrespects more than half the human beings in this country. He thinks that because he has money, that he can call women fat pigs and bimbos. He thinks that because he is a celebrity that he can rate women's bodies from one to 10. He thinks that because he has a mouth full of Tic-Tacs, he can force himself on any women within groping distance."

Warren went on to say, "Women have had it with guys like you. And nasty women have really had it with guys like you."

The speech drew attention to Warren's past praise for the late Senator Ted Kennedy, whom she described as her moral compass in politics. Warren said, "Ted Kennedy changed my life. He changed how I understood what it is that a public servant does. I think of him in this race every single day, and I come to this convention and think about him every single hour."

Kennedy's loutish behavior towards women, which included causing the death of one, did not stop Warren from praising him. She spoke of the "special" inscription Kennedy had carved on the Senate desk she sits at.

The speech drew criticism for its hypocrisy, as some pointed out the irony of Warren's support for a candidate who has been accused of questionable actions towards women, while also criticizing Trump for similar behavior. Some also noted the inconsistency in Warren's praise for Kennedy, given his past behavior towards women.

In addition, some criticized Hillary Clinton for her association with Bill Clinton, who has been accused of sexual misconduct. Some also pointed out the contradiction in Clinton's campaign's focus on women's rights, given her support for policies such as sex-selection abortion and partial-birth abortions.

The speech also drew attention to a Clinton campaign ad featuring a young girl looking into a mirror, with Trump's alleged disrespectful comments towards women playing in the background. The ad ends with the question, "Is this the president we want for our daughters?" Some criticized the ad for implying that Clinton is a role model for young girls, while others questioned the authenticity of the ad's message, given Clinton's association with Bill Clinton and her own record on women's issues.

Title: Congressional Democrats and Republicans Disagree on Trump Administration's Proposed CHIP Funding Cuts

Article:

Congressional Democrats and Republicans are at odds over the Trump Administration's proposal to roll back $15 billion in previously allocated funding, with a significant portion of the requested rescissions coming from the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). The White House claims that the $7 billion cut from CHIP funding comes from unspent funds from 2017, which has now expired.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi have spoken out against the administration's proposal, setting the stage for an upcoming fight. Schumer stated, "Let's be honest about what this is: President Trump and Republicans in Congress are looking to tear apart the bipartisan (CHIP), hurting middle-class families and low-income children, to appease the most conservative special interests and feel better about blowing up the deficit to give the wealthiest few and biggest corporations huge tax breaks."

Pelosi, in a statement to members, said her colleagues were not ready to strike a deal. "These Republican rescissions show the hypocrisy of a GOP Congress that insists on tight budgets for children and families while handing enormous, unpaid-for giveaways to corporations and the wealthiest," she said.

The disagreement is not limited to Democratic leadership. Democratic senators have also expressed their disdain for the proposal, citing its requests for cuts to the CHIP program. In March, members of Congress voted to rescind $3.1 billion from the CHIP Contingency Fund and $3.6 billion in funds provided to states, totaling just under $7 billion.

The administration's proposal also includes sections 526, 527, and 529, which outline the rescission of specific funds and the unavailability of certain amounts for obligation in the current fiscal year.

In early February, lawmakers agreed to a 10-year extension of CHIP funding, which included $7 billion towards community health centers, $6 billion to deal with opioids and mental care, and other provisions supported on a bipartisan basis.

In 2011, Democratic Sen. Debbie Stabenow of Michigan put forth an amendment that called for the rescinding of $44 billion in unobligated funds, an amount three times the size of the administration's proposal. The amendment won the support of 81 senators, including several Democrats and Republican Sen. Susan Collins of Maine, who is ambivalent about the president's proposal due to CHIP funding.

Title: Pelosi Suggests President Trump's Actions May Be Building an Impeachment Case, Calls for Attorney General Barr to be Held in Contempt

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi suggested on Wednesday that President Donald Trump's actions, particularly his continued obstruction of congressional subpoenas and demands for testimony, may be inadvertently building a case for impeachment. During a live interview with The Washington Post, Pelosi stated, "He's becoming self-impeachable in terms of some of the things he's doing."

Pelosi has consistently cautioned against the divisive process of impeachment and has previously warned against Democrats rushing to initiate impeachment proceedings. On Tuesday and Wednesday, she suggested that Trump might be attempting to provoke Democratic lawmakers into doing so.

During the interview, Pelosi pointed out that one of the articles of impeachment against President Richard Nixon charged obstruction of Congress, but she did not commit to a similar narrow impeachment push against Trump.

Pelosi also called for Attorney General William Barr to be held in contempt for his refusal to release an unredacted version of the Mueller report. However, she stopped short of calling for Barr's impeachment.

Pelosi argued that the House Judiciary Committee had made accommodations to protect certain parts of the Mueller report, but the White House intervened, invoking executive privilege. She stated, "The accommodations the committee has tried to make...I appreciate protecting sources and methods, some law enforcement concerns. That's not a reason to give us the report. It's an excuse not to give us the report, because we all agree that certain things should be redacted."

The House Judiciary Committee is scheduled to meet Wednesday to vote on a contempt citation for Barr for missing the committee's self-imposed deadline for turning over the full report last week. Pelosi noted that the contempt motion did not account for Barr's refusal to appear before the Judiciary Committee last week, objecting to being questioned by committee staff in addition to lawmakers.

Pelosi also took a swipe at Barr's no-show, suggesting he felt "safer in the Republican majority in the Senate," where he had testified the day before.

Title: "Book Reveals Behind-the-Scenes Strategy of Kavanaugh's Supreme Court Confirmation"

Article:

In the midst of the controversy surrounding Christine Blasey Ford's accusations against Brett Kavanaugh during his Supreme Court nomination, there were speculations that he might withdraw from the nomination battle. However, President Trump and his top aides opted to fight back, according to a new book titled "Justice on Trial: The Kavanaugh Confirmation and the Future of the Supreme Court."

Authors Mollie Hemingway, a Fox News contributor and senior editor at the Federalist, and Carrie Severino, chief counsel of the Judicial Crisis Network, interviewed Trump, top White House officials, several Supreme Court justices, and many others for the book.

The book reveals a central conundrum for Kavanaugh and his advocates, which is that any criticism of Ford would be perceived as a smear and victim shaming. Despite some details about Ford's behavior in high school and college that were "dramatically at odds with her presentation in the media," the Kavanaugh team decided to focus on his record and the damage to his reputation.

The authors are critical of the coverage of the nomination drama, including in the New York Times and Washington Post, and blame in part "the media's irrational personal dislike of Kavanaugh." They particularly unload on the New Yorker for publishing the allegations of Deborah Ramirez, a Yale classmate of Kavanaugh who claimed that he exposed himself to her and caused her to touch his genitals. The magazine was unable to find a corroborating witness, acknowledging that Ramirez had "significant gaps" in her memories and that it took her six days of assessing those memories and consulting with a lawyer to name Kavanaugh. He flatly denied the allegations.

Michael Avenatti, the lawyer now facing criminal charges in three cases, later produced an affidavit from another accuser, Julie Swetnick. She claimed to have attended more than 10 house parties in the early 1980s at which Kavanaugh and a friend became inebriated and sexually assaulted women, and got them drunk so they could be gang-raped.

Hemingway and Severino call the allegations "obviously ridiculous," saying "no one could have hidden such crimes for decades, much less a man who went on to hold high-profile positions in the White House and then became a judge on the second-most prominent federal court." Kavanaugh said the charges were from "the Twilight Zone."

When NBC’s Kate Snow interviewed Swetnick, the network acknowledged that some of her comments on camera "differ from her written statement last week." Swetnick backed off from saying Kavanaugh had spiked the punch, recalling only that he had handed out the punch. More importantly, she dropped her claim that Kavanaugh was present at her rape, saying only that she had seen him earlier at the same party.

"Despite Swetnick’s obvious credibility problems, many in the media continued to air her accusations," the book says. The book also touches on some of those alleged details involving Ford.

The authors, who obviously write from a conservative perspective, offer many examples of what they call "the media’s irrational personal dislike of Kavanaugh." The Times published a story co-authored by Emily Bazelon, who had already announced her opposition to Kavanaugh, saying that in college he was involved in a bar fight that involved throwing ice. (The paper admitted Bazelon was not a newsroom reporter and should not have been used on the story.) In a USA Today column, Erik Brady said Kavanaugh should give up his school coaching duties because "credibly accused sex offenders" should "stay off basketball courts for now when kids are around."

The judge's staunchest supporter was his wife Ashley, who had prayed that her husband wouldn't get the nomination. Ashley sustained herself through the ordeal by praying regularly and studying the Bible. When Sen. Susan Collins, a key swing vote, gave a lengthy speech saying she would vote to confirm Kavanaugh, Ashley made an emotional call to her husband and told him to watch it. Kavanaugh, who knew that it would have been easier politically for the senator not to support him, texted her a message of thanks and promised that he would not disappoint her.

Title: Supreme Court's DACA Ruling Puts Immigration Reform Pressure on Congress

Article:

The Supreme Court's conservative majority has cast doubt on the future of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, potentially leaving the issue in the hands of Congress. The court is expected to make a ruling in the spring of 2020, during an election year, when the politics of immigration are expected to be more challenging.

Since the Senate's failure to pass a comprehensive immigration overhaul in 2013, it has been unable to secure 60 votes for a substantial immigration bill. The chamber did pass a spending bill providing aid to the border this year, but the Democrats' internal disputes over the matter made the party more reluctant to engage with the Trump administration.

The biggest hurdle for a potential deal is the massive trust deficit between Senate Democrats and the president. Many Democrats feel burned by past negotiations, and some in the party seem unwilling to try again. Centrist Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.) stated, "It is exceptionally difficult to make any deal that sticks. For a man who is supposed to be a great deal-maker, we have yet to see a great deal."

The president's tweet this week, stating that "If Supreme Court remedies with overturn, a deal will be made with Dems for them to stay!" has been met with skepticism by both Democrats and some Republicans. In 2018, only eight Republicans joined the Democrats on a compromise immigration proposal, a number advocates say could have been much higher without Trump and his aides' opposition.

The House passed legislation dealing with DACA protections earlier this year, but the Senate has ignored it. The bar is high in the Senate, with its 60-vote requirement, and under the current party splits, the chamber's supermajority threshold on the filibuster would require either seven Democrats or 13 Republicans to cross party lines on any immigration bill.

Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) stated, "We don't have the votes in the Senate, OK?" and expressed his belief that the president liked the 2013 immigration reform but is unable to act due to pressure from hardliners like Stephen Miller. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) suggested narrowing legislation as much as possible to cover only the 660,000 young people whose status could be affected by the Supreme Court's decision.

The Senate, controlled by Republicans, is generally more divided on the issue than the Democratic Party. Trump lost 14 votes from the Senate GOP on his 2018 immigration bill, revealing that any legislation providing a path to citizenship for some undocumented immigrants is a bridge too far for some Republicans.

Despite these challenges, some senators, such as Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas), believe the chamber should begin working on a plan now rather than waiting for the Supreme Court to force Congress' hand just months from a presidential election. The biggest problem might be getting votes from Democrats for any plan that doesn't first have Trump's full and explicit support. The bipartisan immigration deal cut by Sens. Angus King (I-Maine) and Mike Rounds (R-S.D.) last year was supported by every Democrat but three, but King states he wouldn't replicate that deal today after Trump torpedoed it.

Title: Iowa Caucuses Face Challenges in Implementing Absentee Voting Process Due to DNC Rules

Article:

The Iowa caucuses, often viewed as the first step in the presidential nominating season, have faced criticism and comparisons to pests that are difficult to eliminate. However, the caucuses serve a valuable function in the political process, despite efforts to undermine them.

The current challenge for the Iowa caucuses stems from the Democratic National Committee (DNC) requiring states, including Iowa, to establish an absentee voting process. The goal is to expand participation and prevent disenfranchisement of individuals who may be unable to attend in-person caucuses due to work, mobility issues, overseas military service, or other conflicts.

Iowa Democrats have made efforts to create a way to expand participation while maintaining the nature of the caucuses. However, the DNC has expressed concerns about the security of a proposed "virtual" telephonic caucus meeting, citing potential vendor issues. This has led to a dispute between the DNC and Iowa Democrats.

The DNC's concerns seem to arise from a misunderstanding of caucuses, as they are not elections and should not be held to the same standards for participation or security as elections. Caucuses do not produce an irreversible result that might put the wrong person in office.

The Iowa caucuses are unique in that they force voters to give up most of an evening in the middle of winter, which encourages voters to educate themselves about the issues and candidates. The caucuses are also significant for party-building, as candidates must meet voters and campaign on their ideas in Iowa, giving the rest of the country a better opportunity to take their measure.

The DNC's current rules may lead to the elimination of the Iowa caucuses, which could potentially impact the American political process and the "American dream" of anyone being able to become president. The DNC is currently considering a waiver for Iowa's absentee caucus process, but this only delays the issue until 2024. The DNC should reconsider its blanket prohibition on telephone caucuses or rethink its requirement for an absentee caucus process.

Title: U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions' Testimony Under Scrutiny: A Closer Look at the Controversy

Article:

The recent news regarding U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions has been met with skepticism due to conflicting reports in The New York Times and The Washington Post. The controversy revolves around Sessions' failure to disclose two meetings he had with Russia's ambassador to the United States during his confirmation hearing to become attorney general.

The Washington Post reported that Sessions spoke twice last year with Russia's ambassador, a fact he did not disclose during his confirmation hearing. This has led to questions about potential contacts between members of President Trump's campaign and representatives of Moscow.

Former President George W. Bush's chief White House ethics lawyer, Richard W. Painter, has called the story a "bombshell" and suggested that such behavior would typically result in termination, revocation of security clearances, and potential criminal prosecution. On the other hand, Senator Ted Cruz has labeled it a "nothing burger."

Initially, this article aimed to present three hypotheses for the situation: (1) Sessions was colluding with Moscow and trying to hide it; (2) Sessions wasn't colluding with Moscow, but he forgot about his meetings with Kislyak; (3) Sessions wasn't colluding with Moscow, but decided to lie about contacts with Russians.

Upon further investigation, the first hypothesis was dismissed, as collusion would typically involve more discretion. The second hypothesis was also questioned, as Sessions submitted a Questions for the Record (QFR) filing, and such documents are completed with great care, making an omission or falsehood unlikely.

After reviewing the QFR, it was found that the Russia question, as posed by Vermont Democrat Patrick Leahy, was: "Several of the President-Elect's nominees or senior advisers have Russian ties. Have you been in contact with anyone connected to any part of the Russian government about the 2016 election, either before or after election day?" Sessions' answer was: "No."

Therefore, all three initial hypotheses have been dismissed, leaving the question of why Sessions answered "No" to the question about contact with anyone connected to the Russian government, when he had indeed met with the Russian ambassador.

Title: Iran's Foreign Minister Assumes U.S. Will Abandon Nuclear Deal, Hopes Europe Will Maintain Agreement

Article:

Iran's Foreign Minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, has expressed the assumption that the United States will abandon the international nuclear deal restricting Iran's nuclear activities. In an interview with the Financial Times and the Guardian, Zarif stated that if the deal collapses, Iran would no longer be bound by its limitations on uranium enrichment, centrifuge numbers, and the production of plutonium. However, he reiterated that Iran would only use nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.

Zarif's comments come as U.S. President Donald Trump is set to announce next month whether he believes Iran has complied with the terms of the deal. If Trump determines that Iran has failed to adhere to the agreement, the U.S. Congress will initiate the process of reimposing sanctions on Iran. Trump has previously criticized the deal, referring to it as an "embarrassment" in a speech to the United Nations this month.

France, Germany, and the UK, which, along with Russia and China, signed the deal, have recently defended it. If the deal collapses, Iran would no longer be bound by its limitations, according to Zarif. He stated, "You either live by it [the deal] or you set it aside. You can not be half pregnant."

Zarif also noted that the deal allowed Iran to continue its research and development, thereby improving its technological base. He suggested that if Iran were to abandon the deal, it would do so with better technology.

In response to questions about Trump's unpredictability, Zarif said, "I think he has made a policy of being unpredictable, and now he's turning that into being unreliable as well. He has violated the letter, spirit, everything of the deal."

Zarif added that Iran's options would depend on how the international community responds to the U.S.'s actions. "If Europe and Japan and Russia and China decided to go along with the U.S., then I think that will be the end of the deal," he said. "Europe should lead."

European Union officials have stated they could act to legally protect European investors in Iran if the U.S. reimposes sanctions. However, they have also criticized Iran over its non-nuclear activities in the region.

Title: Trump Administration Announces Plan to Resurrect "Gag Rule" on Planned Parenthood

Article:

The Trump administration has announced plans to reinstate a rule that would prohibit federally funded family planning clinics, including Planned Parenthood, from discussing abortion with patients. White House senior adviser Kellyanne Conway stated that the administration is recognizing "that abortion is not family planning" and that the funds are intended for family planning services.

The Department of Health and Human Services officially filed the rule with the Office of Management and Budget on Friday. Planned Parenthood's clinics are major recipients of grants for family planning and basic preventive care. During the 2016 election, President Trump campaigned on defunding the organization.

The policy, often referred to as a "gag rule," is likely to trigger lawsuits that could prevent it from taking effect. Planned Parenthood's executive vice president, Dawn Laguens, stated that the policy would make it impossible for women to access Planned Parenthood's services.

However, the administration stated that Planned Parenthood can still receive Title X grants if it keeps the family-planning money separate from funds used to pay for abortions. An administration official told Fox News, "This proposal does not necessarily defund Planned Parenthood, as long as they’re willing to disentangle taxpayer funds from abortion as a method of family planning."

Known as Title X, the nation's family planning program serves about four million women a year through clinics, at a cost to taxpayers of about $260 million. The policy was rescinded under President Bill Clinton, and a new rule went into effect which allowed "nondirective" counseling to include a range of options for women.

According to a Trump administration summary, the new proposal would roll back the Clinton requirement that abortion should be discussed as an option along with prenatal care and adoption. Doctors' groups and abortion rights supporters argue that a ban on counseling women infringes on the doctor-patient relationship. They point out that federal family planning funds cannot currently be used to pay for abortion procedures.

Abortion opponents allege that the federal family planning program in effect cross-subsidizes abortion services provided by Planned Parenthood. The Republican-led Congress has unsuccessfully tried to deny federal funds to Planned Parenthood, and the Trump administration has vowed to religious and social conservatives that it will continue the effort.

Title: Study Finds Similar Motivation for Ideological Bubble Formation Among Liberals and Conservatives

Article:

A new study published in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology has found that both liberals and conservatives are similarly motivated to avoid information that contradicts their beliefs, challenging the common perception that conservatives are more prone to forming ideological bubbles. The study, led by psychology professor Jeremy Frimer of the University of Winnipeg in Canada, was inspired by a conversation with a liberal philosophy professor who expressed a reluctance to engage with the opposing view on same-sex marriage.

The research, which involved five experiments with approximately 2,400 participants, identified several issues that people are particularly keen to avoid debating, including climate change, the merits of former U.S. presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, and same-sex marriage. In one experiment, participants from both sides of the debate willingly forfeited a chance to win money to avoid hearing from someone with an opposing view on same-sex marriage.

The study's authors found that this avoidance of opposing viewpoints was not due to election fatigue or a feeling of being well-informed about the issues. Instead, participants from both sides were trying to avoid the discomfort that comes with conflicting opinions and were concerned that disagreeing with someone would damage their relationship with them.

Frimer and his colleagues also found that this lack of interest in opposing viewpoints was not related to the participants' political ideology. "People are looking to avoid feeling angry and frustrated when they hear from the other side, and they are also looking to avoid fights," Frimer said. The study suggests that people have a fundamental need to feel mental synchrony with others, and seeking out information from like-minded others could satisfy this need, while avoiding information from unlike-minded others could undermine it.

The study's findings add a new nuance to previous research on ideological bubbles, which has generally found that political conservatives are more prone to avoiding dissenting opinions than liberals. Frimer and his colleagues argue that the tendency to self-segregate by political beliefs is far from one-sided. "Liberals are very open-minded — toward other liberals. Beyond that, they might be a little more self-congratulatory than the evidence warrants," Frimer said.

The study has some caveats. The participants were disproportionately wealthy, well-educated, and white. Additionally, the opinions included in the analysis were ones that the subjects had already developed; the researchers did not ask subjects to form a new opinion on a novel or hypothetical issue. It's also possible that one side may have better reasons to want to ignore the other or be justifiably disinterested in what the other side has to say.

Regardless of political ideology, people tend to see their own views as unquestionably right and others' as unquestionably wrong. "Liberals may think that conservatives' views truly are irrational, indefensible, and the product of fear — and thus not worth hearing," Frimer and his colleagues wrote. "A conservative might have a similar impression of liberals' beliefs, opinions, and reasoning." The result: "What could ultimately be a contest of ideas is being replaced by two, non-interacting monopolies" — a situation we're all responsible for helping to create.

Title: Kentucky Senate Debate Sparks Controversy: McConnell and Grimes Clash on Obama Agenda, Jobs, and Coal

Article:

The first and only Kentucky Senate debate of the season took place on Monday, with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell and Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes engaging in a heated exchange. The debate, which was televised for an hour, centered on topics such as the Obama administration's agenda, job creation, and the coal industry.

McConnell accused Grimes of supporting President Obama's "jobs-killing agenda," particularly in relation to the war on coal in Kentucky. Grimes countered that McConnell "doesn't want to take responsibility for all that is wrong with Washington," attributing the issues to gridlock and partisanship championed by McConnell.

Grimes also defended herself against McConnell's attempts to link her to Obama, stating, "I have my disagreements with the president, but the president is not on the ballot this year." When asked about her voting history, Grimes, who has identified as a Clinton Democrat, declined to disclose whether she voted for President Obama, citing her constitutional right to privacy at the ballot box.

McConnell, who has faced criticism for his ties to the coal industry, accused Grimes of trying to "deceive Kentuckians" and "hide her views." He also reiterated his opposition to the Affordable Care Act, calling it "the worst piece of legislation in the last half century" and advocating for its complete removal.

Grimes, who has been critical of McConnell's conservative leadership, emphasized her plan to grow the middle class and create jobs. McConnell, in response, expressed his experience and steadfast leadership, even when faced with Grimes' accusations of profiting from his government job and opposing legislation to help children.

The closely-watched race is considered one of the toughest in McConnell's 30-year Senate career and is among the six or seven races that will determine whether Republicans take control of the Senate. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee has invested $1.4 million in Grimes, in addition to the half-million already spent on the race.

According to a nonpartisan average of polls by RealClearPolitics.com, McConnell currently leads by 3 percentage points. McConnell, who would likely become the Senate majority leader if his party takes control of the upper chamber, could potentially derail the remainder of Obama's second term if the Republicans win a net total of six races.

Throughout the campaign, both candidates have received significant financial support from outside interests. Hollywood types are eager to unseat a top Capitol Hill Republican, while McConnell supporters are trying to prevent what they consider to be overspending and overreach by the Obama administration, including the Environmental Protection Agency's crackdown on the coal industry.

The McConnell campaign and its allies have consistently run TV ads comparing Grimes to Obama. Two groups, Kentuckians for Strong Leadership and the Kentucky Opportunity Coalition, have collectively invested $5.2 million in General Election ad time. Grimes, in response to these ads, accused McConnell and his allies of misleading Kentuckians with $50 million in deceptive ads.

Title: Democrats' Strategies in Response to Kavanaugh's Supreme Court Nomination

Article:

In the ongoing battle over President Trump's Supreme Court nominee, Judge Brett Kavanaugh, Democrats have resorted to two primary strategies: disruption and criticism. The nuclear option, invoked by former Sen. Harry Reid, has left Democrats with limited power to block Kavanaugh's ascension, prompting demonstrative actions and vocal opposition.

Senators Kamala Harris and Cory Booker, both vocal opponents of Kavanaugh's nomination, attempted to halt the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing by calling for adjournment and interrupting proceedings multiple times. Other senators, including Richard Blumenthal, Mazie Hirono, Amy Klobuchar, Sheldon Whitehouse, Patrick Leahy, and Chris Coons, also disrupted the hearing.

Protests outside the hearing included Women's March activist Linda Sarsour, who was arrested for disrupting the proceedings, and feminist protesters dressed as characters from "The Handmaid's Tale." Social media platforms were flooded with criticism and calls to action, with Planned Parenthood Action tweeting, "This is what the resistance looks like, and we're going to fight like hell to #StopKavanaugh."

One controversial incident involved accusations of white supremacy symbolism against Zina Bash, a former Kavanaugh law clerk. Amy Siskind of The Weekly List tweeted, "What fresh hell is this!!!??? Kavanaugh's assistant Zina Bash giving the white power sign during the hearing? This alone should be disqualify!!!" However, it was later revealed that Bash, who is half-Mexican and half-Jewish, and whose paternal grandparents were Holocaust survivors, was not making a white supremacy gesture.

Another controversy arose when Fred Guttenberg, the father of a Parkland shooting victim, claimed that Kavanaugh refused to shake his hand. However, it was later revealed that this encounter did not occur as described.

With judicial hearings often proving fruitless in terms of gaining insight into nominees' judicial philosophies, the hearing process has been criticized for its lack of substance. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell could potentially end the circus by bringing Kavanaugh up for a vote. However, the political theater is expected to continue, with Democrats maintaining a visible presence in the opposition.

Title: Supreme Court's Decision on Affordable Care Act: Three Potential Outcomes for the Obama Administration

Article:

The Supreme Court is expected to rule on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) this month. The court's decision could potentially impact the 2012 election, although the Obama administration aims to keep health care from becoming a defining issue of the campaign.

According to sources close to the situation, the Obama administration is preparing for three main scenarios: the law being upheld, the individual mandate being struck down while the rest of the law remains, or the court overturning the entire ACA.

If the court upholds the ACA, the administration would likely celebrate a significant legislative victory. However, if the individual mandate is struck down, leaving the rest of the law intact, the administration would retain popular provisions such as covering pre-existing conditions, eliminating the "donut hole" gap for senior prescription benefits, and allowing young adults to stay on their parents' health plans until age 26.

A poll by The New York Times/CBS suggests that 51% of voters either want the individual mandate struck down or the entire law upheld, while 41% want the whole law trashed. This aligns with years of polling showing that individual parts of the ACA, particularly banning discrimination based on pre-existing conditions, are more popular than the law as a whole.

If the court strikes down the individual mandate and also removes the provision covering pre-existing conditions, it would create a policy dilemma. The individual mandate is crucial for funding the popular provisions of the ACA. Without the mandate, the administration would need to find alternative funding sources to maintain these provisions.

Another scenario, considered a good bet by some SCOTUS watchers, is that the court could knock out the individual mandate and also strip out the pre-existing condition coverage, since it wouldn't work without the mandate. This is the scenario the Obama administration suggests the court should adopt if it eliminates the mandate.

In the worst-case scenario for the administration, a split verdict could result in a phantom law on the books that energizes tea party Republicans who want the ACA dead. The Obama administration is reportedly preparing for these outcomes, with quiet plans underway to address potential policy and political challenges.

Title: Republican National Convention Shaping Up to Be a Contentious Event Amidst Lack of Support from GOP Leaders

Article:

The Republican National Convention, scheduled to take place in Cleveland this year, is shaping up to be a contentious event amidst a lack of support from several GOP leaders. The Democratic National Convention, on the other hand, is expected to follow the traditional script, with Hillary Clinton set to emerge as the party's nominee.

The Republican convention is facing a significant challenge, with numerous GOP governors, senators, and House members expressing reluctance to speak or attend the event. Trey Gowdy, the Republican Congressman from South Carolina, and Florida Rep. Carlos Curbelo are among those who have publicly stated they will not be attending.

The lack of interest in speaking at the convention is unusual, as a speaking slot at a national convention is a significant opportunity for politicians to introduce themselves to the country and potential campaign financiers. The reluctance to participate in the convention is attributed to the widespread opposition to Donald Trump's campaign, with approximately 70% of the country objecting to it, according to Stuart Stevens, a Republican strategist.

Furthermore, the #NeverTrump forces are reportedly planning to stage a coup at the convention, with an "advance team" heading to Cleveland this week to lay the groundwork for a contested convention. The plan is to "unbind" the GOP delegates, allowing them to "vote their conscience," which is another way of saying they would overturn the will of their voters. However, the RNC is aware of the potential damage that could result from usurping the party's democratically elected nominee at the convention.

Despite the efforts of the #NeverTrump forces, the RNC is expected to face challenges in papering over the chaos, given the conspicuous lack of relevant or respectable speakers. The convention's proceedings will likely be a stark reminder of a party without a clear identity or a strong chance of winning in November.

Title: Unemployment Claims Decrease, but Remain Historically High in the U.S.

Article:

First-time unemployment claims in the United States totaled 2.1 million last week, marking a decrease from previous weeks and the lowest total since the onset of the coronavirus crisis. This figure, however, still indicates a high number of Americans remain jobless. Economists surveyed by Dow Jones had anticipated 2.05 million claims.

The total represented a decrease of 323,000 from the previous week's upwardly revised 2.438 million. Continuing claims, or those who have been collecting benefits for at least two weeks, numbered 21.05 million, showing a clear picture of the ongoing joblessness. This number dropped sharply, falling 3.86 million from the previous week.

Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, stated that the decline in continuing claims suggests that the reopening of states is pushing businesses to rehire some of the workers let go when the virus hit. However, Shepherdson noted that some of the data, particularly from California, remains noisy and may not accurately represent some states' situations.

The insured unemployment rate, a basic calculation of those collecting benefits versus the total labor force, decreased sharply to 14.5% from 17.1% the previous week. Gus Faucher, chief economist at PNC, commented that layoffs continue at a massive scale, but it may be that the job market is nearing a turning point.

The four-week moving average, which helps smooth out weekly volatility, rose to 22.72 million, an increase of 760,250 from the previous week. Since the pandemic was declared in mid-March, 40.8 million have filed claims as social distancing measures aimed at containing the coronavirus outbreak resulted in much of the $21.5 trillion U.S. economy being in lockdown for 2½ months.

A separate report Thursday showed that first-quarter GDP contracted by 5%, while the Atlanta Fed's GDPNow tracker is indicating a 41.9% plunge in Q2, which would be the worst in U.S. history. This would place the U.S. firmly in recession territory, though most economists are expecting a rebound in the second half of the year after restrictions are lifted.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Faces Criticism Over Actions Detailed in DOJ Inspector General Report

Article:

The Department of Justice Inspector General released a report yesterday, alleging that former FBI Director James Comey violated FBI rules, protocol, and potentially laws in his efforts to investigate President Trump and his administration. The report states that Comey failed to safeguard sensitive information obtained during his tenure at the FBI and used it to create public pressure for official action.

According to the report, Comey's actions set a dangerous example for the over 35,000 current FBI employees and thousands more former FBI employees who have access to or knowledge of non-public information. The report states, "In a country built on the rule of law, it is of utmost importance that all FBI employees adhere to Department and FBI policies, particularly when confronted by what appear to be extraordinary circumstances or compelling personal convictions."

Despite these findings, Comey demanded an apology from his critics. In response to the report's release, Comey tweeted, "I don't need a public apology from those who defamed me, but a quick message with a'sorry we lied about you' would be nice."

The demand has been met with harsh responses from legal experts on both sides of the political aisle. Democrat and George Washington University Law Professor Jonathan Turley wrote in The Hill that Comey's actions "establish that Comey is the very antithesis of the ethical leader he described." Turley further stated, "Rather than rave about who stole his strawberries, as Queeg did in 'The Caine Mutiny,' Comey claims someone stole a reputation that he tossed away two years ago."

Republican Gregg Jarrett argues at Fox News that Comey owes the American public a sincere apology for abusing his position as FBI director, violating government rules, concealing information from his former agency, leaking sensitive documents without authorization, mismarking memos without classification banners, improperly retaining records in an unsecured location, failing to surrender those records to the FBI, and assuming "carte blanche authority" he did not have.

The report's findings and the subsequent criticism have not deterred Comey from maintaining his innocence. In a statement, Comey portrayed the scathing report as a type of victory and encouraged his critics to send their apologies to him. The report states that Comey not only knowingly violated rules governing all FBI employees but that his decisions "set a dangerous example for the over 35,000 current FBI employees."

The report's findings and the subsequent criticism have not deterred Comey from maintaining his innocence. In a statement, Comey portrayed the scathing report as a type of victory and encouraged his critics to send their apologies to him. The report states that Comey not only knowingly violated rules governing all FBI employees but that his decisions "set a dangerous example for the over 35,000 current FBI employees." It is unclear what the future holds for Comey, but given his former colleague and fellow leaker Andrew McCabe's recent hiring at CNN, he may not be far behind.

Title: President Trump Signs $1.3 Trillion Omnibus Spending Bill, Criticizes Excessive Spending and Democratic Tactics

Article:

President Donald Trump signed a $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill on Friday, emphasizing the need for military rebuilding, but criticized Democrats for adding unnecessary spending and vowed never to sign another budget-busting measure.

"I've told Congress, I will never sign a bill like this again," Mr. Trump said, labeling the legislative process that produced it "ridiculous."

Hours prior, the president had threatened to veto the bill, potentially leading to a government shutdown as funding was set to expire at midnight Friday. The veto threat took Washington by surprise, following repeated assurances from White House officials, including Vice President Mike Pence and budget chief Mick Mulvaney, that the president would sign the massive spending package.

Ultimately, the president decided to sign the bill "because of the gains we made for our military," he said.

Criticizing the bill he was about to sign for unnecessary spending, not addressing the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, and not fully funding a border wall, Mr. Trump called for changes to Congress' rules to make progress on vital issues. He demanded Congress approve a line-item veto for the president and for the Senate to eliminate the filibuster rule that requires 60 votes to advance most legislation.

"We've got to get a lot of great legislation approved, and without the filibuster rule, it will happen just like magic," said Mr. Trump. Allowing a line-item veto would require a constitutional amendment, as the Supreme Court ruled the procedure unconstitutional in the 1998 decision Clinton v. City of New York.

Mr. Trump boasted that the bill provided a historic boost to military spending, including the largest pay increase for troops in a decade. The investments, he said, fulfilled his pledge to rebuild the U.S. military into the most formidable fighting force in the world.

"They hollowed our readiness as a military unit and put America at really grave risk," he said of years of defense cuts. "The omnibus bill reverses this."

He blamed the omnibus's huge price tag on Democrats, who he said demanded extra spending in exchange for funding the military. He said the Democrats oppose military spending.

"If we take something for the military, they want something that in many cases are a wasted sum of money," he said. "It's not right, and it's very bad for our country."

Title: Sarah Palin Dismisses Martin Bashir's Attacks, Calls for Higher Media Standards

Article:

Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor and 2008 Republican vice presidential nominee, dismissed the attacks of former MSNBC host Martin Bashir on Thursday, stating that such incidents are "par for the course." In her first comments since Bashir's resignation, Palin expressed her familiarity with such attacks during an interview on Fox News' "Fox & Friends."

Bashir resigned on Wednesday following comments he made on his Nov. 15 broadcast, where he referred to Palin as a "world class idiot" and compared her to a slave owner, citing a diary of a former plantation manager who forced a slave to defecate in another slave's mouth.

Palin acknowledged that many in the media had criticized Bashir's comments, stating, "It was refreshing to see though, that many in the media did come out and say, ‘Look, our standards have got to be higher than this.’" She emphasized that those with a media platform have a greater responsibility to maintain higher standards.

When asked whether Bashir's resignation was sufficient, Palin responded that she had to move past it. She referred to Bashir's on-air apology during his Nov. 18 broadcast and expressed her willingness to accept his apology and move on.

Palin stated that, five or six years ago, she would have been personally hurt by such attacks, but now she feels "kind of calloused." She added that attacks are often directed towards conservative women and that there is an "obvious" double standard.

"As I've said before, the target of the attack is usually more significant than what the attack, the articulated words used, actually are, and that's part of that double standard," Palin said, adding that she had not heard from any feminist groups or organizations.

Title: WikiLeaks Founder Julian Assange Discusses Alleged U.S. Focus on Russia's Role in Democratic Hacks

Article:

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has stated that there is an "obvious" reason the Obama administration has focused on Russia's alleged role in Democratic hacks leading up to the 2016 U.S. presidential election. In an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, Assange suggested that the Obama administration is attempting to delegitimize the Trump administration as it enters the White House.

"They're trying to say that President-elect Trump is not a legitimate president," Assange said during the interview, which was conducted at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London where he has been staying.

Assange reiterated WikiLeaks' denial that Russia was the source of the Democratic documents released over the summer. "Our source is not a state party, so the answer for our interactions is no," he said.

In December, Assange told Hannity that the documents the anti-secrecy group received looked "very much like they're from the Russians" but said his source was not them. When asked if WikiLeaks influenced the 2016 election, Assange pointed to private comments from members of the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign in documents published by the group.

"Did [WikiLeaks] change the outcome of the election? Who knows, it's impossible to tell," Assange said. "But if it did, the accusation is that the true statements of Hillary Clinton and her campaign manager, John Podesta, and the DNC head Debbie Wasserman Schultz, their true statements is what changed the election."

Title: Putin Suggests Consideration of Statehood for Eastern Ukraine, Blames West for Crisis

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin has called for immediate talks on the political future of eastern Ukraine, suggesting for the first time that the region could be granted statehood. In a televised program on Sunday, Putin stated, "We need to immediately begin substantive talks...on questions of the political organization of society and statehood in southeastern Ukraine with the goal of protecting the lawful interests of the people who live there."

Historically, Russia has advocated for greater autonomy for the eastern regions of Ukraine, where predominantly Russian-speakers reside, under a decentralized federal system. However, in the program, Putin did not directly address additional Western sanctions on Russia.

Putin attributed the crisis in Ukraine to Western interference, accusing the West of supporting a "coup" against pro-Kremlin president Viktor Yanukovych in February. He stated, "They should have known that Russia can not stand aside when people are being shot almost at point-blank range."

Putin has denied that Moscow has sent regular troops to fight in Ukraine, but pro-Russian rebels have claimed that many Russian soldiers have volunteered while "on vacation." The West accused Moscow this week of orchestrating a counter-offensive that has put Ukrainian government forces on the defensive in the nearly five-month conflict.

NATO stated on Thursday that Moscow had over 1,000 troops on the ground in Ukraine and 20,000 troops massed by the border. Analysts, including Russian experts, see Putin's actions as an attempt to create a statelet in eastern Ukraine, similar to the de facto separatist states in Moldova and Georgia.

Putin referred to the fighters in eastern Ukraine as defenders of "Novorossiya," a loaded Tsarist-era name for what is now southern and eastern Ukraine. He first used the term in April, following the annexation of Crimea from Ukraine, which sparked outrage in Kiev and the West.

Despite Putin's stated support for a negotiated political solution to the crisis, he has used fiery, uncompromising rhetoric in recent days. In a talk with youth activists on Friday, he compared the shelling of the rebel-held cities of Lugansk and Donetsk to the Nazi siege of Leningrad. Aid groups have condemned indiscriminate shelling by both sides in the conflict, which has claimed almost 2,600 lives.

Putin placed the blame for the fighting in eastern Ukraine squarely on Kiev. "What is now happening, it seems to me, to be an absolutely natural reaction by people who live there and who are defending themselves -- they were not the first to take up arms," he said.

While people in eastern Ukraine had been concerned about attempts to downgrade the status of the Russian language, there had been no serious incidents of violence in the region until pro-Russian rebels took control of several cities in April.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Campaign Strategy and Image Control Revealed in AP Report

Article:

The Associated Press has obtained emails that offer insights into the careful image-control apparatus of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's campaign. The emails reveal a behind-the-scenes effort to review introductory remarks for college presidents and students presenting Clinton as a speaker, as well as suggesting questions that align with her campaign platform.

The campaign reportedly injects itself into minute details of Clinton's appearances, including suggesting questions for college officials to ask during events. For instance, in an email to the president of Greenville Technical College, the campaign suggested a question about making college affordable, which is one of Clinton's campaign issues.

The emails also suggest a meticulous planning approach that has sometimes pulled local officials uncomfortably into the political arena. Becky Mann, the head of public relations for South Carolina's Greenville Technical College, wrote in an email to the college's president that Clinton's campaign offered to write her introduction, but she declined.

The campaign's efforts to make Clinton appear less wooden and scripted than she did during her 2008 campaign have been countered by some of her worst answers, particularly in relation to her email scandal. The recently released State Department inspector general report, which found Clinton broke government rules with her personal email use, has increased the likelihood and pressure for the Justice Department to pursue criminal charges, according to an intelligence source familiar with the FBI investigation.

Meanwhile, some U.S. intelligence officials are concerned that Donald Trump's "shoot from the hip" style could pose national security risks as they prepare to give him a routine pre-election briefing once he is formally anointed as the Republican presidential nominee. Despite their worries, the officials said the "Top Secret" briefing to each candidate would not deviate from the usual format to avoid any appearance of bias.

Title: Romney Delivers Aggressive Speech Accusing Obama of Divisive Campaign Tactics

Article:

Mitt Romney, during a rally in Chillicothe, Ohio, delivered a fiery speech on Tuesday night, marking the most aggressive address of his presidential campaign. The Republican presidential candidate accused President Obama of running a "campaign of division and anger and hate," taking on what he termed an "outrageous charge" by Vice President Biden.

Romney's speech, which was personally written by him over two days, set the tone for the rest of the week as Romney plans to attend closed-camera fundraisers through Saturday while handing off the campaign to his new running mate, Paul Ryan.

In the address, Romney dismissed all euphemisms and claimed recent flare-ups on the campaign trail were signs of a president's campaign gone bitter. He pointed to Biden's claim Tuesday in Virginia that Romney and the Republicans intend to roll back Wall Street regulations and "put y'all back in chains." Romney's campaign called it a "new low," while Romney himself accused the president of being "intellectually exhausted" and out of ideas.

"His campaign and his surrogates have made wild and reckless accusations that disgrace the office of the presidency," Romney told a crowd of thousands at the final stop on his five-state bus tour. "Another outrageous charge came a few hours ago in Virginia. And the White House sinks a little bit lower. This is what an angry and desperate presidency looks like."

Romney also mocked Obama's statements during the 2008 campaign that without fresh ideas "you use stale tactics to scare voters." Romney accused Obama of now making that strategy "the heart of his campaign."

Obama campaign spokesman Ben LaBolt responded that Romney "seemed unhinged" during the campaign speech.

"Particularly strange coming at a time when he's pouring tens of millions of dollars into negative ads that are demonstrably false," he said.

Earlier, the Obama campaign defended Biden's comments, likening them to language used repeatedly by Republican officials.

"For months, Speaker Boehner, Congressman Ryan, and other Republicans have called for the 'unshackling' of the private sector from regulations that protect Americans from risky financial deals and other reckless behavior that crashed our economy," Stephanie Cutter, deputy campaign manager, said in a written statement. "We find the Romney campaign's outrage over the vice president's comments today hypocritical, particularly in light of their own candidate's stump speech questioning the president's patriotism."

Biden made the remarks during a stop in Danville, Va. He took a swipe at Romney's plan to ease financial regulations, by recycling a Romney bank analogy and creating an analogy of his own.

"He said in the first 100 days, he's going to let the big banks once again write their own rules," Biden said. "Unchain Wall Street! They're gon na put y'all back in chains."

The remark's context is unclear. Some conservative blogs claimed Biden had just made a reference to slavery. Danville, aside from being the last capital of the Confederacy, is racially split—the city is nearly half black and half white. The crowd at Tuesday's event reflected that makeup. The Romney campaign fired back without accusing Biden of any racial reference.

In his speech Tuesday evening, however, Romney accused Obama of seeking to divide America—whether by race, occupation, or party affiliation—as a campaign strategy.

"But he won't win that way. America is one nation under God. American history has been a story of the many becoming one—uniting to preserve liberty, uniting to build the greatest economy in the world, uniting to save the world from unspeakable darkness," he said. "So, Mr. President, take your campaign of division and anger and hate back to Chicago and let us get about rebuilding and reuniting America."

Romney championed himself as the savior of the middle class, ticking off areas where Obama and his policies have failed the American people.

"After four years, it's clear that President Obama's policies are not fixing these problems, they're making them worse," Romney said.

Title: France to Award Grants for U.S. Scientists to Relocate and Conduct Climate Research

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron is set to award all-expenses-paid grants for U.S. scientists to relocate to France as part of his response to U.S. President Donald Trump's climate policies. The grants are part of Macron's "Make Our Planet Great Again" competition, which he announced in June following Trump's decision to withdraw the U.S. from the Paris climate agreement.

In an address from the Elysée Palace, Macron, in response to Trump's announcement, urged scientists who were displeased with the move to "come to France and work with us together" on climate policy-related research. The competition will select around 50 projects out of a shortlist of 90 for the grants, which will be funded by the state.

While the majority of candidates who entered are from the U.S., the competition for research grants was expanded to include climate scientists from other countries outside of France. However, some French researchers have expressed dissatisfaction with the president's decision to fund foreign scientists at a time when funding for domestic projects is reportedly lacking.

Macron's attacks on Trump over the Paris agreement were met with praise from the French and international media. However, the Guardian reported that Macron's "tough stance" may have "backfired," and likely prompted the U.S. leader to remind people he "was elected to serve the citizens of Pittsburgh — not Paris."

Speaking in the Rose Garden after his announcement that the U.S. would be leaving the Paris climate agreement, President Trump said that the accord signed by the Obama administration in 2015 without the consent of Congress "disadvantages the United States to the exclusive benefit of other countries." Trump explained that the agreement would have left American taxpayers having to "absorb the cost in terms of lost jobs, lower wages, shuttered factories, and vastly diminished economic production."

Title: "Bernie Sanders: A Political Career Defying the Odds and the Establishment"

Article:

Senator Bernie Sanders, a 78-year-old independent from Vermont, is a front-runner in the Democratic race for the presidency. His political career, which spans nearly 40 years, has been marked by defying the odds and challenging the political establishment.

Sanders' political journey began in 1981 when he ran for mayor of Burlington, Vermont, against a Democratic machine that had controlled the city for decades. Despite facing formidable resistance, Sanders won by a margin of 10 votes. However, within Vermont's city council, 11 of 13 members opposed Sanders and actively conspired against his agenda.

Two years later, Sanders faced the same Democratic machine in his re-election bid but emerged victorious, this time with more than 20 percentage points. This early battle offered a taste of Sanders' career, which has been a nearly 40-year challenge to the political establishment.

Bouncing back from a bitter loss to former US First Lady and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in 2016, Sanders is running again for the top prize. This time around, he has faced a heart-attack and has raised over $100 million for his campaign.

Born in Brooklyn, New York, to Jewish parents, Sanders' humble upbringing in a tiny apartment made him class-conscious at an early age. He attended the University of Chicago and participated in anti-war and civil rights activism, including the 1963 March on Washington. He applied for conscientious objector status during the Vietnam War but was too old to be drafted by the time his application was rejected.

Sanders entered politics in 1971, running for a US Senate seat in Vermont as a Liberty Union candidate, a party with anti-war and socialist roots. He lost that race, as well as a couple of campaigns to become governor. His first major political success came when he was elected mayor of Burlington, Vermont, in 1980, beating a six-term incumbent. He went on to serve four terms.

During this time, he met and married his current wife, Jane O'Meara, the former president of Burlington College, once described as a "key adviser" in his political career. Combined, they have four children from previous relationships.

He was first elected to the US House of Representatives in 1990, the first independent to do so in 40 years. He served there until he ran for and won a seat in the Senate in 2007. During that campaign, a younger Barack Obama stumped for him.
