Since first arriving in Washington, Sanders has assailed Republican and Democratic politicians alike as being beholden to wealthy donors and industries. For this, he was sometimes dismissed as a gadfly. He is the longest-serving independent in congressional history.

In 2010, he famously stood and spoke for eight-and-a-half hours to attempt to block the extension of Bush-era tax policies that Sanders said benefited the rich and worsened the nation's income gap. He became the chairman of the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs in 2013 and helped negotiate bipartisan solutions when former soldiers complained of dangerously delayed and inadequate care around the country. He was a staunch opponent of the Iraq War.

Sanders is fond of praising the social policies of Nordic countries, like universal healthcare and paid leave for new parents. He wants to make college free and erase all student debt.

Sanders has been attacked for his voting record on gun control, including his opposition to various forms of the Brady Bill, which required background checks and waiting periods for gun purchasers. He says his record merely reflects the priorities of his Vermont constituents.

In 2016, during his last presidential run, Sanders jumped into the Democratic race as a long-shot candidate, squaring off against establishment favorite Hillary Clinton. But once again, Sanders confounded expectations: setting fundraising records and, for a time, casting doubt on the once-seemingly inevitable nomination of Mrs. Clinton.

Now, anti-establishment tone intact, Sanders is running on a characteristically progressive platform, featuring Medicare for all, a $15 minimum wage, and tuition-free public college. He is quick to note that many items on his agenda - once deemed radical - are now embraced by Democrats.

Still, some Democratic leaders remain sceptical that Sanders could win their party's nomination, a degree of doubt that seems to galvanize him. In October, his candidacy appeared in peril after Sanders suffered a minor heart attack and was forced to suspend his campaign. The episode reignited criticism that Sanders is too old to compete for the presidency. The Vermont senator - who will be 79 by election day - would be the oldest US president in history.

But within weeks, he was back, bolstered by an endorsement from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the party's liberal darling and youngest ever US congresswoman. Sanders is an unapologetic curmudgeon - he shrugged off a recent claim by Mrs. Clinton that nobody likes him, saying: "On a good day, my wife likes me." And few other candidates could get away with telling a voter's crying baby to "keep that down." But Sanders' supporters say it goes to show he is authentic.

He now draws crowds in the tens of thousands, as he makes the case that the 2020 election will be won because of his principle and policy, not in spite of it. And if the outsider candidate is able to clinch victory in Iowa, he may be poised to beat the odds once again.

Title: Texas Abortion Law Based on Fertilization May Face Constitutional Challenges

Article:

The state of Texas has become the 12th state to ban most abortions after 20 weeks, following a trend in state legislation this year. However, the definition of the 20-week limit may cause complications for women and their doctors, potentially affecting the constitutional validity of these laws.

Like most abortion bans passed in states so far, the Texas law starts its 20-week limit at fertilization. But this is not the same as 20 weeks of pregnancy, as doctors measure pregnancy from the date of the last normal menstrual period (LMP).

Dr. Daniel Grossman, an assistant professor of obstetrics, gynecology, and reproductive sciences at the University of California, San Francisco, and a vice president of IBIS Reproductive Health, explains, "For a woman who has a normal menstrual period, ovulation or fertilization would generally occur two weeks later, after the start of that normal menstrual period. The age of the embryo or the fetus is essentially two weeks less than the number of weeks measured from the last menstrual period."

Last menstrual period is generally how doctors refer to the weeks of pregnancy. Forty weeks LMP is considered full term for a normal pregnancy, even though at that point fertilization occurred only 38 weeks before. The use of a measurement that seems imprecise is due to the standard developing in the old days before ultrasound was widely used.

However, most state laws, as well as a bill that passed the U.S. House last month, are written with a beginning of pregnancy pegged to fertilization. Elizabeth Nash, who tracks state issues for the Guttmacher Institute, an abortion rights think tank, explains, "What we're seeing with these laws is that they are pegging the beginning of pregnancy to fertilization."

The reason people continue to refer to these laws as 20-week laws, despite the imprecision, is due to the term being used in the bill and often becoming the headline, according to Nash.

Regardless of whether the laws seek to ban abortion at 20 weeks or 22 weeks, one thing is clear, says Daniel Grossman. The ban they would impose is earlier than what's currently considered viability, or when a fetus can survive outside the womb.

"I think there's definitely consensus that viability doesn't happen before 24 menstrual weeks," Grossman says. "So when we're talking about banning abortion at 20 or 22 weeks even, that's clearly at least two weeks before the earliest point in pregnancy where viability would be a concern."

This is important because current Supreme Court precedent states that states cannot ban abortion before viability. Those pushing these laws, however, hope that by the time one of these laws makes its way to the justices, they might change their minds.

Similar doubts were raised about the constitutionality of an earlier ban that few thought would survive court scrutiny, according to Douglas Johnson of the National Right to Life Committee. "The Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act was struck down by every lower federal court that considered it," Johnson said last week at a press conference on the federal version of the 20-week ban. "Three U.S. District Courts; three U.S. Courts of Appeals all ruled it was in clear violation of U.S. Supreme Court precedent. But when it reached the U.S. Supreme Court, they said otherwise."

Whether you count to 20 or 22, the ultimate number that will matter most is five—the number of Supreme Court justices needed for a majority.

Title: Obama Surprises National Security Team, Seeks Congressional Approval for Syria Strike

Article:

President Barack Obama's decision to seek congressional approval for a military strike against Syria came unexpectedly, as none of his national security team were aware of the move, according to three senior administration officials.

During a National Security Council meeting last weekend, Obama hinted at his inclination towards taking action against Syria but had not made a final decision, the officials stated, requesting anonymity discussing internal deliberations. As Obama weighed his options, his advisers advised against seeking congressional authorization for a military strike, they said.

However, when Obama gathered his senior advisers Friday night to inform them of his decision to launch a targeted strike against the Bashar Assad regime, he also disclosed an unprecedented move: he would ask Congress to authorize it first.

Obama first broached this idea to his national security team on Friday night following a one-on-one conversation with White House Chief of Staff Denis McDonough. During Friday night's discussions and again on Saturday morning in the Situation Room, Obama explained his rationale to his aides, some of whom were opposed to seeking congressional approval, according to the unnamed officials.

"Many people have advised against taking this decision to Congress, and undoubtedly, they were impacted by what we saw happen in the United Kingdom this week when the Parliament of our closest ally failed to pass a resolution with a similar goal, even as the prime minister supported taking action," Obama told the nation on Saturday, the officials reported. "Yet, while I believe I have the authority to carry out this military action without specific congressional authorization, I know that the country will be stronger if we take this course, and our actions will be even more effective."

In the months leading up to Saturday's announcement, Obama had expressed his desire for broad support for any potential action against Syria—a reflection of his long-held view that the credibility of military action comes with numbers. However, Russia, Syria's most powerful patron, would block any United Nations Security Council resolution against Syria. After the British Parliament rejected Prime Minister David Cameron's call for military action last week, it became clear to Obama that a groundswell of international support was not forthcoming.

Notably, Obama contacted President Francois Hollande of France—the only major U.S. ally that has endorsed a military strike—before publicly announcing his decision to seek backing from Congress.

As Obama edged toward calling for a limited military strike against the Assad regime following Syrian forces' alleged killing of more than 1,400 in a chemical attack in a rebel stronghold outside of Damascus on Aug. 21, White House officials maintained their view that the president did not need to seek congressional approval.

However, aides said Obama, who, as a presidential candidate, criticized President George W. Bush's rush to war in Iraq, saw formal consultation with Congress as a central part of his desired legacy to take the United States off a permanent war footing. The president was further convinced that this was the best course of action after the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Martin Dempsey, told him a Syria operation was not time-sensitive, and there was no negative impact for waiting, the officials said.

Congress is set to return from its summer recess on Sept. 9 and is expected to debate and vote on an authorization that week. Obama would not rule out taking action immediately if Assad deploys chemical weapons before Congress is set to vote, the officials said.

The officials also emphasized that the president changed his own mind, and no congressional leaders directly asked him to seek authorization, even though about a third of rank-and-file House members have called for it. They declined to speculate what Obama would do if Congress does not approve use of force, while maintaining that Obama retains the authority to act alone.

Obama made clear in his remarks on Saturday that a "no" vote would send the wrong message to Assad and America's enemies. "Here's my question for every member of Congress and every member of the global community: What message will we send if a dictator can gas hundreds of children to death in plain sight and pay no price?" Obama said. "What's the purpose of the international system that we've built if a prohibition on the use of chemical weapons that has been agreed to by the governments of 98% of the world's people and approved overwhelmingly by the Congress of the United States is not enforced?"

Title: Partisan Divide Emerges Over Vote-by-Mail Expansion Ahead of November Election

Article:

The expansion of vote-by-mail options during the coronavirus pandemic has become a contentious issue in the lead-up to the November 3 U.S. election. President Donald Trump and his Republican allies have expressed concerns about vote-by-mail's vulnerability to fraud and its potential impact on their party's electoral prospects.

Democrats and voting rights groups argue that vote-by-mail is a necessary measure to protect voters from the virus and prevent disenfranchisement, particularly for vulnerable groups such as the poor and African Americans who tend to vote Democratic. The recent turbulent Wisconsin elections, which took place despite Republican efforts to block Democratic attempts to delay in-person voting and expand absentee balloting, highlight the partisan divide and the urgency to find a solution before the November election.

Republicans argue that vote-by-mail is more susceptible to fraud since voters do not have to appear in person at a polling place. President Trump has claimed, without evidence, that mail ballots are "cheaters" and "fraudulent in many cases." However, Trump himself cast an absentee ballot by mail in Florida's Republican primary last month.

Trump's opposition to vote-by-mail appears to be driven, in part, by concerns about higher voter turnout, which Democrats believe could disadvantage Republican candidates. Trump stated that a shift to easier voting would mean "you'd never have a Republican elected in this country again."

Trevor Potter, a Republican former chairman of the Federal Election Commission and founder of the Washington-based Campaign Legal Center, found Trump's reaction puzzling, as Republicans often perform well in mail-in balloting. Potter noted that older Americans, who are more likely to support President Trump and are thought to be most vulnerable to the virus, are more likely to vote by mail. Conservative Utah is one of five states that have gone all-mail voting with little sign of fraud.

Academic, government, and news investigations over the years have found little evidence of election fraud of any kind. Utah and four other states that vote entirely by mail - Hawaii, Oregon, Washington, and Colorado - have reported little fraud.

Election experts have noted scattered incidents of "ballot harvesting," in which people collect and manipulate absentee ballots. The most recent example came in a 2018 North Carolina congressional race, where an operative gathered ballots for the Republican candidate, leading to the race's outcome being overturned.

More than a dozen states have already postponed primaries or expanded vote-by-mail to avoid crowded polling places. Vote-by-mail was used by about one-quarter of all voters in the 2018 midterm elections, according to a report by the U.S. Election Assistance Commission. Along with the five states that vote entirely by mail, 28 states will allow voters to request a mail ballot without any excuse in November, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.

Senator Ron Wyden (D-OR), co-sponsor of a bill to expand vote-by-mail and early voting to all states, stated that the expansion is not a novelty but an upscaling of what is already taking place. There are still 17 states, such as Texas, New York, and Louisiana, that would need to change their policies to guarantee that everyone who wants to vote by mail in November can, according to the Brennan Center.

The cost of ensuring vote-by-mail is available for all voters could be up to $1.4 billion, with postage alone costing up to $600 million. Even advocates of vote-by-mail acknowledge that states should keep the option of in-person voting for voters with disabilities, those who need language access assistance, or those who do not have regular mail access.

Democratic and Republican-aligned groups are already engaged in legal battles over vote-by-mail expansion in federal and state courts. In New Mexico, county clerks have petitioned the state Supreme Court to conduct their June 2 primary almost entirely by mail and allow all voters to be mailed an absentee ballot. State Republicans have sued to oppose both changes. In Texas, the Democratic Party sued the state's Republican leadership in federal court to allow no-excuse absentee voting. In Georgia, the American Civil Liberties Union sued the Republican secretary of state for requiring voters to pay their own postage when submitting mail-in absentee ballots and applications, arguing that this amounts to a poll tax.

Title: Majority of Americans Disapprove of COVID-19 Protests, Support for Restrictions Dips

Article:

A new poll by The University of Chicago Divinity School and The ███-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research indicates that a majority of Americans disapprove of protests against restrictions aimed at preventing the spread of the coronavirus. The poll also shows a decrease in support for such measures, such as stay-at-home orders and restaurant closures, in recent weeks.

The survey finds that 55% of Americans disapprove of the protests that have occurred in some states, while 31% approve. In contrast, 8% said public protests, marches, and rallies should be unrestricted during the outbreak, 41% think they should be allowed only with restrictions, and 50% think they should not be allowed at all.

One notable example of protests against COVID-19 restrictions is the case of Shelley Luther, a Texas hair salon owner who was sentenced to seven days in jail for defying Republican Gov. Greg Abbott's emergency orders. She was released less than 48 hours later after Abbott removed jail as a punishment for defying virus safeguards.

In Michigan, thousands of people rallied outside the state capitol last month to protest Democratic Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's restrictions. Hundreds returned two weeks later, some of them armed, to demonstrate inside the statehouse.

The poll also reveals that 71% of Americans favor requiring people to stay in their homes except for essential errands, down slightly from 80% two weeks earlier. Similarly, 67% of Americans now say they favor requiring bars and restaurants to close, down from 76% in the earlier poll. The poll also suggests a dip in support for requiring Americans to limit gatherings to 10 people or fewer (from 82% to 75%) and requiring postponement of nonessential medical care (from 68% to 57%).

Mark Roberts, a retired transportation worker in Abingdon, Virginia, said he is going about his business despite Democratic Gov. Ralph Northam's stay-at-home order. Roberts said people in his southwestern Virginia community are driving the short distance into neighboring Bristol, Tennessee, to patronize restaurants open there.

The poll was conducted April 30-May 4 using a sample drawn from NORC's probability-based AmeriSpeak Panel, which is designed to be representative of the U.S. population. The margin of sampling error for all respondents is plus or minus 4.2 percentage points.

Title: Hillary Clinton Faces Challenges in Appealing to Women Voters

Article:

Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's statement, "There's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other," was intended to support Hillary Clinton but has raised concerns about Clinton's appeal to women voters. In an email, Clinton asked, "Are you with me?" However, the question may not resonate with young women, as Clinton has faced criticism and low support from this demographic in the Democratic primary race.

During a vox pop in Las Vegas, a location for the first Democratic debate, people expressed a unified dislike and distrust of Clinton. In the Iowa caucus, 84% of women under 30 voted for Bernie Sanders, while only 14% supported Clinton. The projection for New Hampshire shows an even more significant disparity, with 92% of young women under 30 planning to back Sanders, and only 11% supporting Clinton among women aged 30-39.

Historical events, such as the Lewinsky scandal, and Clinton's association with the Clinton family, have contributed to her negative image among some voters. Critics argue that Clinton should have left her husband, Bill, during the Lewinsky scandal, and that she is perceived as entitled, arrogant, elitist, and legally questionable.

Clinton's email arrangements during her tenure as Secretary of State, with all communications going through a private server, have also raised concerns and are the subject of an FBI investigation. This has reinforced the narrative of Clinton exceptionalism, with some people viewing the Clintons as taking unique shortcuts and operating in a manner that is not typical of other US citizens.

The Clinton campaign is grappling with the challenge of winning over young women, a demographic they may have initially considered as low-hanging fruit. Some speculate that this demographic is post-feminist, indifferent to the gender of their next leader, or yearning for change, which Sanders offers with his socialist platform.

Clinton's campaign strategy includes addressing public health issues, such as the water crisis in Flint, Michigan, to appeal to the African American constituency, which has traditionally supported the Clintons. However, controversial statements, such as Albright's comment about women not helping each other, may not be beneficial to Clinton's campaign.

In conclusion, Hillary Clinton is facing challenges in appealing to women voters, particularly young women, in the Democratic primary race. Criticism of Clinton's association with the Clinton family, her email arrangements, and her perceived elitist image have contributed to her low support among this demographic. The Clinton campaign is currently exploring strategies to address these issues and win over young women voters.

Title: Federal Budget Deficit Drops Below $500 Billion for First Time Since 2008

Article:

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) reported on Wednesday that the federal budget deficit for fiscal year 2014, which ended on September 30, totaled $486 billion. This marks the first time since President Obama took office that the deficit has fallen below $500 billion.

The deficit for 2014, as a percentage of the gross domestic product (GDP), was 2.8%, which is slightly below the average experienced over the past 40 years. This indicates that President Obama has surpassed his self-imposed goal of cutting the deficit in half from its peak of $1.4 trillion, or 9.8% of GDP, in 2009.

Taxes have increased significantly in the last two years, with government revenue crossing the $3 trillion mark for the first time in history in 2014. Spending, which had reached $3.6 trillion in 2011, decreased in 2012 and 2013, and rose only 1% or $44 billion in 2014.

New spending on Medicaid and Obamacare's subsidies for health insurance purchased on the exchanges increased by $49 billion, which was more than the overall increase. Social Security spending rose 5% or $37 billion, while the government's student loan subsidies boosted education spending.

On the other side of the ledger, the Defense Department withstood a 5% cut, totaling $30 billion, and unemployment benefit spending dropped as the jobless rate declined.

Spending began to decrease after Republicans took control of the House in 2011 and began to battle President Obama over his budget plans. A series of spending cuts, including the budget sequesters, helped keep spending in check.

On the revenue side, President Obama pushed through a tax hike for the wealthiest at the beginning of 2013, and the recovering economy has helped boost corporate income taxes by 17.5% over the last year.

The White House budget office did not respond to a request for comment, but outside budget analysts cautioned that the good news should be tempered by the dangers that still lurk ahead.

"While the deficit has indeed dropped significantly, this drop followed a massive increase, was largely expected, and does not suggest the country is on a sustainable fiscal path," the Committee for a Responsible Federal Deficit said in its analysis. "Currently, debt levels are at historic highs and projected to grow unsustainably over the long run."

CBO's projections from over the summer signal that $1 trillion deficits will return within a decade, and debt will also steadily grow. Driving that long-term debt is entitlement spending, particularly major programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.

Net interest on the debt will also rise quickly in future years as interest rates rise. However, for now, low rates continue to help keep the deficit down. The government paid $271 billion in interest costs in 2014, the CBO said. Final 2014 numbers will be released by the Treasury Department later this month.

Title: Media Outlets and Political Figures Respond to Allegations Against Alabama Senate Candidate Roy Moore

Article:

Following the Washington Post's report on Thursday that Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore allegedly molested a 14-year-old girl and dated three other underage girls, several Republican senators, including Vice-President Mike Pence, called for him to drop out of the race if the allegations are true. However, they did not specify what evidence would prove the events, which occurred decades ago, actually took place.

Moore, in response, denied the claims without addressing the specifics, stating that he is the victim of a campaign to "silence and shut up Christian conservatives like you and me." On Twitter, Moore wrote, "The forces of evil will lie, cheat, steal –– even inflict physical harm –– if they believe it will silence and shut up Christian conservatives like you and me."

Alabama state auditor Jim Ziegler echoed Moore's religious themes, noting that "Mary was a teenager and Joseph was an adult carpenter. They became parents of Jesus."

Steve Bannon, President Trump's former chief strategist, compared the allegations to the video of Trump bragging about sexual assault, painting both as orchestrated political attacks. Bannon stated, "The Bezos–Amazon–Washington Post that dropped that dime on Donald Trump, is the same Bezos–Amazon–Washington Post that dropped the dime this afternoon on Judge Roy Moore. Now is that a coincidence?"

Breitbart, the news outlet Bannon runs, began working to discredit the Washington Post report before it was even published. The article described the Post's forthcoming report, highlighted Moore's denial, and noted that the paper endorsed Moore's Democratic opponent, Doug Jones.

On Fox News, Tucker Carlson took a similar approach, dedicating only 46 seconds to the Moore allegations. Hannity, on the other hand, discussed Moore extensively, generating a controversy on his radio show when he appeared to call the candidate's alleged behavior with a 14-year-old "consensual." Hannity later apologized, stating he "misspoke and was not totally clear earlier today."

Hannity started his Fox News show by carefully and accurately laying out the allegations and Moore's response. However, the segment later highlighted the sexual-misconduct allegations against liberal Hollywood figures and Bill Clinton.

Later in the program, Fox News legal analyst Mercedes Colwin claimed that women frequently make false sexual-harassment allegations in an attempt to make money. "A lot of these women, it's all about money," Colwin said. "And they bank on the fact that these corporations have a reputation that they want to save."

In response to the allegations, some right-leaning sites, such as Hot Air, the Daily Caller, and the Blaze, only published brief, straightforward posts noting the Moore news. On Fox News, Tucker Carlson took a similar approach, dedicating only 46 seconds to the Moore allegations. Hannity, on the other hand, discussed Moore extensively.

Title: White House Denies 'Amnesty' Claims on Trump's Immigration Plan; Proposes Three-Year Legal Status for Certain Immigrants

Article:

The White House has refuted accusations from conservative groups that President Trump's new immigration plan, unveiled on Saturday, constitutes an "amnesty" for illegal immigrants. Vice President Mike Pence stated that the plan offers only a temporary solution and does not provide a pathway to citizenship.

In a press briefing at the White House, Mr. Pence, Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, and Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser and the president's son-in-law, presented the new deal as a compromise between hard-right and hard-left factions. The hard-right has opposed any legal status for illegal immigrants, while the hard-left has resisted any funding for border fencing and demands a full amnesty for "Dreamers" without additional conditions.

Mulvaney, a former House member, reportedly received positive feedback from Democratic colleagues in Congress, though he did not disclose their names. The plan aims to end the ongoing government shutdown and prevent a second missed paycheck for federal employees as the shutdown approaches a month in length.

The proposal includes $5.7 billion for border wall construction, as well as changes to expedite the deportation of illegal immigrant families and address abuses in the asylum system. In exchange, it offers hundreds of millions of dollars in new humanitarian aid for the safety and health of illegal immigrants, restores a program terminated in 2017 that allows Central American children to apply for U.S. asylum from their home countries, and provides a three-year legal status for approximately 700,000 individuals currently under the Obama-era DACA program, as well as around 300,000 individuals under humanitarian protections who may soon become illegal immigrants.

The deal also includes items both sides generally agree on, such as more technology for drug detection at legal border crossings and an increase in the number of immigration judges to reduce the backlog of cases. The Senate will vote on the plan next week, and the fate of the shutdown and workers' paychecks reportedly depends on the bill's outcome.

While Democrats have criticized the bill from the left, some of Mr. Trump's supporters on the right have expressed disapproval of the proposal's provision of legal status for illegal immigrants, including those under Temporary Protected Status. Activist Ann Coulter tweeted, "Trump proposes amnesty. We voted for Trump and got Jeb!" in reference to Jeb Bush, a 2016 GOP opponent of Mr. Trump who was a prominent advocate for legalizing illegal immigrants.

Vice President Pence clarified that the bill offers a three-year legal status, and he and Kushner indicated that if they can find agreement with Democrats on this issue, it could pave the way for broader negotiations on comprehensive immigration reforms. "If we can get through this, I think there is a way toward having a lot of next steps," said Mr. Kushner.

Title: North Charleston Police Chief Condemns Officer's Actions in Walter Scott Shooting

Article:

Following the release of a video showing the fatal shooting of Walter Scott, an unarmed African-American man, by former North Charleston police officer Michael Thomas Slager, the police department's chief, Ed Driggers, spoke out against the officer's actions. Unlike in similar cases in Ferguson, Missouri; Cleveland, Ohio; Staten Island, New York; and Los Angeles, California, Driggers did not defend Slager, who claimed that the shooting occurred during a physical altercation after a routine traffic stop for a busted taillight.

In the video, Slager can be seen shooting Scott multiple times as he runs away. However, Slager's account, as reported in the official incident report, was contradicted by the evidence. There is no evidence that Scott tried to use Slager's taser against him, and Slager's demeanor during the shooting suggests he was not in fear for his life.

Neither Driggers nor Mayor Keith Summey of North Charleston attempted to defend Slager, who is now facing charges for murder. Instead, they distanced Slager's behavior from that of the North Charleston police force as a whole. Driggers stated, "The one does not totally throw a blanket across the many." He and the mayor noted that the police department is composed of more than 340 officers, and the video did not represent the overall law enforcement system.

However, another officer, Clarence Habersham, who is African-American, was also present at the scene after Scott had fallen to the ground. Habersham's body language suggests he had witnessed similar incidents before, and he did not make a significant effort to save Scott's life. The circumstances surrounding the interactions between Slager, Habersham, and the third officer, who is Caucasian, are unclear.

In the past five years, police officers in South Carolina have used their guns against 209 individuals, and they were exonerated of wrongdoing every time. Walter Scott, a father, brother, cousin, and veteran, died after being shot multiple times with his back turned. If he remained conscious after being handcuffed, he spent his final moments alone and enchained.

Title: Kentucky Gubernatorial Race Amidst Collapse of Obamacare-Funded Health Co-op

Article:

The collapse of the Kentucky Health Cooperative, a nonprofit health plan established with federal loan dollars under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), is causing a political stir in the tight gubernatorial race in Kentucky. The co-op's demise, part of a national trend with more than a third of the 23 nonprofit health plans created under Obamacare with $2.4 billion in federal loan dollars having failed, is particularly significant in Kentucky due to its high enrollment during the first two years of operations and the upcoming gubernatorial election.

Republican challenger Matt Bevin has seized on the failure as a validation of his concerns about Obamacare, laying blame on his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Jack Conway. Conway, on the other hand, attributes the co-op's collapse to "market forces" and argues that Kentucky consumers still have more choices due to the health law, with seven insurers to choose from during the upcoming open-enrollment season, up from just three plans two years ago.

The nonprofit co-op program was designed as a compromise to appease those who were dissatisfied with the health care law's lack of a government insurance option. Critics argue that the program was undermined from the outset, with the original $6 billion funding being slashed by more than half and the plans being saddled with rules that prohibited them from using federal funds for marketing and restricted which customers they could target.

The collapse of the co-op is not the only health care issue with political relevance in the Kentucky governor's race. The vast majority of Kentuckians who have gained coverage under Obamacare are enrolled in public programs, with over 500,000 individuals added to the Medicaid and CHIP rolls since 2013. During the Republican primary, Bevin was unequivocal about wanting to roll back Obamacare's Medicaid expansion, a stance that has led Democrats to criticize him for potentially abandoning half a million low- and middle-income residents.

The political impact of health care issues in the election remains uncertain, with some political observers doubting their decisiveness due to voters' lack of knowledge about the details of the policy arguments. However, veteran GOP strategist Scott Jennings argues that the collapse of the co-op, combined with plan cancellations and average rate hikes, could sway voters due to their unease.

Title: Rep. Adam Schiff Compares Wuhan Coronavirus Casualties to 9/11 in Interview

Article:

During an appearance on MSNBC Monday night, Democratic Representative Adam Schiff argued that victims of the Wuhan coronavirus can be considered victims of the failed impeachment of President Donald Trump. Schiff stated, "We can't act even slightly surprised by this because you told us this was going to happen in your argument in the Senate impeachment trial."

Schiff continued, "We said a lot, but little did we know just how great the casualties would be. Some days we lose the equivalent of the number of people we lost on 9/11."

Fox News' Sean Hannity previously reminded viewers in March that perhaps if Democrats had been less focused on the impeachment and more attentive to actual threats, more could have been done to protect and warn Americans about the coronavirus. Hannity stated, "January 21, the very first person with coronavirus arrived in the U.S. from China. That's not long ago. The same time, Democrats, what were they doing? They were in the throes of an all-consuming, what has been the culmination of a three-year quest to impeach and throw Donald Trump out of office, undo an election that they never accepted the results of in the beginning."

Hannity further noted, "January 23, House impeachment managers, what were they doing? Oh, they were doing their opening arguments and impeachment. Same day, China completely sealed off the entire province of Wuhan. Then on January 31, look at this. The president then declared that national health emergency, ordered mandatory two-week quarantines. He issued the travel ban on all travel to and from China. And on that same day, what were the Democrats doing? They were busy with impeaching the president. They were not caring. January 31, Senate Democrats desperately pushing for more impeachment witnesses, the day that Donald Trump put the travel ban quarantine in effect."

According to the World Health Organization, the global death toll from the coronavirus surpassed 200,000 as of May 5, 2020. The reason for the pandemic is attributed to China's initial lies about the virus and suppression of physician whistleblowers who tried to speak out.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Calls on Biden and Sanders to Urge DNC for Debate Participation

Article:

Representative Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) has called on former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) to urge the Democratic National Committee (DNC) to allow her participation in the next primary debate. The call comes after the DNC announced new qualifications for the event that barred Gabbard from participating.

Gabbard, who has refused to drop her long-shot White House bid despite dismal results in the first several nominating states, has garnered just two of the 1,385 delegates awarded thus far, falling way below the threshold set by the DNC. The new qualifications require candidates to have at least 20 percent of the delegates awarded thus far to make the debate stage in Phoenix on March 15.

Six states will hold primaries and caucuses on Tuesday, though it is virtually impossible that Gabbard will net enough delegates from the contests to hit the 20 percent mark.

Gabbard has repeatedly railed against the DNC, accusing it at times of seeking to kneecap her campaign. She specifically cited a rule change last month regarding the polling qualifications for debates that allowed former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg to appear onstage twice before he dropped out of the race.

"To keep me off the stage, the DNC again arbitrarily changed the debate qualifications," she tweeted. "Previously they changed the qualifications in the OPPOSITE direction so Bloomberg could debate. I ask that you stand w/ me against the DNC’s transparent effort to exclude me from the debates."

The Hawaii lawmaker, an Iraq War veteran, has centered her long-shot White House bid around reducing America’s military entanglements abroad, but she has faced criticism over a 2017 meeting with Syrian President Bashar Assad and her past positions opposed to LGBTQ rights.

Title: Wall Street Braces for Tariffs as Gary Cohn Departs White House

Article:

The Dow Jones Industrial Average experienced a decline of up to 349 points on Wednesday, but recovered most of its losses, closing with a decrease of 82 points. This market volatility, according to Quincy Krosby, chief market strategist at Prudential Financial, reflects a "jittery market."

The market's unease stems from the White House's plan to impose a 25% tariff on imported steel and a 10% tariff on aluminum. Gary Cohn, Trump's top economic adviser who opposed these tariffs, has recently left the White House. Press Secretary Sarah Sanders stated on Wednesday that the president is expected to sign the tariff plan by the end of the week, with potential "carve-outs" for Canada and Mexico.

Wall Street is concerned that these tariffs could initiate a trade war, potentially damaging the economy. Trump's tariff announcement last week caused significant market turbulence and backlash from top US trading partners, including Canada and the European Union.

Brad McMillan, chief investment officer for Commonwealth Financial Network, stated, "Tariffs will hurt business and investor confidence, which are two of the pillars holding up the markets."

In addition to the looming tariff implications, negotiations over the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) also remain unresolved. Trump has threatened to terminate the 1994 trade agreement between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. The three countries have made little progress on a re-negotiated deal since beginning talks in August.

Ryan Detrick, senior market strategist for LPL Financial, commented, "The market is holding its breath and getting ready for a clearer picture."

US companies with less investment overseas are currently benefiting from the trade uncertainty. The Russell 2000 index, which tracks small companies, closed up for the fifth consecutive day.

However, the market has also grappled with the implications of Cohn's departure. Cohn, a former president of Goldman Sachs, played a significant role in designing Trump's tax cuts and was a leading proponent of free trade. He served as a calming influence on the market.

Alec Young, FTSE Russell's managing director of global markets research, stated, "His departure has caught investors off guard." McMillan described Cohn as "the voice of economic stability and a spokesperson for financial markets."

Cohn's resignation has left the president with a group of economic advisers perceived as less aligned with Wall Street interests. Investors view Trump's choice for Cohn's replacement as a potential indicator of the president's future trade moves. Detrick commented, "They want to see Cohn 2.0."

Title: Islamic State Threat to U.S. Homeland: Fact vs. Perception

Article:

The Islamic State, also known as ISIS, has been a topic of debate in the mainstream media regarding its threat to the United States. Some commentators argue that ISIS poses a threat to the U.S., while others contend that it does not pose an imminent threat.

In an interview with The Huffington Post, The Atlantic's Jeffrey Goldberg stated, "Yes, I understand ISIS poses a threat to the United States. It's not clear it poses an imminent threat." New York Times columnist Tom Friedman wrote, "ISIS is awful, but it is not a threat to America's homeland."

President Obama has also expressed similar sentiments, stating that the perception of an ISIS threat is due to social media and not a change in the threat level. The New York Times asserted that the actual danger posed by ISIS has been distorted in media coverage and political statements.

However, the facts on the ground tell a different story. On June 21, 19-year-old Brendan Tevlin was murdered in cold blood by a man who claimed it was an act of retribution for U.S. military action against Muslims in the Middle East. The murderer, Ali Muhammad Brown, has also confessed to killing four other men in the same manner.

In addition, the largest police operation in Australian history was implemented last week in Sydney and Brisbane, where counterterrorism forces detained 15 people after receiving intelligence that ISIS was planning public beheadings in two Australian cities. The plan involved kidnapping randomly selected members of the public, beheading them on camera, and releasing the recordings through ISIS's propaganda arm in the Middle East.

The Islamic State does not need to be physically present in the United States, Canada, or Australia to be a threat. The terrorist group's continued success in the Middle East and its propaganda inspires sociopaths around the world to carry out attacks.

The New York Police Commissioner Bill Bratton has warned that the Islamic State is targeting New York City, calling for "lone wolf" attacks on Times Square. ISIS is also reportedly calling for radicalized individuals in the United States to target military personnel in their homes.

The reality of the ISIS threat is all too real for the family of Brendan Tevlin, and the Australians have taken action to save lives on their soil by understanding the reality of the ISIS threat. As long as ISIS survives, it will continue to inspire disturbed individuals to carry out attacks, and pretending otherwise will only lead to more deaths.

Title: Pope Francis Navigates Political Divides with Subtlety and Humility During U.S. and Cuba Visits

Article:

Pope Francis, during his recent visits to the United States and Cuba, has demonstrated a quiet and deferential moral authority in navigating bitter political divides. This moral authority is rooted in personal gestures and a humble lifestyle, as well as the historic teachings of the Catholic Church.

Terrence Tilley, professor of Catholic theology at Fordham University in New York, describes Francis' political instincts as "a kind of style that keeps him involved with the people, without regard to all the trappings of his office."

Upon his arrival in the United States, Francis addressed two of the country's most contentious political issues: immigration and climate change. He praised President Obama for his proposals to combat air pollution and expressed his support for immigrants, stating, "As the son of an immigrant family, I am happy to be a guest in this country, which was largely built by such families."

In the spirit of Jesus' words, Francis has also wielded his papal power with subtlety and shrewdness. For instance, he made an unplanned stop at the convent of the Little Sisters of the Poor, showing support for the nuns suing the president over the birth control provision of Obamacare.

During his visit to Cuba, Francis navigated his moral authority with a series of subtle gestures. Although some criticized him for not meeting with dissidents or forcefully speaking out for greater human rights, others saw the pope sending clear messages through his homilies and the places he chose to visit.

In Havana's Revolution Square, Francis told a crowd, "Service is never ideological, for we do not serve ideas, we serve people." He later visited a group of students at the Felix Varela Institute, named for a 19th-century advocate for Cuban independence. Francis' visit served to bolster the slow-moving economic reforms in the communist country.

In his address before a joint session of Congress, Francis invoked symbols of American heritage, urging divided lawmakers to "defend and preserve the dignity of your fellow citizens in the tireless and demanding pursuit of the common good."

Throughout his visits, Francis remained circumspect, clothing his forays into politics as gentle moral exhortations. He did not enter the divisive politics of abortion but pivoted instead to the need to end the death penalty.

In his final days in the United States, Francis will visit Our Lady Queen of Angels School in East Harlem and the Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility in Philadelphia.

John Sniegocki, professor of theology at Xavier University in Cincinnati, Ohio, notes that Francis has been more attentive to the symbolism of the papacy. "A simple lifestyle, a simple papacy resonates with people and gives more impact to his broader words and broader critiques of global systems," Sniegocki says.

Title: Trump Meets with Media Executives, Culture War Brews Amidst Transition

Article:

In a move that may not come as a surprise, President-elect Donald Trump has met with several network executives and anchors at Trump Tower, following a campaign where he frequently criticized their organizations as dishonest and corrupt. The meeting, described as "tough" by Variety, reportedly saw Trump reserving particularly harsh words for CNN and NBC News.

According to reports, the meeting was relatively pleasant, with Trump expressing his displeasure with certain aspects of the coverage. He reminded his guests of their misjudgments during the election, such as underestimating his ability to win states like Michigan, where he campaigned in the final days.

The New York Post offers a more dramatic account, stating that Trump told CNN President Jeff Zucker, who worked with him on "The Apprentice," "I hate your network, everyone at CNN is a liar, and you should be ashamed." However, Kellyanne Conway, counselor to the president-elect, described the meeting as "very cordial, very productive, very congenial." She added, "It was also very candid and very honest. From my own perspective, it's great to hit the reset button."

The meeting reportedly provided an opportunity for network executives to express their concerns about media access, news conferences, and press pools. Trump is set to meet today with executives from The New York Times and other outlets, which he has labeled as "failing."

As the 45th president, Trump's relationship with the mainstream media is expected to be challenging, given the adversarial nature of their relationship during the campaign. However, it is hoped that they can find a way to work together, considering Trump's popularity among cable networks during the primaries and his understanding of what makes good television.

Meanwhile, a culture war seems to be brewing against Donald Trump. Less than two weeks after his election, his vice president received a stern lecture from the cast of the musical "Hamilton." At the American Music Awards, model Gigi Hadid mocked Melania Trump's accent and demeanor. These incidents are seen as a finger in the eye of the 60 million Americans who voted for Trump, who felt marginalized by the political, media, and cultural elites.

While the president-elect's policies and appointments are fair game for criticism, some argue that the hostility towards Trump, particularly from entertainers and cultural figures, is unwarranted and disrespectful to the democratic process. The political arena has also seen hostility, with former Attorney General Eric Holder questioning media figures' willingness to "normalize" Trump at a funeral for PBS anchor Gwen Ifill. Unlike his former boss, Barack Obama, Holder has not wished the new president well.

In a hopeful sign, the new ombudsman at The New York Times, Liz Spayd, has acknowledged reader dissatisfaction with the newspaper's coverage of the election. Spayd's conversations with readers have revealed a "searing level of dissatisfaction" with the paper's forecasting methods, its attempt to understand Trump supporters, and its perceived liberal bias. While partly faulting the candidates, Spayd acknowledges the media's role in turning Trump's remarks into a "grim caricature" that was applied to his supporters.

Title: Facebook Discovers Potential Coordinated Inauthentic Behavior Linked to Internet Research Agency Ahead of U.S. Midterm Elections

Article:

Facebook has identified and removed 32 pages and accounts from its platform that exhibited coordinated inauthentic behavior, potentially linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA), a Russian-based organization with ties to the Kremlin. The accounts, which had a combined total of 290,000 followers, were pushing American political stances, organizing events, and using virtual private networks (VPNs) to conceal their locations and internet phone services to hide their identities.

In October 2017, Facebook admitted that Russia-backed content reached as many as 126 million Americans during the 2016 presidential election. The accounts sometimes used Russian IP addresses and paid for advertising in roubles. The people behind the accounts removed on Tuesday used these tactics to evade detection, spending approximately $11,000 on about 150 ads on Facebook and Instagram.

Nathaniel Gleicher, Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy, stated that while there is not enough technical evidence to definitively attribute the activity to the IRA, they have shown similar activity and have connected with known IRA accounts. Alex Stamos, the company's chief security officer, noted that it is unclear whether this was the IRA with improved capabilities or a separate group.

One interesting finding is that a known IRA account was a co-admin on one of the pages for seven minutes before the account was removed from Facebook. However, Facebook's security team cautions that this is not definitive evidence of IRA involvement.

Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat, quickly attributed the activity to Russia, stating, "Today's disclosure is further evidence that the Kremlin continues to exploit platforms like Facebook to sow division and spread disinformation."

The removed pages included "Aztlan Warriors," "Resisters," and "Black Elevation." The "Resisters" page created a Facebook event for a protest on 10-12 August titled "No Unite The Right 2." Admins for the page connected with the admins of five legitimate pages to promote the event and post logistical information for protesters. About 600 users said they would attend the event, and 2,600 expressed an interest in attending.

Facebook disabled the event and reached out to the legitimate admins of the five other pages. The company also pledged to inform the people considering attending the protest about what happened.

There was also coordinated activity around the #AbolishICE campaign, a left-wing movement aimed at shutting down the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency. The activity appears to echo the Kremlin's creation and promotion of black activism pages such as "Blacktivist" in the run-up to the presidential election.

Facebook revealed that the bad actors had created 30 Facebook events since May 2017, most of which had been scheduled over the past year. The company said it did not know if people had shown up to those events.

Facebook will continue to investigate the activity and share any further findings with law enforcement and Congress. Mark Zuckerberg, the company's CEO, acknowledged the ongoing challenge of security, stating, "Security isn't a problem you ever completely solve. We face sophisticated and well-funded adversaries that are always evolving and trying new attacks."

Lukasz Olejnik, a cybersecurity researcher, expressed concern about artificially inducing civil unrest or protests via internet platforms, noting that the activity touching Washington indicates that concerns about European parliament 2019 elections might now be viewed in a "rather intriguing light."

Title: Employers Shift Toward Part-Time Work Amid Affordable Care Act Concerns

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, is reportedly causing employers to consider reducing full-time employees' hours to avoid additional costs associated with the law. The Act requires mid-sized and large employers to offer health insurance to all full-time employees, defined as those working 30 hours a week or more.

Big labor unions, initially supporters of the new law, are now expressing concerns about the potential impact of premium hikes on businesses, leading to a reduction in employees' working hours. This could affect millions of families across the United States, according to analysts. However, the White House has stated that there is no evidence of an adverse impact on job growth or the number of hours employees are working.

Jason Furman, chairman of Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, said, "We are seeing no systematic evidence that the Affordable Care Act is having an adverse impact on job growth or the number of hours employees are working."

However, United Food and Commercial Workers Union President Joseph Hansen argues that the impact is already being felt, stating, "Wait a year. You'll see tremendous impact as workers have their hours reduced and their incomes reduced."

Christopher Conover, an American Enterprise Institute researcher, argues that the trend toward part-time employment is accelerating due to ObamaCare. In an analysis, he wrote, "ObamaCare is accelerating a disturbing trend towards a nation of part-timers."

Three key groups that could be significantly affected are unions, school workers, and local government workers. In states such as Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and Indiana, school workers, including teacher aides, bus drivers, and cafeteria workers, are expected to lose hours. In California, Texas, and Michigan, government workers, including parks and recreation officials, librarians, and secretaries, could also have their hours and benefits reduced.

Fast-food CEOs at Subway and Papa John's have already reported feeling the impact of the health care overhaul. Papa John's CEO, John Schnatter, estimates the change will cost his company $5 million to $8 million annually. He expects franchise owners to cut employees' hours due to the costs of health insurance plans.

In an interview, Schnatter stated, "That's probably what's going to happen. It's common sense. That's what I call lose-lose."

An informal survey by NBC News found that approximately 20 businesses are cutting workers to 29 hours a week due to the health care law. However, not everyone agrees with the critics' claims. A recent Bloomberg analysis argues that the method used by researcher Christopher Conover is shaky, and the data used is "far too volatile to draw reliable conclusions from small samples."

Evan Soltas wrote, "I think the 30-hour rule in ObamaCare is bad public policy that will eventually hurt full-time work, as do Conover and Graham. In fact, I'd like to get rid of the employer mandate entirely. But I also believe in thorough, objective use of data. And they show no evidence of a part-time surge yet."

Title: President-elect Trump Praises Electoral College System, Vows to Continue Rallies

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump, during his final "Thank You" tour stop at Ladd-Peebles Stadium in Mobile, Alabama, praised the Electoral College system for requiring candidates to campaign across the country. Trump won 306 electoral votes in the November 8 election, with electors set to officially cast their votes on Monday.

Trump told supporters that the Founding Fathers were "genius" for creating a system that required candidates to canvass the nation to talk directly to voters. He stated that he visited 17 states in the last month of the campaign.

"That is the beauty of this electoral system," he said. "If you go with the popular vote, I'd go to New York State, California, back and forth. It would be much easier. The problem is that every other place—you stop in Florida, you stop in Texas—you wouldn't see anyplace else."

Trump pledged to continue holding rallies after moving into the White House. "This is the last time I'll be speaking at a rally for maybe a while," he said. "They are saying that as president, he should not be doing rallies."

Trump's choice for attorney general, Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions, spoke at the rally, stating that the first rally in Mobile was when "people began to see this was more than a normal campaign, but a movement."

Campaign manager Kellyanne Conway, now a senior adviser to the transition team, noted that Trump won more than 2,600 counties, including 200 that flipped from President Barack Obama in 2012, as well as 31 of the nation's 50 states.

Trump also commented on the popular vote, stating that he would have won the popular vote if that had been the method needed to get to the presidency. He also addressed comments made by Michelle Obama in an interview with Oprah Winfrey, stating that she had said "there is no hope" as his administration takes power. Trump responded by stating that he believes there is tremendous hope.

The overall mood at Ladd-Peebles Stadium was celebratory, with Trump basking in his election-night victory and introducing his cabinet nominees. Sessions spoke for slightly under five minutes, longer than the other cabinet nominees Trump presented at his rallies. The event closed with Trump's admonition: "Never, ever give up. I should have given up in this campaign five times. I could take you over 10 different things that happened where people would have given up. But I never gave up."

Title: Presidential Candidates Criticize Corporations for Taxes and Wages, with Amazon, Facebook, McDonald's, and Walmart as Top Targets

Article:

Presidential candidates are receiving the most online engagement when they target corporations for paying little or no taxes, according to data from High Lantern Group, an analytics firm specializing in corporate reputation. The companies are facing increased pressure to comply with the Democratic candidates' visions for the future, which include offering employees a living wage, paying more in taxes, and allowing workers to unionize.

Trump's complaints tend to focus on technology, communication, and social media companies. At times, the president elevates conservative allegations that their messages are being repressed or censored. At other times, Trump voices concerns that companies whose empires include credible, mainstream news organizations are peddling "fake news."

In the broader context, candidates have criticized corporations before, but those facing attacks today differ from those targeted in 2016, when Wall Street was the primary target. No banks crack the Top 10 of companies facing criticism on Twitter from the 2020 field of presidential hopefuls. Amazon, Facebook, McDonald's, and Walmart have been called out the most.

Presidential candidates have spent months taking shots at big companies on the campaign trail, and this trend has been observed since last summer. Several 2020 Democrats marched with McDonald's workers during their strike against sexual harassment in the workplace and low wages.

Matt Levy, director of issue analysis at HLG, stated, "We've noticed that companies really pay attention when they or their competitors are called out by huge players."

Unlike many other companies, Amazon has responded to candidates who have called them out and threatened to break up Big Tech if they become president. In a statement to ███, Walmart urged candidates to engage with the company to learn more about its practices and initiatives before "recycling critiques that haven't been relevant for years." The company added, "From our investments in wages and training to our work on environmental sustainability, some candidates have a lot to learn about who we are today."

An interesting finding is that, beyond Sanders and Warren, Trump is the next most-likely 2020 candidate to publicly criticize companies on Twitter. Twitter itself is among the top companies called out by candidates, ranking No. 8. Trump's lines of attack are not usually about a living wage or workplace safety.

Title: Trump Promises Mass Deportations, Challenges Union Stance on Immigration

Article:

In a hardline speech in Phoenix on Wednesday, former President Donald Trump outlined a plan for increased immigration enforcement, warning of an undocumented criminal threat and promising mass deportations beginning on his first day in office.

"We will begin moving them out Day One. As soon as I take office," Trump said, according to transcripts. He tied his promise to carry out deportations to anti-globalist economic ideas, but also drew a direct line between the fortunes of the country's native-born laborers and the presence of undocumented immigrants – a connection he has rarely made in his remarks on the topic.

"While there are many illegal immigrants in our country who are good people, this does not change the fact that most illegal immigrants are lower-skilled workers with less education, who compete directly against vulnerable American workers," Trump said. "These illegal workers draw much more out from the system than they can ever possibly pay back."

Trump's stance on immigration has been a contentious issue, with some arguing that his policies would harm the economy and others supporting his efforts to enforce immigration laws. The globalization that Trump denounces has also contributed to a decades-long reshaping of unions – a traditional voice for workers and often vocal opponents of globalization – toward greater inclusion of immigrants, even those without legal status.

According to Lowell Turner, a professor at Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, the reasons behind organized labor's shifting stance on immigrant workers may undercut Trump's narrative of foreigners arriving to America to crowd out the native-born.

"If you have a union job, you know that immigrants are not stealing your jobs," Turner said in an interview with The ███. "You see your reality around you and know that's not happening."

During the 2016 election, Trump saw greater support among union members than any Republican candidate in recent memory, enough to spook Democrats and union leaders. However, he has garnered endorsements from only two unions – those representing border patrol and New England police – and his low approval among Hispanics and other minorities has likely helped ensure that the vast majority of union endorsements have chosen to remain firmly in the Democrats' camp.

One of those Hillary Clinton supporters is Richard Trumka, president of the AFL-CIO, who was the guest at a Monitor Breakfast earlier this week. Trumka expressed confidence in organized labor's ability to turn out votes for Clinton, despite Trump's inroads into the white working class.

"We're probably about where we were with Barack Obama at this point with the election," Trumka said, adding that the more organized labor gets information out to workers, "the better off we get."

For much of their early history in the United States, unions viewed certain groups of immigrants with suspicion, if not outright animus. The Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, passed largely at the behest of the organized labor, is perhaps the most notorious example of this. The fear of job replacement faded after the passage of a 1924 national-origins quota, as immigration levels fell for several decades.

When national reform came up for passage again in 1986, unions' focus was on winning sanctions against employers that hired the undocumented, whom they saw as potential strikebreakers. But by then, changes in unions' attitudes were already beginning. Deregulation measures had sent membership numbers reeling, and in urban areas like Los Angeles, deteriorated wages, benefits, and working conditions caused many native-born workers to abandon certain lines of low-skilled manual jobs.

When they left, immigrants stepped in to take their place, mostly from Central America and Mexico. Union leaders in favor of organizing immigrants thought they were likely to be too nervous for collective action, but campaigns like the Service Employees International Union's Janitors for Justice, first conceived in 1985, won important victories from employers and showed unions that immigrants, including the undocumented, were capable of loud advocacy.

As those efforts were replicated across labor, especially in meatpacking, hospitality, restaurants, and other service industries, immigrants and native-born Hispanics began to exercise growing clout within the ranks. In 2000, the AFL-CIO, the largest union confederation in the country, called for an end to employer sanctions and for legal status for 6 million undocumented immigrants. The move came largely as a result of pressure from an immigrant-led coalition known as the Change to Win Federation, and it caused a sea change in thought.

"I think there was a shift in consciousness," says Mae Ngai, a historian at Columbia University who specializes in immigration and labor. "Even if some of these older unions like the Machinists were not organizing immigrants, they could see other people doing it. They could see that immigrants were not their enemy, not their competition, not their enemy they had to fear."

Title: Obama Shores Up Chances in Final Debate, Race Remains Too Close to Call

Article:

In the final presidential debate on Monday, President Barack Obama shored up his chances in the upcoming election, according to political analyst David Gergen. However, Mitt Romney also passed a test in the debates and remains a formidable opponent.

Gergen, a political adviser to several U.S. presidents, stated that Obama's clear victories in the final two debates have strengthened his campaign, making him an odds-on favorite to win. However, he also noted that Romney has accomplished a great deal in the debates and is poised for a possible surprise.

Obama's performance in the final debates allowed him to reassert himself and restore the faith and energy of his supporters, particularly on key issues such as healthcare and foreign policy. He also appealed to minority, women, and youth voters, key constituencies he will need to win the election.

Romney, on the other hand, was able to avoid a warmonger label and pass the commander-in-chief test, according to Gergen. However, he was criticized for appearing tired and less effective in the final debate compared to his performance in the first debate.

The race remains too close to call, with Gergen putting the chances at about 53% for Obama and 47% for Romney. The outcome will depend on how the polls settle out in the coming days.

Obama's campaign also has a strong ground game, with a superior field organization in key battleground states such as Ohio. The Romney team, however, is not ready to concede an inch and continues to gain support from some voters, particularly on economic issues.

The debates have transformed the campaign into a horse race, and the final two debates have been particularly significant in shaping the narrative of the election. The online prediction market Intrade showed that the odds in favor of Obama moved up only a point, to 61%, after the final debate, and have since dropped to 59%.

The race to the finish is expected to be a wild ride, with both candidates fighting hard to win over undecided voters and solidify their bases. The election will take place on November 6, 2012.

Title: Gun Range Operator Near Dallas Shooting Suspect's Home Expresses Disbelief, Questions Motivation

Article:

Mesquite, Texas — Vickie Kale, a certified firearms instructor who runs Gibson's Outpost & Shooting Range, expressed disbelief and confusion as gunshots echoed around her facility, barely a mile from where police say Micah Xavier Johnson lived before his attack on Dallas police Thursday night, which resulted in the deaths of five officers. Johnson, the shooting suspect, is believed to have practiced at a different location, as no one at the range recognizes him or remembers him.

Dallas police have not yet disclosed details about the type of rifle Johnson used, the number of rounds he fired, or where he may have practiced before the attack. WFAA-TV reported on Saturday that authorities believe Johnson had planned a larger attack, based on the ammunition he was carrying and his access to explosives.

At the range, regular customers fired various firearms, including a.45-caliber 1911 handgun and rifles. Some of the gun owners, who preferred to remain anonymous, expressed concern about speaking to reporters, fearing it could bring trouble to their homes or make them a target of a government they are skeptical or afraid of.

In Texas, open carrying of rifles is legal, and many firearms owners argue that the media focuses too much on whether someone has a gun, rather than on the people who use them improperly. They question the lack of individual accountability and the absence of family values that teach respect for authority and deference to police officers.

Gun owners at the range view their firearms as tools or objects of beauty, but Johnson abused them when he opened fire on the police officers working the protest, according to the unquoted range operators. Kale stated, "Our government has pushed this situation to the point where police officers aren't respected."

Johnson reportedly learned to shoot during his six years in the U.S. Army Reserve and served one tour of duty in Afghanistan beginning in late 2013. He was a private first class with a specialty in carpentry and masonry but did not appear to have specialized training as a sniper.

Dallas police have not yet released a complete timeline of how they believe Johnson moved around the area during the shootings. Johnson was killed Thursday night by police using a pound of C-4 explosive delivered by a remote-controlled robot. During the standoff with police, Johnson told negotiators that he was upset over recent police-involved shootings of blacks and wanted to kill white people, especially white police officers.

Authorities who searched Johnson's home in Mesquite found a personal journal of combat tactics, as well as bomb-making materials, ballistic vests, rifles, and ammunition. Mesquite is about a 20-minute drive east of downtown Dallas, and the drive takes visitors past multiple firearms stores tucked near nail salons and doughnut shops. Few of the gun dealers wanted to discuss the incident, but at least one store made it clear that President Obama would not be welcome inside its aisles selling noise-suppressors and cases of ammunition.

Gun-control advocates have used Johnson's attack to rally support in favor of stricter laws, including against open carrying of firearms, which is legal in Texas. Back at the range near Johnson's house, Kale said she and her friends always remark that their guns never clean the kitchen or take out the trash, but somehow get blamed for killing other people, even though they've never fired a shot in anger.

"It's not the gun. It's not the car. It's the people driving, the person firing," she said. "Why don't we talk about that?"

Title: Supreme Court to Address Workplace Discrimination Based on Sexual Orientation

Article:

The Supreme Court's new term has commenced with significant oral arguments on Tuesday in two cases that highlight contrasting interpretations of how statutes should be construed. The cases revolve around the question of whether workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation is prohibited by the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which outlaws discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.

In the case of Kimberly Hively, a part-time adjunct professor at an Indiana community college, she claims she was denied a full-time position and her part-time contract was not renewed due to her being a lesbian. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in a majority decision, questioned whether actions taken on the basis of sexual orientation are a "subset of actions taken on the basis of sex."

The Seventh Circuit majority, citing the broader context of the statute, acknowledged but disregarded the fact that Congress has declined to add "sexual orientation" to the Act. The majority argued that it is unclear what inference to draw from congressional inaction and that the meaning of the phrase "sex discrimination" has evolved over time.

A concurring judge argued that the meaning of the statute has changed, and the word "sex" now connotes both gender and sexual orientation. The judge stated that homosexuality was not a significant factor in the minds of the legislators in 1964, and since then, attitudes towards sex have broadened.

The minority, however, argued that the Supreme Court should give effect to the enacted text, interpreting the statutory language as a reasonable person would have understood it at the time of enactment. The minority stated that "sexual orientation" is not the same forbidden category of employment discrimination as "sex" is, and that the terms are not used interchangeably in other laws such as the Violence Against Women Act and the Hate Crimes Act.

The Seventh Circuit's minority also acknowledged the significant cultural change since 1964 but emphasized that the Supreme Court's role is to interpret the law, not to update it. The minority concluded that if Hively was denied a job because of her sexual orientation, she was treated unjustly, but not illegally under the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

The Supreme Court's decision in these cases will likely influence the interpretation of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and may prompt Congress to reconsider the inclusion of sexual orientation as a protected category.

Title: Presidential Daily Briefing on Afghanistan-Taliban Allegations Discussed on Fox & Friends

Article:

On June 30, 2020, during the Fox & Friends program on Fox News, a discussion ensued regarding allegations of foreign support for the Taliban in Afghanistan.

Brian Kilmeade, a co-host, stated, "We cannot pull totally out of Afghanistan. We will turn over the country to Russia, and the minerals to China. That will be a huge mistake." Ainsley Earhardt, another co-host, added that the Taliban's support has been known for years, with Russia providing arms, Iran cash, equipment, and training, and Pakistan soldiers being found with weapons from Iran.

Earhardt further explained, "The point here is, if it's not verified by our 16 intelligence agencies—that's their job, that's what they do—it does not get to the president's desk. The president, he has to make decisions based on intel that is in front of him. And if he's not briefed on it, then he doesn't know about it. But if he is briefed on it, then he can act on it."

Steve Doocy, another co-host, mentioned that the allegations were reportedly in the president's presidential daily briefing on February 27th, 2020. Earhardt noted that presidents do not read all of their briefings, and a person comes in to inform the president of the contents. However, it was not specified whether the president had actually read or been informed about the specific allegations in question.

The discussion concluded with Earhardt stating, "So, that's the danger here, that if it's not true, and the president acts, then that causes a lot of trouble. So, we want to be safe here." The article does not provide further details on the specific allegations or the president's response to them.

Title: Christie Fundraises in Florida Amid Ongoing Traffic Jam Scandal

Article:

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie is currently in Florida, assisting Republican Governor Rick Scott in fundraising events across the state. The visits come over a week after allegations surfaced that a significant traffic jam in Fort Lee was caused by road closures on the George Washington Bridge as political retaliation from Christie's team against the town's mayor.

Christie's itinerary includes stops in Orlando, Fort Lauderdale, and Palm Beach. However, it remains unclear whether the ongoing scandal has affected his popularity, as all the meetings are closed-door events.

Traveling with Christie, Scott has shown no hesitation in supporting him. Scott told CNN affiliate WSVN that Christie "did the right thing. He apologized. He went to the community and apologized. And I look forward to seeing him."

In his role as chairman, Christie will also raise money for the Republican Governors Association and network with potential donors who could be key players if Christie decides to run for president in 2016. The main political event is Saturday night at the home of billionaire Ken Langone, the co-founder of Home Depot.

Langone told CNN he has been inundated with requests to meet the governor, regardless of the ongoing scandal.

Meanwhile, Democrats have not missed the opportunity to comment on the Christie scandal. Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz is in Florida, following Christie's every move, and criticized the governor for his private campaign events.

"I think that means that Chris Christie does not want to answer any questions or Rick Scott does not want to be seen with Chris Christie in public – probably a little of both," Wasserman Schultz told CNN.

Florida's Republican Party chairman, Lenny Curry, accused Democrats of attempting to turn Christie's visit into a circus.
