"I'd say Chris Christie apologized. Chris Christie took action. He's the head of the Republican Governors Association, and he's down here doing his job, and that's raising money to make sure that Rick Scott gets re-elected," Curry said.

Title: Trump Announces Houses of Worship as Essential, Urges Governors to Allow Reopening

Article:

President Donald Trump on Friday announced that new Centers for Disease Control (CDC) guidance will classify houses of worship as "essential," as he called on governors to allow them to open "right now" after being closed during the coronavirus lockdowns. The policy applies to churches, synagogues, and mosques.

During a short briefing at the White House, Trump stated, "The governors need to do the right thing and allow these very important essential places of faith to open right now -- for this weekend." He added, "If they do not do it, I will override the governors."

Trump took issue with certain businesses being open while churches are not. Attorney General William Barr already warned last month that coronavirus restrictions by state and local government should be applied evenly and not single out religious organizations.

"Some governors have deemed the liquor stores and abortion clinics as essential," Trump said. "But have left out churches and other houses of worship. It's not right. So I'm correcting this injustice and calling houses of worship essential."

The CDC released interim guidelines Friday for communities of faith that acknowledge "millions of Americans embrace worship as an essential part of life" but also warn that "gatherings present a risk for increasing the spread of COVID-19."

The guidelines encourage the use of cloth face coverings during services, limiting the size of gatherings, social distancing during services, and suspending or decreasing choirs and singing in church since "singing may contribute to transmission of COVID-19, possibly through emission of aerosols."

Last week, the CDC released new guidelines that schools, businesses, and other organizations can use as states reopen from coronavirus shutdowns. However, the document excluded guidance for churches and faith-based groups because the White House raised concerns about the recommended restrictions, the Associated Press reported.

Cities across the country have been taking their cues from their governors on when and how to reopen. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's executive order still remains in effect in hard-hit New York City, officials said Friday.

"Houses of worship never closed in New York City, but have been under reasonable capacity requirements that prohibit large gatherings," said Olivia Lapeyrolerie, Mayor Bill de Blasio's deputy press secretary. "We will continue to work closely with faith leaders to ensure people can safely worship during these stressful times, but will not take any steps that could jeopardize New Yorkers' health."

The White House's Friday announcement comes after Trump has been hearing an earful from faith leaders who are unable to hold services due to coronavirus restrictions at a time when their parishioners are grappling with the crisis.

On Thursday, Trump had a conference call with 1,600 pastors and faith leaders from around the country, including Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council. He reassured them he wants to get churches reopened. The evangelical Christian community was instrumental in supporting Trump during his 2016 White House bid and he's maintained strong ties with Christian leaders throughout his presidency.

Churches across the country had to close down due to stay-home orders necessary to stop the spread of the contagious virus. Faith leaders set up online services, and families tuned in Sunday mornings from their computers at home.

Earlier in the pandemic, Trump expressed optimism that churches would be opened by Easter Sunday, April 12. But April turned out to be an extremely deadly month for the pandemic, and parishioners had to celebrate Easter from home.

Some faith leaders have argued that social distancing rules have violated First Amendment religious freedoms. Others have defied state and local rules and tried to reopen.

"The discrimination that has been occurring against churches and houses of worship has been shocking," said Kelly Shackelford, president of the First Liberty Institute, a legal organization dedicated to defending religious freedom. "We applaud the President's strong stance today demanding that these attacks must stop and that churches and houses of worship be freed to safely open. Americans are going to malls and restaurants. They need to be able to go to their houses of worship."

But other faith leaders warned that congregating is too dangerous right now.

"The President is wrong, plain and simple," said Rabbi Jack Moline, president of Interfaith Alliance. "... The virus does not discriminate between types of gatherings, and neither should the president... It is completely irresponsible for the president to command a mass reopening of houses of worship. The illness and death that afflicts religious communities who follow the president's dictates will be his responsibility."

Earlier this week, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a report that showed just how quickly the virus can spread at church. The study showed that two symptomatic people who later tested positive for COVID-19 attended church events in rural Arkansas back in early March. At least 35 of 92 attendees at the events contracted the virus, and three of them died. Twenty-six other people in the community with links to the church have also contracted the virus, with one person dying.

"We stayed home so the virus quieted down and stopped spreading widely where it was spreading widely," former CDC director Tom Frieden told Fox News Wednesday. "So anytime you have a lot of people together in an indoor space and one of them is infectious, you can have a lot of cases."

Title: Health and Human Services Secretary Apologizes for Obamacare Website Issues, Defends Law Amidst Criticism

Article:

Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius apologized for the malfunctioning HealthCare.gov website on Wednesday, acknowledging that it would take another month to fix the issues. The website, intended to be the primary means for many Americans to purchase insurance from state-based health care exchanges, has been plagued by glitches since its launch on October 1.

During her testimony before the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Sebelius also faced questions about President Obama's 2010 promise that his health care program would not force Americans out of their existing insurance. In a later speech in Boston, Obama addressed this issue, stating that while some may be forced off their plans, they would ultimately receive better deals from their insurance companies.

Both Sebelius and Obama took responsibility for the website's early problems. Sebelius stated, "Hold me accountable for the debacle. I'm responsible." This was her first appearance before Congress to answer for the website's problems.

The hearing was marked by calls for subsidies and stories of constituents who have lost their health care plans and could face higher premiums. Lawmakers also used humor and personal challenges to make their points. For instance, Rep. Cory Gardner asked Sebelius if she would enroll herself in a health care plan on one of the Obamacare exchanges, to which she declined, citing her employer-based coverage from the federal government.

Sebelius appeared to confuse the law when she told lawmakers, "If I have available employer-based coverage, I am not eligible for the market." However, HealthCare.gov states that if individuals are eligible for job-based insurance, they can consider switching to a marketplace plan but may put their subsidies at risk.

Both Sebelius and Marilyn Tavenner, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, testified before Congress. They attributed some of the website's problems to the lead company hired to help build the site. The vendors have stated that the Obama administration did not test the system "end to end" until days before its launch, and a CMS memo revealed that the website had not completed security testing as of Sept. 27.

In addition to the website problems, concerns have arisen this week about the preservation of health care plans as promised by Obama. Committee Chairman Fred Upton stated that Obama's vow has been called into question by a flood of cancellation notices nationwide. Sebelius explained that if a plan was in place in 2010, when the legislation was passed, it could have been grandfathered in as long as the companies did not make major changes.

Americans are "scared" and "frustrated" due to the situation, according to Upton, as many cannot use the Obamacare websites to explore their options, just weeks after Sebelius and her lieutenants assured lawmakers that the federal exchange system was ready to launch. Rep. Marsha Blackburn reminded Sebelius that the law is taking away a personal choice to hold a bare-bones plan, stating, "Some people like to drive a Ford, not a Ferrari, and some people like to drink out of a red Solo cup, not a crystal stem."

Title: Biden's Role in Financial Reform and Consumer Protection During His Vice Presidency

Article:

Jared Bernstein, who served as President Joe Biden's chief economist and economic adviser during his first term as vice president, stated that a senator from a state with significant credit-card and financial interests has a different constituency compared to a vice president. During his tenure as vice president, Biden led the Middle Class Task Force and played a key role in consumer protection issues.

In 2015, Congress passed legislation requiring clearer monthly statements and protecting against retroactive interest rate increases, while limiting the fees that banks charge merchants on debit card purchases. This legislation was a result of the efforts spearheaded by the Obama administration, of which Biden was a part.

Biden's support for financial reform and consumer protection was significant, according to a spokesman for the vice president, Stephen Spector. Spector cited Biden's support for the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act, intended to protect consumers from unfair billing practices, and the Dodd-Frank Act, the 2010 financial overhaul legislation that provided new consumer safeguards and created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

The extent to which Biden can claim credit for these bills could be significant in a primary campaign, according to Bernstein. Christopher J. Dodd, a former Democratic senator from Connecticut, stated that Biden, as vice president, was not necessarily a central player in the passage process but was a "classic progressive Democrat" on economic issues.

Dodd, a sponsor of the Dodd-Frank Act with Barney Frank, a former Democratic congressman from Massachusetts, did not recall Biden playing a significant role behind the scenes, either for or against credit-card companies. However, Frank noted that the Obama administration's record on financial issues could serve as a "pretty good defense for Joe" against criticism of his earlier ties to the credit-card industry before he was no longer representing the interests of his home state.

Title: Former Prosecutor Predicts Indictment of President Trump on Campaign Finance Charges

Article:

Former Assistant U.S. Attorney Andrew McCarthy, a conservative legal analyst, has suggested that prosecutors may indict President Donald Trump on charges related to campaign finance violations, based on the sentencing memo for Michael Cohen, Trump's former personal attorney, released on Friday.

In a column for Fox News, McCarthy, who worked as a prosecutor in the same Southern District of New York jurisdiction currently prosecuting Cohen, argued that the prosecutors' focus on Cohen's relatively minor campaign finance violations indicates an intention to charge Trump over payments of hush money to two women before he became president.

The 40-page sentencing memorandum filed by federal prosecutors for Cohen on Friday states that the president is likely to be indicted on a charge of violating federal campaign finance laws. McCarthy asserts that Trump has been a primary subject of the ongoing investigation by the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York.

When Cohen pleaded guilty in August, prosecutors induced him to make an extraordinary statement in open court: the payments to the women were made "in coordination with and at the direction of" the candidate for federal office – Donald Trump. McCarthy contends that prosecutors would not have made such a statement if Trump was not a focus of their investigation.

McCarthy acknowledges that Trump has a strong defense, but suggests that prosecutors may be focusing on him regardless.

On Friday, Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor who was also once the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and now serves as one of Trump's lawyers, dismissed the legal danger to the president. Giuliani pointed to Cohen's conviction for lying to the FBI, which would make his testimony on other matters unreliable. "You have to believe Cohen. Who believes Cohen?" he reportedly said.

Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███, offers a different perspective. He is a winner of the 2018 Robert Novak Journalism Alumni Fellowship and the co-author of How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution, available from Regnery. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Title: Connecticut Senator Richard Blumenthal's Response to Candy Crowley's Question on Gun Control Legislation

Article:

Connecticut Senator Richard Blumenthal, a former Attorney General, has responded to Candy Crowley's question regarding the effectiveness of the proposed gun control legislation in preventing tragedies like the one in Newtown. During a Senate debate, Crowley asked, "How would anything in the bill, as it currently stands, have stopped anything that went on in Newtown?"

Blumenthal did not suggest abandoning the bill but instead emphasized the need for further measures. He stated that the Senate Majority Leader has assured him and other proponents of the bill that amendments on both the assault-weapons ban and the prohibition on high-capacity magazines will be allowed. Blumenthal also mentioned his intention to offer an amendment that would ban high-capacity magazines.

The article discusses the ongoing debate within the Democratic party on gun control, with President Obama criticizing gun control opponents as insensitive to the Sandy Hook tragedy, while Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has reportedly blocked a ban on assault weapons due to insufficient support within the Democrat-held chamber.

The article then addresses Crowley's question, suggesting that even a bill including an assault weapons ban and high-capacity magazine prohibition would not have prevented the Newtown shooting. The article cites three reasons:

1. Background checks: The Newtown shooter obtained his weapons illegally from his mother, who bought them legally. There is no method for checking people determined to obtain a gun illegally.
2. "Assault weapons" ban: Connecticut has a federal-style ban in place, but the weapons used in the Sandy Hook massacre were not prohibited by that law.
3. Magazine limits: Forcing a spree shooter to reload may provide an opportunity for unarmed victims to intervene, but the likelihood of defenseless, terrified children overpowering a deranged gunman is negligible.

The article concludes by expressing hope for a reasonable compromise on gun control, but emphasizes the need for serious consideration of the effectiveness, duplicative nature, and potential infringement on Second Amendment rights of proposed restrictions. The article also warns against hasty, ill-conceived action, citing New York Governor Andrew Cuomo's enactment of unworkable prohibitions and oversights as an example. The article ends with a quote from the nation's foremost gun safety expert, stating that the Assault Weapons ban and magazine size limitations are just the beginning of potential gun control measures.

Title: Trump Imposes Tough Sanctions on Iran, Iranian President Responds

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has issued a strong warning to anyone trading with Iran, following his re-imposition of sanctions on the country. In a tweet, he stated, "Anyone doing business with Iran will NOT be doing business with the United States." Some re-imposed sanctions took effect overnight, and tougher ones relating to oil exports will begin in November.

The sanctions follow the U.S. withdrawal from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, also known as the Iran nuclear deal, earlier this year. The deal, negotiated during the presidency of Barack Obama, saw Iran limit its controversial nuclear activities in exchange for sanctions relief.

Mr. Trump has called the deal "one-sided," "disastrous," and the "worst I've ever seen." He believes renewed economic pressure will force Iran to agree to a new deal. The European Union, which remains committed to the original agreement, has spoken out against the sanctions, vowing to protect firms doing "legitimate business" with Iran.

In his latest tweet, Mr. Trump praised the "most biting sanctions ever imposed" and said they would "ratchet up to another level" in November. He also said, "I am asking for WORLD PEACE, nothing less!"

On Monday, he had said that Iran faced a choice to "either change its threatening, destabilizing behavior and reintegrate with the global economy, or continue down a path of economic isolation." He added, "I remain open to reaching a more comprehensive deal that addresses the full range of the regime's malign activities, including its ballistic missile program and its support for terrorism."

Mr. Trump signed an executive order that brought sanctions back into place at 00:01 EDT (04:01 GMT) on Tuesday. The sanctions target the purchase or acquisition of U.S. banknotes by Iran's government, graphite, aluminum, steel, coal, and software used in industrial processes. A second phase is planned to come back into effect on 5 November, which will have implications for Iran's energy and shipping sectors, petroleum trading, and transactions by foreign financial institutions with the Central Bank of Iran.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said the U.S. government had "turned their back on diplomacy." He added, "They want to launch psychological warfare against the Iranian nation." Rouhani also stated, "Negotiations with sanctions does not make sense. We are always in favor of diplomacy and talks... but talks need honesty."

The foreign ministers of Germany, the UK, and France released a statement on Monday that said the nuclear deal remained "crucial" to global security. They also unveiled a "blocking statute," which is intended to protect European firms doing business with Iran despite the new U.S. sanctions.

The impact of the new sanctions on Iran's economy is already being felt, with rising food prices, unemployment, and even poor water supplies leading to protests in a number of cities. The sanctions may bite hardest in November, when the U.S. blocks Iranian oil sales, which could halt about half of Iran's exports of some two million barrels a day. Iran may look to China and Russia to keep its industry afloat.

The International Monetary Fund said in March that Iran's net official reserves could decline this year to $97.8bn, which would finance about 13 months of imports. Analysts at BMI Research say Iran's economy could contract by 4.3% in 2019. However, Barbara Slavin, of the Future of Iran Initiative at the Atlantic Council, told the Wall Street Journal that when sanctions hit hard, it often means ordinary people become "totally dependent" on their government, and so sanctions do not tend to topple regimes.

As the first tranche of new U.S. sanctions kicks in, young Iranians have been sharing their stories with BBC Persian. Many are already feeling the effects, as the economy had slowed down in anticipation of what was to come. "I used to work in marketing for a home appliance manufacturer," said Peyman. "I lost my job as the company can't import the components." Aerospace engineer Ali lost his job of 13 years because his company could not import equipment. "Now I'm working as a taxi driver to feed my family," he said. Many people say they're no longer being paid on time and are finding it hard to make ends meet.

Title: U.S. Re-imposition of Iran Sanctions and Withdrawal from Nuclear Deal Affects Global Response

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to re-impose sanctions on Iran and withdraw from the 2015 nuclear deal has prompted U.S. allies in Europe, China, Russia, and Iran to consider their next steps. Trump described the deal as a "horrible, one-sided deal" that "didn’t bring peace" and "never will."

The non-renewal of the waivers required under the nuclear agreement could have a "devastatingly chilling effect on any kind of economic activity" between Europe and Iran, according to Tony Blinken, who was deputy secretary of State under President Barack Obama and helped negotiate the deal.

Robert Einhorn, a former arms control official at the State Department under Obama's first secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, stated that it will take time to establish the regulatory scheme necessary to re-impose sanctions. The practical effect of not issuing the waivers is to notify banks, businesses, and purchasers of Iranian crude oil that they must either stop importing Iranian crude oil or significantly reduce their purchases within the next 180 days.

Trump's decision to withdraw from the deal was based on several concerns, including the elimination of expiration dates on the most important restrictions on Iran's nuclear activity, allowing inspections of military sites, and addressing Iran's support for terrorist groups across the Middle East. French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson have urged Trump to stay with the deal and work with him to address his concerns.

Iran's President Hasan Rouhani has stated that his country will respond to the U.S. action, but he and other signatories to the deal have expressed their intention to stay in it. Russia, a crude oil exporter, does not import much, if any, crude oil from Iran. China could direct its oil purchases through its Kunlun Bank, which is already under U.S. sanctions.

The European Union has announced plans to protect companies if Trump pulls out of the deal. However, it may be difficult for European companies to achieve this due to their reliance on the U.S.-led financial system. Banks and businesses are already wary of doing business in Iran due to its poorly managed and corrupt economy.

Stephen Rademaker, a former arms control official at the State Department under President George W. Bush, stated that Trump's ideal goal is to negotiate a better deal with Iran. Even after refusing to waive sanctions and those sanctions go back into effect, Trump will still have the waiver authority. Iran's leaders are expected to refuse to negotiate a new deal, but Trump has expressed his willingness to negotiate a new deal if the opportunity arises.

Title: Opponents Express Concerns Over Interim Nuclear Deal with Iran, Propose Legislation to Maintain Sanctions

Article:

Opponents of an interim nuclear deal being negotiated with Iran are taking steps to prevent what they perceive as a "bad deal" from becoming a means for Iran to obtain a nuclear weapon. The deal's opponents acknowledge that neither Congress nor the vocal opposition of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu can derail an accord agreed upon by world powers. Instead, attention is shifting towards ensuring immediate consequences for Iran if it fails to comply with the terms of any such agreement.

On Thursday, the six world powers meeting with Iran in Geneva reported no progress in narrowing the remaining differences between the two sides. Some Iranian officials suggested that the gaps might have widened since the last meeting earlier this month. However, this apparent lack of progress did not deter some members of Congress from meeting with administration officials at the White House to express their misgivings.

At least one Republican senator announced that he was proposing legislation to force the immediate reinstatement of any lightened sanctions on Iran upon any evidence of Iran not abiding by the terms of a first-step deal. An interim deal with Iran would aim to freeze progress in Iran's nuclear program while a comprehensive agreement verifiably stopping Iran's program short of a nuclear weapon could be worked out.

Opponents appear most concerned that a short-term plan accepting some level of uranium enrichment – a process that can result in the fuel for a nuclear weapon – would turn into permanent acceptance of Iran's "right" to enrich. John Bolton, the former US ambassador to the United Nations and a prominent critic of the Obama administration's Iran diplomacy, stated, "The Iranian nuclear program has been fundamentally a weapons program from the beginning, and I don't see that changing – certainly not if we go with an interim deal that accepts uranium enrichment."

Such a deal would be "fatally flawed," according to Bolton, because, without any vision for what a final plan should look like, the risks are great that an interim accord "becomes permanent" – enshrining Iran's enrichment program and leaving Iran on a path to a nuclear weapon.

Sen. Bob Corker (R-TN) introduced legislation on Thursday to "keep the pressure on Iran" during the period between a first-step and a final deal. The bill would postpone any additional lifting of sanctions – beyond what the White House says would be "limited and reversible" sanctions relief as part of an interim deal – until after Iran agreed to the "essential terms of an acceptable final deal," according to Senator Corker. The legislation also calls for any sanctions lifted as part of an interim deal to "snap back" in the event of any violation of the deal's obligations.

In order to secure substantial US sanctions relief as part of a final agreement, Iran would have to verifiably "eliminate the threat of its nuclear program," Corker says. Even as negotiations were underway in Geneva, the White House continued to brief members of Congress in an effort to head off debilitating criticism should a deal be reached.

One member of a delegation invited to the White House on Thursday, Rep. Brad Sherman (D-CA), says he "remains a skeptic" that a good interim deal is possible. However, he says he left the meeting, which he said was attended by 10 Democratic representatives, "a little more convinced that they [in the administration] are focused on getting this right" and not above all on getting any deal.

Earlier in the day, Representative Sherman had cut short his attendance at a Capitol Hill meeting of Iranian dissidents addressing the plight of Iranian refugees in Iraq, telling a cheering crowd that he had to leave for the White House "to convince them not to accept a bad deal in Geneva." After the White House meeting, Sherman said, "I still fear they would be willing to enter a deal that [to them] would be better than no deal at all" – echoing a charge leveled against President Obama not just by other members of Congress but also by French leaders, who are also involved in the Geneva talks.

"But after what I heard," he added, "I'm a little less concerned about that than I was before." Sherman says a key challenge after an interim deal – and one reason he never favored the idea of a "first step" before a comprehensive agreement – will be the thinking expected to bloom in international business circles "that it's OK to do business with Iran now." To battle such trends and to keep the pressure up on Iran, Sherman says he and other members of the House will continue to press the Senate to proceed with considering a new round of sanctions. The point, he says, would be to keep Iran motivated to reach a comprehensive agreement on its nuclear program.

More ardent critics of the administration's Iran diplomacy say any rush into a "bad deal" won't just leave Iran's nuclear challenge unaddressed, but could embroil Obama in another losing political battle. "I think the administration is set on getting some deal," says Bolton, now a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. "But if they go with a deal with such deficiencies that the opposition here in Washington is swift and sustained, they're not going to get that."

Title: White House Pushes for Expanded Childcare and Family Leave Options

Article:

President Donald Trump called for expanded access to childcare and family leave during a White House meeting on Thursday, aiming to appeal to women voters by focusing on issues that Democratic challengers are emphasizing in their campaigns. The meeting, part of a push by administration officials, could potentially move forward legislation improving access to assistance for working parents.

Trump stated that families are struggling to pay for childcare and advocated for the expansion of in-home and faith-based programs for children. He expressed the desire to "expand childcare options and reduce unnecessary regulations so that parents can choose the best care for their children."

Ivanka Trump, the president's daughter, spoke at the event, emphasizing the importance of addressing childcare and family leave issues. She stated, "Lack of child care and paid leave is not a women's issue — it is a family issue. That said, they disproportionately impact women, who provide the vast majority of unpaid care to our nation's children and adult dependents."

Childcare and family leave have been a focus for several Democratic candidates running in 2020. Proposed legislation includes Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey's plan to increase eligibility for the childcare block-grant subsidy and provide free childcare to some student parents. Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts has called for universal childcare for all children under 5, and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota has proposed three months of paid family leave.

This week, House Democrats reportedly struck a deal with the White House that provides 12 weeks of paid parental leave for federal workers in exchange for establishing the president's proposed space force as a new branch of the government in the defense authorization bill. White House domestic policy adviser Joe Grogan called the possible new benefit for federal workers an "important first step" toward the administration's priority of providing paid family leave for all Americans.

The administration is also asking lawmakers to reauthorize and overhaul a block-grant program that provides childcare subsidies to low-income working families. Last year, lawmakers increased the amount of childcare funds distributed to states through the program by $2.4 billion to $5.6 billion overall. However, the White House argues the program could benefit more families if lawmakers removed "overly stringent regulations" on facilities and staff that the administration says drive up childcare costs.

As part of the White House effort, the Council of Economic Advisers completed a report detailing the impact of childcare costs on the economy. The report found that while women with young children are about twice as likely to participate in the labor force as they were 50 years ago, some 3.8 million parents with children under the age of 6 are currently outside the labor force. The report argues that expanding childcare options—particularly by removing some regulations—could meaningfully increase the number of Americans who work rather than stay home out of concern over childcare costs.

Title: Marco Rubio Discusses Presidential Campaign and Pope Francis' Visit

Article:

In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) stated that he does not consider the current polling in the Republican presidential nomination race as a "breakout moment" for his campaign. According to a recent CNN/ORC poll, Rubio is in fourth place with 11 percent support.

When asked by host George Stephanopoulos if this was his breakout moment, Rubio responded, "No. These polls do not really mean anything at this stage." He added, "You're a veteran of campaigns, and I'm not sure the mid-September winners are where you want to be."

Rubio, a Catholic who also attends an evangelical church, also discussed Pope Francis' upcoming visit to Washington. He expressed respect for the pope's doctrinal authority but maintained that he can disagree with the pope on political matters. Rubio stated, "The pope is the spiritual head of the church, who has authority to speak on matters, doctrinal matters and theological matters. And I follow him 100 percent on those issues."

However, Rubio added that the pope's political opinions are separate and that individuals are free to disagree with them. He also expressed support for the pope meeting with dissidents during his visit to Cuba and the United States.

Regarding President Barack Obama, Rubio stated that Obama is a Christian born in the United States. Rubio also expressed support for the pope meeting with dissidents during his visit to Cuba and the United States.

Finally, Rubio added that he believes the pope should meet with dissidents during his nine-day visit to Cuba and the United States, which began on Saturday.

Title: Facebook-Organized Protests Attended by Hundreds Possibly Part of Disinformation Network

Article:

At least three events co-organized on Facebook by a group now suspected of being part of a coordinated disinformation network appear to have been held, with hundreds of people attending. The events, in New York City and Springfield, Missouri, were all co-hosted on Facebook by a group called the Resisters. All three events were critical of President Trump.

Archived versions of the event pages showed that 674 people responded on Facebook to say that they would attend the "We Stand with DREAMers! Support DACA!" event in New York on September 9, 2018. Another 3,000 said they were interested in attending. The New York Post reported that "thousands" of people gathered in Midtown on September 9 to protest Trump's decision to unwind the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which allowed children brought to the U.S. illegally to live and work in the United States.

It appears to be the same event co-hosted by Resisters on Facebook, as it took place on the same date and at the same location as the group's "We Stand with DREAMers! Support DACA!" event. More than 2,000 people said they were interested in attending "The People's Protest. Springfield against Trump" in the Missouri town on August 30, and 726 said that they planned to attend the event. Springfield, Missouri's NBC affiliate, KY3, and the Kansas City Star reported that hundreds of protesters showed up on that date to protest President Trump's trip to Springfield at the time.

The third event that appears to have taken place was titled "Protest Trump and ideology of hate at Trump Tower!" Around 4,700 said they were interested in attending the event and 1,400 said they were attending on the Facebook page. DNAInfo reported that thousands protested Trump at Trump Tower on August 14, 2017, the same day and location of the event promoted on Facebook. Reports at the time from multiple sources, including NBC and The Washington Post, also highlighted the protest.

All three events were hosted by what appear to be legitimate groups in addition to the Resisters. Facebook on Tuesday said "inauthentic" groups, including Resisters, created roughly 30 events. Facebook, in a call with reporters, highlighted fake pages set up by the groups, but said it had no evidence on whether the events actually took place.

There is some evidence that the events set up by Resisters were meant to piggyback on existing, legitimate events by opponents of Trump. Indivisible St. Louis told ███ that its Springfield event was already being organized when Resisters contacted them on Facebook. They also said that they did not encounter any representatives from Resisters at the protest.

The Columbus Circle in New York protest similarly capitalized on nationwide outrage over Trump's DACA policy and may have been organized regardless. Protests against the policy had already occurred early in September 2017. Roger Ray of the Emerging Church in Springfield said that the protest he was involved in would have happened regardless.

"I don't doubt there were lots of fake groups that might have tried to glom on, but they didn't have any physical representation. They wouldn't have had any influence," he told ███ in a phone interview.

Facebook executives did not blame Russia or the Russian troll group the Internet Research Agency (IRA), but said that the behavior matched past work by the IRA. The IRA during the 2016 presidential election created events that were highlighted on Facebook, including one in New York City attended by thousands. Multiple organizers told ███ that they were frustrated by the possibility that the involvement of a fake account could undermine their actual cause and stressed that they were engaged in real organizing.

"I certainly was not inspired by Russia or anything like that," Ray said.

Title: Pennsylvania and Delaware Voters Embrace Trump as GOP's Presumptive Nominee

Article:

Republican voters in Pennsylvania and Delaware, traditionally deep-blue states, are expressing their support for Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee for the 2016 presidential election. This shift in allegiance is significant, as neither state has voted for a Republican president in a generation.

In York, a Pennsylvania State Police trooper, who requested anonymity due to his job, voted for Senator Ted Cruz in the primary but is now backing Mr. Trump. He cited the candidate's financial management skills as a reason for his support.

North of York, in Harrisburg, gun shop owner Joe Staudt, a former Marine, also voted for Mr. Cruz but has joined the "Trump Train." He criticized the reluctance of top Republicans to support Mr. Trump, describing it as childish or selfish.

Megan Sweeney, spokeswoman for the Republican Party of Pennsylvania, stated that the party is a bottom-up organization, and the voters have spoken clearly about their preferred nominee.

Despite calls for party unity by Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus, some establishment figures, including House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney, and several of Mr. Trump's primary rivals, have refused to pledge their support. Mr. Trump and Mr. Ryan are scheduled to meet on Thursday in Washington, and the speaker has offered to give up his role presiding over the Republican National Convention this summer in Cleveland if requested by Mr. Trump.

Republican strategist and pollster Jim McLaughlin noted that Mr. Trump beat Mr. Cruz by 25 points among evangelicals and 30 points among self-described conservatives in the Pennsylvania primary. Mr. Trump's economic message of making America "win" again resonates with disaffected working-class voters in Pennsylvania, one of five Northeast states Mr. Trump swept on April 26 as he moved to secure the nomination.

In York, Katie Nimon, a registered Democrat who waits tables at Otto's Kitchen & Cocktails, voted for Senator Bernie Sanders in the primary but plans to cast her ballot for Donald Trump in November if he faces likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. She described Mrs. Clinton as a manipulative liar.

Similar support for Mr. Trump was heard in nearby Delaware, another state that hasn't voted for a Republican since George H.W. Bush won the White House in 1988. Donna Pusey, a 64-year-old barber and registered Democrat, vowed to vote for Mr. Trump in November, stating that she sat out the Democratic primary because she would "rather get run over by a semi" than choose between Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders. She also criticized the treatment of Mr. Trump by GOP leaders as an "abomination."

Title: Bill Cosby Convicted of Sexual Assault in Pennsylvania

Article:

Comedian Bill Cosby was convicted on Thursday of drugging and sexually assaulting Andrea Constand in 2004, marking the first such conviction of a celebrity since the #MeToo movement. The 80-year-old, best known for his role as the lovable father on the 1980s TV hit "The Cosby Show," faces up to 10 years in prison for each of three counts of aggravated indecent assault.

Following a three-week trial at the Montgomery County courthouse in Norristown, Pennsylvania, Cosby exploded when prosecutors asked the judge to take him into custody, stating he was a flight risk in part because he owned a plane. "He doesn't have a plane, you asshole!" Cosby responded in a booming voice as he leapt to his feet.

The verdict was read with a somber expression from Judge Steven O'Neill, who ruled Cosby could remain out of jail on $1 million bail pending sentencing, as long as he surrendered his passport and remained at home. Cosby then left the courthouse with his lawyers and publicist.

Defense lawyer Thomas Mesereau told reporters that an appeal would be filed, and sentencing was expected within 60 to 90 days, after Cosby submits to a "sexually violent predator assessment." Although he could get up to 10 years for each count, state sentencing guidelines suggest a term of less than 10 years.

The conviction marks the downfall of a man once celebrated as "America's Dad" but whose reputation was ruined after some 50 women accused him of similar offenses going back decades. Cosby had been a transcendent figure in show business, coming up as a black comedian during the civil rights movement of the 1960s and winning over white audiences with a clean routine. He went on to several successful television series when African-Americans were largely absent from TV. In "The Cosby Show" from 1984 to 1992, he played the wise and witty Dr. Heathcliff Huxtable, the father of an affluent black family.

All the while, his accusers say, he had been drugging and molesting women. Only one of those cases was recent enough to be eligible for prosecution, that of Constand, a former administrator for the women's basketball team at Temple University, Cosby's alma mater. She had no comment after the verdict.

"The most important person in our team was Andrea Constand," District Attorney Kevin Steele told reporters. "She was the first courageous person who stood up in public and went to authorities and said, 'Bill Cosby drugged and raped me.'"

Attorney Gloria Allred, who represents 33 of the Cosby accusers, rejoiced that Cosby was found "guilty, guilty, guilty."

"We are so happy that finally we can say, women are believed, and not only on #MeToo, but in a court of law," Allred told reporters.

Other Cosby accusers celebrated the verdict with hugs, cries, and applause.

"I feel like my faith in humanity is restored," Bernard said.

The seven-man, five-woman jury reached a unanimous verdict after deliberating for 14 hours over two days. Less than a year ago, a different jury was deadlocked after six days of deliberations on the same charges, prompting the judge to declare a mistrial.

Soon after the first trial, a series of women leveled sexual assault and harassment accusations against men in media, entertainment, and politics, giving rise to the #MeToo and #TimesUp movements that encouraged women to go public with personal stories of abuse, in some cases after years of silence.

Like many of Cosby's other accusers, Constand said she was drugged and violated while unable to defend herself. Cosby has said any sexual encounters were consensual, and his lawyers portrayed the accusers as fabricating stories in search of wealth and fame.

"Mob rule is not due process," defense lawyer Kathleen Bliss said, referring to the #MeToo movement.

President Donald Trump has been accused by several women of sexual misconduct, including after the release during the 2016 presidential campaign of a video in which he had spoken in vulgar terms about trying to have sex with women. He later called it "locker room banter" and his campaign issued an apology to anyone who was offended.

Trump, whose inauguration and first anniversary as president were met with nationwide women's protests, denies accusations of sexual misconduct and accuses rival Democrats and the media of a smear campaign. He faces a defamation lawsuit from Summer Zervos, a contestant on his former reality show who accuses him of sexually harassing her. Trump's lawyer has said her accusations are false and politically motivated.

Title: House Democrats' Support for Impeachment Inquiry: A Closer Look at the Current State of Affairs

Article:

The ongoing impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump has seen a significant shift in the number of House Democrats expressing support for the investigation. As of recent reports, there are 116 House Democrats who have voiced their support, which is just shy of a majority of the party. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals a more nuanced picture.

It appears that those who do not support an impeachment inquiry are instead advocating for the continuation of the current investigations. In reality, these ongoing investigations amount to the same thing, as House lawyers admitted last week. The notion that an impeachment inquiry requires special grants of power to move forward is no longer accurate, as officially opening an impeachment inquiry under current House rules and procedures is, for the most part, a formality.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is leveraging this illusion of a dispute to her advantage. A formal vote in the full House might not set any wheels in motion, but it would increase the pressure to make a decision on impeachment one way or the other. Pelosi is right to avoid this pressure on behalf of her caucus, as there appears to be plenty to investigate, and it is both in the party's interest to keep the inquiry going and the responsible thing to do.

However, actual articles of impeachment might not have the votes on the House floor, and a failed effort would likely be a victory for President Trump. Even if Pelosi could whip enough votes to send impeachment to the Senate, it would be an extremely weak statement unless Democrats were unified. A bare majority in the House for impeachment would almost certainly produce a majority against removal in the Senate, with 53 Republicans united and the 47 Democrats quite possibly split.

By contrast, keeping the investigation going is good politics, and fighting the administration's stonewalling in court is the responsible thing to do. Maintaining the fiction that there is some significant tension over whether to move to an impeachment inquiry reduces the pressure to make a premature decision and gives House Democrats an opportunity to "vote" by declaring themselves for or against the inquiry itself.

In summary, the ongoing impeachment inquiry against President Trump is a complex issue, with House Democrats strategically navigating the political landscape. The illusion of a dispute over an impeachment inquiry serves a purpose for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, but it is not necessarily indicative of a deep divide within the Democratic Party.

Title: Researchers Link WannaCry Ransomware to North Korea's Lazarus Group

Article:

Security researchers have identified lines of code in the WannaCry ransomware that match work by the Lazarus Group, a hacking group believed to be linked to North Korea. Google security researcher Neel Mehta pointed out similarities between WannaCry and malware used by Lazarus, the group responsible for the Sony Pictures hack in 2014 and the theft of millions of dollars from a Bangladeshi bank in 2016.

After Mehta highlighted the code elements, other researchers confirmed similarities between WannaCry, also known as WannaCrypt, Wana Decryptor, or WCry, and malware tools used by Lazarus. While the connection does not definitively assign blame, it is the most substantial public information about the cyberattack's origin.

The WannaCry attack, which made headlines on Friday by locking computers in the U.K.'s health system and Spain's largest telecom, did not appear to target the U.S. or South Korea, despite heightened tensions on the Korean Peninsula. At least 12 South Korean companies have been hit by the WannaCry computer virus, but South Korea does not seem to have been disproportionately affected.

Security firm Symantec has identified tools exclusively used by Lazarus on machines also infected with earlier versions of WannaCry, which could have been used to spread the worm to vulnerable computers. The shared code is based on a specific sequence of 75 ciphers, which have only been seen across Lazarus tools.

However, malware researcher Paul Burbage of Flashpoint, a business risk intelligence company, has not seen a solid connection between the ransomware and North Korea. "We compared the code samples between WannaCry and previous Democratic People's Republic of Korea activity, but the only similarities are public libraries," Burbage said. "Perhaps Symantec has more to go on than us at this point, but we are not seeing a DPRK link with the WannaCry worm campaign at this point."

The WannaCry cyberattack has affected more than 300,000 computers, according to White House homeland security adviser Tom Bossert. U.S. investigators do not know who is responsible for WannaCry, but there are clues to follow.

Title: Cruz's Speech at the Republican National Convention Leaves Endorsement Unclear

Article:

The Republican National Convention in Cleveland is approaching its climax, and one question remains unanswered: will Texas Senator Ted Cruz board the Trump train or remain a bitter rival of the Republican nominee, Donald Trump? Cruz is scheduled to deliver a prime-time address on Wednesday, with no indication yet that he plans to endorse Trump.

It is widely believed that Cruz is positioning himself for a future presidential run, whether in four or eight years. The nominee's campaign manager, Paul Manafort, has stated that Cruz's speech could provide a sign of his stance on Trump that would be pleasing to the Trump campaign and the Republican Party. Manafort mentioned that their operations have been in communication regarding Cruz's speech, and he plans to review a draft soon.

While party unity was on display on Tuesday, Cruz's address could have an impact. He placed second in the delegate count during the nominating process and still has loyal supporters in the convention hall, some of whom disrupted proceedings on Monday. However, on Tuesday night, after Trump and his running mate, Mike Pence, were formally nominated, House Speaker Paul Ryan and other party leaders attempted to bring the delegates and GOP voters together.

Ryan, who has had his share of disagreements with Trump over the nominee's controversial remarks and tactics, closed his address Tuesday night with a call to action, saying, "Only with Donald Trump and Mike Pence do we have a chance at a better way." Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, a former primary rival turned supporter, warned that the country "may never recover" from another Clinton presidency, stating, "I'm proud to support Donald Trump."

Trump also addressed the convention hall via video message, saying, "This is a movement... but we have to go all the way." While party leaders called for unity, many of the convention speakers focused heavily on Hillary Clinton. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., stated, "Hillary Clinton has changed her position so many times, it's impossible to tell where the conviction ends and the ambition begins." New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, who was considered for the running mate before Trump ultimately chose Pence, delivered one of the toughest speeches of the night on Clinton. His address was frequently interrupted by chants from the crowd of "lock her up."

"We can not promote someone to commander-in-chief who has made the world a more violent and dangerous place with every bad judgment she has made," Christie said. "The facts of her life and career disqualify her." The exact content of Cruz's speech and his stance on Trump remain to be seen.

Title: Trump Administration Considers Six Candidates for Two Vacancies on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit

Article:

The Trump administration is considering six candidates for two vacancies on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which has jurisdiction over federal districts in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas. According to a report by Legal Times, the candidates under consideration include Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett, U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor of Fort Worth, former Texas solicitor general James Ho, Andy Oldham, a deputy general counsel to Gov. Greg Abbott, Michael Massengale, a justice on Houston's First Court of Appeals, and Brett Busby, a justice on Houston's Fourteenth Court of Appeals.

Two names on the list that stand out are Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett and former Texas solicitor general James Ho.

Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett is a prominent figure in conservative and libertarian legal circles and was also on Trump's recent list of potential U.S. Supreme Court nominees. Willett is best known for his concurring opinion in the 2015 case of Patel v. Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation, where he argued against a state regulation requiring eyebrow threaders to obtain an occupational license. Willett's 49-page concurrence is a call to judicial arms in defense of economic liberty.

Former Texas solicitor general James Ho is known for a 2006 law review article defending the constitutionality of birthright citizenship for the U.S.-born children of undocumented immigrant parents. Ho's position on birthright citizenship is directly at odds with the stated views of Donald Trump, who has vowed to "end birthright citizenship."

The potential appointment of either Willett or Ho to the 5th Circuit would significantly impact the court's composition and decisions. However, it is unclear at this time which candidates will be selected for the two vacancies.

Title: U.S. Stock Market Rebounds After Iranian Missile Strike on U.S. Bases in Iraq

Article:

U.S. equity markets experienced a rebound on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 index, Nasdaq Composite Index, and Dow Jones Industrial Average approaching record closes, despite an Iranian missile strike on two U.S. Iraqi bases in retaliation for the killing of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani. The less bellicose posture adopted by President Donald Trump, who a day ago had warned of a harsh response to any action by Iran, helped to push the markets higher.

President Trump, during an afternoon speech, stated that no Americans were harmed in the Iranian attack and that only minimal damage was sustained at the military bases. He also noted that Iran appears to be standing down, which is a good thing for all parties concerned and a very good thing for the world.

The S&P 500 index, Dow Jones Industrial Average, and Nasdaq Composite Index had shown signs of a more negative response to the brewing conflict late Tuesday, as indicated by futures contracts. However, market participants attribute the rebound to more than just the calming words from Trump and Iranian officials. Equities have historically been good at shaking off or discounting entirely military conflicts that have initially been unsettling.

LPL Financial senior market strategist Ryan Detrick stated, "No doubt worries over Iran have investors on edge. Stocks could be volatile for a while, but the impact to stocks from geopolitical events historically has tended to be short-lived."

Indeed, the S&P 500 has declined 5% on average in 20 major geopolitical events dating back to the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. However, the S&P 500 recovered those losses in fewer than 50 calendar days on average. The stunning assassination of President John F. Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963, for example, led to a 2.8% decline in the S&P 500, which was recovered in a day. It took markets 307 sessions to rebound from the Pearl Harbor attacks in 1941, which resulted in a total decline of nearly 20%.

Crude-oil prices, which had spiked overnight, fell back during the trading day. West Texas Intermediate crude oil for February delivery settled at $59.61 a barrel, after touching an intraday peak at $65.65, its highest level since April. Oil has been the biggest beneficiary of the rising tensions in the oil-rich Middle East, and some investors point to the strong gains oil has seen in the face of rising Mideast tensions as a reason for the strong pullback.

Title: New Tax Bill Aims to Offer Mixed Benefits for Individual Taxpayers

Article:

The recently proposed tax bill is set to offer a mix of benefits for individual taxpayers, with the extent of these benefits largely dependent on factors such as income level, location, and common tax deductions claimed.

For taxpayers earning up to $24,000, no income tax will be imposed. For married taxpayers filing jointly, earnings up to $90,000 will be taxed at a 12% rate, while earnings up to $260,000 will fall under the 25% tax bracket. Earnings up to $1 million will be taxed at a 35% rate. For unmarried individuals and those filing separately, the bracket thresholds will be half of these amounts, except for the 35% bracket, which will be $200,000 for unmarried individuals.

The proposal aims to significantly expand the standard deduction for middle-class families. The standard deduction for married couples will be increased to $24,000, up from the current $12,700, and set at $12,000 for individuals, up from $6,530 today. Additionally, the child tax credit is planned to be expanded to $1,600 from $1,000, and a $300 credit for each parent and non-child dependent, such as older family members, is proposed, although this credit would expire after five years.

However, the bill also tightens rules for claiming the child tax credit, a change that could impact immigrant parents whose children were born in the United States. Filers would now need to provide a "work-eligible Social Security number" rather than just a taxpayer identification number to claim the credit. The left-leaning Center on Budget Policy and Priorities estimates that the bill would roll back eligibility for about three million children in working families, including about 80% of whom were born in the United States.

The bill includes a variety of other changes that will affect taxpayers in different ways. For instance, it repeals certain tax credits, including a 15% credit for individuals aged 65 or over or who are retired on disability. This credit, which currently allows individuals to claim up to $7,500 for a joint return, $5,000 for a single individual, or $3,750 for a married individual filing a joint return, will be entirely repealed under the House bill.

The bill also proposes changes to the popular mortgage interest deduction. Under the Republican plan, existing homeowners can keep the deduction, but future purchases will be capped at $500,000, down from the current $1 million limit.

Title: FBI Decides Not to Recommend Criminal Charges Against Hillary Clinton in Email Investigation

Article:

FBI Director James Comey announced on Tuesday that the bureau will not recommend to the Department of Justice (DOJ) that criminal charges be brought against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton regarding her handling of classified emails on a private server. In a statement, Comey said, "Our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case."

Clinton's spokesman, Brian Fallon, issued a statement shortly after the announcement, saying, "We are pleased that the career officials handling this case have determined that no further action by the Department is appropriate." He added, "As the Secretary has long said, it was a mistake to use her personal email and she would not do it again. We are glad that this matter is now resolved."

Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, Clinton's rival, criticized the FBI's decision on Twitter, saying, "FBI director said Crooked Hillary compromised our national security. No charges. Wow! # RiggedSystem." Trump later issued two separate statements on the matter, including one that read, "Comey let Clinton off the hook... The fix was final. The Obama administration's anointed successor has had an indictment removed from her path and will now be able to glide to the rigged Democrat nomination."

Despite not recommending charges, Comey delivered a blistering rebuke of Clinton's actions, saying the FBI found that 110 emails were sent or received on Clinton's server containing classified information. He added it was possible that people hostile to the U.S. had gained access to her personal email account.

"Although we did not find clear evidence that Secretary Clinton or her colleagues intended to violate laws governing the handling of classified information, there is evidence that they were extremely careless in their handling of very sensitive, highly classified information," Comey said.

Comey said seven email chains were classified at the "Top Secret/Special Access Program level" when they were sent and received on Clinton's server. "There is evidence to support a conclusion that any reasonable person in Secretary Clinton's position, or in the position of those government employees with whom she was corresponding about these matters, should have known that an unclassified system was no place for that conversation," he said.

Tuesday's decision removes what was arguably the biggest threat to Clinton's presidential campaign going forward – a criminal referral that could have led to an indictment – just weeks before her party's national convention in Philadelphia, where she is set to seal her nomination as the Democrat standard-bearer.

Clinton consistently downplayed the FBI investigation, even calling it a "security review," and as recently as June 3 said there was "absolutely no possibility" she'd be indicted. Weeks ago, a scathing State Department inspector general report directly countered her long-running claim that her personal email use was allowed, though her campaign continued to defend the candidate's actions.

In the wake of that report, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, stepped up his criticism of Clinton's email actions and said she belongs in "jail." The DOJ decision does not strip the email controversy as a campaign issue – Trump and the Republicans are sure to keep hammering it as the campaign lurches into full general election mode post-conventions – but shows the federal investigation did not determine the actions to be criminal, even if they were ill-advised and potentially damaging to national security.

House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, a Republican, said the decision not to prosecute Clinton defied explanation, adding, "No one should be above the law." The decision comes more than a year after knowledge of Clinton's use of a personal email account and server first became public. Clinton responded at the time with a point-by-point written explanation and a press conference in which she said she had opted to use her personal server for "convenience."

However, critics said she was clearly circumventing government systems in order to try to shield her communications from public records requests, potentially putting sensitive and highly classified government secrets at risk in the process. During a subsequent review, more than 2,000 emails on the server were found to have contained information now deemed classified, though they apparently were not marked classified when sent.

Title: Tennessee Governor Grants Clemency to Cyntoia Brown, Convicted for 2004 Murder

 Article:

 Tennessee Governor Bill Haslam has ordered the release of Cyntoia Brown, a woman who was sentenced to life in prison for the 2004 murder of a man she claimed was a sex solicitor when she was 16 years old. The decision, made on Monday, grants Brown parole supervision on August 7, 2019, after almost 15 years behind bars.

 Brown was tried as an adult and convicted in 2006 for the murder of a Nashville estate agent, Johnny Allen. Prosecutors argued that the crime was robbery, while Brown maintained that she was a child sex-trafficking victim who acted in self-defense. Her case gained support from celebrities such as singer Rihanna, reality TV personality Kim Kardashian West, comedian Amy Schumer, and NBA star LeBron James.

 The case was the subject of the 2011 documentary "Me Facing Life: Cyntoia's Story." According to the film, Brown was picked up in Nashville by Allen, who agreed to pay her $150 for sex and drove her to his home. However, Brown stated that once at Allen's home, he groped her roughly and reached for the side of the bed, leading her to fear he was reaching for a gun. She then shot him.

 Prosecutors at the time alleged that Brown killed the victim while he was sleeping and stole his money, guns, and truck before fleeing the scene. They claimed that she was motivated by greed, but her defense lawyers argued that she was afraid of returning home empty-handed to her violent pimp, who went by the nickname Kutthroat.

 After entering a plea of self-defense, a jury found her guilty of first-degree premeditated murder, first-degree felony murder, and aggravated robbery. In a statement on Monday, Governor Haslam said he had ordered that Brown be released to parole supervision on August 7, 2019.

 "Cyntoia Brown committed, by her own admission, a horrific crime at the age of 16," the statement said. "Yet, imposing a life sentence on a juvenile that would require her to serve at least 51 years before even being eligible for parole consideration is too harsh, especially in light of the extraordinary steps Ms Brown has taken to rebuild her life."

 Nashville Mayor David Briley called the decision a "great day for social justice and our city." Brown, who has earned an associate degree while in prison, said she would do everything to justify Governor Haslam's faith in her. "I am thankful for all the support, prayers, and encouragement I have received," she said in a statement. "We truly serve a God of second chances and new beginnings."

 After the announcement was made, Kim Kardashian West tweeted her thanks. Actresses Alyssa Milano and Sophia Bush were also among the celebrities voicing their support on Twitter. Stacey Abrams, who ran as the first black female nominee for governor in the US during the mid-term elections, said the victory belonged to Brown and the activists "who refused to concede injustice."

Title: Hillary Clinton Calls for Adult Summer Camps to Bridge Political Divide, Discusses 2016 Campaign Plans

Article:

In a speech at the American Camp Association of New York and New Jersey's annual Tri-State CAMP Conference in Atlantic City, New Jersey, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton called for adult summer camps to help bridge political differences and close the "serious fun deficit" in America. The speech, which was Clinton's last scheduled paid speech before her expected April launch of a potential second presidential campaign, focused on the need for Americans to come together and work across political aisles.

Clinton steered clear of thorny issues and controversies that have surrounded her in recent weeks, instead focusing on the need for a pragmatic approach to getting things done in a gridlocked Washington. She lamented the growth of political division and partisanship, pointing to changes in the media and campaign finance laws as culprits.

The former senator spoke for about an hour to more than 3,000 camp professionals, including a 30-minute Q&A session with her longtime donor and ally, Jay Jacobs. Clinton also spoke about her advocacy for children, her book It Takes a Village, and praised camp professionals for teaching life skills to kids.

She reiterated her call for universal pre-kindergarten education, portraying it as an economic and national security issue. Clinton has a perceived lock on the Democratic nomination, and her team insists she has not made a final decision on a run. A specific launch date remains uncertain, but a formal declaration sometime in April is all but assured.

Clinton's team is already preparing for the campaign, with staffers being told to be ready to report for duty by April 1. Unlike Republicans testing the waters for a 2016 bid, Clinton has no entity to raise money or pay staff. Most aides are volunteering their time until she formally declares her run.

In a lighter moment, Clinton answered a series of "lightning round" questions from Jacobs, including revealing that she and her husband binge-watch "House of Cards," though they have not yet seen the newest season. Instead, she recommended a Danish show about a woman who is elected prime minister.

Title: Trump Announces Participation in Fall Debates Despite Perceived Bias, Predicts AOC Challenge for Schumer

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Donald Trump has announced his intention to participate in debates in the fall, despite past threats suggesting otherwise. The president, who has often accused the Commission on Presidential Debates of bias against him, has also predicted that Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York will challenge Senator Chuck Schumer in a Democratic primary, stating that she would "kick his ass."

Looking ahead to his speech on Tuesday night, President Trump hinted at the possible presence of Rush Limbaugh, the conservative radio host who announced on Monday that he has advanced lung cancer. The president suggested that he might award Limbaugh the Presidential Medal of Freedom during the speech.

Tensions with Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who orchestrated his impeachment, remain high. President Trump expressed displeasure at the prospect of Pelosi sitting behind him and next to Vice President Mike Pence during the speech, stating, "There’s one person behind me who’s going to be friendly and one who’s not going to be friendly."

The president spent a significant portion of his speech criticizing John Bolton, whose unpublished book confirms a central allegation of the impeachment charges by reporting that the president conditioned security aid to Ukraine on its willingness to announce political investigations of former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and other Democrats. "He turned on me," said Mr. Trump of Mr. Bolton.

The Iowa debacle, coupled with Gallup reporting that Mr. Trump’s approval rating has climbed to 49 percent, its highest in that survey since his presidency began, has not deterred the president. While polls indicate that most Americans want the Senate to call witnesses, his impeachment trial is set to end Wednesday with an assured acquittal. It is possible, though not certain, that one or more Democratic senators will vote with him.

Matt Schlapp, the chairman of the American Conservative Union, commented, "What other people would look at as a moment of completely political meltdown for this president, it all appears to accrue to his benefit. He actually looks like the adult in the room."

Furthermore, Mr. Schlapp suggested that the delayed count in Iowa will sow discord and suspicion within Democratic ranks. "The problem for the Democrats is it will make people think and assume the fix is in again because they don’t like who is leading," he said.

Title: Trump's Pardons Under Scrutiny: Dinesh D'Souza Case Raises Questions About Presidential Power of Pardon

Article:

President Donald Trump's use of the presidential power of the pardon is under renewed scrutiny following his decision to pardon conservative commentator Dinesh D'Souza. The pardon, announced on Thursday, comes after recent pardons for the late heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson, former Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff Lewis "Scooter" Libby, and former sheriff of Maricopa County, Arizona, Joe Arpaio.

D'Souza had pleaded guilty to making illegal campaign contributions, claiming that he was a victim of a politically-motivated prosecution by the Obama-era Department of Justice (DOJ). In September 2014, the judge at his sentencing hearing described his claims as "all hat, no cattle."

In addition to the D'Souza and Libby pardons, Trump pardoned Arpaio in August 2017 for criminal contempt of court for ignoring a judge's orders to stop detaining migrants who were not suspected of a crime.

Critics of the president express concern over the political nature of some of Trump's pardons, particularly in light of his attacks on the DOJ, FBI, and special counsel Robert Mueller. Lisa Gilbert of Public Citizen, a not-for-profit watchdog group, stated, "Trump's feeling that people who say the right things or show some kind of loyalty or play on his team should be pardoned is completely antithetical to how our justice system works."

Grant Reeher, a professor of political science at Syracuse University, asserted that Trump's pardons appear "more politically oriented" compared to other recent presidents. He noted that Trump is focusing on people whose political actions are consistent with his own.

Defenders of the president argue that he is not unusual in this regard. They point to President Clinton's controversial pardon of financier Marc Rich, whose ex-wife, Denise Rich, was a major fundraiser for the Democratic Party. Trump backers also note that, when asked about the pardon of D'Souza by reporters on Thursday, the president indicated he was considering pardons for businesswoman Martha Stewart and Rod Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois.

The other question that has dogged Trump's pardons is whether he is seeking to send a signal to former aides who are now feeling the heat from Mueller's investigation into allegations of collusion with Russia. Some theorize that Trump is displaying his willingness to issue pardons to discourage people from cooperating with Mueller. However, there is no hard evidence to support this theory.

Observers across the political spectrum have raised the issue of whether Trump might have a bias in favor of celebrities or celebrity-backed causes over more anonymous figures. The Jack Johnson pardon was prominently backed by actor and director Sylvester Stallone. Trump told reporters on Thursday that he did not know D'Souza personally but "I read the papers, I see him on television."

The pardon of D'Souza came the day after Trump received an Oval Office visit from Kim Kardashian, who is advocating for prison reform and a pardon for Alice Marie Johnson, a 63-year-old woman serving a life sentence for drug offenses. "The narrative may build that he's only focused on famous people," said Republican strategist Matt Mackowiak. "Often, famous people have the best legal defense money can buy, and others don't have that opportunity."

White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley pushed back on suggestions that the president was mostly focused on celebrity pardons when he spoke to reporters on board Air Force One on Thursday. "Look, there are plenty of people the president is looking at right now under the pardon process," Gidley said.

However, the fact that Trump has tended to issue pardons without going through the usual process of review at the DOJ concerns some skeptics. While they acknowledge that a president has expansive power to pardon, they worry about Trump's propensity to flout norms. "There is a process set up for pardoning people and he is ignoring it," Gilbert said. "I am not saying he is running afoul of the Constitution. But this is off-the-cuff, and he is doing things that a DOJ that he is simultaneously attacking might not be that into."

Meanwhile, the reverberations from the decision to pardon D'Souza will continue to be felt. Late Thursday, the lead prosecutor in his case, Carrie H. Cohen, released a statement plainly critical of Trump's decision.

Title: Pennsylvania Special Election Results: Three Key Takeaways from the PA-18 Race

Article:

In the special election for Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional District, Democrat Conor Lamb has likely won by a thin margin, marking a significant loss for the Republican Party. The final tally is pending a possible recount, but the outcome, even if it changes, indicates a challenging outlook for the GOP in the upcoming November midterm elections. Here are three key takeaways from Tuesday's results:

1. The GOP should be concerned about November:
   - The historical trend of midterm elections working against the president's party cannot be ignored.
   - The president's approval rating is in the low 40s, which is not favorable, especially given the strong economy.
   - In the past, this district had been a relatively safe Republican seat, but the close race indicates a potential shift in voter sentiment.

2. Candidates matter:
   - The underwhelming performance of Republican candidate Rick Saccone, who was not a strong campaigner, fundraiser, or grassroots mobilizer, may have contributed to the loss.
   - Democrat Conor Lamb's robust fundraising and retail politics skills, as well as his moderate stance on several issues, proved to be a potent combination.

3. More Democrats will attempt to neutralize the Pelosi Factor:
   - The Lamb campaign's decision to publicly oppose Nancy Pelosi as Democratic leader was effective in distancing him from the unpopular San Francisco liberal, a key element of the GOP's attack strategy.
   - More Democrats in purple-to-red districts are expected to follow suit, as the inability to take a clean hit at Pelosi hurt Republicans in PA-18.

These findings suggest that the political landscape may be shifting, with the opposition party feeling increasingly optimistic about their chances to gain a significant number of seats in the upcoming midterm elections. The economy's strong performance and the tax law's popularity may not be enough to counteract the president's low approval rating and the intensity gap between the two parties.

Title: House Republican Announces Imminent Release of Alleged Surveillance Abuses Memo

Article:

Rep. Dave Joyce (R-Ohio) announced on Saturday that the House Intelligence Committee plans to begin the process of releasing a memo detailing alleged government surveillance abuses "very soon," if not immediately. The release process could take up to 19 congressional working days, which, according to the House's 2018 calendar, means the earliest the document could be released is sometime in mid-March.

The memo, which has been highly classified, alleges that the Obama administration unlawfully used the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISA) to spy on the Trump campaign and transition. This claim has been repeatedly denied by former administration officials. The alleged evidence in the memo has led numerous GOP congressmen to demand its public release, with some suggesting it could potentially end the special counsel Robert Mueller's Trump-Russia investigation and lead to the dismissal of senior FBI and CIA officials.

Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.), who is leading the push for the memo's release, said on Fox News Saturday that the memo will "shock the conscience of this country."
