He added, "There are four pages of a memorandum prepared by the intelligence committee that will shock the conscience of this country when it comes to the horrific abuses that occurred during the last administration and that I believe continue to pose a threat to Donald Trump’s presidency."

Before the memo can be released, it must undergo review by federal records reviewers due to its highly classified nature, and it must receive multiple levels of approval. On Thursday, Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) explained on Fox News that the document's release would first need approval from the House Intelligence Committee and then President Donald Trump would have to give it the green light.

Title: John Conyers and Nancy Pelosi's Response to Sexual Misconduct Allegations Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a recent interview on NBC's Meet the Press, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) sparked controversy by advocating for "due process" for Representative John Conyers (D-MI) amidst a series of sexual misconduct allegations. This stance has been met with criticism from both sides of the political spectrum, with many viewing it as a double standard in the handling of sexual misconduct allegations.

Pelosi's defense of Conyers has been criticized by those who believe she is protecting members of the political establishment, while at the same time insisting that allegations against President Trump and Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore are grounds for their disqualification. Pelosi has stated, "We are strengthened by due process," when discussing Conyers, but has labeled Moore a "child molester."

This stance has been met with backlash, particularly from Republicans who argue that the political establishment selectively applies standards of conduct to delegitimize and destroy their enemies while exempting their own. Many conservatives have used this perceived double standard as a justification for dismissing allegations of sexual abuse against Trump and Moore.

The controversy surrounding Pelosi's comments extends beyond the political sphere, as she is a vocal supporter of Title IX regulations, which have been used to dismantle due process for sexual assault allegations on college campuses. When Education Secretary Betsy DeVos introduced reforms to Title IX, Pelosi denounced them as "outrageous, immoral attacks on Title IX protections" and a "shocking attack on women."

In response to the ongoing partisan hypocrisy, some have suggested a return to the concept of the "original position," a thought experiment proposed by philosopher John Rawls. This thought experiment imagines individuals in a state of limbo, hidden behind a "veil of ignorance," with no knowledge of their future identity or circumstances. The goal is to consider what fair rules for society would look like if one were to be born into any number of possible circumstances.

The original position is intended to encourage a focus on fairness and equality, as individuals would be forced to consider the potential impact of rules on all members of society, regardless of their own identity or circumstances. In a time marked by tribalism and identity politics, the original position offers a potential way out of the current political impasse, by encouraging a focus on fairness and equality for all, rather than favoring one's own tribe.

Title: Obama Urges House Republicans to Pass "Clean" Spending Bill to End Government Shutdown

Article:

President Obama, in his weekly radio and internet address on Saturday, called on House Republicans to immediately pass a "clean" spending bill to end the ongoing federal government shutdown, now in its second week. The President read two letters he received from individuals affected by the shutdown, highlighting the real-world consequences of the impasse in Washington.

An Alabama woman shared her story of a closed Head Start agency, while a North Dakota family was cited as being in danger of losing their federal home loan due to the government closure. The President's strategy aims to pressure Congress to act.

"There's only one way out of this reckless and damaging shutdown: pass a budget that funds our government, with no partisan strings attached," Obama said. "There are enough Republican and Democratic votes in the House of Representatives...to end this shutdown immediately. But the far right of the Republican party won't let Speaker John Boehner give that bill a yes-or-no vote."

The White House has been attempting to create a rift among House Republicans, pitting moderate members against their tea party counterparts. The administration argues that a "clean" spending bill, one that doesn't include measures to repeal, delay, or defund Obamacare, could pass the House with bipartisan support.

However, Speaker Boehner has yet to allow such a bill to come up for a vote. As the shutdown crisis, the first in 17 years, continues, the President has escalated his rhetoric.

"The American people don't get to demand ransom in exchange for doing their job. Neither does Congress," Obama said. "They don't get to hold our democracy or our economy hostage over a settled law."

With the shutdown ongoing, the President is also looking ahead to the expected U.S. reaching its "debt ceiling" in late October or early November. Analysts predict the economic damage from a default will be worse than the current shutdown.

"For as reckless as a government shutdown is, an economic shutdown that comes with default would be dramatically worse," Obama said.

Title: Diverse Interpretations of Martin Luther King Jr.'s Legacy on the 50th Anniversary of His March on Washington

Article:

The 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s historic march on Washington has sparked a multitude of events and discussions, with various groups using the occasion to advocate for their respective causes. From gun control to D.C. statehood, the Republican National Committee's outreach to African-Americans, and economic rights, the anniversary has become a platform for a wide range of issues.

The commemorations began on Saturday with a march retracing the 1963 route, and will continue on Wednesday with speeches at the Lincoln Memorial. The anniversary, however, has also exposed disagreement over the interpretation of King's legacy and the meaning of continuing his movement.

Martin Luther King III, the civil rights leader's oldest living child, expressed that he is not concerned about the dilution of his father's core message. Instead, he aims to "arouse a new coalition of conscience" that can counter the energy of the tea party movement. King III attributes the recent Supreme Court ruling dismantling a key part of the Voting Rights Act, rising income inequality, and the Trayvon Martin shooting as reminders of the need for continued activism.

Alveda King, Martin Luther King Jr.'s niece, has expressed concern that tying specific social causes to her uncle diminishes his overarching significance. She emphasizes that her uncle was "an imperfect human who served a perfect God" and wants the celebrations to focus on a unifying message of love.

One contentious issue is the debate over whether King would have embraced gay marriage as the next frontier for civil rights. The gay community has closely aligned itself with the tributes, with multiple events honoring Bayard Rustin, who was openly gay and helped organize the 1963 march. A coalition of over 40 groups signed an open letter calling for "clear federal laws barring discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity."

President Barack Obama endorsed gay marriage last year, and the NAACP followed suit shortly after. However, many African-Americans still oppose gay marriage. Grammy-winning gospel singer Donnie McClurkin was uninvited from a concert at the King Memorial after a few activists complained about his past comments regarding homosexuality. McClurkin described the incident as "bullying...discrimination...intolerance," and a "civil rights infringement."

King himself never spoke out firmly for or against gays. The Supreme Court did not even strike down laws banning interracial marriage until 1967. Coretta Scott King, King's wife, stated before her death that she believed her husband would have supported gay rights.

Title: Bernie Sanders' Millionaire Status and the Fox News Town Hall

Article:

Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist and a millionaire, has faced criticism from some quarters for his wealth despite his political ideology. However, his supporters argue that his millionaire status does not diminish the potency of his ideas and policy proposals. The recent Fox News town hall was considered a success by Sanders' camp, with the candidate focusing on issues affecting the working class and offering policy solutions.

Sanders' critique of wealth accumulation in the hands of a small elite is rooted in the disproportionate political power wielded by the super-rich, who fund campaigns and lobby politicians. Sanders' campaign, which is funded by small donors, does not seem to contradict this argument, as he has not amassed his wealth through such means.

The controversy surrounding the wealth of politicians and ex-politicians, particularly their methods of capitalizing on their fame, is a point of contention. For instance, the practice of giving speeches at big Wall Street banks is criticized for potential corruption, with bankers allegedly paying for access to potential future senators and presidents.

A minority view suggests that Sanders is not a hypocrite due to his genuine disdain for charity and the belief that the wealthy should use their resources to alleviate social evils. However, critics argue that the wealthy, with their resources, could significantly improve living conditions for many, making the choice not to do so questionable.

Regarding the Fox News town hall, it was praised for Sanders' ability to rally a majority of Americans, offering a contrast to President Trump's right-populism and a potential formula for winning an election.

In a separate development, a summary of a call between President Trump and Ukraine's president has raised concerns about potential wrongdoing. The call, which reportedly shows Trump using his conversation to pursue unsubstantiated conspiracy theories and engaging in a quid pro quo, is being investigated for potential impeachable offenses. Trump's defenders argue that the evidence is circumstantial, but experts suggest that circumstantial evidence can be strong evidence and can be used to prove a criminal exchange. The focus of the investigation will be on the context and circumstances surrounding the call.

Title: East Coast Storm Disrupts Political Campaigns, Virginia Governor Plans to Keep Voting Machines Running

Article:

The approach of a significant storm along the East Coast has led to the cancellation of political campaign events. The unpredictable weather conditions have left even seasoned political strategists uncertain about the impact on the final week of the campaign.

President Barack Obama, in response to the potential disaster, has canceled his campaign trips to the swing states of Florida and Colorado. He has moved to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to be seen as a president actively engaged in emergency response efforts.

"It's so important for us to respond big and respond fast as local information starts coming in," President Obama said at FEMA.

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney has also canceled appearances in the weather-threatened swing state of Virginia, as well as the president, to avoid consuming resources and to not interfere with storm preparations.

Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell has stated that the state board of elections is already planning for extended hours for absentee voting and prioritizing power restoration for voting facilities, moving them to the same level as hospitals and police stations.

In states where polls are already open, such as Maryland, early voting has been canceled for Monday. The impact of these weather-induced pauses on the election campaigns remains uncertain.

David Axelrod, senior adviser to President Obama, expressed concern about the potential difficulties in accessing the polls, stating, "Obviously we want unfettered access to the polls because we believe that the more people come out, the better we'll do, and so to the extent that it makes it harder, you know, that's a source of concern."

The Romney-Ryan ticket, not in power, is limited in their ability to respond but still needs to remain attentive. Romney has expressed concern for those in the path of the storm and has taken steps such as stopping fundraising emails in affected states, making a campaign bus available for relief efforts, and setting up a blog with weather-related advice.

The Romney campaign is also monitoring the situation closely, with a top Republican noting that the schedule may change based on the storm's progression. Mixing politics and weather is a complex situation, as one can never predict the exact impact of a natural disaster on campaigning.

Title: Barnum's Animal Crackers Reimagines Packaging, Depicts Animals in Natural Habitat

Article:

In a move towards cultural evolution and animal rights awareness, the packaging for Barnum's Animal Crackers has undergone a significant transformation. For over a century, the iconic box depicted lions, tigers, and bears confined within a circus boxcar. However, this imagery is now a thing of the past, as the animals are now shown in their natural habitats.

Kimberly Fontes, a spokeswoman for Mondelez International, the parent company of Nabisco, explained the decision, stating, "To continue to make the brand relevant for years to come, we felt this was the right time for the next evolution in our design." The new design depicts the animals standing shoulder to shoulder, proudly walking in the wild. The packaging reads, "NEW LOOK, Same Great Taste!"

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) had long advocated for a change in the design. The group has been opposed to the use of animals in circuses for decades, as reported by NPR. Last year, Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus announced its closure after nearly 150 years due to pressure from animal rights groups and declining ticket sales.

In 2015, the circus made the decision to stop using elephants in its shows, one of the reasons the company believed attendance was dropping. For PETA, the new box design signifies a cultural shift. "Big victories can come in small packages," PETA said in a statement, "and no matter where we look, we find new evidence that people are embracing compassion for animals like never before."

PETA participated in discussions with the company regarding the redesign and praised the new box design, stating, "The new box for Barnum's Animals perfectly reflects that our society no longer tolerates caging and chaining exotic animals for circus shows." The group further added, "No living being exists simply to be a spectacle or to perform tricks for human entertainment, yet all circuses and traveling shows that use animals treat them as mere props, denying them everything that's natural and important to them."

Mondelez International has previously used its classic design to drive awareness around key animal and environmental issues, as noted by The Associated Press. Examples of these "limited-time special editions" include packaging that featured endangered species and encouraged conservation efforts.

Title: House Rules Committee Finds Speaker Pelosi's Criticism of President Trump Violates Chamber's Rules

Article:

The House of Representatives ruled on Tuesday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi's criticism of President Trump violated the chamber's rules. The ruling came in a 232-190 vote, with members choosing to keep her words in the official record. The House also allowed Pelosi to continue debating on the House floor in a 231-190 vote.

Majority Leader Steny H. Hoyer, who took over the gavel to make the announcement, stated that Pelosi's words contained an accusation of racist behavior on the part of the president. He said, "The words used by the gentlewoman from California contained an accusation of racist behavior on the part of the president. The words should not be used in debate."

Pelosi, the top-ranking House Democrat, had previously called President Trump's comments about four freshman congresswomen—Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts, and Rashida Tlaib of Michigan—"divisive and dangerous" to the country.

House GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy stated that Pelosi could have just taken back her words and apologized. "What we just saw was a very sad day in this House—probably a historic day—so the very person who is supposed to uphold the rules broke the rules of the House," the California Republican told reporters.

Following the vote, Pelosi told reporters that she stood by her statement. "I'm proud of the attention that is being called to it because what the president said was completely inappropriate against our colleagues, but not just against them, but against so many people in our country to say, 'Go back where you came from,'" the California Democrat said.

The rules, which trace back to Thomas Jefferson's writings, allow members to criticize the government or the president on the House floor in an official capacity, but they are prohibited from using language that is "personally offensive" to the president. For example, lawmakers cannot call the president a liar or hypocrite.

On the matter of racial rhetoric, Jefferson's Manual explicitly states that any reference to "racial or other discrimination on the Part of the President" is not allowed. According to the Congressional Research Service, Pelosi could be punished by being barred from speaking on the floor for the rest of the day. Several other warnings about this rule, which also extends to other members of Congress, had to be issued throughout the debate.

However, earlier Tuesday, Hoyer argued that the resolution itself wouldn't cross any lines because the criticism was aimed at tweets, not the president. "We're condemning the language that was used, not the president himself," he said.

Rep. Emanuel Cleaver, who was serving as chairman, stepped down out of frustration. "Unfairness is not enough because we want to just fight," the Missouri Democrat said before dropping the gavel. Cleaver continued to express his frustration with reporters after the vote, saying he was trying to be fair and not escalate complaints from either side of the aisle.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul to Attend President Obama's Promise Zone Announcement

Article:

Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.), known for his frequent disagreements with President Obama, is among a bipartisan group of senators expected to attend the president's announcement on Thursday regarding the designation of "Promise Zones" to aid communities in addressing poverty.

Paul is also anticipated to join Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell and other lawmakers in a private meeting with the president at the White House prior to the announcement, an aide for Paul confirmed to Fox News.

Though Paul's presence may seem unexpected, the conservative senator recently introduced separate legislation to establish "economic freedom zones" in struggling cities like Detroit, where taxes and bureaucratic hurdles would be reduced to foster growth.

In response to the announcement, Paul told Fox News, "They say the sincerest form of flattery is imitation," confirming his attendance at the White House on Thursday. However, he questioned why the president's plan does not include Detroit, as his does.

President Obama's announcement is part of a focus on income inequality in the lead-up to his State of the Union address. Promise Zones are areas where the federal government offers tax incentives and grants. Obama first announced the initiative during last year's State of the Union speech.

An eight-county region of southeastern Kentucky will be among five locations that Obama will announce this week as "Promise Zones." The president's proposed zones also include San Antonio, Texas; Philadelphia; Los Angeles; and the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma.

The Paul invitation could signal another Obama "charm offensive" to engage with Republicans, as he did early in 2013 in an attempt, unsuccessfully, to achieve a "grand bargain" budget deal.

Paul, who has recently launched a class-action lawsuit against the administration over the National Security Agency's spying practices and has pressed Obama on various issues, including a filibuster over his drone policy, may prove an elusive legislative partner.

Senator McConnell (R-Ky.) said in a statement Wednesday that he was pleased the Obama administration decided to include Eastern Kentucky in its promise zone designation.

"I wrote a letter last year supporting this designation because this region has suffered enormous economic hardship over the last several years," McConnell said. "Thousands of jobs have been lost and economic opportunity is extremely limited, particularly because of this administration's hostile policies toward the coal industry."

Title: White House Response to Global White Supremacy: A Closer Look at Trump Administration's Actions and Statements

Article:

Last Friday, a reporter at the White House asked President Donald Trump if he believed that white nationalism was a growing threat around the world. Trump responded, "I don't, really. I think it's a small group of people." This statement came after a gunman killed 50 Muslims in Christchurch, New Zealand, and the White House advisor Kellyanne Conway dismissed the alleged shooter's murderous racism, labeling him an "eco-terrorist."

Two days later, the acting White House chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, appeared on Fox News Sunday. Chris Wallace, the host, asked Mulvaney if the president "had considered giving a major speech condemning anti-Muslim, white supremacist bigotry." Mulvaney responded, "The president is not a white supremacist."

Despite these denials, the president's record speaks louder than any words. Trump may try to evade the issue, but the fact remains that a dangerous and global white supremacy is on the march, and Trump himself is at least partly to blame.

In January 2017, a man stormed a mosque in Quebec City and shot six people dead while they prayed. An ardent Trump supporter, the man said he was afraid that refugees coming to Canada were a threat to him and his family. The New Zealand shooter scrawled the Quebec City shooter's name on one of his ammunition cartridges and directly applauded Trump in his own manifesto.

According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), far-right attacks in Europe have jumped 43% between 2016 and 2017. On the domestic front, the rise is even more disturbing. According to CSIS, the number of terrorist attacks by far-right perpetrators in the United States more than quadrupled between 2016 and 2017.

The intimate connections between the president and white nationalists are well known. In 2017, the president refused to condemn the white nationalists who marched through the streets of Charlottesville, Virginia, screaming such disgusting nonsense as "Jews will not replace us." Heather Heyer, a counter-protester, was also killed during the rally. Days later, the president defended the marchers and claimed that there were "some very fine people on both sides" of that rally.

In 2015, Trump stated, "I think Islam hates us" during a CNN interview while on the campaign trail. The number of organized anti-Muslim hate groups nearly tripled in 2017, a rise that the Southern Poverty Law Center credited in part to the "incendiary rhetoric" of Trump.

Hate crimes generally have risen precipitously since Trump appeared on the national political stage. Nationwide, hate crimes across the board rose by 17% in 2017, according to FBI statistics, the third year in a row to see an uptick (2018 numbers are not yet available).

The president's actions and statements have been criticized for emboldening a racist and extremist fringe. Trump's political responsibility for the rise in white supremacy and hate crimes is a matter of debate, but his words and actions have been closely linked to these incidents. The president sets the national tone for what is permissible speech and impermissible speech in the political arena. Trump, on the other hand, merely revels in the impermissible.

Title: Four Killed, Including Shooter, in Gilroy Garlic Festival Shooting; At Least 12 Injured

Article:

A shooting at the annual Gilroy Garlic Festival in Christmas Hill Park, Gilroy, California, on Sunday resulted in four fatalities, including the shooter, and at least 12 injuries. The suspect, identified by CBS as Santino William Legan, 19, was shot and killed by police at the scene.

City officials in Gilroy, located about 33 miles south of San Jose, stated that witnesses indicated there may have been a second suspect, and a search is underway for that person, though it's unclear if the second possible suspect actually fired shots or assisted the gunman in some other way.

The gunman used an assault-style rifle and started firing around 5:41 pm local time. One witness, who spoke to a local NBC station, described the shooter as wearing Army fatigues and "rose his gun up, and, just, started spraying out rounds." Another witness told the Washington Post the man was shooting "left to right and right to left."

Police on the scene engaged the shooter within one minute, according to Gilroy Police Chief Scot Smithee, and shot the suspect dead. Security at the event was tight and included bag searches and metal detector wands. Smithee said investigators believe the shooter entered the festival by cutting through a perimeter fence.

Festivalgoers fled in panic, and shots rang out. Videos of the chaotic scene were posted to Twitter.

> somebody was shooting at the gilroy garlic festival. be safe pic.twitter.com/B39ZIYe8wr
>
> — niah ㊝ (@wavyia) July 29, 2019

> # BREAKING: Video shows moment gunman opens fire on Gilroy garlic festival Sunday evening; 4 people killed (including suspected gunman), 15 others injured. [Warning: Potentially-distressing footage] # GilroyGarlicFestival # GilroyActiveshooter pic.twitter.com/Qiv7GW3j4V
>
> — California Brief (@CaliforniaBrief) July 29, 2019

One of the victims was a 6-year-old boy named Stephen Romero. NBC reports that the two other victims were a 13-year-old girl and a man in his 20s. Their names have not yet been released.

A witness who had a brief interaction with the shooter said they asked him, "Why are you doing this?" According to the Associated Press, the witness said the shooter replied by saying, "Because I'm really angry."

Heavy tracked down an Instagram page that reportedly belongs to the shooter. According to Heavy, one post from the Instagram page posted just before the shooting recommends a book that promotes racist and misogynistic principles.

Title: Trump's Decision to Withdraw U.S. Troops from Syria Stuns Turkey, Leaves Middle East in Flux

Article:

President Donald Trump's announcement during a phone call with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan that he was withdrawing U.S. troops from Syria has left Turkey scrambling to respond to the changing battlefield on its southern border. In the phone call two weeks ago, Trump was expected to deliver a standard warning to Erdogan over his plan to launch a cross-border attack targeting U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in northeast Syria, according to U.S. officials. Instead, Trump reshaped U.S. policy in the Middle East, abandoning a quarter of Syrian territory and handing Ankara the job of finishing off Islamic State in Syria.

In the Dec. 14 call between the two leaders, Trump asked, "If we withdraw our soldiers, can you clean up ISIS?" Erdogan replied that Turkish forces were capable of the task. "Then you do it," Trump responded abruptly. To his national security adviser John Bolton, also on the call, Trump said, "Start work for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria."

Turkish officials described the decision as "unexpected" and "a shock." The U.S. withdrawal potentially frees Turkey's military to push the Kurdish YPG militia back from 500 km of border without risking a confrontation with American forces. However, it also opens up an area of Syria far larger than anything Turkey had expected to fill, potentially pitting it against not just Kurdish forces but also the Damascus government, which is committed to regaining control of all of Syria, and its Russian and Iranian backers.

The YPG, on Friday, asked the Syrian government to take over the town of Manbij, which the Kurdish militia currently controls with U.S. support, to protect it from Turkish attack. If Turkish forces are to take on Islamic State in its last pocket of Syrian territory near the Iraqi border, they would first have to cross 250 km of territory controlled by the Kurdish-dominated Syrian Democratic Forces.

As it takes stock of the new challenge, Turkey is launching intensive talks with Washington and Moscow. Ankara expects U.S. military officials to visit within days, as well as Bolton and possibly the U.S. special Syria envoy, James Jeffrey. Turkey's intelligence chief and defense and foreign ministers are also due in Moscow on Saturday.

Washington is also grappling with what to do with weapons it provided to the YPG militia and promised to take back after the campaign against Islamic State ended. Turkey says the weapons must be collected so they are not used against Turkish troops, but U.S. officials say they cannot disarm their own allies when the fight is not yet over.

Erdogan announced last week that Turkey is postponing its planned military operation against the YPG in light of Trump's decision. The Turkish military has already carried out two incursions into northern Syria, backed by pro-Turkey Syrian rebels. In 2016, they targeted Islamic State and Kurdish fighters, and earlier this year took control of the YPG-held Afrin region. However, Ankara and its Syrian rebel allies alone do not have the capacity to take over the whole region which the United States is abandoning. Turkey's priority, therefore, may be to secure its southern frontier.

Title: House Majority Whip Steve Scalise Shot in Virginia; Gunman Identified as James T. Hodgkinson

Article:

In a shocking incident, House Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-LA) was shot and wounded during a congressional baseball practice in Northern Virginia on Wednesday morning. Scalise, who is the third-highest-ranking House Republican, was hit in the hip and underwent surgery at MedStar Washington Hospital Center, where he remains in critical condition.

Four others, including a congressional staffer, a lobbyist, and two members of the Capitol Police, were also injured in the attack. The shooter, identified as James T. Hodgkinson, a 66-year-old man from Illinois, was taken to a hospital after being shot by police during the attack and died of multiple gunshot wounds to the torso on Wednesday.

The shooting occurred during an early morning practice for an annual charity baseball game near Eugene Simpson Stadium Park in Alexandria, Virginia. The game, a partisan match between Democratic and Republican lawmakers, had been scheduled for Thursday evening.

As of Friday afternoon, Scalise remains in intensive care, and his condition is described as "critical" by Dr. Jack Sava of MedStar. Sava said that Scalise will "hopefully" be able to walk and run again at some point in the future, but there isn't yet a timetable for his recovery.

The FBI and the Alexandria Police Department are actively investigating Hodgkinson, including his associates, whereabouts, social media impressions, and potential motivations. The ATF is also running a trace on two weapons, including a 9 mm handgun and a 7.62 caliber rifle, according to Capitol Police.

The FBI and Alexandria Police released the following account of the incident: At approximately 7:09 a.m. on June 14, the Alexandria Police Department responded to the scene at 400 East Monroe Avenue in Alexandria, Virginia. They arrived at 7:12 a.m. to shots fired in the vicinity of Eugene Simpson Stadium Park, where members of a congressional baseball team were practicing. Multiple members of Congress were present on the scene, resulting in United States Capitol Police officers also being on the scene. The subject was engaged by law enforcement and shot at approximately 7:14 a.m. Five individuals were transported by Alexandria EMS, Arlington County EMS, and U.S. Park Police helicopter to local hospitals with gunshot wounds. Those transported include a United States Capitol Police officer who is hospitalized and is reported to be in stable condition, a congressman, one congressional staffer, one lobbyist, and the subject. A second congressman sustained minor injuries and was also transported by a medic unit. One additional United States Capitol Police officer was transported to the hospital in a police cruiser for minor injuries and has been released.

The suspect, Hodgkinson, was taken to a hospital but died of his injuries on Wednesday morning, according to President Donald Trump and the FBI.

Rep. Mo Brooks (R-AL), who was at the scene, used his belt as a tourniquet to stop the bleeding from an unidentified victim, Brooks said on CNN. Rep. Brad Wenstrup (R-OH), who is a doctor, also tended to Scalise, Wenstrup told CBS News.

Zachary Barth, a staffer for Rep. Roger Williams (R-TX), posted on Facebook that he was among those shot but is "at the hospital and okay." Matt Mika, a lobbyist who is the director of government relations for Tyson Foods, was also shot in the attack, according to a Tyson Foods statement (and reported by NBC).

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-WI) identified Special Agent David Bailey and Special Agent Crystal Griner, both of Capitol Police, as other victims of the attack.

Five people, including the gunman, were transported to local hospitals, according to Alexandria Police Chief Michael Brown. George Washington University Hospital received two victims from the Alexandria shooting, both of whom were in critical condition as of Wednesday morning, according to Susan Griffiths, assistant director of marketing and public relations for the hospital. The hospital would not identify the patients, and it's not clear whether one of them was the shooter (who has since died) or whether they were both victims.

Special Agent Crystal Griner is also at MedStar Washington and is in good condition as of Friday afternoon, according to the hospital.

Police received a call reporting the shooting at around 7:09 am and arrived three minutes later, according to Brown. Brooks said he heard about 50 shots.

Two Alexandria police officers exchanged gunfire with the shooter, according to Alexandria Police Chief Michael Brown. Two Capitol Police officers, who were already at the scene with members of Congress, also exchanged gunfire with the shooter, according to Capitol Police Chief Matthew Verderosa.

The FBI took over the investigation, said Tim Slater, the special agent in charge of the bureau's Washington field office. "It's too early to tell" the motive of the shooter, he said during a press briefing, adding that he does not believe it was an assassination attempt.

Eyewitnesses, including Sen. Rand Paul (R-KY) and Flake, said that the officers were members of the Capitol Police force, which is specifically charged to protect Capitol Hill and individual members of the House and Senate leadership. "Had [Capitol Police] not been there, it would have been a massacre," who was at the scene said on MSNBC after the shooting.

Rep. Jeff Duncan (R-SC) said in a Facebook post that he saw the shooter before the attack and plans to give a statement to police. (It's not clear if Duncan is correct that the man he spoke to was the shooter; the way that Duncan described him, according to RealClearNews's Rebecca Berg, doesn't match up with the eyewitness description of the shooter provided by Flake.)

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Controversial Arizona Immigration Law's "Reasonable Suspicion" Provision

Article:

In a 5-3 ruling on Monday, the Supreme Court upheld the controversial "reasonable suspicion" provision of Arizona's immigration law, SB 1070. This provision allows law enforcement officers to question the immigration status of individuals they have reasonable grounds to suspect are in the country illegally and report their identities to federal authorities.

The law, signed by Arizona Governor Jan Brewer in 2010, had four main components. Three sections setting up state criminal penalties for immigration violations were struck down in the ruling. Justice Elena Kagan recused herself from the case.

President Obama and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., among others, had previously expressed concerns that the provision would lead to racial profiling. However, the Supreme Court's unanimous decision upheld this very provision, stating that it would provide police an opportunity to enforce the law without violating civil rights, given the uncertainty about the law's interpretation and enforcement.

Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the majority, stating, "There is a basic uncertainty about what the law means and how it will be enforced. At this stage, without the benefit of a definitive interpretation from the state courts, it would be inappropriate to assume [that section] will be construed in a way that creates a conflict with federal law."

In 2010, when Arizona enacted the law, both Mr. Obama and Mr. Holder expressed their concerns about racial profiling. Mr. Obama stated, "Now suddenly if you don't have your papers and you take your kid out for ice cream and you're going to be harassed—that's not the right way to go." Mr. Holder testified to Congress that he believed the law would lead to racial profiling, although he had not yet read the law at the time.

However, when the Justice Department filed its lawsuit challenging the law, it did not include the racial profiling argument, instead focusing on issues of federal versus state power over immigration. Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli stated during oral arguments in April, "We're not making any allegation about racial or ethnic profiling in the case."

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat who has emerged as a top voice for legalizing illegal immigrants, expressed concerns about racial profiling, stating, "Experience has shown us that police are highly unlikely to stop an individual with the last name of Kennedy or Roberts on suspicion of not being a legal U.S. citizen, but if you are a Gutierrez or Martinez, watch out."

In response, Mr. Holder stated his lawyers would closely monitor how Arizona and other states enforce these kinds of immigration status checks to ensure they do not discriminate against the Latino or any other community. The Supreme Court left open the possibility for further challenges if the law becomes discriminatory.

The court also expressed concerns about the potential for the law to unconstitutionally prolong the amount of time an officer detained someone during the status checks. However, the court acknowledged the possibility that the law could be implemented fairly.

In a statement on Monday, Ms. Brewer stated, "Our critics are already preparing new litigation tactics in response to their loss at the Supreme Court, and undoubtedly will allege inequities in the implementation of the law. As I said two years ago on the day I signed SB 1070 into law, 'We can not give them that chance. We must use this new tool wisely, and fight for our safety with the honor Arizona deserves.'"

Title: Reflection on the Iraq War: A Decade of Conflict and Its Aftermath

Article:

The United States' involvement in Iraq, which spanned over eight years, has come to be regarded as one of the longest wars in American history. The war, initiated under the pretext of destroying weapons of mass destruction, has resulted in thousands of American casualties, tens of thousands of wounded, and trillions of dollars in expenditure. The war's aftermath, however, has left little to show for these significant losses.

The primary reason for the war's failure, according to the article, is the fundamental cultural and societal differences between the Middle East and the West. The article argues that the Middle East perceives war as the default state, while peace is a temporary state that occurs between wars. In contrast, the West views peace as the norm, with war being a temporary state that occurs when peace fails.

The article highlights the Iraq War's missteps, starting with the questionable intelligence that led to the invasion. The war was initially won, but the peace-building process failed, leading to a resurgence of insurgency and the reemergence of Al-Qaeda in cities like Fallujah. The predominantly Shiite Iraqi government has vowed to retake the city, but the possibility of another civil war between Shiite and Sunni Arabs looms large.

The article emphasizes that the military's performance during the war was heroic, but it was the political leaders who failed the nation. The Iraq War was marked by tragic missteps, including the failure to anticipate the insurgency, the attempt to build a new democratic Iraqi state in the image of the West, and the premature withdrawal of American forces, leaving a fragile Iraq that was not ready to stand on its own.

The article concludes by acknowledging the tragic nature of the Iraq War but expresses optimism for the future. The author suggests that the United States will recover from the Iraq War, as it did from the failures of Vietnam, and will once again lead the world in the Energy Age. The hope is that the United States will learn from its mistakes and approach future conflicts more soberly, shrewdly, and strategically.

Title: Business Groups Lobby for TPP Approval Amidst Political Divide

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing political divide, business groups have launched a national effort to lobby for the approval of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade agreement spearheaded by former President Barack Obama. This push comes as both major political parties have expressed opposition to the deal during their respective party conventions.

Caterpillar Inc., a leading manufacturer, has hosted lawmakers such as Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland and Republican Rep. Erik Paulsen of Minnesota at its factories. These meetings aim to demonstrate the positive impact of the TPP on the company's workers.

Trade Benefits America, a leading business coalition, is coordinating a grassroots advertising campaign, sending approximately 60 to 70 pro-TPP letters to members of Congress daily. The Association of Equipment Manufacturers is also actively promoting the agreement through a truck tour across the Midwest, featuring interactive displays on trade. Additionally, they are running digital ads in key Senate races to highlight candidates' trade positions.

Kevin Madden, a strategist working with the Trade Benefits America coalition, emphasized the importance of these face-to-face interactions: "When you see trade, when it's just a sign being waved on a convention floor... that's one thing. But when it's somebody who has a small- or medium-size enterprise in your local economy, who is directly responsible for the employment of people whose jobs are tied to exporting... that has an impact on lawmakers, and that's important."

Leading supporters of the TPP remain optimistic, insisting that the agreement still has a chance of approval later this year despite opposition from both major-party presidential candidates and a majority of Democratic leadership outside of the White House. They point to opinion polls showing a majority of Americans support free trade and argue that the back-to-back party conventions have merely amplified a few anti-TPP voices that do not fully understand the agreement's facts.

Proponents of the TPP believe the issue could make it onto the crowded legislative agenda during the lame-duck period after the election. They are hoping to address the remaining concerns, such as protections for biologic drug firms and tobacco companies, in a similar manner to the financial services companies' issue, which was largely settled before the Republican convention.

If the administration can duplicate this success with the outstanding issues, it should still be possible to gather enough votes to pass the agreement, despite the challenging political environment, according to Bill Miller, a senior vice president in charge of lobbying operations at the Business Roundtable. Linda Dempsey, vice president of international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers, echoed this sentiment, stating, "It's not going to be easy, but it's certainly doable."

Lobbying groups are employing various strategies to connect with lawmakers, including writing op-eds, attending town halls, and flooding congressional offices with handwritten letters from company employees. John Michael Gonzalez, a Democratic lobbyist and strategist who works on trade, expressed optimism, stating, "From my experience, it always looks so bleak. But it always prevails. At the end of the day, our government and our elected officials move forward, not backwards."

Some groups are taking advantage of the summer recess to show lawmakers the importance of trade deals on their home turf. For instance, the agriculture community is using summer fairs to demonstrate the significance of trade deals. In mid-September, executives from the footwear industry plan to meet with lawmakers on Capitol Hill to emphasize the importance of the TPP, despite the negative rhetoric surrounding it.

Matt Priest, president of the Footwear Distributors and Retailers of America trade association, described the upcoming meetings as an "all-hands-on-deck moment." He added, "We can not leave any stone unturned, any email not sent or call not made."

Title: Court of Military Commission Review Overturns Conviction of Guantánamo Detainee

Article:

In a significant ruling, the Court of Military Commission Review has overturned the conviction of a Guantánamo detainee, Ahmed al-Darbi, who was accused of being part of Al Qaeda but not of plotting any specific terrorist attack. The decision, which was largely supported by three judges, including Judge Brett Kavanaugh, a former lawyer in the White House for President George W. Bush, has been hailed as a major blow to the legitimacy of the Guantánamo military commissions.

Al-Darbi, a Yemeni national, traveled from Yemen to Pakistan and then Afghanistan in 1996. He attended a Qaeda training camp, met Osama Bin Laden, and became a driver carrying jihadis and their weapons. He eventually drove Bin Laden personally and was told by Bin Laden several days before Sept. 11, 2001, that they would have to evacuate their compound because of an impending operation that might provoke retaliation.

Al-Darbi's legal journey began in 2001, after his capture in Afghanistan. He was sent to Guantánamo Bay soon after it opened in early 2002. His case proceeded slowly due to legal challenges to the Bush administration's new system of military commissions for terrorism suspects. He was charged with conspiracy as well as eight counts of material support in 2008. He was acquitted of the conspiracy charge, which might have produced a longer sentence. He was sentenced to 66 months of confinement and credited for having already served most of that time since being charged.

The verdict was a setback for the military prosecutors, who had contended that they could detain him indefinitely. Even after his release, he continued to challenge his conviction. The ruling was upheld in 2011 by the Court of Military Commission Review, but the Appeals Court has now reversed it.

Zachary Katznelson, senior staff attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union, said the decision "strikes the biggest blow yet against the legitimacy of the Guantánamo military commissions, which have for years now been trying people for a supposed war crime that in fact is not a war crime at all." He suggested that the government should prosecute in civilian courts any Guantánamo prisoners against whom it has enough admissible evidence.

The ruling calls into question whether other Guantánamo detainees accused of being part of Al Qaeda but not of plotting any specific terrorist attack can receive military trials. The decision is likely to have far-reaching implications for the future of the Guantánamo military commissions and the treatment of detainees.

Title: Nationwide Commemorations Mark 50 Years Since JFK Assassination

Article:

As the United States commemorates the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, cities across the nation are hosting events to honor the late president. In Dallas, where the assassination occurred, a public event will take place on Friday, Dealey Plaza, the site of the tragic event.

The commemoration will feature Pulitzer Prize-winning presidential historian David McCullough, who will read excerpts from Kennedy's presidential speeches. The U.S. Naval Academy Men's Glee Club will perform, and religious leaders will offer prayers and a benediction. Approximately 5,000 tickets have been issued for this event.

The Texas Theatre in Dallas will offer a partial screening of the film "War is Hell," which was being shown in the theater when Lee Harvey Oswald, Kennedy's killer, sneaked in after the assassination. The film will be shown at 1:20 p.m. on Friday, with approximately 40 minutes of the original film being shown due to its loss. Admission is 90 cents, the price of a ticket in 1963.

In Washington, D.C., the Newseum will host "JFK Remembrance Day" on Friday, featuring a rebroadcast of three hours of CBS News' live television coverage of the assassination. President Obama will give a speech at the Smithsonian American History Museum on Wednesday evening on Kennedy's legacy of service. On Friday, he will meet privately with leaders and volunteers from the Peace Corps, an organization Kennedy established in 1961.

The Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, where Kennedy's funeral took place, will host a Choral Mass of Remembrance on Friday. Arlington National Cemetery's eternal flame at Kennedy's grave site was restored last month and is open to the public, with large crowds expected over the anniversary weekend. President Obama will visit the grave on Wednesday, accompanied by First Lady Michelle Obama, former President Bill Clinton, and former First Lady and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

In Brookline, Massachusetts, the John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site, the neighborhood and house where the president spent his childhood, will provide free admission to the public on Saturday and Sunday. A brief memorial ceremony will be held at the president's birthplace at 2 p.m. on Sunday, including a reading of President Lyndon Johnson's 1963 National Day of Mourning Proclamation and a wreath-laying.

John F. Kennedy University in Pleasant Hill, California, the only university in the country with Kennedy's name, will hold a memorial on Friday, including an unveiling of a bust of Kennedy and the announcement of a project for students to honor the president's service legacy.

In Chicago, city and state flags will fly at half-staff on Friday, with a citywide moment of silence at 1 p.m, and church bells to toll to commemorate the assassination of the president. In Dearborn, Michigan, the 1961 Lincoln Continental that carried Kennedy through Dallas on the day he was assassinated is on permanent display at The Henry Ford Museum. The museum offers special programs this week, including sold-out events with newscaster Dan Rather, who covered the assassination, and former Secret Service agent Clint Hill, who was on duty that day in Dallas.

Kennedy's last official act as president took place in San Antonio, where he dedicated buildings at the Brooks Air Force Base School of Aerospace Medicine and gave his "Cap over the Wall" speech, one day before his death. Brooks City-Base will hold a commemorative event at the same place the president spoke at 2510 Kennedy Circle on Thursday at 2 p.m. The event is free and open to the public, with remarks by San Antonio Mayor Julián Castro and Bexar County Judge Nelson Wolff. A commemorative video of the speech, along with historic photos, will also be presented.

Title: Federal School Safety Commission Recommends Rescinding Discipline Guidance, Emphasizes Mental Health Services and Armed Personnel

Article:

The Federal Commission on School Safety, established in response to the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida, has concluded that a top recommendation to prevent mass shootings is to rescind policies protecting minority students from disproportionate discipline. The commission's nearly 200-page report, released on Tuesday, offers guidelines on school safety, mental health services, and the potential arming of "highly trained school personnel" in certain circumstances.

The report, which avoids discussing gun laws and does not recommend arming teachers, suggests that schools review their infrastructure security and, in some instances, have someone on school grounds armed with a firearm to collaborate with law enforcement. The commission also recommends increased coordination between schools and local law enforcement, hiring military veterans or retired law enforcement officers into school roles, and ensuring students have better access to mental health services at school.

The report encourages news outlets to be more responsible in their coverage of school shootings, suggesting they should not publish pictures of the perpetrator. The commission also recommends social and emotional learning for students, and suggests states consider adopting "extreme risk protection orders" that would temporarily withhold guns from those who pose a risk to themselves or others.

President Trump hosted the commissioners and people affected by school shootings at the White House on Tuesday, with Trump calling the report "a very important thing." The report has received mixed reactions from families affected by school shootings, with some praising its comprehensive approach to school safety, while others criticize the report for not addressing the role of guns in school shootings.

Andy Pollack, whose daughter Meadow died in Parkland, called the report "the most comprehensive report by any administration on a school shooting." Lori Alhadeff, the mother of 14-year-old Parkland victim Alyssa, praised the commission's findings, while Fred Guttenberg, whose daughter Jaime Guttenberg, 14, was killed in Parkland, expressed concern over the report's lack of discussion on the role of guns in school shootings.

Mark Barden, whose son Daniel was one of the 20 first-graders killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, issued a statement praising the report's emphasis on mental health services, but expressed concern over the commission's continued support for arming school personnel. Barden stated, "We believe that teachers and school administrators should be focused on education, not weapons training."

The commission's report is a significant step in the ongoing national conversation on school safety, with many families affected by school shootings offering their perspectives on the report's recommendations. The report's ultimate impact on school safety policies remains to be seen.

Title: ObamaCare Exchanges May Limit Access to Doctors, Analogized to Medicaid

Article:

As the enrollment for private health care coverage on the ObamaCare exchanges begins on January 1, analysts are warning that the plans may provide limited access to doctors and hospitals. This could potentially lead to a system that resembles Medicaid, the health care program for low-income Americans.

Merrill Matthews, director of the Council for Affordable Health Insurance, stated, "Indeed, I think this will eventually be like Medicaid." He explained that insurers may control costs by "simply clamping down on the amount they are willing to pay."

Analysts warn that if payments get too low, many doctors might refuse to see patients, leaving more and more patients competing for fewer and fewer doctors. James Capretta, of the Ethics and Public Policy Center, noted, "About half of the physicians in many communities refuse to take Medicaid patients because the payment system is just too low."

Doug Holtz-Eakin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, suggested that some plans on the exchanges are heading in the same direction. He stated, "If you look at something where you get a dollar by treating a private payer, you get about 70 cents out of Medicare for that same treatment, you get about 55 cents out of Medicaid for that, ObamCare started to look like Medicaid of the future, and in the Medicaid in the present, you can have the insurance but a doctor won't see you."

By the end of March, the Obama administration hopes to increase the number of people on Medicaid by 9 million, and the number in private plans by 7 million. New Medicaid enrollments have far outpaced enrollments in private plans on the exchanges. However, since Medicaid patients already have access to relatively few doctors, expanding that population while opening the door to lower payments for private insurance raises the prospect of rationing, as too many people chase too few doctors.

Robert Laszewski, president of Health Policy and Strategy Associates, stated, "These networks are going to be jammed with people. Far more than they're treating now, and I do not doubt that we're going to have problems with access to these doctors. There just aren't going to be enough of them."

For now, the Obama administration is trying to move past a year of some ups and many downs for its health care law and encourage people to sign up during the final three months of open enrollment. President Obama stated in his year-end press conference that enrollment has picked up considerably as problems with the federal exchange website have been addressed. "The law is working: More than half a million Americans have enrolled through HealthCare.gov in the first three weeks of December alone -- and 800,000 more are on track to get Medicaid through their states," he said in an email message on Sunday. Obama continued to stress that the law is providing health insurance to those previously unable to get it. "Now, thousands of Americans are signing up for coverage every day. That matters. It means financial security for families all across the country. It means freedom from the fear that one illness or accident might cost you everything you've worked so hard to build."

Title: Biden's Focus Shifts to Trump as Sanders Chapter Closes in Democratic Race

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden, in a speech in Henderson, Nevada on February 14, 2020, emphasized the need to replace President Donald Trump as the unifying message for his potential voters. Despite Biden's decisive victory in the February 19 debate, further debates within the Democratic Party may be canceled, and Biden does not need to engage with his opponents anymore, according to the article.

The article suggests that Biden's strategy of limited speaking time in previous debates, which was intended to minimize gaffes and Bidenisms, worked against Senator Bernie Sanders during their one-on-one matchup. Sanders' disciplined and focused performance in earlier debates appeared repetitive and canned in the one-on-one format, with Sanders seeming older and less energetic compared to Biden for the first 45 minutes.

The article criticizes the debate as being uninspiring and filled with senatorial arguments that resembled a dispute over restaurant tips. The author also notes that Biden does not need to engage with Sanders anymore, as Sanders has become a single-issue candidate after losing the Super Tuesday primary.

The article criticizes Sanders for his response to the coronavirus pandemic, stating that his emphasis on the weaknesses of the current healthcare system and his attacks on the "health-care industry" were ill-timed and tone-deaf during a public-health emergency. The article also criticizes Sanders for using the economic consequences of the pandemic as an opportunity to replay his message on income inequality, arguing that voters want more immediate and practical solutions rather than ideological debates.

The article suggests that Biden's focus on replacing Trump is the unifying message for his potential voters, and that letting Sanders pull him to the left would be a mistake. The author argues that Biden should use every opportunity to turn the question to the imperative of replacing Trump, rather than engaging in debates about the direction of the Democratic Party. The article concludes by stating that the Sanders chapter is over, and the general election has begun.

Title: Trump Announces Increased Tariffs on Turkish Steel and Aluminum

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Friday that he would increase tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Turkey, citing the depreciation of the Turkish Lira against the U.S. dollar. The new tariffs will see aluminum duties rise to 20 percent and steel to 50 percent.

In a series of tweets, Trump stated, "I have just authorized a doubling of Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum with respect to Turkey as their currency, the Turkish Lira, slides rapidly downward against our very strong Dollar!" He added, "Our relations with Turkey are not good at this time!"

The tariff threat comes less than a week after the Trump administration imposed sanctions on Turkish officials over the imprisonment of American pastor Andrew Brunson, who has been detained in Turkey since 2016. The sanctions targeted Turkey's Minister of Justice, Abdulhamit Gul, and Minister of Interior, Suleyman Soylu.

Bulent Aliriza, an expert on Turkey with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington-based think tank, said Trump's latest decision to escalate tariffs will push Turkey's economy "into more difficult waters."

White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said Trump "has authorized the preparation of documents" to raise steel and aluminum tariffs on Turkey, citing a section of the U.S. trade law that allows penalties "on imports from particular countries whose exports threaten to impair national security."

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan responded defiantly to Trump's announcement on Friday. "We will not lose the economic war," Erdogan said during a tour of Black Sea provinces, according to the Hurriyet Daily News, an English language outlet. "This is a national struggle."

Ruhsar Pekcan, Turkey's trade minister, said Trump's decision would harm U.S. companies and consumers. "Turkey is deeply disappointed by the U.S. Administration’s decision to double steel and aluminum tariffs. The tariffs were groundless when they were announced in June, and remain so now," Pekcan said.

Aliriza said Trump's move will strengthen Erdogan in the short run, because it allows him to fan existing anti-American sentiment in Turkey. "It's difficult to be optimistic" about reaching a resolution to the standoff and lowering tensions between the two countries, he said.

The proposed tariff hikes come just days after Turkey's deputy foreign minister was in Washington to meet with U.S. officials on a range of contentious issues, including Brunson's detention. State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert declined to detail those conversations during a briefing with reporters on Thursday.

"Obviously you all know that we have a very broad relationship with Turkey and a host of issues that we talk about with the Turkish government whenever we do meet," Nauert said Thursday. "Yesterday we had a wide-ranging conversation with Turkish government officials. We made it clear that Pastor Brunson needs to be returned home."

She declined to say whether the two sides made any progress on the release of Brunson. "We would define progress as Pastor Brunson being brought home," she said.

More: Trump administration sanctions Turkish officials over American pastor's arrest

Previously, Trump has used tariffs against countries he claims are engaging in unfair trade practices against the United States. The action against Turkey appears to flow from political differences between the two countries, particularly the Brunson case.

Turkey accuses Brunson, arrested in 2016, of being a spy and says he was involved in an attempted coup. The United States says he has been falsely charged. Trump has discussed the Brunson case with Erdogan but has been unable to obtain the pastor's release.

Erdogan said last week that U.S. sanctions will not affect the Brunson case. "We will not give any credit to this type of threatening language," Erdogan told reporters Wednesday in Ankara. "It is not possible for us to accept that America gets up, especially with an evangelist, Zionist mentality, and uses this kind of threat-filled language."

Title: Ellen DeGeneres and George W. Bush Share Friendship Amidst Controversy

Article:

Ellen DeGeneres, a popular television host, attended a Dallas Cowboys football game on Sunday, where she was seated next to former President George W. Bush. The pair was joined by their respective partners, Portia de Rossi and Laura Bush, during the game.

The unexpected friendship between DeGeneres and Bush sparked controversy on social media, with some expressing their disapproval of the pair's camaraderie. Tweets criticizing the friendship included:

- Hasan Abi (@hasanthehun, October 8, 2019): "Ellen DeGeneres is rehabilitating a war criminal, and any liberal who buys into the lie that GWB is a sweet old man is a trog."
- Oliver Willis (@owillis, October 8, 2019): "George W. Bush literally ran for reelection on a constitutional amendment so @TheEllenShow would be barred from being able to marry. I know they're both rich, but that's not a mere 'difference of opinion.' That's an attempt to make one person less of a person than the other."
- Rafael (@rafaelshimunov, October 8, 2019): "This is what Bush brought Iraqi families, daily, for his oil friends. @TheEllenShow and @gwenstefani are patting themselves on the back for rainbow capitalism, comparing a war criminal to 'disagreements' while actively sanitizing them in service of endless greed and selfishness."

On Tuesday, DeGeneres addressed the controversy during her show. She emphasized a supportive tweet that read, "Seeing Ellen and George Bush together makes me have faith in America again." DeGeneres stated, "I'm friends with George Bush. In fact, I'm friends with a lot of people who don't share the same beliefs I have. We're all different, and I think that's okay that we're all different."

DeGeneres continued, "Just because I don't agree with someone on everything doesn't mean I'm not going to be friends with them. When I say, 'Be kind to one another,' I don't mean only the people that think the same way that you do."

The controversy surrounding DeGeneres and Bush's friendship highlights the increasing emphasis on canceling individuals who have made controversial statements or engaged in questionable actions. The debate over the appropriateness of maintaining friendships across political and ideological divides continues to be a topic of discussion in contemporary cultural dialogue.

Title: NSA Declassifies Documents Detailing Metadata Collection Programs

Article:

The National Security Agency (NSA) has declassified a series of documents that provide insights into previously secret programs that collect vast amounts of metadata on domestic phone calls and electronic communications of foreigners within the United States. The Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, stated that the release was "in the public interest."

The most significant document is a 17-page ruling by the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) outlining the so-called minimization procedures or safeguards the government must follow when dealing with the collected data. The New York Times reports that the releases also include two formerly classified briefing papers to Congress from 2009 and 2011, when the provision of the USA Patriot Act that the court relied on to issue the order was up for reauthorization.

These briefing papers portray the bulk collection of metadata as an "early warning system" that allows the government to quickly identify individuals linked to a terrorism suspect. The 2011 briefing paper states, "Both of these programs operate on a very large scale. However, as described below, only a tiny fraction of such records are ever viewed by N.S.A. intelligence analysts."

The documents released contain numerous redactions, and at first glance, they do not seem to reveal significantly more detail than what was already known from the leaked documents provided to The Guardian and The Washington Post by former NSA contractor Edward Snowden.

One thing that remains unclear is the legal rationale for allowing the bulk collection of the electronic data of Americans. The government's authorization for the collection of phone metadata is based on section 215 of the USA Patriot Act. The briefing document, however, points out that no "content" is being collected. Instead, the program is only collecting information that the Supreme Court has decided is "not protected by the Fourth Amendment."

The government's interpretation of the law is subject to the Judicial Branch's interpretation, which many legal scholars and civil libertarians have been waiting for. The FISC order also includes exceptions for technical personnel, who are allowed to query the data without adhering to the safeguards. However, any information queried is not allowed to be used for "intelligence analysis purposes."

Update at 12:35 p.m. ET: Seeking to Calm Privacy Fears:

The Washington Post frames the release of the FISC order as an attempt to allay privacy concerns, stating, "The release of the FISC order is the latest move by the Obama administration to try to calm privacy fears raised by the Snowden leaks." The article goes on to explain that the order "provides the most detailed account yet of the government's collection of phone records under the USA Patriot Act." The Washington Post also notes that the order "reveals that the government can collect records of calls made by millions of Americans, but it does not reveal the content of those calls."

Title: Hillary Clinton Accuses Donald Trump of Catering to Racist and Conspiratorial Elements in Campaign Speech

Article:

In a speech delivered in Reno, Nevada, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton accused her Republican counterpart, Donald Trump, of building his campaign on prejudice and paranoia. Clinton's speech, titled "Donald Trump and his advisors' embrace of the disturbing 'alt-right' political philosophy," focused on portraying Trump as a racist, a conspiracy theorist, and a man unfit for the presidency.

The 'alt-right,' an umbrella term for a collection of racist micro-movements and online subcultures, was initially presented as the primary focus of the speech. However, the 'alt-right' was not the main antagonist of the address. Instead, the central villain was Donald Trump himself.

Clinton's arguments in the speech were not always consistent. She began by quoting Trump's recent comments about the struggles faced by the black community, which she interpreted as a "dog whistle to his most hateful supporters." She also overstated the influence of the 'alt-right,' claiming that the perceived merger between Breitbart and the Trump campaign had led to the 'alt-right' effectively taking over the Republican Party.

However, Clinton's speech contained several strong arguments, such as Trump's habit of retweeting white nationalists and his false claim that he witnessed thousands of New Jersey Muslims celebrating the 9/11 attacks.

Throughout the speech, a consistent theme emerged: Donald Trump is a bigot and a conspiracy theorist. While this idea has been prevalent since Trump entered the presidential race, this speech represented one of the most forceful and concentrated expressions of it from Hillary Clinton.

The speech is expected to energize Clinton's supporters and potentially increase voter turnout. The extent to which it will lead curious conservatives to research the 'alt-right' depends on the amount of coverage the speech receives in the following days.

Meanwhile, the individual who may be most delighted by the speech is Alex Jones. Hillary Clinton's attack on him by name will likely be a topic of discussion among his listeners for some time.

Title: Fox News and GOP Purge Controversial Figures in Response to 2012 Election Loss

Article:

Following the 2012 election, both the Republican Party and Fox News have initiated a purge of controversial political figures who were perceived as divisive and damaging to their respective brands.

Fox News, the top-ranked cable news network in the United States, has terminated contracts with two of its most partisan contributors, Sarah Palin and Dick Morris. The network is also reportedly working to limit the influence of controversial conservatives in Senate primaries through the Conservative Victory Fund, a super PAC co-founded by Karl Rove, who was sidelined by Fox after the election.

In an effort to tame anti-establishment conservatives, Senate GOP leaders have created a "buddy system" with Senators Rand Paul of Kentucky and Ted Cruz of Texas. This collaboration aims to help manage the actions and rhetoric of conservative members of the Republican caucus.

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal has been vocal in his criticism of the Republican Party, urging them to avoid nominating extreme candidates. He stated, "The fact that we lost a winnable election has caused Republicans to take this very, very seriously. I don't think it's just a marketing change. I don't think it's just cosmetic changes. It is going to require some serious changes, not in principles, but in the way we talk and act."

A high-profile Republican strategist, who wished to remain anonymous, commented on the deliberate effort by party leaders to "marginalize the cranks, haters, and bigots—there's a lot of underbrush that has to be cleaned out."

For the Republican Party, this purge is a survival tactic, following two consecutive elections in which extremely conservative candidates lost winnable Senate races. For Fox News, the move is about credibility, as the cable network has seen its ratings decline since the election, in part, due to conservative viewers feeling misled by the coverage.

Roger Ailes, Fox News' chairman and CEO, has a keen understanding of his audience, having revolutionized television by tapping into Republican disdain and anger towards the mainstream media. This strategy has resulted in the creation of both the most-watched cable news channel in the country and political celebrities, several of whom were prominent figures in the 2012 Republican primary. However, during the 2012 campaign, Fox News was criticized for its coverage, particularly in regards to the Benghazi attacks and the presidential election results.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya in Response to Slaughter of Egyptian Christians

Article:

Egypt's military carried out a series of airstrikes against ISIS militants in Libya on Monday, in retaliation for the slaughter of 21 Egyptian Christians by the jihadist group. The bombing raids, which reportedly targeted 10 training and storage facilities in ISIS' Libyan stronghold of Derna, deepened Egypt's involvement in the international fight against ISIS and highlighted the extremists' growing presence in North Africa.

Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry told CNN that the airstrikes were "surgical strikes based on very accurate intelligence and related to degrading the capabilities of ISIS within the city of Derna." However, an umbrella group of Islamist militias in Derna issued a statement claiming that the city "woke up to a disaster today as Egyptian military jets targeted civilians in residential areas in the city."

The airstrikes followed the release of a gruesome video by ISIS on Sunday that appeared to show militants beheading at least a dozen Egyptian Christians on a Libyan beach. The video, which bore many of the hallmarks of previous ISIS videos of the killing of hostages, has intensified international concerns about ISIS' deepening reach into countries far beyond its strongholds in Syria and Iraq.

Twenty-one Egyptian Christians were kidnapped in the Libyan coastal city of Sirte in two separate incidents in December and January. They were reportedly from impoverished villages and went to Libya looking for work. Although the ISIS video showed around a dozen men being beheaded, Egyptian officials said that all 21 Christians were believed to have been killed.

The U.S. government condemned the killings, with U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry calling Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry on Sunday to offer condolences. The State Department said that Kerry expressed the U.S.'s "deepest condolences for the loss of life and reaffirmed the United States' commitment to stand with Egypt in the fight against terrorism."

Egypt is already fighting against ISIS-allied militants on its own territory in the Sinai Peninsula, where dozens of people were killed in a series of attacks in January. Concern has increased over ISIS' rising influence in Libya amid the power and security vacuum prevalent in the country since the 2011 uprising that overthrew former dictator Moammar Gadhafi.

CNN reported in November that fighters loyal to ISIS had complete control of the city of Derna, which has a population of about 100,000 and is situated not far from the Egyptian border. Jihadists with allegiance to ISIS had also expanded their presence westward along the Libyan coast, forming chapters in cities including Benghazi, Sirte, and even Tripoli, the capital, according to Noman Benotman, a former Libyan jihadist now involved in counterterrorism for the Quilliam Foundation.

In an example of the group's spreading reach, a Libyan branch of ISIS claimed responsibility for a deadly attack on a luxury hotel in Tripoli that killed 10 people, including one American. "There's been a real radical Islamist presence in Libya for some time," said Lt. Col. Rick Francona, a retired U.S. Air Force intelligence officer. "What's worrying is now they are self-identifying with ISIS."

Questions remain over how much direct command and control the ISIS leadership in Syria and Iraq has over its North African affiliates. The killings of the Egyptian Christians has filled in some of the detail. Before the grisly video was released, ISIS had released photos in its English-language magazine Dabiq, claiming they had been killed.

"There's certainly communication between the Libyan affiliate and the affiliate in Syria about matters of importance to both of them," said CNN national security analyst Peter Bergen. He said the ties between Libyan jihadists and ISIS' precursor, al Qaeda in Iraq, "go back a very long time." The links between the different branches present "a real challenge" for Western leaders, Francona said, as U.S. President Barack Obama asked Congress to formally authorize the use of military force in the war against ISIS.
