"While we can come up with a military solution or a military operation in a restricted area like Syria and Iraq, what do we do when it expands to North Africa?" Francona asked.

Title: Trump Kicks Off First Official Week in Office with Meetings, Executive Orders, and International Calls

Article:

President Donald Trump is set to meet with congressional leaders from both parties this week as he begins his first official week in the White House and works to deliver on his ambitious campaign promises. Trump considers Monday to be his first real day in office and has a packed schedule that focuses on jobs and national security.

The president tweeted early Monday, "Busy week planned with a heavy focus on jobs and national security. Top executives coming in at 9:00 A.M. to talk manufacturing in America." The schedule includes a breakfast and a listening session with business leaders in the morning, another listening session with union leaders and workers in the afternoon, and a reception later with members of Congress he'll need to overhaul the nation's health care system, among other goals. He will also hold his first meeting as president with the speaker of the House, Paul Ryan.

The outreach effort comes after a tumultuous first weekend in the White House that included lambasting news organizations for correctly reporting on the size of the crowds at his inauguration and mass protests against his presidency on the following day. Trump delivered a more unifying message on Sunday and sought to reassure Americans he was up to the daunting task ahead.

Speaking in the White House East Room during a swearing-in ceremony for top aides, the president warned his staff of the challenges ahead but declared he believed they were ready. "But with the faith in each other and the faith in God, we will get the job done," he said. "We will prove worthy of this moment in history. And I think it may very well be a great moment in history."

Trump said his staff was in the White House not to "help ourselves" but to "devote ourselves to the national good."

"This is not about party, this is not about ideology. This is about country, our country. It's about serving the American people," he said.

Earlier on Sunday, Trump offered a scattershot response to the sweeping post-inauguration protests, first sarcastically denigrating the public opposition and then defending the right to demonstrate a short time later.

Trump also spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accepted an invitation to visit the White House in early February. The prime minister said he is hoping to forge a "common vision" with the newly inaugurated U.S. president that could include expanded settlement construction and a tougher policy toward Iran.

Trump also announced that he's set up meetings with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto. "We're going to start some negotiations having to do with NAFTA," he said of his meeting with Pena Nieto. Mexico is part of the free trade agreement with the U.S. and Canada. Trump said he also will discuss immigration and security at the border. He has promised to build a wall along the length of the southern border and insisted that Mexico will pay for it.

Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, said on "Fox News Sunday" the president would spend his first full week in office undoing some of former President Barack Obama's agenda and planned to sign executive orders on immigration and trade. Trump planned to sign some executive orders on Monday, but it was unclear which.

Trump has pledged to scuttle trade deals such as a pending Asia-Pacific agreement and overturn Obama's executive order deferring deportations for 700,000 people who were brought into the country illegally as minors.

Later in the week, he'll address congressional Republicans at their retreat in Philadelphia and meet with British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Title: Eva Longoria Advocates for Immigration Reform as a Priority for President Obama's Second Term

Article:

Award-winning actress and prominent Washington figure Eva Longoria has expressed her support for immigration reform as a top priority during President Obama's second term. In an interview on "This Week," Longoria stated, "People say, 'Oh, get in the back of the line,' but people don't realize there's a hundred lines to get into. It's a very broken system."

The Wall Street Journal recently labeled Longoria, known for her role in "Desperate Housewives," as a "Hispanic activist and power player in Washington, D.C." She has been a strong supporter of President Obama, serving as a co-chair of his reelection campaign and delivering a speech at the Democratic National Convention last September.

Currently, Longoria is an executive producer and host of the Latino Inaugural, a concert at the Kennedy Center featuring performances by artists such as Jose Feliciano, Melanie Griffith, and New York City's Ballet Hispanico. She is also a co-chair of the Presidential Inauguration Committee, which is currently preparing for Obama's second inauguration.

For live streaming video coverage of Inauguration 2013: Barack Obama, tune in to the ███.com Live page on Monday morning starting at 9:30 a.m. EST, or access the coverage on the ███ iPad App and mobile devices.

Longoria expressed optimism that the administration, particularly President Obama, recognizes immigration as an economic issue. "We have to understand that we are dependent upon a labor in this country, specifically agriculture, to provide low-cost products, and they're jobs that nobody else is doing," she said.

Despite the partisanship in Washington, Longoria believes there is room for compromise on both sides of the aisle regarding immigration. "There was a historic mobilization this election with the Latino vote," she said. "I think the Republicans are going to realize, if they don't do it because it's morally imperative, they have to do it because it's politically imperative. And if they're not going to do it because it's politically imperative, they've got to do it because it's economically imperative. So there's a lot of gains for everybody, no matter what party affiliation, to get this done and to fix this problem."

While she plans to remain politically active, Longoria stated she has no intentions of running for office in her home state of Texas. "I respect everything that politicians do. I think it's a very, very big job," she said. "It's not my day job, so I'm just doing what I can to help the communities in which I came from."

Title: President Obama Issues Executive Order on Gun Control and Background Checks: Constitutional Implications

Article:

President Barack Obama announced on Tuesday the issuance of an executive order on guns and background checks. This order aims to address the requirement for background checks in occasional sales and the need for occasional sellers to become federal licensees, as well as the imposition of reporting upon physicians.

An executive order is a written instruction from the president to the executive branch of the federal government, outlining the manner in which the president wants federal laws or regulations enforced. Executive orders do not direct private persons or individuals in the legislative or judicial branches of government. Executive orders remain in effect until abandoned or rescinded by the president who issued them or by a successor president.

However, President Obama's ability to issue executive orders on guns is limited due to the extensive, detailed, and clear nature of congressional legislation on the matter. Congress has expressly removed occasional sales (sales not made by full-time dealers) from the obligation of obtaining federal licenses and conducting background checks. The president's attempts to negate this congressional will would be invalidated by the courts.

The president's order requires that anyone who sells a gun, even an "occasional" seller, will be required to perform a background check. By defining what an "occasional seller" is, the president is essentially interpreting the law, a job reserved for the courts. The courts will likely ignore his interpretation and impose their own.

Furthermore, the president's requirement for physicians to report conversations with their patients about guns to the Department of Homeland Security could potentially infringe upon the patient/physician privilege. This requirement, if implemented, could encourage governmental intrusion into private conversations between patients and their physicians.

The Supreme Court has made it clear that the right to keep and bear arms is a fundamental liberty. Under the Constitution, fundamental liberties (such as speech, press, worship, self-defense, travel, and privacy) are accorded the highest protection from governmental intrusion. The president's actions could potentially lead America down a slippery slope towards totalitarianism, where a president can negate liberty.

It is important to note that under the Constitution, Congress writes the laws, the president enforces them, and the courts interpret them. President Obama's ability to write his own laws or impose his own interpretations upon them is constitutionally limited, just as the Congress or the courts cannot command the military.

Title: NASA Launches Parker Solar Probe on Mission to Study Sun's Behavior

Article:

The United States space agency NASA has launched the Parker Solar Probe, a mission aimed at sending a satellite closer to the Sun than any before. The probe, named after astrophysicist Eugene Parker, lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on a Delta-IV Heavy rocket at 03:31 local time (07:31 GMT).

The Parker Solar Probe is set to become the fastest-moving manmade object in history. Its data promises to shed light on longstanding mysteries about the Sun's behavior. This mission marks the first time a spacecraft has been named after a living person. Dr. Parker, 91, who first described solar wind in 1958, watched the launch and expressed his anticipation.

The launch came after a failed attempt the previous day due to a last-minute alarm. Just under an hour after the successful launch, NASA confirmed that the spacecraft had successfully separated and was released into space.

The probe aims to dip directly into the Sun's outer atmosphere, or corona. It will make a close approach to Venus in six weeks and a first rendezvous with the Sun a further six weeks after that. Over the course of seven years, Parker will make 24 loops around the Sun to study the physics of the corona, the place where much of the important activity that affects the Earth seems to originate.

The probe will dip inside this tenuous atmosphere, sampling conditions, and getting to just 6.16 million km (3.83 million miles) from the Sun's "surface." Dr. Nicky Fox, the UK-born project scientist affiliated with the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory, explained, "I realize that might not sound that close, but imagine the Sun and the Earth were a meter apart. Parker Solar Probe would be just 4cm away from the Sun."

The probe will also be the fastest man-made object ever, traveling at speeds of up to 430,000mph (690,000km/h)—faster than New York to Tokyo in under a minute.

Title: Reporters Committee Urges Washington Court to Quash Subpoena for News Outlets' Protest Footage

Article:

The Reporters Committee has filed a friend-of-the-court brief urging the King County Superior Court to quash a subpoena issued by the Seattle Police Department to five local news organizations. The subpoena, served earlier in June, demands the outlets to hand over all raw footage and photographs taken within a several block radius during a May 30 protest in Seattle. The police are seeking the materials to aid in identifying suspects involved in the arson of a police car and theft of firearms.

The Reporters Committee's brief, filed on June 29, argues that the subpoena is unenforceable as it allegedly violates the Washington shield law, the First Amendment, and creates the impression that journalists serve as an extension of law enforcement. The brief highlights the dangers that journalists face while covering protests, citing instances of violence against journalists during recent demonstrations.

The brief argues that enforcing the subpoena could lead to further violence against journalists, as some protesters view journalists as being associated with the police. This was evident in a Tucson protest where a journalist, wearing press credentials, was assaulted by protesters who believed he was working with the police.

The Reporters Committee's brief states, "Enforcement of the Subpoena could mislead the public into perceiving reporters at protests as a mere arm of law enforcement, thus eroding public trust in the news media and increasing the already-significant risk of physical harm that journalists face when covering protests."

The Reporters Committee regularly files friend-of-the-court briefs and represents journalists and news organizations pro bono in court cases that involve First Amendment freedoms, the newsgathering rights of journalists, and access to public information. To stay updated on their work, sign up for their monthly newsletter or follow them on Twitter or Instagram.

Title: Morgan Stanley Strategist Sees Parallels Between Current Market and 2009 Recovery

Article:

Michael Wilson, the head of U.S. equity strategy at Morgan Stanley, has suggested that the current stock market recovery mirrors the market's behavior during the 2009 financial crisis recovery. In a note to clients on Monday, Wilson argued that the stock market's rebound is following a similar pattern to March 2009, when the U.S. economy was emerging from the crisis, and the S&P 500 index was beginning its longest bull-market run in history.

Wilson noted that the equity-risk premium, or the expected earnings yield for the S&P 500 minus the 10-year Treasury yield, has reached levels observed in March 2009. This indicator gives investors a rough estimate of the extra return they'll get investing in stocks compared with risk-free government bonds. Wilson's bullish call in March, when he predicted a stock-market bottom, was based on the equity-risk premium reaching the same levels observed in March 2009.

One of the key similarities between the two periods is the performance of cyclical stocks, such as small-capitalization stocks, which typically lead at the beginning of recoveries. The Russell 2000 has risen 8.3% during the past month, compared to the S&P 500's 2.9% rise. However, other cyclical stocks, like financial stocks, have not performed as well. In fact, bank stocks are performing worse relative to the S&P 500 than during the bank-driven financial crisis.

Wilson attributed this dynamic to the Federal Reserve's stimulus measures, which have repressed government bond yields and are scaring bank investors. He believes the market is underestimating the chances that longer-term bond yields, like the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note, will rise significantly as the economy recovers from the coronavirus. Wilson pointed to Congress passing at least $3 trillion in fiscal stimulus, the potential for a faster and more sustained recovery in the post-coronavirus economy, and unexpected inflation as possible catalysts for higher inflation and long-term interest rates.

Wilson wrote, "While hypothetical, these are real possibilities and worth considering given current levels of inflation and 10-year Treasury yields. We continue to think higher 10-year rates would be perhaps the biggest surprise to markets at the moment and would have significant implications for equity markets and leadership."

Title: Key Democratic Figures Remain Neutral in 2016 Presidential Primary Race

Article:

President Barack Obama has announced his intention to vote in the March 15 primary in Illinois, potentially sending a strong signal as he abstains from voting for former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, with whom he previously competed for the nomination in 2008. Vice President Joe Biden, who declined to challenge Clinton for the nomination in October, has yet to announce his support for the former first lady, instead criticizing her during a debate and warning against attacks on President Obama's record.

Senate minority leader Harry Reid and House minority leader Nancy Pelosi have strongly indicated their support for Clinton, but have yet to make a formal endorsement. Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren, who was heavily recruited by progressive Democrats to challenge Clinton, has insisted that she is not running for the nomination.

Richard Trumka, the head of the nation's largest federation of labor unions, the AFL-CIO, has praised both Senator Bernie Sanders and Vice President Biden, but some labor leaders have criticized Clinton for her support of some of President Obama's trade legislation. California Governor Jerry Brown, who challenged Bill Clinton for the nomination in 1992, has been critical of Hillary Clinton during her email scandal, but has spoken warmly of her in recent months.

Despite Hillary Clinton's alleged backing from the Democratic establishment, she has not been able to attract the support of key party figures. President Barack Obama, Vice President Joe Biden, along with top Democrats in Congress and one of the nation's largest labor unions, are remaining neutral in the primary race.

Clinton, however, holds the most endorsements so far over key rival Bernie Sanders in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. The former secretary of state's campaign reports that Clinton is backed by 145 House members, 38 of the 46 senators who caucus with Democrats, 12 governors, and 17 national unions. By comparison, Sanders has been endorsed by two members of Congress and three labor groups.

Here are some of the key Democrats and groups who remain on the sidelines as the primary race gathers steam:

* President Barack Obama
* Vice President Joe Biden
* Senate minority leader Harry Reid
* House minority leader Nancy Pelosi
* Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren
* Richard Trumka, head of the AFL-CIO
* California Governor Jerry Brown

Title: Trump Denies Agreement with Julian Assange, Cites Media Misrepresentation

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has stated that the media is misrepresenting his stance on WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange. In a series of tweets on Thursday, Trump clarified that he merely reports what Assange states, leaving the interpretation of the information to the public.

Trump's tweets come in response to accusations that he aligns with Assange, who has been a subject of controversy due to the release of hacked emails from prominent Democratic individuals and institutions. The cyberattacks, which the U.S. intelligence community attributes to Russia, have been a point of contention between Trump and the intelligence community.

While the U.S. intelligence community has maintained for months that Russia is responsible for the cyberattacks, Trump has been reluctant to concede this point. The cyberattacks, publicly released by WikiLeaks and other similar sites, have been a significant factor in the 2016 presidential election.

Assange, who has been residing in the Ecuadorian embassy in London since 2012 to avoid extradition on sexual assault charges, has stated that his source for the emails was not a foreign state.

Trump's willingness to cite Assange is a departure from his stance on WikiLeaks in 2010, when the website published thousands of pages of classified information provided by Chelsea Manning, an Army private known as Bradley Manning at the time. In a tape uncovered by CNN, Trump expressed disapproval of WikiLeaks in 2010, stating, "I think it's disgraceful... I think there should be like death penalty or something."

Instead of accepting the assessment of the intelligence community, Trump has argued that it would be nearly impossible to identify the true culprit responsible for the cyberattacks. He has also stated that he possesses information regarding the cyberattacks that others do not, although he has not elaborated on the nature of this information.

Trump is scheduled to receive a briefing on Friday from the nation's top intelligence officials outlining the government's evidence blaming Russia for the cyberattacks. Trump had previously stated that the briefing was scheduled for earlier in the week but later tweeted, "The ‘ Intelligence ’ briefing on so-called ‘ Russian hacking ’ was delayed until Friday, perhaps more time needed to build a case. Very strange!"

A U.S. official disputed Trump's claim, telling ███ that the president-elect's briefing was always scheduled for Friday.

Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.), who ran against Trump as Democrat Hillary Clinton's vice presidential pick, expressed shock at Trump's citation of Assange. While the FBI and CIA are the only two intelligence agencies whose assessments regarding Russia's motives have been made public, Kaine, a member of the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations committees, told CNN's "New Day" that it was the "unanimous conclusion" of the intelligence professionals who had briefed him that Russia had indeed sought to aid Trump's campaign.

"I note that he does not go to his intelligence briefings most days. I do go to my intelligence briefings, and I know what the evidence is," Kaine said in his first national TV interview since the presidential election. "If he went to his intelligence briefings, maybe he'd have a different conclusion about this. There's something very unusual, indeed even sort of suspicious, about the degree to which he casually kicks aside the intelligence community when he won't even go to the briefings and again and again takes the Assange-Vladimir Putin line on this important question."

Title: Presidential Disagreement with Review Group: Obama's Approach to National Security Policies

Article:

Michael Allen, a former aide to President Bush and author of the book "Blinking Red," has raised questions about how a president might express disagreement with the recommendations of a review group, particularly in the context of national security policies. Allen suggests that a president's response should indicate a significant acceptance of the group's suggestions, stating, "It needs to be seen at the very least as, 'I'm largely or in some nonsymbolic way taking most of what they're offering.'"

Allen, now managing director of Beacon Global Strategies, expresses concern that such pressure might lead President Obama to make decisions that could expose the country to more danger. He anticipates that Obama might say, "We need to make a major course correction."

President Obama assumed office after running against President Bush's first term but inherited his second. Before leaving office, Bush had already moderated his counterterrorism program in an attempt to ensure its survival. He ceased waterboarding, emptied secret C.I.A. prisons, transferred many prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and secured bipartisan legislation on detention, interrogation, and surveillance.

Upon taking office, President Obama made further adjustments but maintained much of the program and, in the case of drone strikes, even expanded it. His decisions were influenced by a terrorist attempt to down an airliner with explosives during his first presidential Christmas in Hawaii.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, a Republican critic, has characterized Obama as being more authoritarian than Bush on privacy issues. Paul, who has expressed concern over N.S.A. programs, finds the disclosures about these programs to be more alarming than he had anticipated.

White House officials reject such characterizations, but the momentum to revamp N.S.A. rules comes at a time when President Obama also faces other decisions on how much to shift course. Allies are pressing him to support the release of a comprehensive Senate report on the history of interrogations and torture. The president is also left to decide how much to scale back drone strikes, as he signaled he planned to do in a speech this year.

Adm. Dennis C. Blair, President Obama's first director of national intelligence, suggests that the president should take a deeper look at national security policies beyond simply surveillance. Blair criticizes the administration's approach, stating, "Appointing this commission on one small aspect of an important issue for American democracy is a typical small-ball play by this administration. When the administration asks for a debate, it doesn't really want it. What we need is a debate about what level of security we want traded off against what level of privacy we want to maintain."

Title: Obama Escalates Unilateral Actions as Time Winds Down on Second Term

Article:

With the clock ticking on his second term, President Barack Obama has intensified his efforts to accomplish policy goals without Congressional approval, a strategy that could yield swift results but may be vulnerable to reversal by lawmakers or a future president.

The most recent example of this approach was Mr. Obama's policy, announced Thursday, to shield more than four million illegal immigrants from deportation. The President has also announced an aggressive climate deal with China, presided over an Environmental Protection Agency plan to order carbon-emission cuts at power plants, and pursued nuclear negotiations with Iran.

Furthermore, the White House has been exploring options to close the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay without Congressional approval.

The President has long promised to press ahead on his agenda with or without Congressional support, but the new actions are more sweeping in scope than earlier moves, such as raising the minimum wage for federal contractors.

With prospects uncertain for passing major legislation in the new, Republican-controlled Congress, Mr. Obama has begun to build a second-term legacy that is likely to be defined in large part by unilateral action.

However, this strategy comes with risks. Republican lawmakers have threatened to undo the President's actions, and a future President potentially could reverse some of Mr. Obama's moves on immigration and climate change.

More immediately, the President's decision to bypass Congress could diminish the chances of forging agreements with Republican leaders on other issues. GOP lawmakers warned that Mr. Obama would "poison the well" by acting unilaterally on immigration.

In an interview that aired Sunday on ABC, Mr. Obama said, "What the American people expect is that if we disagree on one thing...then we work on everything else."

Suggesting that the legislative process wasn't at an end, some Republicans said the party should respond to Mr. Obama by taking the reins on policy and passing GOP-sponsored immigration bills, though it remained unclear what policy the party would put forward and whether Mr. Obama would sign on.

"It's incumbent on Republicans to come up with our own agenda, a positive, constructive agenda," said Rep. Michael McCaul (R-TX) on CBS on Sunday. Mr. McCaul, who leads the House Homeland Security Committee, said such an effort likely would lead with a border-security bill, but noted that Congress wouldn't take up the issue until next year.

Mr. Obama said in the interview that both Republican and Democratic presidents have taken similar executive actions.

"The history is that I have issued fewer executive actions than most of my predecessors, by a longshot," he said. "Take a look at the track records of the modern presidency; I've actually been very restrained. And I've been very restrained with respect to immigration."

The first two years of Mr. Obama's second term yielded few legislative victories and little progress on the White House's top goals, such as raising the minimum wage and enacting comprehensive immigration legislation.

Mr. Obama was largely sidelined during this fall's campaigns, and Republicans cast Democratic defeats in the midterm elections as a rejection of the President's policies.

The White House has resolved to push forward on Mr. Obama's agenda during the remaining two years.

"He does feel the pressure of time," Dan Pfeiffer, an Obama senior adviser, said Friday at a breakfast sponsored by the Christian Science Monitor. "We all do."

On both immigration and climate change, the President tried but failed to work with Congress to pass legislation before acting on his own. In addition to striking a deal with China to cut carbon pollution, Mr. Obama has laid out aggressive limits on power-plant emissions, another unilateral move that could stand as one of the more far-reaching actions of the second term.

William Galston, a former policy adviser to President Bill Clinton, said acting on immigration and climate change always have been priorities for Mr. Obama, but they have risen in importance as legislative avenues have been closed off.

"Things that you can get done through executive decisions look much more attractive in highly polarized circumstances," said Mr. Galston, who is now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

White House officials also see a range of opportunities to define the President's second term in the foreign-policy realm.

The Obama administration has continued to press for an agreement with Iran on its nuclear program, despite skepticism in Congress. Some Republican lawmakers have suggested that they would move to impose more sanctions on Iran if they aren't comfortable with a deal. Mr. Obama said in the ABC interview that he remained confident that if an agreement is reached, he could convince Congress it is the right thing to do.

Mr. Obama also appears determined to make good on a campaign promise to close the detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba—another potentially dramatic use of executive power. The White House has discussed ways to override a congressional ban on bringing detainees to the U.S., senior administration officials have said.

While the President has said he wants to work with Congress, he and his advisers recently have struck a more defiant tone about Mr. Obama's powers to act on his own. Mr. Obama has said he has an answer for lawmakers who question his authority on immigration: "Nobody is stopping them from passing a bill."

John Podesta, counselor to the President, predicted that Republicans who want to undo the President's power-plant rules would fail, saying, "I don't believe they can stop us from doing that."

Such statements have fanned discord between the White House and the GOP. But on Sunday, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) placed blame on both his party and the President, saying "shame on us as Republicans" for failing to pass legislation to overhaul the immigration system.

"My party has failed," he said on CNN. "This President has failed miserably, and he's made it worse."

Title: Republican Party Faces Transformation as Trump's Unconventional Campaign Gains Momentum

Article:

In the political landscape, conservative activist and talk-radio host Laura Ingraham has stated, "They have to come to terms with what they created." She refers to the Republican Party, which, according to her, tends to avoid discussing the unpopularity of their policies.

This divide within the Republican Party was amplified by the Supreme Court's 2010 decision in the Citizens United case, which increased the influence of wealthy donors in Republican circles. This development occurred amid indications that the party's working-class voters were demanding more representation.

Many of these voters had previously distanced themselves from the increasingly liberal and cosmopolitan Democratic Party. In Donald Trump, they found a champion: a blue-collar billionaire who promised to expand Social Security, reject big donor money, challenge Chinese central bankers, and alleviate Americans from unfair competition due to foreign workers.

The Democratic Party is also grappling with a populist uprising this year, driven in part by economic hardship and growing resentment towards Washington and Wall Street. However, while Senator Bernie Sanders trails Hillary Clinton in delegates, Trump's improbable campaign has become a seemingly unstoppable force, one that Republican lawmakers, donors, and activists are only now fully acknowledging.

Foster Friess, a Wyoming investor and significant donor to the Republican Party, commented, "Republicans and Democrats alike had neglected 'the people who truly make our country work—the truck drivers, farmers, welders, hospitality workers.'"

Six years ago, as the 2010 elections approached, it seemed the Republican Party was on the verge of a resounding rejection of President Obama in congressional races, with the potential to pick up 63 seats. At a fundraiser for Republican Senate candidates hosted by Paul Singer, a billionaire investor, on the ninth floor of the Beresford apartment building on Central Park West, guests celebrated this impending victory.

Singer, a self-proclaimed Goldwater conservative and proponent of an immigration overhaul deal, had publicly lamented "indiscriminate attacks by political leaders against anything that moves in the world of finance." In 2010, Singer tripled his campaign giving, contributing almost $3 million to Republican candidates.

Title: Special Counsel Recommends Up to Six Months' Imprisonment for George Papadopoulos

Article:

Special counsel Robert Mueller has recommended a judge sentence George Papadopoulos, a former aide to Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, to up to six months in prison for lying to the FBI. The recommendation, contained in court documents, includes a strong rebuke of Papadopoulos for failing to assist with the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 elections.

Prosecutors did not specify a sentence but urged the judge to impose jail time, stating that a sentence within the guideline range of up to six months imprisonment was "appropriate and warranted." The government argued that Papadopoulos should be held accountable for repeatedly misleading investigators about critical facts in an investigation of national importance, after having been explicitly warned that lying to the FBI was a federal offense.

Papadopoulos' wife, Simona, on Friday evening told ABC7 Chicago I-Team that "unfortunately they [prosecutors] didn't value George's cooperation." Simona Mangiante Papadopoulos said that federal authorities have ignored evidence favorable to her husband.

Papadopoulos, who served as a volunteer to the Trump team, traveled as an emissary from the campaign to foreign leaders in the Middle East and the Mediterranean. In July 2017, he was charged with lying to the FBI about his contacts during the campaign with a professor who had "substantial connections to Russian government officials."

Court records filed by special counsel Robert Mueller describe how the professor approached Papadopoulos after learning of his role in the Trump campaign. The court filing does not name the professor, but he has since been widely identified as Joseph Mifsud, then the director of the London Academy of Diplomacy.

The professor told Papadopoulos the Russians had "dirt" on Democrat Hillary Clinton in the form of "thousands of emails" that they had procured, according to the court documents. Papadopoulos reportedly bragged about that offer to an Australian diplomat, who then tipped off the FBI and launched that agency's counterintelligence investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.

Papadopoulos was arrested by the FBI when he arrived at Dulles International Airport in July 2017 and charged under seal. He agreed to cooperate with investigators in exchange for a lighter sentence.

The government's sentencing recommendation includes clear signs that the Mueller team felt betrayed by Papadopoulos after he struck a plea agreement and pledged his full cooperation. The filing says Papadopoulos repeatedly withheld key details about his contacts with Russians and neglected to turn over the cell phone he used to communicate with Mifsud until the government expressly asked for it.

"His lies negatively affected the FBI's Russia investigation, and prevented the FBI from effectively identifying and confronting witnesses in a timely fashion," the filing says. "His lies were not momentary lapses. He lied repeatedly over the course of more than two hours, and his lies were designed to conceal facts he knew were critical: the importance of the information he received from the Professor, and his own communications and contacts with Russians and Russian intermediaries during the Trump campaign."

The filing also says that, even after his initial FBI interview, Papadopoulos made repeated attempts to land jobs with the fledgling Trump administration, including a high-level post with the National Security Council.

Papadopoulos' legal team will file their own sentencing assessment to the court in two weeks, and is expected to ask for probation. The sentence recommendation comes as Simona Mangiante Papadopoulos has mounted the latest in a series of publicity campaigns, this one suggesting her husband has misgivings about his plea agreement.

Back in December, in an interview with ABC's George Stephanopoulos, she had described her spouse as the "John Dean" of the Russia probe, a reference to the Watergate-era former White House counsel who pleaded guilty to conspiracy to obstruct justice and became a key witness against President Richard Nixon and his aides.

Earlier this month, Papadopoulos received a sealed sentencing document prepared for the court. After that, the defendant's wife began an aggressive media blitz in which she strongly hinted her husband is considering changing lawyers and rescinding his plea deal.

After appearing before Democratic members of the House intelligence committee earlier this summer, she said that Papadopoulos has come to believe the professor may have been working for Western intelligence agencies and set him up.

"I actually never said explicitly that it was an entrapment from the FBI. I just said that he definitely was... the target of a different set-up," she said.

In June, the Daily Caller News Foundation reported that Simona Papadopoulos said, "It looks to be one among a series of attempts to entrap George," adding, "The question today to me [is whether] these people are simply shady businessmen or are they part of a greater attempt to entrap George in illegal activity."

Since her husband's guilty plea in exchange for cooperation with the Mueller probe, Papadopoulos has been living in Chicago. Federal investigators have imposed restrictions on his travel until his sentencing, which is now scheduled for September 7.

Title: Court Case Garza v. Hargan Divides Judge Brett Kavanaugh on Abortion Rights for Illegal Immigrant Minors

Article:

The court case Garza v. Hargan, involving an illegal immigrant teen seeking an abortion while in government custody, has become a contentious issue for Judge Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump's nominee to the Supreme Court. The case, which involved a girl identified as Jane Doe, a Unaccompanied Alien Child (UAC), has drawn criticism from both pro-life and pro-choice activists for Kavanaugh's attempt to find a middle ground.

Jane Doe, who arrived in the U.S. last year, was sent to a government-funded facility and was told she was pregnant after an entry medical exam. She requested an abortion, but the Trump administration delayed the process, citing their interest in protecting the fetus while the girl was in government custody. The girl had funding for the procedure and obtained a judge's consent in Texas, but the government argued that it would still have to transport her and provide any necessary aftercare, which violated federal law prohibiting taxpayer spending on elective abortions.

The government proposed finding a family member or willing sponsor for the girl, arguing they would be best able to help her make such a significant decision. A lower court ruled in favor of the girl and the American Civil Liberties Union, which represented her in the case. However, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court for the District of Columbia, led by Judge Kavanaugh, sided with the government, overturning the lower court's decision.

The full D.C. Circuit then overturned the three-judge panel's decision, ruling that illegal immigrants have a right to abortion and that the Trump administration's efforts to delay the procedure to find a sponsor were infringing on that right. Judge Kavanaugh penned a dissent, stating that the majority's decision established a new right for unlawful immigrant minors in U.S. government detention to obtain immediate abortions on demand.

The Supreme Court later erased the lower court's opinion, ruling that since Jane Doe had rushed to get an abortion, there was no longer a live controversy and no precedent should be set. However, the ruling has left activists on all sides of the issue furious.

Sen. Kamala Harris, a California Democrat, expressed concerns about Judge Kavanaugh's nomination, stating that he disregarded Supreme Court precedent and opposed the health care rights of a vulnerable young woman. From the right, the American Family Association also expressed concerns, finding Judge Kavanaugh's ruling not strong enough in upholding abortion rights.

However, the Rev. Frank Pavone, national director of Priests for Life, expressed support for Judge Kavanaugh's selection, while the Susan B. Anthony List, a major pro-life advocacy group, praised Kavanaugh's decisions in both the Garza and Priests for Life v. HHS cases, where they said he rejected the ACLU's assertion of a constitutional right to abortion on demand for illegal immigrants.

In conclusion, the court case Garza v. Hargan has become a significant point of contention for Judge Brett Kavanaugh, with activists on both sides of the abortion rights issue expressing concerns about his rulings in the case.

Title: Modest Deficit Reduction Goals Raise Concerns for Future Fiscal Policy

Article:

Some on the left are defining successful deficit reduction as stabilizing the federal debt at about 70 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by 2022. This goal, according to some analysts, is far too modest and could leave future fiscal policy perilously constrained.

Under current assumptions, achieving this goal would require combined reductions in spending growth and/or increases in taxes of $1.4 trillion over the 2014-2022 period, less than the total deficit reduction provided by the 2011 Budget Control Act (BCA) and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2013 (ATRA).

Richard Kogan of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, supported by Martin Wolf of the Financial Times, argues for more modest deficit reduction. The Washington Post's editorial page shares similar concerns.

The potential danger of such a low debt-GDP ratio is that, in the event of a future recession, the debt-GDP ratio could quickly surpass 100 percent. This could make it harder to argue for stimulus measures during economic downturns, potentially exacerbating the severity of the recession.

However, if the economy were to maintain a steady growth path, the deficit associated with stabilizing the debt-GDP ratio at 70 percent of GDP would be more than 10 percent higher than that consistent with a 60 percent ratio, the limit chosen by the drafters of the Maastricht treaty that created the Euro. This would represent a significant increase in the rate at which the nation's wealth is being depleted.

Kogan and Wolf assume that the discretionary spending caps imposed by the BCA through 2021 will be enforced successfully. The caps imply that discretionary spending will fall to the lowest level relative to GDP since World War II. They would also require both defense and non-defense outlays to grow less than the rate of inflation from 2014 to 2021, after already falling considerably from the levels inflated by the stimulus and the recession.

The biggest risk is that it will be impossible to maintain defense at such low levels, given the ongoing war on terror and the growing Chinese defense budget. In non-defense, population growth will put upward pressure on spending for programs like education, infrastructure, national parks, etc. True reforms in Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid have a better chance of lasting than arbitrary caps on discretionary spending that do not specify individual program cuts.

Rudolph G. Penner, an Institute Fellow at the Urban Institute and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1983 to 1987, has expressed concerns about the potential risks of a higher debt-GDP ratio. Sovereign debt crises occur at all manner of debt-GDP ratios and are impossible to predict, but it is hard to believe that a higher ratio does not increase the risk to some degree. It is sobering to note that, in 2008, just before their crises, the net debt to GDP ratio in Spain was less than 31 percent and in Ireland less than 25 percent.

Title: Scalia's Death May Not Set U.S. Precedent for Texas Abortion Case

Article:

The U.S. Supreme Court is set to hear its most significant abortion case in at least a decade, with the passing of Justice Antonin Scalia potentially impacting the reach of the decision due to his absence. Scalia, who died over the weekend, was widely expected to provide a fifth vote to uphold abortion restrictions.

The Texas law in question requires doctors to have local hospital admitting privileges and for clinics to make costly building upgrades to operate like outpatient surgical centers. Similar laws have been passed in numerous other states, and a 4-4 split in the court would leave in place the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that upheld these provisions.

Ilyse Hogue, president of NARAL Pro-Choice America, states that such a split decision would result in the closure of several clinics that perform abortions, exacerbating an already challenging healthcare situation in Texas. Currently, half of the state's clinics have already closed due to various restrictions.

However, a 4-4 split decision would have no national precedent. This means that other appeals court rulings striking down similar laws would also stand. Hogue also notes that there are more cases concerning reproductive rights coming before the Supreme Court.

One such case is a challenge to the Affordable Care Act's mandate on covering birth control for female employees, which the court will hear next month. Additionally, there has been a wave of abortion restrictions passed since Republicans took control of numerous statehouses in 2011, and many of these cases are making their way through the appeals courts.

Abortion opponents had hoped to have these restrictions affirmed by the Supreme Court with Scalia's support. Clarke Forsythe, senior counsel with Americans United for Life, states, "He was one of the two justices on the court who has publicly opposed Roe v. Wade in prior cases and prior votes."

Scalia had expressed the view that since the U.S. Constitution does not recognize a right to abortion, the Supreme Court should not either. The issue, he wrote, should be left to the states.

With a potential shift to a liberal majority, Forsythe foresees a significant rollback of decades of abortion restrictions. He suggests that a liberal Supreme Court may overturn the ban on public funding for the procedure, known as the Hyde Amendment, a policy that both presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have pledged to overturn.

Forsythe also anticipates that a liberal Supreme Court "will probably throw out all parental notice and parental consent laws in the country, will throw out all informed consent laws in the country, and virtually any regulation, and create an absolute right to abortion for any reason at any time that we have not seen in 42 years."

Abortion rights groups, however, view these predictions as speculative at best. With so much at stake, both sides of this contentious issue are reportedly throwing themselves into the fierce battle over Scalia's replacement.

Title: Median Household Income and Poverty Rate Show Significant Increase in 2015, According to U.S. Census Bureau Report

Article:

The United States Census Bureau has released its annual estimates of Americans' incomes and the poverty rate for 2015, revealing a substantial increase in median household income and a decrease in the poverty rate. The report indicates a 5.2% real-term growth in median household income, or $2,800, marking a significant change from the stagnation observed following the recession.

According to Michigan economist Justin Wolfers, the income growth was particularly pronounced at the lower end of the income distribution. People at the 10th percentile, or the poor, experienced a 7.9% increase in income, while those at the 95th percentile, or the rich, saw a 3.7% growth. This income growth is even more significant when considering the Federal Reserve's PCE deflator, an alternative measure of inflation, which typically shows slower inflation growth.

The decrease in income inequality between 2014 and 2015 is noteworthy, although it does not reverse the long-term upward trend. The official poverty rate fell from 14.8% to 13.5%, with 3.5 million fewer people falling below the poverty threshold. However, the official poverty rate is considered a poor statistic due to its exclusion of important social programs like the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) and food stamps, and its pegging to the price of food in 1955.

A more accurate metric, according to the Census Bureau, is the Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM), which takes all important social programs into account and is pegged to the present-day cost of basic goods like food, clothing, shelter, and utilities. The SPM also decreased, falling by a full percentage point, from 15.3% to 14.3%. According to this metric, 45.7 million people were in poverty in 2015, 2.7 million fewer than in 2014.

The report also covers health insurance, and the ongoing rollout of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) continued a trend toward lower and lower uninsured rates. The rate for 2015 was a mere 9.1%, and more recent federal data shows that in the first quarter of 2016, that rate fell even further to 8.6%, the lowest on record. The drops in uninsurance for poor Americans were concentrated in states that participated in the law's Medicaid expansion, but even non-expanding states saw some declines.

Overall, the report suggests that the ongoing economic recovery's gains are finally being broadly shared, although it would take multiple reports like this to reverse longstanding trends in income inequality and poor median income growth.

Title: U.S. Congress Address by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: A Controversial Speech and its Implications

Article:

The speech delivered by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to the U.S. Congress has become a significant and ongoing story, rather than a one-day event, as it was initially intended to be. The address, which was met with controversy due to its timing and the political dynamics surrounding it, has brought increased scrutiny to the U.S. Capitol and raised questions for President Barack Obama and the Democrats.

The Democrats, historically strong advocates for Israel, have recently shown a cooling stance towards the Jewish state. U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry has referred to Israel as an "apartheid state," and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has criticized Israel for the "brutal occupation" of the West Bank and the denial of "dignity and self-determination" to the Palestinians.

The speech by Netanyahu, who is known for his straightforward approach, has raised speculation about potential disclosures and embarrassing secrets that may emerge from the discussions between Israel and the Obama administration. A Kuwaiti newspaper, citing Israeli sources, reported that President Obama once threatened to shoot down Israeli bombers attempting to reach Iranian nuclear reactors.

In his speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), Netanyahu emphasized the long-standing friendship between Israel and the United States, recalling three instances where Israel acted independently to ensure its survival despite American misgivings: the declaration of statehood in 1948, the Six Day War in 1967, and the bombing of the Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981.

The friendship between the two nations has been a central theme of Netanyahu's speech, as he seeks to reassure Americans that his visit does not intend to harm the relationship. However, some observers suggest that President Obama may not share the same sentiments towards Israel as his predecessors.

The article concludes by drawing parallels between the situation in 1941, when Winston Churchill visited Washington amidst the aftermath of Pearl Harbor, and the current political climate. Churchill's visit was intended to bolster American spirits, and the article suggests that Netanyahu's speech aims to remind Americans of their nation's exceptional status and to challenge President Obama's perceived indecisiveness in the face of adversity.

Title: World Bank Forecasts Slightly More Pessimistic Growth Outlook for 2012 and 2013 Compared to IMF

Article:

The World Bank's predictions for global economic growth in 2012 and 2013 are slightly more pessimistic compared to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The IMF forecasts a growth of 3.5 percent in 2012 and 4.1 percent in 2013. The global outlook brightened early in 2012, according to the World Bank's report, as European leaders promised to devote more money to resolve their crisis and implement policy changes to further unite the Continent.

However, the calm of the winter has dissipated in the spring. Investors have returned to punishing a variety of European bonds, pushing Spain to request a bailout for its faltering banks last weekend. Political uncertainty is rife, with a Greek exit from the euro zone increasingly mentioned as a possibility.

In the last few months, fearful investors have again cut their risk exposure, pulling money from around the world and parking it in the safety of assets like American bonds. Capital flows to developing countries fell an astonishing 44 percent from April to May, according to Mr. Burns in an interview.

Such market gyrations are likely to be fairly common in the post-crisis period, the bank said, and the effects will be felt globally. "Sharp swings in investor sentiment and financial conditions will continue to complicate the conduct of macro policy in developing countries," the report said.

The World Bank sees Europe muddling through its sovereign debt crisis without any market catastrophe, and the world maintaining its lackluster but steady growth path, as the most likely outcome. The forecast is not entirely reassuring, however. Economists at the World Bank, like most forecasters, have failed to foresee crises in the past, and are warning of significant uncertainties ahead.

"This is the third May or June in a row where Europe has been embroiled in tensions," Mr. Burns said. "In each and every previous incident, it has calmed towards the end of June. That is our baseline expectation."

The bank strongly reiterated a warning to developing countries in the report: prepare for market turbulence by strengthening your balance sheets, such as by cutting deficits and reducing short-term debt exposures.

According to the bank's data, about 40 percent of developing countries were running a surplus in 2007, before the global downturn began. Last year, just 19 percent were. "That doesn't mean that their policies have deteriorated," Mr. Burns said, suggesting that the swing was largely the result of the crisis. But Mr. Burns noted that the countries' relatively strong fiscal position heading into the crisis served them well, and he urged them to "move in that direction once again."

More generally, the bank's economists said that while Europe might pose a short-term threat to middle- and lower-income countries, in the long term their prospects and growth trajectories remained strong.

In the case of China, for instance, growth "doesn't depend on domestic demand in high-income countries, and ultimately it doesn't depend on their export demand," said Hans Timmer, the director of the World Bank's development prospects group. Future growth would instead come largely from within the country and other poorer but fast-growing economies, he said.

Officials at the bank also warned that high-income countries were not making the changes necessary to ensure that their economies would be competitive, prolonging their periods of economic malaise and losing ground to the rest of the world. Such changes might include reducing long-term deficits, making certain industries more competitive, or investing in infrastructure.

"In high-income countries, a good crisis is being wasted," said Mr. Timmer.

On Tuesday, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, also warned of a global growth slowdown and renewed threats to financial markets.

"We need a strategy that is good for stability and good for growth," Ms. Lagarde said at a Center for Global Development event in Washington, according to her prepared remarks. "This must start with the advanced economies, especially in Europe." Ms. Lagarde urged "very accommodating monetary policy," "direct support to banks," and "growth-friendly" fiscal policies.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Takes Lead in Several National Presidential Primary Polls

Article:

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has surpassed former Vice President Joe Biden in several recent national presidential primary polls, marking a significant shift in the Democratic Party's nomination race. According to most national polls since the end of September, Warren has led the pack, albeit by narrow margins.

Biden, who had previously led in almost every national poll with double-digit leads since 2018, has now come in second place in four out of the past five and six out of the past ten polls. The RealClearPolitics average currently places Warren ahead of Biden by 0.2 percent, marking the first time Biden has not held the lead in the race's RCP average since December.

The most recent poll to place Warren at the top was released Tuesday by Quinnipiac University. This poll found Warren ahead of Biden 29 percent to 26 percent, with Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont coming in third at 16 percent.

Warren has also performed well in the early primary states, which are crucial for securing the nomination. Last month, a Des Moines Register/CNN/Mediacom Iowa Poll found her leading in the first-in-the-nation caucus state, and a Monmouth University poll put her narrowly ahead of Biden in New Hampshire. A Suffolk University/███ Network Poll released on Sept. 24 placed her just 4 points behind Biden in Nevada, the third state where primary voters will cast their ballots.

Elizabeth Warren:
- Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has taken over the top spot in several recent national presidential primary polls.
- According to most national polls since the end of September, Warren has led the pack, albeit by narrow margins.
- The most recent poll to place her at the top was released Tuesday by Quinnipiac University.
- Warren has also performed well in the early primary states, which are crucial for securing the nomination.
- In the latest Quinnipiac University Poll, Warren was ahead of Biden 29 percent to 26 percent.
- Warren held narrow leads with both men and women and had a 12-percentage-point lead with white voters.
- Biden was favored by black voters 36 percent to 20 percent and by voters over 65 by a 41 percent to 26 percent margin.
- The survey was conducted Oct. 4-7 from among 1,483 self-identified registered voters with a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percent.
- Warren also has performed well in the early primary states that can be key to securing the nomination.
- Last month, a Des Moines Register/CNN/Mediacom Iowa Poll found her leading in the first-in-the-nation caucus state, and a Monmouth University poll put her narrowly ahead of Biden in New Hampshire.
- A Suffolk University/███ Network Poll released on Sept. 24 placed her just 4 points behind Biden in Nevada, the third state where primary voters will cast their ballots.
- Biden maintains a comfortable 41 percent to 12 percent lead over Warren in South Carolina, the fourth state on the primary calendar, according to a recent Fox News poll.
- The former vice president's drop in the polls comes as President Donald Trump and his personal attorney Rudy Giuliani have mounted a public campaign accusing Biden of impropriety in Ukraine during his time in office.
- Trump's effort to pressure Ukraine to dig deeper into the matter has sparked an impeachment inquiry.
- Warren's latest hurdle to the presidency: Democrats' belief women face tougher fight against Trump
- Tuesday's poll from Quinnipiac shows that voters approve of the impeachment inquiry 53 percent to 43 percent and that 45 percent think Trump should be removed from office while 49 percent do not.
- Only 34 percent said they approved of the way Trump has responded to the impeachment inquiry, compared with 57 percent who disapproved.
- But 43 percent agreed with the president that it was a "political witch hunt," while 51 percent said it was a "legitimate investigation."
- Though Trump has said his effort to push Ukraine to investigate Biden was motivated by a desire to battle corruption rather than taint a political opponent, only 33 percent of voters bought that explanation, and 48 percent said he was out to hurt a rival.
- Twenty percent were not yet certain or thought both reasons were true.
- Polls have consistently found that Democratic voters care more about picking a candidate in 2020 who can defeat Trump than any particular policy issue.
- When asked whom they would vote for if the election was held today, Quinnipiac found that both Warren and Biden would beat the incumbent president – Biden by a margin of 51 percent to 40 percent and Warren by a margin of 49 percent to 41 percent.
- Trump indirectly acknowledged Warren's rise in the polls in a tweet Tuesday in which he called on his 2016 Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton to "enter the race to try and steal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren."
- Speaking to House Republicans in Baltimore last month, Trump said Warren had "emerged from the ashes." And now it looks like she can beat Sleepy Joe (Biden)."
- Opinion: 5 reasons why Elizabeth Warren has the best chance to beat Donald Trump.

Title: Trump Campaign Staffers Face Exclusion from Federal Agency Positions

Article:

Donald Trump campaign workers are finding themselves in competition with GOP veterans for key positions in federal agencies, with the former group reportedly facing exclusion, according to Politico. This trend is evident in departments such as the State Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, where campaign staffers, who refer to themselves as "originals," claim they are being sidelined.

Campaign staffers have reportedly been kept out of meetings and targeted by damaging leaks, with some Trump supporters already resigning from their new roles. Sid Bowdidge, a former Trump campaign staffer who left his Energy Department position after reports of anti-Muslim slurs on social media, attributed the leaks to rival coworkers, as reported by Politico.

Many of the campaign loyalists were placed in agencies on Inauguration Day to facilitate a smooth presidential transition, often referred to as the "beachhead" team. CBS News reports that about a dozen members of the beachhead team at the U.S. Agriculture department have been informed they will not secure permanent positions. Other agencies, including Treasury and Transportation, have reportedly informed former campaign workers that their positions are ending.

A former campaign staffer, who was not offered a full-time role at his agency, commented, "The perception (among agency staff) is, we were Mr. Trump's goons who were good at knocking on doors, but can't do much else."

Some Cabinet secretaries have privately expressed concerns about being forced to take employees with little or no relevant expertise, according to Politico. However, Trump loyalists maintain they do not deserve to be discarded. A former campaign aide stated, "As we get further away from Inauguration Day, it is very obvious that no one cares what happens to the people who worked for the campaign or who have loyalty to the president."

The statement, "The swamp is winning the battle. And longtime campaign staffers are proving to be the first casualties," was made by a former campaign aide.

Title: Trump Denies Firing Comey Over Russia Investigation, Contradicts Previous Statements

Article:

Washington - President Donald Trump has stated that he did not dismiss FBI Director James Comey due to the Russia investigation, contradicting video and documentary evidence to the contrary. In a series of tweets before departing for a fundraising trip to Texas, Trump asserted, "Not that it matters but I never fired James Comey because of Russia!" He continued, "The Corrupt Mainstream Media loves to keep pushing that narrative, but they know it is not true!"

Two days after the May 9, 2017, dismissal, Trump told NBC News that while Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein had endorsed Comey's firing, he would have taken the same action without the recommendation, and he cited Russia as a reason. Trump told NBC's Lester Holt, "And, in fact, when I decided to just do it, I said to myself, I said, 'you know, this Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story.' It’s an excuse by the Democrats for having lost an election that they should’ve won."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., responded to Trump's claim, tweeting, "@realDonaldTrump tweets he did not fire Comey over the Russia investigation. Let's go to the videotape."

The claim came a day after news that former deputy FBI director Andrew McCabe authored a memo quoting Rosenstein as saying that Trump asked him to refer to the Russia investigation as a reason for recommending Comey's dismissal. However, the Rosenstein memo referred only to Comey's overall management of the bureau, including his handling of the Hillary Clinton private email server case.

The day after Comey's firing, Trump reportedly told visiting Russian diplomats, "I just fired the head of the FBI. He was crazy, a real nut job. I faced great pressure because of Russia. That’s taken off."

Additional reporting has revealed that McCabe authored a memo stating that Trump asked Rosenstein to mention Russia in Comey's dismissal, and that Comey believes he was fired because he rebuffed Trump's request to go easy on a central figure in the Russia probe, former national security adviser Michael Flynn. The FBI director's firing is central to an obstruction of justice investigation being conducted by special counsel Robert Mueller, who is also looking into Russian attempts to influence the 2016 election in order to help Trump.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Chairman Nadler Outlines Democratic Strategy for Mueller Report, Impeachment Unlikely

Article:

House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has stated that Democrats will request documents from dozens of individuals close to the White House this week, as part of investigations into obstruction of justice, corruption, and abuse of power. In an interview with ABC's This Week, Nadler downplayed talk of impeaching President Trump, stating that they do not currently have enough evidence to initiate impeachment proceedings.

Nadler indicated that before impeaching a president, they must persuade the American people that such action is necessary. He acknowledged that this could be a high bar, but stated that they may or may not reach this threshold.

On Monday, Democrats will request documents from 60 people, including Donald Trump Jr. and Trump Organization chief financial officer Allan Weisselberg. The chairman stated that they aim to uncover information regarding Russian meddling in the 2016 campaign, and will subpoena this information if the Justice Department withholds it.

House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy accused Democrats of engaging in a fishing expedition, claiming they will latch onto whatever they can to impeach the president. Nadler countered that their actions are a result of Michael Cohen's high-profile testimony, which implicated the president in crimes, including pay-offs to a porn actress, Stormy Daniels, on the eve of the election to cover up an alleged affair.

Nadler asserted that seeking to sabotage a fair election would be an impeachable offense, but they are currently far from making decisions about impeachment. McCarthy, on the other hand, argued that any violations committed by Cohen, as an attorney, would not be impeachable offenses.

Title: Trump Administration Halts Risk Adjustment Payments for Obamacare Insurers

Article:

The Trump administration announced on Saturday evening a temporary freeze on billions of dollars in payments to health insurance companies intended to help them manage higher-risk patients within the Obamacare marketplace. The move has sparked backlash from the insurance industry's lobbying arm, as insurers continue to struggle to adjust to the administration's repeated attacks on the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare).

The federal government provides risk adjustment payments to Obamacare insurers, which are designed to cushion insurers from taking steep losses on high-risk patients in the Obamacare marketplace. In 2017, the government paid out over $10 billion in these payments.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) announced the halt of these payments on Saturday evening, citing a February 2018 ruling from the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico that invalidates them.

"We were disappointed by the court's recent ruling," CMS Administrator Seema Verma said in a statement. "As a result of this litigation, billions of dollars in risk adjustment payments and collections are now on hold. CMS has asked the court to reconsider its ruling, and hopes for a prompt resolution that allows CMS to prevent more adverse impacts on Americans who receive their insurance in the individual and small group markets."

The insurance industry is already speaking out against the administration's decision, calling it a crucial blow during a time when insurance companies are trying to come up with premiums and packages for 2019.

"We are very discouraged by the new market disruption brought about by the decision to freeze risk adjustment payments," trade group America's Health Insurance Plans (AHIP) said in a statement on Saturday. "This decision comes at a critical time when insurance providers are developing premiums for 2019 and states are reviewing rates."

Insurers themselves are voicing concerns for market destabilization following the announcement.

"This action will significantly increase 2019 premiums for millions of individuals and small business owners and could result in far fewer health plan choices," Blue Cross Blue Shield Association President and CEO Scott Serota said in a statement. "It will undermine Americans' access to affordable coverage, particularly those who need medical care the most."

Over the course of his first 18 months in office, the president has targeted Obamacare with a series of moves intended to undermine the system and disrupt the marketplace. The president has rolled back funding for a program intended to help individuals navigate the insurance marketplace, Obamacare's navigator program, signed an executive order to allow for groups to purchase insurance across state lines, stopped federal funding for Obamacare subsidies, pushed for consumer access to more affordable short-term, limited duration health insurance plans, cut Obamacare's open enrollment period in half and its advertising budget 90 percent.

Trump made repealing and replacing Obamacare a key part of his successful bid for the presidency in 2016, but he has, thus far, been unable to materialize that goal. House Republicans passed a bill—the American Health Care Act—in May 2017 after a few months of rocky negotiations that nearly stopped the effort in its tracks. Senate Republicans had a more difficult time, given their 52- and subsequently slim 51-seat majority in the upper chamber. The Senate tried roughly a handful of times in 2017 to repeal and replace Obamacare, offering up a "skinny repeal" in July 2017 with no replacement as a last-ditch effort to overhaul the American health care system. That, too, failed to pass muster within the entirety of either the Republican or Democratic conferences.

Ultimately, Republicans and the White House have moved on from repealing and replacing Obamacare, although a coalition of outside conservative groups have hopes of reviving the debate in the Senate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has made it clear he is ready to move on from the issue, but he has said he would entertain a proposal that was guaranteed to get enough votes to pass.

Title: Ambassador to EU Recalled Amidst Impeachment Inquiry; Witnesses Ousted from White House Jobs

Article:

U.S. Ambassador to the European Union, Gordon Sondland, announced his recall from his position on Friday, stating, "I was advised today that the president intends to recall me effective immediately as United States Ambassador to the European Union." Sondland, who testified during the House impeachment inquiry, had previously stated that "everyone was in the loop" regarding an effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate Democratic presidential candidate Joseph R. Biden.

The announcement came hours after Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, another witness in the impeachment inquiry, was ousted from his White House job with the National Security Council. Vindman, a U.S. Army officer, testified about a phone call between President Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky that was at the center of the impeachment inquiry.

Sen. Ron Wyden (D-OR) commented on the personnel moves, stating, "Firing Ambassador Sondland and a hero like LTC Vindman for telling the truth is yet more abuse of power by the president." Wyden further tweeted, "These self-serving acts won’t stop until Donald Trump is out of office, or Republicans finally decide to stand up against this petty retaliation."

Sondland, a political appointee, is a hotel magnate who donated $1 million to President Trump's inaugural committee through companies he controls. Tom Fitton, an ally of the president who heads the watchdog group Judicial Watch, approvingly called the personnel moves "cleaning house."

Sen. Bob Menendez (D-NJ), the top Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, described the ousters of Sondland, Lt. Col. Vindman, and his twin brother, Yevgeny, from the National Security Council as "clear political retaliation, the likes of which is seen only in authoritarian countries around the world."

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-FL) noted that Sondland is a political appointee who serves at the pleasure of the president. Rubio also stated that Lt. Col. Vindman wasn't "fired," but is still an Army officer. "He was assigned to NSC to serve the President who has a right to have people he trusts on his staff," Rubio said.

Title: Unintended Consequences of the Affordable Care Act: Reduction in Full-Time Jobs and Impact on Self-Funded Health Plans

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has several unintended consequences, according to Republican strategist Karl Rove. One of these consequences is a decrease in full-time jobs and an increase in part-time jobs.

In a Wall Street Journal opinion piece titled "Here Comes the Unaffordable Careless Act," Rove points out that the Affordable Care Act requires companies with at least 50 workers to provide health insurance to any employee who works more than 30 hours a week or face a fine. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of hourly employees working 30-34 hours a week decreased by an average of 146,500 a month over the past year, while the number working 25-29 hours increased by 119,000 a month.

Rove argues that this lack of hours can particularly affect single working mothers and younger workers. He also suggests that the 50-employee threshold may prevent businesses from growing beyond that size, leading the U.S. to follow in the footsteps of countries with sclerotic economies.

Additionally, Obamacare is expected to damage businesses with self-funded health plans, according to Rove. These companies serve as their own insurer, gathering premiums and paying claims filed by their workers. A Kaiser Family Foundation survey shows that 61 percent of workers are in self-funded plans. Rove claims that more companies have an incentive to choose self-funding because the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) governs self-funded plans, not the Affordable Care Act. ERISA allows self-funded plans to charge premiums based on risk, offer a wider menu of options, and avoid expensive provisions such as Obamacare's new tax on insurance policies.

However, Rove notes that Obamacare supporters do not like the success of these programs in curbing premium increases and managing costs. Delaware, New York, and Oregon have already forbidden small- and mid-size companies from using self-insurance plans, and administrators of self-funded plans worry that new Labor Secretary Thomas Perez will issue regulations that erode the attractiveness of self-funded plans and push more companies' health policies into Obamacare's "morass."

Furthermore, Rove states that the amount of uninsured Americans will not drop below 30 million in the next 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office. This contradicts Obamacare's promise of "universal" coverage.

Title: Court Documents Detail Aggressive Sales Techniques of Trump University

Article:

A federal judge has released hundreds of pages of court documents related to Trump University, the real estate and investment training venture of former President Donald Trump that has been the subject of lawsuits from former students. The records include a sales guide and strategies for selling courses and mentoring sessions to students, often emphasizing the "Gold" level courses that cost nearly $35,000.

The documents, released in response to a request from The Washington Post, were categorized into two main sections: depositions from Trump University executives and "playbooks" detailing marketing and sales strategies. The topics range from expense reporting to sales techniques in various environments, from one-off preview events to three-day sessions. Most of the pages are marked "Confidential."

Tips for dealing with the news media are included in the 2008 edition of the playbook, starting with directing any reporters to a Trump media contact. The playbooks were released on the same day that Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, called ABC News reporter Tom Llamas "a sleaze" during a news conference.

The playbooks, spanning several years, also include suggested responses to customers who balk at a sale, offering rebuttals to objections that range from a need to consult a spouse to a reluctance to go into debt. The 2010 Playbook requires sales staff to "Be Deliberate."

"Be deliberate and conscious when communicating to potential students," the sales guide states.
