"Remember that we have time to think and plan and develop questions and commands that lead people into a flow that they must deal with and respond to. Without a game plan, you are required to respond to them and do much more thinking on your feet. Remember that we need to stay on 'offense.'"

The playbook also advises Trump's sales teams not to let a lack of money be used as an excuse for turning down Trump University's three-day training. "Money is never a reason for not enrolling in Trump University," the sales guide states, adding, "if they really believe in you and your product, they will find the money."

The documents and records were ordered to be released by U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel of the Southern District of California, who has been the subject of personal attacks from Donald Trump. Trump previously questioned whether Curiel's Hispanic heritage made him biased due to Trump's support for building a wall on the Mexican border.

The documents stem from lawsuits filed by Trump University's customers back in 2013; their case gained new prominence back in February when Trump's Republican rival Marco Rubio brought them up during a debate. After that debate, Michael Isikoff, the chief investigative correspondent for Yahoo! News, spoke to NPR's Robert Siegel about the former students' complaints against Trump.

Title: Mistrial Declared in Corruption Trial of U.S. Senator Bob Menendez

Article:

A mistrial was declared on Thursday in the corruption trial of New Jersey's Democratic U.S. Senator Bob Menendez, following a jury's inability to reach a verdict on bribery, fraud, and other charges. The hung jury marked a victory for Menendez and a setback for federal prosecutors in what was the Justice Department's first high-profile corruption trial since a U.S. Supreme Court decision last year limited its ability to bring such cases.

Menendez, 63, a longtime political figure in New Jersey who joined the Senate in 2006, was accused of accepting private flights, campaign contributions, and other bribes from a wealthy patron, Florida ophthalmologist Salomon Melgen, in exchange for official favors.

One juror, Ed Norris, told reporters that the panel was split 10-2 in favor of acquittal, which could discourage the government from pursuing a second trial. It remains unclear whether prosecutors will seek to retry Menendez, who is expected to run for re-election next year. In a statement, the Justice Department said it would "carefully consider next steps."

Republican Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, called for the Senate's ethics committee to investigate the allegations against Menendez. The committee said it would resume its inquiry, which was put on hold in 2013 to allow the criminal probe to proceed.

In a statement outside the courthouse in Newark, New Jersey, a tearful Menendez thanked God, his family, the jurors, and two senators who testified on his behalf as character witnesses, Democrat Cory Booker and Republican Lindsey Graham.

"The way this case started was wrong," said Menendez, flanked by his grown children. "The way it was investigated was wrong. The way it was prosecuted was wrong. The way it was tried was wrong as well."

"To those who were digging my political grave so they could jump into my seat: I know who you are, and I won't forget you," he said.

The mistrial provides at least a temporary measure of relief for Menendez's Democratic colleagues in the Senate, where Republicans likely would have pushed for resignation or expulsion if Menendez had been convicted.

During the 10-week trial, prosecutors accused Menendez of pressuring Medicare officials to change the agency's billing practices after it concluded that Melgen overbilled it by millions of dollars. Melgen, Menendez's co-defendant in the corruption trial, was separately convicted in Florida earlier this year of a massive Medicare fraud.

According to the government, Menendez also helped secure visas for the married Melgen's foreign girlfriends and asked U.S. officials to resolve a port dispute in the Dominican Republic involving one of Melgen's businesses. In exchange, Melgen showered the senator with luxury vacations and hundreds of thousands of campaign dollars, prosecutors said. Defense attorneys said prosecutors cherry-picked gifts exchanged between close friends to suggest impropriety when none existed.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Accuses Russia of Undermining American Democracy

Article:

The United States intelligence community has concluded with high confidence that President Putin personally ordered his security services to undertake an influence campaign aimed at undermining confidence in American democracy and sowing chaos in the electoral system. Russia's efforts to hack political organizations and state election boards are well-documented, as are the Russian disinformation campaigns on social media platforms.

Russia is identified as an adversary not just of the United States but of freedom-loving people everywhere. Disinformation and chaos is a Russian art form developed during the Soviet era, which Russia has now updated using modern tools. The result has been Russian disinformation spreading like a virus throughout the Western world. From elections in Britain, France, and Montenegro to invasions of Georgia and Ukraine, Moscow has pursued an aggressive foreign policy aimed at spreading disorder and expanding Russian influence in states formerly under the heel of Soviet Communism.

These efforts weaken U.S. allies and strengthen those who seek to undermine the democratic order that has helped prevent another world war in Europe since 1945. The threat of Russian meddling in United States elections is not behind us. Just last week, Dan Coats, the director of national intelligence, cautioned that "the warning lights are blinking red" that Russia and other adversaries will undertake further cyberattacks on the digital infrastructure. This includes many of the energy companies in South and West Texas.

Many of the author's constituents have asked what Congress can do to protect the American people from Russian threats and provide a check on the executive branch's demonstration in Helsinki. If necessary, Congress should take the lead on European security issues as it has in recent years. For example, during the Obama administration, Congress repeatedly pressed the president—using the power of the purse through appropriations bills—to send lethal weaponry to assist Ukraine in its fight against Russian-backed separatists.

Last year, Congress passed the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act to impose severe sanctions on Russia as retaliation for its meddling in the presidential election. And this year, the House passed the Ukraine Cybersecurity Cooperation Act to improve Ukraine's ability to respond to Russian-supported disinformation and propaganda efforts. The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has also asked Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to testify on the president's recent meetings with both Kim Jong-un and Vladimir Putin.

Title: Trump's 1995 Tax Return Leak: A Look at the Financial Loss and Carried Forward Losses

Article:

The recent leak of Donald Trump's 1995 tax return by the New York Times has sparked a political debate, with the return showing a significant financial loss of over $900 million. This loss could have allowed Trump to carry forward against taxable income for up to 18 years.

The article suggests that this leak might be the first in a series of political attacks against Trump in the lead-up to the November election. It is noted that Trump should have disclosed his tax returns to prevent such leaks and potential political damage.

The article discusses Trump's investment in the Atlantic City gaming and tourism market, which was heavily impacted by the legalization of gambling in various parts of the United States during the early 1990s. The losses in 1995, resulting from the bankruptcy of Trump's casinos in Atlantic City, are seen as a reflection of the market's decline.

The article also addresses the controversy surrounding Trump's ability to carry forward his losses to minimize his tax burden in better years. It is argued that this practice is common in businesses and is not necessarily a "loophole." The article cites statistics from the Tax Foundation, stating that about 1 million taxpayers had a net operating loss in 1995.

The article criticizes the New York Times for anonymously leaking Trump's tax information, stating that Trump, as an American citizen, has the right to keep his returns private. The article questions the identity of the leaker, suggesting potential involvement from the IRS, state revenue departments, lawyers, or accountants.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of uncovering the leaker and prosecuting them for violating Trump's confidentiality. The article also expresses concern about the "corrupt enemies on the Left" and the potential threat they pose to freedom and the rule of law.

Title: Trump Transition Team Accuses Special Counsel's Office of Unlawful Email Acquisition from GSA

Article:

The Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office has responded to explosive accusations by Kory Langhofer, the attorney for President Donald Trump's transition team, that the investigators looking into claims of collusion with Moscow during the campaign unlawfully received tens of thousands of emails from the General Services Administration (GSA).

In a seven-page letter sent to the Senate Homeland Security Committee and the House Oversight Committee, Langhofer claimed that employees of the GSA, which holds all the transition documents, unlawfully produced TFA's private materials, including privileged communications, to the special counsel's office. The GSA, according to Langhofer, handed over the requested "copies of the emails, laptops, cell phones, and other materials" of 13 members of the transition team even though the agency "did not own or control the records in question."

The transition emails are said to include sensitive exchanges on matters such as potential appointments, gossip about the views of particular senators involved in the confirmation process, speculation about vulnerabilities of Trump nominees, strategizing about press statements, and policy planning on everything from war to taxes. A source told Axios that the transition team will be sending a letter to Mueller asking for some emails to be returned because they're privileged.

However, Mueller's team has pushed back against these claims. Peter Carr, Mueller's spokesman, stated, "When we have obtained emails in the course of our ongoing criminal investigation, we have secured either the account owner's consent or appropriate criminal process."

GSA Deputy Counsel Lenny Loewentritt also contradicted the claims made by Trump's transition team. Loewentritt specifically rejected a claim by the transition lawyer that the late GSA general counsel made a commitment to inform Trump's team if there were specific requests for any documents because the campaign "owned and controlled" emails that were sent at the time. In an interview with BuzzFeed, Loewentritt said that the truth is the exact opposite because the transition team was clearly told that "in using our devices," materials "would not be held back in any law enforcement" actions.

Former federal prosecutor Renato Mariotti took to Twitter to explain why Trump's transition team is "playing politics" but the issue itself "is a bad sign for them." Mariotti noted that what is unusual in this case is that Mueller's team got the emails from the GSA rather than the Trump transition. That, according to Mariotti, suggests "Mueller was concerned that he wouldn't receive all of the emails if he obtained them from the Trump team," implying that he has reason to distrust Trump's team.

Mariotti also made clear that "disputes over privilege are common when prosecutors obtain emails and documents from third parties." He further stated that the privilege claims could have been easily resolved with a letter to Mueller rather than Congress, noting that's the biggest hint that the ultimate goal is to taint the investigation.

Rep. Eric Swalwell also dismissed the supposed complaints by the transition team as much ado about nothing, stating on Twitter, "Private documents' on a U.S. Government, public email system? What are they afraid was found? Baloney. This is another attempt to discredit Mueller as his #TrumpRussia probe tightens."

Title: John Bolton's Departure from Trump Administration: Motives and Principles

Article:

John Bolton, the former National Security Advisor to President Donald Trump, has revealed in a forthcoming book that he was distressed by Trump's actions regarding NATO, Russia, and Ukraine, among other issues. This, according to reports, may have influenced Bolton's decision to resign from his position in the Trump administration.

Bolton, a seasoned government professional with a career spanning various diplomatic roles, including ambassador to the United Nations, undersecretary of state, assistant secretary of state, and assistant attorney general, reportedly viewed Trump's actions as a breach of foreign policy professionalism.

In the book, Bolton is said to have characterized Trump's dealings with Ukraine as a "drug deal," a metaphor for actions that violate his sense of foreign policy professionalism. He also reportedly disdained the president's circumvention of normal diplomatic channels by informally enlisting Rudolph Giuliani, Trump's personal lawyer, whom Bolton called a "hand grenade who’s going to blow everybody up."

While speculation about Bolton's motivations for leaving the administration has included personal indignation and financial gain, the book's release, set for March 17, is expected to make it an instant bestseller. However, it is unclear to what extent these factors influenced Bolton's decision-making.

It is worth noting that Bolton served for almost a year and a half under a president known for his mercurial nature, and toward the end of his tenure, reports suggest he was unhappy in the role. Furthermore, the reported $2 million advance for his book did not necessitate the revelations to make it a hot item or line his pockets.

In conclusion, while the exact reasons for John Bolton's departure from the Trump administration remain somewhat unclear, his reported principles, professional and personal indignation, and potential financial gain are likely factors in his decision.

Title: Civil Rights Leader Jesse Jackson Criticizes Lack of Discussion on Poverty and Gun Violence in Presidential Debates

Article:

The Reverend Jesse Jackson expressed his disappointment on Wednesday over the lack of discussion on key issues, such as poverty and gun violence, in the presidential and vice presidential debates.

In an interview with ███, Jackson criticized the candidates for focusing on reconciling a $5 trillion dollar issue, which he described as "incomprehensible," while ignoring the impact of foreclosed housing driving the middle class into poverty.

The civil rights leader argued that the moderators missed opportunities to discuss issues like controlling semi-automatic weapons and poverty in areas where these subjects are particularly relevant. He cited the shootings in Aurora, Colorado, and Columbine, Colorado, as examples of gun violence that were not addressed in debates held in Denver.

Jackson also pointed out that the poorest county in America is located in Kentucky, the state that hosted the vice presidential debate. He noted that no moderator had raised the issue of poverty or low credit scores, despite the fact that 50 million people are living in poverty and another 50 million have such low credit scores that they cannot borrow money from banks.

In addition to poverty, Jackson expressed frustration with the scarce attention given to "voter suppression." He stated that voter suppression and roll purging could potentially result in a candidate winning a debate but losing the election.

Despite his criticisms, Jackson praised President Barack Obama's performance in Tuesday's presidential debate, describing him as "alive and vibrant" and noting that he "punched and counterpunched."

Regarding his son, Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr. (D-Ill.), who is currently on a medical leave of absence and is reportedly under criminal investigation, Jackson said that his son is "still recovering and under medical supervision."

Title: Joe Biden Criticizes Trump's Handling of Coronavirus Pandemic in Speech

Article:

In a highly anticipated public address on the coronavirus pandemic, former Vice President Joe Biden, who is widely expected to secure the Democrat nomination, criticized President Donald Trump's approach to the crisis. The speech, billed as commander-in-chief-worthy by supporters, did not meet the expected standards, with Biden focusing on criticizing Trump rather than presenting a unified response to the growing pandemic.

Biden accused Trump of ignoring science, having an "adversarial relationship with the truth," and promoting racism. He stated, "Unfortunately, this virus laid bare the severe shortcomings of the current administration." Biden argued that effective leadership requires open-mindedness and cooperation across national boundaries, stating that the government's response has been undermined by the Trump administration's actions.

Biden proposed several solutions to combat the virus, including rejoining the Paris climate accord, which some of the members of his newly unveiled "Public Health Advisory Committee" support. The former vice president also accused Trump of sowing fear and racial division, particularly in his approach to China's role in the pandemic. Biden claimed that Trump's efforts to hold China accountable for failing to contain the virus were emboldening racism and "xenophobia."

The speech followed the announcement of Biden's "Public Health Advisory Committee," a group tasked with providing guidance on the pandemic. The political leanings of some committee members were made evident by the proposals included in Biden's speech, such as rejoining the Paris climate accord. The former vice president also condemned acts of racism and xenophobia against the Asian American and Pacific Islander community.

Title: Pennsylvania Woman Dies in Jail While Serving Sentence for Unpaid School Fines

A Pennsylvania woman, Eileen DiNino, passed away in a jail cell over the weekend while serving a 48-hour sentence for unpaid school fines related to her children's attendance. The cause of her death is yet to be determined, and the police have stated that it is not considered suspicious. DiNino was 55 years old and a mother to seven children.

District Judge Dean Patton, who expressed reluctance in sentencing DiNino, stated that "We don't do debtors prisons anymore. That went out 100 years ago." More than 1,600 people have been jailed in Berks County alone due to similar fines, with the majority being women.

Patton stated that he has lost sleep over DiNino's death. He acknowledged that a short jail stint can sometimes "break the habit" of parents who prefer partying into the night instead of taking their children to school the next day. The county started a program a few years ago that gives families 30 to 60 days to keep daily logs of each class and assignment. Patton estimated that the district truancy rate had dropped more than 30 percent due to this program.

DiNino, according to Patton, did not work or appear to have much help with four children still at home. She frequently skipped hearings or arrived without the required documents. "She cared about her kids, but her kids ruled the roost," Patton said. "She was just accepting what was coming, and (would) let the cards fall where they may."

Berks County Commissioner Kevin Barnhardt, chairman of the county prison board, expressed outrage that DiNino died alone and away from her family while serving a sentence for being poor. "This woman died in prison, away from her family," Barnhardt said. "And for what?"

The circumstances of DiNino's death serve as a stark and tragic reminder of how being poor is considered a crime worthy of punishment in the United States. Thousands have been jailed in Berks County for failure to pay truancy fines, but court fees and other fines have put thousands of others behind bars across the country. An investigation by National Public Radio revealed instances such as a homeless man being sentenced to a year in jail for inability to pay a $2,600 penalty for shoplifting a $2 can of beer, and a teenager being jailed for three days for inability to pay the fine associated with catching a fish out of season.

Title: U.S. Welcomes Home Three Americans Released from North Korean Detention

Article:

President Donald Trump welcomed home three American citizens who were released from detention in North Korea early Thursday morning. The three men, Kim Dong Chul, Kim Hak Song, and Kim Sang Dok, were greeted by Trump and First Lady Melania Trump at Joint Base Andrews.

The three men, who are of Korean-American descent and share the common surname Kim but are not related, were flown to Washington after their release, which was facilitated by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Pompeo had traveled to Pyongyang on Tuesday in an attempt to secure the detainees' release.

Kim Dong Chul, who was sentenced to 10 years of hard labor in 2016 on charges of espionage for South Korea, expressed his gratitude for being home when asked how it felt. He stated, "We were treated in many different ways. For me, I had to do a lot of labor. But when I got sick, I was also treated by them."

The return of the prisoners clears an obstacle for direct talks between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Trump expects to announce a date and location for the summit within days and has ruled out the Korea Peninsula's Demilitarized Zone. An administration official has indicated that Singapore is the preferred location for the summit.

Trump thanked Kim for releasing the men and expressed optimism about the upcoming summit, stating, "I really think we have a very good chance of doing something very meaningful. I really think he wants to do something and bring that country into the real world."

Senator Angus King of Maine, an independent who caucuses with Democrats, cautioned against taking a victory lap until a deal is in place. "A word of caution: We're not there yet," King said on CNN.

The three men were handed over to Pompeo during his second visit to Pyongyang this year. Asked if he might visit Pyongyang himself in the future, Trump said, "It could happen."

The former detainees expressed their gratitude in a statement as they flew to Washington, stating, "We would like to express our deep appreciation to the United States government, President Trump, Secretary Pompeo, and the people of the United States for bringing us home."

Vice President Mike Pence, who joined Trump at the homecoming, stated that all three men "seem to be in good health" and were glad to be heading home. Pence also spoke with the parents of Otto Warmbier, an American college student who was detained in North Korea for trying to steal a propaganda poster from a hotel and died shortly after being returned home in a coma last year.

After meeting Trump and Pence, the former detainees were transported to Walter Reed military hospital in Bethesda, Maryland for evaluation and treatment. Vice President Pence is scheduled to sit for interviews with NBC, ABC, and CBS to be broadcast on their morning news programs.

During an interview with CBS News, Pence stated, "Promises were made and then promises were broken. But the promises weren't made by North Korea until there were concessions. Kim's agreement to release the three gives us hope that this may be different."

Title: CNN Drops Donna Brazile: A Look at the Ecosystem of Paid Partisan Commentators

Article:

CNN terminated the contract of Donna Brazile, the interim chair of the Democratic National Committee, from its roster of on-camera contributors. The decision was made following the revelation that Brazile had leaked debate questions to the Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, as shown in the hacked Podesta emails.

In one of the emails, Brazile wrote, "From time to time I get the questions in advance," with the subject head "From time to time I get the questions in advance." In another email, she provided a sneak peek of a question that would be asked by a Flint "woman with a rash," inquiring about Clinton's plans for Flint as president.

Brazile's actions were deemed wrong, as she violated an implied oath that the partisanship that got her the job would not include such open and shut chicanery. The primary debates were not reduced to a shambles, but Brazile's deceit has brought to light an ugly aspect of news talk that may go unremedied.

The issue at hand is not just one corrupt act but the entire ecosystem of paid partisan commentators. The news shows rely on these individuals not for their political insights but as a cheap form of on-air talent to fill the 24/7 programming needs. A partial list of notable politicians or political operators who have worked their way into TV includes Tim Russert, Bill Bradley, George Stephanopoulos, Joe Scarborough, Van Jones, William Safire, James Carville, Jeffrey Lord, Kayleigh McEnany, Pat Buchanan, Rick Santorum, Paul Begala, David Gergen, Chris Matthews, Peggy Noonan, Sarah Palin, Jennifer Granholm, David Axelrod, Tony Blankley, Mary Matalin, Jesse Jackson, Al Sharpton, Mike Huckabee, John Bolton, Newt Gingrich, Eliot Spitzer, and Corey Lewandowski.

These individuals are hired not for their political insights but because they are known quantities who provide safe and predictable idle talk. By dividing their partisan contributors between Republicans and Democrats, TV creates the illusion of impartiality and inclusion. The contributors take the job because it's easy, and the face-time makes them more marketable on the lecture circuit.

Not every TV contributor moment is a complete botch. Most of these people, with the exception of Lewandowski, know something about politics. However, they tend to conform to the expectations of the producers putting on the show, hit their marks, fill the dead spaces with palaver, keep the commercials from bumping into one another, and sit at attention until called on or interrupt should the show stall.

What transpires during the paid contributor segments is not journalism, not politics, and rarely entertaining. It's not in, say, David Axelrod's interests to share a damaging insight about Barack Obama, the horse he rode to prominence on. Almost to a one, the contributors pull punches and dilute the political conversation to the weakest of teas so the people in the bar and riding the elliptical trainers at the gym don't have to strain to follow the Punch and Judy of it all.

Instead of deploying political hacks, the news shows would be smarter to hire journalists whose job it would be to extract meaningful information from the political hacks. Under this scheme, the Braziles and Carvilles and Palins could still be interviewed on TV, but they couldn't draw pay—and they'd have to have something worthy to say or accept having the camera cut away from them.

Donna Brazile is probably sipping a cocktail tonight somewhere in Washington, wondering what hit her. CNN hired her to be a partisan, although not as much as her real employer, and what can be more partisan than leaking valuable political intelligence to help your side? Did CNN really think that the elementary concepts of journalistic fairness would govern her conduct?

Title: Washington State City's Minimum Wage Hike to Set Highest Rate in U.S., Employers Face Challenges

Article:

As discussions intensify on Capitol Hill regarding a potential increase in the federal minimum wage, the city of SeaTac, Washington, is set to establish the highest minimum wage rate in the nation, starting on January 1. Approximately 1,600 hotel and transportation workers in SeaTac will see their pay rise to $15 per hour, a 60 percent increase from the state's current minimum wage of $9.32.

While many workers welcome the higher pay, employers are seeking ways to manage the significant increase in labor costs. Some are considering job eliminations. Cedarbrook Lodge General Manager Scott Ostrander stated, "We're going to be looking at making some serious cuts. We're going to be looking at reducing employee hours, reducing benefits, and eliminating some positions."

In the short term, these cuts are expected, but the Cedarbrook Lodge plans to offset the higher labor costs by building an addition to the hotel. The aim is to increase revenue to cover the increased wages. However, not every employer is as ambitious. One has announced plans to close one of its two restaurants, eliminating 200 jobs.

The minimum wage increase has also caused Han Kim, who runs Hotel Concepts, a company that owns and manages 11 hotels in Washington state, to postpone plans to build a hotel in SeaTac. The company already has three hotels in SeaTac, and Kim and a business partner were looking to build a fourth on land they own. "Uncertainty is bad for business, and right now we're right in that area, so we're just putting everything on hold," Kim said.

Opponents of the $15 minimum wage scored a legal victory late last week when a King County, Washington, judge ruled that it does not apply to any of the workers at the SeaTac airport. Superior Court Judge Andrea Darvas ruled that only the Port of Seattle can set wage and other work rules at the airport, eliminating 4,700 workers from the successful ballot initiative.

Backers of the $15 minimum wage have vowed to appeal the ruling up to the state Supreme Court. One of the biggest supporters is Kshama Sawant, a socialist who also won her election to the Seattle City Council. She plans on making Seattle the next city to have a $15 minimum wage. "There may be a few jobs lost here and there, but the fact is, if we don't fight for this, then the race to the bottom will continue," Sawant said.

Sawant is skeptical that the higher minimum wage will lead to mass layoffs. However, the American Car Rental Association estimates that 5 percent of low-wage jobs will be cut, and another 5-10 percent of those workers will be replaced by more experienced workers. The owner of Dollar Rental Cars told Fox News she will outsource some functions, change schedules, and cut some staff in response to the new policy.

Title: Minneapolis Mayor Frey Rejects Calls to Abolish Police Department; City Council Members Advocate for Defunding

Article:

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey has reiterated his opposition to abolishing the city's police force, contradicting a veto-proof majority of Minneapolis City Council members who have expressed support for the drastic step in response to the in-custody death of George Floyd.

On Sunday, Frey, who ordered the evacuation of a police station during riots last month, faced a large gathering of demonstrators near his home. He was booed and shouted down when he defied their demands to dismantle the city's police forces entirely.

"I'll work relentlessly with Chief [Medaria] Arradondo and alongside community toward deep, structural reform and addressing systemic racism in police culture," Frey said in a statement to KARE. "We're ready to dig in and enact more community-led, public safety strategies on behalf of our city. But, I do not support abolishing the Minneapolis Police Department."

Before the crowd, Frey had prefaced his comments by saying he was "coming to grips" with his "own brokenness," and by promising to put the police union "in its place." However, many protesters were unconvinced, shouting, "It's not about you!" and "Go home, Jacob, go home!"

Nine city council members spoke at a protest at Powderhorn Park on Sunday, representing a veto-proof majority to push the measure through, according to Fox 9. Council President Lisa Bender, VP Andrea Jenkins, and Councilmembers Alondra Cano, Jeremiah Ellison, Steve Fletcher, Phillipe Cunningham, Cam Gordon, and Jeremy Schroeder were among those in attendance.

Councilmember Jeremiah Ellison, the son of state Attorney General Keith Ellison, has openly declared his support for Antifa, the left-wing group that President Trump has sought to designate as a terrorist organization. Most members of the city council have belonged to the Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor Party.

"Our commitment is to end our city's toxic relationship with the Minneapolis Police Department," Bender said. "It is clear that our system of policing is not keeping our communities safe. Our efforts at incremental reform have failed, period."

Bender went on to say she and the eight other council members that joined the rally were committed to ending the city's relationship with the police force and "to end policing as we know it and recreate systems that actually keep us safe."

On Monday, Bender told CNN that people worried about having no one to call during a home invasion were speaking from a "place of privilege." Those comments drew widespread backlash.

Ellison, for his part, promised that the council would "dismantle" the department.

Nationally, efforts to defund the police have been broadly unpopular, with only about 20 percent of Americans favoring reductions in police forces. Citing publicly available data, commentators have asserted that the very idea of systemic racism by police is questionable.

In 2018, African-Americans made up 53% of known homicide offenders in the U.S. and committed about 60% of robberies, though they are 13% of the population, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal this week. In 2018, there were 7,407 black homicide victims. Assuming a comparable number of victims last year, those nine unarmed black victims of police shootings represented 0.1% of all African-Americans killed in 2019. By contrast, a police officer is 18.5 times more likely to be killed by a black male than an unarmed black male is to be killed by a police officer.

A 2015 Justice Department analysis of the Philadelphia Police Department found that white police officers were less likely than black or Hispanic officers to shoot unarmed black suspects. Research by Harvard economist Roland G. Fryer Jr. also found no evidence of racial discrimination in shootings. Any evidence to the contrary fails to take into account crime rates and civilian behavior before and during interactions with police.

Fryer's work has also determined that when police pull out of communities, black deaths tend to increase.

Disbanding an entire department has happened before. In 2012, with crime rampant in Camden, New Jersey, the city disbanded its ineffective union-run police department and replaced it with a new force that covered Camden County. Compton, California, took the same step in 2000, shifting its policing to Los Angeles County.

The move to defund or abolish the Minneapolis department is far from assured, with the civil rights investigation likely to unfold over the next several months.

Title: Voter Fraud Ring Busted in Los Angeles: Nine Accused of Forging Signatures for Ballot Measures and Voter Registration

Article:

In Los Angeles, a voter fraud ring has been uncovered, with nine individuals accused of forging signatures on state ballot measure petitions and voter registration forms. The accused, who face several criminal charges including circulating a petition with fake names, voter fraud, and registering a fictitious person, reportedly lured the homeless with cash and cigarettes in exchange for their forged signatures.

The district attorney's office announced the charges on Tuesday, three weeks after the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) conducted a crackdown on suspected election fraud on skid row. The defendants, some of whom were scheduled for arraignment on Tuesday, are alleged to have approached homeless individuals on skid row and asked them to forge signatures.

The charges follow a report by The Los Angeles Times, which stated that the forged signature exchange occurred hundreds of times during the 2016 and 2020 election cycles. Los Angeles elections chief, Dean Logan, told the publication that his staff, which manually compares signatures, did not let the forgeries slip through. However, he expressed concern about any activity that undermines voter trust in the system.

This is not the first instance of voter fraud in the United States. Similar incidents have been reported in states such as Pennsylvania, Texas, and Wisconsin. The issue of voter fraud has been a contentious topic, with some arguing it is rare, while others claim it can potentially impact election outcomes. It is important to note that the frequency and impact of voter fraud remain subjects of debate.

Title: Michael Cohen Identified as Legal Representative for Fox News Host Sean Hannity

Article:

In a federal court hearing on Monday, it was revealed that Donald Trump's longtime attorney, Michael Cohen, has been representing Fox News host Sean Hannity. The disclosure came as part of a dispute over evidence seized by the FBI from Cohen's home and office earlier this month.

Federal judge Kimba Wood ordered an attorney for Cohen to reveal the identity of a client that Cohen's team had withheld in earlier court documents. Cohen and Trump had sought either to permit them to review the material before prosecutors got to see it or to appoint an independent "special master."

The judge stated that she could not decide about how seriously to treat Cohen's and Trump's claims about attorney-client privilege unless she knew what clients Cohen has been representing. As a result, an attorney for Cohen, who had asked whether he could submit the name to the judge in a sealed envelope or to the "special master," had no choice but to reveal it in open court.

Cohen's attorney had previously identified two other clients: Trump and Republican fundraiser Elliott Broidy. These men are involved in cases in which Cohen allegedly arranged payments to women to keep them quiet about alleged sexual encounters. Cohen has acknowledged paying pornographic actress Stormy Daniels $130,000 shortly before the 2016 election for what her lawyer said was silence about her alleged liaison with Trump in 2006. Cohen also reportedly arranged a deal for Broidy in which model Shera Bechard was paid $1.6 million when she became pregnant after an affair.

Trump denies any sexual relationship with Daniels. Broidy acknowledged the affair with Bechard and apologized to his family. There was no indication as to whether Hannity might have been involved in such an arrangement. Hannity issued a statement on Monday afternoon that said his discussions with Cohen had never involved anyone else.

"Michael Cohen has never represented me in any matter," Hannity said. "I never retained him, received an invoice, or paid legal fees. I have occasionally had brief discussions with him about legal questions about which I wanted his input and perspective. I assumed those conversations were confidential, but to be absolutely clear they never involved any matter between me and a third party."

Hannity said separately on Twitter that his discussions with Cohen "dealt almost exclusively about real estate."

Hannity has been a vocal supporter of Trump and Cohen on his show and a critic of the FBI and Justice Department. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich said on Hannity's show last week that the FBI raid on Cohen was like the abuses of the "Gestapo."

After a long hearing on Monday, Wood said she had concluded the hearing without deciding whether to appoint the "special master" sought by Cohen or to permit the Justice Department's "filter team" to continue its work. While federal investigators will retain possession of what was seized, they still cannot look at the substance yet even as they are cataloging the amount of papers, electronic files, and other materials.

Title: Americans' Dissatisfaction with Obama's Handling of ISIS and National Security, According to New CNN/ORC Poll

Article:

A new CNN/ORC poll released on Monday indicates that Americans are increasingly displeased with President Barack Obama's handling of ISIS and foreign affairs, national security, and terrorism. The survey suggests a growing belief among Americans that the fight against ISIS is going poorly.

The poll shows that 57% disapprove of Obama's handling of foreign affairs, 54% disapprove of his handling of terrorism, and 60% rate him negatively on his handling of electronic national security.

The declining approval ratings for Obama on national security come as a weekend of international turmoil further underscores the growing threats abroad. Egypt launched a second round of airstrikes against Islamic State strongholds in Libya on Monday, in response to a video released Sunday that appeared to show ISIS militants beheading a group of 21 Egyptian Christians.

Obama issued a statement condemning the killing of the Christians on Sunday night, but his Republican opponents have consistently argued that the growing Islamic State threat is exacerbated by what they see as his weak leadership.

In the poll, Americans increasingly believe the U.S. military action against ISIS is going badly, with 58% saying so in the latest survey, up from 49% who said the fight was not going well in October. Even among Democrats, nearly half—46%—say things are not going well in the battle against ISIS.

About half of respondents, 51%, say they trust the President as Commander-in-Chief of the military. However, support for sending ground troops to Iraq and Syria to confront the threat appears to be growing. In November, just 43% supported deploying ground troops, while 55% of Americans opposed it; now the number in support has ticked up to 47%, the highest level of support yet measured, with just half of Americans opposed.

The parties have become more polarized on the prospect since November, with 61% of Democrats opposed and a similar majority of Republicans supportive of the prospect, an eight-point increase. Independents, meanwhile, are split, with 48% in favor and 50% opposed.

The prospect of sending in ground troops remains a sticking point for both congressional Democrats and Republicans in the debate over Obama's Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF), which would give him legal authority to combat ISIS. However, the AUMF, and Obama's decision to go to Congress for the official authority to continue battling ISIS, is widely popular, according to the new poll.

Seventy-eight percent of Americans say Congress should give Obama the authority to fight ISIS, a slight decline from 82% who supported it in December. A similarly large majority say Obama was right to ask Congress for the authority, rather than proceeding with the battle unilaterally.

The survey was conducted among 1,027 adult Americans from Feb. 12-15, and has a margin of sampling error of 3%.

Title: White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer's Inaccurate Statements Regarding Michael Flynn's Contact with Russian Ambassador

Article:

During the early days of the Donald Trump administration, Press Secretary Sean Spicer made inaccurate statements regarding National Security Advisor Michael Flynn's contact with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak.

On the first official workday of Trump's presidency, Spicer, during his inaugural briefing, stated that there had only been one call between Flynn and Kislyak. This was proven false three weeks later when The Washington Post reported that Flynn had allegedly discussed U.S.-imposed sanctions on Russia with Kislyak and had misled the White House about the nature of their conversation. Flynn resigned on February 13.

Less than three weeks after Flynn's resignation, it was also revealed that Spicer's assertion about the single call was false. The White House confirmed that Flynn had met with Kislyak alongside Jared Kushner, Trump's senior adviser and son-in-law, in December. This meeting was first reported by The New York Times and later confirmed by The Hive.

A White House official explained that Spicer was not aware of the meeting with Kushner, Flynn, and Kislyak because Kushner had met with numerous foreign officials throughout the transition. This has become a common line of defense in the White House, as aides struggle to explain the interactions, topics discussed, and reasons for Kislyak's ubiquity during a time of a cyber quasi-war between Russia and the Obama administration.

It remains unclear why Flynn was unforthcoming about his meetings with Kislyak, or why those within the Trump administration who were aware of Flynn's misdirection chose to conceal that information from others, including Vice President Mike Pence. It is also unclear who knew that Attorney General Jeff Sessions had met with Kislyak during the election season, as Sessions recused himself from any investigations pertaining to Russia and the Trump campaign. Spicer apparently was not aware of Flynn's discussions or the meeting with Kushner, Flynn, and Kislyak, and Trump has stated he did not know about Sessions' sit-down with the ambassador either.

Title: Army Regulations Determine Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl's Discharge Status

Article:

The U.S. Army is expected to discharge Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl upon the expiration of his active duty commitment, unless the Army proceeds with a court-martial, according to military law expert Charles Gittins. The decision comes down to Army regulations that dictate how service members are discharged.

Those still serving their enlistment commitment are treated differently than someone like Sgt. Bergdahl, who has completed his agreement and is on an administrative hold. A non-hold active duty soldier whom the Army wanted to discharge could be sent to an administrative board. However, Sgt. Bergdahl, who is awaiting an Army decision on whether he will face criminal charges for walking off his base in Afghanistan on June 30, 2009, and becoming an enemy captive until last May, is not subject to this process.

"You can't administratively discharge someone after their EAS [End of Active Service] has expired," said Gittins. "If he is on legal hold, they either court-martial him or discharge him with an honorable discharge."

If the Army wants to seek an other-than-honorable discharge, it would have to pursue criminal charges. At that point, there is a regulation that would allow the soldier to negotiate a less-than-honorable discharge in lieu of a trial, Gittins said. Conviction at court-martial could bring a bad conduct or dishonorable discharge.

Maj. Gen. Kenneth Dahl, the officer tapped to investigate Sgt. Bergdahl's actions in Afghanistan, has completed his report and submitted it to the office of Army Secretary John McHugh. A source familiar with the probe said Sgt. Bergdahl has denied that he deserted and provided an explanation for why he walked away that day. Soldiers from Sgt. Bergdahl's unit have accused him of desertion.

Sgt. Bergdahl is now at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, assigned to the company headquarters, where he was interviewed last August by Gen. Dahl. Also present was the soldier's attorney, Eugene Fidell, who specializes in military law and teaches at Yale Law School.

"He answered every question that was put to him," Mr. Fidell told The ███. "I came away extraordinarily impressed by Gen. Dahl. I thought the country is lucky to have him. And sort of wonder what the rest of his career trajectory will look like, because I wish him well."

Gen. Dahl, a West Point graduate who completed two combat tours in Afghanistan, is a well-respected battlefield commander. He is now deputy commander of Army I Corps at Joint Base Lewis-McChord in Washington.

The source familiar with the investigation did not know Gen. Dahl's conclusions, which have ramifications beyond the fate of Sgt. Bergdahl himself. The investigation's findings could potentially impact the ongoing debate about President Obama's decision to release five hardened Taliban leaders to gain Sgt. Bergdahl's release and the subsequent criticism of the White House for not notifying Congress ahead of time, as required by law.

A finding that Sgt. Bergdahl deserted and faces court-martial would bolster the argument that Mr. Obama endangered troops in Afghanistan for the benefit of a deserter. The president announced Sgt. Bergdahl's release with great fanfare, bringing the parents, Robert and Jani Bergdahl of Hailey, Idaho, to the White House for a joint appearance.

National Security Adviser Susan Rice told ABC News that the soldier "served the United States with honor and distinction." She said Sgt. Bergdahl "wasn't simply a hostage; he was an American prisoner of war captured on the battlefield."

The White House praise brought waves of rebuttals from the sergeant's battlemates, who went on TV and radio. They painted the picture of a loner who simply abandoned them one morning by walking away from Combat Outpost Mest-Lalak in Paktika Province. Worse, they said, people died in combat while searching for him.

"The American people need to be educated that Bowe Bergdahl is not a hero," Joshua Cornelison, the medic in his platoon, told "Fox News Sunday." "After Bowe Bergdahl purposely and willfully walked away, every single mission was titled toward finding him."

The source familiar with the investigation said that the sergeant, while a captive for nearly five years at the hands of the extremely violent Haqqani network in Pakistan, tried to escape and was abused.

"It is actually surprising how well he withstood abuse," the source said.

A Rolling Stone article quoted then-Private Bergdahl's emails as expressing disenchantment with his combat role in Afghanistan. House Armed Services Committee member Duncan Hunter, California Republican, has accused the Pentagon of orchestrating a ransom payment for Sgt. Bergdahl, then being taken in by an "Afghan intermediary."

He wrote in a Nov. 5 letter to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel that Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC), the home of SEAL Team Six and Army Delta Force, paid money earlier this winter. The go-between took the cash, disappeared, and never helped to gain the soldier's release, Mr. Hunter wrote, citing confidential sources.

The Pentagon denied it made a ransom payment. The congressman has asked the Defense Department inspector general to investigate. Navy Rear Admiral John Kirby, Mr. Hagel's press secretary, said the defense chief was to be briefed on the Dahl probe on Friday. But, he said, it's up to the Army to make decisions. He said that generally, reports such as Gen. Dahl's are not released publicly if there are judicial proceedings to follow.

"It's for the Army to decide what the next steps are," he said. "They're not going to go any faster than they need to go in terms of process."

He added, "I suspect that at the appropriate time, the Army will make the investigation public."

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Criticizes Facial Recognition Technology and Hiring Practices in Detroit Crime Center

Article:

Representative Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) has sparked controversy after visiting Detroit's "Real-Time Crime" center, which uses facial recognition technology. During the visit, Tlaib expressed concerns about the racial composition of the analysts working at the facility, stating that African Americans would be more effective in identifying African Americans and Latinos.

According to The Detroit News, Tlaib visited the center on Monday, following her tweet expressing concern about the city's use of facial recognition technology. During the tour, Tlaib took issue with the predominantly white analysts in a city that is 80% black.

When asked about her comments regarding the qualifications of white analysts, Tlaib referred to studies that suggest non-white individuals may have difficulty identifying individuals of other races. When asked if this meant non-whites should be barred from working as crime analysts in mostly white communities, Tlaib responded, "Look it up."

Critics, including Detroit Police Chief James Craig, have condemned Tlaib's remarks as reverse racism. Craig stated, "We have a diverse group of crime analysts, and what she said—that non-whites should not work in that capacity because they think all black people look alike—is a slap in the face to all the men and women in the crime center."

Several studies have shown that facial recognition technology and white people often misidentify non-white faces. For instance, a study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found that facial recognition algorithms misidentify black faces 5 to 10 times more often than white faces. Researchers at MIT have also noted that the technology is flawed because it learns from human programmers, who are predominantly white and male.

Tlaib has cited these studies in her criticism of facial recognition technology, but her comments have been met with skepticism by some, particularly those who reject scientific consensus on issues such as global warming, police killings, and the capabilities of their political leaders.

Title: Legal Challenges Mount Against Trump's National Emergency Declaration for Border Wall Funding

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to use emergency powers to secure funding for the construction of a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border is facing legal challenges from several states and advocacy groups. California and New York have announced their intention to challenge the move, which bypasses Congress, with California Governor Gavin Newsom dismissing the president's decision as "political theatre."

On Friday, Mr. Trump signed an emergency declaration and a spending bill aimed at preventing a repeat of the recent government shutdown. The emergency declaration could give him access to billions of dollars for the wall project, which was a key pledge of his campaign. Democrats have criticized the move as a "gross abuse of power" and vowed to contest it "using every remedy available."

Within hours of the announcement, the first legal challenge against the declaration of national emergency was launched by the liberal advocacy group Public Citizen, on behalf of a nature reserve and three Texas landowners who have been told the wall may be constructed on their properties. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has also announced plans to file a lawsuit in the coming days to challenge the "blatantly illegal executive action."

New York state's Democratic attorney general, Letitia James, said the state would "not stand for this abuse of power and will fight back with every legal tool at our disposal." The ACLU has suggested that the remark by Mr. Trump that he "didn't need to do this" could undermine his case that the country is facing an emergency.

The National Emergencies Act contains a clause that allows Congress to terminate the emergency status if both houses vote for it and the president does not veto. With a comfortable majority in the House, Democrats could pass such a resolution to the Senate. The Republicans control the Senate, but a number of Republican senators have been vocal in their unease about the president invoking a national emergency.

The dissenting Republicans include 2012 presidential contender and new senator for Utah Mitt Romney, Florida senator Marco Rubio, and the senator from Maine Susan Collins, who said the move was of "dubious constitutionality." The resolution would still require Mr. Trump's signature to pass, allowing him to veto it. A supermajority in both houses of Congress is needed to overturn a presidential veto.

The National Emergencies Act is intended for times of national crisis. Mr. Trump has claimed that there is a migration crisis at the nation's southern border - a claim strongly refuted by migration experts. The largest number of illegal migrants settling in the U.S. each year is those who stay in the country after their visas expire.

Declaring a national emergency would give the president access to special powers that effectively allow him to bypass the usual political process, and he would be able to divert money from existing military or disaster relief budgets to pay for the wall. Emergency declarations by previous presidents have been overwhelmingly used for addressing foreign policy crises. The $8 billion for the wall would be made up of funds from the Department of Defense, with the largest amount coming from the military construction budget. This is almost certain to bring a legal challenge.

Title: Over 50 Pakistani Journalists Test Positive for Coronavirus as Country Eases Lockdown

Article:

At least 54 journalists and media workers have tested positive for the coronavirus across Pakistan, according to data released by the Freedom Network rights group on Monday. This marks a significant increase in infections among the country's media personnel, as the South Asian nation continues to ease its lockdown amid a spike in cases and deaths.

One of the first journalists to test positive for the virus in the country is Salman Ashraf, a reporter for local television station Geo News in the southwest city of Quetta. Ashraf, who was one of seven people to test positive for the coronavirus in his organization's Quetta bureau, described his symptoms as a high fever and severe body pain.

The data shows a similar pattern of clusters of coronavirus cases in newsrooms and bureaus across the country, where journalists, technical staff, and media assistants often work in close proximity to each other. The number of infections in Pakistan began spiking last week, with several consecutive days of record increases in new infections and deaths.

On Sunday, reported infections rose by a further 1,476 to 30,941, with at least 667 deaths and 8,212 patients having recovered. On Monday, provinces began implementing a government-mandated easing of lockdown measures, with smaller markets and several industries allowed to reopen for up to five days a week, operating from sunrise until 5 pm each day.

Prime Minister Imran Khan's government has insisted that a full lockdown is not economically sustainable for a country that was already in the midst of an economic crisis when its outbreak began in late February. Last month, the International Monetary Fund estimated that Pakistan's economy would contract by 1.5 percent owing to the coronavirus-related lockdowns, close to the worst such figures since the country gained independence in 1947.

Khan has insisted that industries follow government-mandated standard operating procedures to keep workers safe, or face being closed down again. For journalists working across the country, individual news organizations have issued guidelines regarding social distancing and protective equipment while reporting, but implementation on the ground has been inconsistent.

One journalist in Quetta, speaking on condition of anonymity fearing reprisals from his employer, said, "We are going into the field in the same way. We are working in the same way, in the field and in the office. We are contacting the public in the same way." The journalist said guidelines were in place but were not being enforced or followed by many journalists.

Competition in Pakistan's news media landscape is cut-throat, with more than 30 24-hour television news channels competing with each other for ratings, in addition to dozens of national and regional newspapers. "The general behavior that we are seeing, I am mentally prepared that I am going to get the virus. And I do not feel like I can save myself from this," said Syed Shahzad Kazmi, a cameraman for the local Roze News television station in the northwestern city of Peshawar.

Kazmi, who tested positive for the coronavirus late last month, spent two weeks in quarantine at home before being certified as having recovered by health authorities. Another cameraman, Asad Ali, tested positive for the coronavirus after being infected by a co-worker at his organization's bureau. After spending two weeks in quarantine, he said he was back at work on the night shift, working as normal.

Iqbal Khattak, representative for the global media rights group Reporters Without Borders in Pakistan, said, "The protocol is quite good, but still, I think the protocol needs some [additional] steps." RSF's recommendations to Pakistani news organizations include no longer requiring television reporters to report live from places with large crowds, restricting coverage of press conferences where large numbers may gather, and avoiding commissioning reports from hospitals.

"I was just watching the 3 pm bulletin [on television]... and these journalists were all on the streets, close to the public," said Khattak. "This is a worrying sign... Getting live hits from the field is a risk that they are taking, and I think media houses should avoid taking these risks."

Title: Retired General John Allen to Coordinate International Coalition Against ISIS

Article:

Retired four-star Marine General John Allen, who previously served as the commander of American forces in Afghanistan, has been appointed to coordinate the international coalition against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Friday.

Allen's new role marks a return to a challenging mission with no clear solutions, a mission he is familiar with due to his extensive experience in the region. Allen was one of the top commanders in western Iraq during the "Sunni Awakening," a program that aimed to turn Sunni tribes in Anbar province against the al Qaeda affiliate operating in Iraq at the time.

The militant organization currently occupying portions of both Syria and Iraq, which President Barack Obama has vowed to destroy, is the successor to that al Qaeda group.

Allen graduated with honors from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1976 and has a long and distinguished list of accomplishments, both on the battlefields of Afghanistan and Iraq and as a peacemaker in one of the Middle East's longest and most intractable conflicts.

In 2011, Obama tapped Allen to take command of the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan, the NATO-led coalition of military forces in that country, after Obama nominated Gen. David Petraeus, then the coalition's commander, to become director of the CIA. Allen was the first Marine to head up the military effort in Afghanistan.

Later, Allen was appointed by Kerry to develop a security plan for Israel and the West Bank during negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians over the possibility of a future Palestinian state that eventually collapsed. Before his command in Afghanistan, Allen was deputy commander at U.S. Central Command, which oversees all military operations in the Middle East.

Allen is a decorated veteran of the armed forces, having received the Defense Distinguished Service Medal and the Defense Superior Service Medal among others. While controversy mostly eluded his impressive rise to the top ranks of the U.S. military, Allen was briefly caught up in the 2012 scandal involving Petraeus' infidelity that ultimately led the widely admired retired general to resign his CIA post.

An investigation into "flirtatious" email exchanges between Allen and Jill Kelley, the Florida woman whose complaints about threatening emails from Petraeus' mistress, Paula Broadwell, brought the scandal into the public, led Allen to withdraw his nomination by Obama to become NATO's supreme allied commander in 2013. The Defense Department eventually cleared him of any wrongdoing, and Allen retired from the Marines.

Allen is the married father of two daughters and holds master's degrees from Georgetown University, the Defense Intelligence College, and the National War College.

Title: Defense Workers Return to Duty as Shutdown Enters Second Week

Article:

The United States federal government shutdown, now in its second week, has seen a significant development as the Department of Defense has ordered the recall of most of its furloughed civilian employees. According to The Two-Way's Bill Chappell, this affects approximately 400,000 workers.

The decision was announced by Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Saturday, following the passage of the "Pay Our Military Act" by Congress and its subsequent signing by President Obama. The law, which allows for the recall of civilians who support service personnel, does not permit a blanket recall of all civilians, Hagel stated.

As of the weekend, there were no signs of serious negotiations, and the longer the standoff continues, the more likely it is to collide with the Oct. 17 deadline to raise the debt ceiling, setting the stage for a potential battle over fiscal policy in the coming weeks.

In a weekend of partisan exchanges, more than a dozen lawmakers appeared on Sunday shows to reinforce their positions in the congressional impasse, as reported by Politico.

The Washington Post, acknowledging that no party in Washington looks good amid the ongoing shutdown, offers a guide to the losers and not-quite losers. The Post suggests that Republican governors with White House aspirations are faring better than their partisan colleagues on Capitol Hill. The Post states, "The Bobby Jindals and Chris Christies of the world are having a field day right about now. Need evidence that all of Washington is broken and that a problem-solver from outside the Beltway is the only answer? The shutdown — along with the name-calling that has followed — says it all."

Title: Obama's Shift in Perspective: From Emphasizing Construction Jobs to Criticizing Keystone XL Pipeline Project

Article:

In a recent speech in Chattanooga, Tennessee, President Barack Obama expressed skepticism towards the Keystone XL oil pipeline project, a stark contrast to his previous enthusiasm for construction jobs during his first term. During the speech, Mr. Obama chuckled derisively when mentioning the pipeline's potential to create thousands of jobs over two years.

"They keep on talking about this—an oil pipeline coming down from Canada that’s estimated to create about 50 permanent jobs," Mr. Obama said. "That’s not a jobs plan."

In a previous interview, the president estimated that the pipeline project would create "maybe 2,000" construction jobs, referring to these jobs as "a blip" of what the nation needs. This contrasts with Mr. Obama's attitude during his first term, when he expressed enthusiasm for construction jobs of all kinds.

In November 2011, as part of his "We Can’t Wait" campaign, Mr. Obama held an event at the Key Bridge in Georgetown to call on Congress to approve more temporary stimulus spending on infrastructure projects to help unemployed construction workers. At the time, Mr. Obama said, "Of all the industries hammered by the economic downturn, construction has been among the hardest hit."

In February 2009, Mr. Obama urged Congress to approve an $800 billion-plus economic stimulus package, citing the need for construction jobs. He stated that the stimulus legislation "has the right priorities to create 3 [million] to 4 million jobs and to do it in a way that lays the groundwork for long-term growth by fixing our schools; modernizing health care to lower costs; repairing our roads, bridges, levees, and other vital infrastructure; and moving us toward energy independence."

Even before taking the oath of office in January 2009, Mr. Obama was promoting government-funded infrastructure projects, stating that they were "shovel-ready all across the country." Many of these projects would have been temporary jobs, given the act's proposed life of two or three years.

Two years later, amid criticism that the stimulus law hadn't produced the promised number of construction jobs, Mr. Obama wisecracked, "Shovel-ready was not as shovel-ready as we expected."

Mr. Obama's top aides stated that the president was not disparaging the value of construction jobs in his most recent comments but was trying to make a point that House Republicans lack a comprehensive strategy for creating jobs. Dan Pfeiffer, senior adviser to Mr. Obama, told The ███ on Wednesday that the president's latest comments are "not inconsistent" with previous statements about construction jobs.

"One infrastructure project is not a jobs strategy," Mr. Pfeiffer said at a breakfast meeting with reporters hosted by The Christian Science Monitor. "That would be like saying our jobs strategy is to repair the Key Bridge. We’re talking about one thing, and it would have some temporary jobs which would be significant. But in the overall scale of the employment situation in this country, as the president said, it’s a blip. And when that’s done, contrary to… the rhetoric you hear, it’s 50 to 100 permanent jobs."

Mr. Pfeiffer suggested that the president's comments about Keystone are aimed at September confrontations with Republicans over spending and borrowing.

"He’s put his jobs ideas on the table, he’s calling on Republicans to do the same," Mr. Pfeiffer said. "To date, the core of the Republican jobs package… is vote to repeal Obamacare for the 40th time and build the Keystone pipeline. There’s a legitimate debate over whether you should build that pipeline or not. The president’s point is that’s not a jobs strategy."

Republican lawmakers suspect that the president is signaling his disapproval of the project, which environmentalists vehemently oppose. Last month, Mr. Obama said his administration would approve the pipeline only if it would not contribute to carbon pollution. Canadian government and private officials have stated repeatedly that they will mine the oil and sell it in the U.S. or elsewhere to burn and put carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, regardless of whether the pipeline is built.

Republicans said that whether Mr. Obama is trying to kill the pipeline or is posturing for September, he is way off base in the jobs numbers for the project.

"The president famously pledged to 'do whatever it takes' to create jobs—but this is a new low," said House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton, Michigan Republican. "Attacking new job opportunities is not a jobs plan. Unions and manufacturers are desperate for the president to say yes to the Keystone pipeline because it will get thousands of workers off of unemployment and back on the job. The president should listen to these American workers looking for a job and embrace the opportunity to realize the benefits of $7 billion in private investments."

The State Department has estimated that the pipeline project would create 5,000 to 6,000 construction jobs per year. TransCanada Corp., which would build the pipeline, has said it would generate about 13,000 jobs over two years. The State Department also said the project could support another 42,000 jobs per year for two years across the U.S. in related industries.

Title: Trump Endorses Paul Ryan, Shocks Some Grassroots Conservatives

Article:

In a significant move, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump endorsed House Speaker Paul D. Ryan on Friday, marking an end to his previous hesitation to support the party's most powerful elected leader. The endorsement, made at a campaign rally in Wisconsin, signaled Trump's readiness to work with the Republican Party establishment that had initially opposed his candidacy.

At the rally in Green Bay, Trump stated, "In our shared mission to make America great again, I support and endorse our speaker of the House, Paul Ryan. He's a good man."

The endorsement, however, sparked discontent among grass-roots conservatives who had hoped Trump would help overthrow establishment figures like Ryan, viewed as fake conservatives or RINOs, the derogatory acronym for those deemed to be Republicans in name only.

Trump had withheld his endorsement in Ryan's primary race against an anti-establishment rival, Paul Nehlen, a strong Trump supporter. In recent days, Trump had expressed his reservations about backing Ryan, echoing the speaker's earlier comments when he resisted endorsing Trump.

Trump, referencing Ronald Reagan's philosophy, stated, "We may disagree on a couple of things, but mostly we agree. And we're going to get it done, and we're going to do a lot of wonderful things."

In addition to endorsing Ryan, Trump also announced endorsements for two Senate Republican incumbents in tough races who have been tentative in their support for him: Arizona Sen. John McCain and New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte.

The trio of endorsements, particularly the one for Ryan, surprised some of Trump's diehard supporters. Trump supporter Sue Payne, a conservative activist working to defeat Ryan, expressed her disappointment, stating, "He has broken our heart doing this tonight. We finally thought we had a voice to stand up against the RINO establishment. He sold us out."

Paul Nehlen, Ryan's primary rival, understood Trump's decision to back the party leadership. In a statement, he said, "Given his stature as our party's official nominee, Mr. Trump's decision to support the Republican Speaker is appropriate and is a display of true leadership."

Nehlen further stated, "Mr. Trump's early refusal to endorse Ryan sent a clear signal to Wisconsin voters that Ryan is not his preferred candidate in this race. Speaker Ryan's globalist agenda stands in clear opposition to the will of the Republican electorate, who want safe communities, immigration control, smart trade deals, and leaders who put the needs of the American people first."

Facing an uphill battle against the powerful House speaker, Nehlen's poll numbers were not in his favor, with Ryan leading in the Janesville district 80 percent to 14 percent, according to a Remington Research Group poll released Friday.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Rule to Limit Food Stamp Benefits for Millions

Article:

The Trump administration has unveiled a proposal that could potentially affect the food assistance of up to 3.1 million individuals. The rule, which aims to eliminate "loopholes" and save money, has been met with criticism from anti-poverty advocates, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), who described it as an "act of staggering callousness."

Under the proposed rule, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) would no longer provide benefits to families solely because they are enrolled in food assistance programs run by the states where they reside. This change is intended to address instances where some states have expanded eligibility to recipients who would not otherwise qualify for the federal program based on asset or income limitations.

USDA officials argue that the proposed rule would "fix a loophole" that allows households to receive assistance "when they clearly don’t need it." The agency claims the proposal could save billions in taxpayer funds. Recipients who lose their benefits could reapply and qualify if they meet the federal standards for assistance.

Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue stated, "For too long, this loophole has been used to effectively bypass important eligibility guidelines. Too often, states have misused this flexibility without restraint."

The proposal has been met with opposition from various quarters. Joel Berg, CEO of Hunger Free America, stated, "USDA’s plan to take away flexibility from states to allow people to save funds while working their way out of poverty and still receive SNAP is horrid in four ways. It will make working Americans hungrier. It will make it harder for families to work their way out of poverty. And it is hypocritical since Republicans are denying flexibility to states."

In December, the administration proposed a rule that would tighten work requirements for SNAP recipients. This rule would restrict states from exempting work-eligible adults from receiving food stamps if they're not seeking employment. Weeks ago, Congress rejected Republican-sponsored changes to SNAP as part of a $400 billion farm bill.

Rep. Marcia Fudge (D-Ohio), who chairs the House Agriculture Subcommittee that oversees SNAP, criticized Tuesday's proposal as a hypocritical dictate from a party that often preaches states' rights. "When it comes to putting that rhetoric into practice for SNAP, they take the opposite position," she said.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Disrupt U.S. House Impeachment Inquiry, Prevent Pentagon Official's Testimony

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Republican lawmakers disrupted a closed-door hearing of the U.S. House of Representatives impeachment inquiry on Wednesday, preventing Pentagon official Laura Cooper from testifying. The incident occurred during an escalating probe that focuses on President Donald Trump's request for Ukraine to investigate his political rival, Democrat Joe Biden.

The Republicans stormed into a hearing room where Cooper, the U.S. defense official who oversees Ukraine and Russia matters, was due to testify. According to lawmakers and aides, the Republicans began yelling, and a witness inside the room stated that they brought cellphones into the high-security facility where electronic devices are forbidden.

The impeachment inquiry centers on Trump's request for Ukraine to investigate Biden for his personal political benefit. In a confrontation that threatened Trump's presidency as he seeks re-election next year, Capitol police were called in to clear the room and restore order.

Republican Representative Ted Lieu stated, "They're freaked out. They're trying to stop this investigation. They don't want to hear from witness Cooper today. They know more facts are going to be delivered which are absolutely damning to the president of the United States."

Republican Representative Mark Meadows told reporters, "There's about 20 members (lawmakers) down there, at least a dozen that are not on the three committees. And they're going to wait until there's a more open and transparent process."

Republicans have criticized the rules for the impeachment inquiry set by the Democratic-led House, stating that they are unfair. The U.S. Constitution grants the House wide latitude in how to conduct the impeachment process and set rules for the inquiry.

The witness who saw the events stated that the Republican lawmakers pushed past Capitol Police personnel and started yelling, voicing their objections to the Democratic leaders of the House's decision to hold depositions in closed sessions and not release transcripts of the testimony.

Cooper, the deputy assistant secretary of defense for Russia, Ukraine, and Eurasia, did not testify, according to Democratic Representative Stephen Lynch, who is allowed to attend depositions as a member of the House Oversight Committee. A House aide stated that the day's impeachment-related proceedings were suspended for the time being.

Democratic Representative Eric Swalwell told reporters that the Republicans had compromised a secure area of the Capitol, obstructing the impeachment inquiry and seeking to intimidate a witness. However, Swalwell added that this would not delay the impeachment probe overall.

Cooper was expected to face questions about Trump's decision to withhold $391 million in security assistance to Ukraine approved by Congress. In testimony to the inquiry on Tuesday, William Taylor, the top U.S. diplomat in Ukraine, stated that Trump had made the aid contingent on Ukraine announcing it would conduct politically motivated investigations that the president demanded.
