The impeachment inquiry, triggered by a whistleblower complaint against Trump, focuses on a July 25 telephone call in which Trump asked Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to carry out those two investigations. Zelenskiy agreed during the call. The aid was later provided.

Federal election law prohibits candidates from accepting foreign help in an election. So far, few of Trump's fellow conservatives have appeared inclined toward his removal, though there have been some cracks in their support.

Title: Bernie Sanders Calls for Unprecedented Measures to Address COVID-19 Crisis, Advocates for Universal Healthcare and Paid Leave

Article:

Bernie Sanders, a U.S. senator from Vermont and a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, is urging for an immediate and comprehensive response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. In a commentary published by CNN, Sanders emphasizes the need for a unified, nationwide effort to combat the medical and economic crisis.

Sanders argues that the current crisis necessitates unprecedented measures to protect all individuals, regardless of their income. He emphasizes that the response should be guided by the advice of medical professionals, scientists, and researchers, rather than politicians.

In the short term, Sanders proposes increasing the availability of coronavirus test kits, accelerating the processing of tests, building out more intensive care units, obtaining additional ventilators, and improving international collaboration to learn from other countries' experiences with the novel coronavirus.

Looking beyond the immediate crisis, Sanders calls for long-term changes to the U.S. healthcare system, advocating for universal healthcare as a human right. He points out that, despite spending twice as much per capita on healthcare as countries like Canada, 87 million Americans are uninsured or underinsured.

Sanders also addresses the issue of paid family and medical leave, stating that thousands of workers may be ill and continue to work due to financial constraints, potentially spreading the virus. He advocates for guaranteed paid family and medical leave for all workers, as is the case in many other countries.

Furthermore, Sanders criticizes globalization and disastrous trade policies for outsourcing jobs and factories overseas, leaving the U.S. vulnerable in times of national crisis. He calls for fair trade policies that bring production and manufacturing back to the United States.

Sanders concludes by emphasizing the need for far-reaching policies to transform the country for the better, stating that this is the focus of his presidential campaign and what the entire country should strive for in the coming months.

Title: Democrat Ralph Northam Wins Virginia Governor's Race, Delivering a Setback to President Trump

Article:

Democrat Ralph Northam has been declared the winner of the Virginia governor's race on Tuesday, dealing a significant blow to President Donald Trump. Northam, the state's lieutenant governor, secured a victory over Republican Ed Gillespie, who had adopted some of the president's controversial tactics and policy stances.

Trump, who endorsed Gillespie but did not campaign with him, issued tweets and recorded messages in support of the former Republican National Committee chairman on Tuesday. However, after the election results, Trump quickly distanced himself from Gillespie.

"Ed Gillespie worked hard but did not embrace me or what I stand for," Trump tweeted. "With the economy doing record numbers, we will continue to win, even bigger than before!"

At his victory party, Northam told supporters that the Democratic win in Virginia sent a clear message to the nation.

"Virginia has told us to end the divisiveness, that we will not condone hatred and bigotry, and to end the politics that have torn this country apart," Northam said.

The Virginia race was part of a series of state and local elections that also included a governor's race in New Jersey, where Democrat Phil Murphy, a former investment banker and ambassador to Germany, defeated Republican Kim Guadagno for the right to succeed Republican Chris Christie. Murphy had pledged to serve as a check on Trump in Democratic-leaning New Jersey. Guadagno, the lieutenant governor, was hindered by her association with the unpopular Christie.

Murphy's win, along with Northam's victory in Virginia, a state that Hillary Clinton won by 5 percentage points in the 2016 presidential election, provided a much-needed boost for national Democrats who were eager to translate grassroots resistance to Trump into election victories. Democrats had already lost four special congressional elections earlier this year.

A strong turnout in the Democratic-leaning northern Virginia suburbs of Washington helped propel Northam, who ultimately won with a 53% to 45% margin. Exit polls in Virginia showed that one-third of the voters went to the polls to oppose Trump, and only 17% went to support him.

Democrats also won the offices of lieutenant governor and attorney general in Virginia and gained seats in the Virginia House of Delegates. Democrat Danica Roem became the first transgender person to win a state legislative race.

"This is a comprehensive political victory from statehouse to courthouse. Thank you, Donald Trump!" Democratic U.S. Representative Gerald Connolly of Virginia told Northam's supporters at a victory party in northern Virginia.

In Virginia, Democrats had expressed concern that a Gillespie win would embolden Republicans to emphasize divisive cultural issues in their campaigns for next year's elections, when all 435 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives and 33 of the U.S. Senate's 100 seats come up for election. Republicans currently control both chambers.

Gillespie, speaking to his crestfallen supporters in Richmond, Virginia, said he had run a "very policy-focused campaign." However, voters in Arlington County, a suburban Democratic stronghold bordering Washington, expressed that national politics played a significant role in their votes.

"Trump talks about draining the swamp, but Gillespie kind of is the swamp," said Nick Peacemaker, who works in marketing and considered himself a Republican until Trump won the party's presidential nomination. Peacemaker noted that Gillespie seemed to shift closer to Trump's policies after securing the Republican gubernatorial nomination.

In local races across the country, Democratic Mayor Bill de Blasio in New York and Marty Walsh in Boston both easily won re-election. Voters were also picking mayors in Detroit, Atlanta, Seattle, and Charlotte, North Carolina.

Title: U.S. Restores Sanctions on Iran, Exempts Eight Countries for Oil Imports

Article:

The Trump administration has reinstated U.S. sanctions on Iran that were lifted under the 2015 nuclear deal, effective from Monday. The sanctions target Iran's shipping, financial, and energy sectors. This is the second batch of sanctions re-imposed since President Trump withdrew from the landmark accord in May.

The 2015 deal, one of former President Obama's significant diplomatic achievements, provided Iran with billions of dollars in sanctions relief in exchange for curbs on its nuclear program, which many believed was being used to develop atomic weapons. President Trump repeatedly criticized the agreement, calling it the "worst ever" negotiated by the United States, arguing it gave Iran too much in return for too little.

Proponents, as well as the other parties to the deal - Britain, China, France, Germany, Russia, and the European Union, have strongly defended it. The Europeans are concerned that the new sanctions will drive Iran to pull out and resume all of its nuclear work.

The new measures are expected to impact Iranians significantly. In Tehran, one man stated the harder the U.S. pushes, the more people will resist. In a wealthier area, a report by Elizabeth Palmer met the Hossein family. Essam, an accountant, expressed a desire to escape from Iran, voicing his discontent with both the U.S. and Iranian governments.

Friday's announcement was made just days before the U.S. congressional midterm elections, allowing President Trump to highlight his decision to withdraw from the deal, a move that was popular among Republicans. Shortly after the announcement, President Trump tweeted an image resembling a movie poster from the TV series "Game of Thrones" with the tagline "Sanctions are Coming, November 5."

In a statement issued Friday night, President Trump stated, "Our objective is to force the regime into a clear choice: either abandon its destructive behavior or continue down the path toward economic disaster." Secretary of State Mike Pompeo added that the sanctions are "aimed at fundamentally altering the behavior of the Islamic Republic of Iran."

Pompeo has issued a list of 12 demands that Iran must meet to have the sanctions lifted, including an end to its support for terrorism and military engagement in Syria and a halt to nuclear and ballistic missile development. Eight nations will receive temporary waivers allowing them to continue importing Iranian petroleum products as they phase out such imports entirely. These countries, which are expected to include U.S. allies such as Turkey, Italy, India, Japan, and South Korea, have made efforts to eliminate their imports but could not complete the task by Monday.

The waivers will be valid for six months, during which time the importing country can buy Iranian oil but must deposit Iran's revenue in an escrow account. Iran can spend the money but only on a narrow range of humanitarian items.

Pompeo defended the oil waivers and noted that since May, when the U.S. began to pressure countries to stop buying Iranian oil, Iran's exports had dropped by more than 1 million barrels per day. He also stated that the Iranian economy is already struggling due to the earlier sanctions, with the currency losing half its value since April.

Some Iran hawks in Congress and elsewhere have criticized Friday's move, stating it should have gone even further. They were hoping for Iran to be disconnected from the main international financial messaging network known as SWIFT.

With limited exceptions, the re-imposed U.S. sanctions will affect Iran as well as countries that do not stop importing Iranian oil and foreign firms that do business with blacklisted Iranian entities, including its central bank, a number of private financial institutions, and state-run port and shipping firms, as well as hundreds of individual Iranian officials.

"Our ultimate aim is to compel Iran to permanently abandon its well-documented outlaw activities and behave as a normal country," Pompeo told reporters in a conference call with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Mnuchin added that 700 more Iranian companies and people would be added to the sanctions rolls, including more than 300 that had not been included under previous sanctions.

On Saturday, the eve of the anniversary of the 1979 takeover of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei stated that the Islamic Republic is the "victorious party" after nearly 40 years of confrontation by the United States. Khamenei said that despite military, economic, and propaganda wars waged by the U.S. against Iran over the last four decades, "the U.S. is the defeated side and the Islamic Republic is the victorious party." Khamenei added that the U.S. has failed to dominate Iran in the way it did before the 1979 Islamic Revolution that ousted a pro-Western monarchy. He stated that the U.S. is weaker than it was in 1979.

Title: Weinstein Company Requests Removal of Controversial Interviews from 'Fed Up' Documentary on YouTube

Article:

The Weinstein Company, the distributor of the 2014 documentary 'Fed Up' narrated by Katie Couric, has requested that two interviews at the center of accusations of deceptive editing be removed from YouTube. The takedown request, listed as "manually detected" in YouTube documentation, was made by the Weinstein Company.

The videos, which have been moved to another video platform and reinserted into the original story while the dispute is settled by YouTube, feature two interviews from 'Fed Up' where the producers are accused of unethical editing techniques. In one of the videos, Dr. David Allison is shown stumbling during an answer and then pausing for several seconds before the film cuts to another interview, with an answer to the question he was asked never shown. Dr. Allison stated that he did provide an answer to the question and that Couric assured him he could pause to rework answers if needed.

In the other video, an interview with former Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation spokesperson Lisa Gable is featured. Industry sources claim the audio of the off-camera interview was manipulated to embarrass Gable. An audio clip of the off-camera interviewer saying she did not believe Gable was answering her questions did not occur at the moment it is portrayed in the film, according to the sources. "That response from the producer didn’t actually follow that particular exchange and was edited to make it look like that was how their conversation actually went," one source said.

The Weinstein Company did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Title: Trump Revokes Obama-Era Policy on Transparency in Drone Strike Civilian Casualties

Article:

President Donald Trump has rescinded an executive order implemented by his predecessor, former President Barack Obama, which required U.S. intelligence officials to disclose the number of civilian casualties resulting from drone strikes outside of war zones.

The 2016 executive order was a response to pressure on Obama to increase transparency. Since the 9/11 terror attacks, drone strikes have been increasingly utilized against terror and military targets.

The Trump administration deemed the rule as "superfluous" and distracting. The order applied to the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), which has conducted drone strikes in countries such as Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Somalia.

An official stated, "This action eliminates superfluous reporting requirements, requirements that do not improve government transparency, but rather distract our intelligence professionals from their primary mission."

The order mandated the head of the CIA to release annual summaries of U.S. drone strikes and assess the number of casualties. Mr. Trump's executive order does not repeal reporting requirements on civilian deaths set for the military by Congress.

According to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism, a UK-based think tank, there have been 2,243 drone strikes in the first two years of the Trump presidency, compared to 1,878 in Mr. Obama's eight years in office.

Human-rights activists criticized the drone program under the Obama administration, claiming the operations were overly secretive and failed to acknowledge civilian casualties in the strikes. President Obama responded by stating that strikes were carried out in a precise manner, and intelligence officials would release data on civilians who were accidentally killed in the strikes that occurred outside of war zones.

During Mr. Obama's eight years in office, 1,878 drone strikes were conducted, according to researchers. Since Mr. Trump was elected in 2016, there have been 2,243 drone strikes. The Republican president has also made some of the operations, those outside of war zones, more secretive.

Lawmakers and rights groups have criticized Mr. Trump's decision, stating it could allow the CIA to conduct drone strikes without accountability. Rita Siemion of Human Rights First told AFP news agency, "The Trump administration's action is an unnecessary and dangerous step backwards on transparency and accountability for the use of lethal force, and the civilian casualties they cause."

Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat who chairs Congress's intelligence committee, called the requirement issued by Obama "an important measure of transparency," and said "there is simply no justification" for canceling it.

Title: Nike and Colin Kaepernick: A Controversial Partnership Amplifies NFL Protest Controversy

Article:

Nike has chosen to make Colin Kaepernick, the former NFL quarterback and controversial figure, the face of its 30th anniversary "Just Do It" campaign. The move has escalated the ongoing debate surrounding Kaepernick's kneel-down protest against police brutality, which has divided the nation.

The Nike campaign, which features a close-up of Kaepernick's face and the words "Believe in something. Even if it means sacrificing everything," has sparked a significant backlash. Nike's stock fell 3 percent on the news, and other athletic shoe companies experienced similar or greater dips, which some economists attributed to tariffs. The hashtag #NikeBoycott trended on Twitter, with reports of Nike gear-burning and other protests.

The NFL season is set to begin on Thursday, and the league is a partner of Nike. In late March, Nike and the NFL signed a billion-dollar extension of their deal that runs through 2028. Every NFL player wears a Nike-made uniform, and all sideline gear worn by players and coaches is likewise logoed. Any player or coach who wishes to protest the Kaepernick-Nike partnership might have to deface their own uniform.

The NFL player-protest issue is currently in limbo. Team owners voted in the offseason to punish players who protest on the field, but the owners put that rule on hold pending negotiations with the players union. Cowboys owner Jerry Jones stated that any of his players who protests will be punished or banned. His team opens on Sunday at Carolina.

The demonstrations are a cause close to President Trump, who has openly urged owners to fire protesting players. Many NFL team owners are known to be wary of Trump's demands and threats. It's important to remember that the protests had largely disappeared from public view until Trump revived the movement early last NFL season with insulting and demeaning tweets.

Last week, an arbitrator denied the NFL's request for a dismissal of Kaepernick's grievance against the league for colluding to deny him employment. A portion of the money Nike pays the league for sponsorship could potentially wind up in Kaepernick's pocket.

Nike reportedly plans to sell Kaepernick shoes and sportswear, and to back up the initial "Believe" ad with billboards, TV commercials, and online ads. A billboard of the first Kaepernick ad went up near Niketown at Union Square on Tuesday.

Nike's corporate sincerity in backing Kaepernick's cause has been called into question. If the company didn't have its heart and soul in this campaign, why would it take the enormous and obvious risk in alienating millions of customers?

The NFL released a statement from Jocelyn Moore, the NFL's vice president of communications and public affairs, saying, "The National Football League believes in dialogue, understanding, and unity. We embrace the role and responsibility of everyone involved with this game to promote meaningful, positive change in our communities. The social justice issues that Colin and other professional athletes have raised deserve our attention and action."

A recent NBC News and Wall Street Journal poll showed 54 percent of Americans feel the NFL protests are "inappropriate," while 43 percent go with "appropriate." Whatever profits Nike might make on Kaepernick gear would seem to be more than offset by the loss of revenue from protests of Nike.

The NFL is now in a difficult position. If the owners follow the lead of Trump, Jones, and a majority (however narrow) of Americans, the league risks alienating about half its fans and maybe more than half its players. Almost all the protesting players are black, and 70 percent of the league's players are black. That's a powerful lobby.

However, if the NFL caves to the players' union and allows at least some protests, the league risks suffering boycotts of games and team and league sponsors. Other than the racial component of the debate, there are many shades of gray. Support for Kaepernick is problematic for those who can't forget or forgive him wearing cartoon-pig socks to protest police brutality.

For some, the new Nike campaign casts doubt on Kaepernick's rebel persona. "Revolutionaries aren't sponsored by major corporations," said Fox Sports commentator Jason Whitlock. But if a revolution is being waged against forces backed by money and power, isn't money and power needed by the revolutionaries?

And does anyone really believe Kaepernick willingly gave up a pro football career in order to cash in on his revolution by selling shoes? This is a man who, while unemployed, donated $1 million to hand-selected causes and who continues to lead educational camps for inner-city kids.

If that's all been a Kaepernick scheme to get rich selling shoes, it's certainly revolutionary.

Title: Comedian Nimesh Patel Removed from Columbia University Event for Offensive Jokes

Article:

Comedian Nimesh Patel, a former Saturday Night Live writer, was removed from a performance at Columbia University's "cultureSHOCK: Reclaim" event after 30 minutes due to jokes deemed homophobic and racist. The Asian American Alliance (AAA) had invited Patel to perform at their annual charity showcase, which aims to promote Asian-American artistic expression and challenge harmful stereotypes.

According to the Columbia Daily Spectator, Patel's performance included commentary on his experience living in a diverse area of New York City, which included a joke about a gay black man in his neighborhood. AAA officials found this material inappropriate.

During the performance, Patel made a joke about sexual orientation, stating, "No one looks in the mirror and thinks, 'This black thing is too easy; let me just add another thing to it.'" Members of AAA interrupted the performance and denounced his material regarding racial identities and sexual orientation. Patel was given a few moments for closing remarks but pushed back, claiming that none of his jokes were offensive. He reportedly asserted that he was simply exposing the audience to ideas found "in the real world." Patel's microphone was cut off from offstage, and he exited.

AAA defended its decision to remove Patel, stating on Facebook, "Patel's remarks ran counter to the inclusive spirit and integrity of cultureSHOCK, and as such, the choice was made to invite him to leave." The group added, "We acknowledge that discomfort and safety can coexist, however, the discomfort Patel caused was unproductive in this space." AAA also apologized for inviting Patel in the first place.

Audience members were reportedly split over AAA's decision to remove Patel.

As of this writing, Patel has yet to comment on the event. The 32-year-old comedian was the first Indian-American writer for SNL but left after last season. He has since been nominated for an Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing and has opened for comedians such as Chris Rock.

Title: Polls Show President Trump Trailing in 2020 General Election, Suggesting Weak Position for Reelection

Article:

The latest polls indicate that President Donald Trump is trailing most Democratic candidates in the 2020 general election, both nationally and in individual states, including traditionally Republican stronghold Texas. While these polls may offer some encouragement to Democratic voters, they should exercise caution, as historical precedent shows that polls taken 14 months before an election are not always predictive.

In Texas, a new survey conducted by Latino Decisions, North Star Opinion Research, and the University of Houston, shows Trump polling behind not only Joe Biden but also Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and Kamala Harris. The poll results indicate that Trump's support in Texas ranges from 41% to 44%, while the Democratic candidates poll between 45% and 50%.

Similarly, a recent poll by the Washington Post and ABC News at the national level among registered voters shows Trump failing to breach 45% against any of his potential Democratic opponents.

While it may be tempting to analyze the marginal differences between the Democratic candidates in these polls, several pollsters and political handicappers advise against over-interpreting these differences. The results, they say, reveal more about Trump's vulnerability than they do about the relative strengths of the various Democratic candidates.

Trump's low approval rating, which has been consistently unpopular throughout his first two years in office, is a significant concern. According to Kyle Kondik, managing editor at Sabato's Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, Trump sometimes runs a little behind his approval rating in some polls, which is an ominous sign for a president who was so reliant on voters who disliked both him and his opponent in the 2016 election.

Furthermore, presidential approval ratings have historically been strongly linked to voting behavior. Trump's approval rating, which has been consistently unpopular throughout his first two years, is a significant concern. So far, at his best, he was 7 points more unpopular than popular. A recent uptick has swiftly eroded.

In conclusion, the latest polls suggest that President Trump is in a weak position for reelection. His low approval rating and poor showing in hypothetical head-to-head match-ups indicate that he may struggle to win over voters, particularly in traditionally Democratic strongholds like Texas. Trump's path to victory becomes increasingly narrow if he is unable to win over voters who dislike him.

Title: Rep. Peter T. King Urges FBI to Focus on Muslim Community in Wake of Boston Marathon Bombings

Article:

Representative Peter T. King, a New York Republican and the chairman of the House Homeland Security subcommittee on counterintelligence and terrorism, has called for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to focus their investigations on threats from within the Muslim community following the Boston Marathon bombings. In an interview on "Fox News Sunday," King stated, "If you know a threat is coming from a certain community, that's where you look."

King's comments come as authorities continue to investigate the motives behind the Boston Marathon bombings, which occurred on Monday, April 15, 2013. The two suspected bombers, 26-year-old Tamerlan Tsarnaev, who died during a shootout with police on Thursday night, and his brother, 19-year-old Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was shot and remains in serious condition in a hospital, were of Islamic faith.

According to King, the strategy of terrorists has changed since the September 11, 2001, attacks. No longer are al Qaeda or related groups plotting massive attacks from training camps in the Middle East. Instead, they are using individuals such as the Tsarnaev brothers to carry out attacks within the United States.

King also criticized the FBI for failing to catch the Tsarnaev brothers before the bombings. The FBI reportedly interviewed Tamerlan Tsarnaev but found nothing to link him to terrorism.

In a statement, the Islamic Society of Boston Cultural Center expressed sympathy for the victims of the bombings and acknowledged that both suspects were known to the Boston community. The statement read, "Yet, no one inside these institutions was able to predict these acts of terror by the alleged suspects."

The Islamic Society of Boston Cultural Center also expressed regret that they could not have prevented the bombings. The statement concluded, "This hurts, and we wish we all could have done something to prevent this."

Title: GSK Begins Mass Production of Ebola Vaccine in Unprecedented Move Amid Ongoing Outbreak

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing Ebola epidemic in West Africa, drug company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has announced it will begin mass production of a vaccine that is currently in the early stages of human testing. This decision follows the World Health Organization's (WHO) groundbreaking decision that it is ethical to try unproven and experimental treatments during this public health emergency.

The process of bringing a drug or vaccine to market in the United States typically involves three phases of clinical trials in humans. Before testing it on humans, researchers must first present promising data from animal studies to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and receive approval to begin recruiting patients. This initial phase, known as the "pre-clinical" phase of drug development, can take several years, and for every 5,000 compounds discovered at this stage, only about five are allowed to be tried in humans.

If a drug or vaccine is approved for human trials, researchers must find hundreds and then thousands of volunteers to participate. In the first phase, they check for safety in a small group of healthy people to ensure the drug is not immediately making anyone sick or worse, and to determine how much of the drug people can tolerate.

In a larger group of participants, they test to ensure the treatment delivers on its promise and monitor how well it works against the best-available therapies or a placebo. The third phase involves an even bigger group, up to 3,000 people, and researchers compare how the drug works against other treatments on the market and carefully analyze safety data. This entire drug development process takes an average of 12 years and costs between $100 million and $1 billion.

If the drug makes it through phase three, the data are submitted to the FDA for approval. Only one in five therapies make it this far, and it usually takes the FDA a couple of years to consider the data and bring the drug to market, if it so chooses. The US has some of the most stringent standards in the world when it comes to getting new medicines to people, and for this reason, the overwhelming majority of promising drugs in animal studies never even make it to phase one trials, let alone past all the regulatory hurdles.

GSK is already starting to manufacture an Ebola vaccine that only has promising animal studies behind it, but has not yet been fully tested in humans. The company has said it will have 10,000 doses stockpiled should the science for the vaccine check out. However, the vaccine is only in phase one, which is a long way from the end of the development road.

When asked about the timeline for the Ebola vaccine, GSK representatives explained that the normal pathway for bringing a vaccine to market takes 10 years, and that they were already three years into the process with the Ebola vaccine. While this crisis has focused attention on Ebola drug development and helped to galvanize resources, they were not yet clear on what would happen after a successful phase one trial and how much longer it would take to scale-up manufacturing and get the vaccine approved for use in people.

There is a chance that the usual process might be condensed or phases of clinical testing skipped, since Ebola is an unusually deadly pathogen and will be treated differently by regulators. However, even in dire situations, developing safe, new therapies takes time, and unfortunately, mostly ends in failure. We're only in phase one with the Ebola vaccine. If data look promising, hopefully, regulators will find ways to make sure it's not seven more years until we can prevent another Ebola epidemic.

Title: President Trump's Apology to Kavanaugh and City's Third Gender Birth Certificates Law

Article:

Two significant events took place in the last two days, with President Trump's speech at the swearing-in of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court and the passing of a law in the city allowing third-gender birth certificates.

In the Supreme Court swearing-in ceremony, President Trump issued an apology on behalf of the country to Kavanaugh and his family for the "terrible pain and suffering" they endured during the confirmation process. He criticized the unfounded allegations against Kavanaugh, stating they violated fairness and the presumption of innocence. Trump also addressed Kavanaugh's young daughters, praising their father as a "great man, a man of decency, character, kindness, and courage."

The event was more than a political rally; it aimed to restore dignity to the judiciary and counter the character-assassination attempt on Kavanaugh. With the eight other Supreme Court justices present, Trump's speech was a clear attempt to set a new tone for the judiciary.

In a separate event, the city passed a law allowing third-gender birth certificates. The law removes the requirement that a medical or mental health professional affirm an individual's gender to change the certificate. The law takes effect on January 1, and it's unclear if there are age requirements or limits to the number of times an individual can make changes.

The impact of this change on society, including gender roles in various aspects of life, is a subject of debate. Some argue that it's a significant step towards recognizing the identities of gender non-binary people, while others question the priorities of the mayor and City Council, given the complexity and urgency of other issues, such as public safety, education, and the tax system.

In both events, strong opinions and reactions have been expressed, with some viewing the Supreme Court ceremony as a necessary step towards restoring the dignity of the judiciary, while others question the priorities of the city's leaders in passing the third-gender birth certificates law. As always, these events spark important discussions and raise questions about the direction of our society.

Title: Investigative Journalism Group Alleges Violent Tactics by Rose City Antifa in Portland

Article:

Investigative journalist group Project Veritas has released undercover footage that allegedly shows members of the Rose City Antifa (RCA) in Portland, Oregon, promoting violence and teaching combat techniques. The footage, released on Thursday, reportedly shows Project Veritas infiltrating RCA through an unnamed individual who recorded the group's ultra-secretive meetings.

In one of the clips, a man identified as Nicholas Cifuni is seen discussing the need to hide weapons from the police, stating, "Don't be that fucking guy with the goddamn spike brass knuckles getting photos taken of you." He also suggests practicing eye gouges, stating, "It takes very little pressure to injure someone's eyes."

The infiltrator, wearing a hoodie, ski mask, and sunglasses to protect his identity, described the process of becoming a member of Antifa, stating he was a "prospect" for the group. By his account, RCA enforced strict security measures, such as placing their phones in a neighboring bathroom with a fan that muffles sounds during meetings to prevent surveillance.

The source also detailed the vigorous security precautions deployed by the group upon their first meeting, remarking, "They were getting this tradecraft from someone else, someone with much more experience, someone who did this for a living."

Project Veritas identified the alleged founder of Rose City Antifa as Caroline Victorin. Records uncovered by ███ indicate the couple moved in 2017 following a 2015 Gofundme fundraiser that attempted to procure funds for a green card for Caroline's husband.

Sweden has a large Antifa scene; a Swedish Defence Research Institute (FOI) report detailed the extent of the movement and tied the Swedish "anti-hate" group, the Expo Foundation, along with the UK anti-hate group Hope not Hate to the Antifa anarchist scene. Both groups have also received cash in the past from Hungarian-American left-wing billionaire George Soros through his Open Society Foundation.

Based in the city of Portland, RCA has become well-known as one of the most violent cells of Antifa in the United States and has been well-documented by journalist Andy Ngo. Ngo himself was brutally beaten by the group during a protest last year and suffered a brain bleed as a result.

President Donald Trump announced plans to designate the violent leftist group Antifa as a terrorist organization in May 2020. In November of last year, Gage Halupowski pled guilty to second-degree assault with an expandable baton and was sentenced to six years in prison. The victim, Adam Kelly, suffered a concussion and required 25 staples to his head following the vicious attack.

As the riots that began in Minneapolis continue to engulf the United States, RCA has also been active in Portland in recent days. They are allegedly behind a May 30 attack on a man carrying an American flag during the anti-police brutality protest, shouting, "Black lives matter, faggot," as they beat him.

Title: Five Killed, Two Injured in Shooting at Maryland Newspaper Office

Article:

A shooting incident occurred at the offices of the Capital Gazette newspaper in Annapolis, Maryland, on Thursday, resulting in five fatalities and two injuries. The gunman, identified as Jarrod Ramos, was arrested shortly after the attack and charged with five counts of first-degree murder.

The attack began at 14:40 local time (18:40 GMT) when the gunman entered the building with a shotgun and fired through a glass door into the newsroom. Staff members inside the building posted updates on social media as the attack unfolded.

Reporter Chase Cook tweeted, "We are putting out a damn paper tomorrow." Staff worked in the parking lot to get the paper out despite the tragic circumstances.

An intern at the paper, Anthony Messenger, and crime reporter Phil Davis were among those who shared their experiences during the attack. Davis described the scene as "like a war zone" and tweeted about his experiences as he waited to be interviewed by police.

County executive Steve Schuh stated that the suspect had been hiding under a desk in the building when police officers arrived "within 60 seconds" of receiving news of the incident. There was "no exchange of fire," he added.

Deputy chief of Anne Arundel County Police, William Krampf, confirmed that an item believed to be an explosive device was found at the premises and destroyed. It was later determined to be a smoke bomb.

Police safely evacuated 170 people from the building, which housed 30 other businesses. The Committee to Protect Journalists reported that before the Maryland shooting, seven journalists had been killed in the US in relation to their work since 1992.

The Capital Gazette reportedly wrote an article in 2011 about a woman who said Jarrod Ramos was stalking her, and he failed in his attempts to sue the paper for defamation the following year. Police did not ascribe any motive after arresting him following Thursday's attack.

Ramos is scheduled for a bail hearing on Friday morning in Annapolis. Federal agencies, including the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, were involved in the response to the attack.

Maryland governor Larry Hogan and President Donald Trump expressed their condolences for the victims and their families. The New York City Police Department (NYPD) deployed counterterrorism teams to media organizations in and around New York City as a precaution.

Mayor of Annapolis Gavin Buckley and Democratic senator Chris Van Hollen also responded to the shooting. Writer and alt-right figure Milo Yiannopoulos faced criticism online for a controversial tweet regarding journalists. Yiannopoulos later defended himself, stating the message was "a troll."

Title: Trump Unifies Nation, Outlines Policy Priorities in Joint Address to Congress

Article:

In a speech aimed at unifying a divided nation and inspiring the future, President Donald Trump outlined his policy priorities and reaffirmed his commitment to keeping his campaign promises. The address, delivered to a joint session of Congress, was followed by a Democratic response and analysis from various news outlets.

President Trump commemorated Black History Month and acknowledged the work that remains to be done in addressing racial issues. He emphasized the importance of education, suggesting that school choice could help revitalize urban regions and benefit failing minority youths.

The president also addressed recent threats against Jewish Community Centers and vandalism of Jewish cemeteries, as well as the shooting in Kansas City, stating that while the nation may be divided on policies, it stands united in condemning hate and evil.

Immigration was another key topic, with Trump reiterating his promise to get tough on illegal immigration. He stated, "We are removing gang members, drug dealers, and criminals that threaten our communities and prey on our citizens."

Healthcare was another significant point of discussion, with Trump expressing a desire to ensure that Americans with pre-existing conditions have access to coverage and a stable transition for those currently enrolled in the healthcare exchanges.

In a moving moment, the president recognized Carryn Owens, the widow of Senior Chief William "Ryan" Owens, who was killed last month in a covert raid against al-Qaeda in Yemen. Trump praised Owens' sacrifice, stating, "For as the Bible teaches us, there is no greater love than to lay down one's life for one's friends."

The Democratic response was delivered by former Kentucky Governor Steve Beshear, who criticized the president for rolling back regulations, waging war on immigrants, and calling to repeal Obamacare.

Following the address, congressional members offered their reactions. Many praised the president's unifying speech and statesman-like demeanor, while others expressed a desire for more specifics and details from the president.

Republican lawmakers feel encouraged and are ready to work on priorities like immigration reform and repealing and replacing Obamacare. Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have expressed their support for the president's bold agenda.

Title: "GOP Congressmen's Late-Night Swim in the Sea of Galilee Sparks Controversy and Allegations"

Article:

A report by Politico detailing a late-night swim by Republican congressmen in the Sea of Galilee last year, including one who allegedly went skinny-dipping, has led to a series of clarifications from Capitol Hill and accusations between two primary opponents.

The report states that the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) looked into the incident, which occurred during a visit by a mix of GOP congressional freshmen and leaders as guests of The American Israel Educational Foundation in Israel.

According to Politico, Kansas Rep. Kevin Yoder reportedly stripped naked and jumped into the water that night, with several other clothed or partially clothed lawmakers and staff members also participating in the swim. Alcohol may have been a factor for some, the report suggests.

The congressmen named in the report include Florida Rep. Steve Southerland, New York Rep. Tom Reed, California Rep. Jeff Denham, and New York Rep. Michael Grimm. The report also named Arizona Rep. Ben Quayle as participating, but his office and his wife vehemently denied his involvement.

Jay Heiler, Quayle's spokesman, told Fox News that Politico's inclusion of the congressman in the beach scenes was inaccurate. He stated that people were leaving the dinner that night at different times, and Quayle did not go to the beach afterward.

Quayle's primary opponent, Rep. Dave Schweikert, has accused Quayle of embarrassing "both the institution of Congress and Arizona with his completely inappropriate behavior that calls into question yet again his fitness to be in Congress."

In response, Quayle's wife, Tiffany, claimed the Quayle family did not partake in the water antics, despite the Politico report. She stated, "Ben and I and our daughter Evie were there together that evening in the Holy Land, although I was eight and a half months pregnant with her. We were neither party nor witness to any of the inappropriate behavior described in the article, nor were we a part of, or aware of any inquiry. We did return to Arizona with some water from the Sea of Galilee to baptize Evie after she was born."

The Sea of Galilee is a significant religious site, where Jesus is said to have walked on water.

Rep. Kevin Yoder has expressed remorse for any embarrassment caused, stating, "I feel incredibly remorseful that I have caused embarrassment to my constituents and I have caused folks who believe in me to be disappointed."

The original report states that the lawmakers who participated were rebuked last year by House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, the most senior Republican on the trip and the most senior Jewish lawmaker in Congress.

Title: FBI Faces Questions Over Possible Missed Signs in Florida School Shooting

Article:

The mass shooting at a Florida high school has reignited discussions about potential missed opportunities for the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to prevent such incidents. Last fall, a Mississippi bail bondsman and video blogger reported a comment on one of his YouTube videos that stated, "I'm going to be a professional school shooter." He immediately reported it to YouTube and the FBI, and the next day, two FBI agents visited his office to take a printout of the comment and inquire about the commenter's identity.

Although the commenter's username was "Nikolas Cruz," the same name as the 19-year-old suspect in the shooting, the FBI has not been able to identify the poster, according to Robert Lasky, the special agent in charge of the FBI office in Miami. The FBI interviewed the individual who reported the comment and searched public records databases, actions consistent with those taken during an FBI assessment, the lowest level and least intrusive stage of an FBI inquiry. However, the FBI has not conclusively linked the account to the shooter.

On Wednesday, Cruz allegedly entered his former high school in Florida with an AR-15 rifle and opened fire, killing 17 people on school grounds. This incident is the latest in a series of attacks that have raised questions about whether individuals who have previously come to the attention of law enforcement should have remained under investigation. In the last two years, individuals responsible for massacres at an Orlando nightclub, in the streets of New York City, and at a Florida airport had all been scrutinized by federal agents but were eventually deemed not to warrant continued law enforcement attention.

FBI assessments are initiated following the receipt of a tip, which could be based on something as simple as observing unusual activity in a neighbor's garage or a classmate's comments. Agents often face the challenge of determining which of the tens of thousands of tips received each year, and more than 10,000 assessments opened, could yield a viable threat.

Had the FBI been able to confirm that Cruz was the same person as the YouTube poster, they would have found numerous photos of rifles, ammunition, and targets filled with bullet holes, likely leading to a face-to-face interview. The FBI did not notify police in Florida about the post before the mass shooting.

"They owe us some more detail on what they did," retired FBI assistant director Ron Hosko said.

The questions arise as the FBI is already under scrutiny and facing criticism from President Donald Trump and some congressional Republicans, who have accused the agency of anti-Trump bias, particularly in relation to special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe. However, it is unclear whether the agency dropped the ball in this case, Hosko said.

"With anything that the FBI receives, they are constrained to act based on what they have in front of them," said Hosko. "You have a random internet posting that suggests the person wants to do something, not that they are planning on doing something."

FBI guidelines, designed to balance national security with civil liberties protections, impose restrictions on the steps agents may take during the assessment phase. Agents may analyze information from government databases and open-source internet searches, and can conduct interviews during an assessment. However, they cannot request wiretaps or internet communications without higher levels of approval and a more solid basis to suspect a crime.

"It's a tricky situation because sometimes you get information regarding individuals and they may be just showing off, blustering," said Herbert Cousins Jr., a retired FBI special agent in charge.

A vague, uncorroborated threat alone may not be enough to proceed to the next level of investigation, according to Jeffrey Ringel, a former FBI agent and Joint Terrorism Task force supervisor who now works for the Soufan Group, a private security firm. Many assessments are closed within days or weeks when the FBI concludes there's no criminal or national security threat, or basis for continued scrutiny. The system is designed to ensure that a person who has not broken the law does not remain under perpetual scrutiny on a mere hunch—and that the FBI can reserve its scarce resources for true threats.

Had he pledged his allegiance to the Islamic State, for example, investigators might have had enough evidence to proceed with a more intrusive probe. Tips like the one that came in about the Florida gunman are among countless complaints that come into the FBI daily with varying degrees of specificity.

"How many of these do you expect the FBI to handle before it becomes the Federal Bureau of Complaints?" said retired FBI assistant director Ron Hosko. "They could spend their entire workforce tracking down internet exchanges that never going to go anywhere."

Title: Putin's Intervention in Syria: A Turn of Events and Its Implications

Article:

The recent Syrian crisis, unfolding as the new academic year began, has sparked discussions among the nation's future leaders, who are now settling into their college campuses. The Class of '17, equipped with tales of adventure and unique experiences, is studying in institutions boasting luxurious amenities, from gyms and playing fields to Olympic-sized swimming pools.

However, the educational experience of these students has been a subject of debate. With the liberal arts diminished and the focus on practical, career-oriented subjects, students may not be adequately prepared to analyze and critique arguments, as the study of poetics and rhetoric has been removed from the curriculum.

The latest turn of events in the Syrian crisis, as described by President Barack Obama, has been compared to a theatrical performance or a "theater of war." Secretary of State John F. Kerry's gaffe, inviting an improbable rescue, has been likened to the "deus ex machina" in Greek and Roman theater, a plot device where a god intervenes to resolve an intractable situation.

This comparison, however, was lost on a young graduate of an elite school when the concept was explained to him. The deus ex machina, a device used to resolve a plot without a plausible solution, is a reminder of the importance of historical and cultural knowledge, a skill that is increasingly rare in today's education system.

The Syrian crisis reached a critical point when Congress took votes on whether to authorize missile strikes on Syrian stocks of poison gas. With a likely defeat looming, President Obama found himself in a precarious position. Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has been a key supporter of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, dispatched a chariot, so to speak, to rescue Obama from this predicament.

Putin's intervention has been hailed as a "victory" for Obama by some, but the world, and particularly Washington, may not be able to afford such a turn of events. The Russian leader's intervention has effectively delayed help for the Syrian rebels and taken control of the civil war and events in the Middle East.

The debate on the Syrian atrocity, as President Obama had called for, is now effectively over, decided by who best exploited and manipulated Secretary Kerry's gaffe. The use of the deus ex machina, in this case, has raised questions about the future of international relations and the role of the United States in global conflicts.

Suzanne Fields, a columnist for The ███, has written that the Putin rescue operation is a reflection of what students may not have learned. The Greek and Roman classics, once the roots of a Western education, no longer form the common cultural knowledge that enables reasoning through analogies and metaphors.

Putin's intervention in Syria has been a reminder of the importance of historical and cultural knowledge, as well as the need for critical thinking and the ability to analyze and critique arguments. As the world watches the events unfold, it remains to be seen how this turn of events will shape the future of international relations and the role of the United States in global conflicts.

Title: Secret Service Director Julia Pierson Resigns Following White House Security Breach

Article:

Secret Service Director Julia Pierson resigned Wednesday, following a security breach at the White House and other high-profile incidents that raised concerns about the safety of the president and his family. Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson announced the resignation in a written statement, and the White House confirmed her decision shortly afterward. President Obama stated that "new leadership of that agency was required," according to White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest.

Johnson said, "Today Julia Pierson, the Director of the United States Secret Service, offered her resignation, and I accepted it. I salute her 30 years of distinguished service to the Secret Service and the Nation." A source familiar with the situation told Fox News that Johnson told Pierson the resignation would be effective immediately, after she offered.

The resignation comes just days after the Sept. 19 incident where an intruder jumped over the White House fence and darted past several layers of security to enter the White House itself. He was able to make it to the East Room before being apprehended.

Pierson's departure, though, marked a sharp turnaround from a day earlier, when despite her rocky performance during congressional testimony, the White House voiced support for her leadership. Asked Tuesday whether Obama had confidence in the director, Earnest said "absolutely."

However, on Wednesday, the director was facing bipartisan calls to step down. Rep. Elijah Cummings, top Democrat on the committee that grilled Pierson, notably told NPR she is "not the person to lead that agency" -- though he later clarified he thinks she should go if she cannot restore public trust.

Asked what had changed to lead to her resignation, Earnest said foremost that Pierson had offered her resignation. But he also said Wednesday that "recent and accumulating reports" raised "legitimate questions" about the agency. Earnest said Obama agrees that Pierson's resignation is in the best interest of the agency.

Among those reports was the revelation that on Sept. 16, a security contractor armed with a gun who had previously been arrested for assault rode on an elevator with Obama and his security detail at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, violating Secret Service protocol. Earnest said the president only learned about that incident on Tuesday.

New and alarming details also emerged -- seemingly by the day -- about the multiple security failures in the Sept. 19 intrusion. Not until late Monday was it reported that he made it into the East Room, a detail that was confirmed by Pierson during her testimony.

Johnson said that he now agrees that a "panel of independent experts" should review the Sept. 19 incident -- something that had been called for by lawmakers. He said such a panel will submit its assessment and recommendations by Dec. 15.

"I will also request that the panel advise me about whether it believes, given the series of recent events, there should be a review of broader issues concerning the Secret Service. The security of the White House compound should be the panel's primary and immediate priority," he said.

He said a separate internal review will be completed by Nov. 1. Johnson said he's appointing Joseph Clancy, a former special agent in charge of the Presidential Protective Division who retired in 2011, as interim director.

The Sept. 19 incident involving a Texas Army veteran who jumped the White House fence and was able to make it deep into the Executive Mansion before being stopped is now just one of several embarrassing disclosures about lapses in presidential security involving the Secret Service.

Despite more than three hours of questioning by House lawmakers on Tuesday, Pierson neglected to mention the incident in Atlanta. Her failure to do so prompted Rep. Jason Chaffetz, R-Utah, to call for Pierson's resignation -- or firing -- in an interview with Fox News Tuesday night. In a statement on Wednesday, Chaffetz welcomed the decision to step down and urged the president to fill the post with "new leadership from outside the Secret Service for a fresh start."

At Tuesday's hearing, Pierson said she was the one who briefs Obama on threats to his personal security and said she had briefed him only once this year, "for the Sept. 19 incident." She also disclosed that shortly before the alleged intruder, Omar J. Gonzalez, scaled the fence at least two of her uniformed officers recognized him from an earlier troubling encounter but did not approach him or report his presence to superiors.

Lawmakers were aghast, too, about a four-day delay in 2011 before the Secret Service realized a man had fired a high-powered rifle at the White House, as reported by the Washington Post on Sunday.

Pierson told the hearing the security plan for protecting the White House was not "properly executed" on Sept. 19. The Secret Service's story about the extent of that breach changed late Monday night after the Washington Post first reported that Gonzalez got well past the front door of the White House. Previously it had said Gonzalez had been stopped just inside the front door. After hours of questioning Tuesday, it remained unclear what and when Pierson and Johnson knew about the incident. The Secret Service is part of the Homeland Security Department.

The Sept. 19 breach was the latest black eye for the agency. Pierson was originally brought in early last year after the 2012 prostitution scandal in Colombia.

Gonzalez was indicted Tuesday and pleaded not guilty on Wednesday before Magistrate Judge Deborah A. Robinson in U.S. District Court.

Title: U.S. and Turkey Face Criticism Over Syria Offensive as American Troops Withdraw

Article:

The United States and Turkey are facing criticism over the ongoing military operation in northern Syria, with many expressing concern over the potential consequences of the U.S. troop withdrawal.

Critics argue that the decision to withdraw U.S. troops and allow Turkey to take a more active role in the region is a departure from previous U.S. policy and could have far-reaching implications.

One critic, whose identity was not specified, stated, "Trump may indeed have campaigned on getting out of Syria. He didn't campaign on potentially freeing thousands of Islamic State fighters, or greenlighting ethnic cleansing, or empowering Syrian president Bashar al-Assad and Russian president Vladimir Putin."

Another critic, also unnamed, expressed concern that the decision to withdraw U.S. troops could lead to a humanitarian crisis, stating, "Even operating within the constraints that Trump has foolishly adopted, there are actions the U.S. could—and should—take to mitigate the damage."

The U.S. has imposed sanctions on Turkey in response to the military operation, but it remains unclear whether these sanctions will be effective in altering Turkey's actions in Syria. The U.S. has a history of imposing sanctions on countries as a means of exerting pressure, but the effectiveness of this approach is debated.

It is also unclear what the long-term consequences of the U.S. withdrawal and Turkey's military operation in Syria will be, as the situation is still unfolding. The U.S. and its allies are reportedly working to evacuate U.S. troops from the affected areas, and the Kurds have signed on to cooperate with the Syrian army.

The U.S. has not released any official statements regarding the effectiveness of the sanctions or the long-term consequences of the U.S. withdrawal and Turkey's military operation in Syria. It is also unclear what, if any, actions the U.S. plans to take to mitigate the potential humanitarian crisis in the region.

Title: Rand Paul Navigates Challenges in Advancing Libertarian Agenda on College Campuses

Article:

Rand Paul, the Kentucky Republican senator and potential 2016 presidential candidate, is visiting various college campuses to promote his libertarian agenda. However, Paul faces a challenge in appealing to young people without alienating other Republicans.

During a recent appearance at the College of Charleston, Paul was asked about his stance on Plan B, the emergency contraception commonly known as the morning-after pill. The question, posed by a young woman, highlighted the challenge Paul faces in balancing his libertarian views with the Republican party's stance on social issues.

Notably uncomfortable with the question, Paul initially stated, "I am not opposed to birth control." He then elaborated, "That's basically what Plan B is. Plan B is taking two birth control pills in the morning and two in the evening, and I am not opposed to that."

Another student questioned Paul about the legalization of marijuana, cocaine, and heroin. Paul expressed his opposition to drug use but supported leaving drug laws up to the states, citing Colorado and Washington's experimentation with legalized marijuana as an example.

Paul has had success on the college circuit, with visits to universities such as Harvard and Howard garnering positive headlines and support from Republicans seeking to modernize the party and broaden its national appeal. His opposition to government surveillance, a topic he often discusses with young people, has been a popular talking point.

In March 2013, Paul won a straw poll at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) after delivering a passionate speech against government surveillance. He also attracted a crowd of young supporters at a nearby restaurant, where he danced and sang with college students.

During a post-talk interview in the College of Charleston's sun-splashed campus courtyard, Paul was asked about thorny issues that often put his party at odds with young people, such as drug legalization and same-sex marriage.

When asked about the legalization of hard drugs like cocaine or heroin, Paul hedged, stating his position as less criminalization and more fair adjudication for those caught with drugs. He also expressed support for second chances for young people who make mistakes.

Regarding same-sex marriage, Paul favors traditional marriage but supports states determining their own marriage laws. When asked about the Republican Party's ability to win a national election if it is out of step with rapidly changing opinions on the issue, Paul took a soft tone, acknowledging that society is changing and that even within the Republican Party, opinions on the issue are evolving.

When asked if he could reconsider his stance on marriage, Paul seemed to hint at the possibility but did not commit to a change in his views. He emphasized his traditionalist beliefs but also expressed a desire for the Republican Party to accommodate people on both sides of the issue.

In conclusion, Rand Paul's visits to college campuses highlight the challenge he faces in balancing his libertarian views with the Republican party's stance on social issues. His responses to questions about Plan B, drug legalization, and same-sex marriage reveal a politician who is navigating a complex dance as he tries to color outside the lines of the Republican Party while maintaining his appeal to young voters.

Title: U.S. Presidential Candidates Address Police Shootings, Email Controversy, and Party Platforms

Article:

In the aftermath of a series of high-profile police shootings and subsequent violence, the U.S. presidential candidates have found themselves navigating a tumultuous political landscape. Last week, two black men were shot dead by police officers in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and a suburb of St. Paul, Minnesota, prompting a violent response from a black extremist in Dallas, Texas, who killed five police officers.

Both candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, have responded to these events, with Trump's statement on Facebook receiving widespread coverage. Trump strongly defended the police while expressing sympathy for the victims, Alton Sterling and Philando Castile, and acknowledging the worsening racial divisions in the country. Clinton, on the other hand, addressed a conference of black religious leaders, urging national guidelines for police use of force.

As the country grapples with these issues, the candidates are being judged not just as politicians, but as potential healers for a divided nation. Trump is perceived as a strong leader and a supporter of law enforcement, while Clinton has adopted a more unifying tone in her campaign, aiming to connect with the African-American community.

The email controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton also continued last week, with FBI Director James Comey finding Clinton guilty of setting up an unauthorized private email server, being "extremely reckless" in handling classified material, and making false statements to the American people. However, Comey refused to indict Clinton, a decision that has not diminished the public's perception of her as dishonest and untrustworthy.

In the aftermath of Comey's announcement, Trump spent most of his Cincinnati speech defending his campaign's use of a Star of David in a tweet, rather than addressing Clinton's email scandal. This strategy may have missed a significant opportunity to make the email controversy a more prominent issue in the eyes of swing voters.

Meanwhile, Clinton has moved further to the left, endorsing free college for families with incomes below $125,000 and advocating for a single-payer healthcare system. However, her allies have rebuffed proposals to oppose a vote on President Obama's Trans-Pacific Trade Partnership in the lame-duck congressional session after the election.

In the coming weeks, Bernie Sanders is expected to endorse Clinton, but further challenges to the Democratic Party's rules and platform are likely. The Republican and Democratic party rules and platform committees will meet this week, with potential fights over the party platforms and resolutions. Trump is also expected to announce his running mate this week or at the Republican National Convention. Potential choices include Newt Gingrich, Michael Flynn, and Mike Pence.

Overall, the presidential race is shaping up to be a battle of contrasting ideologies and leadership styles, with both candidates seeking to appeal to a divided and concerned electorate.

Title: White House and Republicans Begin Detailed Discussions on Fiscal Cliff, Tax Increases and Spending Cuts Proposed

Article:

President Obama's top aides presented a budget framework to Republicans on Thursday that includes $1.6 trillion in tax increases and future spending cuts to avoid the "fiscal cliff." The offer was immediately rejected by GOP leaders, who called for the White House to "get serious" about spending cuts.

The discussions mark the beginning of real, detailed negotiations after weeks of negotiating over principles. Republicans have already agreed to allow the government to raise revenue, and they are looking for Democrats to agree that major entitlements such as Medicare will have to be cut. However, Democrats say Republicans have yet to specify which taxes they will raise or propose their own spending cuts.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, said at a news conference, "Now is the time for the Republicans to move past this happy talk about revenues — ill-defined, of course — and put specifics on the table." He was surrounded by his leadership team.

The White House's wish list includes billions of dollars more in stimulus spending, a call to curtail Congress' control over the federal debt limit, a rise in the estate tax, and an increase in taxes on dividends. These items would undo parts of President Bush's 2001 and 2003 tax plans and are likely to be contentious among some Democrats, as well as with Republicans.

In exchange, Mr. Obama repeated his pledge to find up to $400 billion in entitlement spending cuts later, as well as to undertake an overhaul of the tax code.

Speaker of the House John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, said after meeting with Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner that they are no closer to a deal.

The White House has signaled some flexibility. Although Mr. Obama has called for tax rates on upper-income earners to rise from 35 percent to 39.6 percent, he and his aides have privately told key players that they would be willing to accept something less than the 39.6 percent rate. However, they have said that rates will have to rise somewhat.

White House spokesman Jay Carney said Republican leaders must "accept the essential fact" that tax rates on the nation's top earners must go up as part of a deficit-reduction deal.

"The president will not sign any legislation that extends the Bush-era tax cuts for the top earners in this country," he said.

Congressional Republicans said that is out of the question. Instead, they want the additional government revenue to come from ending tax breaks and closing loopholes.

"I've made clear that we've put real concessions on the line by putting revenues on the table right upfront," said Mr. Boehner. "Unfortunately, many Democrats continue to rule out sensible spending cuts that must be part of any significant agreement that will reduce our deficit."

However, Mr. Boehner has not laid out what specific tax breaks he would end, nor have Republicans proposed spending cuts as part of these negotiations. Instead, Mr. Boehner pointed reporters back to the House Republican budget for a list of ideas.

All sides are trying to head off the "fiscal cliff" — the expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts on Jan. 1, followed by $110 billion in automatic spending cuts. Going over the cliff and staying there likely would plunge the country into a short, sharp recession, though delaying the spending cuts and tax increases would mean deeper pain in the long run, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

The challenge for Mr. Obama and Congress is to try to spread the pain while doing the least harm to the economy. Mr. Geithner's separate meetings with congressional leaders marked the first major get-together between top negotiators since Mr. Obama called the leaders to the White House two weeks ago. At that time, Mr. Boehner, Mr. Reid, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, met with Mr. Obama at the White House and emerged sounding optimistic about the chances of reaching a deal to extend tax cuts and replace the spending cuts, known as "sequestration," that were set into motion through last year's bipartisan deal to raise the nation's borrowing limit.

Mr. McConnell accused the Obama administration of being more interested in appealing to the "hard left" than having a "serious discussion about how we fix the economy, reduce the federal debt, and return the country to a path of growth and prosperity for all."

Mr. Boehner said he is "disappointed" with the negotiations and warned that "there's a real danger of going off the fiscal cliff."

"Without spending cuts and entitlement reforms, it's going to be impossible to address our country's debt crises and get our economy going again and to create jobs," he said. "So right now, all eyes are on the White House."

The two parties also have staked out different positions on how best to increase the nation's $16.4 trillion debt limit, which the federal government could reach as early as next month. Mr. Reid said that any agreement in the "fiscal cliff" talks must include an increase in the borrowing limit, while Mr. Boehner said any increase has to be matched dollar for dollar with spending cuts.

Democrats said they see signs of cracks in the Republican opposition to raising tax rates. They pointed to Rep. Tom Cole, the Oklahoma Republican who is calling on his party to extend the Bush-era tax cuts for families making less than $250,000 a year, and then return to the negotiating table to fight to extend current tax rates for those making more.

"As Tom Cole said, let's give a Christmas present to the American people," Mrs. Pelosi told reporters.

Sen. Charles E. Schumer, meanwhile, said Democrats don't expect "the Republicans to be enthusiastic and start cheerleading about a deal that includes higher rates on the wealthiest Americans."

"They're not going to openly concede on this point this far out from the deadline," the New York Democrat said. "But they see the handwriting on the wall."

Other Republicans said the majority of the caucus does not agree with Mr. Cole's approach.

"I think he is wrong, and I think most of the conference thinks he is wrong," said Rep. Raul R. Labrador, Idaho Republican, to CNN. "I think that he is a good man who has served here for a long time, but he is also a man who has voted for a lot of the increased spending in Washington, D.C."

Title: Obama Contemplates Wide-Ranging Executive Actions, Including Cybersecurity Measures and Mortgage Refinancing Policies

Article:

President Barack Obama is reportedly considering a series of executive actions, one of which will focus on establishing new standards for private-sector companies to protect computer systems from hackers. This move is expected to spark controversy among Republican lawmakers.

Other potential executive actions under consideration include policies to aid homeowners in refinancing mortgages, new protections for homosexual government contractors, energy-efficient building requirements, and stricter regulations for coal-fired power plants.

Last month, Obama issued 23 administrative actions on gun violence, and in the past, he has issued orders that delayed the deportations of young illegal immigrants and lowered student loan payments.

A White House official stated that Obama is not using his executive powers to bypass Congress but rather to advance his top priorities. However, Republicans view these actions as a power grab and a violation of the Constitution.

Recently, a federal appeals court ruled that the president exceeded his constitutional powers by appointing new members to the National Labor Relations Board while the Senate was on break.

One of the more significant executive actions being considered by the president, according to The Washington Post, would provide homeowners with a better opportunity to refinance at today's low interest rates. Obama has already used his powers to make refinancing easier for people with loans backed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, but his new plan could extend these opportunities to people who are behind on the payments of their privately backed mortgages.

The decision to pursue new executive actions is reportedly due to Obama's conclusion that Republicans are unlikely to pass many of his major agenda items.

Title: "2016 Presidential Prospects: A Review of the Former GOP "Deep Bench"

Article:

The 2016 presidential race has seen a significant shift in the perceived strength of potential Republican candidates, with many from the once-touted "deep bench" now facing challenges or exiting the race altogether.

In 2012, former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell, who was the third-ranked candidate on National Journal's "deep bench" list for 2016, is currently fighting public corruption charges for accepting an estimated $165,000 in gifts from a donor. His class of 2009 colleague, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, is also under scrutiny, with investigations into the George Washington Bridge retribution scandal and allegations that his lieutenant governor threatened to withhold Sandy aid as payback for a development deal.

Marco Rubio, the second-ranked contender, has also faded from prominence after attempting to appeal to the center with immigration reform and then shifting to the right. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, who was lucky to be seventh on the list, flamed out after criticizing the GOP and becoming the most unpopular Republican governor in the country in 2013.

Texas Senator Ted Cruz, who was not on the list, has imploded due to his self-promoting and extremist political style. Senator Rand Paul, who was sixth on the list, has been criticized for his lightweight persona, plagiarism issues, and politically suicidal foreign policy skepticism.

Representative Paul Ryan, who was fifth on the list, has reinvented himself as a champion of the poor and a supporter of Pope Francis, but his performance on the 2012 ticket was criticized for hurting Mitt Romney. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who is receiving renewed attention due to Christie's troubles, is under investigation for ethically challenged associates and has been named one of the nation's "worst governors" by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

This leaves former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who was fourth on the list, as a potential frontrunner. Bush is beloved by the GOP establishment but faces criticism from the Tea Party and questions about his ties to Wall Street. His association with the failed Lehman Brothers, which cost Florida's state and local pension funds $1 billion, could be a potential conflict in a national race.

South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, South Dakota Senator John Thune, and Indiana Representative Mike Pence rounded out the National Journal list. The future of the 2016 race remains uncertain, but it is clear that the once-promising "deep bench" of Republican candidates has taken a significant hit.

Title: Michelle Williams Advocates for Reproductive Freedom at 2020 Golden Globes

Article:

Actress Michelle Williams won her second Golden Globe award for her role on Fosse/Verdon during the ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday night. In her acceptance speech, she emphasized the importance of reproductive freedom.

Williams began her speech by acknowledging the choices made by the actor and as a person. She expressed gratitude for the recognition of her choices and for living in a society where choice exists.

According to a report by Anna North for ███, it is likely that the Supreme Court will dismantle Roe v. Wade in 2020. Already, multiple states have enacted laws that effectively ban abortions. In March, the Court will hear arguments for June Medical Services v. Gee, a case centered on whether Louisiana can restrict abortions to treatment centers where at least one doctor has admitting privileges at an area hospital.

Admitting privilege laws, a common tactic used by red states to limit the number of abortion providers, are often justified in the name of women's safety. However, advocates for abortion rights argue that it is rare for anyone to need hospitalization after an abortion. With Brett Kavanaugh on the bench, it is believed that the Court will uphold Louisiana's law, making it possible for states to outlaw abortion and potentially overturn Roe.
