South Bend Common Council member Oliver Davis, a black leader from the hometown of White House hopeful Pete Buttigieg, has endorsed Buttigieg's 2020 presidential rival, former Vice President Joe Biden. The endorsement was announced on Friday by Biden's campaign.

In a statement, Davis stated, "In times like these, when the political winds are fiercely blowing across our country, it's important for us to have an experienced leader who has been through the diverse storms of life to guide our country." He further added, "That's why I am very pleased to support Vice President Joe Biden to be our next President of the United States of America."

Biden's campaign noted that the former vice president has received support from over 600 national, state, and local leaders across the country. Davis is the third African American elected official from Indiana to endorse Biden.

The endorsement comes as Buttigieg's campaign has seen momentum, particularly in the early caucus state of Iowa. However, Buttigieg has struggled to gain support from black voters. Davis told Politico that Buttigieg's failure to gain support from communities of color "is not a new problem for him."

Davis ran to replace Buttigieg as South Bend's mayor this year, but lost in the Democratic primary to Buttigieg's preferred candidate, James Mueller.

Title: Investigations into Alleged Collusion and Wiretapping: Lack of Evidence and Ongoing Uncertainty

Article:

The ongoing investigations into alleged collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian intelligence, as well as the claim of Obama-era wiretapping of Trump Tower, have left the political landscape in a state of uncertainty. As of today, there is no concrete evidence to support either charge.

James Clapper, former Director of National Intelligence under President Obama, has stated unequivocally that he has seen no evidence of Trump campaign collusion with Russia. Similarly, no evidence has been presented to support the claim of Obama-era wiretapping of Trump Tower.

The lack of evidence has not deterred the launch of multiple investigations, with the potential for a special prosecutor. The collusion narrative stems from the unusual circumstances surrounding Michael Flynn's false denial of discussing sanctions with the Russian ambassador and Jeff Sessions' false denial of having any contacts with Russians. However, these actions do not inherently constitute inappropriate behavior, and the reasons for concealment remain unclear.

The wiretapping storyline, on the other hand, is considered less plausible than a zombie invasion by many, including Congressional Republicans and key figures within the Trump administration. The Obama administration's alleged dissemination of information about Trump associates' contacts with Russians has raised questions about potential abuse of the right to listen in on foreigners to improperly monitor Americans.

Despite the ongoing investigations and speculation, the truth remains elusive. The intelligence agencies are tasked with gathering information, but their actions do not necessarily equate to evidence of wrongdoing. The focus should shift from these internal investigations to addressing pressing national and global issues, such as the escalating tensions with North Korea and the imminent installation of an antimissile shield in South Korea.

In the midst of these self-created crises, it is crucial to remain vigilant and prepared for the real challenges that lie ahead. The political landscape is fraught with uncertainty, and it is essential to separate fact from fiction to make informed decisions and navigate the complexities of the global stage.

Title: Repurposed Drugs Show Promise in Cancer Treatment, According to New Study

Article:

A new study published in Nature Cancer has revealed that drugs originally developed to treat diseases such as diabetes and alcoholism may have applications in cancer treatment. Researchers tested thousands of existing medications, many of which have already been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treating diseases other than cancer, against hundreds of different human cancer cell lines in the lab. The study identified dozens of newly identified cancer-killing compounds.

The lead author of the study, Steven Corsello, practices oncology at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and researches new cancer drug development at the Broad Institute of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard University. Corsello, who regularly treats patients with chemotherapy medications, many of which were developed decades ago, says, "I deeply appreciate the need for improved and better-tailored cancer therapy."

New drug development is costly and time-consuming, often requiring years of painstaking research, and potential treatments rarely progress beyond the lab. Even when a medication makes it to clinical trials, it must undergo years of safety testing. Many of those that kill cancer efficiently are also so toxic to test subjects that they are never approved.

Because of these limitations, the field of repurposing existing drugs is "really coming to the forefront," says Jonathan Sexton, a medicinal chemist who directs the University of Michigan's Center for Drug Repurposing and was not involved in the study. "We're notoriously very bad at predicting what [compounds] are going to be most efficacious against specific cancers, which is why there is a huge attrition rate [for drugs] in clinical trials for cancer," he says. This situation has produced a wealth of medications that may not work for one type of cancer but could work for another type. And as libraries of these compounds continue to grow, Sexton says, a veritable pharmacopeia of treatments is becoming available.

At the Broad Institute, Corsello and his colleagues investigate how drugs affect gene expression—the degree to which genes are turned on or off—to determine whether the compounds have potential applications in cancer treatment. The institute developed a library of more than 1.5 million gene expression profiles from thousands of potential drug molecules, called the Connectivity Map, to guide the search. "In the course of that research, I realized that we were missing many drugs, including ones that the FDA has already approved for other uses," Corsello says. With that in mind, he and his colleagues at the Broad Institute launched the Drug Repurposing Hub (DRH) in 2017 to test existing drugs against various disease models. That open-access library, which researchers anywhere can use for free, now includes more than 6,000 drugs—ranging from aspirin to Zantac—originally developed for other applications.

Rong Xu, a medical bioinformaticist at Case Western Reserve University, who was not involved in the study, says that for "dry" labs—which use computer-generated models to investigate new drug applications—libraries such as the DRH are invaluable. "We'll use this as a starting point and correlate and also integrate these data sets with what we know about disease genetics" to design computer algorithms that can identify potential treatment avenues, Xu says.

In the new study, published Monday in Nature Cancer, Corsello and his colleagues systematically tested 4,518 compounds from the DRH (of which 3,350 are already approved for use in the U.S. or Europe) against 578 cancer cell lines. Most were developed to treat diseases other than cancer; about a quarter were originally developed for cancer. Using a molecular bar-coding method to keep track of the vast array of cancer cell lines, which employs short sequences of DNA as "bar codes," the researchers were able to test multiple cancer cell types simultaneously in each Petri dish, speeding the process considerably. In total, the team identified nearly 50 compounds that killed cancer cells and left other cells unscathed.

The researchers found 11 different drugs that trigger the same cancer-killing mechanism. These included one previously approved to treat essential thrombocytosis—a blood disorder—as well as progesterone medications. The drugs all appear to work by inducing an interaction between two proteins: PDE3A, which plays a role in regulating blood pressure, and SLFN12, whose role is not well understood. (In contrast, many existing cancer treatments merely inhibit enzymes.) Corsello says the interaction is "an attractive target" for developing new therapies. "The drugs we found are a nice starting point to do that," he adds.

Once a drug shows selective anticancer effects, the next step is to find out how it works. Corsello says the team does so by looking at "everything that's known" about the cancer cell lines the drug kills. He lists a battery of genomic features the researchers analyze to determine where and how the killing blow lands, including gene expression, mutation, and the number of copies of the gene in the genotype. "Then, using predictive modeling approaches, [we] determine predictive biomarkers of response to each of these therapies," he says.

Of course, not all of these medications will turn out to work against cancer in humans. Predictive biomarkers can indicate how effective a treatment will be against a particular type of cancer cell line in the lab or how well it can treat a patient in the clinic. "We prioritized drugs for follow-up that had selective [anticancer] activity and drugs that had predictive biomarkers from these cell line features," Corsello says. Medications that can predictably kill certain cancer cells could eventually be tested in patients and predict individuals who could benefit from those treatments.

Corsello says that the research team plans to add 300 new cancer cell lines and 300 drug compounds to the library. "I think there's still a lot that remains to be learned and discovered from this data," Corsello says. By using technologies such as CRISPR gene editing and screening, "we're able to take a drug with promising activity and actually figuring out how it's working, which I think is a really promising strategy for the future that may have an impact on drug development."

Title: The Onion's Satirical Approach to Mass Shootings in America Sparks Debate

Article:

The satirical news site, The Onion, has published a recurring article titled "No Way to Prevent This," which has been republished three times over the past year and a half following mass shootings in the United States. The most recent instance was this week after a shooter killed nine people at an Oregon community college, following similar events in a black Charleston church in June and at the University of California Santa Barbara in May 2015.

The article's content remains consistent, with the specifics of each shooting changing, but key lines remain the same. The article highlights the nation's high rate of gun violence and the perceived helplessness of its citizens in preventing these tragedies.

The article has been shared thousands of times on social media, and some on Twitter have acknowledged its impact. Katie Reeves, a Twitter user, commented, "This is peculiarly powerful: The Onion simply re-posts its gun violence article with updated locations and dates." Drew Thaler, another Twitter user, said, "This is how you make a point. Three different articles from The Onion."

Journalist Dave Cullen, who has covered mass shootings for years and wrote the New York Times bestseller Columbine, praised The Onion's article, stating, "I think what [the article's popularity] says is we look for the people who tell us the truth—kind of the emperor's new clothes—who see through the stuff, and don't just print the same old stuff, or do the same old stuff, or do the safe stuff—the people who call us on our s**t."

Cullen also noted that The Onion's satirical coverage of mass shootings in America has not always been well-received. After a shooting that killed 12 at Washington Navy Yard in 2013, The Onion published a story with the headline "Location of Newest Mass Shooting Revealed. It's A Navy Yard, Authorities Confirm." Some criticized the article as "not funny" and "gross stupidity."

However, not all tragedies leave satirists speechless. After the Charleston church massacre, Jon Stewart, host of The Daily Show, started his comments after the shooting with the words, "I've got nothing." The Onion, after the Sandy Hook massacre, wrote an article with the headline "F**k Everything, Nation Reports."

The Onion's satirical approach to mass shootings in America has sparked debate, with some praising the site for saying what many feel but are afraid to express, while others find the humor inappropriate during times of tragedy.

Title: Iowa Campaign Events: Trump and Clinton Address Supporters in Opposing Styles

Article:

In the town of Oskaloosa, Iowa, over a thousand people gathered at Oskaloosa High School on a hot and muggy Saturday afternoon. The event, organized by billionaire businessman Donald Trump, featured a free catered barbecue and the opportunity to sign up for a mailing list in exchange for T-shirts and other merchandise. Trump delivered a rally in his signature meandering style, criticizing Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker and his fiscal policies, recounting his recent trip to Laredo, Texas, and expressing his business acumen.

Simultaneously, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton held a more intimate gathering with less than 100 Third District Iowa Democrats under a sycamore tree on the grounds of the Madison County Historical Complex. Clinton, dressed in a striped shirt and slacks, reminisced about her past campaigns with her husband, Bill Clinton, and expressed her appreciation for the support in Iowa.

Trump's rally was designed to attract a large crowd, while Clinton's event was more focused on engaging with a smaller group. Trump's remarks touched on immigration, veterans, competition with China and Japan, and his issues with the Republican Party and Washington. Clinton, on the other hand, went through her policy-heavy stump speech, discussing her opposition to big money in politics, her support for early-childhood education, the Affordable Care Act, gay rights, and elder care.

Trump criticized Wisconsin's current state, claiming it was in turmoil due to Governor Walker's policies. He also highlighted his relationship with veterans, presenting a stack of letters allegedly written by veterans in the past day. Clinton, however, did not mention her primary opponents, despite former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley serenading the crowd with songs, including a rendition of "This Land Is Your Land."

Trump responded to criticism of his comments about Mexican immigrants and Arizona Senator John McCain, while Clinton did not address her email use as Secretary of State. Trump trails Walker in recent Iowa polls, and he jokingly asked the crowd to put him in first place. Both candidates continue their campaigns in Iowa, with Trump focusing on his business acumen and Trump's immigration policies, while Clinton emphasizes her policy positions and experience.

Title: Supreme Court Expected to Uphold Individual Mandate in Narrow Fashion, According to CNN's Bill Mears

Article:

CNN's Bill Mears, in response to repeated inquiries about the Supreme Court's upcoming decision on the Affordable Care Act, predicts that the individual mandate will be upheld, albeit in a narrow fashion. Mears suggests that Chief Justice John Roberts may write the majority opinion, asserting that the power to assign the opinion-writing is one of the chief justice's prerogatives when in the majority.

The individual mandate, which requires most Americans to purchase health insurance, is expected to survive, according to Mears. However, he notes that this prediction goes against conventional wisdom and that no one, including himself, has inside information about the court's decision.

If Chief Justice Roberts takes on the task of writing the majority opinion, Mears believes he will attempt to navigate between the two polar views on the mandate's constitutionality and Congress's power to regulate "commerce." The division of opinion on the mandate's constitutionality was evident during the oral arguments, with Roberts and Justice Anthony Kennedy asking tough questions of both sides.

The decision may not command a majority, meaning at least five justices agree on the outcome but not the constitutional basis. This split reasoning could lead to further uncertainty if Congress and the White House were to revise or entirely rework health care reform in the wake of the court's decision.

Mears suggests that the task of commanding a five-vote majority and maintaining it throughout the contentious opinion-writing process may lead Roberts, or whoever writes the opinion, to think small and narrow. This approach would involve upholding the mandate by insisting that health care is unique in the national economy and warning Congress not to go much further when regulating "commerce," such as imposing a mandate to buy broccoli or American cars.

The exact outcome of the Supreme Court's decision remains uncertain, as only the justices, their law clerks, and a handful of court officials know how this will end. However, Mears anticipates a complex, lengthy, and potentially baffling ruling or series of rulings.

Title: The Effectiveness of Conservative Economic Policies: A Perspective on American Economic Growth

Article:

A recent New York Times article surveyed the state of the American economy and suggested that conservative economic policies, such as deregulation and tax cuts, are more effective than the mainstream press would have readers believe. The article, however, argues that the evidence linking regulation levels to growth is weak, and that deregulation does not necessarily stimulate economic activity.

The article asserts that the Trump administration has stopped hundreds of Obama-era regulations from being enacted and thousands of yet-to-be-invented regulations from ever being considered. It is suggested that this kind of deregulation has contributed to investment and job growth.

The article also criticizes the media for propping up economists who focus on issues such as inequality, labor unions, and climate change, rather than economic growth. It argues that these economists are often quoted in the media to support liberal policy positions, giving them a veneer of scientific certitude.

The article cites examples of policies such as the minimum wage hike, which has led to job losses in cities that have implemented it. It also points out that the predictions made by economists regarding the economic impact of policies such as the "stimulus," the Affordable Care Act, and the minimum wage have often been inaccurate.

The article concludes by stating that while deregulation and tax cuts are not a panacea, they have already had an impact on the economy, with businesses acting on these policies and announcing bonus checks for their workers. The article suggests that the media should give voice to the economists who argue in favor of the free market and the positive impact of conservative economic policies.

Title: Republican National Convention Shifts GOP Messaging: Disappointment as a Subtle Strategy Against Obama

The Republican National Convention in Tampa, Florida, has been characterized by the theme of disappointment, with the Republican Party criticizing President Barack Obama for failing to meet the expectations set in 2008. The convention, according to Obama's team, was a "miss," with the Republicans not landing a significant blow on their opponent.

However, the GOP's strategy, as presented in Tampa, represents a more nuanced and potentially dangerous approach for Obama. Instead of the kitchen-sink attacks that preceded the gathering, the Republicans posed as Obama 2008 voters, expressing their disillusionment with the president's unfulfilled promises.

Both parties acknowledge the power of the disappointment theme. The hope Obama offered for economic recovery, political transformation, and environmental protection has waned, according to the Republicans. Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, stated in his acceptance speech, "President Obama promised to begin to slow the rise of the oceans and heal the planet. My promise is to help you and your family."

Senator Marco Rubio, in his speech, said, "Our problem with President Obama isn't that he's a bad person...Our problem is that he's a bad president."

The convention saw a shift in tone, with the shrill hyperbole, petty critiques, and Party of No intransigence absent from the proceedings. The convention, at times, resembled a Democratic gathering, with appealing vice-presidential candidate Paul Ryan praising his mother and vowing to protect Medicare for seniors, and Senators Marco Rubio and Susana Martinez speaking of the opportunities the United States afforded them to rise into leadership positions.

The convention's criticism of Obama was more subtle, aimed at shifting momentum and softening the opponent for the remainder of the campaign. The convention's tone may not be immediately apparent to the casual observer, but it represents a strategic body blow that could impact the outcome of the election.

Title: China Imposes Tariffs on U.S. Imports in Response to U.S. Tariff Hikes

Article:

China announced on Monday that it will impose tariffs on more than 5,000 U.S. products, in response to President Donald Trump's decision to raise duties on Chinese goods amid ongoing trade talks between the two countries. The new tariffs, which will take effect on June 1, will impact approximately $60 billion in U.S. imports and will range from 5% to 25%.

The U.S. had previously increased import taxes on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25% on May 10. The White House stated that President Trump is fine with China taking some retaliatory action, as long as it does not exceed an unspecified level. However, economists predict that the costs of the tariffs will be passed onto consumers in the form of higher prices.

The tariffs will impact a wide range of U.S. products, including coffee, beef, salmon, flowers, and some fruits and vegetables. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped more than 600 points, or 2.3%, and closed at 25,324, its biggest one-day loss since January. The Standard & Poor's 500 index slipped 2.4%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq, which has been the most vulnerable to trade tensions, was down 3.4% at the closing bell.

Boeing's stock plummeted more than 4% after the editor of a state-owned newspaper speculated that China may single out the jet manufacturer for retaliation for Trump's tariffs. "China may stop purchasing US agricultural products and energy, reduce Boeing orders, and restrict US service trade with China," Hu Xijin, editor-in-chief of the Global Times, wrote on Twitter.

On Capitol Hill, one of the leading Republican critics of Trump's tariffs, Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), stated that both the U.S. and China would suffer from the tit-for-tat actions coming out of Washington and Beijing. "Raising tariffs will hurt both US & China economies + more importantly will hurt US farmers/consumers/businesses," Grassley wrote on Twitter.

Cailin Birch, global economist at The Economist Intelligence Unit, stated that she still expects the U.S. and China to reach a limited trade agreement in the next month or so, due to the serious economic ramifications both countries will be dealing with otherwise. However, she also noted that a cooling-off period may be necessary to allow each party to save face before meaningful progress can be made.

Douglas Holtz-Eakin, an economist and president of the American Action Forum, a nonprofit policy group, stated that the Chinese tariffs are an extension of its previous strategy. "At every point they have matched, but not exceeded, a U.S. tariff move," Holtz-Eakin said. "This represents additional tariffs on items already facing duties—just as are the tariffs that President Trump announced last week. Stepping back, they are evidence of an escalating and increasingly troubling trade war."

Title: Bipartisan Senators to Introduce Legislation to Protect Special Counsel's Office

Article:

A bipartisan group of senators will introduce legislation on Wednesday aimed at protecting the office of the special counsel, following President Donald Trump's comments about potentially firing the special prosecutor investigating Russia and the 2016 election.

Robert Mueller, the special counsel, is currently probing allegations of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election, an investigation that has expanded to include whether the Trump campaign colluded with Moscow. Russia has denied interfering in the election, and Trump and the White House have stated there was no collusion.

After the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the offices of Trump's personal lawyer on Monday, based partly on a referral by Mueller, Trump called the investigation "a disgrace" and suggested he may consider firing the special counsel.

On Wednesday, four senators announced they would merge two different proposals to protect the office of the special counsel. The original bills were introduced last summer. If passed, the legislation would allow the special counsel to be fired only "for good cause" by a senior Justice Department official, with a reason given in writing; provide recourse if the special counsel was fired without good cause; and preserve the staffing and materials of a pending investigation.

"We need to ensure not only that Special Counsel Mueller can complete his work without interference, but that special counsels in future investigations can, too," said Democratic Senator Chris Coons, one of the sponsors of the bill, in a statement.

On Tuesday, Senate leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican, said that while he thought Mueller should be allowed to continue his probe, he did not think legislation to protect him was necessary. It remains unclear whether the proposal could pass the House or that Trump would approve it. Spokespeople for McConnell and the White House did not immediately respond to emailed requests for comments.

However, Coons said in an interview with MSNBC that he thought some Republicans, who currently have the majority in the Senate, could be swayed to back the bill. "I think the events of the past week have changed some minds in the Republican caucus, that there is a moment here for the Senate to stand up and save the president from himself," said Coons.

Title: United States and World: Parallels to 1968 Amidst Political, Social, and Economic Unrest

Article:

The United States and the world are experiencing a resurgence of language, politics, and global instability reminiscent of 1968. The country, then, was grappling with the Vietnam War, a contentious presidential election, antiwar protests, racial unrest, political assassinations, terrorism, and a looming economic recession, leaving it deeply divided between a vocal radical minority and a silent conservative majority.

In 2017, the nation appears to be repeating this pattern, with the divide between liberal coasts and red-state America being far deeper and more evenly split. The removal of century-old statues, the NFL's political turmoil, and the permeation of politics in popular culture are just a few examples of the old foundations of American life eroding.

The European Union, once a model for the future, is unraveling due to the exit of Great Britain, the divide between Spain and Catalonia, the bankruptcy of Mediterranean nation members, terrorist attacks, and the influx of immigrants from war-torn Middle Eastern countries. Germany is once again asserting itself, but this time through insidious means other than military might.

North Korea claims to have nuclear-tipped missiles capable of reaching the U.S. West Coast, and Iran is likely to follow a similar nuclear trajectory, while its new Shiite hegemony in the Middle East is feeding on the remnants of Syria and Iraq.

Despite the social unrest and media hysteria, the U.S. economy is growing, unemployment and inflation remain low, the stock market and middle-class incomes are up, and business and consumer confidence are high. Energy production has expanded, the border with Mexico is being enforced, and corporate profits are up.

The question remains whether this chaos is a necessary and long-overdue purging of dangerous and neglected pathologies or a sign that the conventional wisdom of the past is drawing to a close. The traditional political parties seem to have no answers, with Democrats being overwhelmed by progressive identity politics and socialism, and Republicans torn between populist nationalists and the calcified establishment status quo.

The instability may be less a symptom of America falling apart and more a sign that the old conventional wisdom is coming to an end, along with the careers of those who profited from it. Historically, any crisis that did not destroy the United States has ended up making it stronger. However, the current situation is marked by a struggle over which is more toxic: the chronic statist malady that has been eating away at the country, or the new populist medicine deemed necessary to cure it.

Title: FBI Officials Discussed 25th Amendment to Remove President Trump, According to Former Acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe

Article:

In 2017, a series of discussions among high-level officials within the Department of Justice (DOJ) reportedly took place to consider the possibility of invoking the U.S. Constitution's 25th Amendment to remove President Donald Trump from office. These discussions, as claimed by former acting FBI Director Andrew McCabe, involved discussions about declaring the president unfit for office and installing the vice president in his place.

The 25th Amendment provides a mechanism for removing a president who is unable to perform the duties of the office. However, it is important to note that this is different from impeachment, the process for removing a president for misconduct. The vice president and a majority of cabinet officers must agree, in writing, that the president is unable to discharge the duties of the office. There is no provision for law enforcement or government officials to force a president from office.

McCabe's claims that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein was part of this coup attempt are shocking, given Rosenstein's role in making numerous decisions that impact a wide range of issues. McCabe's veracity is questionable, as he was fired for providing false information to the DOJ. However, it is unlikely that a serious deputy attorney general would joke about such matters.

McCabe claims that he and others believed they were working for a president who might have conspired with Russia to betray the country. However, there is no evidence to support this claim, and special counsel Robert Mueller, who was investigating potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, has not taken any steps to remove the president.

McCabe and his colleagues were reportedly aware that the explosive claims in the Steele dossier, a document produced by former British spy Christopher Steele for the Democratic Party and Hillary Clinton's campaign, were unverified. By May 2017, the FBI had months of data from electronic spying on former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page and those with whom he communicated, but none of this data resulted in any verification of the claims in the Steele dossier.

Francey Hakes, a former prosecutor and consultant on national security and the protection of children, served as a prosecutor for 16 years and appeared before the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. She now consults on national security and the protection of children. Follow her on Twitter @FranceyHakes.

Title: Dow Jones Industrial Average Experiences Historic Decline Amid COVID-19 Outbreak and Federal Reserve's Monetary Stimulus

Article:

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) plummeted significantly on Monday, marking its worst day since the "Black Monday" market crash in 1987 and its third-worst day in history. The DJIA closed 2,997.10 points lower, or 12.9%, at 20,188.52. The 30-stock Dow was briefly down more than 3,000 points in the final minutes of trading.

The S&P 500 dropped 12% to 2,386.13, reaching its lowest level since December 2018, while the Nasdaq Composite closed 12.3% lower at 6,904.59, marking its worst day ever.

Frank Cappelleri, executive director at Instinet, commented in a note, "The markets are getting no break with yesterday's historic Fed actions and COVID-19 dominating the world's headlines. While the news continues to worsen and with the price action doing things we've only seen a handful of other times in the last century, it's nearly impossible to keep things in perspective."

The major averages fell to their lows into the close after President Donald Trump stated that the worst of the COVID-19 outbreak could last until August. He also suggested that the U.S. "may be" heading into a recession.

Liz Young, BNY Mellon strategist, stated on ███'s "Closing Bell," "The market didn't hear what it wanted to hear. I don't think that it wanted to hear that this was going to last until July and August, and now the market does the math. If it lasts until July and August, that means we may have a contraction in the second quarter and the third quarter, and that means recession."

Monday's losses put the Dow down 31.7% from its all-time high and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq more than 29% below their records last month. The Dow fell to its lowest point since 2017.

The Dow's drop was the worst decline since its "Black Monday" crash three decades ago when it fell more than 22%. The drop surpassed its 9.99% tumble last Thursday. It was also the Dow's third-worst day ever; it dropped more than 13% in late 1929.

Title: Japan Resumes Commercial Whaling in Defiance of International Criticism

Article:

Japan has initiated its first commercial whale hunt in decades, a move that defies international criticism and withdraws from the International Whaling Commission (IWC) regulations. The whaling fleet, permitted to catch 227 minke, Bryde's, and sei whales this year, set sail from Kushiro, Japan, with a kill cap of 52 minke, 150 Bryde's, and 25 sei whales.

The last commercial whale hunt in Japan occurred in 1986, but the country has continued whaling under the guise of research. The IWC, comprising member nations, had agreed to an effective ban on whale hunting, but Japan argues that sustainable whale hunting is possible.

The fisheries ministry has set a quota for the season, with last year's catch under its scientific program at 333 whales. Shigeto Hase, the head of the agency, expressed his excitement for the resumption of commercial whaling, stating that it would preserve the culture and way of life for future generations.

Yoshifumi Kai, head of the Japan Small-Type Whaling Association, shared similar sentiments, emphasizing the long-standing history of whale hunting in his hometown. Whalers expressed a mix of excitement and nervousness as they set sail for the season.

The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species classifies minke and Bryde's whales as not endangered, while sei whales are endangered but with increasing numbers. Conservationist groups like Greenpeace and Sea Shepherd remain critical of Japan's resumption of whaling, but have yet to announce concrete plans for action against the country.

Nicola Beynon of Humane Society International described the resumption of commercial whaling as a "sad day for whale protection globally," accusing Japan of beginning a "new and shocking era of pirate whaling." Sam Annesley, executive director at Greenpeace Japan, stated that Japan is "out of step with the international community."

Whaling is considered part of Japan's culture, with coastal communities having hunted whales for centuries. Consumption of whale meat became widespread after World War Two when other food sources were scarce. Whales were brought to the brink of extinction by hunting in the 19th and early 20th Century, and the IWC imposed a hunting moratorium in 1986 to allow whale numbers to recover.

Since 1987, Japan has killed between 200 and 1,200 whales each year under an exemption to the ban allowing scientific research. Critics argue this was a cover for Japan to hunt whales for food, as the meat from the whales killed for research usually ended up for sale. In 2018, Japan attempted one last time to convince the IWC to allow whaling under sustainable quotas, but failed. Japan left the IWC, effective from July 2019.

Title: Deadliest Day of Violence in Gaza Since 2014 War: At Least 52 Palestinians Killed, 2,400 Wounded

Article:

At least 52 Palestinians have been killed and 2,400 wounded by Israeli troops, according to Palestinian officials, marking the deadliest day of violence since the 2014 Gaza war. The escalation in violence occurred on the day the United States opened its embassy in Jerusalem, an event Palestinians view as clear US backing for Israeli rule over the city's eastern part, which they claim.

The violence began six weeks ago with protests at the Gaza border, dubbed the "Great March of Return" and led by Gaza's Islamist rulers, Hamas. Hamas had previously stated it would escalate the protests on Tuesday, when Palestinians commemorate the Nakba or Catastrophe, marking the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians following the foundation of the Israeli state on May 14, 1948.

On Monday, the Israeli military reported that 40,000 Palestinians participated in "violent riots" at 13 locations along the Gaza Strip security fence. Palestinians hurled stones and incendiary devices, while the Israeli military used snipers. Black smoke poured from burning tires, and the health ministry, run by Hamas, reported that children were among those killed.

The Israeli military stated that it had killed three people attempting to plant explosives near the security fence in Rafah. Aircraft and tanks also targeted military positions belonging to Hamas in the northern Gaza Strip, according to the Israeli military.

Israel claims the protests are aimed at breaching the border and attacking Israeli communities nearby. There were also violent clashes between Israeli police and protesters who raised Palestinian flags outside the new embassy, with several protesters being detained.

Tuesday is expected to see larger and potentially more violent demonstrations, as Palestinians bury those killed on Monday and return to demonstrate. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated, "Every nation has the right to defend its borders. Hamas clearly says its intentions are to destroy Israel and sends thousands to break through the border for that end."

Western nations, including the UK, called for restraint. EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini said, "We expect all to act with utmost restraint to avoid further loss of life." Germany stated that Israel has the right to defend itself but should do so proportionately.

The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein, condemned the "shocking killing of dozens, injury of hundreds by Israeli live fire." A small interim embassy will begin operating from Monday inside the existing US consulate building in Jerusalem, with a larger site to be found later when the rest of the embassy moves from Tel Aviv.

The opening ceremony was brought forward to coincide with the state of Israel's 70th anniversary. US President Donald Trump's daughter, Ivanka, and her husband Jared Kushner, who are both senior White House advisers, joined US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Deputy Secretary of State John Sullivan for the ceremony.

After Ivanka Trump unveiled the seal of the embassy, Jared Kushner said in his address, "When President Trump makes a promise, he keeps it... We have shown the world that the US can be trusted. We stand with our friends and allies." Kushner also referred to Trump's withdrawal from the "dangerous, flawed, and one-sided Iran deal," drawing applause from the guests.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated, "What a glorious day. Remember this moment. This is history. President Trump, by recognizing history, you have made history." Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas condemned the embassy as a "settlement in East Jerusalem," stating that the US was "no longer a mediator in the Middle East."

Arab League chief Ahmed Abul Gheit stated it was "shameful to see countries participating with the US and Israel in celebrating the former's embassy move to occupied Jerusalem in a clear and grave violation of international law." The status of Jerusalem goes to the heart of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with Israeli sovereignty over Jerusalem not recognized internationally.

Since 1967, Israel has built a dozen settlements, home to about 200,000 Jews, in East Jerusalem. These settlements are considered illegal under international law, although Israel disputes this. Various countries once had embassies based in Jerusalem but many moved after Israel passed a law in 1980 formally making Jerusalem its capital.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Discusses Personal Struggles and Achievements

Article:

In the upcoming Democratic debates on July 30, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren is one of ten presidential candidates participating on Tuesday at 8 p.m. ET on CNN. Ten other candidates will debate on Wednesday evening. Warren is a U.S. senator from Massachusetts, and the opinions expressed in this commentary are her own; view more opinion at CNN.

In a personal account shared by Warren, she recounts her childhood experiences and the challenges her family faced. At the age of 12, Warren's father suffered a heart attack, and the family faced financial hardships, nearly losing their family station wagon and their home.

One significant event that marked a turning point in Warren's life occurred when she walked into her parents' bedroom and found her mother preparing for a job interview. Her mother, who had never worked outside the home, donned a dress typically reserved for weddings, funerals, and graduations, and took a minimum-wage job answering phones. This job, Warren explains, saved her family.

Warren grew up in Oklahoma with three older brothers who all joined the military. Initially, she aspired to become a public school teacher, but the financial burden of college seemed insurmountable for her family. Despite the obstacles, Warren managed to secure a scholarship and attended George Washington University.

However, Warren's journey was not a straightforward one. At 19, she dropped out of college after the first boy she loved proposed marriage, and she took a job answering phones. Despite the setback, Warren maintained a good job and a good life.

Warren then learned about the University of Houston, a public four-year college with affordable tuition. She completed her degree and went on to become a teacher for students with speech and learning disabilities, fulfilling her dream.

Title: Study Challenges LGBT Left's Narrative on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity

Article:

A comprehensive study titled "Sexuality and Gender: Findings from the Biological, Psychological, and Social Sciences" has been released by The New Atlantis, challenging the narrative of the LGBT Left on sexual orientation and gender identity. The study, authored by Lawrence Mayer, a scholar-in-residence at Johns Hopkins University, and Paul McHugh, the former psychiatrist-in-chief at Johns Hopkins Hospital, presents findings that contradict the widely accepted notion that sexual orientation and gender identity are innate, biologically fixed properties of human beings.

The study argues that the view that sexual orientation is an innate, biologically fixed property is not supported by scientific evidence. The authors highlight numerous studies finding that sexual orientation is often fluid, with one study showing high rates of abandonment of non-heterosexual identification as young men grow out of adolescence.

Regarding gender identity, the study asserts that the idea that it is an innate, fixed property independent of biological sex is not supported by scientific evidence. The authors note that only a minority of children who experience "cross-gender identification" will continue to do so as they get older.

The study also reveals that compared to the general population, non-heterosexual subpopulations are at an elevated risk for a variety of adverse health and mental health outcomes. The numbers are sobering, with non-heterosexual populations having 1.5 times the risk of anxiety disorders and substance abuse, twice the risk of depression, and 2.5 times the risk of suicide. The transgender population also is at elevated risk for mental-health problems, with the suicide numbers particularly troubling, with the rate of lifetime suicide attempts across all ages of transgender individuals estimated at 41%, compared to under 5% in the overall U.S. population.

The study is lengthy and comprehensive, and when delving into its depths, it becomes clear that McHugh and Mayer are not positing simplistic alternative explanations for human sexuality that would mirror and rebut the Left's narrative. Instead, what emerges is a messy, realistic vision of human beings who are shaped by myriad social, cultural, and biological forces.

The study spends considerable time discussing the high incidence of childhood sexual and physical abuse in the LGBT community. The authors note that the answer to whether LGBT people experience higher rates of abuse and assault because of their orientation or whether the life-altering experience of abuse and assault contributes to the formation of an LGBT identity is not necessarily either/or. A person can be targeted because they're perceived to be gay, and sexual abuse perpetrated by men might cause boys to think they are gay or make girls averse to sexual contact with men.

The messy reality described by McHugh and Mayer has been experienced by humans since time immemorial. The LGBT Left's narrative is the new nonsense, but in response to the new nonsense, there are sectors of American and European politics and culture that can't kick away the old norms of marriage and gender fast enough. They keep doing so in spite of the mountain of evidence that those who forsake the allegedly oppressive "Western-prescribed nuclear family structure requirement," to quote Black Lives Matter, face far greater challenges than those who stick faithfully to the heteronormative nightmare of traditional male-female marriage.

What's even worse, what's downright insane, is that some on the Left want to end the debate. They want to keep selling their moral vision to the public without any competition. The Judeo-Christian model, by contrast, is aspirational, calling on people not to do what they want but what they should. Admittedly, this path is far easier for some than others, but there has always been some play in the cultural joints. The Left's response is alluring, but it offers a self-indulgent path down which lies cultural ruin. The LGBT Left is driving us there just as fast as it can depress the gas pedal, but thanks to McHugh and Mayer, we now know they most assuredly are not doing so in the name of "science."

Title: Illinois Legalizes Recreational Marijuana, Establishes Statewide Marketplace

Article:

Illinois has become the 11th state in the United States to legalize marijuana for recreational use, following Governor J.B. Pritzker's signing of a bill that allows residents to purchase and possess up to one ounce of cannabis at a time, and non-residents up to 15 grams. The law, which fulfills one of Pritzker's campaign promises, also implements the nation's first comprehensive statewide cannabis marketplace designed by legislators.

The legislation, effective from January 1, 2020, permits adults 21 and older to purchase cannabis at approved dispensaries. However, possession remains a crime until the dispensaries are licensed and established.

The law offers expungement of criminal records for nearly 800,000 people with past convictions for purchasing or possessing 30 grams or less of marijuana. The marketplace portion of the Illinois law also addresses the disproportionate impact of the war on drugs on minority communities.

The law provides preference to would-be marijuana vendors in areas of high poverty and with records of large numbers of convictions. Portions of the tax proceeds must be reinvested in impoverished communities.

Police organizations are wary, expressing concerns about enforcing driving under the influence laws and the need for more development of technology for testing marijuana impairment. They were successful in removing an earlier provision that would have allowed anyone to grow up to five marijuana plants at home for personal use.

The law now allows five plants to be maintained only by authorized patients under the state's medical marijuana law. Previously, they could not grow their own.

Ten other states and the District of Columbia have legalized smoking or eating marijuana for recreational use since 2012. Vermont and Michigan were the latest states to legalize marijuana in 2018. Vermont did so through the Legislature, but did not establish a statewide marketplace as Illinois did. Other initiatives have failed, with promising proposals in New York and New Jersey fizzling late this spring. Despite a statewide listening tour on the issue by Pennsylvania's lieutenant governor last winter, the idea never took flight.

Title: Nobel Prize in Literature Awarded to Controversial Austrian Writer Peter Handke

Article:

The Nobel Prize in Literature for 2019 was awarded to Austrian writer Peter Handke, a decision that has sparked controversy due to Handke's controversial views on the Bosnian War and the genocide committed by Serbs against Muslims in Bosnia.

The controversy revolves around Handke's political stance, which is best exemplified in a series of essays he wrote in 1996, collected in a short book titled "A Journey to the Rivers: Justice for Serbia." In these essays, Handke criticized the media for portraying the Serbs as evil and distanced himself from Serbian leader Slobodan Miloševic, who was later tried for genocide and war crimes.

Handke's views on the Bosnian War and the genocide committed in Bosnia have been criticized as a form of denial. In a concise article he wrote for the French newspaper Liberation after his 1996 essays appeared, Handke questioned the use of the term "concentration camps" in Bosnia, stating that there were also Croat and Muslim camps, and that the crimes committed by all sides would be judged at The Hague.

However, it is widely accepted that the Serb camps in Bosnia were concentration camps, and that the Muslims had nothing like those industrial-scale camps. The United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague sentenced Serbs to lengthy prison terms for the crimes committed there.

In his article for Liberation, Handke also equated the abominable massacre in Srebrenica, where several thousand Muslims were executed by Serb forces, with the massacres committed by Muslim troops. This has been criticized as a form of deception and deflection.

David Rieff, a journalist who has reported from Bosnia, assessed Handke's book as follows: "The truth is that he doesn't know what he's talking about... He came to Serbia knowing nothing about its complicated politics and, to judge by the book, left knowing no more."

The Nobel Prize in Literature is awarded annually to an author who has produced "in the field of literature the most outstanding work in an ideal direction" and is considered one of the most prestigious literary prizes in the world. The decision to award the prize to Handke has been met with criticism and controversy, with many arguing that the prize should not be used to legitimize controversial political views.

Title: Email from Former Clinton Administration Official Suggests Need for "Unaware and Compliant Citizenry"

Article:

A recently released email from the Wikileaks data dump, dated March 13, 2016, discusses the need for maintaining political power by producing an "unaware and compliant citizenry." The email was sent to Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta, by former Clinton administration official Bill Ivey.

Ivey, who served as Chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts during Bill Clinton's second term, is a trustee of the Center for American Progress, a think tank with ties to the Clinton campaign. In the email, Ivey expresses concern over the perceived inability of Hillary Clinton to match Donald Trump's celebrity appeal.

Ivey suggests that Trump's success in capturing media attention could not be replicated by Clinton, who is not an entertainer or celebrity in the Trump or Kardashian mold. He laments that Trump's larger-than-life appeal might not be countered by simply focusing on policy.

In the email, Ivey also acknowledges the left's role in "conspiring" to produce an unaware and compliant citizenry, but notes that this strategy is becoming less effective. He characterizes public "unawareness" as a positive for the Clinton campaign.

The email concludes with Ivey's admission that the left is struggling to navigate forces that cannot be fully understood, and his intention to attend a Clinton fundraiser.

The email, penned by Ivey, offers a glimpse into the perceived elitist and arrogant mindset within the Clinton campaign, with Americans viewed as easily manipulated and herded in a certain direction.

Paul Joseph Watson, editor-at-large of ███.com and Prison Planet.com, has commented on the email, stating that it reveals the elitist and arrogant mindset that pervades the Clinton campaign.

Title: Rep. Tom Cole Discusses Minimum Wage Increase, Accuses White House of Politicizing the Issue

Article:

Rep. Tom Cole (R-OK) has expressed opposition to an increase in the minimum wage but is open to considering proposals that include job creation measures such as the Keystone pipeline. In an interview on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" on Friday, Cole accused the White House of using the minimum wage issue as a "political weapon."

A proposal to raise the federal minimum wage from $7.25 an hour to $10.10 an hour was blocked by a filibuster in the U.S. Senate earlier this week.

Cole acknowledged that there is a case for raising the wage, but he also pointed out that there is opposition to the increase. He cited the Congressional Budget Office's estimate that raising the federal minimum wage to $10.10 an hour, phased in over three years, would reduce total employment by about 500,000 workers while substantially boosting wages for low-income workers. The report also noted that the uncertainty is substantial, and the job loss could range from "very slight" to as many as 1 million jobs.

Cole argued that the issue has been politicized and accused the White House of using it as a political tool. He suggested that if the president were serious about raising the minimum wage, he would propose other measures that would attract Republican support.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) has indicated a willingness to compromise on the wage issue but not on the $10.10 figure. White House press secretary Jay Carney said on Thursday that offering a different number would not likely be effective, as Republican leaders have not expressed support for a lower figure.

The information regarding the potential job loss and the political stance of the White House and Congressional leaders is based on the user-provided text. The opinions and interpretations expressed by Rep. Tom Cole and White House press secretary Jay Carney are included in the article. The article does not take a political side or express personal opinions.

Title: Sanders and Bloomberg: Two Contenders with Distinctive Political Histories Compete in Democratic Primary

Article:

Senator Bernie Sanders and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, two prominent figures in American politics, are currently engaged in a heated competition in the Democratic primary race. The two candidates, who represent distinct strands of liberalism, have been compared to comic book characters, with each embodying different ideological perspectives.

Senator Bernie Sanders, known for his progressive stance, has a history that dates back to the anti-war socialist and populist movements of the early 20th century, with roots in figures such as William Jennings Bryan and Eugene Debs. Sanders is also associated with reformers like Jane Addams. His supporters appreciate his consistent advocacy for democratic socialism and his opposition to economic elites, particularly the "billionaire class."

On the other hand, Michael Bloomberg, a billionaire businessman, represents a different kind of liberalism. He is often associated with a technocratic, data-driven approach to governance, having implemented policies in New York City that were met with controversy, such as restrictions on large-sized sodas and the controversial stop-and-frisk policy. Bloomberg's political leanings have evolved over time, from a lifelong Democrat to a Republican, and then an independent, before returning to the Democratic Party in his bid for the presidency.

The contest between Sanders and Bloomberg has raised questions about the future direction of the Democratic Party. If Sanders were to win the nomination, the party could potentially shift towards a more populist, social democratic orientation. Conversely, if Bloomberg were to win, the party could lean towards a more bureaucratic, authoritarian approach.

It is important to note that both Sanders and Bloomberg are beneficiaries of the hollowed-out political parties, which have been unable to effectively manage the nomination process. This has led to the rise of outsider candidates like Trump in the Republican Party and potentially Sanders or Bloomberg in the Democratic Party.

The stakes of their contest are high, as the outcome could significantly shape the identity of the Democratic Party. The choice between these two candidates is zero-sum, and the eventual winner could define the party as much as Donald Trump has defined the Republican Party. Other options for primary voters do exist, but the choice between Sanders and Bloomberg is a significant one that could determine the direction of the Democratic Party in the coming years.

Title: Danish Parliament Member Criticizes Potential U.S. Purchase of Greenland as a Commodity

Article:

Speculation surrounding the potential purchase of Greenland by the United States has sparked controversy, with some social media users making light of the situation through photoshopped images and humorous comments. However, at the center of the international incident, there is little humor to be found, according to politicians and residents of Greenland.

Aaja Chemnitz Larsen, a Greenlandic member of the Danish Parliament, stated, "It's never nice to be treated as a commodity." Greenland, a nation of 56,000, has a shared history with Denmark dating back a millennium. If the relationship were to change, it would not be up to Denmark, and certainly not up to an American president's "impulse," according to Henrik O. Breitenbauch, an expert on Greenland and the head of the Center for Military Studies at Copenhagen University.

The speculation suggests that the American president, a former real estate developer, may be interested in Greenland due to its natural resources and strategic location. Greenland offers a real estate investor fresh air, direct access to the sea, an abundance of seafood, and a backyard rich with lucrative minerals. The island's proximity to international sea routes allows for quick passage to various parts of the world (when the ice permits).

However, the island's population may not see much benefit from exchanging the Danish queen as their head of state with an American president who has strained relations with traditional allies by criticizing NATO and withdrawing from treaties like the Paris climate accord. Henrik O. Breitenbauch commented, "Greenland could choose to become Puerto Rico with snow, but I doubt there's much interest in that."

In conclusion, the potential purchase of Greenland by the United States has sparked controversy and criticism from Greenlandic politicians and residents, who view the situation as a dehumanizing commodification of their nation. The speculation suggests that the American president may be interested in Greenland for its strategic resources and location, but the long-term implications for Greenland's population and sovereignty remain uncertain.

Title: Speaker Ryan Defends Journalists, Sessions Announces Crackdown on Leakers

Article:

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan, also known as Paul Davis Ryan (R-Wis.), defended journalists on Friday, stating that while leaks can compromise national security, the issue lies with the leaker, not the journalist. Ryan's comment comes shortly after Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced a government-wide crackdown on leakers.

Sessions warned that the media could be part of the crackdown, and the Justice Department could request sources behind leaks. The investigation will include a review of the Justice Department's policies on subpoenas for media outlets that publish sensitive information.

"We respect the important role that the press plays and will give them respect, but it is not unlimited," Sessions said. "They can not place lives at risk with impunity." He added, "We must balance their role with protecting our national security and the lives of those who serve in our intelligence community, the armed forces, and all law-abiding Americans."

Sessions concluded, "I have this message for the intelligence community: The Department of Justice is open for business. And I have this warning for would-be leakers: Don’t do it."

Meanwhile, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, Mark Warner (D-Va.), suggested on Thursday that Congress should investigate the leak of transcripts of President Trump's phone calls with the leaders of Mexico and Australia. Both political parties have condemned the leaks.

Title: CDC Officials Receive $25 Million in Bonuses Since 2007 Amid Flat Funding and Ebola Outbreak

Article:

Top public health officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have received $25 million in bonuses since 2007, according to data compiled by American Transparency's OpenTheBooks.com. This comes as the agency's headcount increased by 23 percent during the same period, despite relatively flat funding.

From 2010 to 2013, all federal wages were frozen due to budgetary constraints, but CDC officials found ways to pay themselves through bonuses, overtime, within-grade increases, and promotion pay raises. Donald Shriber, the deputy director of policy and communication at the CDC's Center for Global Health, received the highest bonus in the six years analyzed—$62,895 in 2011.

Kathleen Dunlap, the deputy budget director at the CDC, was awarded an $8,000 bonus last year, the highest among her fellow employees. Ms. Dunlap did not respond to a request for comment.

The CDC's handling of the Ebola outbreak has been criticized, and the agency has been accused of using budgetary constraints as an excuse for its response. National Institutes of Health Director Francis Collins told The Huffington Post last week that the CDC had been working on an Ebola vaccine for more than a decade but was hampered by shrinking budgets.

The CDC's budget has remained relatively flat since President Obama took office. In fiscal year 2010, the budget request for CDC funding was $6.31 billion. In President Obama's latest budget request, funding is set at $5.39 billion, with additional contributions of $809 million expected from the Prevention and Public Health Fund—totalizing about $6.2 billion.

Despite stagnating funding, the CDC still handed out bonuses and added 1,888 positions from 2007 to 2013, data show. Employees at the CDC earn more than the federal average. According to figures kept by the Office of Personnel Management, the average salary for a full-time federal employee working on a permanent appointment was $79,030 as of September 2013, the most recent date for which the figure has been released. The average salary for a CDC employee was $95,015 last year, OpenTheBooks shows.

"Employees at the embattled CDC have been making millions in higher-than-average salaries and bonuses," said OpenTheBooks.com founder Adam Andrzejewski. "CDC executives 'gamed the system' to increase employee pay through bonuses during three years of the 'official federal wage freeze.' CDC officials should be focused on preventing diseases rather than pumping up their salaries."

It's too early to tell whether it was money well spent, Mr. Andrzejewski said. "The CDC's mission is to protect the health of the nation, but will these highly compensated executives be successful and earn their pay, not to mention bonuses?" he asked.

Excluding Atlanta, where the CDC is based, CDC employees at the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Maryland, received the largest federal payout of $304 million in total wages from 2007 to 2013, as well as about $640,000 in bonuses. CDC sites in Cincinnati; Chamblee, Georgia; Bruceton, Pennsylvania; and Morgantown, West Virginia, all had CDC staff earning more than $100 million from 2007 to 2013. They also collectively paid out $1.8 million in bonuses.

According to OpenTheBooks, 40 people have been on the CDC's payroll in Dallas since 2007. They have earned about $3 million, on par with the CDC's presence in Richmond, Virginia, or Sacramento, California, but significantly less than the agency's commitment to Fort Collins, Colorado ($64 million in payouts) or Anchorage, Alaska ($14 million in payouts).

Title: DoD Policies Regarding Transgender Service Members' Health Care and Deployability: A Review of RAND Study Findings

Article:

The RAND Corporation, a federally funded research and development center, has conducted a study on the health care needs of transgender individuals, with a specific focus on transgender service members in the United States military. The study, sponsored by the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, examines various aspects of transition-related treatments, costs, and their potential impact on force readiness and deployability.

The RAND report identifies the health care needs of the transgender population and transgender service members, outlines the costs associated with transition-related treatments, assesses the potential readiness implications of a policy change, and reviews the experiences of foreign militaries that permit transgender personnel to serve openly.

The study finds that, if transgender service members are allowed to serve openly, certain DoD policies would need to be changed to accommodate their health care needs. These changes may include:

1. Access to gender transition-related health care: The RAND report suggests that the DoD would need to provide a range of transition-related treatments, including hormone therapy, counseling, and surgeries, to ensure the health and well-being of transgender service members.

2. Coverage of transition-related treatments: The report examines the costs associated with these treatments and finds that the costs vary widely, depending on the specific treatment and the individual's health insurance plan. The report notes that the DoD would need to establish policies for covering these costs, ensuring equitable access to care for all service members.

3. Impact on force readiness and deployability: The study assesses the potential impact of transition-related health care needs on force readiness and deployability. The report finds that, with proper management, the impact on readiness and deployability would be minimal.

4. Experiences of foreign militaries: The RAND report reviews the experiences of foreign militaries that permit transgender personnel to serve openly, providing insights into the challenges and benefits of such policies.

It is important to note that the RAND report does not take a political stance on the issue of transgender service members in the military. The report's findings are based on objective research and analysis, and it is up to the DoD to consider these findings and make policy decisions accordingly.

The RAND Corporation is a nonprofit institution that aims to improve policy and decision-making through research and analysis. The report underwent rigorous peer review to ensure high standards for research quality and objectivity. The report is part of the RAND research report series, and permission is given for personal use only. Unauthorized posting of RAND PDFs to a non-RAND Web site is prohibited. The RAND Corporation's publications do not necessarily reflect the opinions of its research clients and sponsors.

Title: Former State Department Official Explains Obama Administration's Avoidance of "Radical Islamic Extremism" Label

Article:

A former State Department official, Richard Stengal, has provided an explanation for the Obama administration's reluctance to use the term "radical Islamic extremism" to describe radical Islamic extremism. In a New York Times op-ed, Stengal, who served as the former under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs, stated that the practical reason for this avoidance was not due to timidity or political correctness, but rather to maintain relationships with Islamic allies.

Stengal argued that the Obama administration needed the cooperation of countries like Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia to combat radical Islamic extremism. These allies believed that the term unfairly vilified an entire religion, and they did not consider the Islamic State to be Islamic, as its violent actions against Muslims proved.

Stengal also noted that ISIS as a military force is "on the ropes" in Iraq and Syria, suggesting that the previous administration's strategy is working. He urged the Trump administration to reassure these Arab allies that references to "radical Islam" and "Islamic extremism" are only directed at the small percentage of the world's Muslim population that has embraced violence.

Despite this, Stengal expressed apprehension about the new direction the Trump administration is taking, stating that it is not up to the U.S. to define what is Islamic and what is not. Instead, he argued that mainstream Muslims and independent clerics in Muslim countries should create a narrative that refutes the Islamic State's ideology and offers a more positive alternative, which may help in countering the group's recruiting efforts.

Title: President Trump Criticizes Puerto Rico's Infrastructure, Urges Congress to Decide on Aid Duration

Article:

President Donald Trump issued a series of tweets on Thursday, criticizing Puerto Rico's infrastructure and suggesting that federal aid may not be sustained indefinitely. The comments come a week after Trump visited the U.S. territory, which is still recovering from the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria, the strongest hurricane to hit Puerto Rico in nearly a century.

Trump's trip to Puerto Rico was met with criticism, including his comparison of the storm's death toll to that of Hurricane Katrina in 2005. He stated, "Sixteen people versus in the thousands," referring to the lower death toll in Puerto Rico.

The president has repeatedly called for more help from Puerto Rico on a local level and has had an intermittent feud with the San Juan mayor. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., responded to Trump's latest tweets, questioning, "Why do you continue to treat Puerto Ricans differently than other Americans when it comes to natural disasters?"

According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), there were over 10,000 federal officials on the ground on the island earlier this month. House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., plans to lead a small bipartisan group to visit Puerto Rico on Friday. The group includes the chairman and top Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, and they are expected to meet with local officials and emergency personnel.

The House is expected to vote this week on an emergency spending package that includes billions of dollars more in relief for Puerto Rico, Texas, and Florida in the wake of the hurricanes Maria, Harvey, and Irma this season. The president asked Congress this week for a $4.9 billion loan to help Puerto Rico pay its bills from the storm. The island faced more than $70 billion in debt prior to the storm and declared bankruptcy in May.

Title: Former Senator Rick Santorum Ponders 2016 Presidential Run, Discusses Policy Ideas and Party Strategy

Article:

Former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, has expressed reservations about another White House run but has not ruled it out. In an interview with The Associated Press, Santorum discussed his policy ideas, the state of the Republican Party, and his thoughts on the 2016 primary field.

Santorum, who is currently serving as CEO of EchoLight Studios, a movie studio focused on faith and family-themed films, cited his professional and personal commitments as reasons for not pursuing another presidential bid. His daughter's health remains a concern, and he is also involved in writing a book about his daughter, who has a genetic disorder.

In the interview, Santorum emphasized the need for the Republican Party to focus on policies that help working Americans and criticized the libertarian streak within the party. He argued that the GOP will struggle to win elections unless candidates offer solutions for working-class voters.

Santorum's book, "Blue Collar Conservatives: Recommitting to an America That Works," offers policy proposals on energy, education, the economy, and healthcare. The book is part policy paper, part campaign playbook, and part communications advice on connecting with working-class voters.

One of Santorum's key points is that the Republican Party should not focus solely on business leaders and "job creators" but should speak to employees. He argued that anxiety among working-class voters remains high, and Republicans have for too long talked to the top earners and not the workers.

Santorum also criticized the Republican Party for not painting a positive vision for America and for being overly negative in their messaging. He expressed concern that the party is heading toward "No-ville," which he described as a focus on being against things rather than offering a positive vision.

Santorum's book contains incendiary rhetoric that could potentially haunt him should he run again. For example, he writes that poor voters "took their lie about sex without consequences as gospel" and calls climate change a "hyped-up crisis."

Santorum's potential 2016 candidacy remains uncertain, and he has not yet indicated a timeline for deciding on a bid. A primary might feature the libertarian wing of the party, led in part by Senators Rand Paul of Kentucky and Ted Cruz of Texas. Santorum's family's support and his daughter's health will be key factors in his decision.

Title: U.S. Officials Adopt Dual Messaging Strategy in Iran Nuclear Talks

Article:

Washington, CNN - The Iran nuclear talks are progressing, but tough issues remain, and a deal may or may not be reached. This ambiguity is a deliberate strategy by the Obama administration to manage expectations and maintain pressure on Iran, according to experts.

U.S. officials are making bold public statements, such as Secretary of State John Kerry's assertion that the U.S. is prepared to leave Iran hanging at the negotiating table if necessary. This messaging is intended to signal to Tehran that it needs to make concessions or risk losing the sanctions relief it has pursued for years.

Sen. Chris Coons of Delaware, a key Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, interprets Kerry's words as a determination to send a message to Iran's Supreme Leader: "The deal that is on the table is the best deal you're going to get. You either need to accept it or we're going to walk away."

The dual messaging strategy also aims to reassure restive members of Congress, who fear that Iran is gaining the upper hand and sticking to its demands while the U.S. caves. By passing the July 9 date set by Congress and entering a 60-day congressional review period instead of the initial 30 days, the administration now has more time to address skepticism and rally votes.

The coalition of five world powers negotiating alongside the U.S. is already showing signs of strain, with Russia adopting a stance on relaxing sanctions more in line with Iran's. The new Iranian demand that the arms embargo on it be lifted has caused frustration for the U.S. while winning support from Moscow.

On Thursday, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov indicated that his country was backing Iran's bid to lift the arms embargo "as soon as possible." Russia is a top supplier of weapons to Iran.

Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey stated this week on Capitol Hill that "under no circumstances should we relieve pressure on Iran relative to ballistic missile capabilities and arms trafficking."

The talks are extended yet again, and the U.S. needs to keep not just Iran, but its partners, in the negotiations pressing full steam ahead at the negotiating table. The Obama administration's dual messaging strategy is a calculated attempt to influence Iranian decision-making from the outside and manage expectations both at home and abroad.

Title: David Hogg Outlines Political Ambitions, Criticizes Older Democrats in New York Magazine Profile

Article:

Parkland shooting survivor and gun-control activist David Hogg has outlined his political ambitions in a new profile piece by New York Magazine. The article, titled "The New David Hogg," delves into Hogg's plans to work on a 2020 presidential candidate's campaign and potentially run for Congress in the future.

In the interview published Sunday, Hogg criticized older Democrats for not relinquishing control to younger generations. "The reason Republicans are successful right now is because they're empowering young people," Hogg told writer Lisa Miller. "Older Democrats just won't move the f--- off the plate and let us take control. Nancy Pelosi is old."

Hogg noted that U.S. House Speaker Paul D. Ryan was 45-years-old when he took up the leadership role. Hogg, who is 18, stated that if he could design his future without obstacles, he would go to college in the fall of 2019, read a "sh--load of books," and take some time off in 2020 to work on a presidential campaign.

Hogg added that he believes Democratic Socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez will eventually run for the White House successfully. While he expressed admiration for Ocasio-Cortez, Hogg expressed dissatisfaction with the current state of the Democratic Party. "Sen. Bernie Sanders is a great guy, terrible on guns," Hogg said. "Former President Obama increased drone warfare and killed a lot of civilians.... Honestly, they all kind of suck."

The article also mentions that Hogg and his friends in the March for Our Lives organization plan to spend the next several months meeting more activists and canvasing in advance of the midterm elections. Hogg's seven-year plan includes college in the fall of 2019 and a potential congressional run after college.

Title: Hurricane Florence Threatens US East Coast, Evacuation Orders in Place as Storm Approaches

Article:
