Hurricane Florence, now a category three storm with maximum sustained winds of 120mph (195km/h), is heading towards the US East Coast, prompting evacuation orders for up to 1.7 million residents across South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. The National Weather Service has warned that the storm is "extremely dangerous."

The storm is expected to make landfall as early as Thursday evening. Four South Carolina motorways have been diverted one-way to expedite the evacuation process. Georgia, following the Carolinas, Virginia, Maryland, and Washington DC, has declared a state of emergency.

A National Weather Service forecaster described Florence as "the storm of a lifetime for portions of the Carolina coast." The storm could bring 20-40 inches (50-100cm) of rain and life-threatening storm surges of up to 13 feet (4 meters). As of Wednesday evening, officials say these surges are now "highly likely" as Florence approaches.

The National Weather Service also predicts "catastrophic flash flooding and prolonged significant river flooding" in parts of the Carolinas and Appalachians. Hurricane force winds will extend up to 70 miles from the storm's center, according to meteorologists.

North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper warned that "disaster is at the doorstep" and "tens of thousands" of buildings may be flooded. Waves 83 feet (25 meters) tall were recorded at sea on Wednesday morning.

While many coastal residents have complied with mandatory evacuation orders, others are choosing to stay and board up their homes. CoreLogic, an analytics firm, estimates that Florence could cause over $170 billion (£130 billion) of damage and affect nearly 759,000 homes and businesses.

In 1999, Hurricane Floyd left hundreds of thousands of dead hogs and chickens floating in floodwaters in North Carolina. North Carolina farms are currently moving livestock to safety.

Approximately 1,000 prisoners in South Carolina will not be moved from their cells, despite a mandatory evacuation order in the area. A state department of corrections spokesman stated, "In the past, it's been safer to leave them there."

There are concerns for wild horse herds in North Carolina's Outer Banks, but experts say these equines can sense bad weather coming and head to higher ground.

US President Donald Trump warned residents in Florence's path to heed official warnings, stating, "Get out of its way, don't play games with it." European astronaut Alexander Gerst shared images of Florence's eye wall from space, calling the storm a "no-kidding nightmare."

The relationship between climate change and hurricanes is complex, with warmer seas powering hurricanes and a hotter atmosphere allowing hurricanes to dump more water on affected areas. However, it has been difficult to tease out clear trends from the data due to the many factors contributing to these rare events.

For more information, contact the BBC at the following numbers or through the provided contact methods.

Title: Clinton Taps into Black Voter Anger over Supreme Court Vacancy

Article:

In the wake of the death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, Democratic state representative Stacey Abrams, the House minority leader of Georgia, stated that the upcoming presidential election on November 8th has become more than a mere "thought exercise." Abrams' comments suggest that the vacancy on the Supreme Court could be a crucial issue for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, who is relying on nonwhite voters to secure her victory against Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

Clinton moved quickly on Tuesday to address the anger of black voters over the opposition of Senate Republicans to President Barack Obama's nomination of a replacement for Justice Scalia. In remarks before a predominantly black audience in Harlem, Clinton criticized the Republican senators' stance, stating, "Now the Republicans say they'll reject anyone President Obama nominates no matter how qualified. Some are even saying he doesn't have the right to nominate anyone!"

Clinton added that this behavior is in keeping with a longstanding pattern of mistreatment. She also accused Republicans of demonizing President Obama and encouraging "the ugliest impulses of the paranoid fringe."

Republicans have been sensitive about the notion that they are diminishing President Obama because of his race, and several Republican senators, including Mitch McConnell and Tim Scott of South Carolina, declined to comment or were unavailable for comment when approached by the media.

The suggestion that racism is playing a role in the Senate's handling of the Supreme Court vacancy has angered McConnell's supporters, who point out his formative political experience working for a Republican senator who supported civil rights, his role in overriding President Ronald Reagan's veto of sanctions against the apartheid government in South Africa, and his marriage to an Asian-American woman.

Title: U.S. Courts Deliver Opposing Rulings on ACA Subsidies

Article:

Two U.S. appeals courts have delivered conflicting rulings on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) subsidies, with one court striking down subsidies in states that did not establish their own insurance exchanges, and the other upholding subsidies for both state and federal exchanges.

In a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, a three-judge panel ruled that subsidies are not available for the 36 states that did not set up their own insurance exchanges. The Obama administration has announced its intention to seek a review by the full 11-judge panel, stating that the decision is inconsistent with Congressional intent and at odds with the law's goal of making healthcare affordable for all.

The ruling has the potential to affect nearly 5 million Americans who signed up for Obamacare through federal exchanges. Losing the subsidies could make health plans sold through the exchange unaffordable for many, potentially leaving millions of U.S. residents uninsured.

In a separate case heard by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, a three-judge panel ruled unanimously that the ambiguity in the ACA's language allows for subsidies to be given to both those who signed up using state exchanges and those who used federal exchanges on behalf of states.

The dispute over ACA subsidies may ultimately be decided by the Supreme Court.

Title: Trump's Claim of Total Authority Unconstitutional, Experts Warn

Article:

The United States is currently grappling with two critical emergencies: the coronavirus pandemic and the presidency of Donald Trump. This article will focus on the latter, examining the president's handling of the pandemic response and his assertion of unlimited authority.

During a recent news briefing, President Trump claimed, "When someone is president of the United States, the authority is total. And that's the way it's got to be." This statement, made on Twitter by the political podcast "Pod Save America," has sparked controversy and concern among experts, who argue that the president's claim is untrue and unconstitutional.

The Constitution divides federal authority between the three branches of government, and the 10th Amendment explicitly delegates power to the states. The system is designed so that no person or branch has "total authority." Trump's assertion, if enacted, would undermine the balance of power established by the Constitution.

Trump's performance during the pandemic has been criticized for his slow response and prioritization of his own image over public health. Reports have shown that Trump was slow to take action on the virus, and early discussions were diverted to talk of vaping and accusations towards advisers who warned of the potential need for shutdowns.

The most troubling part of Trump's Monday performance came when he suggested ordering state governors to ease shelter-at-home rules and re-open their economies. Experts fear that lifting the lockdowns too quickly could lead to a new wave of coronavirus illnesses and deaths.

In the absence of federal leadership, the nation's governors are devising their own workarounds. Governors from several states, including California, New York, and Massachusetts, are forming partnerships to plan how to re-open their economies.

In short, the federal government under President Trump is currently unable to perform the tasks expected of it during a national emergency. The president wants all the power, all the credit, and none of the responsibility. The result is a terrifying mix of authoritarianism and fecklessness that threatens American democracy and public health.

Voters should remember not just that Trump mismanaged this deadly pandemic, but that his own behavior constituted a crisis in its own right. The November election will be an opportunity for the American people to decide the direction they want their country to take.

Title: Open Carry Advocates and Public Safety Concerns

Article:

In recent times, the practice of open carry, the act of openly displaying firearms in public, has become a contentious issue in the United States. This article explores the implications of open carry in public places, focusing on instances where open carry enthusiasts have caused apprehension and discomfort among civilians and employees.

In Georgia, following a new law that allows the open carrying of deadly weapons at all times and in all places, an armed man entered a park where children were playing little league baseball, waving his gun and shouting. The police, upon arrival, found no violation of the law, causing concern among the parents.

Similarly, after the Sandy Hook elementary school massacre, open carry advocates staged demonstrations at Starbucks stores across the country, including in Newtown, Connecticut. No incidents were reported, but the CEO of Starbucks politely requested that these demonstrations not take place in his stores due to employee safety concerns.

Recently, open carry proponents staged a demonstration at a Jack in the Box, causing such fear among employees that they sought refuge in the walk-in freezer. The police, assuming an armed robbery was in progress, responded in force.

One open carry advocate, Haros, defended the demonstrations, stating, "We’re not breaking the laws, we’re not here to hurt anybody. We’re not trying to alarm anybody. We’re doing this because it’s our constitutional right." Haros believes that open carry helps police, as they cannot be present at all times.

The article questions the actions of these open carry advocates, suggesting that they are, in essence, acting as self-appointed vigilantes. It argues that while these individuals claim to be exercising their constitutional rights, they are often causing discomfort and fear among the general public, particularly in situations where children are present.

The article concludes by stating that, in the presence of open carry enthusiasts, the general public may not truly have any rights, as they are often forced to remain polite and avoid confrontation with armed individuals. The article questions the definition of freedom in such situations, suggesting that while open carry advocates may feel free to carry their weapons, the rest of the public may not feel the same level of freedom due to the potential for danger and discomfort.

Title: Romney's Overseas Trip: A Mixed Bag of Successes and Controversies

Article:

Mitt Romney's overseas trip, aimed at showcasing his foreign policy expertise during the election year, has been marked by both substantive highlights and distractions, according to Romney and his top campaign advisers. The Republican candidate's final leg in Poland concluded on Tuesday, with Romney's advisers expressing confidence in the trip's success.

In a speech at Poland's national library, Romney offered an emotional tribute to the country's journey from the Iron Curtain to the economic envy of Europe. He emphasized the path of freedom trodden by the people of Poland, stating, "I, and my fellow Americans, are inspired by the path of freedom tread by the people of Poland."

However, the trip was not without controversy. In Britain, Romney's comments questioning the readiness of London to host the Summer Olympic Games drew criticism, with British Prime Minister David Cameron responding with a not-so-subtle dig at Romney's Games in Salt Lake City. In Israel, Romney's remarks on Jerusalem as the undisputed capital of Israel and his comments on the economic disparity between Israelis and Palestinians inflamed already raw feelings in the region.

During the trip, Romney's campaign was also embroiled in a heated exchange with the traveling press. In an incident at the Polish Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, Romney's press secretary, Rick Gorka, was reported to have shouted at reporters, "Kiss my ass. This is a holy site." Gorka later apologized for his remarks.

Romney's advisers, including senior adviser Stuart Stevens, have maintained a positive outlook on the trip, with Stevens stating, "I think it was a great success." Stevens added, "The idea is that, can people get a good sense of who he is? Can people listen and see that this is a person speaking from the heart about Israel and about Poland? And he is."

Conservative bloggers have also defended Romney, with Powerline blog writer John Hinderaker stating, "By any reasonable standard, Romney's trip has been successful. Yet press coverage has been unrelentingly negative." However, Fox News Channel anchor Greta Van Susteren expressed a different perspective, stating, "There has been no press access to Governor Romney since we landed in Poland. We (press) are in a holding pattern."

Upon returning to the United States, Romney will be greeted by a slew of new ads from his campaign and supporting super PACs, as well as a new mobile app called "Mitt's VP" about his vice presidential selection process.

Title: President Trump Calls for Tougher Travel Ban, Criticizes Terrorism Following London Attack

Article:

President Donald Trump called for a "larger, tougher" travel ban early Friday in response to the attack at a London subway station, which sent at least 22 people to hospitals. The incident, declared a "terrorist incident" by London's Metropolitan Police, was caused by the detonation of an improvised explosive device.

In a series of tweets, Trump described the perpetrator as a "loser terrorist" and emphasized the need for a more aggressive approach to combat terrorism. He stated, "Loser terrorists must be dealt with in a much tougher manner. The internet is their main recruitment tool which we must cut off & use better!"

The president's tweets followed a fire at a London subway station on Friday. The White House later confirmed that Trump spoke with British Prime Minister Theresa May to express his sympathies and prayers for those affected. The statement from the White House indicated that Trump pledged to continue close collaboration with the United Kingdom to combat terrorism and extremism worldwide.

Trump reiterated his stance on political correctness in a series of early morning tweets, advocating for his travel ban and criticizing the Obama Administration's efforts against ISIS. He tweeted, "The travel ban into the United States should be far larger, tougher and more specific-but stupidly, that would not be politically correct!"

In June, Trump expressed concern over the terror threat in London following an attack on the London Bridge, which resulted in seven deaths and numerous injuries. British Prime Minister May responded to Friday's attack, stating, "My thoughts are with those injured at Parsons Green and emergency services who are responding bravely to this incident."

Former chief of staff to May, Nick Timothy, criticized Trump's "loser terrorist" tweets as "unhelpful." Timothy tweeted, "True or not—and I’m sure he doesn’t know—this is so unhelpful from leader of our ally and intelligence partner."

Title: New Jersey Allows Illegal Immigrants to Obtain Driver's Licenses, Becoming 14th State to Enact Such Measure

Article:

New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy signed a bill on Thursday, allowing illegal immigrants to obtain driver's licenses. This move makes New Jersey the 14th state, along with the District of Columbia, to enact such a measure.

Governor Murphy stated, "Expanding access to driver's licenses is critical for the safety of New Jerseyans and a step toward building a stronger and fairer New Jersey for all."

The bill was approved by the Democratic majorities in both the state Assembly and Senate during their final legislative sessions of the year. Assembly Speaker Craig Coughlin, a Democrat, told The Wall Street Journal, "The legislation advanced on the Assembly floor and by the Senate today is fair and responsible. It brings us one step closer to ensuring all motor vehicles and drivers are insured, thereby creating safer roadways for all New Jersey residents."

The legislation allows individuals over the age of 16 who are illegal immigrants to obtain driver's licenses and learner's permits. Applicants can use foreign documents such as passports or their old driver's license from their home country to complete the process. A Social Security number is not required, according to The Associated Press.

The law reportedly establishes two types of licenses. One would conform to federal REAL ID requirements and would require proof of legal residency. The second license would only require six points of identification. The applicant would not have to provide proof of U.S. citizenship.

A similar measure known as "The Green Light Law" was signed by New York's Democratic Governor Andrew Cuomo earlier this year and went into effect this week. It also allows illegal immigrants to obtain a license without having to provide a Social Security number or proof of American citizenship.

This report includes contributions from Danielle Wallace of Fox News and The Associated Press.

Title: New York Times' Publication of Senator Cotton's Op-Ed Sparks Controversy

Article:

The publication of Senator Tom Cotton's Op-Ed in The New York Times has sparked controversy, with critics questioning the paper's editorial standards and the motives behind its decision to publish the piece. The editors' note stated that the senator's Op-Ed did not meet the Times' editorial standards.

One criticism is that the paper could have examined Cotton's views without giving him an unmediated platform. Some argue that his proposal should have been evaluated by the news department, not published uncritically in the Opinion pages. Another point of contention is that his arguments went beyond the moral pale.

However, the value of Cotton's Op-Ed does not lie in its goodness or rightness. Instead, it lies in the fact that Cotton is a leading spokesman for a significant current of public opinion. To suggest that readers should not have the opportunity to examine his opinions for themselves is to patronize them, according to the newspaper.

The most serious criticism is that the publication of the piece puts black lives at risk, including members of the Times' staff. This is a crucial consideration, especially in the current climate, and one about which no responsible publisher can be indifferent. However, it is not the duty of the paper to make people feel safe by refusing to publish a dismaying Op-Ed. Even if one concedes that Cotton's call to send in the troops poses potential risks, it poses those risks whether his call appears in these pages or not.

Knowledge, however unpleasant, is always a source of strength, a belief that lies at the core of our profession. The same goes for any other type of knowledge: having more of it is always a source of strength.

Title: US Imposes New Sanctions on Russia Over Novichok Poisoning Incident

Article:

The Russian rouble has plummeted to its lowest level since November 2016, following the United States' announcement of new sanctions in response to the poisoning of a former Russian spy and his daughter in the UK using the nerve agent Novichok. The dollar-rouble rate reached 66.7 on the Moscow stock exchange, marking a significant drop from Tuesday's rate of 63.4.

The attack occurred in Salisbury in March, where Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia were poisoned. Both have since recovered and their current whereabouts are being kept secret. The UK has blamed Russia for the attack, and the UK Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, thanked the US on Thursday for imposing these sanctions.

The new sanctions, which will take effect on or around August 22, cover exports of sensitive electronic components and other technologies that can have military applications. There will also be some further restrictions on Russian access to US financial services. If Russia fails to provide reliable assurances that it will no longer use chemical weapons and allow on-site inspections by the United Nations, more draconian sanctions, including a far-reaching trade embargo on Russia and a ban on Aeroflot flights to the US, may be imposed within 90 days.

The US and EU have previously imposed sanctions on dozens of Russian state officials and firms accused of involvement in the 2014 Russian annexation of Crimea and support for separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine. These sanctions restrict travel and financial transactions.

The Russian embassy in the US has responded to the new sanctions, stating that it has become "accustomed to not hearing any facts or evidence" and that it continues to strongly stand for an open and transparent investigation of the crime committed in Salisbury. The US determination that Russia used chemical or biological weapons against its own nationals is only the third time such a decision has been made, with previous occasions being against Syria and North Korea for the assassination of Kim Jong-nam, the half brother of leader Kim Jong-un.

President Donald Trump has yet to comment on this latest move, which could potentially complicate his efforts to develop a new, warmer relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The US and the UK have both stated that relations between Russia and the West have reached a new low following the incident.

Title: Coronavirus Ravages U.S. Prisons and Jails: A Growing Public Health Crisis

Article:

The New York Times has reported on the devastating impact of the coronavirus in federal and state prisons across the United States. The Federal Correctional Complex in Oakdale, Louisiana, has become a hotspot for the virus, with seven inmates having died and over 100 inmates and staff members infected.

In Cook County Jail, the largest in the country, four inmates have died, and 215 have tested positive. Over 190 correctional officers and 34 other sheriff's office employees have also tested positive. The situation in Ohio prisons is equally dire, with 2,300 prisoners in three prisons testing positive.

Prisons and jails, due to their overpopulation and the impossibility of social distancing, are becoming breeding grounds for the virus. Inmates, many of whom have pre-existing health conditions, are particularly vulnerable. Correctional officers, their families, and the communities where they live are also at risk.

In response, some facilities have taken measures such as reducing their population, providing soap and disinfectants, isolating those with symptoms, and increasing cleaning frequencies. However, testing remains inadequate, putting both prisoners and corrections officers at risk.

Prison uprisings have begun as inmates demand protection and more information. Corrections officers have joined in lawsuits to secure adequate protective equipment, information, and testing.

To address this growing crisis, it is crucial for prison officials to speed the release of nonviolent offenders, the elderly, and the vulnerable. Universal testing is an imperative. Prisoners need more access to soap and water, and both prisoners and corrections officials need protective gear and information on how to protect themselves.

The U.S. incarcerates more people than any other country, including China. Prisoners are disproportionately poor and people of color, often victims of institutionalized racism. The pandemic is turning incarceration into a potential death sentence, further exposing the moral outrage of the U.S. prison system.

Title: Rep. John Conyers Settles Sexual Harassment Complaint, Acknowledges Payment to Former Staffer

Article:

In a reversal of his earlier denial, Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.), the longest-serving House member, admitted Tuesday that he settled a sexual harassment complaint with a former staffer who reportedly claimed she was fired for rejecting his advances.

Initially, Conyers told the Associated Press on Tuesday that he had not settled any such harassment complaints. The AP also reported that Conyers, when confronted at his Detroit home, said he knew nothing about claims of inappropriate touching, all of which were made in an extensive BuzzFeed article.

Conyers' office issued a detailed clarification Tuesday afternoon, acknowledging the complaint was real, though the lawmaker adamantly denied the underlying claims.

"The Associated Press made an unannounced visit to the home of Congressman Conyers this morning," a spokesperson for Conyers said Tuesday. "Congressman Conyers was under the impression the reporter was speaking of recent allegations of which he was unaware of and denied."

Conyers said he has been a "fierce advocate for equality in the workplace" and supports the rights of his employees, but noted that it was "important to recognize that the mere making of an allegation does not mean it is true."

"In this case, I expressly and vehemently denied the allegations made against me and continue to do so," Conyers said, adding that his office resolved the allegations. "That should not be lost in the narrative. The resolution was not for millions of dollars, but rather for an amount that equated to a reasonable severance payment."

Conyers added that he would "fully cooperate with an investigation," once the House determines the "extent" they will look at "these issues."

The allegations against Conyers amounted to yet another bombshell rocking Capitol Hill. In documents obtained by BuzzFeed News, several former staff members reportedly accused Conyers of requesting sexual favors, rubbing their hands sexually, and rubbing their legs and backs.

The woman who complained about her firing reportedly claimed she was dismissed because she did not "succumb to [his] sexual advances." She reportedly believed she had no other option than to remain quiet and take the settlement in 2015.

Her identity remains anonymous reportedly due to fears of retribution. Conyers, 88, has served in the House for decades. He was active in the civil-rights movement and helped found the Congressional Black Caucus; he's now the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) called the report "extremely troubling" in a statement released Tuesday. He noted he already had directed "the Committee on House Administration to conduct a full review of all policies and procedures related to workplace harassment and discrimination."

According to BuzzFeed News, the Congressional Office of Compliance did not confirm or deny dealing with the case.

"Pursuant to the Congressional Accountability Act, the OOC can not comment on whether matters have or have not been filed with the office," Laura Cech, publications and outreach manager at the Office of Compliance, told BuzzFeed.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) said she was not aware of the reported settlement involving Conyers.

"No," Pelosi told Fox News in a statement. "The current process includes the signing of non-disclosure agreements by the parties involved."

Pelosi pointed to new legislation put forth by Democratic Rep. Jackie Speier which the Democratic leader said would provide "much-needed transparency on these agreements" and make "other critical reforms."

The report said the woman who settled with Conyers ended up with a confidentiality agreement in exchange for a roughly $27,000 settlement—which reportedly came from Conyers' office budget as opposed to a massive fund that has been used to settle hundreds of cases with federal employees.

Chairman of the Michigan Democratic Party Brandon Dillon said in a statement Tuesday that the allegations against Conyers are "incredibly serious and disheartening to learn," but also said that media reports of the case also "point to other troubling allegations of misconduct, including the potential misuse of congressional resources."

"That is why we are calling for a full investigation by the House Ethics Committee into all of the allegations against Mr. Conyers, and we urge the Speaker to order a full-scale inquiry into the abuse of authority that has pervaded the halls of power in Washington, along with state capitols across the country, for far too long," Dillon said.

The revelations about Conyers’ alleged conduct are just the latest in a series of allegations shaking the halls of Capitol Hill in recent days. Last week, a TV and Radio broadcast host based in California, LeeAnn Tweeden, accused Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.) of groping and kissing her without her consent. On Monday, a second woman, Lindsay Menz, accused Franken of groping her in 2010 while they took a photo together.

And Senate Republican candidate Roy Moore in Alabama is battling multiple allegations. The woman whose account started the controversy spoke Monday to NBC's "Today" show, and said she was "absolutely not" paid to go public. Leigh Corfman claims Moore had sexual contact with her when she was 14 and he was in his 30's. Moore has denied the allegations against him.

Title: U.S. Senator John McCain Diagnosed with Glioblastoma, Reviewing Treatment Options

Article:

Veteran U.S. Senator John McCain has been diagnosed with glioblastoma, a particularly aggressive brain tumor, and is reviewing treatment options, according to his office. The 80-year-old politician is recovering at home and is reported to be in "good spirits."

The senator underwent surgery at a clinic in Phoenix, Arizona, last Friday to remove a blood clot from above his left eye. Tissue analysis revealed that the clot was associated with a primary brain tumor known as glioblastoma. A statement from the Mayo Clinic said, "The senator's doctors say he is recovering from his surgery 'amazingly well' and his underlying health is excellent."

Treatment options may include a combination of chemotherapy and radiation, according to the statement. Senior Republicans and Democrats have wished him a speedy recovery, prompting McCain to tweet his thanks and a warning: "I greatly appreciate the outpouring of support - unfortunately for my sparring partners in Congress, I'll be back soon, so stand-by!"

John McCain is known in Washington as a tough, independent-minded senator. He earned his reputation as a prisoner of war in Vietnam, where he was held for more than five years, including two in solitary confinement. During the most recent presidential election campaign, Donald Trump belittled the senator as "not a war hero," saying "I like people who weren't captured."

McCain may have annoyed many Republicans by arguing for reforms to campaign finance and immigration laws. He may have irritated opponents of America's many wars with his forceful arguments in favor of the projection of US military might.

Glioblastoma is a tumor that affects more men than women and increases in frequency with age. McCain, who is the chairman of the Senate Committee on Armed Services, is reported to be in "good spirits as he continues to recover at home with his family." His family reacted with "shock" to the news, his 32-year-old daughter Meghan said.

President Donald Trump said McCain had "always been a fighter" and, in a statement, said: "Get well soon." Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said McCain was a "hero to our country." "He has never shied from a fight, and I know that he will face this challenge with the same extraordinary courage that has characterized his life," he said on Twitter. Former President Barack Obama tweeted: "John McCain is an American hero and one of the bravest fighters I've ever known. Cancer does not know what it's up against. Give it hell, John."

Title: Army Warns of Potential Impact of Sequestration on Ground Forces

Article:

The United States Army has issued an internal memo urging active and retired generals to advocate against potential future automatic budget cuts, known as sequestration, as they could significantly impact the Army's ground forces. According to the memo, written by Maj. Gen. Laura Richardson, the Army may become "hollow" if relief from sequestration is not granted.

The budget caps, or sequestration, are currently suspended under a bipartisan budget deal but could resume in fiscal 2016, beginning on October 1, unless an agreement is reached. General Raymond T. Odierno, the Army Chief of Staff and former top commander in Iraq, is reportedly one of the military leaders most vocal about the potential consequences of another round of sequestration.

The active-duty soldier force peaked at 570,000 during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars and is scheduled to shrink to approximately 450,000. However, sequestration poses a threat to further reduce the active force to 420,000, according to General Odierno. He asserts that the 450,000 level is the absolute minimum the active force can be while still fulfilling its strategic responsibilities.

Maj. Gen. Richardson, the Chief of Army Legislative Affairs, wrote in the memo that caps on defense spending are having a detrimental effect on the Army, damaging readiness, reducing manpower, and cutting modernization programs. The memo, obtained by The ███, states that General Odierno wants all Army general officers to be aware of the impacts of sequestration so they are prepared to discuss the matter with members of Congress and their staff during their engagements.

Recent deployments demonstrate a busy U.S. Army, with forces sent to Europe for war games as a warning to Russian President Vladimir Putin, a headquarters element deployed to Baghdad to advise the Iraqi Security Forces, soldiers inserted into West Africa to help combat the spread of the Ebola virus, and ground units maintained in Afghanistan.

General Odierno recently told a group of defense reporters that the Army may need to operate with smaller capabilities on four different continents simultaneously due to the evolving nature of the world. In an interview, he stated that further budget cuts would take the Army to a "breaking point." He added that he would have to further reduce purchases of weapons systems needed to modernize a war-weary force.

"As I look at that," he said, "it's end strength, it's modernization, it's readiness. I can't go any faster on end strength, so that means you have to take further reductions in readiness and modernization."

Title: Gun-Violence Prevention Organizations Launch Voting Rights Campaign

Article:

The gun-violence prevention organizations March For Our Lives, Brady, and Team Enough have launched a joint campaign on Wednesday, focusing on voting rights in an effort to highlight the link between gun violence prevention and democracy. The groups are releasing a report titled "Accessing Democracy: A Gun Violence Issue," which focuses on four categories: voting by mail and absentee voting, voter registration, early voting, and restoration of voting rights.

The report, "Accessing Democracy," emphasizes the historical marginalization of communities that bear the brunt of gun violence in the democratic process. The report reads, "These communities have been deprived of the avenues of direct democracy most necessary for citizens to have agency in their own future -- their right to vote."

The campaign will distribute the report and tool kits to hundreds of March For Our Lives, Brady, and Team Enough chapters, as well as the groups' network of other gun-violence prevention organizations. The tool kits will provide information on polling locations, voter registration, vote-by-mail and absentee voting laws, early voting options, and the status of voting rights for citizens with misdemeanor or felony records.

The tool kits also offer "action plans" for the states, providing citizens with contact information for their representatives and suggesting actions such as mailing ballots to eligible voters, extending in-person early voting, repealing voter ID laws, and supplying personal protective equipment to poll workers.

The campaign, titled Voting Access Saves Lives, comes amid protests and calls for racial justice following the death of George Floyd, a Black man who died in Minnesota after an officer knelt on his neck. The groups emphasize that while gun violence disproportionately affects Black communities, voting rights are often suppressed within those communities as well.

The coalition believes there is a discrepancy between what Americans want and what they get when it comes to policy, in part because of a flawed electoral system and voter suppression. For example, a majority of people support background checks for private gun sales and sales at gun shows, according to the Pew Research Center. However, a bill that would require background checks for all firearms sales, which passed in the House last year, has stalled in the Senate.

The Voting Access Saves Lives coalition says it is committed to ensuring that communities are able to vote for elected officials who represent them and their beliefs in free and fair elections. "The reality for our cause is that unless we ensure that we truly have free and fair elections, much of the work that we're trying to do will remain stalled in certain places," said Kris Brown, President of Brady.

Through calling for the restoration of voting rights, the coalition aims to make sure all citizens can participate in the electoral process. Maxwell Frost, national organizing director for March For Our Lives, expressed his excitement about the campaign, stating, "I'm really excited about this campaign personally because it's specific actions that are going to be helping different communities, you know, specifically the Black community, which is obviously the centerpiece of a national and international movement right now."

Frost noted that former felons are among those who historically have had their voting rights suppressed. His own experience with the issue came while he was in Florida working for the American Civil Liberties Union during the campaign for a constitutional amendment that would restore voting rights for most previously convicted felons. The amendment passed in November 2018. Before then, more than 1 in 5 Black adults in the state could not vote.

Title: NHTSA Vehicle Safety Ratings Show Increasing Trend Toward Higher Safety Scores

Article:

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has been providing safety ratings for new vehicles since 1978, evaluating crash protection and rollover safety. The agency awards up to five stars to vehicles based on various safety measures. High ratings can serve as a significant government seal of approval for automakers.

An analysis by The Times, using data from car-shopping and research site Edmunds.com, shows that almost every model has received high marks. From 2001 to 2010, 87% of all safety ratings awarded through the program were four or five stars.

John O' Dell, a senior editor and vehicle safety expert at Edmunds.com, stated that automakers have become adept at meeting NHTSA's requirements over the years, designing their cars to perform well in the ratings. For instance, the agency tests a vehicle's ability to withstand a rollover accident, an area that automakers have focused on improving.

In 2011, the agency introduced new standards to make it more challenging to score high and added an overall safety rating. "The program raised the safety bar by implementing more stringent crash tests, making it harder for vehicles to achieve the top ratings of five stars," the agency noted in a request for increased funding for the ratings program.

However, the ratings have continued to improve since then, according to The Times' analysis. From 2011 to the present, 92% of the overall safety ratings were four or five-star ratings. The percentage of four and five-star overall ratings increased each year, from 83% for 2011 models to 96% for 2015 models.

Jack Gillis, a former NHTSA official involved in early efforts to develop a ratings program at the agency and now a publisher of an independent rating, expressed a different view. He stated, "The government would have the opportunity to dramatically stimulate competition if they were to present this information on a more relative basis."

Title: President Obama Addresses National Security Agency Surveillance Concerns

Article:

In a candid interview with CNN's Chris Cuomo on Friday, President Barack Obama acknowledged concerns over the National Security Agency (NSA) surveillance programs, stating that the rapid advancement of technology could potentially outpace the legal protections in place.

"There are legitimate concerns that technology is moving so quickly that, at some point, does the technology outpace the laws that are in place and the protections that are in place?" Mr. Obama questioned. He further added, "Do some of these [surveillance] systems end up being like a loaded gun out there that somebody at some future point could abuse?"

During the two-day bus tour through upstate New York and Pennsylvania, the president also conceded that the American public remains skeptical of the government's assurances that it is not monitoring citizens' phone calls and emails. This skepticism has been fueled by recent disclosures that the NSA looked at as many as 56,000 communications of Americans over a three-year period, despite no connection to terrorism.

"This can only work if the American people trust what's going on," Mr. Obama said. "People don't have enough information and aren't confident enough that between all of the safeguards and checks we put in place in the executive branch, and the federal court oversight, and the congressional oversight, people are still concerned that their emails are being read..."

The president expressed confidence that the NSA surveillance programs are not being abused at the current moment. The NSA programs were first revealed by Edward Snowden, a former federal contractor who was granted asylum in Russia and is charged by the Justice Department with espionage and other offenses. Snowden is viewed by many civil liberties activists as a hero for exposing the extent of government surveillance on its own people.

Title: Obama Defends Bergdahl Deal, Claims Consultation with Congress on Prisoner Swap

Article:

President Barack Obama defended his administration's efforts to rescue Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from captivity during a press conference in Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday, stating that the primary objective was to bring an American soldier home. Obama argued that the U.S. has a "sacred rule" not to leave its service members behind, a policy that dates back to the earliest days of the nation.

Though some members of Congress have expressed dismay about the lack of 30-day advance notice for the prisoner swap with the Taliban, Obama asserted that his administration had been consulting with lawmakers "for some time" and had made clear that it might have to take quick action. However, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers (R-Mich.) disputed this assertion, stating that Congress had not heard from the Obama administration since 2011 on the possibility of a prisoner swap with the Taliban.

The White House did not inform lawmakers of the deal until after it had been executed, and the formal notification did not occur until Monday, two days after Obama announced the successful rescue in the Rose Garden of the White House with Bergdahl's parents present.

Obama argued that his administration acted appropriately to bring Bergdahl home, seizing an opportunity when the Qataris offered to facilitate an exchange. He emphasized that the administration did not want to miss the opportunity due to concerns about Bergdahl's health.

Bergdahl has faced criticism from some of his fellow soldiers who served with him in Afghanistan, who allege that he deserted by walking off his base unarmed in 2009 after expressing concerns about the U.S. mission against the Taliban. Obama acknowledged that there are questions surrounding the circumstances that led to Bergdahl's capture, but stated that the immediate focus is on helping the soldier recover from the stresses of his captivity.

Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey wrote on Facebook early Tuesday that any concerns about Bergdahl's conduct are separate from efforts to recover any U.S. service member in enemy captivity. Dempsey added that "like any American, [Bergdahl] is innocent until proven guilty" and that the Army will not ignore misconduct if it occurred.

When asked whether Bergdahl will face questioning and possibly a court martial for desertion, Obama stated that such discussions are premature, as the immediate priority is ensuring a successful transition for Bergdahl after five years of captivity.

Obama also addressed concerns that the release of five members of the Taliban, who had been detained for years at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, poses a threat to U.S. national security. He stated that their release was conditioned on the Qataris monitoring their activities and that the U.S. would be keeping eyes on them. Obama acknowledged that there is a risk of recidivism among released prisoners from Guantanamo, but expressed confidence that the U.S. would be able to take action if the released Taliban members engage in activities that threaten U.S. defenses.

Title: NSA Director Opposes Proposed U.S.-Russia Cyber Security Working Group

Article:

National Security Agency (NSA) Director Mike Rogers has expressed opposition to the idea of establishing a U.S.-Russia cyber security working group, a proposal that has been met with skepticism by several senior U.S. lawmakers. The proposal, which was initially indicated as a possibility by President Donald Trump, appears to have been retracted following widespread criticism.

U.S. intelligence agencies have assessed that Russia interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election by hacking Democratic emails and distributing online propaganda to support Trump's campaign over his rival, Hillary Clinton. Moscow has denied any interference, and Trump has stated that his campaign did not collude with Russia.

This week, a Russian presidential envoy reported that discussions were underway between Moscow and Washington to create a joint cyber security working group. In response to a question about the feasibility of setting up a cyber security cell with the Russians, Rogers, speaking at the annual Aspen Security Forum, stated, "I'm not a policy guy here... I would argue now is probably not the best time to be doing this."

Trump mentioned the idea of creating such a group during a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Group of 20 summit in Hamburg earlier this month. Senior Republicans have criticized the idea, stating that Russia cannot be trusted, and Trump later appeared to back away from the proposal, tweeting, "The fact that President Putin and I discussed a Cyber Security unit doesn't mean I think it can happen. It can't."

The widespread concern and confusion about the possible cyber working group reflects the Trump administration's struggles to articulate a clear approach to international cyber security issues due to inconsistent statements by the president and ongoing personnel changes. Rogers suggested that such a unit could be a possibility if there were changes in Russia's behavior.

Title: U.S. and Allies Seize Opportunity to Target Islamic State in Kobani, Acknowledge Long-Term Campaign Against ISIS

Article:

Military and White House officials have stated that the ongoing fighting in the Syrian border town of Kobani has created a favorable situation for taking out large numbers of Islamic State (IS) fighters congregating in the area. Army Gen. Lloyd Austin, head of U.S. Central Command, claimed on Friday that the enemy is pouring manpower into Kobani, making it a target-rich environment for American and coalition air strikes.

While touting the opportunity to take out a significant number of targets in Kobani, military officials have cautioned against expecting quick progress in the overall campaign against ISIS. Austin stated that the campaign to destroy ISIL will take time, and there will be occasional setbacks along the way, particularly in the early stages of the campaign as U.S. forces coach and mentor Iraqi forces that are actively working to regenerate capability after years of neglect and poor leadership.

In addition to Kobani, the U.S. military is also focusing on other regions, such as Anbar province in Iraq, where the militants have made recent gains. Austin expressed optimism that the Iraqi government will successfully enlist the support of Sunni tribal leaders in Anbar to turn the tide in that important region. He also stated that there is no imminent threat to the international airport west of Baghdad, where U.S. Apache helicopters are monitoring Islamic State efforts to make inroads on the capital.

As an example of fresh progress, Austin mentioned that Iraqi soldiers attacked north from Baghdad to Beiji, home to Iraq's largest oil refinery, on Friday. However, the militants are making gains in some parts, such as the Sunni-dominated Anbar province, even as they stall or retrench in other areas. Pentagon spokesman Rear Adm. John Kirby stated that Baghdad is not believed to be in imminent danger of falling but is "certainly in their sights."

The Pentagon is preparing to set up a more formally organized command structure, known as a joint task force, to lead and coordinate the campaign from a forward headquarters, possibly in Kuwait. On Wednesday, it formally named the campaign "Operation Inherent Resolve." As of Thursday, the U.S. had launched nearly 300 airstrikes in Iraq and nearly 200 in Syria, and allies had tallied fewer than 100, according to Central Command. These figures do not capture the full scope of the effort because many airstrikes launch multiple bombs on multiple targets. Central Command stated that as of Wednesday, U.S. and partner-nation air forces had dropped nearly 1,400 munitions.

Title: Russian An-148 Plane Crashes Near Moscow, Killing All 71 On Board

Article:

A Russian An-148 regional jet, belonging to Saratov Airlines, crashed minutes after takeoff from Domodedovo Airport in Moscow on Sunday, resulting in the death of all 71 passengers and crew members on board, according to officials. The plane was en route to Orsk, approximately 1,000 miles southeast of Moscow, as reported by REN-TV.

The Moscow Inter-Regional Transport Prosecutor's Office confirmed the fatalities in a statement to Interfax, stating, "The plane was carrying 65 passengers and six crewmembers. All of them died." Transport Minister Maxim Sokolov added, "Judging by everything, no one has survived this crash."

Authorities have recovered a black box from the crash site, and the area has been cordoned off, as reported by regional head of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, Sergei Poletykin, in a conference call. "One recorder was found at the crash site," Poletykin said.

The crew of the doomed aircraft did not report any malfunctions, according to Svetlana Petrenko, an official representative of the Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation, who told Interfax, "At the moment it has been established that there have been no reports of aircraft failure from the crew."

All passengers aboard the airliner are believed to have been residents of the Orenburg region, along the border with Kazakhstan, according to Interfax news agency and regional governor spokesman Sergei Sheremetsinsky.

Russian President Vladimir Putin postponed a planned trip to Sochi to closely monitor the investigation and offered his condolences to the families of those killed. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov stated, "The president expresses deep condolences to all those who lost their relatives and friends in this disaster."

Putin was to meet Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas on Monday in the Black Sea resort where the president has an official residence. Instead, Abbas will meet with Putin in Moscow in the latter part of Monday, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told Russian news agencies.

Fragments of the jet were found in the Ramenskoye area, about 25 miles from the airport, according to REN-TV. No on-ground casualties were reported. The flight took off from Moscow's Domodedovo Airport and spent about 5 minutes in the air before a signal was lost about 12 miles southeast of the airport, according to Flightradar24, a flight-tracking website.

The cause of the crash remains unclear, with weather conditions and pilot error being among the possible reasons. Russia's Investigative Committee is looking into all possible crash causes. The An-148 jet was developed by Ukraine's Antonov company in the early 2000s and was manufactured in both Ukraine and Russia.

The plane had been flying since 2010, with a two-year break due to a shortage of parts, according to Russia's state news agency Tass. The jet was ordered by Rossiya Airlines, a subsidiary of Aeroflot, but was put into storage during 2015-2017 because of a lack of parts. Tass reports it re-entered service for Saratov Airlines in February 2017.

Shabby equipment and poor supervision had plagued Russian civil aviation for years after the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union, but its safety record has improved markedly in recent years. The last large-scale crash in Russia occurred on Dec. 25, 2016, when a Tu-154 operated by the Russian Defense Ministry on its way to Syria crashed into the Black Sea minutes after takeoff from the southern Russian city of Sochi. All 92 people on board were killed. In March 2016, a Boeing 737-800 flown by FlyDubai crashed while landing at Rostov-on-Don, killing all 62 people aboard. An onboard bomb destroyed a Russian Metrojet airliner soon after taking off from Egypt's Sharm al-Sheikh resort, killing 224 people in October 2015.

Title: Former FEMA Director James Lee Witt Considering Run for Arkansas House Seat Amid GOP Troubles Boosting Democratic Recruitment

Article:

The ongoing fiscal crises in the United States have provided a boost to Democratic candidate recruitment efforts for the 2014 midterm elections, with more than a dozen blue-chip Democratic candidates now considering or announcing their intention to run in top-tier races.

In Arkansas, former Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) director James Lee Witt is looking at running for the seat being vacated by Republican Rep. Tom Cotton. Witt served as the director of FEMA under former President Bill Clinton.

In Nebraska, Omaha city councilman Pete Festersen, who previously declined to run against GOP Rep. Lee Terry, is now considering a challenge after Terry came under fire for his response to a question about accepting pay during the government shutdown. National Democrats see Festersen as a pro-business moderate who could give the party a shot in the Republican-friendly 2nd Congressional District.

Similarly, in New Jersey, attorney Bill Hughes Jr., the son of a popular former congressman, is likely to run against longtime GOP Rep. Frank LoBiondo after watching the budget drama unfold. In Indiana, University of Notre Dame official Joe Bock, who had been hesitant about running, recently announced that he will most likely run.

Some of the Democratic recruits have statewide or national profiles. In Florida, Alex Sink, the state's former chief financial officer who narrowly lost a bid for governor in 2010, is considering running for a seat in the St. Petersburg area.

Republicans are quick to point out that strong recruits are not a guarantee of success in red districts. However, in an election that has given Democrats little reason for hope, the new recruits provide at least a glimmer. The combination of redistricting and demographics has limited the number of competitive seats in 2014, giving Democrats few opportunities to chip away at the GOP's 17-seat majority.

The shutdown and debt ceiling standoff have prodded candidates who had been on the fence or inclined not to run to jump in. National Democratic Congressional Committee chairman Rep. Steve Israel said the fiscal debate has unquestionably hurt the GOP brand, but it's unclear how lasting the damage will be and whether voters will even care a year from now.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Denies Communication with Russians, but New Report Suggests Otherwise

Article:

Attorney General Jeff Sessions, under oath at his confirmation hearing, stated that he did not communicate with Russians during the 2016 campaign. However, a new report by Adam Entous, Ellen Nakashima, and Greg Miller for the Washington Post claims that Sessions did speak with the Russian ambassador to the US, Sergey Kislyak.

According to the report, Justice Department officials told the Post that Sessions spoke with Kislyak twice, including, as reported, "at the height of what U.S. intelligence officials say was a Russian cyber campaign to upend the U.S. presidential race." This contradicts Sessions' testimony at his January confirmation hearing, where he was asked by Sen. Al Franken, a Minnesota Democrat, about any evidence that anyone affiliated with the Trump campaign communicated with the Russian government during the 2016 campaign. Sessions responded, "I'm not aware of any of those activities."

The Washington Post report suggests that Sessions' contact with Kislyak, even as a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee at the time, was unusual. Among the 20 (of 26) members of the committee who responded to the Post, none of them met with Russia's ambassador last year.

The blockbuster report is the latest in a string of controversies surrounding the Trump administration's ties to Russia. Last month, former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn was forced to resign after it was revealed that he talked to Kislyak in December and may have suggested that Trump would lift sanctions against Russia—a potential violation of the Logan Act, which bans people outside the executive branch from making foreign policy on behalf of the U.S. administration. (Flynn and Trump were not in office at the time of the call.)

Democrats responded to the report by calling on Sessions to recuse himself from any investigation into Trump's ties to the Justice Department. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi called on Sessions to resign, stating, "After lying under oath to Congress about his own communications with the Russians, the attorney general must resign. Sessions is not fit to serve as the top law enforcement officer of our country and must resign. There must be an independent, bipartisan, outside commission to investigate the Trump political, personal, and financial connections to the Russians."

For more on the growing Trump-Russia scandal, read [publication's explainer].

Title: Trump's Response to Florida School Shooting: A Look at the Current State of Gun Control Debate

Article:

In the aftermath of the mass shooting at a Florida school that left 17 dead, there has been a renewed push for gun law reform, with students who survived the tragedy leading the charge. Over the weekend, several major corporations, including Delta Air Lines, United, and Avis Budget Group, cut ties with the National Rifle Association (NRA). A CNN/SSRS poll showed that 70% of Americans want tougher regulation of firearms.

However, as lawmakers returned to Washington this week, the political landscape appeared to revert to business as usual, with a push for new regulation and strengthened background checks losing momentum. The political realities surrounding the Second Amendment remain as entrenched as ever, and the passage of significant gun laws becomes less likely the more time passes without action.

President Donald Trump has promised to "turn our grief into action," pledging to outlaw bump fire stocks and to "harden" U.S. schools to protect them from shooters. He has also expressed support for "strong" background checks to prevent "sickos" from obtaining guns. However, his actions and statements have been met with skepticism, as it remains unclear whether he will offer the leadership necessary to push significant gun control measures through Congress.

Trump has reportedly been considering expanding background checks to gun show sales and making them more efficient, as well as including private transactions. He has also suggested raising the age at which someone can buy a long gun from 18 to 21, but has since stopped discussing this idea in public.

Given the lack of details from Trump and the sometimes contradictory nature of his remarks, it remains unclear whether he is poised to offer the kind of leadership that would grant his fellow Republicans political cover to push significant gun control measures through Congress. Some Republicans have expressed skepticism about measures such as raising the age for purchasing long guns and banning bump stocks.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has called for more action, but has given no indication that he is ready to expose his fellow senators to tough votes on measures that would ban assault-style weapons, a plan backed by some more liberal members of the Senate. Some Republicans have signaled that measures such as raising the required age for purchasing long guns and banning bump stocks are unlikely to pass.

Senators Pat Toomey (R-PA) and Joe Manchin (D-WV) have attempted to forge a path forward for their bill on universal background checks, which failed to pass in 2013 after the Sandy Hook school massacre. Manchin expressed hope that the presence of a Republican in the White House could reassure some GOP lawmakers. "The reason we were not able to get the support we needed was because they were afraid President Obama would go further," Manchin said. "Well, they're not having that fear with President Trump," he added. "It's really up to him."

Title: Hong Kong Government Withdraws Extradition Bill, Protesters Call It "Too Little, Too Late"

Article:

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced on Wednesday the government's decision to fully withdraw the controversial extradition bill from the legislature, addressing one of the five demands protesters have been advocating for since June. The bill, which would have allowed the Communist Party of China to extradite individuals accused of violating communist "crimes" into the Chinese prison system, has sparked widespread fear among Hong Kong residents due to China's reputation for human rights violations, including political imprisonment, forced organ harvesting, and severe restrictions on free speech and religious activity.

In her public address, Lam stated that the Legislative Council would fully withdraw the bill "in order to fully allay public concerns." She also acknowledged the violence that has engulfed the city, primarily due to police actions, and lamented the disruptions to daily life caused by the protests.

In addition to withdrawing the bill, Lam announced modifications to the membership of the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC), a move that addresses one of the remaining four demands for an independent inquiry on police brutality. However, concerns remain that the police will exonerate themselves of human rights crimes if they conduct the investigation.

The Global Times, a Chinese regime propaganda outlet, cautioned against interpreting Lam's moves as a concession, warning that radical forces should not view it as a victory in matters related to the "one country, two systems" principle that governs Hong Kong and China's sovereignty.

The protesters' five demands include the withdrawal of the extradition bill, an independent inquiry on police brutality, freedom for political prisoners, direct election of lawmakers, and an apology for labeling the June 12 protest a "riot." Currently, Hong Kong residents can elect only half of lawmakers in the Legislative Council, while the others are appointed by a small group of special interests representatives controlled by China. Similarly, only 1,200 Hong Kong residents, part of a special committee, can vote for their chief executive, and even then only among a list of candidates handpicked by China.

Prior to Wednesday, Lam had refused to withdraw the extradition bill, stating that legislators had tabled it and declaring it "dead" in July. However, tabling a bill keeps it alive and allows lawmakers to revive it at any time. Protest movement leaders have criticized Lam for using the term "dead," arguing that it is not a legal term for a bill and that she gave no guarantees lawmakers would not bring it back to life.

The announcement follows the destruction of the Legislative Council floor and much of the building it uses as its headquarters. Protesters meticulously destroyed all the technology and every facility used to pass laws, but left historical documents, the building's cafeteria, and other irrelevant areas untouched.

Lam's concession comes after the publication of a bombshell report this week by Reuters, revealing audio of the chief executive saying she would like to resign from the post but is not allowed. In the audio, Lam expressed regret for causing "huge havoc" to Hong Kong and expressed a desire to step down and make a deep apology. However, the Global Times called the Reuters report "fake" without elaborating.

Protest leaders have called Lam's withdrawal of the bill "too little and too late," insisting they will continue their struggle for freedom from China.

Title: Trump, Kim Jong Un's Sister Discuss Denuclearization and Unification

Article:

President Donald Trump has expressed cautious optimism following a rare two-day visit by a South Korean delegation to North Korea, during which the Hermit Kingdom expressed a willingness to hold talks with the United States on denuclearization and normalization of relations.

South Korea's presidential national security director, Chung Eui-yong, announced that North Korea has committed to the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula and will not attempt any strategic provocations, such as nuclear and ballistic missile tests, while dialogue continues.

In a tweet, Trump praised the "possible progress" but remained cautious, stating, "Possible progress being made in talks with North Korea. For the first time in many years, a serious effort is being made by all parties concerned. The World is watching and waiting! May be false hope, but the U.S. is ready to go hard in either direction!"

Chung led a 10-member South Korean delegation to Pyongyang for the two-day visit. North Korea is reportedly ready to have "heart-to-heart" talks with the U.S. about its potential denuclearization and normalization of relations between the countries.

The North and South Korean leaders have agreed to hold summit talks in April at the border, and to establish a "hotline" communication channel to lower military tensions. The two Koreas also agreed to cooperate in various areas, including sports, culture, and exchanges.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, however, called for countries to further isolate North Korea despite the Hermit Kingdom's offer to discuss denuclearization. Tillerson stated that North Korea poses a threat to the global community through its unlawful nuclear and ballistic missile programs and proliferation activities.

The recent thaw in relations between North and South Korea follows the Pyeongchang Olympics, during which North Korea sent a delegation of athletes, cheerleaders, art troupe members, and officials to Pyeongchang. Kim Jong Un's sister, Kim Yo Jong, attended the opening ceremony and met with South Korean President Moon Jae-in over a three-day visit.

Kim Yo Jong wrote of her "wishes" for closer ties in a guest book at South Korea's presidential office, stating, "I expect Pyongyang and Seoul to get closer in the hearts of our [ Korean ] people and the future of unification and prosperity will be advanced." However, the "future of unification" phrase is seen as a threat by some, as North Korea has touted unification as a "final victory" to the Korean War that ended in an armistice in 1953.

Kim Jong Un's apparent olive branch to South Korea and the U.S. comes after months of mounting sanctions against the volatile regime. Some analysts believe that the North Korean regime is scrambling to keep its economy afloat due to the crippling effects of international sanctions. According to a South Korean lawmaker, North Korea's hard currency is expected to run dry by October.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Responds to Hillary Clinton's Remarks, Accuses Her of Being "Queen of Warmongers"

Article:

Presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard, a Democratic representative from Hawaii, responded forcefully on Friday to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's suggestion that Gabbard is a "favorite of the Russians" for the 2020 election. In an interview on the podcast "Campaign HQ," Clinton had implied that Gabbard was being supported by Russian sites, bots, and other means.

While Clinton did not mention Gabbard by name, her comments were widely interpreted as a reference to the Hawaii congresswoman, who has repeatedly denied accusations of being a Russian asset. In a series of tweets, Gabbard directly addressed Clinton, calling her the "embodiment of corruption" among the Democratic Party establishment.

"From the day I announced my candidacy, there has been a concerted campaign to destroy my reputation," Gabbard tweeted. "We wondered who was behind it and why. Now we know — it was always you."

Gabbard challenged Clinton to "join the race directly" if she was going to attack her. "It’s now clear that this primary is between you and me. Don’t cowardly hide behind your proxies. Join the race directly," she added.

Gabbard, a member of the Hawaii National Guard and an Iraq War veteran, has faced ongoing concern from political observers that her campaign is being amplified by Russian bots and online trolls. She has raised eyebrows with her anti-establishment foreign policy positions, especially her accusation that the U.S. engages in regime-change wars and her meeting with Syrian President Bashar Assad in 2017.

Gabbard's tweeted attack on Clinton left fellow Democratic 2020 candidate Sen. Cory Booker speechless. According to the RealClearPolitics polling average, Gabbard is polling at 1.2 percent nationally, making her one of the lower-tier candidates to make this week's primary debate in Ohio.

Title: Iran Denies Reports of Downing Civilian Plane, Invites International Investigation

Article:

Iranian officials have denied reports from American and European intelligence agencies that Iran shot down Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752, which was en route from Tehran to Kyiv on Friday. The denial comes after U.S. officials claimed the plane was hit by an anti-aircraft missile battery.

President Donald Trump suggested on Thursday that the incident was the result of an error, stating, "Somebody could have made a mistake on the other side." However, Iran's aviation department head, Ali Abedzadeh, stated at a press conference, "What is obvious for us, and what we can say with certainty, is that no missile hit the plane."

Abedzadeh also invited Boeing officials to join the investigation and expressed Iran's intention to study the aircraft's black box flight recorders before sharing them. The head of the Iranian investigative team, Hassan Rezaeifar, stated that Iran would not share the black boxes immediately but would consider reaching out to international experts if it was unable to extract the recordings. The investigation could take over a month to fully retrieve the black box data, with the investigation itself potentially continuing for up to a year.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed that Canadian intelligence believed the crash was caused by a missile strike, as at least 63 Canadian citizens were on board the aircraft. "The evidence indicates that the plane was shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile," Trudeau said on Thursday.

In total, 176 people died in the crash, with most being Iranian and Canadian citizens. Ukraine International Airlines has yet to comment on the incident, while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has stated his country "will conduct a detailed and independent investigation" into the crash.

Title: Trump's Grip on Republican Primary Voters Remains Strong Despite Few News Headlines

Article:

In the ongoing race for the Republican presidential nomination, Donald Trump continues to demonstrate a unique resilience that sets him apart in modern political history. Despite a few setbacks, he maintains a strong grip on the Republican primary voter base.

In the past two weeks, Trump has been largely absent from news interviews and major policy announcements. However, his absence from the media has not diminished his support significantly. The media has been filled with discussions about the intricacies of Colorado, North Dakota, Wyoming, Rule 40B, and the second ballot. Despite running minimal paid media, Trump has managed to secure an overwhelming victory in New York and is leading in all five states set to vote a week later (Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, Rhode Island, and Connecticut). This puts him less than 100 votes shy of 1,000 delegates, needing 1,237 to take the nomination outright.

Ted Cruz, who has been making a comeback, could potentially win Pennsylvania, where 54 of the total 71 delegates are not bound, and where the senator is doing well in the delegate selection process. Cruz could also win Indiana's 57 votes and Nebraska's 36. If Cruz managed to parlay his strength in the far West into wins on the Pacific Coast, he could potentially block Trump and win on the second ballot.

However, Trump's grip on the Republican primary voter is unyielding. Despite a 75 percent negative rating among American women, there is little gender gap in his primary vote. He does about as well among Republican women as he does with Republican men.

In the 2004 election, Republicans brought 10 million more (largely white) voters out than in 2000. Barack Obama won in 2008 by bringing out 10 million more blacks, Latinos, and young people than in 2004. Mitt Romney lost, in part, because 10 million white voters stayed home in 2012. Trump has demonstrated a vote-getting power that is extraordinary, pushing Republican turnout to a level 75 percent higher than it was in 2012.

The question remains whether Trump's ability to get his voters out and hold their support can win in the face of his terrible national general election numbers. Trump runs 10 points worse among women against Hillary Clinton than Romney did against Obama. He is 10 points less favorable and 10 points more unfavorable than Clinton. He loses to her by 10 in the RealClearPolitics average, 49 percent to 39 percent.

However, Trump's opposition to trade deals and his refusal to take super-PAC money could potentially rally voters, including those of Bernie Sanders, who supported Sanders over the same issues. The impact of the FBI investigation into Clinton's State emails and the release of the Benghazi report remains to be seen.

Title: Reflections on the 15-Year Anniversary of 9/11: America's Ongoing Struggle Against Terrorism

Article:

Fifteen years have passed since the tragic events of September 11, 2001, a day that left an indelible mark on the United States and the world. The attacks on the Twin Towers, the Pentagon, and Flight 93, as well as subsequent incidents such as San Bernardino, Orlando, Nice, Paris, Ansbach, and Istanbul, have shaped the nation's response to terrorism and its foreign policy.

In the aftermath of 9/11, the United States found itself embroiled in a global war on terror that continues to this day. The events of that fateful day marked the beginning of a worldwide jihad, a conflict that has resulted in significant changes in American society and the implementation of extensive security measures.

The aftermath of 9/11 saw a shift in American attitudes and behaviors. Roads became quieter, work came to a halt, and citizens clung to their loved ones in fear of further attacks. The skies were devoid of planes, and the silence was a stark reminder of the new reality.

The TSA, or Transportation Security Administration, was established in response to the attacks, and Americans have grown accustomed to increased security measures such as removing shoes, travel-size toiletries, and undergoing pat-downs at airports. However, the TSA has been criticized for its inability to prevent terrorist attacks, with some arguing that it is merely a theatrical display intended to make people feel safer.

The question of whether mass surveillance is an effective means of protecting the public is a contentious issue. The Orlando shooter, for example, was interviewed by the FBI, and they concluded he was not a threat. The subsequent attack raises questions about the effectiveness of current security measures and the need for change.

The war on terror has also led to a significant increase in immigration, as people flee conflict zones in the Middle East. The compatibility of Islamic beliefs with Western-style democracy is another contentious issue, with some arguing that there is a need for reassessment and a reevaluation of solutions.

The war on terror has been long and costly, with no clear end in sight. The question of whether America should withdraw from its global commitments or continue to engage remains a topic of debate. The potential consequences of both options, including the possibility of more subtle forms of terrorism such as EMP (Electromagnetic Pulse) attacks on the electric grid, are significant.

The aftermath of 9/11 has also led to the growth of a vast bureaucracy, with agencies such as the NSA and TSA tasked with protecting the nation. However, the effectiveness of these agencies has been called into question, with some arguing that they infringe on personal freedoms while missing obvious threats.

The events of 9/11 have left a lasting impact on the United States, shaping its foreign policy, security measures, and societal attitudes. The nation continues to grapple with the complexities of the war on terror, attempting to balance the need for security with the preservation of individual freedoms. The terrorists may not have won on 9/11, but the United States has been forever changed by the events of that day.

Title: Julie Swetnick's Credibility Questioned as She Partially Walks Back Sexual Assault Allegations Against Brett Kavanaugh

Article:

Julie Swetnick, who has made uncorroborated and salacious sexual assault allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, is facing credibility questions as she appears to partially walk back some of her claims and details about her past emerge. Republican Sen. Bill Cassidy has suggested the FBI scrutinize her, tweeting:

"A criminal referral should be sent to the FBI/DOJ regarding the apparently false affidavit signed by Julie Swetnick that was submitted to the Senate by @MichaelAvenatti."
