In a sworn statement last month, Swetnick claimed she had seen Kavanaugh "engage in abusive and physically aggressive behavior toward girls" and "grinding" against girls and attempting to remove their clothes in the early '80s. She also claimed she "became aware of efforts by [friend] Mark Judge, Brett Kavanaugh, and others to ‘spike’ the ‘punch’ at house parties" with drugs or alcohol to lower girls' defenses and get them disoriented so they could be "gang raped" in a side room by a "train" of boys.

Swetnick, in an interview with NBC News, appeared to walk back some of the claims about Kavanaugh, while standing by her claims of sexually aggressive behavior. While she said in her statement she became aware of "efforts" by Kavanaugh to spike the punch, she said in the interview she was unclear about what Kavanaugh was actually doing.

"I saw—I saw him giving red solo cups to quite a few girls during that time frame, and there was grain punch at those parties," she said. "I saw him around the punch—I won’t say bowls, the punch containers. I don’t know what he did, but I saw him by them."

As for the claim about "trains" of boys lining up outside rooms to rape girls, she said in the interview she saw boys including Kavanaugh and Judge "huddled by doors." Asked if she was suggesting she thought Kavanaugh was involved, she answered: "I would say yes, it's just too coincidental." She did not offer further details to support the claim he was waiting his "turn."

She also clarified that while she saw Kavanaugh and Judge at the party and where other boys were gathered, she "can not specifically say that he was one of the ones who assaulted me" -- her original statement did not specifically accuse them of assaulting her, either.

Meanwhile, she said she told her mother and the Montgomery County Police the next day. Police officials told NBC News it could take up to a month to recover documents related to any report she may have made. Further, NBC reported that both her mother and the officer she said she spoke with have died.

Swetnick has struggled to provide corroborating witnesses, though her statement said she was aware of other witnesses who could "attest to the truthfulness" of her account. Swetnick provided four names to NBC News to back up her story: One is dead, two did not respond to NBC requests, and one other said he didn’t remember Swetnick and didn’t think he had socialized with her.

Swetnick's shifting, uncorroborated claims also led NBC News to issue a statement ahead of the interview.

"NBC News, for the record, has not been able to independently verify her claims. There are things she told us on camera that differ from her written statements last week," host Kate Snow told viewers.

Kavanaugh has called Swetnick's accusations a "joke," while Judge has said he "categorically" denies her claims. Lawyer Michael Avenatti, who is representing her, responded to some of the controversy by saying that Swetnick is willing to take a polygraph test and told CNN he had done "significant due diligence" before going ahead with them. Avenatti, who has also represented adult film star Stormy Daniels in her legal fight against President Trump and has floated the possibility of a 2020 Democratic presidential run, has fueled Republican claims that the impetus behind the sexual assault claims is politically motivated.

Swetnick's ex-boyfriend, Richard Vinneccy, told Fox News' "The Ingraham Angle" Monday that she had threatened to kill his unborn child. He also said that although they dated on-and-off for seven years, she never mentioned her Kavanaugh claims to him, and was known for wanting to be the center of attention.

"She was exaggerating everything. Everything that came out of her mouth was just exaggerations," he said.

It was also revealed this week that Swetnick was sued in 2000 by her former employer, Portland-based Webtrends, for allegedly falsifying her educational background and concocting false sexual harassment allegations. The suit, which Avenatti has called "bogus," was voluntarily dismissed by Webtrends shortly afterwards.

The Associated Press reported on Sunday that Swetnick has been involved in at least six legal cases in the last 25 years. Avenatti told The Associated Press that court cases involving her have no bearing on the credibility of her claims about Kavanaugh. The FBI is currently conducting a background investigation into sexual assault claims made against Kavanaugh. The agency is expected to wrap up its investigation by Friday.

Title: Trump's Path to Securing Republican Nomination Before July Convention

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — The possibility of a contested Republican convention this summer may not materialize as Donald Trump is still on track to clinch the nomination before the July convention in Cleveland. Trump is the only candidate with a realistic chance of reaching the 1,237 delegates needed to secure the nomination before the convention, according to the latest polls and delegate allocation rules.

Trump currently has 744 delegates, and he can potentially win an additional 1,226 delegates by the end of the primaries on June 7, if he wins a significant number of upcoming contests.

New York, with 95 delegates at stake, is crucial for Trump's path to the nomination. If Trump wins a majority of the state's delegates, he could take 77 delegates on the night. Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Rhode Island, Indiana, Nebraska, West Virginia, Oregon, and Washington State hold primaries in April and May, with a total of 534 delegates at stake.

Trump can afford to lose Rhode Island, which awards its 19 delegates proportionally. In all, it's a day on which Trump could claim 93 delegates. Indiana's May 3 primary is important for Trump, with 57 delegates at stake. If Trump can win the state and a majority of the congressional districts, he could collect 45 delegates.

West Virginia is another unique state in which voters elect 31 delegates in the May 10 primary. If Trump does well here, he could pick up 20 or more delegates. Nebraska's 36 delegates are winner-take-all, but if Nebraska is like its neighbors Kansas and Iowa, two states Cruz won earlier in the race, Trump can't count on these delegates.

Oregon and Washington state award delegates proportionally, so even the losers get some. Five states vote on June 7, with 303 delegates up for grabs. The biggest prize is California, along with New Jersey, South Dakota, Montana, and New Mexico. California is more complicated, with 172 delegates at stake. The statewide winner gets only 13. The other 159 are awarded according to the results in individual congressional districts.

For Trump to clinch the nomination on June 7, the last day of the primary season, he has to win a big majority of California's congressional districts. If he wins 39 districts, he gets 130 delegates. On the last voting day of the primary campaign, Trump could win 242 delegates, leaving him 11 delegates short of the magic number.

Missouri has certified the results of its March 15 primary, with Trump beating Cruz by 1,965 votes. If the results survive a potential recount, Trump wins Missouri and another 12 delegates. Trump's running total is 1,226, 11 delegates short of the magic number.

Title: NSA Director Denies Collecting Millions of European Phone Records, Addresses International Spying Controversy

Article:

In a hearing on Tuesday, the head of the National Security Agency (NSA), General Keith Alexander, adamantly denied reports that the agency is collecting millions of phone records across Europe. The denial was one of the highlights of a House Intelligence Committee hearing about improving information gathering and privacy protections.

The hearing took place amid an international uproar over reports that the NSA monitored the cellphone of German Chancellor Angela Merkel for a decade, which is part of a pattern of the agency eavesdropping on friendly countries' leaders. Officials at the hearing did not deny that such spying takes place, but their answers cast doubt on White House assertions that President Obama did not know the extent of the spying on Chancellor Merkel.

When asked by Chairman Mike Rogers (R-MI) if the US would consider it important to get access to the communications of foreign leaders, Director of National Intelligence James Clapper responded that knowing "leadership intentions" was "one of the first things I learned in intelligence school in 1963."

When asked further if America's allies "conduct espionage on us," Mr. Clapper responded "absolutely" – before summarizing that the brouhaha over friends-on-friends spying reminded him of a scene from the movie "Casablanca."

As for the "false" reports of the NSA gathering millions of European phone records, General Alexander said that the data in question were actually collected by foreign intelligence agencies. Moreover, to a large extent, they were gathered outside of Europe, often in war zones of crucial security interest to the US and its European allies.

"This is not information we collected on European citizens," Alexander said, defining it instead as "information that we and our NATO allies have collected in defense of our countries and in support of military operations."

The documents Mr. Snowden provided European media were actually screenshots of data and were not the documents themselves, Alexander said.

Some committee members asked why European leaders would offer such harsh judgments of US intelligence practices if their services are doing the same thing. Some European parliamentarians and policymakers "may not have familiarity with exactly how their intelligence operations work," Clapper said, adding that officials are often unaware of "everything" their own intelligence agencies do.

The uproar over US intelligence practices overshadowed the purpose of Tuesday's hearing, which was to discuss proposed reforms to the NSA's program for bulk collection of communications under the Foreign Intelligence Security Act (FISA). One proposal from a bipartisan group of House and Senate members would effectively discontinue the program, while an opposing bipartisan collection of lawmakers would keep the program intact while focusing on strengthening its privacy protections.

The House Intelligence Committee's top Democrat, Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger of Maryland, said the program "allows the government to connect the dots" of brewing terrorist activities. "I shudder to think what would happen if the program were completely eliminated," he said. But he added that "FISA must be reformed" to increase "transparency" and "privacy protections" if the government wants to "restore the public's confidence" in national intelligence activities.

NSA's Alexander said the record offers proof that the US intelligence community is getting things right. Contrasting a tally of more than 2,300 deaths overseas last year in terrorist attacks with the absence of any "mass casualty" attack in the US since 9/11, he said, "That's not by luck."

But Alexander also said the door was open to improving both the NSA's operations and its protections of civil liberties and privacy. "We're doing the right things," he said, "but that doesn't mean we shouldn't change."

Title: Ben Carson Endorses Donald Trump as Republican Presidential Nominee

Article:

Retired neurosurgeon and former presidential candidate Ben Carson has officially endorsed Donald Trump as the Republican nominee for president. The announcement was made alongside Trump at Mar-a-Largo, Trump's luxury club in Palm Beach, Florida, on Friday.

Carson, who dropped out of the race last week, stated during a press conference announcing his endorsement, "I have found that, in talking with him, that there's a lot more alignment philosophically and spiritually than I ever thought there was."

When asked about his decision, Carson responded, "It's about 'we the people.' We need to empower the people." He further explained, "That is not going to be done through politics as usual, be that Republican politics as usual, or be that Democrat politics as usual."

Carson elaborated on why he endorsed Trump, stating, "It requires someone who's a bit of an iconoclast but someone who has the ability to listen and to make wise decisions."

Thursday night's GOP presidential debate saw Trump and Carson discussing education and improving schools. According to sources close to Carson, the two met in Palm Beach earlier Thursday and reached an agreement.

The Washington Post reported that Carson had been torn between Trump and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, but opted to support Trump due to a rumor circulated ahead of the Iowa caucuses by the Cruz campaign that Carson had dropped out of the race.

In an interview with Fox News Radio's "John Gibson Show" on Thursday, Carson was asked whether he was planning to join the Trump campaign. "Let's put it this way, I'm certainly leaning," he said, adding that there are "two Donald Trumps" - the one seen on television and the one he's gotten to know behind the scenes.

Carson concluded, "We will be looking at ways to do things that benefit all Americans that create an equal playing field - equality of opportunity - that's what we're looking for."

Title: Ross Perot, Self-made Billionaire and Former Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89

Article:

Ross Perot, the self-made billionaire and former presidential candidate, has passed away at the age of 89 following a five-month battle with leukemia, according to The Dallas Morning News. Perot, who won 19 percent of the vote as a third-party candidate in 1992, died early Tuesday at his home in Dallas surrounded by his family, family spokesman James Fuller said.

Born in Texarkana on June 27, 1930, Perot made his billions by founding Electronic Data Systems Corp. (EDS). He was seen by admirers as a patriot who served his country well before his two failed bids for the White House. In 1979, Perot financed a private commando raid to free two EDS employees being held in a prison in Iran. He was also a tireless advocate for Vietnam veterans.

In 1992, Perot spent more than $60 million of his own money to run against incumbent President George H.W. Bush and challenger Bill Clinton, promising to bring his business acumen to the nation's finances. Some Republicans blamed him for Bush's loss, noting he pulled the largest percentage of votes for a third-party candidate since former President Theodore Roosevelt's 1912 bid.

Perot's second campaign four years later fizzled, as he gathered just 8 percent of the vote, and the Reform Party that he founded and hoped to build into a national political force began to fall apart. However, Perot's ideas on trade and deficit reduction remained part of the political landscape. He blamed both major parties for running up a huge federal budget deficit and letting American jobs be sent to other countries. The movement of U.S. jobs to Mexico, he said, created a "giant sucking sound."

Perot continued to speak out about federal spending for many years. In 2008, he launched a website to highlight the nation's debt with a ticker that tracked the rising total, a blog, and a chart presentation.

Young Perot's first job was delivering papers in a poor, mostly black part of town from his pony, Miss Bee. Perot said when the newspaper tried to cut his commission, he complained to the publisher—and won. He said he learned to take problems straight to the top.

From Texarkana, Perot went to the U.S. Naval Academy even though he had never been on a ship or seen the ocean. After the Navy, Perot joined International Business Machines in 1955 and quickly became a top salesman. In his last year at IBM, he filled his sales quota for the year in January.

In 1962, with $1,000 from his wife, Margot, Perot founded Electronic Data Systems. Hardware accounted for about 80% of the computer business, Perot said, and IBM wasn't interested in the other 20%, including services.

Many of the early hires at EDS were former military men, and they had to abide by Perot's strict dress code—white shirts, ties, no beards or mustaches—and long work days. Many had crew cuts, like Perot.

The company's big break came in the mid-1960s when the federal government created Medicare and Medicaid, the health programs for seniors, the disabled, and the poor. States needed help in running the programs, and EDS won contracts—starting in Texas—to handle the millions of claims.

EDS first sold stock to the public in 1968, and overnight, Perot was worth $350 million. His fortune doubled and tripled as the stock price rose steadily. In 1984, he sold control of the company to General Motors Corp. for $2.5 billion and received $700 million in a buyout. In 2008, EDS was sold to Hewlett-Packard Co.

Perot went on to establish another computer-services company, Perot Systems Corp. He retired as CEO in 2000 and was succeeded by his son, Ross Perot Jr. In 2009, Dell Inc. bought Perot Systems.

In September 2011, Forbes magazine estimated Perot's wealth at $3.5 billion and ranked him No. 91 on its list of richest Americans.

Title: Trump Threatens to Close Southern Border, Cut Aid, and Alter Trade Relations with Mexico

Article:

President Donald Trump has warned that he will close the Southern border entirely if Congress does not provide funding for a border wall and change the current immigration laws. In a series of tweets on Friday, Trump stated, "We will be forced to close the Southern Border entirely if the Obstructionist Democrats do not give us the money to finish the Wall & also change the ridiculous immigration laws that our Country is saddled with."

The threat comes amid a partial government shutdown that is now entering its second week. The shutdown began last Saturday as a result of the inability of Republicans and Democrats to agree on a funding package that would keep the government open and fund Trump's promised border wall. Trump has demanded $5 billion for the barrier, but Democrats have refused, offering $1.3 billion for general border security instead.

With both sides refusing to compromise and little activity on Capitol Hill during the holiday break, there are no signs of the impasse ending soon. One member of the House Republican leadership told a news outlet on Thursday that a resolution may not emerge until the new year.

In addition to renewing his demands for the wall, Trump also threatened numerous consequences in the absence of the funding. He suggested pulling back on the recently renegotiated North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which now goes by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).

"The United States loses soooo much money on Trade with Mexico under NAFTA, over 75 Billion Dollars a year (not including Drug Money which would be many times that amount), that I would consider closing the Southern Border a 'profit making operation,'" Trump tweeted.

Trump also suggested bringing the U.S. car industry back to the United States and going back to pre-NAFTA conditions before so many of the companies and jobs were sent to Mexico. He stated, "Either we build (finish) the Wall or we close the Border."

Trump then said the U.S. would terminate aid with Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, which he said are doing "nothing for the United States but taking our money." He also referred to reports of another caravan of migrants planning to leave Honduras in January.

"Word is that a new Caravan is forming in Honduras and they are doing nothing about it. We will be cutting off all aid to these 3 countries - taking advantage of U.S. for years!" Trump said.

Trump has previously threatened to shut down the border and cut aid to countries that do not assist or stop the caravans. However, he took no action following those threats. Earlier this month, the U.S. pledged a total of $10.6 billion in aid and investment for Central America and southern Mexico as part of a push to promote better security and job opportunities to prevent Central Americans and Mexicans from emigrating to the U.S.

A cut-off of trade relations with Mexico could also risk a new agreement that Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen announced this month, which calls for immigrants claiming asylum in the U.S. to be returned to Mexico as their cases are processed.

Mick Mulvaney, Trump's incoming acting chief of staff, claimed on "Fox & Friends" on Friday that Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer is interested in a deal but that Speaker-designate Nancy Pelosi is preventing it. Mulvaney alleged that Democrats are not negotiating because Pelosi is waiting until she secures the speakership.

However, Pelosi has denied claims that Democrats have not provided a counteroffer. Drew Hammill, Pelosi's deputy chief of staff, stated, "Democrats have offered Republicans three options to re-open government that all include funding for strong, sensible, and effective border security – but not the President's immoral, ineffective, and expensive wall." Hammill added, "With the House Majority, Democrats will act swiftly to end the Trump Shutdown, and will fight for a strategic, robust national security policy, including strong and smart border security, and strong support for our servicemembers and veterans."

Title: House Oversight Committee Accuses President Trump of Obstruction Following Refusal to Comply with Congressional Subpoenas

Article:

The Democratic chairman of the U.S. House Oversight Committee, Elijah Cummings, has accused President Donald Trump of a "precedent-setting and growing pattern of obstruction" after Trump ordered federal employees not to comply with congressional investigations. The Republican president has directed officials not to obey legal requests from the Democratic-led House of Representatives, which is conducting multiple investigations of his administration, including his tax returns, White House security clearances, and the probe of Russian interference in U.S. politics.

In a statement, Cummings stated, "President Trump and Attorney General (William) Barr are now openly ordering federal employees to ignore congressional subpoenas and simply not show up - without any assertion of a valid legal privilege." Cummings warned federal employees to "think very carefully about their own legal interests" in refusing to comply with the panel's requests.

Trump has vowed to resist every subpoena from House Democrats investigating his administration and to fight any effort by them to impeach him. Removal from office is unlikely barring a change of heart by his fellow Republicans, who hold a majority in the U.S. Senate.

Trump filed a lawsuit earlier this week to prevent material from being turned over to lawmakers, and on Wednesday, the Justice Department rebuffed a House committee's request for an interview with an official involved in the administration's decision to put a citizenship question on the 2020 census. The department said John Gore, a deputy assistant attorney general in the Civil Rights Division, would not participate in a deposition scheduled for Thursday if he could not have a Justice Department lawyer at his side. The committee had offered to allow a lawyer to sit in a different room.

Cummings said the committee would gather to hear Gore's deposition on Thursday and suggested he "should be well aware of his constitutional, legal, and ethical obligations to comply with a duly authorized subpoena from Congress." A Department of Justice (DOJ) official said the committee had provided "no legitimate or constitutional basis for excluding a DOJ lawyer from assisting at the deposition."

The Constitution empowers Congress to remove a president from office for "treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors." The House is given the power to impeach a president - bring formal charges - and the Senate then convenes a trial, with the senators as jurors. A two-thirds vote is needed to convict a president and remove him from office. The Constitution gives no role to the Supreme Court in impeachment, though it does assign the chief justice the task of presiding over the Senate trial. Conservative John Roberts currently serves as chief justice.

Title: House Democrats Reveal Details of Alleged Illegal Nuclear Technology Sale to Saudi Arabia

Article:

A new report from the House Oversight and Reform Committee has unveiled disturbing details about a secretive effort by top Trump administration officials to sell sensitive nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia, potentially in violation of some ethics statutes. The report, released on Tuesday, provides additional insight into the behind-the-scenes maneuvers to push the proposal through.

The plan, spearheaded by former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, aimed to export technology for approximately 40 nuclear power plants to Saudi Arabia. The effort was part of a broader Middle East economic development plan that Flynn began developing before President Trump's inauguration, while he was serving as an adviser to Trump's campaign and transition team.

During the same time period, Flynn was also working as an adviser for a private company called IP3 International, a firm run by retired US military generals with a clear financial interest in exporting US nuclear energy technology to Saudi Arabia. Once Trump was inaugurated, Flynn, along with longtime Trump associate Thomas Barrack, worked with other senior officials in the new Trump administration to make the plan a reality.

On January 27, 2017, just seven days after the inauguration, several retired generals from IP3 visited the White House to discuss the nuclear plan for Saudi Arabia with Derek Harvey, a senior staffer on Trump's National Security Council at the time. According to the House report, Harvey immediately directed the NSC staff to add information about IP3's "plan for 40 nuclear power plants" to the briefing package for President Trump's call with Saudi Arabia's King Salman.

As of now, the proposal's status is unclear, but the White House is still in discussions to sell nuclear equipment to Saudi Arabia despite fierce Democratic opposition. To sell nuclear technology to a foreign country, the US must sign a "123 agreement," as per Section 123 of the 1954 US Atomic Energy Act. If a country wants to buy nuclear equipment from the US, it must meet nine conditions, including a guarantee that it will not use the technology to make nuclear weapons.

According to the Democrats' report, Harvey ignored the requirements for a 123 agreement and insisted that the decision to transfer nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia had already been made. If true, this could potentially allow Riyadh to pursue a nuclear weapon with US-sold equipment in the future.

Furthermore, there is concern over Michael Flynn's personal involvement in the deal. Flynn had previously consulted for IP3, and "whistleblowers" who spoke with House Democrats were reportedly worried about Flynn potentially violating ethics rules. White House ethics officials apparently raised these concerns, with one senior political official reportedly stating that Harvey's proposal was "not a business plan," but rather "a scheme for these generals to make some money."

The report's release marks a significant step in House Democrats' oversight of Trump's foreign policy, as promised when they took the House last November. The report provides new details about the Saudi nuclear deal's progression from an idea conceived by Flynn and a few retired generals to a serious policy being pursued at the highest levels of the White House.

The report's release could potentially hinder the White House's ability to sign the nuclear deal with Saudi Arabia, as it is now met with stiff resistance from Democrats in Congress. This development may be a warning shot, but it could also signal bigger things to come in terms of Democratic oversight of Trump's foreign policy.

Title: Florida Stops Publishing Real-Time Coronavirus Death Data Compiled by Medical Examiners

Article:

Florida health officials have ceased publishing real-time coronavirus death data reported by medical examiners, following a discrepancy between the data and the official state total. The last nine days have seen the withholding of lists compiled by the state Medical Examiners Commission.

The change in policy was initiated after state health officials intervened, according to Dr. Stephen Nelson, who heads the commission. The officials plan to redact causes of deaths and descriptions of cases from the data, a move Nelson described as making the lists "meaningless."

Dr. Nelson stated, "This is no different than any other public record we deal with. It's paid for by taxpayer dollars, and the taxpayers have a right to know." He added that the lists have always been made public since medical examiners began to compile them in 1992.

Paul Petrino, who runs the Palm Beach County medical examiner's office, told The Tampa Bay Times that county lawyers instructed him to stop releasing the numbers last week. Petrino expressed concern that the data's public release was important for individuals to have accurate information about the health crisis.

The Florida Department of Health told The Times that it "participated in conference calls" with law enforcement officials to express "privacy concerns for the individuals that passed away related to COVID-19." The health department's actions come after it attempted to block access to death records last month, according to The Miami Herald.

Barbara Petersen of the First Amendment Foundation told The Times, "It's just shocking to me the level of interference." Florida's Democratic congressional delegation wrote a letter to Governor Ron DeSantis last week, questioning the "inconsistencies between COVID-19 death tracking methods used by the Florida Department of Health and county medical examiners."

The efforts to keep public health information under wraps come as Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, a Republican, moved to reopen parts of the state's economy after delaying issuing a stay-at-home order earlier in the outbreak. DeSantis announced the plan to reopen on Wednesday, as the state saw its largest spike in coronavirus deaths since the pandemic began.

Title: "Me Too Movement: A Reassessment of the #MeToo Era and Its Impact on Society"

Article:

The phrase "Me Too" has undergone a significant transformation in meaning since its inception eighty years ago. Originally, it described a group of Republicans who publicly supported the policies of Franklin Roosevelt, leading to the nomination of a Republican presidential candidate who had recently switched parties. Today, the term "Me Too" refers to a social and cultural movement that aims to address sexual harassment and assault, particularly in the workplace.

The movement has gained momentum in recent years, leading to the ousting of numerous high-profile figures in media, entertainment, and politics. One of the latest targets of the movement is Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, who faces allegations of sexual assault made by Christine Blasey Ford.

The allegations against Kavanaugh have sparked a heated debate, with some questioning the credibility of Ford's story. Ford has declined to testify under oath, her story conflicts with that of the man she names as an eyewitness, and the notes taken by her therapist do not provide a clear account of the alleged assault. Additionally, Ford's history of supporting left-wing causes has raised questions about her motives.

Despite these uncertainties, many prominent Democratic politicians have called for belief in Ford's story. Senator Mazie Hirono declared, "They need to be believed," while Hillary Clinton stated, "You have the right to be believed."

The movement's emphasis on belief, rather than evidence, has sparked controversy. Those who express skepticism about the allegations against Kavanaugh or other high-profile figures accused of sexual misconduct are often met with criticism and backlash.

The #MeToo movement's impact extends beyond the political sphere. Comedian Norm Macdonald was disinvited from The Tonight Show after expressing support for the slowdown of the #MeToo movement. Macdonald faces no accusations of misconduct, but he stated that he was "happy" the movement had slowed down. NBC's decision to remove Macdonald from its airwaves was seen as a rebuke of his opinion, contradicting the notion that the movement had slowed down.

Similarly, editor Ian Buruma was forced to resign from the New York Review of Books after publishing an essay by Jian Gomeshi, a talk show host accused of sexual assault but acquitted in court. The backlash against Buruma's decision to publish Gomeshi's essay, despite his acquittal, led to a boycott by university presses that advertise in the magazine, ultimately resulting in Buruma's resignation.

The #MeToo movement's emphasis on belief, rather than due process, has raised concerns about freedom of speech and the presumption of innocence. The movement's impact on comedians, writers, and other public figures has been significant, with many expressing a desire for the movement to slow down or change course.

The #MeToo movement has undoubtedly brought attention to an important issue and led to changes in behavior among powerful individuals. However, the movement's emphasis on belief, rather than evidence, and its impact on freedom of speech and due process have sparked controversy and raised concerns about unintended consequences. As the movement continues to evolve, it remains to be seen whether it can find a balance between addressing sexual harassment and assault and upholding the principles of fairness and justice.

Title: Global Entities Condemn U.S. Investigation into Auto Tariffs

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to launch an investigation into potential tariffs on vehicle and automotive part imports into the United States has been met with condemnation from China, Japan, and the European Union. The move, which invokes a provision allowing the president to restrict imports and impose unlimited tariffs on national security grounds, is seen as a bargaining tool in stalled talks over the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico.

According to the Department of Commerce, Mexico is the top exporter of passenger vehicles and light trucks to the U.S, followed by Japan, Canada, Germany, and South Korea. Japan, which accounts for about 40 percent of U.S. vehicle imports, has expressed concern over the potential impact of such measures, with Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry, Hiroshige Seko, stating that such a measure would "put the global market into turmoil."

Germany's association of industry groups has also voiced opposition, describing auto tariffs as a "provocation" and "another nasty blow to our economic relations" with the United States. The EU executive has stated that such a move would be against the rules of global trade.

In Beijing, Commerce Ministry spokesman Gao Feng expressed similar sentiments, stating that abusing national security provisions would "undermine the multilateral trade system and disrupt the order of international trade." China, a relatively minor player in the U.S. auto import market, has expressed a desire to expand abroad, with China being ranked second in auto parts exports to the U.S last year.

Japanese and European automakers have not issued individual comments, but some have referred to Global Automakers, an industry group of international automakers based in Washington. Global Automakers Chief Executive John Bozzella stated that the move would "hurt American consumers" and lead to "fewer choices and higher prices for cars and trucks in America."

Last week, Japan went to the World Trade Organization to warn of possible retaliation for tariffs on steel and aluminum, which Trump imposed in March. Japan is the only major U.S. ally that was not granted a temporary exemption from the tariffs. Japan estimates these tariffs will cost it about 50 billion yen ( $ 450 million ) a year.

Reports suggest that the president has proposed seeking new tariffs of 20 to 25 percent on automobile imports. Critics fear that other countries may retaliate with trade sanctions of their own and question the effectiveness of such a move given the lengthy review required and potential legal challenges ahead.

Title: Senate Rules Committee's Statement on Press Access Sparks Controversy

Article:

The Senate Rules Committee's recent statement regarding press access on the Senate side of the Capitol complex has sparked controversy among journalists and senators alike. The statement, issued by Chairman Richard Shelby, clarified that no changes have been made to the existing rules governing press coverage, but noted that the committee has been working with press galleries to ensure compliance with these rules to maintain a "safe environment" for everyone.

The "safety" concern is not entirely fabricated, as the Capitol is currently experiencing a surge in the number of reporters. A veteran reporter estimates that under the Trump administration, there are approximately double the number of reporters on the Hill on average legislative days compared to previous administrations. This influx of journalists is due to the increased amount of news coming from the Hill, as the government is currently unified under one party and working towards long-standing ideological goals.

The head of the unified government, President Donald Trump, is a subject of much media scrutiny, with ongoing investigations into Russian interference in the election and questions regarding his actions and policies. This has led to an increased number of questions from reporters to Republican lawmakers, many of which are not met with enthusiasm.

While White House and campaign reporters do not have the same level of access to principals as Capitol Hill reporters, the open press access on the Hill allows for more direct interaction between journalists and senators. If open press access on the Hill were restricted, one more branch of public communication would be conducted exclusively through flacks, and one more check on power would be impeded.

If senators are truly concerned about the size of reporter mobs and their safety, they could be more forthcoming with information about their policies, perhaps through regular press conferences. This would reduce the need for reporters to be creative in their methods of obtaining information.

Until such a day comes, it is important to maintain a safe and open environment for both journalists and senators, and to avoid any potential accidents that could result from the crowded conditions on Capitol Hill.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Calls for GOP to "Stop Being the Stupid Party"

Article:

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, a potential 2016 presidential contender, called on the Republican Party to "stop being the stupid party" during a keynote address at the Republican National Committee's winter meeting on Thursday. In his 25-minute speech, Jindal suggested that the GOP might need to change its strategies and messaging to appeal to a rapidly changing American electorate.

Jindal's address came as Republican leaders promised to release a report, titled the "Growth and Opportunity Project," in March, outlining recommendations on party rules and messaging. The report aims to address the party's struggles in recent elections, particularly in winning over women and minority voters.

President Barack Obama's November victory was fueled, in part, by overwhelming support from the nation's Hispanic, Asian, and African-American communities. Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney and down-ticket candidates alienated many of these voters with comments and policies perceived as offensive or insensitive.

GOP strategist Sally Bradshaw, who is part of a team appointed by RNC Chairman Reince Priebus to craft the report, stated, "I think you're going to see a very renewed, aggressive effort by this party to put on a different face."

Jindal called on conservatives to shift their focus from Capitol Hill number crunching to "the place where conservatism thrives -- in the real world beyond the Washington Beltway."

Hours before the speech, Republican leaders promised to release a report outlining recommendations on party rules and messaging designed to appeal to a rapidly changing American electorate. The report, dubbed the "Growth and Opportunity Project," is set to be released in March.

In the speech, Jindal offered little detail on specific changes but emphasized the need for the GOP to connect with voters across the nation and focus on real-world issues rather than Washington politics.

Jindal's comments come a day after the House passed a bill to permit the government to borrow enough money to avoid a first-time default for at least four months. The House passed the measure on a bipartisan basis, with majority Republicans backtracking on their previous demand for an equivalent level of spending cuts in exchange for an increase in the government's borrowing cap.

Jindal's blunt remarks follow criticism from another high-profile Republican, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, who publicly blasted GOP leadership on Capitol Hill for their handling of disaster relief for victims of Superstorm Sandy. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested that Republicans could use hearings to expose waste and promote better ideas.

Title: Supreme Court Overturns Alabama Redistricting Plan, Deems District Court Ruling "Legally Erroneous"

Article:

The United States Supreme Court has overturned a district court ruling that upheld Alabama's redistricting plan, which allegedly overloaded some districts with black Democratic voters. In a 5-to-4 ruling, the justices rejected the lower court's decision and sent it back for reevaluation.

Justice Stephen Breyer, who delivered the opinion, was joined by the court's other liberal justices, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sonia Sotomayor, Elena Kagan, and Anthony Kennedy, the swing vote. The court's conservatives—Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Antonin Scalia, Samuel Alito, and Clarence Thomas—dissented. Thomas wrote a separate dissent.

As reported by NPR's Nina Totenberg last November, the high court was asked to decide "whether a 2010 state legislative redistricting in Alabama overloaded some districts with black Democrats on the basis of race or party."

In 2000, Democrats controlled the state Legislature and the redistricting process. They used their power to create districts with black majorities under the Voting Rights Act, while at the same time putting enough reliably Democratic black voters into majority white districts so that white Democratic candidates could build black-white coalitions and have a chance of winning. By 2010, Republicans controlled the Legislature, and they set about consolidating the black vote into existing majority-black districts. Under the plan, about one-sixth of all eligible black voters were moved from majority white state Senate districts to majority-black districts. The result was that in some of those districts, the black majority increased to over 70 percent. At the same time, the majority white districts got whiter, and more safely Republican.

The redistricting came after the 2010 census showed population shifts that made some existing districts too big in population terms, and others too small. The Republicans tried to equalize the size of the districts. They also tried to maintain the same number of majority-black districts, contending that under the Voting Rights Act, a simple majority of black voters in those districts was not enough. Democrats disagree and contend that the GOP plan calls for unconstitutional racial quotas.

According to The Associated Press, Justice Breyer said the lower court "should have reviewed claims of racial gerrymandering on a district-by-district level, not just statewide. He also said the court did not apply the right test when it found that race was not the primary motivating factor."

State officials claim they had no choice but to concentrate black voters in some districts, making neighboring seats more white and apt to elect Republicans.

Title: GOP Divisions Threaten Immigration Reform Unity on Capitol Hill

Article:

Following the 2016 election, there appears to be a GOP consensus on the need for immigration reform; however, a significant obstacle could derail a potential deal: disagreement among Republicans in Congress regarding the approach to take. Some favor piecemeal reform, addressing popular issues while leaving contentious matters, such as a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, for later consideration. Others advocate for a comprehensive deal to tackle the issue holistically.

The rifts that existed prior to the election persist, with scant evidence of a promised comprehensive immigration reform materializing as of yet. "Doing a comprehensive bill is a big mistake," said Rep. Raul Labrador (R-Idaho), who supports a piece-by-piece approach. "What you end up having is a bill that nobody likes. Everybody hates one piece of it. It's a way to actually avoid doing what we need to do to solve the immigration problem."

Republicans advocating for a piecemeal approach argue that starting with politically palatable components could generate bipartisan momentum for a broader overhaul. They also point to the frustration generated by large legislative efforts like the Affordable Care Act and the Dodd-Frank financial reform law.

Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas), the incoming Senate minority whip, noted, "There's going to be a natural desire to try to pair things up [on immigration]. But at some point, the bill gets so big and cumbersome that I think by virtue of the size alone, that that makes it harder to pass."

The general outlines of a comprehensive package are clear, encompassing provisions on border security, law enforcement, reforms to the legal immigration system, and a solution for the undocumented immigrants residing in the United States. The contentious issue lies in the last component, which Democrats fear would be neglected if Congress dismantles immigration reform piece by piece.

A pathway to citizenship is the one thing Democrats and immigration advocates will demand, but it is certain to encounter the strongest GOP resistance. "That is probably the part of immigration reform that needs the greatest reform," said Rep. Charles Gonzalez (D-Texas), the outgoing chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. "That's why I've never really understood that people really believe that this piecemeal thing is going to get us anywhere."

California Rep. Xavier Becerra, the incoming House Democratic Caucus chairman, added, "Why only half fix the problem? Let's go ahead and fix the whole thing. If you've got a machine that's not working well, you're not going to fix just half of it and have it still not work well, let's go ahead and fix it right."

Title: Fiscal Slope: Gradual Tax Increases and Spending Cuts as a Solution to the U.S. Budget Crisis

Article:

The ongoing debate regarding the so-called "fiscal cliff" in the United States is not as dire as some have portrayed it. While the potential tax increases and spending cuts, with the exception of the payroll tax increase and extended unemployment benefits, are not expected to take effect on January 1, 2013, or February 1, 2013, if a budget deal is not reached by those dates, the "dramatic impact" on the economy is largely exaggerated.

If President Barack Obama and Capitol Hill lawmakers remain rational and dispassionate, they can mitigate the impact of the fiscal situation by turning the fiscal slope into a smaller or "bunny slope," to borrow a skiing metaphor. This approach, which involves four key elements, would help lessen the impact of a budget deal and gradually reduce the budget deficit.

Element 1: Instead of letting all of the 2001-2003 Bush income tax cuts for families with income over $250,000 per year and individuals over $200,000 expire, the income tax cuts for these groups could be halved on January 1, 2013, and the second half could expire on January 1, 2014. This would result in an income tax increase of approximately $26 billion to $30 billion per year.

Element 2: The sequestration, which involves approximately $100 billion in automatic spending cuts, half from the Department of Defense and half from non-defense programs, could be elongated to three years. In 2013, $20 billion could be cut from DOD and $20 billion from non-defense programs, with the same amount being cut in 2014 and 2015. This would result in a total of $120 billion in cuts over three years, with a $40 billion spending reduction each year.

Element 3: The payroll tax that funds Social Security could be increased to its normal rate of 6.2 percent from 4.2 percent over two years, to 5.2 percent in 2013, and to 6.2 percent in 2014. This would reduce the budget deficit by about $48 billion each year.

Element 4: Business expense tax write-offs, and other business tax provisions, could be allowed to expire over two years, with half expiring in 2013, and half in 2014. This would further reduce the deficit by about $30 billion per year.

The aforementioned tax and spending changes would cut the budget deficit by an equal amount, approximately $148 billion, in both 2013 and 2014, decreasing the projected budget deficit to $980 billion in 2013, and $832 billion in 2014.

Assuming tax or spending policies remain the same after 2014, and the U.S. economy grows at a 3.0 percent rate, the budget deficit should decline to about $652 billion in 2015, $452 billion in 2016, and $230 billion in 2017. In 2017, the budget deficit will occur in a roughly $3.9 trillion U.S. budget, with the net interest payment on the national debt being about $350 billion to $380 billion.

In other words, by deploying the "bunny slope" plan of gradual tax increases and spending cuts, the non-debt-service portion of the U.S. budget will be balanced by the end of 2017. Investors and typical Americans should not agonize over the current budget talks, as the so-called fiscal cliff is really a fiscal slope, and the slope that exists can be converted into a bunny slope, further mitigating any GDP impact, so long as Obama and Congress remain rational and dispassionate. The two parties need to meet in a room and not return until a budget deal is reached. And when the budget deal is reached, the American people, and probably the late, great LBJ, as well, will be very proud.

Title: Trump's Proposed Tariffs on Mexican Goods: Potential Economic Impact and Implications

Article:

President Donald Trump's proposed 25% tariff on Mexican goods could significantly increase the existing tariffs on aluminum and steel imports, as well as Chinese imports. The United States has already collected approximately $19 billion in tariffs under Trump's administration. If implemented, the new tariff could potentially add up to $87 billion annually to this total.

Mexico is expected to retaliate with counter-tariffs, which could negatively impact sectors such as American agriculture. Two weeks ago, Trump ended a tariff on Mexican aluminum and steel, and Mexico reciprocated by ending a tariff on American farm goods. However, this brief respite may be short-lived, as farmers may need to re-evaluate their export markets.

The question remains whether the potential benefits of the tariff outweigh the economic pain. Trump is using tariffs as a means to pressure Mexico into strengthening border control measures. While the cost of the tariff would be borne by Americans, the Mexican economy could also suffer from a loss of sales to the United States.

Trump's strategy of linking immigration and economic issues could potentially disrupt both economies. The manufacturing sectors in Mexico and the United States are closely integrated, with about two-thirds of trade between the countries involving factories owned by the same company, according to Deutsche Bank.

Immigrants seeking to cross the southern border primarily originate from Central America, issues that are largely beyond the control of the Mexican government. While Trump often refers to all immigrants as illegal, many are exercising a legal right to seek asylum.

Previous administrations have sought cooperation from Mexico on immigration matters without disrupting economic relations between the two countries. Trump's decision to conflate the two issues could potentially lead to economic disruption in both countries due to the interconnected nature of their manufacturing sectors.

Title: Sen. Amy Klobuchar Withdraws from Vice Presidential Consideration, Advocates for a Woman of Color

Article:

Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) announced on Thursday that she is withdrawing her name from consideration as Joe Biden's running mate, stating that a woman of color should be chosen as the vice-presidential nominee instead.

In the aftermath of this announcement, some political observers have speculated that Klobuchar may have anticipated a potential backlash, with some Black Lives Matter activists expressing disapproval of her candidacy. However, the exact reasons for Klobuchar's decision remain unclear.

If the Democratic ticket, led by Biden and Klobuchar, were to lose the 2020 presidential election, some have suggested that Klobuchar could face criticism for not being able to help boost African-American turnout in key states such as Florida, Pennsylvania, Ohio, and North Carolina. This hypothetical scenario, in which Biden wins the presidency but fails to secure the necessary electoral votes, would likely result in a significant amount of frustration within the Democratic Party.

Should a Biden administration come into power, there may be cabinet positions available for Klobuchar if she chooses to accept one. It is also possible that Biden may feel obligated to offer her a prestigious post as a gesture of gratitude for her support during the primary and her decision to step aside in the running-mate selection process.

Regardless of the outcome of the 2020 election, it is unlikely that Klobuchar will be held responsible for any shortcomings of the Democratic ticket.

Title: Sixty Percent of Americans Disapprove of President Trump's Job Performance in New Washington Post-ABC News Poll

Article:

A new poll conducted by The Washington Post and ABC News shows that 60 percent of Americans disapprove of President Donald Trump's job performance, marking a new high in disapproval for the president. The poll, released on Friday, was conducted just days after special counsel Robert Mueller delivered a series of legal blows to the Trump administration.

The poll, which was conducted last week, found that only slightly more than one-third of Americans, 36 percent, approve of Trump's job performance. In the previous Washington Post-ABC News poll, conducted in April, Trump's approval rating was 40 percent, and his disapproval rating was 56 percent.

The poll also found that most Americans would oppose Trump granting a pardon to former associate Paul Manafort, with 66 percent of respondents saying they were against a pardon. Only 18 percent said they would support a pardon.

Trump has recently focused negative attention on Attorney General Jeff Sessions, whom Trump has blamed for Mueller's investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 campaign. However, a majority of Americans, 62 percent, side with Sessions, with 64 percent saying Trump should not fire Sessions.

Special counsel Robert Mueller saw similar positive percentages, with 63 percent of those polled supporting Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, and 29 percent saying they oppose it. Further, 53 percent of respondents said they think Trump tried to interfere in Mueller's investigation in a way that "amounts to obstruction of justice," while 35 percent said he did not try to interfere.

A similar portion of survey respondents, 61 percent, said they believe it would be a crime if Trump directed Michael Cohen to make hush-money payments to two women who say they had affairs with Trump during the 2016 election. Cohen pleaded guilty to making payments of that nature, violating campaign-finance laws at the "direction of a candidate for federal office," meaning Trump.

However, when it comes to the economy, Americans were more favorable in their evaluations of the president. Forty-five percent of those polled said they approve of Trump's handling of the economy, while 47 percent said they disapprove.

The poll, which included a sample of 1,003 adults, was conducted from Aug. 26 to Aug. 29 via landlines and cellphones. The poll's margin of error was plus-or-minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Seven Potential Inflection Points in the Tight Presidential Race Between Obama and Romney

Article:

In the ongoing race between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, the contest remains a close one, as indicated by numerous polls. With the Supreme Court's health care ruling now decided, both campaigns are focusing on a limited number of significant events that could influence the election's outcome.

The campaign, marked by swift news cycles, has remained relatively stable since the primaries concluded. In various national surveys, the race is a tight 3-percentage-point contest, with Obama slightly below 50 percent and Romney around 45 percent.

"It didn't take long for the race to solidify. There's no reason to think it won't stay solidified," said Democratic strategist Steve Murphy.

Both candidates are running cautious campaigns, offering little in the way of future vision, and neither has much incentive to change their strategies.

"In a race as close as this one's likely to be, both candidates are going to be ultra-cautious," said Dan Schnur, head of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California. "It's hard to see one of them taking the kind of risk that would be necessary to dramatically change the trajectory."

Several potential inflection points are on the horizon, some known and scheduled, others looming but not yet materialized. Some are within the control of the campaigns, such as their debate performances, while others are global events that could impact voter perceptions of one or both candidates, such as a financial crisis in debt-ridden Europe.

"This race is going to be very close, and there's plenty of action left to come that can influence it—unemployment numbers, credit downgrading, European crisis, VP choice (a little), the health care ruling fallout, and there's always the potential of Mideast or other foreign policy issues flaring up," said Republican strategist Curt Anderson. "But the truth is, there is a lot more peril than upside in all these things for President Obama."

Below are seven potential inflection points that could alter the current close race:

1. Unemployment Numbers: The state of the economy, particularly unemployment rates, could significantly impact the election's outcome.
2. Credit Downgrading: Changes in the U.S. credit rating could affect voter perceptions of the economy and the candidates.
3. European Crisis: The ongoing financial crisis in Europe could impact voter perceptions of the candidates' economic policies and ability to handle global economic issues.
4. Vice Presidential Candidates: The selection of vice presidential candidates could sway undecided voters or solidify support for either candidate.
5. Health Care Ruling Fallout: The impact of the Supreme Court's health care ruling on voter perceptions of the Affordable Care Act and the candidates' positions on health care reform.
6. Middle East or Foreign Policy Issues: Developments in the Middle East or other foreign policy issues could impact voter perceptions of the candidates' foreign policy expertise and ability to handle international crises.
7. Debate Performances: The upcoming debates between Obama and Romney could significantly impact voter perceptions of the candidates' qualifications and leadership abilities.

Title: U.S. Economy Contracts in Q4 2013, First Time Since End of 2008 Recession

Article:

The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) reported a slight contraction of 0.1% in the U.S. economy in the fourth quarter of 2013, marking the first time the American economy has shrunk since the end of the 2008 recession. The real gross domestic product (GDP) decreased at an annual rate of 0.1% in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter, following a 3.1% increase in the previous quarter.

The downturn in real GDP was primarily due to decreases in private inventory investment, federal government spending, exports, and state and local government spending. These decreases were partly offset by an upturn in nonresidential fixed investment, a larger decrease in imports, and an acceleration in personal consumption expenditures (PCE).

The 22% decline in federal military spending was a significant factor in the economic contraction. Nonmilitary spending by the federal government increased by 6%, but this increase was not sufficient to offset the decline in military spending cuts. One possible reason for the sharp decline in defense spending is the looming threat of the budget sequester brought on by the 2011 Budget Control Act. The Department of Defense may have made up for the prospective budget cuts in Q3 2012 before paring back in Q4.

The March budget sequester is still scheduled to take place, and the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the defense spending cuts will result in a 0.4% drop in GDP. Members of Congress from both sides of the aisle will have to agree on some sort of package to delay the cuts to avoid a potential recession.

The GDP report was not entirely negative, as personal consumption spending and investment were growing at 2.2% and 8.4%, respectively. The boost in personal spending was driven mostly by durable goods, indicating that consumers may be replacing worn-out items. However, the lack of consumer confidence could spell trouble for the recovery.

The BEA emphasized that the fourth-quarter advance estimate released today is based on incomplete or subjective data and is subject to further revision. The "second" estimate for the fourth quarter, based on more complete data, will be released on February 28, 2013.

Title: Romney's Foreign Policy Stance: A Look at His Middle East and Iran Policies

Article:

In a speech at the Virginia Military Institute (VMI) last week, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney addressed the Middle East and Iran, leaving himself a degree of flexibility in his policy proposals.

Regarding the Palestinian issue, Romney stated, "I will recommit America to the goal of a democratic, prosperous Palestinian state living side by side in peace and security with the Jewish state of Israel." He criticized President Barack Obama for failing to achieve this goal.

While Romney's speech emphasized the theme of the Obama administration's "weakness" and abandonment of allies, his specific policy proposals on issues like Iran's nuclear program and military aid to difficult allies like Pakistan or Egypt show similarities to Obama's approach.

The speech did not provide specific details on the resources Romney would devote to these tasks, and it appears that the candidate has not engaged deeply with these issues during the campaign. However, a half dozen advisers stated that this is partly due to Romney's lack of enthusiasm for these issues compared to domestic economic issues.

Romney's foreign policy team has been evolving, with Richard S. Williamson, Mitchell B. Reiss, and Jim Talent playing central roles. Liz Cheney, who served in the State Department during the Bush administration, has also joined a weekly conference call.

Divisions within the foreign policy team remain, with some advisers advocating for more specificity in Romney's statements. The neoconservative faction around John R. Bolton, who has expressed displeasure with working through international organizations, has been largely absent from the calls.

Romney's stance on Syria and Iran has been subject to some confusion. In a television interview, he seemed to forget his position on preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear "capability" and sounded like he was in agreement with Obama on simply stopping Iran from gaining a nuclear weapon. In the VMI speech, he returned to the promise to "prevent them from acquiring a nuclear weapons capability."

The Romney campaign's foreign policy team is awaiting resolution of these internal disputes until after the election. Notable figures from establishment Republican foreign policy circles, such as Henry A. Kissinger, have been absent from the team.

Title: Market Analysts Offer Cautious Outlook on U.S. Economic Recovery

Article:

Stocks experienced volatile trading on Wednesday as the U.S. economy began to reopen. The market showed mixed results, with bank stocks rising, but tech-focused "stay-at-home" plays declining. Market analysts and economists are divided on the timeline for economic recovery.

David Lebovitz, global market strategist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management, expressed caution due to uncertainties surrounding the reopening process. He stated, "We have been surprised by the speed and the magnitude at which things have moved, but when you think about building a diversified portfolio, you have the 10-year Treasury yield at 70 basis points. Equities look attractive even if they're trading at north of 20 times. So, we have been encouraging folks to stay long equities despite some of the risks that exist."

Lebovitz's caution stems from the unknowns about reopening the economy, particularly the capacity requirements for businesses to break even, which he estimates to be around 75%. He also noted that turning the economy back on is more challenging than turning it off.

Mike Mayo, managing director and head of U.S. large-cap bank research at Wells Fargo Securities, suggested that the Federal Reserve should let its policies from the previous recession work. He stated, "We've run over 200 earnings models. We've run different scenarios: a V recovery, a U recovery, an L recovery, and it's pretty tough, we think, for the government to conclude that large banks, well-capitalized banks, well-capitalized banks that earned their dividend twice over in the first quarter, in a quarter when they built reserves, we find it very tough for the Fed to conclude that banks should cut the dividends now."

Jason Furman, economic policy professor at Harvard University and former chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, warned investors not to get too eager too soon. He predicted, "I think we're going to have two phases from here. One is a partial bounce back, which will be very rapid. It'll look like we're on the upslope of a V. We've already seen that. When you look at daily data, it bottomed out… around April 15. You've even seen growth in consumption spending, a decent amount of it, from April 15 to May 15. Problem is that's the low-hanging fruit of growth where you turn the lights back on, call some of the furloughed workers back. There's a lot more people that are not coming back to their jobs, businesses that are not going to be revived, and so once you get past that first phase, I think you're in for a long and painful slog."

Title: New York Attorney General's Office Alleges $1 Billion in Hidden Assets by Sackler Family in Ongoing Opioid Crisis Case

Article:

The New York Attorney General's office has alleged in court filings on Friday that the Sackler family, defendants in an ongoing case against Purdue Pharma and the opioid crisis, may have been attempting to hide approximately $1 billion in assets. The filings, which result from subpoenas issued to several financial institutions believed to have information related to the defendants, reveal about $1 billion in wire transfers between and among the Sacklers and their shell companies during the same time frame that they were allegedly draining Purdue Pharma of its opioid proceeds.

New York Attorney General Letitia James stated in a Friday release, "While the Sacklers continue to lowball victims and skirt a responsible settlement, we refuse to allow the family to misuse the courts in an effort to shield their financial misconduct."

The limited number of documents provided to the New York Attorney General's office so far underscores the necessity for compliance with every subpoena, according to James. Records from one financial institution alone have shown approximately $1 billion in wire transfers between the Sacklers, entities they control, and different financial institutions, including those that have funneled funds into Swiss bank accounts.

The New York Attorney General's office is continuing to investigate whether these transactions were a deliberate attempt by the family that owns Purdue Pharma to conceal assets from litigants.

Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin, is facing thousands of lawsuits linked to the opioid crisis that has resulted in tens of thousands of deaths in the U.S. The company announced earlier this week that it had reached a tentative settlement with thousands of local governments and more than 20 states, with a $3 billion upfront payment and additional funds from the sale of Mundipharma, a sister company of Purdue Pharma also owned by the Sacklers.

According to The Associated Press, citing anonymous sources with knowledge of the talks, Purdue would pay up to $12 billion, and the Sackler family would relinquish control of the company. The agreement would not include an admission of guilt.

In response to the proposed settlement, Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey stated, "This apparent settlement is a slap in the face to everyone who has had to bury a loved one due to this family's destruction and greed."

James, in response to the proposed settlement, told ███ in a statement that the deal "does not account for the depth of pain and destruction caused by Purdue and the Sacklers" and that it was "an insult, plain and simple."

A spokesperson for Mortimer D.A. Sackler, formerly a Purdue board member, stated in a statement to The New York Times, "This is a cynical attempt by a hostile A.G.'s office to generate defamatory headlines to try to torpedo a mutually beneficial settlement that is supported by so many other states and would result in billions of dollars going to communities and individuals across the country that need help."

Title: President Obama's Remark on the Private Sector Sparks Controversy

Article:

President Barack Obama found himself at the center of a political storm on Friday after he made an off-hand comment during a White House news conference that the private sector was "doing fine." The statement opened the door for withering attacks from Republican lawmakers and presidential candidates.

During the news conference, Obama was asked to respond to Republican criticisms that his economic policies were failing and that Europe's economic policies were to blame. In response, Obama highlighted the job creation in the private sector, stating that over 4.3 million jobs had been created during his two-year tenure, with 800,000 jobs added this year alone.

However, Obama's comment that the private sector was "doing fine" was met with immediate criticism. House Speaker John Boehner, House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, and Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney were among those who seized on the remark, arguing that the private sector was not in good shape.

In a Capitol Hill availability with journalists, Boehner was the first to respond, stating, "Mr. President, I used to run a small business. And, Mr. President, take it from me, the private sector is not doing well." Cantor followed suit, saying, "As the speaker said, we just listened to the president say the private sector is doing fine. I would say Mr. President, are you kidding? Did you see the jobs numbers last week? The private sector is not doing fine."

Romney, on the campaign trail in Iowa, also weighed in, saying, "He said the private sector is doing fine. Is he really that out of touch?"

Senator Mitch McConnell and many other Republicans also joined in the criticism, using the hashtag #doingfine on Twitter to express their disapproval.

The remark may have been a response to the way Democrats, including Obama, criticized Senator John McCain in 2008 when he said, "The fundamentals of our economy are strong" during the height of the Great Recession.

John Dickerson, who writes for Slate and does political analysis for CBS News, suggested that Obama's remark could be seen as a lack of concern for the very poor. In a tweet, he wrote, "`private sector is doing fine' = `not concerned about the very poor.' Discuss."

In an attempt to clarify his remarks, Obama told journalists during a photo op with Philippine President Benigno Aquino that he was not out of touch with reality and that he understood that the economy as a whole was not "fine."

The White House later clarified that Obama was referring to the fact that the private sector had been adding jobs throughout the recovery, while state and local governments had been shedding jobs, which had helped to restrain job growth. However, the damage had already been done, and the "private sector is doing fine" remark was likely to be a recurring theme in the political discourse in the coming days.

Title: Republican Party Faces Internal Divide After Contentious Nomination Race

Article:

The Republican Party is grappling with internal discord following the tumultuous nomination race, according to comments made by Mr. Buchanan. He stated, "Putting the party back together again will be very hard after this nomination race." The party, he believes, may shift towards a more nationalist, tribal, and protectionist stance, with a focus on border protection.

This internal strife within the Republican ranks has been brewing since the end of the George W. Bush administration, initially over policy differences and later over the party's response to the country's evolving demography. While some party leaders, such as Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, argue that the Republican Party is in a "demographic death spiral" and must appeal to Hispanics and young people to survive, many voters view such statements as a concession.

Instead, these voters yearn for an uncompromising brand of conservatism that confronts rather than accommodates the political establishment, a sentiment that has been reinforced by conservative talk radio hosts like Rush Limbaugh and commentators like Ann Coulter, whose influential rhetoric shapes the party's agenda.

Laura Ingraham, a talk-show host who played a significant role in the primary election defeat of Eric Cantor, then the House majority leader, in 2014, echoed this sentiment, stating, "All the things the voters want have been shoved off to the sidelines by Republican leaders. And the voters finally have a couple of people here who are saying this table has to be turned over."

Regardless of the nominee, the party's divisions will be challenging to mend. If an establishment candidate secures the nomination, the highly energized supporters of Trump and Cruz may rebel, with about two-thirds of Trump supporters indicating they would vote for him as a third-party candidate, according to a Suffolk University/USA Today poll last month. This could potentially aid the Democratic nominee.

If Mr. Cruz is nominated, he will need to win over party leaders without appearing to betray his anti-establishment supporters. A Fox News poll released on Friday found that 66 percent of Cruz supporters in Iowa felt "betrayed" by politicians in their party.

In the event party leaders support Mr. Trump, they would need to run parallel campaigns, backing a candidate who has advocated for mass deportation of illegal immigrants and a temporary ban on Muslims, while simultaneously attempting to diversify their predominantly white male base.

Title: Clinton Email Scandal: A Closer Look at the Allegations and Implications

Article:

The ongoing controversy surrounding the emails sent and received by Hillary Clinton during her tenure as U.S. Secretary of State has escalated, with Clinton admitting to deleting 30,000 government emails and using a personal server for official correspondence.

Federal law defines emails used during the course of one's work for the federal government as the property of the federal government. Clinton could have designated which of the government's emails were personal and then asked the government to send them to her and delete them from government servers. Instead, she decided which of her emails were governmental and sent them on to the State Department. Under federal law, that is not a determination she may lawfully make.

Clinton's decision to use a personal server for government emails has raised concerns about the potential theft of metadata and the denial of the opportunity for the government to trace those emails. When asked why she chose to divert government emails through her own server, Clinton stated she believed it would enable her to carry just one mobile device for both personal and governmental emails. However, she later admitted she carried four such devices.

The scandal took a more serious turn when Clinton's lawyers revealed that after deleting the 30,000 emails and printing the 55,000 she surrendered to the feds, she had the server that carried and stored them professionally wiped clean. Clinton has denied routing classified materials through her server, but both the inspector general of the State Department and the inspector general of the intelligence community found four classified emails among a random sample of 40.

One of the four emails was found to be top secret, containing satellite imagery of a foreign country and intercepts of communications among foreign agents. If Clinton is indicted for failure to secure classified information, she will likely argue that if one of the above markings was not on the email, she did not know it was top secret. However, this argument could be met with a judicial instruction to the jury trying her case, stating that the secretary of state is presumed to know what is top secret and what is not.

The potential consequences of Clinton's behavior with the nation's most sensitive secrets are still uncertain. In the past month, the Department of Justice has indicted individuals for similar offenses, including a young sailor who took a selfie in front of a sonar screen on a nuclear submarine and emailed the selfie to his girlfriend, and a Marine who sent an urgent warning to his superiors on his Gmail account about a dangerous Afghan spy. The emailing Marine was indicted for failure to secure classified materials.

The future course of action remains to be seen, as the FBI continues its investigation and the White House has yet to comment on the matter. The public's reaction to any potential indictment or lack thereof will be a significant factor in the political landscape moving forward.

Title: U.S. Citizens Slaughtered in Mexico, International Issue Arises

Article:

At least three women and six children, all apparently U.S. citizens, were killed by drug cartel gunmen in northern Mexico, according to Mexican officials. Six children were found alive, one child had a bullet wound, and one child is still missing.

The incident occurred in a rural, mountainous area on the Sonora-Chihuahua border. Mexican Security Secretary Alfonso Durazo suggested that the gunmen may have mistaken the group's large SUVs for rival gangs. At least five children have been taken to Phoenix, Arizona for treatment.
