The slaughter of U.S. citizens on Mexican soil has become an international issue, with U.S. President Donald Trump tweeting, "This is the time for Mexico, with the help of the United States, to wage WAR on the drug cartels and wipe them off the face of the earth."

Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador refused this approach, stating at a Tuesday news conference, "The worst thing you can have is war." He added, "We declared war, and it did not work. That is not an option."

This is the second failure in recent weeks for López Obrador's "hugs not bullets" anti-crime strategy. Two weeks ago, Mexican troops had to release a drug lord after his supporters mounted armed attacks in Culiacan, Sinaloa.

President Trump tweeted, "The United States stands ready, willing & able to get involved and do the job quickly and effectively." He also stated, "The great new President of Mexico has made this a big issue, but the cartels have become so large and powerful that you sometimes need an army to defeat an army!"

The victims lived in the hamlet of La Mora in Sonora state, a decades-old settlement founded as part of an offshoot of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The group was attacked while traveling in a convoy of SUVs.

A relative, who asked not to be named for fear of reprisals, stated that the burned-out, bullet-ridden SUV containing the remains of his nephew's wife and her four children - twin 6-month-old babies and two other children aged 8 and 10 - were found.

Two women and two other children were later found dead. A relative said, "The mafia vehicles got her and four of her kids, and then set their vehicle on fire, burnt them to a crisp."

Durazo stated that police, soldiers, and the National Guard were searching the area for the missing child. The relative speculated that it was a case of mistaken identity, as the gunmen may have opened fire on the vehicle because it was an SUV.

Durazo also stated that the Sinaloa cartel had an important presence on the Sonora-Chihuahua border, but that a rival cartel was trying to invade the territory from the Chihuahua side.

Another relative, Julian LeBaron, stated on his Facebook page that one of the dead women was Rhonita Maria LeBaron. Jhon LeBaron, another relative, posted on his Facebook page that his aunt and another woman were dead, and that six of his aunt's children had been left abandoned but alive on a roadside.

It would not be the first time that members of the break-away church had been attacked in northern Mexico, where their forebears settled - often in Chihuahua state - decades ago. In 2009, Benjamin LeBaron, an anti-crime activist who was related to those killed in Monday's attack, was murdered in neighboring Chihuahua state.

Title: Bipartisan U.S. Senators Introduce Tougher Sanctions on Russia and Cyber Crime

Article:

WASHINGTON - A bipartisan group of U.S. senators introduced legislation on Thursday aimed at imposing stricter sanctions on Russia and combating cybercrime. The bill seeks to punish Moscow for its activities in Syria, Ukraine, and alleged interference in U.S. elections.

The proposed legislation includes restrictions on new Russian sovereign debt transactions, energy and oil projects, and Russian uranium imports. It also imposes new sanctions on Russian political figures and oligarchs.

The bill expresses strong support for NATO and requires a two-thirds Senate majority to vote in favor of any attempt to leave the alliance. Russian markets reacted swiftly to the measure, with the rouble slumping toward two-week lows.

Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, one of the measure's lead sponsors, stated, "The current sanctions regime has failed to deter Russia from meddling in the upcoming 2018 midterm elections." Earlier this week, Graham had announced plans for a "sanctions bill from hell" to punish Russia.

Congress passed a Russia sanctions bill last summer, but some lawmakers expressed dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump's perceived reluctance to implement it. He signed the bill only after Congress passed it with overwhelming majorities.

Several provisions of the measure introduced on Thursday aim to strengthen the previous law. Democratic Senator Bob Menendez stated that the administration had not fully complied with those sanctions.

"This bill is the next step in tightening the screws on the Kremlin and will bring to bear the full condemnation of the United States Congress so that Putin finally understands that the U.S. will not tolerate his behavior any longer," Menendez said.

Republicans and Democrats united last month in condemning Trump's failure to publicly condemn Russian President Vladimir Putin for interfering in the 2016 U.S. elections. However, Congress failed to pass any legislation before lawmakers went on their weeks-long summer recess.

The bill would need to pass both the Senate and House of Representatives and be signed by Trump to become law. Aides to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell referred questions about the bill to the Senate Banking Committee. A committee spokeswoman had no details on what measures the panel might consider.

McConnell stated last month that Senate committees should hold hearings on legislation to prevent Russia from future election meddling. Both the Banking and Foreign Relations Committees have since scheduled hearings relating to Russia.

Title: Putin Secures Constitutional Changes in Russia, Allowing Potential Stay in Power Until 2036

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin appears to have secured a significant political victory with 78 percent of votes counted in a national referendum that could extend his tenure in office until 2036. The referendum, which proposed more than 200 constitutional amendments, includes a provision that resets presidential term limits, allowing Putin to run for two more six-year terms in 2024 and 2030 if he chooses.

According to official results after 98 percent of ballots had been counted, Putin, who has ruled Russia for more than two decades as president or prime minister, had easily won the right to run for two more terms. The Central Election Commission reported that 78 percent of votes counted across Russia supported the constitutional changes, while just over 21 percent voted against.

The Kremlin had emphasized more than 200 other issues in the polls, but these amounted to little more than fine print on the ballot papers. The vote was marked by several irregularities, including online voting and a nearly week-long opportunity for citizens to cast their ballots amid the coronavirus pandemic.

The most novel aspect of Wednesday's election was the announcement of early results by the Central Election Commission before polls had closed in many parts of the country. In Moscow, results from the polls in Russia's Far East, seven hours ahead of the Russian capital, were announced with just around 1 percent of the ballots counted.

The opposition leader Alexei Navalny's movement Anti-Corruption Foundation published a video showing one polling station had taken it upon itself to submit ballots on behalf of a family that had never voted before. There was also a small protest in Moscow on Wednesday night.

The result does not set Putin's future in stone. It does, however, pave the way for him to potentially hold on to power until 2036, making him Russia's longest-serving ruler since Peter the Great. But he will have to run two more presidential campaigns, and if he chooses to do so, the question then will be how many people turn out to vote.

Title: Florida High School Shooter's Alarming Behavior Preceded Massacre, Authorities and Witnesses Recount

Article:

The teenager charged with the deadly shooting at a Florida high school had previously alarmed authorities, neighbors, and classmates due to behaviors such as obsessing over weapons, shooting small animals with a pellet gun, and harassing neighbors' pets.

On Thursday, Nikolas Cruz admitted to being the gunman who entered the campus armed with an AR-15-style rifle and shot students he encountered in the hallways and on the school grounds, according to a complaint affidavit released late Thursday.

In September 2017, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) received a tip about a YouTube commenter with the same name as Mr. Cruz who made an alarming claim: "I'm going to be a professional school shooter." The FBI investigated but failed to link the comment to Mr. Cruz.

The 19-year-old former student, who had been expelled from the school, may have stalked one of the girls he killed, according to a senior law-enforcement official.

Neighbors described Mr. Cruz as having a cold, cold stare, and a former neighbor, Malcolm Roxburgh, said, "He had a very strange look in his eyes all the time."

On Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Cruz took an Uber car to his former high school just before classes were dismissed, Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel said. He entered a school building with a legally purchased Smith & Wesson M & P 15 in a soft black bag. He readied his rifle and opened fire into five classrooms, the sheriff said, killing 17 and wounding more than a dozen.

Authorities have noted a trail of worrying signs that seem to have gone unheeded. Neighbors called the police, classmates said he was obsessed with guns, and campus security considered him troubled.

On Thursday, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said this looked like yet another attack preceded by signals. "Perhaps we haven't been effective enough in intervening immediately to deal with that," Mr. Sessions said, speaking to a sheriffs association in Washington, D.C. on Thursday.

President Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Rick Scott announced plans to redouble efforts to try to stop school violence. They didn't speak about gun control, focusing more on mental health.

Broward County Public Schools Superintendent Robert Runcie put the focus on weapons, stating, "Now is the time for this country to have a real conversation on sensible gun-control laws."

Mr. Cruz made his first appearance in court Thursday afternoon for a bond hearing, shuffling in shackles and wearing an orange outfit. He looked subdued and spoke only briefly, answering "Yes, ma'am" when asked to confirm his identity.

Judge Kim Mollica informed Mr. Cruz that he faced 17 counts of premeditated murder and ordered him held without bond. His attorney, Assistant Public Defender Melisa McNeill, said she deferred any arguments until subsequent court proceedings.

After the court proceeding, Gordon Weekes, chief assistant public defender in Broward County and part of Mr. Cruz's legal team, described the defendant as "deeply disturbed, emotionally broken," and said he is on suicide watch. "He fell between the cracks," the attorney said.

The defense is gathering Mr. Cruz's mental-health history and will explore his brain development and the possibility he had autism, according to Mr. Weekes.

Meanwhile, Ben Bennight, a bail bondsman in Mississippi, said he contacted the FBI after seeing the comment from "nikolas cruz" on one of his YouTube posts. He also said he reported the comment as spam to YouTube, which took it down. Mr. Bennight, who said he creates videos about his business, didn't recall what video received the alarming comment.

FBI agents visited Mr. Bennight at the time and returned Wednesday, he confirmed in an interview. He said he felt the agency took the issue seriously. One agent told him they were limited in how they could respond because it wasn't a direct threat, Mr. Bennight said.

"I wish the information could have prevented something like this from happening," he said in a new YouTube video, posted after the shooting.

Robert Lasky, special agent in charge of the FBI's Miami field office, said the FBI "conducted database reviews, checks, but was unable to further identify the person who actually made the comment."

None of that investigation led them to Mr. Cruz, who had developed a reputation in his upscale Parkland neighborhood as a socially awkward menace known to steal the mail of his neighbors, run through the yards of other homes, and hurt animals, according to neighbors and classmates.

Also on Thursday, a white supremacist group, Republic of Florida, told the Anti-Defamation League that Mr. Cruz was affiliated with the group, according to an ADL spokesman. The Republic of Florida didn't return calls for comment.

Former Douglas high-school student Kyle Ramos, who knew Mr. Cruz from the Army Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps, said Mr. Cruz liked to get up early, around 6 a.m., and try to kill squirrels outside his house by shooting them with a pellet gun.

Title: Jobs Report Shows Modest Growth in October, Leaves Little Impact on Election

Article:

The October jobs report, released on Friday, showed a gain of 171,000 jobs, exceeding most mainstream forecasts. The report has refocused the campaign spotlight on the economy, as the United States prepares for the upcoming presidential election on Tuesday.

The jobless rate increased to 7.9 percent from 7.8 percent, denying President Barack Obama a clean opportunity to tout a quickening recovery. Both presidential campaigns used the report to reinforce their economic messages before the election.

Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate, stated during a campaign stop in West Allis, Wisconsin, "He said he was going to lower the unemployment rate down to 5.2 percent right now, today we learned that it is actually 7.9 percent and that's 9 million jobs short of what he promised." He emphasized that unemployment was higher when Obama took office in January 2009 and peaked around 10 percent in October of that year.

Unemployment was at 7.8 percent when Obama moved into the White House, and a year ago at this time, unemployment was at 9 percent. Romney's surrogates portrayed the job growth as far from satisfactory and any positive interpretation as falling short of what should be expected.

President Obama and White House officials, on the other hand, highlighted the continuing trend of job growth as a reason to maintain the current course. Obama stated at a campaign rally in Hilliard, Ohio, "In 2008 we were in the middle of two wars and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression and today our businesses have created nearly five and a half million new jobs and this morning we learned that companies hired more workers in October than in any time in the last eight months."

The October gains are in line with the recent trend and are unlikely to significantly alter the course of the campaign, with swing-state polls suggesting Obama is slightly ahead. Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, stated, "These job numbers shouldn't play an important role in the election. They are not strong enough to help the president, not weak enough to help Governor Romney."

John Silvia, chief economist at Wells Fargo, said the report might provide a modest benefit to Obama but does not change the overall picture of the economy. "It's better than expectations and prior months were revised higher. We've got sustained growth of about 2 percent a year and no return to recession," he said.

Title: Chicago Police-ICE Agreement Sparks Concern Among Immigrant Rights Activists Ahead of City Council Vote on Sanctuary Law Amendments

Article:

As the Chicago City Council prepares to vote on amendments to the city's "sanctuary" law, a recently disclosed agreement between the Chicago Police Department (CPD) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has raised concerns among immigrant rights activists.

The agreement, signed by former CPD Superintendent Eddie Johnson in April, allows ICE to designate certain CPD employees as "customs officers." These officers are authorized to enforce a full range of federal offenses but are not permitted to enforce administrative violations of immigration law.

CPD spokesperson Anthony Guglielmi stated that there are no department employees currently deputized as "customs officers." However, he defended the agreement, explaining that it allows police to investigate drug trafficking, human trafficking, gangs, and financial crimes through Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), a branch of ICE.

Rey Wences, a member of Organized Communities Against Deportations, expressed concern about the agreement. Wences helped draft amendments to the Welcoming Cities ordinance, which are set for a full City Council vote on Wednesday. The amendments prohibit CPD from assisting ICE, Customs and Border Protection, and Homeland Security Investigations in enforcing civil immigration operations and require the department to keep track of every request for assistance it receives.

Wences stated that she was unaware of the agreement between CPD and ICE, as were Ald. Carlos Ramirez-Rosa (35th) and Ald. Michael Rodriguez (22nd), who introduced the amendments in December with Mayor Lori Lightfoot.

"Police-ICE collaboration is police-ICE collaboration, no matter how you paint it," Wences said. "The existence of this agreement... makes you wonder what other kinds of agreements the city has [with ICE]."

Ald. Rodriguez stated that the agreement "goes against the spirit of the Welcoming Cities ordinance."

The mayor's office and ICE officials did not respond to requests for comments Tuesday.

The Homeland Security Investigations office was created in 2010 to handle a range of criminal investigations such as weapons smuggling and child sex tourism. ICE has routinely insisted Homeland Security Investigations is separate from its Enforcement and Removal Operations, which handles all deportations.

However, under the Trump administration, the line between both branches of ICE has blurred. In 2017, former ICE acting director Tom Homan told Homeland Security Investigations to increase time spent on worksite raids "by four to five times."

Within two years, Homeland Security Investigations had conducted several high-profile raids across the country, including a raid of seven food processing plants in Mississippi that landed nearly 700 undocumented immigrant workers in detention. (Almost half of them were released the next day.)

A 2019 report by the Immigrant Legal Resource Center, the National Immigrant Justice Center, and the National Immigration Law Center criticized Homeland Security Investigations for engaging in racial profiling as it targets criminal gangs across the country.

"It is no longer a secret that HSI agents use the 'gang' label as a cover for engaging in widespread round-ups of immigrant youth of color," the report states.

In Boston, a similar agreement between the local police department and ICE led to widespread criticism after it was revealed that officials "regularly offer information back and forth between the agencies," as reported by NPR-affiliate WBUR.

Guglielmi stated that he does not believe incidents similar to those in Boston will occur in Chicago and is confident CPD officers will obey the Welcoming Cities ordinance.

"Our core focus of this department is to protect every resident of the city. We don't care where you were born," he said.

Freddy Martinez, a policy analyst at Open the Government who obtained a copy of the CPD-ICE agreement through an open records request, questioned cooperation between immigration authorities and sanctuary cities.

"We know ICE uses deceptive practices to get CPD to cooperate with them on immigration enforcement, with or without their knowledge," Martinez said. "Significant questions remain about why [CPD] felt the need to enter into these types of agreements when there are no officers deputized to assist ICE."

Title: Iran's Economic Struggles and the Pursuit of Sanctions Relief

Article:

Iran's economy is currently experiencing difficulties, but not everyone in the country is equally affected. In a downtown Tehran restaurant, a young man, who prefers to remain anonymous and identifies himself as Ahmad, sits with a friend, enjoying a water pipe of flavored tobacco. Ahmad, who describes himself as an independent trader in the petrochemical business, shares a common sentiment that President Hassan Rouhani has brought a more positive atmosphere to the country but has not implemented significant economic changes.

Ahmad's personal struggles, however, may not evoke much sympathy from most Iranians. He expresses concerns about the high import tariffs, citing a 105% tariff on each car imported into Iran. Despite this, he admits to wanting to import two Mercedes, but finds it financially impractical.

Income inequality is one of the challenges President Rouhani faces, but he maintains that better economic times are on the horizon for Iran. Iranians are hopeful about his promises, but beyond the marginal improvements that come with greater confidence in the new administration, little has changed on the ground.

Iranians are pinning their hopes on a nuclear agreement and improved relations with the outside world, achievements that are seen as difficult to achieve. Another major problem Rouhani faces in lifting Iran's economy is the opposition of entrenched interests that profit from Iran's isolation, such as the powerful Revolutionary Guard, which is a significant economic player.

One graduate student, who only gives his first name, Arman, states that things were at their worst under former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. "What was really frustrating was the fact that nothing was ever going to get better, because the more sanctions there were going to be, the richer some people are going to get," Arman says.

In the poor neighborhoods of south Tehran, the economic struggles are more apparent. Iran remains an economy of subsidies, although some direct cash payments have been replaced by food baskets for the poor. This change does not sit well with those forced to stand in line in the winter cold. Even there, however, flashes of humor can be found.

An old man in a wool cap startles a reporter by shouting, "We chant 'Death to America' all the time! What are you doing here asking questions?" But then, as the men around him break into grins, he smiles and says, "Well, I guess you're OK then."

Mehdi, a 77-year-old man, makes it clear that they may need help, but they do not like food lines. They know the difference between a poor neighborhood and a refugee camp. "This is the fourth time I've come," Mehdi says. "They tell me to come back later, and then they say they've run out. It's not right."

Besides a slight easing of sanctions last month, Iran has benefited from the widespread conviction that Rouhani's economic team is far more competent than Ahmadinejad's. Greater confidence—along with limited success in nuclear negotiations with six world powers—has helped reverse Iran's brutal inflation rate and stabilized the Iranian rial somewhat against the dollar.

However, achieving more will require the lifting of sanctions by further curtailing Iran's nuclear program, an effort that has enemies at home and abroad. Conservative Israeli and U.S. watchdogs such as United Against Nuclear Iran sound regular alarms that "the architecture of the sanctions regime is crumbling," largely based on an increase in trade delegations visiting Iran and inflated Iranian predictions. President Obama says Washington will come down "like a ton of bricks" on those who violate sanctions.

But inside Iran, people are not seeing any improvements that would justify such concerns. Even the man in charge of making Iran's oil contracts more attractive to foreign companies is tempering expectations. Oil ministry official Mehdi Hosseini says Iran needs a massive $150 billion in foreign investment in the coming years, and so far, companies are not committing.

"We still have sanctions now," Hosseini says. "There are companies coming and going, but we can't sign contracts while the sanctions remain, and contract talks will take time."

For now, Iranians say, there's nothing to do but struggle on, recognizing that better times ahead depend on factors beyond their control.

Title: White House Fires Top Aide Over Discrepancy in Tillerson's Dismissal Account

The White House has reportedly terminated Steve Goldstein, the Under Secretary of State, due to his contradiction of the White House account regarding President Donald Trump's dismissal of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. The Associated Press first reported the firing, citing officials.

The reported dismissal was prompted by a statement from Goldstein on Tuesday, in which he stated that Tillerson was not aware of the reason behind his dismissal and did not speak with Trump before his termination. This account differs from the one provided by a White House official, who stated that White House Chief of Staff John Kelly informed Tillerson on Friday that Trump would fire him.

Trump announced on Tuesday that he made the decision to oust Tillerson on his own and that Tillerson would be "much happier now." The President and Tillerson had reportedly clashed on multiple occasions, most notably after reports that Tillerson referred to Trump as a "moron" in private.

The White House later announced that Heather Nauert, previously the State Department's spokesperson, had been named as Goldstein's replacement. The specific reasons for Goldstein's account differing from the White House's account are unavailable.

Title: Top 10 Notable Segments from "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" in 2013

Article:

This year has been marked by a series of significant events in the United States, including the NSA spying controversy, the government shutdown, and the release of the song "Accidental Racist" by LL Cool J and Brad Paisley. In response to these events, "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" have provided a satirical and humorous perspective, helping Americans cope with the tumultuous year. Here are ten notable moments from both shows:

1. "Oopsie Daisy Homophobe" - Stephen Colbert and actor Alan Cumming performed a musical parody of the controversial song "Accidental Racist," titled "Oopsie Daisy Homophobe."

2. John Oliver's 3-part series on gun control in Australia - John Oliver, who hosted "The Daily Show" during the summer and recently left the show, investigated Australia's strict gun control measures in response to mass shootings, a topic that the U.S. has yet to address.

3. Jessica Williams' segments on race in America - Notable segments include her piece on food stamps and the "Frisky Business" segment, which exposes the hypocrisy and racism of Mayor Michael Bloomberg's stop-and-frisk program.

4. Daft Punk's last-minute cancellation and Colbert's response - After Daft Punk cancelled a "Colbert Report" performance, Colbert spoiled the band's VMA performance, criticizing MTV and suggesting that the band's popularity would wane after their initial performance.

5. Aasif Mandvi's expose on North Carolina GOP leader Don Yelton - Mandvi uncovered Yelton's controversial comments in support of voter ID laws, leading to his resignation and a subsequent defense of his remarks.

6. Fox News' War on Christmas - Every December, "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" often joke about Fox News' perceived war on Christmas. This year, Megyn Kelly was enraged by the idea of a black Santa Claus.

7. The Best F#@king News Team Ever's parody of CNN's shoddy news coverage - The parody is a tribute to CNN's poor journalistic standards.

8. Jon Stewart's verbal assaults on the GOP during the government shutdown - One notable moment includes Stewart calling House Republicans "self-righteous Orwellian zebra queefs."

9. "Pointless Counter Pointless" - Colbert hosted a parody program of CNN's "Crossfire," featuring special guests Oscar the Grouch and Big Bird debating various topics.

10. Former President Bill Clinton's Twitter debut - Clinton joined Twitter with the handle "PrezBillyJeff," admitting his insecurity with the social media platform.

Title: Republican Party's Stance on Gun Control: A Look at the Challenges Ahead

Article:

The recent mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, have prompted calls from Democrats for the GOP-controlled Senate to take action on gun control, particularly passing a bill that would establish universal background checks. However, the likelihood of significant gun control measures passing in the current political climate is uncertain.

Polls show that Republican voters prioritize gun rights over gun control but are not universally opposed to restrictions on firearms. Most Republicans support expanding background checks, "red flag" provisions, and requiring a license to purchase a gun. Yet, the Republican Party as an institution is generally hostile to gun control measures.

One reason for this is the political identity within the GOP, which is closely tied to gun rights. A vote for gun control measures, even popular ones, could potentially make a Republican elected official appear "anti-gun" or "of the left," making them electorally vulnerable.

Another factor is the influence of powerful gun rights organizations such as the National Rifle Association (NRA) and other activist groups. The average Republican member of Congress is more conservative than two decades ago, and this conservatism likely extends to gun policy as well. The party is actively working to expand gun rights at the state level, such as allowing people to carry concealed weapons without permits.

The NRA is a powerful American interest group with millions of members, constant pressure, and a significant number of single-issue voters who could potentially abandon a representative over the issue. This power of single-issue voters is one of the most underappreciated aspects of politics.

In 1994, the U.S. adopted an assault weapons ban, with 38 House Republicans and 10 GOP senators voting in favor. Twenty-five years later, only eight Republicans backed the background checks bill that passed the House earlier this year. Republican voters may be moving towards embracing gun control measures, but don't expect the Republican Party to move significantly anytime soon.

Title: Hydroxychloroquine Shows Promise in Treating Coronavirus, According to Early Studies

Article:

A drug commonly used to treat malaria, hydroxychloroquine, is showing promise in laboratory and clinical studies for the treatment of coronavirus. French researchers found that hydroxychloroquine lowered virus levels in most patients who took part in a clinical study this month. The results of a clinical trial in France and studies conducted in lab settings are building hope that a drug usually used to treat malaria and arthritis can treat and possibly cure coronavirus patients, though scientists say more data is needed before drawing a firm conclusion.

On Tuesday, a team of French scientists released the first results of a clinical study of the use of hydroxychloroquine on 24 coronavirus patients from southeast France. The research team, led by Didier Raoult, a renowned infectious disease expert from l'Institut Hospitalo-Universitaire in Marseille, administered the drug for 10 days along with azithromycin, a common antibiotic. Researchers said the drugs cleared the virus in the nose and throat of most observed patients in three to six days. After six days of treatment, 70 percent of patients administered hydroxychloroquine were clear of the virus, compared to just 12.5 percent of patients who were not given drugs.

Azithromycin boosted the effect of hydroxychloroquine, according to the study. After six days of treatment, all patients treated with the drug combination "were virologically cured," compared to 57.1 percent of patients treated with hydroxychloroquine by itself. "We therefore recommend that COVID-19 patients be treated with hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin to cure their infection and to limit the transmission of the virus to other people in order to curb the spread of COVID-19 in the world," wrote researchers, who acknowledged the small sample size of the study.

Lab studies have shown that hydroxychloroquine, which was developed in the 1940s, inhibited coronavirus. A study published in Cell Discovery on Wednesday by three Chinese scientists found that hydroxychloroquine inhibited coronavirus in vitro, or in a lab culture.

More clinical trials are underway. A researcher at Asan Medical Center, a top research hospital in South Korea, is conducting a clinical trial of 150 patients with mild cases of coronavirus. The lead researcher, Sung-Han Kim, estimates that the trial will be completed in May. According to NBC News, French drug maker Sanofi is working with health authorities to study whether hydroxychloroquine can help with coronavirus. The company is encouraged by preliminary findings, according to NBC News, but still does not have enough data to determine its efficacy.

Health officials in Belgium and South Korea have recommended the use of hydroxychloroquine for patients displaying either severe or mild symptoms from COVID-19, the disease caused by coronavirus. The United Kingdom appears to have some hope for the drug. On Sunday, government officials there banned the export and hoarding of hydroxychloroquine and two other drugs that could be useful as therapeutics, according to Pharmaceutical Technology.

Title: Former Benghazi Investigator Alleges Partisan Shift in Committee's Focus

Article:

A former investigator for the Select Committee on Benghazi, Air Force Reserve Maj. Bradley Podliska, has claimed that the investigation, which he initially perceived as non-partisan, shifted its focus towards former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. Podliska, an intelligence officer, made these statements during an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday.

Podliska, who was fired from the committee, alleges that he was partially let go for not focusing his investigation heavily enough on Clinton, who was the U.S. Secretary of State during the 2012 Benghazi attack that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens.

However, on Sunday, the chairman of the House panel, Republican Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina, released a statement denying Podliska's allegations. Gowdy stated that Podliska was improperly focused on Clinton, and that the committee is seeking a "definitive accounting" of the attacks.

Podliska, who identifies as a conservative Republican, has stated that his allegations are not partisan. He said, "I would just like to state that I am going to vote for the Republican nominee in 2016. I do not support Hillary Clinton for president."

Podliska further stated, "Hillary Clinton has a lot of explaining to do. We, however, did not need to shift resources to hyperfocus on Hillary Clinton. We did not need to de-emphasize, and in some cases drop, the investigation on different agencies, different organizations, and different individuals."

In a statement, the Benghazi committee "vigorously denies all of his allegations." The statement further states, "The employee was terminated, in part, because he himself manifested improper partiality and animus in his investigative work."

Podliska told CNN the victims' families are not going to get the truth. He said, "I know this because the nine months of research I had done is not lost. I have no idea where it is, and I know that I could give those victims' families… a pretty thorough explanation of why they were told that this attack was due to a video."

Title: "Dreamers' Shutdown: A Political Stalemate Over Immigration Policy"

Article:

The recent government shutdown, variously referred to as the Trump shutdown, the Schumer shutdown, and the Dreamer shutdown, has been a result of a prolonged standoff between Democrats and Republicans over the issue of Dreamers, undocumented immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children.

For months, Dreamers have urged Democrats to block government funding unless a bill granting them citizenship rights was included. On Friday, Democrats heeded this call, mounting a filibuster of a four-week spending bill, denying the government the necessary funds to remain open.

Dreamers celebrated the shutdown, stating they were finally being taken seriously. Cata Santiago, a Dreamer, said in a statement, "We know that the public is on our side. We are calling for the immigrant community and our allies to take to the streets immediately to demand that Congress pass legislation guaranteeing permanent protection for immigrant youth NOW."

The shutdown has left many senators stunned, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stating, "Almost everybody on both sides doesn't understand how we ended up here." McConnell laid blame squarely at the feet of the Dreamer debate, saying Democrats held the entire process hostage to the immigration talks.

Democrats suggested there were other sticking points, but acknowledged immigration and the fate of the Dreamers was the chief hurdle. However, they said the hold-up was President Trump's demands for major changes in immigration policy, which the White House said had to be passed along with any action on Dreamers.

The Dreamers and their immigrant-rights allies now find themselves in a similar position as conservative and tea party groups, who pressured Republicans into an Obamacare-fueled shutdown in 2013. That shutdown lasted 16 days, and Republicans relented in the end, walking away with no substantive gains.

Dreamers are likely to emerge from this shutdown in better shape, with most lawmakers saying they do want to find a solution for them. For now, the Dreamers await the outcome, though they were emboldened by their show of political power.

Frank Sharry, executive director of America's Voice, a pro-immigration lobby group, said, "Our fight has never been about a government shutdown; it's about a policy breakthrough. It's not about political advantage; it's about people's lives."

Deemed the most sympathetic figures in the immigration debate, most Dreamers were brought to the U.S. by parents with little say in the decision, and many don't have substantive memories of their home countries. They began "coming out" as illegal immigrants in the last decade, and quickly became a political force, earning invitations to the State of the Union address, meeting at the White House with President Barack Obama, and addressing the Democratic National Convention.

They came close to a solution in 2010, when legislation known as the Dream Act—which they took their name from—cleared the House and came close to passing the Senate, falling in a GOP-led filibuster. Their power has grown in the years since, and they felt emboldened last year to demand a shutdown fight. Democrats balked the first few times, but finally agreed to a self-imposed Jan. 19 deadline for action.

However, the actual firm deadline for Dreamers is March 5, which is when President Trump's phaseout of the Obama-era DACA deportation amnesty, protecting some 690,000 Dreamers, begins to expire. More than 100 Dreamers are losing status each day now, but those are ones who didn't manage to renew their status by Homeland Security's Oct. 5 deadline.

Sen. Richard Durbin, an Illinois Democrat who has led the fight on their behalf for years, said it was a travesty for Congress to have not solved their situation. "To say we're in no hurry—well, we may not be as senators and congressmen, but these young people are in a hurry to find out whether or not they have a life. That's what it comes down to," Mr. Durbin said.

Republicans countered that they, too, wanted to grant long-term certainty to Dreamers, but didn't want a new amnesty to invite another wave of illegal immigration. They demanded more border security and other policy changes be tied to any Dreamer legislation. "We can not deal with the issue of individuals in our country illegally...and ignore how it happened in the first place," said Sen. James Lankford, Oklahoma Republican.

Title: Disparity in U.S. Unemployment Rates: Five States Below 4% While Others Remain High

Article:

The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) data for June 2021 reveals a significant disparity in unemployment rates across different states, with five states reporting rates below 4%. The states with exceptionally low unemployment figures are primarily located in the Great Plains, where an energy boom has contributed to the economy.

North Dakota, with its shale-rich resources, reported a jobless rate of just 2.7% in June. Nebraska, Utah, and South Dakota followed closely with unemployment rates of 3.5%. Wyoming, the only state with a 4% unemployment rate, was the only other state in the Great Plains with a rate below 5%.

At the other end of the spectrum, employment remains high in several formerly industrial states and those with poor populations. Rhode Island, deprived of its factory workers and people from the financial services industry, had an unemployment rate of 7.9% in June. Mississippi, with one of the poorest populations in the country based on median household income, also reported an unemployment rate of 7.9%. In another poor state, Kentucky, the jobless rate is 7.4%, and it is higher in the eastern counties that were once a center of coal production.

Illinois, one of the most factory-rich northern states, had an unemployment rate of 7.1% in June. Michigan's was 7.5%, and Nevada, home to the greatest real estate collapse of the Great Recession, which gutted construction jobs, had a jobless rate of 7.7%.

It is reasonable to conclude that if the U.S. economy is to have a normal, fully recovered jobless rate of 5% or better, these most troubled states have a long way to go to contribute. There is no discernible economic composition in these states that makes such a recovery likely.

24/7 Wall St. is a content partner offering financial news and commentary. Its content is produced independently of ███.

Title: Unemployment Benefits Extension: A Contentious Issue in Upcoming Stimulus Bill

Article:

In late March, Congress passed the largest stimulus package in American history, a $2 trillion bill aimed at mitigating the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. One of the key provisions of the bill was an enhancement of unemployment insurance benefits for those who lost their jobs due to stay-at-home orders related to the virus.

As of now, nearly 39 million Americans have filed for unemployment in the past nine weeks. The benefits are designed to replace a certain percentage of an unemployed worker's lost income. The amount of money given out can vary significantly from state to state, ranging from an average of $213 a week in Mississippi to $555 in Massachusetts. The stimulus bill added an extra $600 a week from the federal government to each of these state payments.

These enhanced benefits are set to end on July 31, unless Congress votes to extend them. The issue is expected to be a key point of contention as Congress considers its next stimulus bill in the coming weeks. House Democrats have passed a bill that would continue the $600 bonus through the end of January. Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham stated that the GOP would allow an extension "over our dead bodies."

Opposition to extending the enhanced benefits centers around the claim that the program will hinder the country's economic recovery by providing an incentive for people to stay home rather than return to work. When combined with the average payout from states, a large number of workers are making more money on unemployment than they would if they were to return to their jobs. Workers typically lose their benefits if they turn down a "suitable" job offer, but some conservatives worry that the scale of joblessness in the country would make that provision impossible to enforce.

This imbalance could cause businesses to suffer, Republican lawmakers argue, if employees refuse to accept what would effectively be a pay cut by going back to work when stay-at-home orders are lifted. The situation could also create resentment among the millions of essential workers who have remained on the job during the crisis for less pay than those who were laid off.

Proponents of continuing the enhanced payments argue that the extra money has helped stave off an even more severe economic collapse. Despite unemployment at levels not seen since the Great Depression, many people have been able to make ends meet thanks to the boost in benefits. The larger checks also mean people have money to spend, which helps businesses stay afloat. If the extra funds go away, the country could see a wave of evictions, foreclosures, and other secondary economic impacts that result in a prolonged and severe recession, some economists have warned.

Others argue that incentives that compel workers to stay home are an important part of limiting the spread of coronavirus, which they see as the No. 1 priority. Not only would extending the enhanced benefits save lives, but lessening the severity of the outbreak would also ultimately benefit the economy more than a premature rush to push people back into the workplace, some public health experts say.

Republicans in the Senate have yet to release a plan for what might be in their next stimulus package, but Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stated that it "won't look anything like" the bill passed by Democrats in the House. The earliest any legislation could move forward will be the first week of June, when senators return from a weeklong recess.

Matthew Yglesias, writing for Vox, stated, "When people's incomes are stabilized, they pay their bills on time... and keep buying things. Since most workers who've been laid off are at the low end of the income spectrum and thus eligible for generous unemployment insurance benefits, the country has mostly avoided secondary shocks that would further exacerbate economic problems. So far."

Kristin Tate, writing for Fox News, said, "It's obvious that this level of aid really disincentivizes productive activity in the market and it puts business owners in a terrible situation. A lot of small business owners, they are getting that green light to start reopening, but they're worried that their employees may prefer to stay home and get paid for that."

Title: Obama's Healthcare Overhaul Threatens Democratic Party's Agenda and Liberalism's Future

Article:

The rollout of President Barack Obama's signature domestic policy, the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has put the reputation of Big Government progressivism at risk for at least this generation. The success or failure of Obamacare is not only a matter for this president but also for the future of the Democratic Party's plausible agenda and liberalism itself.

In his 2006 best-selling book, "The Audacity of Hope," Obama criticized the achievements of the most recent Democratic president, Bill Clinton, stating that Clinton's policies were "recognizably progressive if modest in their goals." This criticism, penned before Obama's presidency, now carries significant weight.

Conservative thinkers have seized on the rocky rollout of Obamacare as proof that the age-old argument over the proper role of state action in American life has reached a critical point for the Democrats. Columnist Charles Krauthammer wrote that the unraveling of Obamacare would "catastrophically undermine" the ideology of ever-expansive central government providing cradle-to-grave care for an ever-grateful citizenry.

Anxious congressional Democrats face a fight-or-flight dilemma of their own. Abandoning Obamacare is no easy proposition, as they supported its creation and understand that their constituents need health care reform. The White House, for its part, maintains a positive outlook, with press secretary Jay Carney stating on Friday, "This is obviously a challenge, and we're facing the challenge, and we're up to the challenge."

However, more dispassionate analysts say it would be hard to overstate the danger of this moment for Obama and for Democrats more broadly. From the beginning, Obama sketched his agenda for the country as the sort that succeeds only once a generation, if then. The success or failure of Obamacare will significantly impact the Democratic Party's ability to pursue their plausible agenda and the future of liberalism.

Title: Central American Migrants Arrive at U.S.-Mexico Border Despite Trump's Orders

Article:

A group of Central American migrants, traveling in a caravan through Mexico, arrived at the border city of Tijuana late on Tuesday. The group, numbering approximately 600, had been making their way north from Mexico's southern border with Guatemala, a journey that began a month ago.

By evening, two busloads of men, women, and children had arrived in Tijuana, a city that borders southern California. The migrants, who fled their homes in Guatemala, El Salvador, and Honduras due to lethal threats or political persecution, gazed toward San Diego, visible at spots through a rusty barrier or across a pedestrian bridge.

Another four busloads were making their way north from Hermosillo, a city 432 miles south of the border, where the migrants had been stalled for days. Many had clung to the hope of receiving asylum in the United States, but their prospects dimmed after U.S. authorities released statements on Monday stating they would be turned back.

Rodrigo Abeja, a coordinator from immigrant rights group Pueblo Sin Fronteras that has been organizing similar caravans for several years, said the caravan planned to regroup before making any decisions. "They will wait for all those seeking asylum to be together," Abeja said.

A third group, resigned to staying in Mexico, awaited processing for year-long visas by immigration authorities in Hermosillo. The number of migrants traveling together had decreased from a peak of about 1,500 people due to waiting for transportation and attacks by U.S. President Donald Trump, who began criticizing the caravan on Twitter in early April.

After Trump's comments, Mexican authorities stalled the caravan in a southern town and began handing out temporary visas that gave them legal status to travel to the border. The U.S. President has ordered officials to repel the migrants.

Title: Hurricane Hermine Makes Landfall in Florida, Threatens East Coast

Article:

Hurricane Hermine, the first hurricane to hit Florida in over a decade, caused significant damage to beachside buildings and toppled trees onto homes on Friday before moving inland. The storm weakened to a tropical storm and was spinning along the North Carolina coast late Friday, but the National Hurricane Center predicted it would regain hurricane strength over the weekend and potentially impact coastal areas as far north as Connecticut and Rhode Island through Labor Day.

The storm's projected path prompted New Jersey Governor Chris Christie to declare a state of emergency for three counties on the Atlantic Ocean on Saturday. In Florida, the main impact of Hermine was power outages and damage from storm surges. A homeless man south of Gainesville died when a tree fell on him, according to Governor Rick Scott.

In the coastal communities of Cedar Key and Steinhatchee, which were hit hard by the storm, Governor Scott pledged that businesses would be eligible for state assistance. However, it remains unclear whether Florida will receive federal disaster assistance as the state begins to clean up from the storm.

An estimated 325,000 people were without power statewide, and over 107,000 in neighboring Georgia, officials said. At 2 a.m. Saturday, the hurricane center said the tropical storm's center was about 60 miles west-northwest of Cape Lookout, North Carolina. The storm threatens a dangerous storm surge into Hampton Roads in southeast Virginia.

Hermine had top sustained winds of 60 mph and was moving northeast at 22 mph. Forecasters predict the system could strengthen back into a hurricane by Monday morning off the Maryland-Delaware coast before weakening again as it moves north. Tropical storm watches and warnings were posted up and down the coastline.

Amtrak has cancelled or altered some service on the East Coast as the storm approaches. Back in Florida, a storm surge at Dekle Beach damaged numerous homes and destroyed storage buildings and a 100-yard fishing pier. The area is about 60 miles southeast of St. Marks, where Hermine made landfall at 1:30 a.m. in the Big Bend area, where Florida's peninsula and panhandle meet.

In nearby Steinhatchee, a storm surge crashed into Bobbi Pattison's home. She wore galoshes and was covered in black muck as she stood in her living room amid overturned furniture and an acrid smell. Tiny crabs darted around her floor. "I had a hurricane cocktail party last night and God got even with me," she said with a chuckle. Where her bar once stood was now only wet sand and rubble.

In Keaton Beach, about two dozen people waited on a road just after sunrise Friday, trying to get to their homes. Police blocked the road because of flooding. Dustin Beach, 31, rushed there from a hospital in Tallahassee where his wife gave birth to a girl Thursday night to see if his home still stood. "When my wife got up this morning, she said, 'Go home and check on the house. I need to know where we're going after we leave the hospital,'" Beach said.

High winds knocked trees onto several houses in Tallahassee, injuring people inside. It was sometime after midnight when Alan Autry, 48, started hearing the large pines in his Tallahassee neighborhood start to crack and fall to the ground. Then he heard one come down on the top floor of his house. The tree did not initially crash through the roof, and Autry and his wife went to a neighbor's house. Sometime before dawn, the corner of his house collapsed from the weight of the tree.

"We've been married 13 years and this is our fifth hurricane," said Autry, who moved from central Florida six years ago. "By far, this is the worst damage we've ever had." Tampa and St. Petersburg escaped major damage. Up to 17 inches of rain fell in the area over the last two days.

The last hurricane to strike Florida was Wilma, a powerful Category 3 storm that arrived on Oct. 24, 2005. It swept across the Everglades and struck heavily populated south Florida, causing five deaths in the state and an estimated $23 billion in damage. The Florida governor declared an emergency in 51 counties and said about 6,000 National Guardsmen stood ready to mobilize for the storm's aftermath. The governors of Georgia and North Carolina also declared emergencies.

Title: Gunman's Actions and Manifesto Aligned with White Nationalist Ideology, Online Trolling Tactics

Article:

The perpetrator of the recent shooting incident appears to have coordinated his actions with the typical online tactics of far-right instigators, engaging a community of like-minded supporters in real-time as they watched the events unfold. The manifesto, which expresses the author's intentions, explicitly states the usual unspoken objectives of internet trolls: to provoke outrage and stir up arguments among opponents.

One of the gunman's stated objectives was to "agitate the political enemies of my people into action, to cause them to overextend their own hand and experience the eventual and inevitable backlash as a result." He also aimed to "incite violence, retaliation, and further divide."

The manifesto, the chilling video, and the gunman's social media posts exhibit typical white nationalist rhetoric, layered with irony and meta jokes, making it challenging to discern what is genuine and what was considered humorous.

The gunman seems to have a profound interest in history, particularly events that align with a white nationalist narrative. He inscribed the names of centuries-old military leaders who led battles against predominantly nonwhite forces, as well as the names of individuals who recently carried out mass shootings against Jewish and Muslim communities, on his weapons.

The manifesto, steeped in anti-Muslim sentiment, refers to nonwhites as "invaders" who pose a threat to "replace" white people. The author's language and specific memes suggest a deep connection to the far-right online community.

The link to the livestreamed video was initially posted on the /pol/ forum of 8chan, a notorious far-right space, where the gunman was celebrated as a hero following the shooting. Some of his references were subtle, such as listening to a song associated with a 1995 Serbian nationalist video, which has recently been adopted as a racist meme, during his drive to the mosque.

Title: Democrats Eye Gains in U.S. House of Representatives as Midterm Elections Approach

Article:

In the central Virginia district of Spotsylvania, voters such as Meg Sneed and Cheryll Lesser are contributing to a significant shift in the political landscape. Sneed, who previously voted for the Republican incumbent, Dave Brat, in the last U.S. congressional elections, is now leaning towards the Democrat running against Brat, Abigail Spanberger. Lesser, who did not vote in the last election, is also considering voting for Spanberger due to her disapproval of President Donald Trump.

This trend is a key reason why Democrats believe they can win more than the 23 seats needed to seize control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the Nov. 6 midterm elections. Some predict that Democrats could take as many as 40 seats by flipping districts like Brat's in Virginia.

Earlier this year, Brat's seat was considered safe. However, if a so-called "blue wave" materializes, it would roll through a district like his, which includes pockets of suburban voters who have been increasingly turning away from Republicans.

Doug Heye, a former official at the Republican National Committee, noted, "Republicans are playing defense in more and more places. The Democrats' map continues to get bigger. The Republicans' map continues to get smaller. That's a real problem."

If Democrats do take the House, much of Trump's agenda would be stalled, and his administration would fall under greater scrutiny. Republicans are favored to retain the Senate, but they must defend seats in several conservative states.

Democrats have poured resources into Brat's district, as well as other battleground districts in states such as Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Southern California, and other parts of Virginia, such as the district currently represented by Republican Scott Taylor. They have been backed by deep-pocketed advocacy groups such as House Majority PAC and NextGen, funded by California billionaire Tom Steyer.

In response, the Congressional Leadership Fund, a Republican political action committee, is running ads attacking Spanberger, a sign that the party is genuinely worried about losing the seat.

Brat, who shocked the political order by beating then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in a Republican primary in 2014, has aligned himself with the ultra-conservative Freedom Caucus. Last year, as protesters crashed his events during a House push to repeal former President Barack Obama's healthcare program, Brat remarked that "women are in my grille no matter where I go."

The firestorm over Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, who was accused of sexual assault while in high school, came at a perilous moment for Brat, given his already difficult reputation with some women voters. Trump has played a part in this, as both Sneed and Lesser were angry that he chose to attack Kavanaugh's accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, at a rally last week.

Kavanaugh was confirmed by the U.S. Senate on Saturday. Democratic activists hope discontent with his nomination will linger through November. Republicans, however, see the Kavanaugh fracas as galvanizing conservative voters who have been looking for a reason to come out and vote in November's elections.

A 39-year-old former officer for the Central Intelligence Agency, Spanberger presents herself as the face of the Resistance, the woman-driven protest movement against Trump. However, she has been careful to not alienate the independent and moderate voters she needs to win the district. At the Spotsylvania event, she didn't mention Trump, Brat, or Kavanaugh, focusing on domestic-policy issues such as healthcare and education.

Asked for her position on Kavanaugh's nomination, her campaign declined to comment. Instead, Spanberger touched on the thing that attracted voters such as Meg Sneed to her: turning down the volume in the civic discourse.

"We've reached a place where we need to restore a level of civility to our conversations," she told the crowd.

Tom Davis, a former Republican congressman from Virginia, stated that it remains Brat's race to win, and that Kavanaugh may be the issue that pulls him over the finish line. "It's still a southern district," Davis said. "There's nothing like a good fight to keep your base in line."

Title: Economic Growth and Life Expectancy: A Comparative Analysis of Hong Kong, Central Europe, and the Baltic States

Article:

Last Friday, the Cato Institute hosted a forum on Neil Monnery's book, "Architect of Prosperity: Sir John Cowperthwaite and the Making of Hong Kong." Sir John Cowperthwaite, the financial secretary of Hong Kong from 1961 to 1971 and its financial under-secretary from 1951 to 1961, is credited for establishing policies that transformed Hong Kong from a poor backwater of the British Empire into one of the world's wealthiest regions.

When asked about Hong Kong's success, Monnery noted that in the years following World War II, Hong Kong's per capita income was one-third of that in Britain. By the time of the British transfer of the territory to China in 1997, incomes in the two countries were equal. Today, the average inhabitant of Hong Kong is over 30% richer than the average Briton.

Economic growth, according to Monnery, is not only crucial for rising standards of living but also for health and life expectancy. In 1960, people in Hong Kong lived four years shorter than those in Britain. Today, they live four years longer. This correlation between economic growth and life expectancy was a key topic of discussion during the forum.

This correlation was also observed in the context of Central Europe, particularly since the fall of the Berlin Wall on November 9, marking 28 years since the end of the communist period. Following the end of the communist period, the region experienced an economic recession, as unproductive industries shut down, and millions of people lost their jobs. Life expectancy started to decline, which opponents of market reforms saw as proof of capitalism's deleterious consequences for people's welfare.

Revisiting life expectancy statistics three decades later, a different picture emerges. Between 1960 and 1989, life expectancy in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, and Slovakia rose by 1.33, 1.46, 3.36, and 1.05 years, respectively. Between 1989 and 2015, it increased by 7.1, 5.68, 6.44, and 5.24 years, respectively. The post-communist dip in life expectancy, such as it was, proved to be small and temporary.

Further afield, post-communist depression was much more pronounced in the Baltic countries, which is, in retrospect, unsurprising. These economies, being parts of the Soviet Union, were much more heavily distorted than their neighbors to the west. In other words, a deeper restructuring was necessary.

However, the relationship between economic growth and life expectancy still holds. In the 31 years between 1960 and 1991, life expectancy in Estonia and Lithuania rose by 1.47 and 0.52 years, respectively, while in Latvia it fell by 0.75 years. Between 1991 and 2015, life expectancy rose by 7.33 years in Estonia, 2.97 years in Lithuania, and 5.02 years in Latvia.

In conclusion, a switch from socialism to capitalism appears to be beneficial for the health and longevity of the citizenry. The data suggests that economic growth, driven by free-market policies, contributes to improved life expectancy and health outcomes. However, it is important to note that the specific circumstances and historical context of each region play a significant role in the outcomes observed.

Title: Deadly Bombing Rocks Bangkok's Downtown Area, Kills 18 and Injures Over 100

Article:

A devastating bomb blast in downtown Bangkok during the evening rush hour on Monday has left at least 18 people dead and over 100 injured, according to authorities. The explosion occurred near the Erawan Shrine, a Hindu religious site.

Alexander Hotz, an American filmmaker working in the area, described the incident as "thunder-like." He was in his office when the blast occurred, initially mistaking it for a heavy rainstorm. One of his Thai interns later informed him of the chaos unfolding outside.

The BBC reported that body parts were scattered and a crater was present, suggesting a bombing. People near the Erawan Shrine were hit by the "full force of the blast," according to the BBC. Burned motorbikes were visible on the road.

Initially, police were concerned about a second explosion due to a suspicious object found near the blast site. However, national police chief Somyot Poompummuang later confirmed that the object was harmless.

The Associated Press reported that at least 18 people were confirmed dead and 117 injured. The Bangkok Post, citing the Royal Thai Police, put the death toll at 19. The explosion occurred at 6.55 p.m. local time, and the Bangkok Post reported that an improvised explosive device was placed inside the shrine complex.

Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Prawit Wongsuwan condemned the bombing and expressed condolences to the families of the deceased and injured. He stated it was too soon to determine if the attacks were politically motivated.

The White House also condemned the attack and extended "our deepest condolences to all those affected by the explosion."

While such attacks are rare in Bangkok, there have been smaller incidents in recent months. In February, a small homemade pipe bomb exploded near a Bangkok shopping mall. In March, grenades were tossed in front of the Central Criminal Court in Bangkok, and in April, seven people were injured in a parking lot blast on the tourist island of Koh Samui.

It is unclear why the shrine was targeted. Over 90% of Thailand's 66 million people are Buddhist, with Hindus making up a tiny fraction of the rest. About 5% of the population is Islamic, and there has been some religious unrest involving Islamic separatists in southern Thailand in recent years.

Thailand experienced a military coup in May 2014. The government was dissolved, replaced by a military-dominated national legislature. The current prime minister, Gen. Prayut Chan-o-cha, has cracked down on dissent and banned criticism of his government.

Anna Mallika, a Thai-American auditor, was in an exercise class when the blast hit. "We heard the most almighty bang," Mallika said. "Most of us thought that something was wrong, but the instructor told us that it was probably just a car crash or something like that. Minutes later we saw people running and panicking outside the window."

Richard Sri-kureja told the BBC he was walking to a mall next to the shrine when he heard the blast. "There was total chaos," he said. "That area is usually very, very crowded as it's in the middle of the city and it's usually very packed. A local hotel is full of injured patients."

This article was reported from McLean, Va. Contributing: Jane Onyanga-Omara in London.

Title: Trump Administration's Emergency Request for Supreme Court Intervention in Border Wall Funding Case

Article:

The Trump administration is seeking the Supreme Court's help in its effort to build a wall on the southwestern border using $2.5 billion reallocated from the Defense Department's budget without congressional authorization. A federal district judge in Oakland, Calif., Haywood Gilliam Jr., previously blocked the Defense Department from spending money that Congress had not appropriated for that purpose.

The administration's request for a stay of Judge Gilliam's order was refused by the judge and a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeals court majority wrote that the public interest weighs against issuing a stay because "the Constitution assigns to Congress the power of the purse." The judges continued, stating that "under the Appropriations Clause, it is Congress that is to make decisions regarding how to spend taxpayer dollars."

Claiming an emergency, the administration went to the Supreme Court last week seeking a stay. Justice Elena Kagan, who has supervisory jurisdiction over cases coming from the Ninth Circuit, gave the plaintiff, the Sierra Club, a deadline of this Friday to file a response to the administration's application. The end of the current fiscal year comes up on Sept. 30, by which time, the administration says, construction contracts have to be in place if the project is to proceed.

This is the 28th time, by the count of Professor Stephen Vladeck of the University of Texas School of Law, that the Trump administration has gone to the Supreme Court with an emergency application of some kind - a request for a stay or for the justices to skip the appeals court and grant direct review of a Federal District Court decision, as the court did in the census case. By contrast, the administration of President George W. Bush sought Supreme Court intervention of this sort only six times in eight years, and for the Obama administration, the number of such requests was four in eight years.

The Trump administration's frequent requests for Supreme Court intervention mark a significant change in the attitude and behavior of a presidential administration towards the Supreme Court. It is a change that warrants close and skeptical watching.

Title: Sen. Charles Schumer Says Gang of Eight Has Completed 90% of Immigration Legislation Drafting

Article:

President Obama expressed optimism on Wednesday that Congress will have a bill overhauling the nation's immigration laws ready next month, with the possibility of passage by the end of summer. In an interview with Spanish-language network Telemundo, Obama stated, "If we have a bill introduced at the beginning of next month as these senators indicate it will be, then I'm confident that we can get it done certainly before the end of the summer."

The president's comments come as four members of the Senate's so-called "Gang of Eight," including Arizona Republican John McCain and Democrat Charles Schumer, completed a tour of the Arizona-Mexico border on Wednesday. Schumer told reporters after the tour that the lawmakers were 90% done with their work crafting the legislation.

Obama called on Congress this week to expedite the process and deliver an immigration bill as soon as possible. The president won the Latino vote overwhelmingly in his race against Mitt Romney, but has faced criticism from some Latinos for failing to address immigration reform in his first term and for a record number of deportations under his administration.

In the Telemundo interview, Obama dismissed the potential political fallout for his party if the push on immigration reform falls short. "I'm not concerned about the Democratic Party," Obama said. "I'm concerned about the people whose actual lives are (going to) be impacted by it."

Obama emphasized the importance of strengthening border security, creating a pathway to citizenship, and ensuring a better life for immigrants and their families. He also noted that he is prepared to introduce his own plan if necessary, but believes it will not be necessary.

Title: Border Patrol Agents Warn of Increased Illegal Border Crossings and Drug Trafficking as Immigration Reform Discussions Intensify

Article:

As the Gang of Eight, a bipartisan group of U.S. Senators, prepares to announce an immigration reform deal later this week, concerns regarding border security and the potential impact on illegal border crossings are rising among Border Patrol agents. According to an anonymous Border Patrol agent, the number of illegal aliens has reportedly doubled, or even tripled, since discussions of amnesty began.

Data obtained by a media outlet and reported within Customs and Border Protection (CBP) from February 5 through March 1, 2013, shows 504 illegal aliens were spotted in the Tucson/Nogales area, with 189 being caught on CBP intelligence cameras. Of those 504, only 174 were apprehended, and 32 of the 189 on camera were carrying large drug loads for Mexican cartels. Some were armed with AK-47 style weapons.

Photos obtained by the media outlet from CBP intelligence cameras in Southern Arizona near the border with Mexico have been provided, with sensitive information redacted to protect the security and identity of the camera locations.

Last week, Fox News reported that sections of the border will soon become unpatrolled as hours for on-the-ground agents are cut. The media outlet has learned that Border Patrol agents working the border have been fully funded, yet internal political battles within CBP may be causing funds to be funneled to managers rather than those on patrol.

"Customs and Border Protection has been given enough money to fully staff the border but has chosen to use the money elsewhere, we believe it is to fund the salaries of Supervisory CBP Officers," Vice President of the National Border Patrol Council Shawn Moran tells the media outlet. "The money they are diverting was to go to AUO (Administratively Uncontrollable Overtime), which is actually straight pay and is used to pay Border Patrol Agents for anything past eight hours. Being that we have to maintain staffing 24/7, this is a huge part of border security. The criminals and drugs do not stop coming, so we have to make sure we have people out there."

"Cutting AUO will be a 30% pay cut for our agents but more importantly a minimum 20% loss of staffing out in the field," Moran continues. "This is internal politics within CBP and also with immigration reform. There are still battles between legacy Customs, INS, and Border Patrol managers as to the direction CBP takes and how the funds are being used. Meanwhile, both parties claim no immigration reform until the border is secured, well, this surely will not secure the border."

As sequestration goes into full effect on April 7 and a deal in Washington on immigration reform gets locked in, illegal crossings are expected to get worse.

"We have seen increased crossings and smuggling since word of staffing cuts began circulating," Moran says. "The illegals have even told us that is why they tried crossing. The border is safer but by no means secure."

Another agent expressed the same sentiment, stating when apprehended, some illegal aliens ask where they can go to find amnesty.

Despite border security being put further at risk through bad policy, the push for immigration reform, well before full border security is ongoing. The AFL-CIO reached a deal with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on a guest worker program late last Friday. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said the Gang of Eight has reached a deal on immigration reform on CNN's State of the Union over the weekend, but Republican Senator Marco Rubio has said reports of a deal are premature.

Title: Michael Cohen's Attorneys Expected to Cease Representation in Criminal Investigation

Article:

Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's longtime personal lawyer, is expected to lose his legal representation in the ongoing criminal investigation into his business dealings, according to a source familiar with the matter. The attorneys from the law firm McDermott, Will & Emery LLP, who have represented Cohen since June 2017, are expected to cease representation after completing a review of over 3.7 million documents seized during an April raid on Cohen's home, office, and hotel room.

The review aims to determine which communications are protected by attorney-client privilege ahead of a Friday deadline set by Judge Kimba Wood of the Southern District of New York. Stephen Ryan, Todd Harrison, and others at the firm will no longer represent Cohen once the review is complete, the source said.

Cohen is yet to secure a replacement law firm, but is reportedly searching for a federal criminal lawyer in New York. Sources familiar with the matter suggest Cohen is looking for a lawyer with close ties to the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office. Cohen has not yet decided whether he will cooperate with prosecutors in the case, according to one of these sources. He has not been charged with any crime.

Judge Wood has appointed a special master to oversee the document review and decide whether communications designated as privileged by Cohen, Trump, or the Trump Organization can be viewed by government investigators. The Manhattan U.S. attorney's office is investigating whether Cohen committed bank fraud, campaign-finance violations, and other potential crimes. A spokeswoman for the office declined to comment. Cohen has denied any wrongdoing.

The expected withdrawal of Cohen's law firm was first reported by ABC News.

Title: FBI Agent Peter Strzok Faces Intense Scrutiny in 10-Hour Congressional Hearing

Article:

In a 10-hour joint hearing between the House Judiciary and Oversight Committees on Capitol Hill Thursday, senior FBI agent Peter Strzok testified, facing intense questioning regarding his role in investigations into Hillary Clinton's private email server and potential coordination between Russia and the Trump campaign.

During the hearing, Strzok addressed allegations surrounding a series of text messages he exchanged with his former FBI attorney, Lisa Page. One of the contentious exchanges, from August 26, 2016, read, "Just went to a southern Virginia Walmart – I could smell the Trump support." When asked about this exchange, Strzok stated, "Sir, that's an expression of speech. I clearly was not smelling one thing or the other."

Strzok maintained that he separated his political opinions from his investigations into Clinton and the Trump campaign. However, after special counsel Robert Mueller discovered his text messages, he was removed from the Russia investigation.

One of the most intense lines of questioning came from House Oversight Committee Chairman Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-SC), who stated, "It wasn't the discovery of your texts, Mr. Strzok. It was the existence of your bias that got you kicked off." Strzok responded, "No, Mr. Gowdy, it was not."

The hearing saw Democrats staunchly defending Strzok, with Rep. Steve Cohen (D-TN) stating, "If I could give you a Purple Heart, I would." Republicans, on the other hand, peppered Strzok with questions and expressed outrage that had been building for months.

At one point, Strzok refused to answer questions, citing a directive by FBI attorneys. This led to a threat of contempt of Congress from Chairman Goodlatte. "And potential criminal liability – do you understand that?" Goodlatte threatened Strzok.

Towards the end of the hearing, it was announced that Lisa Page would be questioned by members of Congress in a closed-door session on a subsequent day, having had the benefit of watching Strzok's testimony.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry Challenges Syrian President's Denial of Chemical Weapons Use

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry has responded to Syrian President Bashar Assad's denial of chemical weapons use in an interview, stating that the world can decide who is responsible for the Aug. 21 attack. Kerry made a surprise appearance at a State Department briefing on Thursday, ahead of a U.N. meeting next week in New York, where U.S. diplomats will continue working on a U.N. resolution to enforce a newly struck agreement that would have the Assad regime turn over its chemical weapons to international control.
