In the interview, Assad admitted to having chemical weapons but denied that his government was behind the attack, continuing to push the theory that the opposition was behind the strike. Kerry stated, "Sarin was used. Sarin killed," and questioned the feasibility of the opposition launching the attack, suggesting that it would be implausible for the opposition to gain control of territory, acquire the necessary rockets and weapons, and possess the chemical agent sarin to carry out the attack.

The U.N. report on the Aug. 21 attack, which was recently released, states that there is conclusive evidence that the chemical attack occurred. The report did not assign blame, but included findings about the type of rocket used, which the U.S. and its allies claim point to Syrian government culpability. Kerry emphasized that nations cannot "have their own set of facts." He stated, "This fight about Syria's chemical weapons is not a game. Anybody who reads the facts (in the U.N. report) and puts the dots together... understands what those facts mean."

Title: Carter Expresses Support for Trump's Diplomatic Efforts, Skepticism on Russia Interference, and Preference for National Anthem Standing

Article:

Former President Jimmy Carter, a liberal Democrat, has expressed support for President Donald Trump on several issues in an interview with The New York Times. Carter criticized the media for treating Trump more harshly than any other president he can recall, stating, "I think the media have been harder on Trump than any other president certainly that I’ve known about."

The 39th president, who voted for Sen. Bernie Sanders in the primary, also praised Trump's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East and his initiative reaching out to Saudi Arabia. Carter, who is good friends with H.R. McMaster, has offered to help the White House but has not yet been accepted.

Regarding the conflict with North Korea, Carter expressed interest in helping President Trump work on a diplomatic resolution. Carter previously flew to Pyongyang in 1994, striking a deal with Kim Il-sung, the grandfather of the current leader, Kim Jong-un. North Korea secretly cheated on the deal four years later. Carter stated, "I would go [to North Korea], yes."

Carter also addressed Russia's attempt to influence the 2016 election, stating, "I don’t think there’s any evidence that what the Russians did changed enough votes, or any votes."

Finally, Carter expressed a preference for NFL players to stand during the national anthem, stating, "I think they ought to find a different way to object, to demonstrate. I would rather see all the players stand during the American anthem."

Title: Obama Delays Employer Mandate in Healthcare Law, Highlighting Ongoing Changes to the Affordable Care Act

Article:

President Obama's decision this week to delay the employer mandate to provide health insurance is the latest modification to his healthcare law, officially known as the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and widely nicknamed "Obamacare." The decision underscores the ongoing changes to the law more than three years after it was signed into law.

The courts have rewritten the way the Medicaid expansion works, while Mr. Obama and Congress have repealed a budget-busting long-term care program and onerous reporting requirements for businesses. On Tuesday, Mr. Obama took unilateral action to postpone the employer mandate for a year, with his aides stating they are trying to show the kind of flexibility all sides have asked for as the massive bill lurches toward full implementation.

The fits and starts have left an ever-shifting platform that could be even more complicated by the time the law's most controversial aspect—the individual mandate to have health insurance or pay a fine/tax—goes into effect on Jan. 1. "There will be certainly opportunities here for further confusing people," said Timothy Jost, a professor at the Washington and Lee University School of Law.

All sides had predicted the law would change over time, and even Mr. Obama and congressional Democrats had said they'd be open to tweaks that might make it work better. However, observers were caught off guard by the White House's sudden decision to delay the employer mandate by one year, to 2015. The provision requires businesses with more than 50 workers to offer insurance to all full-time employees, or else pay a fine of $2,000 per worker.

Opponents of the law said the move exposed its fundamental flaws. "Implementation of the ACA has not lowered costs or increased access as promised," said Sen. Jerry Moran, Kansas Republican. "Individuals, families, and employers still face increasing health insurance costs, new taxes overseen by what we have recently learned is a politically-biased IRS, burdensome mandates, and massive uncertainty because of this flawed law."

Republicans have repeatedly tried to repeal the law, or at least chip away at it, while Democrats say unfounded criticism and a lack of funding have undermined the administration's efforts after years of work. "The problem all along has been that while the program was passed with great fanfare a few years ago, most of the policies that will really impact people won't take effect until 2014," said Jim Manley, a Democratic strategist and former spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid. "Which is a tough way to sell something to the American people, especially when the Republicans are doing everything they can to undermine a bill that is the law of the land."

Mr. Jost also said "widespread, vicious opposition to this law" has been the prime source of turbulence along the path to implementation. "It's like if you're trying to get your work done, and somebody's slapping you in the face all the time," he said.

The choices Congress made in writing the law have contributed to the complexity of getting it up and running. Congress did not employ a single-payer system that would have given the federal government complete control, and in an attempt to give states some flexibility, it offered them the chance to set up their own health insurance marketplaces, or exchanges. However, more than half of the states decided to let the federal government create one for them, creating a hodgepodge of state-run and federally facilitated marketplaces.

The Supreme Court added to the complexity last year when it upheld the core of the law but said states should be allowed to opt out of the Medicaid expansion. Some statehouses are still grappling with whether to accept the opt-out. Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, lawmakers have gone back and recaptured some of the money the law would have overpaid as tax credits for those using subsidies to buy insurance on the exchanges.

In 2011, all sides agreed to repeal a business expense reporting requirement that had been designed so the IRS could make sure employers were paying their full tax burdens. This week's decision signaled that more tweaks and changes may be on the way. "These things have never been that easy," said Mr. Jost. "I just think it's so unfortunate that it's turned out this way."

Title: House to Vote on Sandy Aid Package by Jan. 15, Speaker John Boehner Assures Lawmakers

Article:

Speaker John Boehner has assured New York and New Jersey lawmakers that the House will vote on a massive aid package for Superstorm Sandy victims by Jan. 15, following bipartisan outrage over a decision to postpone the vote until the next session. The House is expected to vote on a $9 billion flood insurance measure on Friday, followed by a vote on a $51 billion aid bill on Jan. 15.

Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.), who earlier criticized party leaders for the move, reported after a closed-door meeting with the speaker that they were told the House would vote on the aid package in two installments. As far as King is concerned, he stated that the meeting was "an extremely positive meeting."

Boehner and House Republican Leader Eric Cantor affirmed the plan in a written statement, saying, "Getting critical aid to the victims of Hurricane Sandy should be the first priority in the new Congress, and that was reaffirmed today with members of the New York and New Jersey delegations."

The decision still pushes a vote until the next session, which starts Thursday. However, the meeting appeared to calm tensions in the party. King, who was among the most vocal in his complaints, earlier called the decision to put off a vote a "disgrace" and "immoral."

President Obama, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo also decried the "failure" to act, saying in a statement, "When American citizens are in need, we come to their aid. That tradition was abandoned in the House last night."

At a press conference earlier in the afternoon, Christie said the blame lies with House Republicans and Boehner himself. However, Boehner's toughest Republican critics on the Hill were walking things back late Wednesday.

Some conservatives had earlier expressed concern about the sheer size of the Sandy bill, with the Senate-passed version exceeding $60 billion. The House Appropriations Committee produced a bill Tuesday that significantly pared back the Senate version, bringing it down to $27 billion. Now, it appears the House will move forward with a vote on the full $60 billion, in two installments.

A procession of lawmakers took to the House floor Wednesday to urge action on the bill and decry the decision to postpone it. "We can not and we should not wait," House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer said. "We must not walk away. I urge the speaker of this House to reconsider and act immediately."

A spokesman for Boehner, Michael Steel, said, "The speaker is committed to getting this bill passed this month."

Title: Vice President Pence Warns North Korea of U.S. Response to Weapons Use, Promises Peaceful Diplomacy

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence, aboard the USS Ronald Reagan on Wednesday, warned North Korea not to test the resolve of the U.S. military, promising an "overwhelming and effective" response to any use of conventional or nuclear weapons. Pence's remarks came as the White House deals with the controversy surrounding the USS Carl Vinson's movement towards Australia instead of North Korea.

Pence, who was speaking to 2,500 sailors in blue fatigues and Naval baseball caps, emphasized the U.S.'s commitment to peace while also highlighting the readiness of the military. He stated, "The United States of America will always seek peace but under President Trump, the shield stands guard and the sword stands ready."

The vice president reaffirmed the U.S.'s commitment to working with allies such as Japan, China, and other global powers to apply economic and diplomatic pressure on North Korea. He also emphasized the importance of readiness, saying, "Those who would challenge our resolve or readiness should know, we will defeat any attack and meet any use of conventional or nuclear weapons with an overwhelming and effective American response."

Pence also addressed the U.S.'s alliance with Pacific Rim nations and its commitment to protecting freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, a region where China has been staking claims to disputed territory.

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, currently on a Middle East tour, also warned against North Korea's latest failed missile launch, describing it as a "reckless act of provocation." Mattis did not specify the type of missile, but stated it was not of intercontinental range, meaning it could not reach U.S. territory.

An unnamed official reportedly said the missile was a Scud variant known as a KN-17. Mattis also credited China with trying to help resolve the North Korea situation with the goal of denuclearizing the peninsula.

The Trump administration has signaled a forceful U.S. stance on North Korea's recent actions, with Pence's visit to the Demilitarized Zone dividing North and South Korea on Monday serving as a show of American resolve. However, the specifics of the administration's next steps remain unclear.

Behind the heated rhetoric, Trump's strategy in the region appears to resemble that of his predecessor, Barack Obama, albeit with the added unpredictability of a new president who has shown a willingness to use force. Pence stated that Trump is hopeful China will use its influence in the region to pressure North Korea to abandon its weapons program, but expressed impatience with North Korea's unwillingness to move toward denuclearization.

In Moscow, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov expressed hope that the U.S. would follow a peaceful resolution to the situation, while China made a plea for a return to negotiations to bring the escalating dispute to a peaceful resolution. China also expressed concern over the U.S.'s plans to deploy a missile defense system in South Korea, stating it was damaging its relations with China.

Title: Sen. Cory Booker Disagrees with Sen. Elizabeth Warren's Proposal to Break Up Tech Giants

Article:

Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ), a 2020 presidential candidate, has criticized his Senate colleague and fellow presidential candidate, Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), for her call to break up some of the country's most powerful technology companies. In an interview with ABC's Jonathan Karl on "This Week," Booker expressed his disagreement with Warren's proposal, stating it as not suitable for a president and sounding "more like a Donald Trump thing to say."

Booker, who has pledged to call for Justice Department investigations and antitrust laws to rein in monopolies if elected, expressed concern over the "really ill effects" of "corporate consolidation" in America. However, he disagreed with Warren's plan to create a level playing field by splitting giant tech firms, including Amazon, Facebook, and Google, which she has accused of unfair competition and "eating up" startups.

"I do not think that a president should be running around pointing at companies and saying breaking them up without any kind of process here," Booker said. He further compared Warren's proposal to Trump's rhetoric, stating, "It's not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks. That sounds more like a Donald Trump thing to say, ‘ I'm going to break up you guys.’"

Booker insisted he was not comparing Warren to Trump, calling her "my friend." However, he added, "I'm telling you right now: We do not need a president that is going to use their own personal beliefs and tell you which companies we should break up."

Another Democratic presidential candidate, Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA), also weighed in on the dominance of Silicon Valley's major tech titans, remarking that Facebook "has prioritized its growth over the best interests of its consumers, especially on the issue of privacy." When asked if Facebook should be broken up, Harris said, "I think we have to seriously take a look at that."

Title: Chaotic U.S. Senate Confirmation Hearing for Brett Kavanaugh Marked by Protests and Document Disputes

Article:

The U.S. Senate confirmation hearing for Brett Kavanaugh, President Donald Trump's Supreme Court pick, was marked by chaos on Tuesday as Democrats protested the withholding of documents related to Kavanaugh's past White House service and numerous protesters were arrested. The hearing, which lasted over seven hours, saw more than 70 protesters removed from the room and charged with disorderly conduct, along with nine more outside the hearing.

Kavanaugh, a conservative federal appeals court judge, told the senators that "a judge must be independent, not swayed by public pressure. Our independent judiciary is the crown jewel of our constitutional republic." The hearing, which was interrupted repeatedly by Democratic senators and protesters, became a tumultuous event.

Democrats decried the withholding of the documents and sought to adjourn the hearing, as Republican Senator Chuck Grassley, the committee's chairman, struggled to maintain order. "This is the first confirmation for a Supreme Court justice I've seen, basically, according to mob rule," said Republican Senator John Cornyn, a characterization Democrats rejected. "What we've heard is the noise of democracy," Democratic Senator Dick Durbin responded.

Protesters, mostly women, took turns yelling as senators spoke, shouting slogans such as "This is a travesty of justice," "Our democracy is broken," and "Vote no on Kavanaugh." Concerns were expressed about the potential impact of Kavanaugh on abortion rights, healthcare access, and gun control.

Democratic Senator Cory Booker appealed to Grassley's "sense of decency and integrity" and said the withholding of the documents by Republicans and the White House left lawmakers unable to properly vet Kavanaugh. "We can not possibly move forward. We have not had an opportunity to have a meaningful hearing," said Democratic Senator Kamala Harris.

Grassley deemed the Democrats' request to halt the hearing "out of order" and accused them of obstruction. Republicans hold a slim Senate majority and can confirm Kavanaugh if they stay united. There were no signs of Republican defections.

President Trump criticized the Democrats on Twitter, stating the hearing was "truly a display of how mean, angry and despicable the other side is" and accusing them of "looking to inflict pain and embarrassment" on Kavanaugh. If confirmed, Kavanaugh, who is 53, is expected to move the court, which already has a conservative majority, further to the right.

Senate Democratic leaders have vowed a fierce fight to try to block Kavanaugh's confirmation. Democrats signaled they would press Kavanaugh on abortion, gun rights, and presidential power when they get to question him starting on Wednesday in a hearing scheduled to run through Friday.

Democrats have demanded in vain to see documents relating to Kavanaugh's time as staff secretary to Republican former President George W. Bush from 2003 to 2006. That job involved managing paper flow from advisers to Bush. Republicans have released some, but not all, documents concerning Kavanaugh's two prior years as a lawyer in Bush's White House Counsel's Office.

U.S. Supreme Court nominee judge Brett Kavanaugh sat quietly, fingers intertwined, as protesters in the audience screamed while being dragged out of the room. He occasionally jotted notes on paper. When he finally got to speak, Kavanaugh called the Supreme Court "the last line of defense for the separation of powers (in the U.S. government) and the rights and liberties guaranteed by the Constitution."

As the hearing paused for a lunch break, Fred Guttenberg, whose daughter who was killed in the Parkland, Florida high school mass shooting in February, tried to talk to Kavanaugh but the nominee turned away. Video of the encounter was shared widely on social media. "I guess he did not want to deal with the reality of gun violence," Guttenberg wrote on Twitter afterward. White House spokesman Raj Shah said security intervened before Kavanaugh could shake Guttenberg's hand.

The Democratic frustrations that boiled over on Tuesday had been simmering for more than two years. Democrats have accused Senate Republican leaders of stealing a Supreme Court seat by refusing to consider Democratic former President Barack Obama's nominee to the high court, Merrick Garland, in 2016, allowing Trump to fill a Supreme Court vacancy instead.

Republicans also last year reduced the margin for advancing Supreme Court nominations from 60 votes in the 100-seat Senate to a simple majority in order to force through the confirmation of Trump's first high court nominee Neil Gorsuch. The Senate is likely to vote on confirmation by the end of September. The court begins its next term in October. The hearing gave Democrats a platform to make their case against Kavanaugh ahead of November's congressional elections in which they are seeking to seize control of Congress from Republicans.

Liberals are concerned Kavanaugh could provide a decisive fifth vote on the nine-justice court to overturn or weaken the landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling legalizing abortion nationwide. Kavanaugh is likely to be questioned about his views on investigating sitting presidents and Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and possible collusion between Moscow and Trump's campaign.

Title: US-Iran Tensions Escalate as Leaders Exchange Hostile Remarks

Article:

The United States and Iran have engaged in a series of hostile exchanges, escalating tensions between the two nations. US President Donald Trump issued a warning to Iran, stating that the country would face consequences "the likes of which few throughout history have ever suffered" if it threatened the US. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani earlier stated that a war with Iran would be "the mother of all wars."

In May, the US withdrew from a deal that curbed Iran's nuclear activities in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions. The US is now re-imposing these sanctions, despite objections from the UK, France, China, Russia, and Germany, who all signed the 2015 agreement.

The US is suspicious of Iranian activity in the Middle East, and is an ally of Israel and Saudi Arabia, two of Iran's foes. President Rouhani's comments, made to Iranian diplomats, did leave open the possibility of future good relations with the US.

"America should know that peace with Iran is the mother of all peace, and war with Iran is the mother of all wars," he said, according to Iran's state news agency Irna. Responding to Mr. Trump's broadside, Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif tweeted, "Color us unimpressed."

President Trump's aggressive rhetoric mirrors his Twitter barrages against North Korea's Kim Jong-un, whom he branded a "madman." Their verbal hostilities, however, have evolved into diplomacy.

On Monday, a senior commander in Iran's Revolutionary Guards suggested the US president's statements were part of a broader strategy. "The remarks Trump makes against Iran are psychological warfare, and he would be mistaken should he seek to take action against Iran," Gholamhossein Gheybparvar said, quoted by the Iranian Students News Agency.

On Sunday, US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he wanted to try to stop countries importing Iranian oil by November as part of continued pressure on Tehran. Addressing a group of Iranian Americans in California, he said the Iranian regime "resembles the mafia more than a government."

The gathering was the first time a top US official had directly addressed such a large number of Iranian Americans, and is seen as part of the administration's strategy to increase pressure on Iran's leadership.

President Trump has consistently opposed the 2015 nuclear deal, which saw the US release billions of dollars of frozen assets in exchange for curbs on Iran's nuclear program. The Trump administration regards Iran as a destabilizing force in the Middle East, arguing the nuclear deal enabled Iran to pursue a more assertive regional policy. Iran has sent hundreds of troops and thousands of volunteer militiamen to Syria, and has strengthened its military presence there.

Gulf states have accused Iran of backing Yemen's Houthi rebels with both money and weapons, though Iran has denied this. Saudi Arabia, a key US ally, is a major adversary of Iran and has repeatedly warned about Iran's intentions.

In May, Mr. Trump called the nuclear accord - or Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) as it is formally known - a "horrible, one-sided deal that should have never, ever been made." He alleged that the deal did not restrict Iran's "destabilizing activities" in the region enough, and could not detect or prevent any breaking of its terms.

Analysts also cited the influence of White House Iran hawks including Mr. Pompeo and US National Security Adviser John Bolton, and Mr. Trump's tendency to target major policies of his predecessor President Obama.

Iran insists its nuclear program is entirely peaceful, and its compliance with the deal has been verified by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which has said Iran is honoring its commitments. The IAEA has said its inspectors were granted access to all locations they needed to visit in 2017, but that they did not seek to enter any military sites, which Iranian officials declared off-limits - a move the US said raised doubts over Tehran's compliance.

In May, Mr. Pompeo outlined 12 conditions for any "new deal" between the US and Iran, including the withdrawal of its forces from Syria and an end to its support for rebels in Yemen. Iran is one of the world's largest oil producers, with exports worth billions of dollars each year. It is already feeling economic pressures, and has seen large-scale protests over rising prices and a decline in the value of its currency, the rial.

Title: Democrats Face Challenges in ACA Implementation, but Lack of Veto-Proof Majority for Repeal

Article:

The implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has faced numerous challenges, with many criticizing its rollout as a debacle. However, the possibility of full repeal of the ACA is unlikely, as it would require a veto-proof majority in both the House and the Senate, a situation that is currently far from reality.

In a recent interview on MSNBC, Representative Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) stated, "I can't see a veto-proof number coming up... I just don't see that happening." He further added, "Democrats are going to be vulnerable to Republican attacks on the Affordable Care Act regardless."

The ACA, while bearing President Obama's name, is a Democratic Party creation. If Democrats were to help Republicans obliterate it, it would be seen as an admission of governing incompetence, potentially leading to a "do not elect me or members of my party because we do not know what we're doing" vote.

Two possible futures for the ACA are foreseeable. One is where the ACA limps ahead, and the other is a swift reversal of fortune. The nightmare scenario is not the repeal of Obamacare, but rather the difficulty in achieving a massive expansion of health insurance coverage in the U.S.

If the Healthcare.gov website takes significantly longer to fix than the Obama administration is forecasting, or if enrollments never spike, political, moral, and substantive considerations could change. For instance, if fewer people enroll through the exchanges than see their policies canceled, it could lead to a net reduction in individual market coverage. This would be politically humiliating and raise questions about the fairness of imposing penalties on people for not entering a system they cannot access or trust.

In this scenario, Democrats would face intense pressure to vote for a delay of the individual mandate. They might do so to stave off a full-scale rebellion, with the administration likely acting unilaterally, agreeing to provide hardship exemptions en masse, and hoping to hold the votes for a universal delay below a veto-proof threshold, to protect markets in states with functioning exchanges.

A more desirable scenario is one where the website works well in a few weeks, enrollments shoot upward, quickly overtaking the number of people whose policies have been canceled. In this scenario, aggregates would begin to matter, and the media's bias towards anecdote and hardship would have to contend with raw numbers. If total enrollments, including new Medicaid beneficiaries, approach anywhere near the 16 million the Congressional Budget Office initially projected, the ACA's success would be impossible for the media to ignore.

Starting Dec. 1, opponents of the law will screen-grab and disseminate every website failure they encounter. However, if the law truly is working well "for the vast majority of users" as the administration likes to say, it will be reflected in swelling enrollment figures and regular updates on the law's improving progress. This will take the sting out of "you can keep it" attacks, and Democrats will no longer have anything to run from. In fact, they might even repurpose the Upton bill, using it to put Republicans on record against stripping new beneficiaries of their health plans.

Such a volte-face could stop the repeal campaign dead in its tracks.

Title: Impeachment of President Obama Unlikely Despite Republican Control of Congress

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the prospect of impeaching President Barack Obama, a long-held dream of some conservative groups, appears unlikely, even if Republicans gain control of the Senate and maintain their majority in the House of Representatives in the November congressional elections.

The reasons for this are twofold. First, the mathematical odds are against Republicans achieving the two-thirds Senate majority necessary to convict Obama if the House of Representatives were to pass articles of impeachment. Under the most optimistic election results for Republicans, they would fall short of this requirement.

Second, a CNN/ORC International Poll last week showed that nearly two-thirds of respondents oppose impeaching the President. This reality is not lost on Republican leaders such as House Speaker John Boehner and House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, who have publicly dismissed the possibility of impeachment.

Boehner stated this week, "We have no plans to impeach the President. We have no future plans." Ryan, who may have presidential ambitions in 2016, also quashed the possibility, saying Wednesday that "this does not rise to the high crimes and misdemeanors level" of impeachment.

Meanwhile, Obama and Democrats are using the threat of impeachment to raise funds and inspire their supporters to turn out in November. The President cited the vote by House Republicans authorizing Boehner to sue him over executive actions, saying Congress should instead be passing legislation.

"They're mad because I'm doing my job," Obama said of his Republican foes, urging them to "stop just hatin' all the time." In debate before Wednesday night's vote, House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi made sure to link the lawsuit proposal to possible impeachment down the road, calling it a first step to trying to oust the President next year.

The issue resonates with Democratic supporters, according to Rep. Steve Israel of New York, who chairs the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. The group has raised $7.6 million online since Boehner announced the lawsuit plan just over five weeks ago, he said.

"You bet we're going to run on a Congress that is just obsessed with lawsuits, suing the President, talking about impeaching him instead of solutions for the middle class, talking about jobs and infrastructure," he said.

The impeachment discussion reflects deeper political undercurrents, particularly for a right wing already divided between diehard conservatives and more moderate Republicans. Wendy Schiller, a political scientist at Brown University, called impeachment a "farfetched" maneuver that could cause independent voters leaning Republican now to instead vote Democratic in November.

"It reflects in the Republican Party the idea that if you lose an election, you can use every means possible to nullify the result," she said. "That's just not how America works."

Jonathan Chait, a writer who predicted four years ago in a New Republic article that House Republicans would vote to impeach Obama before his presidency ended, said Wednesday that he now doubts that will happen. Missteps by Republicans, including primary defeats of viable candidates by conservative extremists and the government shutdown they forced last year, "really convinced the establishment that they could not indulge the base on all its flights of fancy," Chait said.

Now, Boehner and others want to steer their base away from impeachment, he said, noting that they fear getting pushed into holding a vote that would be politically damaging. In dismissing an impeachment move, Boehner and Ryan sought to shift the blame for any discussion about it onto Democrats and the White House.

Boehner called it a Democratic fundraising "scam," adding, "They're trying to rally their people to give money and to show up in this year's elections." Asked about the accusation, White House spokesman Josh Earnest offered a list of Republican legislators who have discussed impeaching Obama in recent months, including Reps. Steve King of Iowa, Ted Yoho of Florida, and Steve Stockman and Blake Farenthold of Texas.

The challenge to Boehner and other GOP leaders is to find a middle path between tea party demands to impeach Obama and less extreme options for action, such as the lawsuit. An impeachment effort after the November election would dominate Washington in the final two years of Obama's presidency, posing possible benefits and risks.

It would divert attention from congressional dysfunction contributing to dismal approval ratings but also could cause the public to blame Republicans for exacerbating that dysfunction. "We've got a lot of tools at our disposal," Rep. Tom Cole of Oklahoma said, citing such steps as cutting funding for some parts of government disproportionate to the problems.

"Nor do I think you ought to do things in a legislative sense to harass the President," said Cole, who is a Boehner ally. "We've got a disagreement between the two branches, and this is not uncommon. You go to court, and that's what we're seeking to do."

The impeachment proceedings against President Richard Nixon and his subsequent resignation still rankle many Republicans today, 40 years later. It was an event that made efforts to remove a sitting president part of routine political discussion in America. A GOP-led House voted to impeach President Bill Clinton on charges of perjury and obstruction in 1998. The Senate acquitted him on both charges, with none of the minority Democrats voting to convict, and he stayed in office.

Today, any Republican with presidential ambitions—such as Ryan, perhaps—wants to avoid making impeachment a reflex response to dissatisfaction with the White House, Schiller noted. "If you want to be president some day," she said, "the last thing you want is for Congress to be able willy-nilly to impeach you."

Title: Edward Snowden Remains in Moscow Airport Transit Zone as Asylum Application Pending

Article:

Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency (NSA) contractor and leaker of classified information, remains in the transit zone of Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport, following a brief period of speculation that he might be able to leave the airport and enter Russia.

On Wednesday, a Russian lawyer was reportedly planning to meet with Snowden at the airport, sparking speculation that he would bring documents allowing Snowden to formally enter Russia. However, it appears that even with new legal papers, Snowden must continue to wait at the airport while Russian authorities consider his asylum request.

Snowden applied for temporary asylum in Russia last week, after his attempts to leave the airport and fly out of the country were thwarted. The Federal Migration Service spokeswoman told the Associated Press they had no information about the status of Snowden's asylum application.

Snowden has been staying at the airport transit zone since June 23, when he arrived on a flight from Hong Kong. U.S. prosecutors charged Snowden last month with espionage and theft of government property. On Monday, the U.S. Ambassador in Moscow, Michael McFaul, demanded that Russia turn over Snowden, stating via Twitter, "Mr. Snowden ought to be returned to the United States to face the felony charges against him."

Russian state news agency RIA Novosti quoted an unnamed security official on Wednesday as saying that Snowden has been issued documents allowing him to formally enter Russia. However, this information has not been confirmed by other sources.

Anna Zakharenkova, a spokeswoman for the airport, told The Associated Press that Anatoly Kucherena, a Russian lawyer advising Snowden, would meet with him. President Vladimir Putin has stated that Snowden can be granted asylum in Russia only if he stops leaking secrets.

Granting Snowden asylum would add new tensions to U.S.-Russian relations, which are already strained by criticism of Russia's pressure on opposition groups, Moscow's suspicion of U.S. missile-defense plans, and Russia's resistance to sanctions against the regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad.

Title: U.S. Calls for Integration of Religious Freedom into Foreign Policy to Counter Terrorism

Article:

The United States is advocating for the integration of religious freedom into its foreign policy as a means to counter terrorism, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa. The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) is reportedly destroying Christian communities and relics, committing atrocities against religious minorities, and causing an escalating refugee crisis.

The Obama Administration has been criticized for its lack of action in defending religious freedom abroad, with the administration repeatedly refusing to address the issue and the devastating consequences it has on targeted religious communities. As a nation founded on the principles of religious freedom, the U.S. is urged to take a more active role in combating religious intolerance, which is contributing to political instability and violence in the region.

The Obama Administration can counter ISIS's strategy by building alliances with local and regional leaders who can expose radical ideologies and champion pluralism and tolerance. The Administration should also combat terrorist propaganda about religious minorities and develop programs that promote tolerance and empower minorities to advocate for their rights and interests.

A U.S. foreign policy committed to religious freedom can advance national security interests, stabilize and consolidate the spread of democracy, help sustain economic growth, and promote the equality of men and women. It can also help prevent religiously-motivated terrorism and undermine the conditions that have helped spur the rise of groups like ISIS, Boko Haram, and the Shuddhikaran Movement.

Furthermore, higher levels of religious freedom are associated with higher levels of economic productivity and growth, as recent studies by groups such as the Religious Freedom and Business Foundation have found. Sustainable political and economic development is only possible when religious freedom and equal opportunity contribute to a secure environment in which citizens and businesses can operate freely.

Finally, the U.S. must remain committed to religious freedom because of the special distinction religious freedom holds as a fundamental human right, a belief shared by democratic countries across the globe and protected by numerous international treaties and agreements. American support for religious liberty sends a powerful message to threatened communities around the world: America is their friend. Such support builds enduring goodwill towards the U.S. among those who could be leading their own nations in the years ahead. It also reminds all observers, whether friendly or hostile, that the U.S. remains committed to a world where justice and human dignity are central to legitimate governance.

Title: Kamala Harris Ends 2020 Presidential Bid, Marks Historic Exit from Democratic Race

Article:

Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) announced on Tuesday that she was ending her bid for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, marking a significant moment in a campaign that once held historic potential.

In a statement to supporters, Harris cited insufficient financial resources as the reason for her decision. "I've taken stock and looked at this from every angle, and over the last few days have come to one of the hardest decisions of my life," the California Democrat said.

A senior campaign aide confirmed that Harris made the decision on Monday after discussing the path forward with family and other top officials over the Thanksgiving holiday.

Harris, the first woman and first black attorney general and U.S. senator in California's history, launched her campaign in front of 20,000 people on a chilly January day in Oakland, California. She was widely viewed as a candidate poised to excite the multiracial coalition of voters that sent Barack Obama to the White House.

Her departure from the race erodes the diversity of the Democratic field, which is currently dominated by a top tier that is white and mostly male.

Throughout her campaign, Harris struggled to craft a message that resonated with voters or secure the necessary funds to continue her run. She raised an impressive $12 million in the first three months of her campaign but was unable to attract the type of attention being showered on other candidates such as Pete Buttigieg and Elizabeth Warren.

In her note to supporters, Harris lamented the role of money in politics and took a shot at billionaire candidates Tom Steyer and Michael Bloomberg, who are funding their own presidential bids. "I'm not a billionaire. I can't fund my own campaign. And as the campaign has gone on, it's become harder and harder to raise the money we need to compete," she said.

Harris's campaign was also marked by inconsistency in her pitch to voters. Her slogan "For the people" referenced her career as a prosecutor, a record that was viewed skeptically by the party's most progressive voters.

With Harris's exit, 15 Democrats remain in the race for the nomination. Several praised her on Tuesday, including former Vice President Joe Biden, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, and New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker. Harris anchored her campaign in the powerful legacy of pioneering African Americans, often referencing the struggles and achievements of Shirley Chisholm and other trailblazers.

Title: Obama's Apology and Healthcare.gov Progress Report

Article:

President Obama's recent interview with NBC's Chuck Todd focused on his apology for the promise that individuals could keep their existing insurance policies, but the most newsworthy moment was his assessment of the progress made in fixing the Healthcare.gov website.

Obama stated, "I'm confident that it will be even better by November 30 and that the majority of people are going to be able to get on there. They're going to be able to enroll. They're going to be able to apply. And they're going to get a good deal -- a better deal than they've got right now when it comes to buying health insurance."

However, the administration's progress report on Thursday revealed that the website's issues persist. A spokeswoman for the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services explained, "Essentially what is happening is people are going through the entire process. As we have fixed certain pieces of functionality, like the account creation process, we're seeing volume go further down the application. We're identifying new issues that we need to be in a position to troubleshoot."

The administration remains confident that Healthcare.gov will be functional for the majority of users by the end of the month. However, the detailed assessments make this increasingly hard to believe, as insurance industry officials and Republicans in Congress express skepticism.

Industry consultant Robert Laszewski suggests policy options, such as encouraging people to enroll directly with insurance companies participating in the exchanges and asking working- and middle-class people to pay full premiums until the subsidy system is functional.

Politically, the situation is complex, with Republicans planning to put legislation on the House floor that would allow people to keep their canceled plans for another year and exempt them from the mandate penalty. This bill has little policy merit but could fracture the pro-Obamacare coalition and potentially require Obama to veto it.

If Healthcare.gov is not functional by the end of the month, the administration may have to consider administrative remedies, such as extending the open enrollment period and providing hardship exemptions from the penalty to people in states without functioning marketplaces. However, this would require admitting failure and could lead to lasting damage to Obama's signature achievement.

Title: Trump Sends Letter to Pelosi, Labels Impeachment as "Illegal, Partisan Attempted Coup"

Article:

In an extraordinary move on the eve of an anticipated historic vote in the House of Representatives to impeach President Donald Trump, the President sent a six-page personal letter to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday. In the letter, Trump denounces the impeachment process as an "illegal, partisan attempted coup."

The President writes, "I write this letter to you for the purpose of history and to put my thoughts on a permanent and indelible record." He further states, "One hundred years from now, when people look back at this affair, I want them to understand it and learn from it, so that it can never happen to another President again."

The letter, which represents a compilation of the President's grievances with the impeachment process and Pelosi's conduct, is a remarkable expression of the President's feelings. The President, making no attempt to mask his personal animus towards the Speaker, accuses Pelosi of being inauthentic for saying she prays for the President.

The President writes, "You are offending Americans of faith by continually saying 'I pray for the President'... when you know this statement is not true, unless it is meant in a negative sense." He further takes issue with her demeanor throughout this process, writing that "Perhaps most insulting of all is your false display of solemnity... no intelligent person believes what you are saying."

The President contends that "more due process was afforded to those accused in the Salem Witch Trials," and accuses Pelosi of turning what he describes as a "policy disagreement" into an impeachable offense. He even harks back to his Electoral College victory some three years ago, saying that Pelosi is trying to undo the results of the 2016 election because "your chosen candidate lost the election" and says Pelosi is suffering from a case of "Trump derangement syndrome."

"You view democracy as your enemy!" the President writes to Pelosi in the exclamation point-laden letter. "You are the ones interfering in America's elections. You are the ones subverting America's Democracy. You are are the ones Obstructing Justice. You are the ones bringing pain and suffering to our Republic for your own selfish personal, political, and partisan gain," the President writes.

Minutes after the President's angrily-worded letter to Pelosi was made public to reporters, the President struck a notably more subdued tone in comments before cameras as he was seated next to the visiting President of Guatemala. When asked if he takes any personal responsibility for the looming impeachment, the President said he takes "zero" responsibility.

"No, I do not take any, zero, to put it mildly," Trump said. "They took a perfect phone call that I had with the President of Ukraine, an absolutely perfect call... to impeach the President of the United States for that is a disgrace and it's a mark on our country."

Title: Trump Threatens to Withhold Federal Funds for California Wildfire Response, Sparking Criticism

 Article:

 In a series of tweets on Wednesday, President Donald Trump threatened to cut off federal funds for California wildfire response, stating that the money is being wasted. Trump wrote, "Billions of dollars are sent to the State of California for Forest fires that, with proper Forest Management, would never happen." He continued, "Unless they get their act together, which is unlikely, I have ordered FEMA to send no more money. It is a disgraceful situation in lives & money!"

 House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from California, responded to Trump's threat, stating that it "insults the memory of scores of Americans who perished in wildfires last year & thousands more who lost their homes." Pelosi's tweet called on House Republican leader Kevin McCarthy, another Californian, to join her in condemning the president's actions and reassuring California residents that federal aid will be available during their time of need.

 Trump has previously threatened to order the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to cut off funds for California wildfires, but the administration has not published an official order. Critics on Twitter questioned whether Trump could legally withhold FEMA money that has been appropriated.

 State officials accused Trump of playing politics with the California wildfires and said he does not understand the issues involved in fighting fires. They also questioned whether Trump is targeting California because it is a Democratic state.

 Brian Rice, president of the California Professional Firefighters, criticized Trump's blame of state forest management for the wildfires. Rice cited the damage in and around Paradise, California, and stated, "The people there have only begun to be able to rebuild their lives... Now, they find themselves being used as pawns in the president’s ill-informed chest-pounding at their expense."

 Rice noted that more than 60 percent of California's forests are controlled by the federal government, not the state. California Governor Gavin Newsom, who has criticized Trump's firefighting policy, proposed $105 million in new spending to prevent, fight, and escape wildfires in the wake of one of the state's worst fire seasons.

 Trump's policy decisions have been known to change or modify days after they are announced, as demonstrated by the slowed-down withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria.

Title: Preparing for a Grocery Shopping Trip During the COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

In the time of the coronavirus, a typical grocery shopping trip may present a different experience than before. Here are some recommendations for how to prepare for the journey:

1. Organize your shopping list by department or aisle to minimize time spent crisscrossing the store.
2. Consider shopping solo to reduce the number of people in the store at one time, making it easier to maintain physical distancing.
3. If possible, combine shopping trips for multiple households to minimize travel and exposure.
4. Be prepared for lines outside the store entrance, as some stores may be limiting the number of shoppers allowed in at one time.
5. Wear earphones to avoid small talk in line, if desired.
6. Sanitize carts or wipe them down if the store allows it. Some stores may be sanitizing carts between shoppers.
7. Practice patience and avoid getting too close to others, but also be understanding if someone invades your personal space.
8. Expect many items to be out of stock, and be prepared to adjust your list with alternative options.
9. If shopping for others, ask them for their preferred alternatives beforehand to reduce shopping time and set expectations.
10. Some stores may not accept reusable bags, so be prepared to use paper or plastic bags instead.

Title: Timeline of Events Leading to the Death of 8-Year-Old Migrant Felipe Alonzo-Gomez

Article:

An 8-year-old migrant, identified as Felipe Alonzo-Gomez, spent his final days in a series of border patrol stations and hospitals, approximately 2,000 miles from his family's home in Guatemala. The child's death, which occurred while in the custody of US Customs and Border Protection (CBP), follows the death of a 7-year-old Guatemalan girl under similar circumstances.

According to a timeline provided by CBP, Felipe was apprehended with his father near the Paso Del Norte port of entry in El Paso, Texas for illegal entry on December 18. The apprehension location is a short drive from the port, but detainees may be held in the field until transportation is available.

Felipe and his father were transferred to the Paso Del Norte processing center, where they received food, snacks, juice, and water, and six welfare checks were logged. They were then moved to the El Paso Border Patrol Station, where they received showers, food, juice, and water, and 17 welfare checks were logged over the next two days.

Due to capacity levels at the El Paso station, Felipe and his father were transferred to the Alamogordo Border Patrol Station in Alamogordo, New Mexico. Upon arrival, they were provided with personal hygiene products and meals, and several welfare checks were conducted.

A processing agent noticed that Felipe was coughing and appeared to have glossy eyes. About 30 minutes later, based on the agents' observations, Felipe was transferred to Gerald Champion Regional Medical Center in Alamogordo with possible influenza symptoms. He was accompanied by his father.

At the hospital, Felipe was diagnosed with a common cold and given Tylenol. He was evaluated for release but was found to have a 103-degree fever and was held for continued observation. Felipe was released from the emergency room with a prescription for Ibuprofen and amoxicillin, a commonly prescribed antibiotic.

Felipe and his father were transported to temporary holding at the Highway 70 checkpoint, where they were offered and accepted a hot meal. Agents provided Felipe with a dose of the prescribed medication as ordered by the medical staff, and several welfare checks were conducted that evening.

However, Felipe appeared to be nauseous and vomited. Agents were aware of this and helped clean up the vomit. His father declined further medical assistance as the child had been feeling better. Due to a lack of an EMT on duty, agents made the decision to return Felipe and his father to Gerald Champion Regional Medical Center out of caution.

During transportation to the hospital, Felipe began to vomit and lost consciousness. Hospital staff were unable to revive Felipe and pronounced him dead. The Guatemalan Consulate was contacted about the child's death, and his father is currently detained at the Alamogordo Station pending transfer to ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations. He has spoken to his spouse in Guatemala and the Guatemalan Consulate.

The Guatemalan Foreign Ministry issued a statement that it was alerted to a minor's death in the US. Guatemala's Consul General in Phoenix, Oscar Padilla Lam, traveled to Alamogordo to meet with the boy's father to "hear his version of the facts," according to the statement. The Foreign Ministry stated it will provide all assistance and consular protection to the boy's father and assume responsibility for the repatriation of the boy's remains.

Title: Strzok Testifies: Hillary Clinton Not a Target in Email Investigation

Article:

In a transcript released Thursday, former FBI Agent Peter Strzok testified before the House Judiciary Committee last year that Hillary Clinton was not a target, witness, subject, or suspect during the investigation into her storage and sending of classified emails on her home server. Strzok stated that while Clinton was considered a "critical player," she was not the only person of investigative interest.

Rep. Doug Collins (R-GA) inserted the transcripts into the Congressional Record during a floor speech, expressing frustration with the Justice Department's slow release of information. Strzok, who was the lead agent in an investigation into President Trump during the 2016 campaign, later worked for special counsel Robert Mueller before being removed from the team due to anti-Trump text messages exchanged with his affair partner, FBI lawyer Lisa Page. He was subsequently fired from the FBI.

During his interview with the House Judiciary Committee, Strzok admitted to his affair with Page, despite acknowledging that it made him vulnerable to being blackmailed by America's enemies. The transcript is the third set released by Rep. Collins, following those from Justice Department official Bruce Ohr and Page herself.

The Strzok transcript reveals some surprising discrepancies between the two lovers. For instance, in a text sent to Strzok, Page described Clinton as a "menace" that needed to be saved, while Strzok stated that he believed the "menace" referred to Russia.

Strzok also disputed the meaning of the now-infamous text exchange where Page expressed concern that Trump would become president, to which Strzok replied, "No. No he won't. We'll stop it." In his June 27, 2018, closed-door appearance with the Judiciary Committee, Strzok clarified that he did not mean he would take official action to impact the presidency.

Strzok also defended his texts from March 2016, before Clinton had won the Democratic nomination and Trump the GOP nomination, where he stated Clinton "should" win the White House 100 million to zero. Strzok maintained that his confidence in Clinton did not influence his investigative efforts.

Title: Justice Scalia's Views on the Death Penalty and the McCollum-Brown Case

Article:

Justice Antonin Scalia, a prominent figure in the United States Supreme Court, has faced criticism for his views on the death penalty, particularly in light of the exoneration of Henry Lee McCollum and Leon Brown, two mentally disabled men who spent decades on death row for a crime they did not commit.

The case, which has garnered significant attention, involves the two brothers who were convicted based on coerced confessions when they were 19 and 15 years old. The conviction was overturned after DNA evidence implicated another man and other evidence from the crime scene that pointed to another convicted rapist was processed.

In 1994, in the case Collins v. Collins, Justice Scalia cited this case in his disagreement with Justice Harry Blackmun on the constitutionality of the death penalty. Scalia, known for his sarcasm, wrote that Justice Blackmun's description of a lethal injection as a "less brutal" method of death compared to other cases was "enviable."

Critics argue that Scalia's comments suggest that the methods of punishment should be directly correlated to the brutality of the crime, a concept rejected by the Enlightenment-influenced writers of the Constitution.

Death penalty supporters often use cases like this to argue that "the system worked," but critics view this as sophistry, as the only reason the system worked in this case was due to an outside commission's investigation into the case. The legal system, they argue, obscured the truth at every level and every step along the way.

Justice Scalia has stated that the Constitution does not forbid the execution of a convicted defendant who has had a full and fair trial but is later able to convince a habeas court that he is "actually" innocent. This stance has been criticized as callous, as it suggests a disregard for the horrifying injustice of executing an innocent person.

Critics question how a person who claims he could not be a judge if he thought his participation in the death penalty was immoral could also believe it is constitutionally acceptable for the state to execute innocent people. The exoneration of McCollum and Brown has sparked debate about the morality and effectiveness of the death penalty in the United States.

Title: Younger Generations' Shifting Political Preferences and Economic Perceptions

Article:

A new survey by YouGov and the Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation reveals a significant shift in the political preferences of younger generations, with a growing inclination towards socialism. The poll, which surveyed 2,100 individuals aged 16 and over, found that 70 percent of Millennials (born between 1981 and 1996) and 64 percent of Generation Z (born from 1997 onwards) are somewhat or extremely likely to vote for a socialist candidate.

The survey also indicates a dwindling support for capitalism, with 50 percent of Millennials and 51 percent of Generation Z holding a somewhat or very unfavorable view of capitalism. This shift in political leanings coincides with a perceived lack of understanding of economic philosophies and recent history among younger Americans.

According to Pew Research, Millennials are better educated than earlier generations, with a higher percentage holding college and postgraduate degrees. However, their economic education appears to be lacking, as evidenced by their understanding of socialism. The Concise Encyclopedia of Economics defines socialism as a centrally planned economy in which the government controls all means of production.

Matt Kibbe, of the libertarian organization Free the People, suggests that the appeal of socialism to young people lies in their values and personal experiences rather than empirical facts. Kibbe states that socialism, as described by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, is associated with community, cooperation, and dignity, but these values are not historically part of socialist reality.

Despite their apparent affinity for socialism, younger Americans also embrace entrepreneurship and small business, hallmarks of capitalism. However, they do not connect these activities with capitalism and a free market.

The survey also reveals a lack of historical knowledge among younger Americans. For instance, almost 20 percent of Millennials thought the Communist Manifesto "better guarantees freedom and equality for all" than the Declaration of Independence, compared to just two percent of Baby Boomers and five percent of Gen X. Additionally, a YouGov survey last year found that 87 percent of high school students flunked a five-question test of basic knowledge about American history, with the worst performance among this age group.

The survey also revealed a lack of knowledge about historical events such as World War II and the Holocaust, with two-thirds of American Millennials unable to identify the Nazi extermination camp of Auschwitz, and 22 percent unaware of or unsure about the Holocaust.

The oldest of the Millennials were small children when the Berlin Wall was dismantled, and they never experienced the threat of the Cuban Missile Crisis or nuclear war drills. They have not lived through the socialist regimes of the Soviet Union, Red China, or Venezuela, which are often associated with socialism in history.

Representative Ocasio-Cortez has stated that her generation has never known true prosperity. However, according to Matt Kibbe, the misery that AOC attributes to capitalism is not a reality. Kibbe argues that, by any conceivable measure, the current times are the most prosperous, opportunistic, and beautiful in the history of the universe.

Title: Former Homeland Security Secretary Criticizes White House's Dismissal of July 4 Terror Warning

Article:

Former Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge has criticized the White House for dismissing the government's July 4 weekend terror warning as "standard operating procedure." In an interview on Fox News Channel's "Your World with Neil Cavuto" on Monday, Ridge stated that the comment made by White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest was inaccurate.

"It's a real threat. I think this is a scourge with which we're going to have to deal with... for the foreseeable future," Ridge said. He further emphasized that the threat is "permanent" and not just a temporary concern.

Former CIA Deputy Director Mike Morell also urged Americans to take the threat seriously. On the same day, Morell stated, "I wouldn't be surprised if we're sitting here a week from today talking about an attack over the weekend in the United States. That's how serious this is."

The July 4 warning was issued by the FBI, Homeland Security, and the National Counterterrorism Center. According to Ridge, unless the United States takes a more aggressive stance against the Islamic State (also known as ISIS or ISIL), the warning may become a standard warning, indicating a constant risk to the country.

The warning comes amid a "confluence of events," as described by House Homeland Security Chairman Mike McCaul on Sunday. This includes the holiday honoring America's founding, ISIS celebrating its one-year anniversary of major territorial wins this week, and increased Internet traffic with ISIS calling for the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, currently underway, to be changed from a month of peace to a month of calamities.

ISIS claimed responsibility for three terror attacks on Friday across three continents, which Ridge suggested were likely coordinated. He stated, "This is a global scourge, and, frankly, until the White House, until this president, western allies, and countries in that region, with the exception of Iran, get serious about destroying ISIL, we're going to be living with this threat on a fairly regular basis."

Title: Federal Workers, Contractors File for Unemployment as Shutdown Continues

Article:

Federal workers and contractors are filing for unemployment benefits as the partial government shutdown, now the longest in U.S. history, enters its fourth week. Long-time federal contractor John Woodson was among those who applied for unemployment at an office in Washington, D.C. on Thursday.

"We should still be at work right now," said Woodson. "Politicians should handle this—don't put this on the citizens. You're hurting us."

Even if Woodson can get unemployment, which pays up to $425 a week in D.C., he says it won't be enough to care for his family. "I might have to wash some cars, go back detailing or wash some windows—whatever it takes to put some food on the table," said Woodson.

Federal workers and contractors are missing paychecks for the first time since the shutdown began on December 22. Officials in D.C. and Maryland say at least 7,000 unemployment claims have been filed by these workers since the shutdown began. They expect that number to rise sharply if the shutdown continues. In all, some 800,000 employees have been affected by the shutdown. An estimated 420,000 are working without pay, according to the Senate Appropriations Committee, while another 380,000 are at home on furlough.

At a rally for federal workers and their supporters in Silver Spring, Md., on Wednesday, some federal workers said they had no choice but to consider applying for unemployment benefits. "This is the first time in my working life I am going to have to go to my creditors and say 'I don't know how to pay you.' And it's embarrassing," said Michelle, a long-time federal employee who did not want to give her full name because she's worried about potential repercussions.

Michelle wiped away tears as she talked with a group of women about how to apply for unemployment. She never expected to be in this position. "I show up to work. I do a good job. I'm doing everything a responsible adult is supposed to do," said Michelle. "All of a sudden, it's all blown up and I don't know what else to do."

According to the federal government, the shutdown will cost at least $50 million a day in lost wages and productivity. However, there are hidden costs, too, that go beyond money, said Randy Erwin, president of the National Federation of Federal Employees. "Who in [the] world is going to want to work for the federal government when [workers] are disrespected...when people are not able to fill prescriptions, bouncing checks [and] ruining their credit?" said Erwin, whose union represents 100,000 federal workers.

The details surrounding who is—and isn't—eligible for unemployment can get complicated. Federal employees who've been furloughed can apply for unemployment benefits; workers who've been deemed "essential" and are working without pay are not eligible for unemployment. Federal employees who do receive unemployment benefits will have to reimburse the government if Congress votes to give employees backpay—which typically happens when the government re-opens.

The U.S. Office of Personnel Management has issued guidance for furloughed workers on what to do during a shutdown—including how to write to creditors and mortgage companies. On Friday, President Trump said he would sign a bill passed by both the House and the Senate to give back pay to federal workers affected by the shutdown.

Title: American Contractor Alan Gross Returns to U.S. After Five-Year Imprisonment in Cuba

Article:

In a significant humanitarian prisoner exchange, American contractor Alan Gross has returned to the United States after spending five years in a Cuban prison. The announcement was made today by President Obama at the White House, following over a year of secret high-level talks between the two governments.

The release of Gross, aged 65, who is reported to be in poor physical condition, marks a first step toward normalizing relations with the neighboring island nation just 90 miles off the Florida coast. The U.S. and Cuba are now set to begin talks to restore diplomatic relations, as announced by the White House.

"What we are doing is beginning the normalization of relations between the U.S. and Cuba," a senior administration official stated. In the coming months, the U.S. plans to re-establish an embassy in Havana, according to President Obama.

"Today, the United States is taking historic steps to chart a new course in our relations with Cuba and to further engage and empower the Cuban people," Obama said. "We are separated by 90 miles of water, but brought together through the relationships between the two million Cubans and Americans of Cuban descent that live in the United States, and the 11 million Cubans who share similar hopes for a more positive future for Cuba."

The announcement follows a phone conversation between Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro on Tuesday. Their discussion was described as a "summing up" of the work done over the past year leading up to these changes. The two leaders discussed issues of importance in the hemisphere, while also acknowledging that they will have differences to address. According to a senior administration official, Obama made clear his intent to maintain U.S. advocacy for human rights in Cuba.

Gross was convicted of espionage by a Cuban court in 2011 and sentenced to 15 years for bringing telecommunication devices into Cuba while working as a subcontractor for the United States Agency for International Development. The Cuban government accused him of being party to a U.S.-led plot to overthrow the government through an "Arab spring."

Following a recent visit, Gross' attorney described him as nearly toothless, barely able to walk due to arthritis in his hips, and blind in one eye. He has been kept in a small room at a military hospital 24 hours a day with two other Cuban political prisoners. Gross has refused medical and dental care or outside privileges, and declined visits and food from the U.S. Interest section in Havana. He had promised a hunger strike leading to death if not released by the end of this year.

In a statement released earlier this month to mark the anniversary of Gross' time in jail, Gross' wife Judy said, "Enough is enough. My husband has paid a terrible price for serving his country and community."

In exchange for Gross, the United States has agreed to the humanitarian release of three Cuban agents convicted of espionage in a controversial trial that found them guilty of spying on anti-Castro groups in Miami, but not the U.S. government. All three were most recently held in North Carolina at a federal medical facility for the U.S. Bureau of Prisons.

This humanitarian release marks the beginning of a promised new relationship with Cuba. The White House is indicating the beginning of new talks on everything from travel restrictions to eventual lifting of the Cuban embargo, which has been in place since John F. Kennedy was president.

In an interview last week with Jorge Ramos for Fusion -- a sister network to ███ -- President Obama said, "We've been in conversations about how we can get Alan Gross home for quite some time."

"We continue to be concerned about him. We think that he shouldn't have been held in the first place," Obama told Ramos. "With respect to Cuba generally, I've made very clear that the policies that we have in making remittances easier for Cuban families, and making it easier for families to travel, have been helpful to people inside Cuba... But the Cuban government still needs to make significant changes."

Title: Prosecutor's Assessment Could Influence Kavanaugh Vote Outcome

Article:

The sex-crimes prosecutor, Rachel Mitchell, hired by Republicans to question Brett Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford during Thursday's hearing informed senators that the case would not hold up in a courtroom, according to sources speaking to Fox News. This guidance could be crucial as wavering lawmakers prepare to vote.

Mitchell presented her findings during an overnight meeting attended by all 51 Republican senators, two people briefed on the session reported. She reportedly told senators that she would not charge Kavanaugh and would not even seek a search warrant.

Mitchell's opinion could sway undecided senators ahead of a critical Senate Judiciary Committee vote scheduled for Friday afternoon. While Kavanaugh does not need majority approval from the committee to advance to the full Senate, a favorable recommendation could bolster his imperiled nomination, and vice-versa.

In a significant development, Republican Sen. Jeff Flake announced Friday morning that he will support Kavanaugh, stating, "I left the hearing yesterday with as much doubt as certainty." With Flake's announcement, 48 Republican senators have now pledged to vote for Kavanaugh at the scheduled full Senate vote on Tuesday. The remaining Republicans are Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Mike Enzi of Wyoming. Enzi is expected to vote in support of Kavanaugh, but has stated he will not announce his position until he votes.

However, Collins, Murkowski, Flake, and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin could potentially vote as a bloc. According to a source, Collins, Murkowski, and Flake huddled with Manchin on the sidelines Thursday evening to discuss the nomination before the GOP lawmakers were briefed by Mitchell. They reportedly spoke for approximately 30 minutes.

"It's a tough one. She offered good testimony, and so did he," Flake, who sits on the Judiciary Committee, said Thursday night before announcing his support. "If you're making an allegation, you want there to be some corroboration. Where is the burden? It's like impeachment. You don't know."

Republicans, including President Trump, have emphasized that none of the sexual misconduct allegations against Kavanaugh made in the last several days have first-hand corroboration.

However, Ford insisted during Thursday's testimony that Kavanaugh and a friend trapped her in a room during a high school gathering in 1982, and the now-court nominee allegedly tried to force himself on her before she escaped. She stated she is "100 percent" sure it was him, though Kavanaugh adamantly denied it.

When asked whether more time or investigation would help, as Democrats suggested repeatedly on Thursday, Flake rejected the idea.

"Where does this start, where does it end?" he asked. "More time, more ludicrous allegations. What does that do to the accused?"

Manchin, from deep-red West Virginia, is seen as a possible "yea" vote for Kavanaugh.

"There have been no decisions," Manchin reportedly said outside the hearing room. "There are some concerns that people have, and we're going to try to close that loop."

Democratic Sens. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota and Joe Donnelly of Indiana have not revealed which way they might vote.

Early Friday, Sen. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., said that he would vote "no."

Republicans hold a narrow 51-49 majority in the Senate, and can only afford one defection in their bid to confirm Kavanaugh, assuming they secure no Democratic votes. Other Republican senators whose votes were expected to be up in the air, like Sens. Bob Corker, came out in support of Kavanaugh late Thursday.

"While both individuals provided a compelling testimony, nothing that has been presented corroborates the allegation," Corker said in a statement, referring to Kavanaugh and Ford.

Kavanaugh vehemently denied the allegations leveled against him by Ford, calling the process a "national disgrace" and a "circus."

"The Constitution gives the Senate an important role in the confirmation process," Kavanaugh said in his opening statement. "But you have replaced advise and consent with search and destroy."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., announced late Thursday a full Senate vote for Tuesday.

"I think we're going to go ahead," Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said. "I worry about every one of these votes."

Title: Facebook's Privacy Agreement with Regulators: A Look at the Company's Data Sharing Practices

Article:

Facebook's agreement with regulators in 2011 was a response to the social media platform's early experiments with data sharing. In late 2009, Facebook altered the privacy settings of its 400 million users, making some of their information accessible to all internet users. This information, including users' locations and religious and political leanings, was then shared with Microsoft and other partners.

This practice, known as "instant personalization," was promoted by Facebook as a step towards a better internet, where companies could use the information to customize content on sites like Bing. However, the feature drew criticism from privacy advocates and Facebook users, who felt that their information was shared without their permission.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) investigated these practices in 2011, citing the privacy changes as a deceptive practice. Caught off guard, Facebook officials ceased mentioning instant personalization in public and entered into a consent agreement with the FTC.

Under the decree, Facebook introduced a "comprehensive privacy program" to review new products and features. Initially overseen by two chief privacy officers, this program was intended to demonstrate Facebook's commitment to privacy. The company also hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to assess its privacy practices every two years.

However, according to four former Facebook employees with direct knowledge of the company's efforts, the privacy program faced internal resistance from the start. Some engineers and executives considered the privacy reviews an impediment to quick innovation and growth. The core team responsible for coordinating the reviews, numbering about a dozen people by 2016, was moved around within Facebook's organization, sending mixed signals about the company's commitment to privacy.

Critically, many of Facebook's special sharing partnerships were not subject to extensive privacy program reviews, according to two of the former employees. Executives believed that because the partnerships were governed by business contracts requiring them to follow Facebook's data policies, they did not require the same level of scrutiny. The privacy team had limited ability to review or suggest changes to some of these data-sharing agreements, which had been negotiated by more senior officials at the company.

Facebook officials stated that members of the privacy team had been consulted on the sharing agreements, but that the level of review "depended on the specific partnership and the time it was created."

Title: Senate Confirms Gina Haspel as First Female CIA Director Despite Controversial Past

Article:

The United States Senate has approved Gina Haspel as the first female director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), despite her role in the agency's post-9/11 interrogation program. The confirmation came in a 54-45 vote following a partisan debate among senators regarding the CIA's use of enhanced interrogation techniques during the Bush era.
