Gina Haspel, a CIA veteran, once oversaw a covert detention site in Thailand following the September 11, 2001 attacks. Her confirmation as the CIA's director follows the departure of former CIA chief Mike Pompeo, who left to become the U.S. Secretary of State.

Senator John McCain, a Republican who was tortured during his more than five years in a Vietnamese prison, announced his opposition to President Donald Trump's nominee. However, six Democrats crossed party lines to vote in her favor.

Virginia Senator Mark Warner, one of the Democrats who voted for Haspel, said she had told him the agency should never have resorted to enhanced interrogation techniques. Warner also stated that Haspel had pledged never to use such methods if the president demanded it.

``I believe she is someone who can and will stand up to the president, who will speak truth to power if this president orders her to do something illegal or immoral, like a return to torture,'' Warner said in a speech before the vote.

Two Republicans, Jeff Flake and Rand Paul, voted against Haspel, meaning she would not have been confirmed without support from Democrats.

Republican chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee Richard Burr spoke before the vote, stating the confirmation of a woman as CIA head would send an important message.

``Many others who have served, or are currently serving, have cracked the glass ceiling at the agency. Gina is poised to break it,'' Burr said.

``It may be impossible to measure the importance of that breakthrough, but I do know that it will send a signal to the current workforce and to the workforce of the future that a lifetime of commitment to the agency can and will be rewarded,'' Burr added.

A 33-year veteran of the agency, Haspel, 61, spent most of her career as an undercover operative. In 2002, she was selected by the agency to run a covert detention site in Thailand where harsh interrogation techniques were used that a Senate report deemed to be torture.

One suspect that was brought there, Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, was subjected to methods that were later banned by President Barack Obama. Al-Nashiri, who was interrogated after Haspel took over the post, was also subjected to sleep deprivation, nudity, extreme temperatures, being held in a small box, and "walling" (being slammed repeatedly into a wall).

Three years later, Haspel ordered the destruction of 92 video tapes that documented the interrogation of al-Nashiri and Abu Zubaydah, who was also held at the Thai location. At least 119 men were tortured by the US in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon, according to a 2014 Senate report.

Human rights groups say Haspel left Thailand to oversee further US torture, but it is unclear what role she played as her exact record has been classified by the CIA. Trump has previously called for the US to resume waterboarding terrorism suspects.

Title: U.S. Senate Reviews U.S.-Saudi Relations Amid Yemen Crisis; Iran's Role in Yemen Conflict Highlighted

Article:

The United States Senate is currently reviewing U.S. relations with Saudi Arabia, including the U.S. involvement in the Saudi-led coalition in the Yemen conflict. The humanitarian crisis in Yemen, caused by the ongoing conflict between the Saudi-supported government and the Iran-backed Houthi rebels, has claimed over 57,000 lives, driven half of Yemen's 28 million people to the brink of famine, and displaced 2.3 million Yemenis from their homes.

The article highlights Iran's direct responsibility for the suffering, violence, and tragedy in Yemen. Iran is reportedly using arms transfers, training, and terrorist proxies to empower the Houthi rebels, terrorize Yemeni civilians, undermine the security of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, and challenge U.S. national security interests in the region.

Houthi rebels have used Iranian-supplied advanced arms in the Yemen conflict, indiscriminately launching over 100 ballistic missiles against Saudi cities, unleashing explosive unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) against Saudi civilian targets, and deploying explosive boats and anti-ship missiles against commercial ships in the Arabian Gulf.

Moreover, Iran-backed Houthi rebels have detained thousands of Yemenis and reportedly subjected many of them to "extreme torture," including being beaten with batons, hung from chains by their wrists or genitals for weeks at a time, and scorched with acid.

Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) and Iran-backed Lebanese Hezbollah terrorists have provided training and support that have greatly increased the lethality and combat effectiveness of Houthi rebels, and enhanced their ability to threaten Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, international shipping in the Gulf, and U.S. forces in the region.

While the article acknowledges the need for accountability for Saudi Arabia's role in the Khashoggi murder, it emphasizes the importance of addressing Iran's central role in perpetuating Yemen's conflict. The article argues that failure to do so risks prolonging the conflict and causing more war, oppression, and misery in the region.

The article also discusses the need for a political solution to end the conflict, but warns against any negotiation that would formalize an Iranian-Yemeni security relationship or provide a strong incentive for the Iranian regime to cause other conflicts in the region. The article also highlights the ongoing threat of extremist networks in Yemen, such as Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and ISIS-Yemen, and the need to maintain U.S. counterterrorism efforts in the region.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address: Focus on Economic Fairness and Middle-Class Economics

Article:

In his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama, with a Congress controlled by an opposing party, addressed the economic challenges facing the nation, emphasizing the disparity between the wealthy and the middle and working classes. He proposed a redistribution of wealth through tax increases on the wealthy and the use of other measures to raise wages and create jobs.

The President did not engage in a stark debate on economic inequality as some economists have, instead focusing on the virtues of "middle-class economics." He posed the question, "Will we accept an economy where only a few of us do spectacularly well, or will we commit ourselves to an economy that generates rising incomes and chances for everyone who makes the effort?"

President Obama's proposals, such as raising the capital gains tax to 28 percent, which was the rate during the Reagan era, and imposing ordinary income tax rates on dividends, are not radical. He also aims to end a provision in the tax code that shields hundreds of billions of dollars in appreciated wealth passed on to heirs. These changes, along with a new fee on big banks, would finance tax breaks for middle-income families, including credits for two-earner couples, increased child care and college tuition credits, as well as other programs, including two years of tuition-free community college for some students.

The proposal is designed to be revenue-neutral, with the tax increases paying for the new programs to avoid the ongoing debates over deficits that have exhausted both political parties and the American public.

While the rhetoric in the address was combative and defiant at times, the President's proposal is not a new concept, as it aims to address the plight of the middle class and the larger issue of economic inequality. By raising these issues, President Obama has inserted economic fairness into the political debate, making it difficult for future Democratic candidates, such as Hillary Rodham Clinton, to ignore these concerns. Even Republican candidates, who may be reluctant to raise taxes on top-tier earners, may find the idea of helping the middle class attractive.

Title: Email Alerts Detail Unfolding Events of U.S. Consulate Attack in Benghazi

Article:

On Tuesday, six weeks ago, the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, was attacked, resulting in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador Christopher Stevens. Newly obtained email alerts reveal the earliest description of the events that transpired during the attack.

At 4:05 p.m. Eastern time on September 11, an alert from the State Department Operations Center was issued to various government and intelligence agencies, including the White House Situation Room, the office of the Director of National Intelligence, and the FBI. The alert read, "US Diplomatic Mission in Benghazi Under Attack." It described approximately 20 armed individuals firing shots and explosions being heard. The ambassador, who was currently in Benghazi, and four COM (Chief of Mission/embassy) personnel were reported to be in the compound's safe haven.

At 4:54 p.m., less than an hour later, another alert was issued: "the firing... in Benghazi... has stopped... A response team is on site attempting to locate COM (embassy) personnel."

Then, at 6:07 p.m., State sent out another alert stating that the embassy in Tripoli reported the Islamic military group "Ansar al-Sharia Claims Responsibility for Benghazi Attack" on Facebook and Twitter and had called for an attack on Embassy Tripoli.

The emails are part of what are likely a large number of communications exchanged throughout the night. They are expected to become part of the ongoing political debate over whether the administration attempted to mislead by stating the assault was an outgrowth of a protest rather than a planned attack by terrorists.

Fourteen hours after the attack, President Obama sat down with Steve Kroft of "60 Minutes" for a previously scheduled interview and said he did not believe it was simply due to mob violence. "You're right that this is not a situation that was -- exactly the same as what happened in Egypt and my suspicion is that there are folks involved in this who were looking to target Americans from the start," Mr. Obama said.

The White House and State Department declined comment on the email alerts. The House Oversight Committee told the source that the information in the emails will be part of their ongoing investigation into the Benghazi attack.

Title: Obama Promises Bipartisan Approach, Vows to Work with Compromising Republicans

Article:

In a political fundraiser on Wednesday, former President Barack Obama pledged to advocate for Democratic ideals while maintaining a bipartisan tone. He emphasized the need for a politics that aligns with the American people's decency, hard work, and creativity.

Speaking at the Chicago Hilton, Obama acknowledged the current political climate's challenges, stating, "We've got a politics that's stuck right now." He vowed to collaborate with Republicans who view compromise as a positive aspect, aiming to create a government suitable for the next generation of Americans.

The event, hosted by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC), was the first of two fundraisers Obama attended during his one-night visit to his hometown. Attendees, who paid between $1,000 and $5,000, listened to Obama discuss gun control, education, U.S. infrastructure, and climate change.

Obama emphasized the potential for energy independence, stating, "We will over the next couple of decades have the capacity to be energy independent for the first time - incredible change." He also highlighted the need to address climate change, stating, "The climate is changing in ways that we can't fully predict, but we know are not going to be good for our kids."

In addition to donors, the audience included members of the Illinois congressional delegation, Democratic power players such as House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, DCCC Chairman Rep. Steve Israel, and Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who served as White House chief of staff during Obama's first two years as president.

Following the Hilton event, Obama visited the home of longtime supporters and Democratic activists Paul and Bettylu Saltzman. Obama expressed gratitude for their support, stating they played a crucial role in his presidential campaign. A crowd of approximately 70 people paid either $10,000 per person or $32,400 per couple for dinner with the president.

The pair of fundraisers marks the third time Obama has headlined events for the DCCC; he is scheduled for three more this year.

Title: Democrats Prepare to Advance Progressive Agenda in New Congress

Article:

With the Democrats set to take control of the House of Representatives in January, a wave of big-government bills is expected to be introduced and potentially voted on. These measures, which have been stalled under Republican leadership for years, include proposals like "Medicare for all" and various generous welfare programs.

Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman (D-N.J.) told Fox News that many of these measures, such as the "Medicare for all" and similar proposals, could see a floor vote under Democratic leadership. However, with the Republican Party's expanded majority in the Senate, it is unlikely these measures would make it to President Trump's desk.

The consideration of these measures on the House side would mark a first step in formally considering major government expansions in areas like education and health care, which Democrats increasingly favor. "Medicare for all" and similar proposals, such as the "Green New Deal" platform being pushed by progressive lawmakers like Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, could reveal the extent of their support.

The "Green New Deal" platform also calls for a tuition-free and federally funded education system, guaranteed jobs with an emphasis on "green" jobs, and more. The support for this plan among Democratic lawmakers is unclear, but more than 40 Democratic lawmakers have expressed backing for the "Green New Deal" in some form.

In addition to these measures, individual bills sponsored by Democratic members during the last two years, which could now be voted on, include proposals for "college for all," "debt-free college," "child care for all," and a "jobs guarantee."

Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.), likely the incoming chairman of the Education and Workforce Committee, has also introduced a "Worker's Freedom to Negotiate Act" that bans state laws that allow employees to opt not to join a union and pay union dues. The Democratic campaign plan also calls for spending $ 40 billion on "universal high-speed Internet."

Rep. David Cicilline (D-R.I.) has been a leading advocate of the Child Care for Working Families Act, a concept promoted in the party's campaign plan. The legislation would ensure that no family under 150 percent of a state's median income pays more than 7 percent of their income for child care.

Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) said he anticipates his Job Opportunities for All Act—with 22 Democratic co-sponsors—will make it to the floor in the new Congress. The legislation, which Khanna has said fulfills part of President Franklin Roosevelt's proposed "economic bill of rights," would provide federal funding to put people to work immediately in both the public and the private sector.

Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) could play a prominent role in such legislative proposals. She is a co-chairwoman of the Medicare For All Caucus, which has nearly 80 members committed to a complete government-run health care system. Jayapal was also the sponsor of the College for All Act in 2017, which would eliminate tuition and fees at public colleges and universities for families earning up to $ 125,000, and make community college free for everyone. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) introduced the Senate version. Rep. Mark Pocan (D-Wis.), the other progressive caucus co-chairman, introduced a similar bill, the Debt-Free College Act, which would provide more federal funding to states to alleviate student loan debt.

Fred Lucas is the White House correspondent for the Daily Signal.

Title: White House Faces Challenges as Democratic Unity Cracks over Obamacare Website Issues

Article:

The Democratic Party's unity, which held strong during the government shutdown in October 2013, has reportedly begun to fracture due to issues with the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) website.

For weeks leading up to the shutdown, President Barack Obama managed to keep every Democrat in the House and Senate united. However, the problems with the Obamacare website have transformed the president from a man with political capital to one who appears to be on the defensive.

The website's botched rollout has led to growing impatience and dismay among Democrats, with some questioning the administration's strategy and others pushing for changes to the current position that the problems can be fixed without altering the deadlines or time frame.

Senator Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) has been vocal in his criticism, suggesting a delay in the individual mandate penalty for a year. Manchin, who has always been suspicious of the individual mandate, has not received a response from the White House regarding his proposal.

Despite these challenges, White House officials maintain that most people outside of Washington view Obamacare as a non-political issue and want to see it preserved, if repaired. They argue that any political fallout will be addressed as they overhaul the site.

However, the situation remains fluid, with the extent of the Democratic Party's internal divisions unclear. The White House is reportedly dealing with a bizarre episode involving Senator Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) and Speaker John Boehner's denial of an unnamed Republican's alleged insult towards the president.

Privately, some Republicans express concern with the party's focus on the website, suggesting that attention should be directed towards other potentially problematic aspects of the law. Polls show support for Republicans remains low, while support for Obamacare is still ticking up.

The situation underscores the challenges the Obama administration faces in implementing the Affordable Care Act and maintaining Democratic unity on the issue.

Title: New York Attorney General Files Lawsuit Against Trump Foundation, Alleges Extensive Lawbreaking

Article:

New York Attorney General Barbara Underwood has filed a lawsuit against the Trump Foundation, President Donald Trump, and his three eldest children, Donald Jr., Eric, and Ivanka, alleging extensive and persistent lawbreaking. The lawsuit seeks to dissolve the foundation and $2.8 million in restitution.

In a statement, Ms. Underwood accused the foundation and its directors, including Mr. Trump, of unlawful political coordination, repeated self-dealing transactions, and violating laws under which non-profit organizations must operate.

The lawsuit alleges that the foundation and its directors illegally coordinated with the Trump presidential campaign, using the foundation's name and funds raised to promote the campaign. The petition also claims that Mr. Trump used charitable assets to pay off legal obligations, to promote his own businesses, and to purchase personal items, including a painting of himself.

The Trump Foundation issued a statement denying the charges and accusing the attorney general of holding its $1.7 million in remaining funds "hostage for political gain."

The lawsuit is the culmination of a two-year investigation that began under the previous New York attorney general, Eric Schneiderman. Mr. Schneiderman resigned last month after several former girlfriends accused him of physical abuse.

In October 2016, Mr. Schneiderman ordered the Trump Foundation to stop fundraising in New York, after finding it had no proper registration. President-elect Trump vowed to shut the charitable foundation down in December 2016, to avoid "even the appearance" of any conflict of interest.

The Trump Foundation lawsuit adds to Mr. Trump's legal challenges, which include a wide-ranging special counsel investigation into alleged ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. Special Counsel Robert Mueller has indicted several of Mr. Trump's associates and raided the home and office of the president's long-time lawyer and fixer, Michael Cohen.

Thursday's 41-page document filed with the NY Supreme Court spells out a range of alleged violations of laws concerning non-profit organizations, dating back more than a decade. The investigation apparently found that the foundation was "little more than an empty shell that functions with no oversight by its board of directors." The board had not met since 1999, despite being legally required to meet annually, and did not oversee the foundation's activities "in any way," the document says.

Mr. Trump, who has not contributed any personal funds to the foundation since 2008, was the sole signatory on the foundation's bank accounts and approved all of its grants. Several pages of the document focus on a charity fundraiser for veterans in Iowa in January 2016, which Mr. Trump chose to hold instead of taking part in a TV debate with other Republican presidential hopefuls ahead of the influential state's caucuses. More than $2.8 million was donated to the Trump Foundation at that event. The petition alleges that those funds raised from the public were used to promote Mr. Trump's campaign for the presidency, in particular in the Iowa nominating caucuses.

The lawsuit also claims that the foundation paid $100,000 to settle legal claims against Mr. Trump's Mar-A-Lago resort, $158,000 to settle claims against one of his golf clubs, and $10,000 to purchase a painting of Mr. Trump to hang at another of his golf clubs. The purchase of the painting was an example of one of "at least five self-dealing transactions" which violate tax regulations on non-profit charities, the statement said.

"As our investigation reveals, the Trump Foundation was little more than a checkbook for payments from Mr. Trump or his businesses to nonprofits, regardless of their purpose or legality," Ms. Underwood said.

Title: NSA Acknowledges Thousands of Privacy Violations in Annual Audit

Article:

The National Security Agency (NSA) faced criticism on Friday following the release of an internal audit showing the agency had violated privacy rules thousands of times annually since 2008. The Washington Post reported the details on Thursday, sparking a renewed debate in Washington over the NSA's impact on Americans' privacy.

Senator Patrick Leahy, D-Vermont, who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee, expressed concern about the NSA's actions and stated that his committee will hold a hearing on the matter. Leahy stated, "I remain concerned that we are still not getting straightforward answers from the NSA."

John DeLong, the NSA's director of compliance, admitted that "mistakes occur," but insisted that only a "tiny" amount of such issues were intentional. In a call with reporters, DeLong emphasized that "no one at NSA thinks a mistake is OK."

The May 2012 audit found 2,776 incidents of "unauthorized collection, storage, access to or distribution of legally protected communications" in the preceding 12 months, according to the Washington Post. Most of these incidents involved failures of due diligence or violations of standard operating procedure, with the most serious incidents including a violation of a court order and unauthorized use of data about more than 3,000 Americans and green-card holders.

Senate Intelligence Committee chairwoman Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-California, stated that her committee "can and should do more to independently verify that NSA's operations are appropriate, and its reports of compliance incidents are accurate." House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi also called for "rigorous oversight" by Congress on the "incidents of non-compliance."

The Washington Post reported that most incidents involved unauthorized surveillance of Americans or foreign intelligence targets in the country. In one case, a programming error led to the interception of a "large number" of calls placed from Washington due to a confusion between the capitol's 202 area code and the international dialing code for Egypt.

The NSA stated that factors such as the implementation of new procedures, technology or software changes, and expanded access can cause the number of incidents to trend up or down from one quarter to the next. The agency also emphasized its commitment to identifying and addressing incidents and driving the numbers down.

White House spokesman Josh Earnest offered a statement on Friday, saying the NSA compliance office's review reflects its commitment to abiding by the law and protecting people's privacy. The man who leaked the audit to the Post, Edward Snowden, has been charged with felony counts, including violations of the U.S. Espionage Act, for the leaks. Snowden currently resides in Russia after fleeing to Hong Kong following the leaks.

A CNN/ORC International survey released last month indicated that 52% of the public disapproved of Snowden's actions, while 44% said they approved of the leaks. Fifty-four percent of those questioned in the poll said the government should attempt to bring Snowden back to the United States and prosecute him for his leaks. As for the program Snowden revealed, there is a noticeable generational divide on the surveillance tactics, with younger Americans more likely to support Snowden than older Americans.

Title: GOP Rep. Lou Barletta Wins Pennsylvania Republican Senate Primary, Faces Off Against Democratic Incumbent Bob Casey Jr.

Article:

Republican Representative Lou Barletta has emerged victorious in the Pennsylvania Republican Senate primary, defeating state Representative Jim Christiana. The Associated Press declared the race for Barletta after 52 percent of precincts had reported their numbers, showing he had 59 percent of the votes.

Barletta, who was endorsed by President Donald Trump in a February tweet, will now face Democratic incumbent Bob Casey Jr. in the high-stakes race for U.S. Senate. In the tweet, Trump praised Barletta as "a Great Republican" and pointed out that he was one of his "very earliest supporters." Trump also criticized Casey, stating that he listens to "Tax Hikers Pelosi and Schumer."

In a tweet on Wednesday, Trump congratulated Barletta on his victory, saying, "Lou is a friend of mine and a special guy, he will very much help MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!"

Trump's endorsement of Barletta was evident in another tweet sent out on May 16, 2018, where he expressed his confidence in Barletta's ability to represent the people of Pennsylvania effectively.

Barletta will now be taking on Casey in the November general election for U.S. Senate. The outcome of this election will determine who will represent Pennsylvania in the U.S. Senate. Further information regarding the candidates' positions and policies is unavailable at this time.

Title: Media's Advice to Trump and the Ongoing Criticism of John Brennan

Article:

The relationship between the media and the Republican Party, particularly in the context of President Donald Trump, has been a subject of debate. The article suggests that the media often provides unsolicited and potentially harmful advice to the GOP, with the party's success often inversely proportional to its adherence to this advice.

In the case of Trump, the article argues that his success is not despite but because of his disregard for media counsel. The author suggests that Trump should continue to criticize Special Counsel Robert Mueller, detailing his conflicts of interest and exposing the partisan nature of the investigation.

The article also criticizes media reactions to the prospect of Trump firing Mueller, stating that such an action would not have significant consequences, and any temporary backlash from the media and the ruling class would be minimal.

The article further discusses a principle it claims the media would not extend to a Democrat, namely, that a duly elected president should not be allowed to run their own executive branch. The author suggests that Trump should challenge this principle, asserting that he was elected by the American people and should govern accordingly.

The article also mentions former CIA Director John Brennan's call for government officials to refuse orders to fire Mueller. The author characterizes Brennan's comments as treasonous and anti-American, comparing him to a Soviet plant and a supporter of the Muslim Brotherhood. The article concludes by stating that there is no difference between the John Brennan of the 1970s and the John Brennan of today, both of whom are calling for mutiny against a duly elected U.S. president.

The article also implies a criticism of the media for normalizing left-wing radicalism and casting such comments as evidence of high patriotism and statesmanlike sagacity. The author suggests that the media's hostility to the American people has not changed from its baby boomerish nihilism.

Title: Obama Warns of Red Line on Syrian Chemical Weapons Use

Article:

In August, former President Barack Obama stated that any evidence of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad moving chemical weapons in a threatening manner or using them would be a "red line" for the United States, potentially prompting direct American intervention.

However, American officials have not yet determined whether the recent activity in Syria approaches the red line set by Obama. A senior American diplomat, deeply involved in the effort to dissuade Assad's forces from using chemical weapons, suggested the activity could be a sign of desperation rather than a direct threat.

A senior Israeli official speculated that the movement of chemical weapons and the apparent preparations to use them could be a bluff, intended as a warning to the West during a time of debate over increased support to opposition groups.

The White House has remained silent on intelligence reports regarding the situation, but a senior administration official issued a warning to the Syrians. The official stated that the use of chemical weapons in Syria would cross a red line for the United States. The official also emphasized that the U.S. is monitoring developments related to Syria's chemical weapons stockpiles and is in regular contact with international partners who share the concern.

Representative Mike Rogers, a Michigan Republican who heads the House Intelligence Committee, declined to comment on the new intelligence reports but expressed concern about the potential collapse of the Assad regime and the dangerous vacuum it would create. Rogers also warned that the use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime would be a serious escalation demanding decisive action from the international community.

Several months ago, the United States military sent a task force of over 150 planners and specialists to Jordan to help the armed forces prepare for the possibility of Syria losing control of its chemical weapons. Turkey has requested two batteries of the Patriot antimissile system from NATO, in part as protection against Syrian missiles that might enter Turkish territory.

This is not the first time activity at stockpile sites has been detected. In September, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta stated that there had been "some movement" of Syria's chemical weapons stockpiles to more secure locations. However, the new activity appears to be of a different nature, and officials are no longer willing to confirm that all the sites remain secure.

Since the crisis in Syria began, the United States and its allies have increased electronic eavesdropping and other surveillance activities of the sites. A senior defense official stated that no U.S. troops had been put on heightened alert in response to the activity, although the Pentagon is prepared to do so if necessary.

Title: George Conway Discusses Trump Administration, Marriage, and Political Allegiance in Interview

Article:

In an interview with Yahoo News' podcast Skullduggery on Friday, George Conway, husband to Kellyanne Conway, one of President Trump's closest advisers, discussed his views on the Trump administration, his wife's role in the White House, and their differing political views.

Conway, who has been a vocal critic of the Trump administration, spoke about being considered for a position at the Justice Department as the chief of the civil division, a role that would have involved him in defending the administration in lawsuits.

Regarding his wife's feelings about his public criticisms of the administration, Conway stated, "I don’t think she likes it." However, he added, "I’ve told her, I don’t like the administration, so it’s even."

Conway compared their political disagreements to those common in Washington, D.C., stating, "If I had a nickel for everybody in Washington who disagrees with their spouse on something that happens in this town, I wouldn’t be on this podcast. I’d be probably on a beach somewhere."

Conway withdrew his candidacy for the Justice Department role, stating, "The administration is like a shit show in a dumpster fire." He cited events such as the firing of James Comey, Trump's comments about Russia, and the appointment of Robert Mueller as special counsel as reasons for his decision.

Despite their differences, Conway praised his wife's work, stating, "She basically got this guy elected. She steadied that boat." He also expressed pride in his wife's role in helping Trump become president during the campaign.

However, Conway criticized the current state of the Republican party under Trump, describing it as a "personality cult." He went on to say that he had switched parties and no longer felt comfortable being a Republican. He also expressed a preference for moving to Australia rather than voting for Trump again.

Title: Israel Warns of Iran's Nuclear Program and Links to Holocaust, as Tensions Rise over Peace Talks and Apartheid Allegations

Article:

Tensions between Israel and the international community, particularly the United States, have escalated in recent days as peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians have stalled and concerns over Iran's nuclear program have resurfaced. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu issued a stern warning during the country's annual memorial day for the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust, linking the Nazi genocide to Iran's suspected nuclear ambitions and its leaders' denial of the Holocaust.

At the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial, Netanyahu questioned why world leaders in the years before the Holocaust failed to recognize the danger ahead of time. He stated, "In hindsight, all the signs were there." The Obama administration's approach to preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons has been criticized, with some claiming it has been placed on the back burner.

Meanwhile, Secretary of State John Kerry's comments about Israel during peace talks have caused controversy. In a closed-door meeting with influential world leaders, Kerry suggested that if a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is not reached soon, Israel risks becoming "an apartheid state." This comparison has sparked outrage among Jewish leaders in America and could attract unwanted attention in Israel.

The use of the term "apartheid" by a senior American official is rare, and President Obama has previously rejected the idea that the term should apply to Israel. The Obama administration's approach to foreign policy, particularly in the Middle East, has been criticized by some as isolating allies and promoting enemies. The potential withdrawal of sanctions by Russia on Iran further complicates the situation.

Title: U.S. Rep. Michael Grimm Faces Criminal Charges from Federal Prosecutors

Article:

New York (AP) - The attorney representing Republican U.S. Rep. Michael Grimm has stated that the congressman has not committed any wrongdoing but expressed no surprise about the criminal charges he is facing from federal prosecutors. Grimm has been under investigation for possible campaign finance violations since his first campaign for Congress in 2009 and 2010.

In a statement on Friday, Grimm's attorney, William McGinley, said, "After more than two years of investigation plagued by malicious leaks, violations of grand jury secrecy, and strong-arm tactics, the U.S. Attorney's Office has disclosed its intent to file criminal charges against Congressman Grimm. When the dust settles, he will be vindicated."

A spokesman for the U.S. Attorney's Office in Brooklyn declined to comment or confirm or deny the case. The FBI's New York office, which handles investigations, also declined to comment.

In November, the House Ethics Committee announced that Grimm was under investigation for possible campaign finance violations. After the announcement, the panel said it would defer its inquiry because of a separate Department of Justice investigation.

Grimm made headlines in January after confronting a New York City cable news station reporter who tried to question him about a long-running FBI investigation into campaign finance on a balcony in the Capitol. Grimm was indicted in Brooklyn on Friday on charges related to the use of straw donors to make illegal campaign contributions.

During Grimm's first campaign, he acknowledged receiving $250,000 to $300,000 in contributions from followers of an Israeli rabbi, Yoshiyahu Yosef Pinto. Some members of Pinto's congregation subsequently said they made tens of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions, including gifts passed through straw donors.

Grimm has denied knowledge of any improprieties, and the FBI hasn't accused him of any wrongdoing. The Israeli businessman who had served as Grimm's liaison to Pinto's followers, Ofer Biton, pleaded guilty in August to an immigration fraud charge.

Three days after Biton's guilty plea, the FBI filed a sealed criminal complaint accusing a Houston woman named Diana Durand, who had been romantically involved with Grimm, of using straw donors to make illegal campaign contributions.

Attorney Stuart Kaplan said Durand would plead not guilty to the charges. Kaplan, who said Durand and Grimm met in Texas before Grimm ran for Congress, said he was hopeful prosecutors wouldn't join the two cases.

"When you take out their relationship, there's no evidence to connect either one with respect to complicity, violating the law by acting in concert or doing something as a criminal enterprise," he said.

A spokesman in Grimm's Washington office did not immediately return emails or a telephone message seeking comment.

A House member who has been indicted does not lose any rights or privileges under federal law or the chamber's rules, according to a report by the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service.

Rules used by the two major political parties require indicted committee or subcommittee chairmen, or members of a party's leadership, to temporarily step aside. Grimm is not a chairman or a member of the leadership.

Title: Sanders Leads in Ad Spending, Trump Excels in Efficiency

Article:

The 2016 U.S. general election is shaping up to be the most expensive in history, with a significant increase in the number of television ads aired compared to the 2012 election. According to a report from the Wesleyan Media Project, 480,000 ads have aired thus far in the 2016 election cycle, a 112% increase over the same period in 2012.

In the Democratic race, Bernie Sanders has spent the most on television ads, totaling nearly 125,000 ads as of May 8. Sanders, who has relied heavily on small donors, has spent approximately $18.5 million, compared to Hillary Clinton's $16.9 million on 105,000 ads. However, Clinton has earned more votes, and when spending per vote is considered, Clinton has spent about $5 per vote, while Sanders has spent about $8 per vote.

On the Republican side, the spending per vote disparities are more pronounced. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, who dropped out before any contests took place, spent approximately $17,000 per vote, according to election tracking site The Green Papers. Jindal's campaign dwarfs all other candidates listed by Wesleyan, but his astronomical figure is skewed due to potentially uncounted write-in votes.

Excluding Jindal's spending, the Republican candidates spent significantly less per vote. Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, Lindsey Graham, and John Kasich, who amassed millions but had few votes to show for it, spent between $2 and $4 per vote. The majority of their ads were bought through money from outside groups like superPACs, with over 90% of the money for Bush, Christie, and Jindal's ads coming from outside groups, along with nearly 60% for Graham.

Donald Trump, who has spent about $2 on TV ads per vote, stands out as the most efficient candidate in terms of ad spending. Trump's name recognition and ability to generate free media coverage may have contributed to the effectiveness of his ads, as he had received an estimated $2 billion in free media coverage as of March.

In conclusion, the 2016 U.S. general election is on track to be the most expensive in history, with significant differences in ad spending and spending per vote between the candidates. Bernie Sanders has spent the most on television ads, but Donald Trump has excelled in ad efficiency, spending less per vote than any of his competitors.

Title: Pentagon Clarifies Number of Troops Treated for Brain Injuries Following Iraq Operation

Article:

The Pentagon has provided an update on the number of troops who have been diagnosed with brain injuries following a recent operation in Iraq. According to the military, 11 troops were initially pulled out for treatment, but subsequent follow-on screenings have revealed that the actual number is 34.

As of Friday, 17 of the 34 troops have returned to duty, including one service member who was transferred to Kuwait for further treatment. Eight service members have been transferred to the United States for treatment after initially being sent to Germany. Nine are still undergoing treatment and evaluation in Germany.

Mark T. Esper, the Secretary of Defense, attributed the change in numbers to symptoms that "are late-developing and manifest over a period of time." He explained that while some troops initially screened for concussion-like symptoms showed improvement, others did not, with some conditions worsening and requiring further treatment.

President Donald Trump had previously played down the initial reports of injuries, stating on Wednesday that the injuries were not "very serious." However, Esper defended the Pentagon's reporting of injuries around the globe, stating that they are committed to being transparent and accurate in their reporting, and that they categorize things properly. Esper also noted that this is not limited to Iraq, but applies to troops engaged worldwide.

Title: Facebook's Trending Topics Allegations: A Call for Informed Consumer Choice

Article:

Facebook's Trending Topics, a feature that provides users with a headline feed of the top stories generating discussion on the social network, has been under scrutiny following a Gizmodo investigation. The investigation alleges that the Trending Topics index is less "organic" than advertised, with conservative news and opinion sites being excluded from the feed.

According to Gizmodo's sources, topics related to conservative events, personalities, and news sites were suppressed. Excluded sites included The Drudge Report, Breitbart News, The Washington Examiner, and RedState, a site owned by Townhall Media Group, which also owns Hot Air, where the author is employed as senior editor.

The suppressed topics ranged from major annual conservative events like the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) to discussions about conservative politicians such as Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker (R). Some curators reportedly received instructions to "inject" topics into the index to artificially produce discussion, with some injected topics appearing to be agenda promotion, such as the Black Lives Matter movement.

Facebook, of course, denies these allegations. Tom Stocky, the Facebook executive in charge of trending topics, stated, "We take these reports extremely seriously, and have found no evidence that the anonymous allegations are true." Facebook's explanation of the trending index states that the topics displayed are based on factors including engagement, timeliness, Pages liked, and location.

In the wake of these allegations, discussion among conservatives on social media has turned to questions of whether conservative sites should abandon Facebook. The author argues that this would be a mistake, as Facebook is a significant platform with nearly three in five American adults having a Facebook account. Failing to be part of Facebook would make conservatism more insular than it already is.

However, the author also emphasizes the need for conservatives (and all Facebook users) to treat Facebook more skeptically than they once did. With the increasing access and choice in news sources, consumers should exercise their own choices and call out those biases when they become obvious. Informed consumer choice is not just an antidote to editorial bias, but a freedom worth embracing on any and all social networks.

Title: White House Clarifies IRS Investigation Involvement, Consults with Treasury Department

Article:

The White House has revised its explanation of its knowledge regarding the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) investigation into the scrutiny of conservative political groups. On Tuesday, press secretary Jay Carney revealed that the White House had consulted with the Treasury Department on the timing and content of the public release of the IRS audit findings.

According to Carney, these discussions, led by Deputy Chief of Staff Mark Childress, focused on the timing of the release of the information and the findings of the actual audit. The conversations reportedly included discussions about a potential speech by Lois Lerner, who oversaw the IRS's work on tax-exempt groups, and the acting commissioner's potential testimony and statements regarding the issue.

Besides Chief of Staff Denis McDonough, Deputy Chief of Staff Mark Childress, and White House Counsel Kathy Ruemmler, Carney has only named one other senior White House staffer who was aware of the IRS probe: White House Counsel Kathy Ruemmler. Carney stated that Ruemmler made the decision not to inform the president of the forthcoming inspector general report on the issue.

Carney's revelation of additional information about which officials were aware of the situation and when they were informed was in response to specific questions. However, when pressed for more details about who else knew of the report's existence before the first news stories about it emerged on May 10, and how they were informed, Carney provided limited information.

The briefing grew testy when Carney was asked whether he was among the senior staff who were told of the IRS investigation before news reports emerged. He confirmed that he was not, like the president, who also learned about it from news reports.

As on Monday, Carney again defended the White House's position of not looping in the president about the inspector general's report of the IRS before the news became public.

CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story incorrectly stated that the White House had consulted with the IRS on how to make the findings public, instead of with the Treasury Department.

Title: Medicaid Doctors Face 42% Pay Cut as Obamacare Payment Boost Expires

Article:

The Affordable Care Act temporarily increased payment rates for primary care doctors who see Medicaid patients in 2013 and 2014. The aim was to ensure doctors continued participating in Medicaid, which typically has low reimbursement rates, as the program expanded to cover millions more Americans in 2015.

The earlier Obamacare pay raise averaged out to a 73% increase for primary care doctors across the country. However, it was temporary, lasting only two years, and is set to end on December 31, 2014. As a result, beginning January 1, 2015, Medicaid doctors will earn less each time they see a patient, or they could decide to withdraw from the program altogether. The exact impact on doctors' decisions remains uncertain.

Here's a quick guide to why the raise happened, why it's ending, and what it means for the future of Obamacare:

1. Obamacare raised Medicaid's primary care payments in 2013 and 2014
Before the Affordable Care Act, Medicare (the federal insurance program for the elderly) paid doctors more than Medicaid (the state-federal insurance program for the poor). On average, Medicaid paid doctors about two-thirds of what Medicare paid, although there was significant variation across the country.

Even though Medicaid paid less, it has generally done a good job ensuring patients can see primary care doctors. However, there was a concern that, after Obamacare, this might not be the case. Medicaid is one of the two main programs the law relies on to expand health insurance coverage (the other is the marketplaces). Forecasters estimated that 13 million additional people would join the program in Obamacare's first decade, and 7 million of those people would sign up in the first year.

Research has found that doctors are more likely to accept new Medicaid patients when their payment rates are higher. The Affordable Care Act included a provision that aimed to encourage doctors to continue or join the program as it expanded to cover millions more Americans. Beginning in 2013, the law increased Medicaid primary care doctors' reimbursement rates to match those of Medicare (specialists did not receive any increase). The law funded the increased payments through the end of 2014, setting up a looming cliff that we're now approaching.

2. Doctors will see a 42% pay cut in 2015
This is an estimate from the Urban Institute, which ran the numbers on how payment rates will change in 2015. The decline will vary significantly from state to state, as each state sets its own payment rates for primary care doctors. In a state like California, for example, which tended to pay Medicaid doctors very low rates, Obamacare has doubled their fees. But in North Carolina, where the two programs' fees were more similar, the pay rate increase was much smaller.

3. The federal government will not extend the pay cut
Mostly because it's expensive: the two years of the pay-bump cost the federal government $11 billion.

Medicaid advocacy groups have lobbied Congress to extend the pay cut for at least two years. Senators Patty Murray (D-WA) and Sherrod Brown (D-OH) did introduce legislation that would extend the pay bump until 2016. However, the issue has not gained traction; the Murray-Brown bill has languished in committee since its introduction this past summer. As a result, barring any last-minute miracle, Medicaid payment rates will decline in many states—but not all—on January 1, 2015.

4. Fifteen states are stepping in to extend the payment raise
Medicaid is a joint federal-state program, with the two governments splitting the bill for patients' coverage. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, 15 states will step in and provide funding to either fully or partially continue the payment increase.

What's notable about this map, however, is that the states stepping in tend to be those that were already paying Medicaid doctors well in the first place. They are places like New Mexico, which, before Obamacare, paid primary doctors 85% of the Medicare rate, or Mississippi, which paid 90%.

The states that have a much bigger gap between Medicaid and Medicare payments, like California, are not generally stepping in to avert the payment cut. This is probably due to the fact that fixing the bigger gaps is so much more expensive.

5. Nobody knows what this will mean for Medicaid patients' access to care
The worry among Medicaid advocates is that lower payment rates will translate into fewer doctors being willing to see patients. This is articulated in a recent New York Times article, citing data from Ohio:

A survey by the Ohio State Medical Association found that some Ohio doctors began accepting Medicaid patients because of the rate increase in 2013. Ohio doctors who were already participating in the program said they had accepted more Medicaid patients after the rate increase. And almost 40% of Ohio doctors indicated that they planned to accept fewer Medicaid patients when the extra payments lapsed.

Previous studies have shown that states that pay more for primary care in Medicaid do have more doctors accepting new patients. This chart from Health Affairs shows the correlation:

Those are the reasons for concern—but there are also reasons to think things might go okay, too. Medicaid patients tend to have just as good access to primary care as patients in private coverage. One 2012 study commissioned by the federal government found that Medicaid patients are equally as likely to have had a routine check-up in the past year as those with private insurance. The real challenges in access tend to happen when patients seek specialty care.

And it's worth keeping in mind that there were thousands of doctors who saw Medicaid patients prior to the Affordable Care Act's pay bump. These are people who, even before they got a big raise, thought it made sense to see these patients at lower rates. That gives decent reason to think that these doctors will stick around after the pay increase disappears, too.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Kelly Announces Immigration Enforcement Changes Per Trump's Orders

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly has initiated a series of immigration enforcement changes in accordance with President Trump's executive actions from January. The changes aim to strengthen enforcement by expanding the categories of illegal immigrants targeted for deportation.

In a memo released Tuesday, Secretary Kelly stated, "It is in the national interest of the United States to prevent criminals and criminal organizations from destabilizing border security." The memos prioritize criminal illegal immigrants and others for deportation, including those convicted or charged with "any criminal offense," or who have "abused" any public welfare program.

The changes will not affect the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, also known as "dreamers." However, DHS will no longer exempt classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement.

The memos also call for expanding the 287(g) program, which allows participating local officers to act as immigration agents, and ending "catch-and-release" policies under which illegal immigrants subject to deportation potentially are allowed to "abscond" and fail to appear at removal hearings.

The memos also outline the planning, design, and construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall. While congressional Republicans have vowed to fund the front-end costs associated with the wall, the memos hint at future efforts to potentially use money otherwise meant for Mexico.

It's unclear what timelines the secretary is setting for these objectives, and what budgetary and other constraints the department and its agencies will face. In pursuing an end to "catch-and-release," one memo calls for a plan with the Justice Department to "surge" immigration judges and asylum officers to handle additional cases.

The DHS directives come as the Trump White House continues to work on rewriting its controversial executive order suspending the U.S. refugee program as well as travel from seven mostly Muslim countries. The order was put on hold by a federal court, and Trump's team is said to be working on a new measure.

The directives also come as the Trump administration faces criticism from Democratic lawmakers and immigration advocacy groups for recent ICE raids of illegal immigrants. DHS officials on Tuesday's conference call stressed that they are operating under existing law and denied an apparently erroneous news report from last week claiming National Guard troops could be utilized to round up illegal immigrants. That will not happen, an official said.

"We're going to treat everyone humanely and with dignity, but we are going to execute the laws of the United States," a DHS official said on the conference call.

Title: FEMA Terminates Contract with Tribute Contracting LLC for Underdelivered Meals in Puerto Rico

Article:

A New York Times investigation has revealed that Tiffany Brown, an Atlanta entrepreneur and self-described government contractor who owns Tribute Contracting LLC, drastically underdelivered on a $156 million contract awarded by FEMA to provide 30 million self-heating meals to Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria.

Brown, the sole employee of her company, only followed through on 50,000 meals, according to the Times. In an attempt to fulfill the contract, Brown hired an 11-person wedding catering company and a Texas nonprofit that had shipped food to a Houston food bank during Hurricane Harvey.

The contract was terminated by email on Oct. 19, after Brown failed to meet a deadline of providing the first 18.5 million meals. Carolyn Ward, a FEMA official who handled the contract with Brown's company, wrote in an email to Brown, seen by the Times, that the operation was "a logistical nightmare."

"Do not ship another meal. Your contract is terminated," Ward wrote.

A FEMA spokesman told the Times that other suppliers provided "ample" food and water for Puerto Ricans, and that Tribute's contract did not result in any missed meals.

This is at least the sixth government contract awarded to Tribute that has been canceled, according to the Times. Brown's company has been awarded dozens of contracts, but has failed to deliver on several, including four that required her to deliver food products to correctional facilities in the Federal Prison System.

At the time the FEMA contract was awarded, the Government Publishing Office had a ban on awarding contracts of more than $35,000 to Tribute until January 2019 due to a mishandled project.

Brown is now fighting the FEMA contract termination and seeking a $70 million settlement. Her appeal argues that FEMA canceled her contract because the meals Tribute provided were packaged separately from their heating pouches, and claims that FEMA did not say the meals had to be self-heating.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is investigating the Tribute contract. Committee Democrats criticized FEMA in a letter to committee chairman Trey Gowdy, stating that FEMA should have considered Tribute's history and lack of large-scale disaster relief experience before awarding the contract.

"Clearly, Tribute did not have sufficient financial resources of its own to support this contract," they wrote, according to the Times. "FEMA should have raised serious questions about whether the company could meet the contract terms—especially since the contract concerned such a critical need."

In the letter, Democrats highlighted the Tribute contract as the latest example of how FEMA was unprepared to handle the hurricane aftermath in Puerto Rico by not preparing contractors in advance.

"It appears that the Trump administration's response to the hurricanes in Puerto Rico in 2017 suffered from the same flaws as the Bush Administration's response to Hurricane Katrina in 2005," they wrote.

Title: FBI Indictments Confirm Russian Interference in 2016 U.S. Elections, Says National Security Adviser

Article:

The national security adviser to President Donald Trump, H.R. McMaster, stated during the Munich Security Conference in Germany that the recently unveiled FBI indictments provide incontrovertible evidence of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential elections. The indictment, led by special counsel Robert Mueller, alleges a sophisticated plot by 13 Russian nationals and three Russian companies to wage "information warfare" against the U.S.

The indictment accuses the Russian nationals of setting a strategic goal to sow discord in the U.S. political system, including the 2016 presidential election. Tech giant executives, including those from Facebook and Twitter, testified recently on Capitol Hill that Russia indeed used social media to disrupt the 2016 White House race and sow discord among voters.

The indictment is the first filed against Russian nationals as part of Mueller's probe into whether Trump associates colluded with Russian officials during the 2016 elections. However, the Justice Department made clear that the indictment does not allege that any of the interference changed the outcome of the presidential race.

Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who oversees the special counsel probe, stated at a Friday press conference that "there is no allegation in this indictment that any American was a knowing participant in this illegal activity. There is no allegation in the indictment that the charged conduct altered the outcome of the 2016 election."

Russia's foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, dismissed the indictment, calling it "just blabber." When asked about the indictments, Lavrov replied, "I have no response. You can publish anything, and we see those indictments multiplying." He argued that U.S. officials also have said no country influenced the U.S. election results.

The 37-page indictment, signed by Mueller, details actions dating back to 2014. The defendants are accused of spreading derogatory information about Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, denigrating Republican candidates Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, and ultimately supporting Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders and then-Republican candidate Donald Trump.

President Trump asserted on Friday that the indictment proved there was "no collusion" between his campaign and the Russians. "Russia started their anti-US campaign in 2014, long before I announced that I would run for President," Trump tweeted after the indictment was unveiled. "The results of the election were not impacted. The Trump campaign did nothing wrong — no collusion."

The three entities charged in the indictment are Internet Research Agency LLC, Concord Management and Consulting LLC, and Concord Catering. The 13 Russians charged are Yevgeniy Viktorovich Prigozhin, Mikhail Ivanovich Bystrov, Mikhail Leonidovich Burchik, Aleksandra Yuryevna Krylova, Anna Vladislavovna Bogacheva, Sergey Pavlovich Polozov, Maria Anatolyrvna Bovda, Robert Sergetevich Bovda, Dzheykhun Nasimi Ogly, Vadim Vladimirovich Podkopaev, Gleb Igorevich Vasilchenko, Irina Viktorovna Kaverzina, and Vladimir Venkov.

Title: Romney's Remarks on Obama Supporters Spark Controversy

Article:

In a video released on Monday, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney made comments about President Barack Obama's supporters that have sparked controversy. The video, posted on the website of Mother Jones, shows Romney speaking at a private fundraiser earlier this year.

In the video, Romney described many supporters of President Obama as dependent on government and unwilling to take responsibility for their own lives. He stated, "There are 47% of the people who will vote for the president, no matter what... These are people who pay no income tax."

Romney also said, "I'll never convince them they should take personal responsibility and care for their lives."

During a hastily scheduled news conference in Costa Mesa on Monday night, Romney did not back away from his remarks. He said, "It's not elegantly stated, let me put it that way. I'm speaking off the cuff in response to a question."

The comments could be read as unflattering to Obama supporters broadly and to millions of people who hold jobs and pay payroll taxes, but do not earn enough to pay the income tax. Some of these people receive tax benefits, such as credits for children, which wipe out their tax burdens.

Romney's comments echoed ideas he has laid out elsewhere as central to his candidacy: that the federal government spends too much money and has unmoored the country from the principles of free enterprise and hard work.

The incident was reminiscent of Obama's remarks this summer, which were interpreted by Republicans as a disparagement of entrepreneurialism. Democrats said the president meant only that government spending on infrastructure and other programs is important to business owners.

In other contexts, the candidates have said these competing ideas go to the heart of the election, with Obama arguing for a government role in the economy and Romney saying government is too intrusive.

In 2008, Obama was also accused of offering a broad and unflattering characterization of voters during a fundraiser when he said people in small towns with high unemployment "cling to guns or religion or antipathy toward people who are not like them."

Obama's campaign manager, Jim Messina, said it was "shocking" that Romney would say that "half of the American people view themselves as 'victims' entitled to handouts... It's hard to serve as president for all Americans when you've disdainfully written off half the nation."

Earlier Monday, the Romney campaign had pledged more policy specifics and rolled out a set of new TV ads, marking an effort by Romney to regain his footing amid signs that Obama is building a lead in national opinion polls and most battleground states.

Democrats and some Republicans have said Romney should lay out more policy specifics, such as which tax breaks he would scrap in order to pay for a 20% cut to tax rates he has proposed for all income brackets.

"We do think the timing is right, at this moment, to reinforce the specifics—more specifics—about the Romney plan," Romney adviser Ed Gillespie said.

Romney did not offer new policy specifics in a speech Monday to small-business owners at the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. He said he would overhaul the legal immigration system. His comments dovetail with House Republicans' effort to pass legislation that would increase the number of visas for workers in fields like engineering and science. A vote is expected this week.

Title: Contact Tracing: A Growing Presence in the U.S. Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

As the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact the United States, a new development has emerged: the deployment of contact tracers to identify and monitor individuals who have tested positive for the virus. This tactic, which has proven useful in other countries, is intended to focus on actual vectors of infection rather than entire populations. However, the prospect of an army of government officials questioning citizens has raised concerns about privacy and potential abuse.

The National Association of County and City Health Officials estimates that at least 100,000 contact tracers will be needed to control the virus as communities reopen. New York state, ground zero for America's pandemic crisis, plans to put between 6,400 and 17,000 contact tracers in place. New York City's "Test and Trace Corps" will launch with 1,000 contact tracers, according to Mayor Bill de Blasio.

Johns Hopkins University, a leading institution in the field, offers a free, online, certificate-granting course in contact tracing through Coursera. The course covers not only the biology of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and the process of gathering information, but also ethical considerations, including privacy. However, it is state, city, and local government agencies, not Johns Hopkins University, that are managing the deployment of the contact tracers they train.

In the state of Washington, Gov. Jay Inslee's reopening plan, including an initial 1,371 contact tracers, has raised questions about privacy rights. The state requires restaurants to create a daily log of all customers and maintain that log for 30 days, including telephone/email contact information and time in. This has sparked concerns about the collection and storage of personal information.

In California, Robert Levin, the director of Ventura County Public Health, had to apologize after a contact tracing program announcement in which he gave the impression that individuals isolated would be taken out of their homes and placed in hotels or motels. This type of statement has contributed to public reluctance to share details of their shopping trips and social interactions with government-employed strangers.

Cooperation with contact tracers is voluntary, and refusal to share information with contact tracers is a patient's right. Across the country, public officials are urging cooperation, but enforcement would be challenging, as people can lie to government officials they do not trust. Bioethicist Jacob Appel notes that countries with authoritarian governments or high levels of social cohesion have successfully used contact tracing, but the U.S. does not possess either.

The success of contact tracing depends on winning the public's trust and cooperation. Public officials must demonstrate that they are deploying an army of helpful contact tracers and not intrusive "cootie cops." If they can convince the public of the wisdom of their tactics and the innocence of their intentions, perhaps we can work together to resolve our health concerns.

Title: Federal Reserve Lowers Economic Outlook, Hints at Delay in Interest Rate Hike

Article:

The Federal Reserve lowered its economic outlook on Wednesday following a harsh winter that slowed the U.S. economy's growth, reducing the likelihood of an initial interest rate hike at the Fed's June meeting. In a statement following a two-day meeting, the Fed did not provide a clear signal of when it plans to raise its benchmark interest rate for the first time since 2006, but policymakers have indicated they expect to act this year.

As of 2:55 p.m. ET, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down about 55 points, or 0.3%, to 18,056, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped 5 points, or 0.3%, to 2110. The Nasdaq composite was down 17 points, or 0.3%, to 5038. Yields on 10-year government bonds rose above 2%.

The Fed stated that economic growth "slowed during the winter months, in part reflecting transitory factors." Unusually cold weather, for example, hindered economic activity. The Fed expects the economy to rebound and grow at a moderate pace in coming months.

While a June rate increase "does not look very likely," it "remains an option if the data suddenly turn much stronger than expected," according to Jim O'Sullivan, chief U.S. economist of High Frequency Economics. Paul Ashworth of Capital Economics stated, "it would take something quite spectacular to convince Fed officials to raise rates in June."

The Fed's statement noted that job growth "moderated" and household spending declined in recent weeks, though inflation-adjusted incomes "rose strongly, partly reflecting earlier declines in energy prices." Business investment, however, "softened" and exports declined, the statement said. The Fed added that inflation continued to run below the Fed's target, "partly reflecting earlier declines in energy prices and decreasing prices of non-energy imports." Fed policymakers expect inflation "to rise gradually toward 2% over the medium-term as the labor market improves further and the transitory effects" of low energy and import prices dissipate.

A strong dollar has hurt manufacturers' exports, and the plunge in oil prices has led energy companies to slash investment. The government reported that the economy grew just 0.2% at an annual rate in the first quarter, down from 2.2% in the October-December period and below the modest 1% pace expected by economists. Meanwhile, inflation remains well below the Fed's annual 2% target, with the Fed's preferred measure, which excludes food and energy costs, rising 0.9% last quarter, the smallest increase since 2010. Employers added just 126,000 jobs in March, compared to average monthly gains of 269,000 in the prior 12 months.

The Fed reiterated that it will raise its federal funds rate "when it has seen further improvement in the labor market and is reasonably confident that inflation will move back" to the Fed's 2% target "over the medium-term." The central bank has kept its benchmark interest rate near zero since the 2008 financial crisis, but with the economic recovery now almost six years old, the central bank has been preparing financial markets and consumers for a return to normal interest rate policy. Last month, the Fed dropped a pledge to be patient as it considers boosting the rate, signaling that it could make the move as early as June.

Many economists say the Fed is unlikely to act until September at the earliest so it can assess whether the economy is regaining the momentum it had built last year. That timetable is consistent with Fed policymakers' median forecast in March as well as with recent speeches by Fed policymakers, including Fed Chair Janet Yellen.

Title: Investigations Allege Abuse of Power and Misuse of State Department Resources by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo

Article:

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has found himself at the center of a series of allegations involving potential abuse of power, disregard for accepted procedures, and misuse of state resources. The allegations, which have been reported by various news organizations, have cast a spotlight on Pompeo's actions during his tenure as Secretary of State.

The investigations allege a pattern of behavior that is familiar in the Trump administration. These allegations include possible abuse of power for personal gain, disdain and circumvention of accepted procedures, and a propensity to treat a government position as a personal fiefdom with little regard for both taxpayer money and common decency.

One of the most prominent allegations concerns luxurious dinners hosted by Pompeo and his wife Susan at the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms. The dinners, which were paid for by taxpayers, were attended by a guest list that was more composed of Republican donors and activists than foreign diplomats and policy experts. According to NBC News, approximately 39% of the nearly 500 invitees were from Fox News.

The allegations took a more serious turn when it was revealed that President Donald Trump had announced his intention to fire the State Department's Inspector General, Steve Linick. Inspectors general are Senate-confirmed government officials charged with auditing and investigating potential instances of fraud and abuse in the government.

Pompeo acknowledged that he had asked Trump to fire Linick, but offered little explanation for the reason other than it should have happened sooner. He called claims that the firing was retribution for probes into his activities "patently false."

Shortly after the announcement, Democratic Rep. Eliot Engel, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, revealed that Linick was investigating Pompeo. Engel, along with Sen. Bob Menendez, ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, opened a probe into the ouster, decrying "the politically-motivated firing of inspectors general and the President's gutting of these critical positions."

Later, NBC reported that Linick was investigating Pompeo's use of a State Department political appointee to conduct personal errands, such as walking his dog and picking up his laundry.

Within hours, the allegations grew more disturbing. Engel told CNN of another possible reason for Linick's firing. The inspector general was investigating the declaration of an "emergency" that Pompeo had cited one year ago as reason for bypassing the requirement that Congress approve an $8 billion sale of weapons to Saudi Arabia.

Engel, who called the declaration "phony," said Linick was conducting an investigation of it at his office's request. The New York Times reported that Pompeo had already answered written questions into that probe.

The NBC investigation identified the dog-walking staffer, whose name appeared in the emails NBC reviewed in connection with the so-called Madison Dinners. The staffer was the principal liaison between Pompeo's office and the protocol office that organized the dinners. "Two administration officials told NBC News that Linick made some type of inquiry to the protocol office last week, before he was fired," NBC reported. "One of the officials said Pompeo's office was then notified. " Whether Linick was also investigating Pompeo's dinners remains unclear.

The details of the Madison Dinners, with their own logo embossed on State Department invitations, brought hundreds of people to the center of US diplomacy more than 20 times since Pompeo became Secretary of State. The majority of the guests came from the corporate world and conservative media and entertainment, along with Republican - only Republican - members of Congress. Among those wined and dined were Fox News' Laura Ingraham, Marjorie Dannenfelser, head of a prominent anti-abortion lobbying group, Bill Miller, head of a leading casino lobbying group, former Major League Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, Chick-fil-A Chairman Dan Cathy, a leading conservative donor, and others, in a detailed mailing list reviewed by NBC.

Sources told NBC that the State Department collected information about each guest, and that information was all forwarded to the private Gmail account of Susan Pompeo, the Secretary of State's wife. Whatever reason she had for receiving the data, it amounts to a treasure trove, should the Secretary of State decide to run for a Kansas Senate seat - or for President. If that is the purpose of the dinners and the emailing, it is a violation of the Hatch Act, which bans most federal employees from using their position for partisan political activities.

Title: Pro-Democracy Movement Sweeps Hong Kong District Council Elections

Article:

Hong Kong's opposition pro-democracy movement has made unprecedented gains in the Chinese territory's district council elections, according to local media counts. Preliminary results indicate that 17 out of the 18 councils are now controlled by pro-democracy councillors. Despite fears the vote could be disrupted or cancelled due to the ongoing unrest, it proceeded peacefully.

The election was seen as a test of support for the government after months of protests and clashes. The government and Beijing had hoped the election would bring a show of support from the so-called "silent majority," but this did not materialize. Instead, some significant pro-Beijing candidates lost their council seats.

One controversial pro-Beijing lawmaker, Junius Ho, who lost his seat, said, "Heaven and earth have been turned upside down." Hong Kong's district councillors have limited political power and mainly deal with local issues such as bus routes and rubbish collection, so the district elections do not normally generate such interest.

However, these polls were the first time people could express their opinion on embattled Chief Executive Carrie Lam's handling of the crisis, which was sparked by a now-withdrawn extradition law. Additionally, 117 of the district councillors will also sit on the 1,200-member committee that votes for the chief executive, so a pro-democracy district win could translate to a bigger share in choosing the city's next leader.

A record 4.1 million people had registered to vote—more than half the population—and more than 2.9 million people cast votes. That's a turnout of more than 71%, against 47% in 2015. The weekend was also the first in months without any clashes between protesters and police.

Over the past months, demonstrations and unrest had been gradually escalating. Police have at times used live rounds, wounding several protesters. Activists in turn have attacked police or in one case set alight a government supporter.
