It was unclear how much of the general population still supported the protesters, and authorities had been hoping the election would identify the protesters as a small group of fringe extremists.

However, in many districts, young first-time candidates, many who had explicitly aligned themselves with the protesters, unseated established politicians backing the government. The hope from activists is that the overwhelming victory of anti-establishment parties will force the government to take protesters' demands more seriously.

Outside the Yau Ma Tei North polling station, local residents lined up to gain entry so they could watch the vote count. The doors opened, and they poured into the public viewing area. Six months into an ongoing political crisis, people have lost faith in government institutions. They wanted to make sure that this process was fair and transparent.

As they waited for the total in their own district council to be tallied, they could see the numbers coming in from elsewhere on their mobile phones. By their facial expressions, it was clear they could not believe what was unfolding, and people cheered in astonishment as one surprising result came in after another. Nobody imagined such a comprehensive wipeout, and Carrie Lam's administration will no doubt come under renewed pressure to listen to the demands of protesters following such an overwhelming defeat for her and her allies.

More than 1,000 candidates ran for 452 district council seats, which, for the first time, were all contested. A further 27 district seats are allocated to representatives of rural districts. Pro-Beijing parties held the majority of these seats ahead of the election. In one of the biggest losses for the pro-Beijing camp, lawmaker Junius Ho—one of Hong Kong's most controversial politicians—suffered a shock defeat.

Jimmy Sham, a political activist who has recently risen to prominence as the leader of the Civil Human Rights Front—a campaign group responsible for organizing some of the mass protest marches—won a seat after running for the first time. Mr. Sham has also been attacked twice, once apparently with hammers. Photographs at the time showed him lying on the street covered in blood.

After the vote, Mr. Sham said, "We have to be leaders of the community that listens to people's voices and opinions." Pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong was barred from running in the elections, a move he referred to as "political screening," but the pro-democracy candidate who replaced him has won.

In a tweet, Mr. Wong said the "historic" results showed that public opinion had not turned against the pro-democracy movement. Reflecting on her reported defeat, pro-Beijing lawmaker Alice Mak suggested Ms. Lam's administration was partly to blame. "In the election campaign, pro-government candidates have been unfairly treated. This is a very important reason," she said.

Starry Lee Wai-king, chairwoman of the city's largest pro-Beijing party, was among the few establishment candidates to secure her seat. "I think [Lee] is the only one who can survive the de facto referendum," said Leung Kwok-hung, her pro-democracy opponent in the poll.

Title: GOP Pivots to Broad Legislative Achievements as Midterm Elections Approach

Article:

Republicans are reportedly working on a backup plan in case the GOP tax law does not prove to be a strong selling point for their party in the upcoming midterm elections. While the booming economy is expected to be a core pillar of the GOP's midterm messaging, it remains unclear whether the party will receive credit for the tax law, which has lagged in polls.

In response, GOP leaders on both sides of the Capitol are emphasizing a breadth of legislative achievements as they seek to convince voters to keep them in charge and not deliver majorities to Democrats. To bolster their case, Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) point to a flurry of wide-ranging bills sent to President Donald Trump's desk last month.

In an interview with a media outlet late last month, McConnell highlighted last year's $1.5 trillion tax-cut package, but also pointed to increased spending for the military, 15 repealed regulations, and the confirmation of a conservative Supreme Court justice and 21 conservative circuit court judges. Ryan and his top lieutenants have made a similar pitch.

"We're doing more things this week to continue to establish our priorities," Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) told reporters Wednesday. "It's not just lowering taxes for families, but it's taking care of our military and taking care of our veterans."

In another move meant to paint the portrait of Republicans hard at work, McConnell announced Tuesday he would cancel most of the August recess so that senators could work through spending bills and Trump's nominations before a Sept. 30 funding deadline. The decision has the added benefit of keeping dozens of Democratic senators off the campaign trail in August.

"We think we have a good chance of passing a number of appropriations bills," McConnell told reporters during his weekly news conference on Tuesday. "In order to do that, and deal with this nominations backlog, we need to be here in August."

It remains unclear whether the GOP's messaging strategy will work, especially when accomplishments on Capitol Hill can be easily overshadowed by more dramatic developments coming out of the White House. The same week that Congress sent a trio of bills to Trump's desk, for example, the president dominated the news cycle by canceling a planned historic summit with North Korea.

The GOP Congress also has come up short on some of Trump's chief priorities, disappointing the president and his most fervent supporters. Despite majorities in both chambers and control of the White House, Republicans failed to repeal and replace ObamaCare or fund Trump's signature border wall. Trump has bashed Congress over the failure on the wall in particular, to the chagrin of Republicans, who think it shortchanges the accomplishments that have been secured.

"I'd like the president to talk about it more often and I believe he will going into the fall campaign," McConnell said of the GOP's successes. The effort to push a more aggressive Republican agenda could please some conservatives, who have said tax reform alone is not enough to run on in the midterms.

"You can't just rest on your laurels," Rep. Mark Walker (R-N.C.), chairman of the Republican Study Committee, told a media outlet on Wednesday. "You've got to keep fulfilling your promises to the American people."

While the tax law's poll numbers have improved, GOP strategists point out that some voters may not see the benefits until next year. There are also concerns that the economic gains from the tax law could be wiped out after Trump slapped tariffs on steel and aluminum imports worldwide, including from the European Union, Canada, and Mexico. Trump has threatened to follow up with additional tariffs on foreign cars and has also talked about imposing new tariffs on imports from China.

It can be difficult to accomplish major policy items in election years, with less time on the legislative calendar and vulnerable members reluctant to take any tough votes. But in recent months, Congress has seen an uptick in activity, with Trump signing legislation to ease financial regulations, improve how veterans access health care, and allow terminally ill patients to try experimental drugs. The House, which also passed a bipartisan prison reform bill last month, plans to take up legislation next week to combat the nation's deadly opioid crisis—an issue that resonates strongly in many communities around the country.

Congressional leaders want to avoid passing another short-term funding patch this year and are hoping to move spending legislation through both chambers before the end of September. Since it is the last train leaving the station, lawmakers will surely push to attach a number of priorities to the legislation. But if there are poison pill amendments—or if Trump refuses to sign any spending measure that doesn't contain money for his border wall—it could bring Congress to the brink of another shutdown just weeks before the midterms. That could chip away at the GOP's argument that they are effective legislators.

"It could be a real mess if it leads to a shutdown," said Matt Mackowiak, a GOP strategist and opinion contributor for a media outlet. "So there's still some political risk out there for Republicans."

Title: President Obama to Announce 19 Separate Steps on Gun Control Without Congressional Action

Article:

President Barack Obama is reportedly considering 19 separate steps on gun control that he can implement without congressional approval. These measures come as more ambitious proposals, such as a ban on military-style "assault weapons," face resistance in Congress from various lawmakers and gun-rights groups.

The potential steps include stricter measures on gun trafficking, increased federal agency research on gun control, and providing schools with flexibility to use grants to enhance safety. According to the Associated Press, President Obama will reveal his proposals this week, with a mix of measures requiring congressional approval and steps he can implement independently.

The President has pledged to take significant action on gun violence following the shooting deaths of 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, last month. Vice President Joe Biden, who is leading a task force on the issue, met with Democratic lawmakers on Monday and discussed some of the measures President Obama might consider.

During the meeting, Vice President Biden did not specify which proposals the President would take up or present to the public this week. A ban on military-style "assault weapons" is one measure that is expected to encounter strong opposition in Congress. Figures such as National Rifle Association President David Keene and U.S. Senator John McCain (Arizona Republican) have predicted that such a measure would not pass through Congress.

In addition to the ban on "assault weapons," Congress may also consider limiting high-capacity ammunition clips and implementing universal background checks for gun buyers. President Obama acknowledged on Monday the challenges of passing some of these items.

"Will all of them get through this Congress? I don't know," President Obama said. "My starting point is not to worry about the politics. My starting point is to focus on what makes sense, what works."

Title: Justice Department Declines Appeal, McCabe Faces Possible Indictment for Alleged Lying to Internal Investigators

Article:

Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, a frequent target of President Donald Trump's criticism, faces the prospect of an indictment after his attorneys were unsuccessful in persuading senior Justice Department officials not to pursue charges that he lied to internal investigators. Two anonymous sources familiar with the matter revealed on Thursday that the deputy attorney general declined an appeal from McCabe's lawyers aimed at preventing a prosecution.

The specifics of when or if the United States Attorney's Office in Washington, which has been leading the investigation, might announce charges remain unclear. McCabe's attorneys argue that he should not face charges on accusations that he lied to internal investigators about whether he had authorized a news media leak in the fall of 2016. McCabe has denied intentionally misleading anyone.

An indictment of McCabe would refocus public attention on the chaotic months of 2016 when the FBI was entangled in presidential politics through investigations touching both main contenders—Democrat Hillary Clinton and Trump, her Republican opponent. While prosecutors are likely to try to keep a narrow focus on whether McCabe lied to investigators on particular dates, McCabe's attorneys are expected to argue that the prosecution is part of a political vendetta driven by the president.

They are likely to highlight the personal enmity between the two men, with Trump criticizing McCabe even before he took office and McCabe describing the president as a "deliberate liar." McCabe's lawyers have said any false statements made to investigators were the product of a faulty memory, and that the interviews took place during a tumultuous time for the bureau as it investigated potential ties between Russia and the Trump campaign.

McCabe became acting director of the FBI after Trump fired former Director James Comey on May 9, 2017. McCabe has said his 2018 firing—for what the Justice Department called "lack of candor"—was politically motivated. He sued the Justice Department in August, saying officials had used the inspector general's conclusions as a pretext to rid the FBI of leaders Trump perceived as biased against him.

The investigation followed an October 2016 story in The Wall Street Journal that described internal debates roiling the FBI and the Department of Justice weeks before the presidential election about how aggressively the Clinton Foundation should be investigated. The article recounted a particularly tense phone call between McCabe and a senior Justice Department official about the investigation.

The inspector general's report said McCabe told internal investigators that he had not authorized anyone at the FBI to speak with the reporter, and he did not know who did. The report said McCabe ultimately corrected that account, and confirmed that he had encouraged the conversation with the reporter to counter a narrative that he thought was false—namely, that he had been trying to stymie investigations into Clinton and the foundation.

Title: Trump Secures Third Consecutive Victory in Nevada Republican Caucuses

Article:

Donald Trump has won the Nevada Republican Presidential caucuses, marking his third consecutive victory in the primary race. With almost all votes counted, Trump received 45.9% of the vote, surpassing his two closest rivals, Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio.

Florida Senator Marco Rubio finished second, narrowly edging out Texas Senator Ted Cruz. This result is unlikely to significantly boost the momentum of either candidate, ensuring both remain in the race.

The upcoming Super Tuesday contests, taking place in a dozen states next week, including several states across the South, the GOP's traditional stronghold, are next on the schedule. An uncharacteristically subdued Cruz warned supporters that it would be "the most important night of this campaign."

According to exit polls in Nevada, Trump carried evangelical Christians over Cruz, the core of the Texas senator's base. He also won among Hispanics, edging out his two Latino rivals. Trump won across every ideological group, every education group, every racial group, and both genders. He also won among both Republicans and independents.

The common theme among Trump's supporters is a shared concern and dissatisfaction with the state of the nation. Nearly 94% of caucusgoers expressed a negative view of the government, with six in ten describing themselves as "angry." An equal number said they wanted the next president to come from "outside politics."

At his victory rally in a Las Vegas hotel, Trump highlighted his success with various demographic groups, stating, "We won the evangelicals, we won with young, we won with old, we won with highly educated, we won with poorly educated. I love the poorly educated. We're the smartest people; we're the most loyal people."

Looking ahead to the primaries and caucuses, Trump predicted, "It's going to be an amazing two months. We might not even need the two months, folks, to be honest."

Trump has already won decisive victories in New Hampshire, South Carolina, and Nevada, vanquishing governors, senators, and a GOP dynasty. He has expanded the Republican electorate, contributing to record turnouts. He has forged the broadest-based coalition of any of his opponents.

The upcoming primaries and caucuses on Tuesday will test Trump's coalition, with contests from Massachusetts and Vermont to Georgia and Texas. At that point, nearly a third of Republican convention delegates will have been chosen. Two weeks later, with March 15 primaries in Florida, Ohio, and elsewhere, nearly two-thirds will be chosen.

The results of these contests will provide insight into questions such as whether a single rival can defeat Trump in a head-to-head matchup and the likelihood of a contested convention for the first time in four decades.

Title: Obama's Strategy: Portraying Romney as a Third Term for Bush

Article:

In the upcoming presidential debate in Denver, President Barack Obama is expected to accuse Mitt Romney of representing a third term for George W. Bush, referring to Romney's policies as a continuation of the financial crisis. This strategy is part of Obama's carefully crafted approach to position Romney as a proponent of Bush's hands-off approach to taxes, spending, and regulation, which Obama believes led to the economic crisis.

The tactic mirrors Obama's successful strategy in the 2008 election against John McCain, where he attempted to associate McCain with the recent Republican administration. While not as direct, Obama's approach aims to remind voters of the negative aspects of recent Republican governance, a strategy that has been effective in reminding voters of the past Republican administration.

According to a CNN poll last month, 62 percent of self-described moderates blame Bush and the Republicans for the country's economic troubles, while only 30 percent fault Obama and the Democrats. By indicting both parties for America's fiscal problems, Romney could distance himself from Bush and gain credibility with voters tired of Washington's politics.

Michael Tanner of the Cato Institute suggests that such a strategy, known as "triangulation," would be beneficial for Romney. Tanner states, "It would blunt Obama's attacks on Romney wanting to return to the Bush policy. And it would help rally those tea party folks who don't think much of Bush or the Republican establishment."

Anti-tax crusader Grover Norquist also supports this strategy, stating, "The speech writes itself." The effectiveness of this strategy remains to be seen, as the debate is yet to take place.

Title: Wisconsin Legislators Propose $100 Million Tax Incentive Package for Kimberly-Clark

Article:

A proposed plan to offer Kimberly-Clark Corporation a $100 million tax incentive package to maintain its operations in Wisconsin has sparked debate over the concept of economic development and the role of government in business.

In January, Kimberly-Clark announced plans to cut 13% of its global workforce, potentially affecting up to 5,500 jobs nationwide and closing ten of its 91 manufacturing facilities, including two in Neenah and Fox Crossing, Wisconsin, which support 600 jobs.

The proposal, which is currently stalled in the state senate, would offer Kimberly-Clark a 17% tax credit for existing jobs paying between $30,000 and $100,000 annually, and a 15% capital-investment credit. This package is worth $100 million, a significant amount compared to the current Wisconsin tax credit of 7%.

The proposal has been met with criticism, with some arguing that it represents a form of central planning and market distortion. The Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty (WILL) has expressed concern that such incentives could set a dangerous precedent, leading to an increased role for government in the economy.

Republicans, who often advocate for minimal government intervention in the economy, have been criticized for their support of such incentives. The argument is that, in an effort to appear "pro-business," they are engaging in what some consider to be "crony capitalism."

Despite the state's strong economy, with unemployment below 3%, wages rising, and business optimism up, the proposal to offer Kimberly-Clark a $100 million tax incentive package has been met with criticism. Critics argue that the proposal will retard growth, as workers who stay at Kimberly-Clark are denied the opportunity to fill open jobs at Wisconsin businesses with better long-term prospects.

The debate over the proposal highlights the ongoing discussion about the role of government in economic development and the potential consequences of using tax incentives to attract or retain businesses.

Title: Second Presidential Debate at Washington University: Trump and Clinton Clash in Town-Hall Style Event

Article:

The second presidential debate, held at Washington University in St. Louis, saw a heated exchange between Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and Republican nominee Donald Trump. The debate, moderated by Anderson Cooper and Martha Raddatz, was marked by accusations, counter-attacks, and a focus on controversial issues.

The debate came on the heels of a damaging tape revealing Trump boasting about his sexual advances towards women without their consent. Clinton declined to shake hands with Trump during their initial encounter at the debate venue. Throughout the debate, Clinton accused Trump of being unfit for the presidency and of lying, while Trump suggested that if elected, Clinton would face legal consequences.

Trump, however, managed to regain some ground by putting Clinton on the defensive and reminding voters of issues they may not like about her. He cited Clinton's destruction of subpoenaed emails, her handling of the Benghazi incident, her stance on Syrian refugees, her wavering support of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and her private versus public positions on various issues.

One of the most contentious moments of the debate was when Trump defended himself against allegations of misogyny, citing the women who had accused Clinton's husband, Bill, of sexual assault or rape. Trump had invited four of these women to a press conference before the debate.

Trump also attacked Clinton for her role in the Democratic National Committee's alleged dirty tricks campaign against Bernie Sanders, her comments about "deplorables," and her lack of action in creating jobs during her time as a senator for New York.

In the foreign policy segment of the debate, both candidates were asked about their plans for dealing with the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo. Trump's response was criticized for lacking specific solutions, while Clinton emphasized her experience in fighting terror and her commitment to children and families.

Both candidates were also asked about their Supreme Court nomination policies. Clinton expressed a desire to appoint justices who would support Roe v. Wade and marriage equality, and would work to overturn Citizens United and get dark money out of politics. Trump, on the other hand, stated that he would appoint justices who would defend the Constitution and uphold the Second Amendment.

The debate did not result in either candidate appearing noble or appealing, but Trump managed to regain some momentum after a difficult few days. The election, it seems, may come down to voters deciding whom they would rather have a beer with.

Title: Iowa's Des Moines Register Endorses Clinton and Rubio Ahead of Presidential Caucuses

Article:

The Des Moines Register, the most prominent daily newspaper in Iowa, has endorsed Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Marco Rubio in the upcoming presidential caucuses, scheduled for February 1. In dual editorials, the paper praised Clinton's "depth" of "knowledge and experience" and Rubio's potential to "chart a new direction" for the GOP.

The Des Moines Register's editorial board acknowledged that Clinton is not a "perfect candidate," citing her email controversy and changing stances on gay marriage and immigration. However, the board argued that Clinton is more qualified than both Bernie Sanders and Martin O'Malley. Regarding Rubio, the board argued that he still faces questions over his experience and ability to unite the party but could offer "an uplifting message" of a new American century.

Both campaigns quickly distributed the respective editorials to their supporters. However, strategists and observers have raised questions about the impact of the paper's endorsement, with some suggesting it could be counterproductive. The Register has been endorsing candidates ahead of Iowa's presidential caucuses since 1988, but this cycle's endorsements came amid an upside-down political atmosphere in which once-vaunted traditions have become unwelcome reminders of insiderdom.

The two Republican candidates most likely to win the caucuses, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, did not even bother to court the paper's endorsement. It is unclear whether they would have wanted it anyway. Republican strategists and political observers predicted that unlike in previous years, a Register endorsement would be an instant talking point for rivals, proof that the winners are aligned with a mainstream media outlet's moderate-to-liberal lean.

The biggest benefit from an endorsement would likely occur outside of Iowa, argued one veteran Iowa Republican strategist. For Rubio, who is seeking to run as an establishment-oriented alternative to Trump or Cruz, the endorsement could signal to voters in New Hampshire and more moderate enclaves that establishment Republicans are coalescing behind him. The endorsement enables him to say "I’m the establishment pick," and yeah, that’s going to be really valuable," the strategist said.

The Democratic endorsement may be more influential since the paper's left-leaning editorial board tends to connect better with Democrats. The Register, who had almost entirely turned over since Clinton's last campaign, would have been hard-pressed to ditch Clinton, whom it backed over then-Sen. Barack Obama in late 2007. The paper that year described her "readiness" to lead the country. "We believe as president she'll do what she's always done in her life: Throw herself into the job and work hard," the board wrote. "We believe Hillary Rodham Clinton can do great things for our country."

Clinton won the endorsement, Yepsen noted, even though the paper's editorial board has almost entirely turned over since her last campaign. The Register's Saturday endorsements were its 10th and 11th since it first backed Democrat Paul Simon in 1988. These days, candidates can afford to do battle with prominent outlets. In previous caucus years, endorsements were more meaningful because candidates did not have 24/7 exposure, and a trusted editorial board was an important liaison to voters. Today, they're only good for a positive news cycle or two.

"Endorsements are like fool's gold," Ari Fleischer, a former press secretary to President George W. Bush, said. "You can spend them the day they come out to get good press, but they don't change voter behavior." In the meantime, he said, the recipients' rivals will be working to spin the endorsement as a negative, especially on the Republican side, "with the dislike of all things establishment this cycle."

Kevin Madden, a spokesman for Mitt Romney's 2012 presidential campaign, said it's a particularly difficult year for newspaper endorsements to make an impact. "Editorial endorsements are more of a conventional barometer of support or progress in a totally unconventional year," he said. "It's less about being blessed by the hands of the establishment and more about their diminished ability—due to a much more fractured media landscape—to drive earned media attention and shape voter attitudes."

Over the years, The paper has had mediocre luck at picking winners, and former New York Times data expert Nate Silver noted in 2011 that there's little evidence candidates even received a statistical benefit from the endorsement. That year, the paper endorsed Romney, who lost the Republican caucuses narrowly to Rick Santorum but ultimately became the party's nominee. But few see the needle moving much, regardless of the Register's decisions. "In general, I just think newspaper endorsements are kind of an antiquity," Yepsen said. "What it’s worth is a little media buzz. The media writes about itself and the race kind of moves on."

Title: Puerto Rico Governor Calls for Cancellation of Whitefish Energy Contract for Power Grid Reconstruction

Article:

Puerto Rico's Governor Ricardo Rosselló has recommended the cancellation of a contract awarded to the small Montana-based firm, Whitefish Energy, for the reconstruction of the island's power grid. The head of the US-controlled island's power authority, Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (Prepa), has accepted the governor's recommendation and intends to terminate the deal.

The contract, worth $300 million, was given to Whitefish Energy, a company with limited experience in projects of such scale, without a public bidding process. As of Sunday morning, more than 70% of Puerto Ricans were still without power, over five weeks after Hurricane Maria devastated the power grid.

Governor Rosselló has instructed Prepa to cancel the Whitefish contract and coordinate with the states of Florida and New York to reinforce the grid rebuilding brigades currently working on the island. Concerns have been raised about why Puerto Rican authorities did not request "mutual aid" from other public power authorities, as is typical during disasters in the US.

In response to the news, Whitefish Energy expressed disappointment in the decision, stating that it would delay the restoration of power on the island. The company maintains that it secured the contract in a legitimate manner.

The White House and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) distanced themselves from the deal last week. The company's headquarters are in the town of Whitefish, the hometown of US Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke. Mr. Zinke has denied any involvement or wrongdoing.

Earlier this week, Fema denied allegations by Prepa that it had reviewed the deal. The contract states that "Prepa hereby represents and warrants that Fema has reviewed and approved of this Contract." In a statement on Thursday, Fema stated, "Any language in any contract between Prepa and Whitefish that states Fema approved that contract is inaccurate."

Fema also expressed "significant concerns" with how Prepa procured the contract and had "not confirmed whether the contract prices [were] reasonable." It is unclear what will happen to any outstanding costs.

Initially, Puerto Rican authorities stated that Fema would pay for the deal. They later said there was "nothing illegal" about the contract. Prepa and the Puerto Rican government are burdened with massive debts, with the power authority declaring bankruptcy in July.

The US House of Representatives Natural Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over the Caribbean island, is also scrutinizing the contract. On Friday, top Democrats from that panel and the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee sent a letter asking the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general to launch an investigation. The correspondence follows similar requests from other members of Congress to the interior department's inspector general.

Walt Green, a former director of the US National Center for Disaster Fraud, told ███ earlier this week that it was "impossible" to say at this stage who was responsible for costs. "Any dispute may result in appeals, administrative hearings, and lawsuits," he added.

Title: Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer to Deliver Democratic Response to State of the Union Address

Article:

Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer will deliver the Democratic response to President Donald Trump's State of the Union address on Tuesday night. The 48-year-old former prosecutor, who made history as the first female leader of the Democratic caucus in the Michigan Senate, was elected governor in 2018 after defeating GOP nominee Bill Schuette.

In 2016, Michigan, a battleground state, helped secure Trump's election victory over Hillary Clinton. During the January primary debate, Democratic presidential hopeful Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) referenced Whitmer as a female candidate who had proven her ability to win against male competitors in various races across the country.

Whitmer's election campaign focused on expanding healthcare and addressing "dinner-table issues," which she described as the core of the Democratic Party's strength. In an interview with the Associated Press after her State of the Union announcement, Whitmer stated that voters in her state are more concerned with "fundamentals," such as fixing deteriorating roads and offering job training for better-paying positions, rather than Trump's tweets.

Upon announcing Whitmer as the Democratic choice for the rebuttal, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) praised her, stating, "Whether it's pledging to 'Fix the Damn Roads' or investing in climate solutions, Governor Whitmer's vision for the future is exactly what this country needs, and I'm thrilled she is giving the Democratic response."

Whitmer will deliver her response immediately following Trump's State of the Union address, which is scheduled for 9 p.m. ET on February 4.

Title: "Judge Napolitano: The Patriot Act and the Threat to Fourth Amendment Rights"

Article:

In an analysis piece, Judge Andrew P. Napolitano, Fox News' senior judicial analyst, discusses the dangers to personal liberty posed by the USA PATRIOT Act, particularly sections 505 and 215, which he argues are weapons of mass surveillance and violate the Fourth Amendment.

The article traces the historical context of the Patriot Act, highlighting its enactment in 2001, following the September 11 attacks, and the lack of thorough debate in Congress. Napolitano points out that these sections of the Act permit federal agents to bypass the requirements of the Fourth Amendment and issue their own search warrants, as well as allow designated federal judges to issue general warrants based on the old writs of assistance standard of governmental need.

Since 2001, federal agents have reportedly issued over 300,000 of these search warrants, known as National Security Letters, to various entities, including financial institutions, telecom providers, and local and state governments. Napolitano argues that this concept of one federal agent authorizing another to seize records is antithetical to the Fourth Amendment and repugnant to the American Revolution.

The article also discusses the expiration of section 215 on March 15 and the potential for structural changes to the Patriot Act by congressional liberals, libertarians, and some conservatives. Section 215, which allows judges to issue general warrants based on the writs of assistance standard, has been criticized for its potential to infringe on privacy rights, as demonstrated by the secret court-ordered seizure of Verizon customers' telephone records in 2013.

Judge Napolitano concludes that both sections 215 and 505 are threats to freedom and should be repealed, as they defy the Constitution and presume that personal rights are not inherent but granted by the government, which can take them back. The article ends with a call to action, encouraging readers to learn more about Judge Napolitano's reports on the subject.

Title: FBI Unable to Arrest Mysterious Maltese Professor Due to Lack of Evidence, Court Filing Suggests

Article:

According to a court filing by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, FBI agents considered arresting Joseph Mifsud, a Maltese professor, during the Russia probe, but he left the United States before they had gathered sufficient evidence. The court filing states that the FBI located Mifsud in Washington D.C., but did not have enough information to detain him due to misleading information provided by George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign volunteer who pled guilty to lying about Mifsud during the initial FBI interview in January 2017.

Papadopoulos is scheduled to be sentenced on September 7, and the court filing recommends a prison sentence of zero to six months. The special counsel noted that a similar case resulted in a 30-day sentence.

In the spring of 2016, while working at a think tank in London, Papadopoulos met with Mifsud, a professor who teaches in Malta and circulates among think tanks in Europe, including Russia. At that time, the public was unaware that Russia had hacked and stolen thousands of emails from the Democratic Party, which would later be released through WikiLeaks.

During their meeting, Mifsud told Papadopoulos that the Kremlin possessed "thousands" of Clinton emails, but the exact meaning of this statement remains unclear. Papadopoulos later lied about the meeting's timing, stating it occurred in February before he joined the campaign, instead of the actual April date.

"Rather than acknowledging these contacts and communications, the defendant concealed them from the FBI. He lied about their timing, extent, and nature," Mueller said in the court filing. The lies, the filing states, impeded the FBI's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

Papadopoulos' self-appointed mission in London was to set up a meeting between then-candidate Trump and the Kremlin. He asked Mifsud for contacts and spoke to a Russian woman with ties to the Foreign Ministry, but no such meeting occurred. Papadopoulos has not been charged with any collusion.

Title: Twitter Introduces Notice for Politicians' Rule-Violating Tweets in Public Interest

Article:

Twitter has announced changes to its policy regarding tweets from politicians and government leaders that violate its rules but are deemed in the public interest. The social media platform will now place a notice over such tweets, requiring users to click or tap on the warning to view the content.

In a tweet, Twitter's safety team stated, "Sometimes, we decide that it may be in the public's interest for certain Tweets to remain on Twitter, even if they would otherwise break our rules." The company further explained, "We're going to start using a new notice to make it clear when we make these decisions."

The new policy will apply to verified government officials, political candidates, and individuals being considered for a government position who have more than 100,000 followers. Before viewing the tweet, users will see a notice that says, "The Twitter Rules about abusive behavior apply to this Tweet. However, Twitter has determined it may be in the public's interest for the Tweet to remain available."

This change is part of Twitter's recent efforts to combat harassment and abuse on its site. The company has previously argued against removing problematic tweets from world leaders, including President Donald Trump, due to their public interest.

President Trump, a prolific Twitter user, has on multiple occasions accused social media companies of being biased against conservatives. Social media companies, for their part, have apologized for how they've handled some conservative content but deny any bias and say they do not censor political views. As of this writing, Trump has not tweeted about Twitter's latest move.

In addition to the notice, tweets that break Twitter's rules will appear less prominently on the site and will not show up in places like safe search or the Explore tab. The notice will not be applied to any tweets sent before Thursday.

A team including regional members will decide when to use the notice and consider factors such as the potential harm from the rule violation, whether preserving the tweet will allow people to hold politicians accountable, and other factors.

The White House did not respond to a request for comment.

This development comes as senators grill Twitter and Facebook over alleged political bias.

Updates:
- June 28: Adds more details on Twitter's notice.
- Adds more background.

Title: Trump's Standoff with Democrats Over Border Wall Funding

Article:

President Donald Trump has reiterated his commitment to securing funding for the U.S.-Mexico border wall, potentially leading to a partial government shutdown if a deal cannot be reached by December 21. The ongoing standoff between the President and the Democrats has been a recurring theme since the previous budget impasse in 2018, which resulted in a $1.3 trillion Omnibus spending bill that did not include funding for the border wall.

In March, President Trump vowed never to sign such a bill again and called for a line-item veto for all government spending bills. In July, he pledged to fix the country's immigration system, even if it requires a government shutdown.

During the last budget impasse, President Trump offered a surprisingly generous deal to congressional Democrats, agreeing to grant legal status to nearly a million DACA recipients in exchange for border wall funding. However, the Democrats rejected the offer, despite the $5 billion requested for the wall accounting for less than 0.004 percent of the amount ultimately appropriated.

With a potential partial government shutdown looming, President Trump now has an opportunity to secure border wall funding, a priority he has pursued since the beginning of his presidency. Senate Democrats have stated they will not accept more than $1.6 billion for border security, and they are threatening to withhold funding from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) if the President does not capitulate.

However, a partial shutdown would not affect most federal employees, as about two-thirds of the federal government is already funded through a budget deal reached earlier in the year. In the event of a DHS funding lapse, Border Patrol and ICE agents would still be required to report for work, although they would not receive paychecks until a funding deal could be reached. History shows that Congress has always appropriated back pay for employees affected by previous shutdowns.

The Democrats are portraying a potential shutdown as a national catastrophe, but this is largely fearmongering intended to manipulate the public and the press. President Trump, aware of the essential nature of a border wall to national security, is unlikely to give up on this priority due to political expediency.

Title: Top Democrats Criticized for Statements Perceived as Criticizing America

Article:

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, a potential 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, found himself in a national controversy this week after stating that America "was never that great." The remark, made during a bill signing, has sparked criticism from both sides of the political spectrum.

Cuomo's statement was followed by a series of tweets from President Trump, who called it a "career-threatening statement" and predicted that "his political career is over." Cuomo has since walked back the statement, claiming it was "inartful."

The remark is the latest in a series of bolder statements from Democrats calling out what they see as injustices or inequalities in America. The Republican National Committee (RNC) has seized on these statements, with the RNC stating in an email blast that "the only thing that seems to unite prominent Democrats these days is their collective bashing of America."

In a similar vein, 2016 Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton was criticized for her statement that half of Trump supporters could be put into "a basket of deplorables." The remark was widely perceived to have hurt her campaign, and many Trump supporters now wear the "deplorable" tag as a badge of honor.

Other possible 2020 candidates have also made statements that appear to take a swing at America or large numbers of people in it. Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) described things as "savagely wrong" in America and claimed there is a "normalcy of injustice." Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) stated that America's economic inequality is "fundamentally immoral." Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) described America's criminal justice system as racist "front to back."

The RNC has used these statements to argue that Democrats are out of touch, and it would appear that there isn't much support from the public for such statements. A 2016 Washington Post poll found that only seven percent of those polled said that America has never been great.

Title: Grassroots Effort in Des Moines Pushes for Elizabeth Warren's Presidential Bid

Article:

A grassroots campaign encouraging Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren to run for the Democratic presidential nomination is gaining momentum in Des Moines, Iowa. The campaign's headquarters is located in a small office park, marked only by a yard sign on a door.

On a recent weekday afternoon, approximately 20 volunteers gathered to strategize on how to persuade their friends, neighbors, and, most importantly, Senator Warren, to join the race.

Gordon Rowe, a retiree, shared his experience when discussing Warren with others, stating, "They don't know who Elizabeth Warren is. I tell them they need to get involved. They are middle class too, and they need representation."

The term "middle class" is frequently repeated among Warren supporters. They believe Warren understands, represents, and will help rebuild the middle class. The conviction that Warren is fighting for them on issues such as income inequality and regulating Wall Street is the driving force behind the effort to draft her into the race, despite her repeated dismissals of a potential run.

Blair Lawton, Iowa Field Director for the Run Warren Run campaign, stated, "We totally take Senator Warren at her word right now. We know that right now she's not running, and if she was, we wouldn't have a reason for a draft campaign like this. Really, me and my staff's goal every day is to show her that she has support all across the state and a path to victory."

The campaign's activities include holding meetings to teach volunteers grassroots political techniques, setting up phone banks to call Iowa Democrats, and having Run Warren Run representatives attend small Democratic meetings across the state.

Beth Farvour, a Run Warren Run regional field director, attended a meeting in Tipton, addressing the 40 or so Cedar County Democrats to explain why she thinks Warren is the best candidate for the Democratic nomination. The campaign is being funded by MoveOn.org, which has pledged to spend $1 million on the effort, and Democracy for America, which has contributed an additional $250,000.

In Iowa, the campaign has eight staff members who travel the state promoting her candidacy. Run Warren Run also has staffers in New Hampshire.

At this time, Warren's supporters, almost to a person, decline to address the possibility that Warren may stand by her word and not run for the White House.

Katie Freerksen, a veterinarian technician who started volunteering three months ago, expressed optimism, stating, "I think we can get her in the race."

Toria Pinter, a law student on medical leave, was drawn to Warren because of the senator's vocal call to lower the interest rates on student loans. Pinter emphasized that the campaign is not an anti-Clinton effort but a pro-Warren movement.

"The campaign is not about Clinton," she said. "That's not what we are here to talk about. We are here to talk about Warren and how important she is to us because she embodies the ideals and issues that are important to us at the end of the day."

Lawton stated that even if Warren decides not to run, he believes there are long-term benefits from this campaign, including "putting a big investment into the progressive community."

"I am confident every day if we do our job we get her to enter this race," he said. "But also, you know, other goals, as well, on top of getting her to run: I want to make sure every time a campaign comes in we are leaving the community in a better place. So really what we are doing right now, by getting volunteers involved and training them, we are really helping to build the progressive movement across the state of Iowa."

Title: Obama Administration's Iran Nuclear Deal May Lack Written Agreement by March Deadline

Article:

The ongoing negotiations between the Obama administration and Iran over the latter's nuclear weapons program may result in a handshake agreement rather than a written accord by the self-imposed March deadline. This development, according to Western diplomats involved in the talks, is due to Iran's increasing resistance to a formal "framework" agreement at this stage, preferring a more general "understanding" followed by a final accord in June.

White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest has consistently downplayed the significance of the March deadline, stating that what is anticipated at the end of March is a "political agreement." This political agreement, according to Earnest, would include specific commitments from Iran regarding its nuclear program and the operation of its facilities, as well as commitments to agree to historically intrusive inspections.

However, the technical experts would then need to discuss the implementation of these political agreements, with the Obama administration anticipating that these technical negotiations would be resolved by the end of June. This means that whatever the Obama administration announces in the coming days will not be a real, binding written agreement but rather a "political" document for domestic consumption in the United States.

Furthermore, the Khamenei regime does not acknowledge the existence of the March deadline, according to a senior administration official who was in Lausanne for the talks last week. The Obama administration had initially hoped to agree on specific limits by the end of March that would define the parameters of a more detailed, comprehensive agreement to be completed by the end of June. However, Ayatollah Khamenei, who has taken his own negotiators by surprise several times, stated that there would be only one agreement, leaving the United States and its allies in an uncomfortable position.

The March deadline, it seems, is intended to provide President Obama with an opportunity to declare victory in "ending" Iran's nuclear program before any actual deal is made. This allows the liberal media to heap praise on Obama and accuse anyone questioning the deal of wanting war with Iran. By the time the actual agreement is signed in June, Obama's legacy will be far too tied up in its "success" for any Democrat, even Hillary Clinton, to oppose it.

Title: GOP Shifts Focus from Policy to Politics as Immigration Reform Stalls

Article:

The Republican Party's political strategy for the upcoming midterm elections appears to be centered on a bet that the Affordable Care Act will negatively impact Democrats, as comprehensive immigration reform and other significant legislative initiatives have been put on hold until after the elections.

According to conservative reporters, including The Washington Post's Robert Costa, bipartisan deals on immigration reform, tax reform, and adjustments to the federal health-care law are unlikely to progress in the current Congress. Representative Devin Nunes (Calif.) stated, "We can do a few things on immigration and work on our principles, but in terms of real legislating, we’re unable to get in a good negotiating position."

Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster who works closely with party leaders, added, "It is an acknowledgment of where they stand, where nothing can happen in divided government so we may essentially have the status quo. Significant immigration reform and fundamental tax reform are probably not going to happen."

While legislative activity slowing down ahead of an election is not unusual, the early transition from policymaking to politicking by one party, particularly when the other party is actively advancing a positive and popular agenda, is noteworthy. The Senate has already passed comprehensive, bipartisan immigration reform and the Employment Non-Discrimination Act. If Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid uses the Senate to pass or force Republicans to filibuster additional bills, such as renewing emergency unemployment compensation, a Voting Rights Act patch, an equal pay bill, a minimum wage bill, and so on, it may appear awkward if the House has little to offer in return.

Health care might be the exception, as House Majority Leader Eric Cantor has expressed a commitment to passing an Affordable Care Act alternative this year. However, past experience suggests this intention may fizzle, leaving Republicans with full repeal—a political loser—as their official health care reform platform going into the midterms.

The electoral map, with Senate Democrats defending seats won in 2008 and the House in a midterm three years after they gerrymandered themselves a durable majority, may also contribute to inertia by making the GOP's strategy unfalsifiable. Even a bad GOP strategy will likely yield significant gains in the Senate and the retention of the House. If Republicans manage to flip the Senate, it will not matter whether it was a consequence of boring fundamentals rather than a wise political strategy. They will treat it as a vindication of anti-ACA absolutism anyway.

It is unusual for a party to put all their chips in one basket like this, so early in the cycle. This article aims to highlight this shift in strategy and its potential implications for the upcoming midterm elections.

Title: Supreme Court to Consider Trump Administration's Contraceptive Coverage Accommodation Policy

Article:

The left is urging the Supreme Court to overturn the Trump administration's accommodation policy regarding contraceptive coverage, which is a shift from the Obama administration's policy. The Obama administration's policy offered a workaround that pushed the cost of contraceptive care onto insurers and plan administrators, meaning that employers who objected to the coverage wouldn't have to pay for it but their employees would still be covered automatically.

The Trump administration's policy, which is currently under review, aims to allow employers with religious objections to opt out of providing contraceptive coverage. The heart of the case is whether the contraceptive mandate and the Obama administration's workaround impose a substantial burden on the religious beliefs of employers. However, if employers aren't providing the contraceptive coverage, there is no burden on them.

Under the Obama administration's compromise, objecting organizations were required to simply inform the federal government that they objected. The government would then work with the objectors' health insurers to offer cost-free contraception directly to their employees. Beyond giving notice, the objectors would have suffered no further involvement and paid nothing for any contraceptive care their employees received.

Critics of the mandate argue that the mere act of giving notice would be intolerable, and that nothing short of offering full exemptions to practically any employer that wants one will do. They argue that federal law demands special care for the concerns of the faithful in striking a balance between religious liberty and governmental interests. The Obama administration accommodated all sides in good faith, and the court is being asked to respect this principled balance.

Every member of the Supreme Court's conservative majority has, in the past, expressed sympathy for religious objectors seeking exemptions from a generally applicable law. However, each has also expressed a desire to limit federal agencies' discretion to make policy. In the two Pennsylvania cases currently under review, several of the Court's conservative justices appeared to realize that these two goals are in tension.

The cases primarily ask whether the Trump administration has the power to give religious objectors a sweeping exemption, regardless of whether such an exemption is required by law. At least three of the Court's conservative justices, Justices Clarence Thomas, Neil Gorsuch, and Brett Kavanaugh, expressed concerns that the Trump administration may not have this power. In a 2019 opinion, Gorsuch proposed revising the largely defunct 'nondelegation doctrine', a constitutional doctrine briefly used in the 1930s to restrict Congress's power to delegate authority to the Roosevelt administration. While Gorsuch's opinion in that 2019 case, Gundy v. United States, is vague, it suggests the possibility of a cross-partisan coalition to strike down the broad exemption.

Title: Fact-Checking President Trump's NATO Defense Spending Claims

Article:

President Donald Trump reiterated his claims about NATO's European allies' defense spending during a breakfast meeting in Brussels on Thursday. According to NPR national security correspondent David Welna, Trump stated that many countries owe the U.S. a significant amount of money due to past unpaid bills. However, this claim is not accurate, as NATO is not like a club with annual membership fees, and there is no ledger that maintains accounts of what countries pay and owe.

NATO members did make a commitment four years ago to spend at least 2 percent of their GDP on defense by 2024. As of this year, only nine of the military alliance's 29 members are expected to reach that mark. Trump singled out Germany, the biggest economic power in NATO after the U.S., stating that Germany is only paying 1.25 percent of its GDP to defense, while the U.S. is spending 4.2 percent. This is partially true, as Germany indeed devotes only about 1.25 percent of its GDP to defense, but it has boosted defense spending the past two years.

Trump also stated that the U.S. is spending 4.2 percent of GDP, but this is at odds with the Pentagon, which puts it at 3.3 percent. American University NATO scholar Garret Martin notes that the U.S. defense needs vastly surpass those of its European allies, as the U.S. is a global military power with global military commitments, while most European members of the alliance do not have the same level of global responsibilities.

Last week at a rally in Montana, Trump made another claim about NATO funding, stating that the U.S. is paying for 70 to 90 percent to protect Europe. However, this claim is also inaccurate, as the U.S. pays 22 percent of a common budget that all NATO allies pay into, which is approximately $2.8 billion.

Trump also sought to take credit for NATO allies spending more, stating that commitments have been made for over $40 billion dollars since the last meeting. While this is close to the truth, NATO reported yesterday that spending by European members has increased by $35 billion. American University's Martin notes that the higher spending continues a trend that predates Trump.

NATO General Secretary Jens Stoltenberg pointed out that despite Trump's complaints about the U.S. spending too much, it is actually spending more than before. He stated that U.S. funding for military presence in Europe, the European Deterrence Initiative, has been increased by 40 percent. This spending was approved by Congress, where the Senate last night and the House today overwhelmingly approved resolutions backing NATO.

Title: Trump and Pence Take Victory Lap for Carrier Job Retention Deal

Article:

Donald Trump and Mike Pence will hold a rally in Indianapolis on Thursday to celebrate a deal with Carrier, a U.S. manufacturing company, to keep nearly 1,000 jobs in the United States instead of moving them to Mexico. The transition team of President-elect Trump claims the deal demonstrates Trump's commitment to protecting U.S. jobs and workers.

Kellyanne Conway, Trump's former campaign manager and top adviser, described the Carrier deal as a successful negotiation led by Trump that could be replicated once he takes office. Few details have been disclosed about the terms of the agreement, but it is believed that Carrier will keep about 850 jobs in Indiana and receive tax incentives from the state government.

Carrier, which is owned by United Technologies, a larger company based in Connecticut with contracts with the U.S. government, issued a statement on Wednesday, stating that incentives offered by Indiana were "an important consideration" in its decision, but providing no further details.

The White House downplayed the news, stating that President Obama's policies had created more than 800,000 manufacturing jobs. However, Trump's team argues that the Carrier deal shows Trump can create a business-friendly climate that will stimulate economic growth at a faster pace than during the Obama years.

John Feehery, a Trump supporter, Republican strategist, and columnist, praised Trump's use of the bully pulpit to keep American jobs in the U.S. Alice Stewart, a Republican strategist, said it was smart of Trump to demonstrate early that he can negotiate policies that will benefit the U.S. economy.

Fiscally conservative groups have yet to comment on the deal, but if Trump and Pence have offered any special concessions to Carrier, these groups may criticize the deal as corporate welfare. Brent Gardner, chief government affairs officer at Americans for Prosperity, stated that the particulars of the agreement have not been released, but the group's position on corporate welfare remains unchanged.

The deal has sparked debate over the use of incentives to keep U.S. companies from moving jobs overseas. Trump has argued against using incentives like low-interest loans and tax cuts to entice U.S. firms to stay put. However, some economists worry that Trump's willingness to negotiate one-on-one with companies could lead to other CEOs threatening to leave the country in exchange for better deals.

House Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) stated that he had no issues with Trump personally getting involved to prevent the outsourcing of jobs. Jordan said, "My attitude is, if the president of the United States thinks it's in the best interest in the country, that's good that he's standing up and encouraging business to stay here and keep jobs here in the United States."

Title: Marco Rubio: A Seabiscuit in the 2016 Republican Presidential Race

Article:

In the 2016 Republican presidential race, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is positioning himself as a candidate with a compelling personal story, much like President Barack Obama eight years ago. Both men are young, first-term senators with eloquent speaking abilities and a desire to lead the United States.

Rubio, like Obama, is in a competitive race, and despite a stumble in the recent New Hampshire debate, he remains in a comfortable position behind the leaders, ready to make his move. As America seeks renewed hope and a sense of identity, Rubio's optimistic outlook and aspirations for a better future could propel him to the White House.

The current political climate is reminiscent of eight years ago, with a sense of anger in the campaigns of Ted Cruz, Donald Trump, and Bernie Sanders. However, beneath the surface, there is an undercurrent of optimism for a leader who will represent the dignity, decorum, and exceptional qualities of the United States.

Marco Rubio has a personal connection to the American people, particularly those of Cuban descent, given his roots in Miami. His parents' struggle and his rags-to-riches story should inspire all ethnic groups, not just Latinos, much like President Obama's story did eight years ago.

Rubio is currently in third place, but the leaders, Cruz and Trump, are within his sights. To win the Republican nomination, Rubio could finish third in Iowa, second in New Hampshire, and first in South Carolina, maintaining his momentum all the way to the national convention. If his performance in the New Hampshire debate lands him lower than second, he has ample time to regain his stride and overtake the leaders.

Rubio has been articulate in addressing issues like immigration, healthcare, and national security, and he has provided more substantive details on his website than any of his opponents. Cruz has criticized Rubio for his involvement with the "Gang of Eight," but seeking bipartisan support to solve problems is a trait of a great president, and Rubio should use that to his advantage.

Marco Rubio is a compassionate, brilliant, articulate, focused leader who can rally America to a new era. Now is his time to sharpen his focus, take the lead at the end of the first turn, pace himself in the backstretch, and leave the others in his dust as he sprints to the finish line.

Title: U.S. and Allies Extend Nuclear Talks with Iran for Seven Months

Article:

The United States and its allies have extended nuclear negotiations with Iran for seven months, aiming to reach a comprehensive agreement that limits Iran's ability to produce nuclear weapons. The extension was announced on Monday following a yearlong effort that failed to reach a deal. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and other Western foreign ministers, who gathered in Vienna for a last-ditch diplomatic push, described the extension as the best way forward.

The new deadline is set for March 1, with a final agreement to follow four months later. The extension aims to address remaining issues, such as the number and type of centrifuges Iran should be allowed to operate, as well as the duration of constraints on Iran's nuclear program.

Critics in the U.S. Congress have expressed concern that Iran is using the negotiations to buy time, with the new Republican-controlled Congress threatening to impose additional sanctions on Iran. Members of the new Congress have already suggested they may have enough votes to overturn an expected veto by President Barack Obama.

Iran's nuclear program remains frozen but intact, without any of the cuts sought by the U.S. During the negotiations, Iran continues to receive monthly payments of $700 million in frozen funds that began under the temporary nuclear deal agreed upon last year.

British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond stated that the sides are giving themselves until March to agree on a text "that sets out in layman's language what we have agreed to do." Experts will then have four months to "translate that into precise definitions of what will happen on the ground."

Negotiators from both sides remain optimistic, with U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry praising his Iranian counterpart, Mohammad Javad Zarif, for his diligent and good-faith approach to the negotiations. Kerry expressed hope that the extension would allow the talks to proceed without sending messages that might be misinterpreted.

In Tehran, hard-liners may increase pressure on Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to break off talks. However, the latest extension appears to have the approval of Khamenei, the ultimate arbiter in Iran. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, who has struggled to sell the idea of negotiating with the U.S. to hard-liners at home, pledged "ultimate victory" for the Islamic Republic in securing a favorable agreement.

The extension was met with frustration by some Iranian residents, despite Rouhani's positive spin. High school teacher Abbas Hoseini expressed concern that the West is pushing Iran toward Russia and China.

Title: Gantz and Lieberman Agree to Collaborate, Threatening Netanyahu's Chances of Forming a Government

Article:

Israeli opposition leader Benny Gantz, head of the Blue and White Party, announced on Monday that he had agreed to work with Avigdor Lieberman, leader of the small Yisrael Beiteinu party, to form a new government following national elections last week. This development represents a new setback for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as he grapples with maintaining power before his upcoming corruption trial.

In a statement, Gantz reported that he had a productive meeting with Lieberman, stating, "We discussed questions of fundamental principle and determined that we will work together to assemble a government that will pull Israel out of the political deadlock and avert a fourth round of elections."

In last week's election, Israel's third in less than a year, Netanyahu's Likud party emerged as the largest party. However, with his smaller religious and nationalist allies, he secured only 58 seats in parliament, three short of the required 61-seat majority needed to form a new government. Netanyahu's opponents, led by Gantz, control a majority of seats. Yet, beyond their shared animosity towards Netanyahu, there are deep divisions between these parties, which include Lieberman's secular, ultra-nationalist party and the Arab-led Joint List.

Gantz's announcement with Lieberman marks a step towards unifying the anti-Netanyahu forces, though it remains unclear whether they can reach a final agreement, much less a deal with Arab politicians. Lieberman, in the past, has branded Arab political leaders as "terrorist" sympathizers.

"We'll continue to discuss the details, formulate our common objectives, and move forward," Gantz said.

Netanyahu is determined to remain as prime minister as he prepares to go on trial on March 17. He has been charged with fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes in connection to a series of scandals that include accepting expensive gifts from wealthy friends and offering to exchange favors with powerful media moguls. Netanyahu's lawyers requested a delay in the start of the trial, saying they need more time to review evidence. Prosecutors on Monday said they oppose any delays.

Israel's president, Reuven Rivlin, must decide by next week who to choose as the prime minister-designate. The president typically chooses the candidate he deems has the best chance of forming a governing coalition. Netanyahu has defiantly insisted he won last week's election and accused his opponents of trying to "steal the elections" by aligning with Arab-led parties he claimed were hostile to the state. "I promise you, I am not going anywhere," Netanyahu said over the weekend.

Title: Obama Defends Use of Drones, Airstrikes in Counter-Terror Operations

Article:

President Obama on Friday defended the regular use of drones and airstrikes by his administration to target terror leaders or training camps in Somalia, Libya, and Yemen. He acknowledged that in the past, such strikes may have inadvertently resulted in civilian casualties, but stated that the procedures for approving such strikes have improved.

"There has been legitimate criticism that the legal architecture around the use of drone strikes or other kinetic strikes wasn't as precise as it should have been, and there's no doubt that civilians were killed that shouldn't have been," Obama said at a press conference following the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington. He added, "What I can say with great confidence is that our operating procedures are as rigorous as they have ever been, and that there is a constant evaluation of precisely what we do."

Obama's remarks came after the U.S. military announced on Friday that it had conducted an airstrike the previous day targeting a senior terrorist leader in Somalia, Hassan Ali Dhoore, an operational commander of al-Shabab, an al-Qaeda-linked terror group. The Pentagon stated that Dhoore was involved in planning a number of attacks, including some that resulted in the deaths of three Americans.

The Pentagon said officials were still assessing the results of the operation to determine if Dhoore was killed in the strike, but noted that his death would be a "significant blow" to the terror group's operations and ability to conduct attacks. Dhoore was reportedly involved in the Dec. 25, 2014, attack on Mogadishu International Airport that killed several African Union personnel and a U.S. citizen, and the March 27, 2015, attack on the Maka al-Mukarram Hotel in Mogadishu that killed 15 people.

Last month, the Pentagon launched a strike that killed up to 150 militants at a terrorist training camp in Somalia.

Title: NBC News Anchor Brian Williams Admits to Fabricating War Story

Article:

In a recent admission, NBC News anchor Brian Williams has confessed to peddling a fabricated war story about himself, joining a list of notable figures who have embellished their war experiences. The story in question involves Williams' account of a helicopter incident during the 2003 invasion of Iraq.

Over the years, Williams has provided varying accounts of the event, with his most recent version claiming that his helicopter was hit and forced down by enemy fire. However, in light of being called out for his fabrication, Williams admitted that it was a different helicopter that was hit, not his own.

This is not an isolated incident, as other notable figures have also been caught embellishing their war stories. In 1983, former President Ronald Reagan claimed to have filmed Nazi death camps as a U.S. Army photographer, a story that was later proven false due to his own admission of never leaving the country during World War II.

During the 2008 campaign, then-Senator Joe Biden implied that he had experienced combat in Afghanistan, stating that his helicopter was "forced down" by enemy fire. However, it was later revealed that a snowstorm, not enemy fire, was responsible for the forced landing of Biden's helicopter.

Similarly, during the 2008 campaign, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton claimed that she and her group landed "under sniper fire" at an airstrip in Tuzla. This claim was later retracted, with Clinton stating that she had "misspoken."

Other politicians, such as Senators Richard Blumenthal, George W. Bush, and Tom Harkin, have also been called out for fabricating their military records.

The dishonest portrayal of military service by politicians is generally accepted, but the public expects higher truth standards from members of the press. Williams, while not a field reporter, is still considered a journalist, and millions rely on him for truthful reporting. The public trusts him as a truth-teller, not a fabulist.

The human tendency to embellish stories is universal, and it seems that some journalists find it impossible to resist. As they tell their personal stories, they tend to add dramatic pauses and incorporate reactions from previous audiences, escalating the drama and making up details to further engage their audiences.

Williams' fabrication of his war story is a breach of the journalistic commandment against embellishment. This is evident in the timeline of his changing stories, as his early tellings were accurate but lacked the dramatic elements that he later added.

The allure of a hero's status can be irresistible, according to scholar W. Joseph Campbell, who has written extensively on media myths. It is possible that Williams stretched his mundane helicopter story into an exhilarating but false one due to feelings of guilt about having gone to war in the company of well-protected generals.

Title: Indiana Governor Mike Pence Endorses Ted Cruz, Praises Donald Trump Ahead of Indiana Primary

Article:

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has announced his endorsement of Republican candidate Ted Cruz for the upcoming Indiana primary on Tuesday. In an interview on WIBC radio in Indianapolis, Pence praised Cruz as a "principled conservative" who has "stood up for taxpayers" in Washington and has shown "strong, unwavering stand" against abortion rights.

However, Pence also went out of his way to praise Republican front-runner Donald Trump, commending him for giving voice to people's frustrations and for taking a stand for Hoosier jobs. Pence emphasized that his endorsement was not intended to sway the votes of Indiana Republicans, stating, "I respect the right of every Hoosier in making their determination."

Pence began by acknowledging his respect for all three candidates, before commending Trump specifically. He expressed gratitude towards Trump for taking a stand for Hoosier jobs and for his voice in the national debate. Pence clarified that he was not against any candidate, but would be voting for Ted Cruz in the Republican primary. He also stated that he would work hard for whoever wins the Republican nomination in the fall.

Pence's endorsement is closely watched due to his potential re-election bid as a candidate this fall and his past speculation as a possible Republican presidential candidate. Cruz is hoping Pence's endorsement will give him a boost in the Hoosier State, where he is currently trailing Trump in recent surveys. Cruz was also helped by Scott Walker's endorsement in Wisconsin, which resulted in Cruz's only big-state primary victory in this campaign.

In Indiana, there are 57 delegates at stake on Tuesday. If Trump sweeps those delegates, his path to the nomination becomes clear and likely. Currently, he needs 42 percent of remaining delegates to win, which is achievable. If he wins all of Indiana's 57 delegates, that drops to 36 percent.

Title: GOP Candidates Engage in Policy Discussion at Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity

Article:

In a departure from the heated rhetoric and controversial statements that have characterized much of the 2016 Republican primary race, several GOP candidates gathered at the Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity in Columbia, South Carolina, for a five-hour discussion focused on policy proposals. The event, moderated by Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and South Carolina Republican Sen. Tim Scott, provided a stark contrast to the recent campaign trail events of front-runners Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, who did not attend the forum.

The forum, which was a welcome change for many candidates struggling to gain traction, featured a collegial back-and-forth discussion of policy proposals, including the earned income tax credit, charter-school education, and alleviating poverty. The event was a breath of fresh air, according to Ryan, who stated that it was a break for both the candidates and the press.

Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson shared the stage, with Ohio Gov. John Kasich boasting about his legislative background, claiming he was involved in writing the first set of welfare reform legislation.

Trump and Cruz's absence and the contrasting tone of the forum were particularly noticeable after the two poll leaders' recent headline-grabbing statements. The night before the GOP poverty event, Trump held a boisterous rally in Rock Hill, South Carolina, where he praised the capture of Mexican drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, had a Muslim woman who silently protested during the event kicked out, and rallied the crowd with exclamations about his plans to "knock the sh-- out of ISIS." Meanwhile, Cruz made headlines in Iowa when he likened spanking his daughter to the spanking Hillary Clinton could receive from voters.

Participants at the Kemp Forum, including Kasich and Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, praised Ryan and Scott's efforts to engage in a substantive conversation more in line with a wonky Washington think tank discussion than the rough-and-tumble presidential campaign. Graham, who sparred with Trump before dropping out of the race last month, noted the difference in tone compared to Trump's rallies, stating, "If you are real loud here, you are a jerk."

The forum was not without interruptions, as young immigration protesters disrupted the afternoon session with Kasich and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.). The protesters, who were quickly escorted out by police, targeted Rubio's position on the country's immigration laws. However, the candidates remained composed, with Rubio responding, "We're going to enforce our immigration laws, guys," and Kasich adding, "We heard it. Thank you very much."

The candidates largely remained in sync during the forum, with Bush, Christie, and Kasich discussing their policy positions on block grants, marriage, and creating a work-based competency system.
