Christie also spent several minutes discussing the details of the earned income tax credit and how increasing the refundable tax credit incentivized poor people to seek employment.

Overall, the Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity provided a unique opportunity for GOP candidates to engage in a substantive policy discussion, away from the heated rhetoric and controversial statements that have characterized much of the 2016 primary race.

Title: What Happens to Campaign Contributions When a Presidential Candidate Drops Out?

Article:

Washington Governor Jay Inslee and former Governor John Hickenlooper, both former presidential candidates, have recently dropped out of the race. As of June, both candidates raised nearly $8.5 million in campaign contributions from individual donors and Political Action Committees (PACs). The question arises as to what happens to these campaign contributions when a presidential candidate drops out of the race.

According to the Federal Election Committee (FEC), any excess campaign funds cannot be used for personal use. However, the world of campaign finance is complex, and the use of excess funds is not always straightforward.

If a campaign has outstanding debt or expenses, part of a donor's contribution might be used to pay these off. This could mean paying salaries for campaign staff or even moving expenses. If a campaign has no accrued debt, part of the donation might be used for the candidate's future campaigns or allocated to other candidates, political action committees, or charities at the candidate's choosing.

There is a grey area regarding the definition of "gifts." Candidates can use donations to purchase gifts, so long as they are not given to the candidate's family. The definition of a "gift" seems open-ended.

To ensure that donations are spent appropriately, one can research a campaign's spending throughout and after a presidential bid is over. "Once a campaign has ended, a candidate's committee must continue to file FEC reports until the committee is terminated," a spokesperson for the FEC said in an email. "So it's possible to track how the campaigns spend any residual funds they maintain."

To view these reports, visit the FEC database, search by a candidate's campaign name—which typically consists of their last name, followed by "For America" or "2020"—and scroll to the bottom of the page to find their expenses. For example, to find Inslee's campaign, search for "Inslee for America." To find Hickenlooper's campaign, search for "Hickenlooper 2020." You can search for any former presidential candidate's campaign from any other election, as well.

There are limits to these filings. For one, they are generally updated quarterly; if you donated to Inslee or Hickenlooper, you won't know how they're spending excess funds until September. Also, you'll have to do a lot of digging into candidates' expenses, and even then, you can't fully interpret a simple line item.

None of this should dissuade you from donating to a candidate of your choosing. In fact, it should provide incentive to vote for a candidate who promotes campaign finance reform, so that your future contributions are spent wisely.

Title: Republican Anxiety Over Romney's Campaign Grows as Election Nears

Article:

Anxiety among Republicans about the presidential race between Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama has spread beyond Washington, with concerns about Romney's campaign strategy and his own miscues affecting local candidates in tight races.

Republican strategists across the country have reported that their candidates are being questioned about Romney's remarks, creating a potential trap for those in challenging races.

Romney has attempted to turn the issue against Obama, labeling the president as an advocate of wealth redistribution and emphasizing, "My campaign is about the 100 percent of America." However, during a campaign stop in Florida on Thursday, Obama focused on Romney's "47 percent" comments.

"My thinking is maybe you haven't gotten around a lot," Obama said about Romney in an appearance at a Univision forum in Coral Gables.

There is a growing sense of frustration among Republicans that Romney has yet to take a commanding lead in any of the major battleground states, particularly North Carolina, which has the nation's fifth-worst unemployment rate, or Nevada, which has the highest jobless rate, 12 percent.

In Ohio, Florida, and Colorado, Republicans who support Romney's efforts have expressed concern that he is not campaigning enough in their states and that resources are not reaching vital counties.

"Could we use yard signs? Could we use information data?" said A.J. Matthews, a Republican State Committee member from Hillsborough County, Florida. "What would we most like from Governor Romney and Congressman Ryan? Visit us more."

In Ohio, some Republicans have expressed concern that Romney is not spending more money and appearing more frequently in rural counties where he needs a strong turnout to win the state—and where his "47 percent" comments threaten to undercut support among working-class voters otherwise inclined to vote for him. A bus trip by Romney next week may address some of these worries.

In Colorado, Dick Wadhams, a longtime Republican strategist and former state party chairman, said he hoped to see Romney campaign harder for swing voters in suburban Denver, and he was pleased the candidate was planning to visit the state on Sunday, the first time in seven weeks.

"They want to vote against Obama, but they haven't quite come to the point where they're going to vote for Romney," said Wadhams, speaking of swing voters.

Wadhams and other party leaders said, however, that they were heartened by Romney's get-out-the-vote operations. Republicans say Romney's on-the-ground efforts are far superior to those of Senator John McCain in 2008.

Officials at the Romney campaign said they believed some of the concern in the tossup states was being created by what they described as hyped media reporting on Romney's latest missteps. The campaign has been meticulously thought out, they said, and its supporters have yet to see activity that, by design, was not scheduled to begin until near the end of the race.

"We're making some very strategic decisions," said Rich Beeson, the political director. "And when we're coming down to the end, you'll see the governor everywhere he needs to be."

Romney has yet to take command of any battleground states, according to polls, many of which show Obama with an edge. The Romney campaign has been focusing on Iowa as one of its more promising states, but an NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist College poll released Thursday evening showed Obama with an 8-point advantage there.

In a stop near Des Moines, Ann Romney said it was time for Republicans to stop second-guessing her husband. "Stop it. This is hard," she told Radio Iowa. "You want to try it? Get in the ring."

The president and his aides are aware that everything could change in an instant, particularly with three presidential debates looming, and said Democrats could not be complacent.

But for the first time in many months, Mr. Obama's job approval rating has reached 50 percent in several recent polls. He has taken the edge away from Romney on questions of who voters believe will be a better steward of the economy, which coincides with the release of modestly positive economic signals.

Construction of new houses and home sales have reached their highest levels in more than two years, new reports show, and the Census Bureau reported that the number of young adults living at home with their parents—a vivid indicator of the personal effect of the recession on young people—is dropping.

Yet the president must still contend with his campaign promises made four years ago, including his pledge to change Washington. When asked about that on Thursday during the Univision forum, he said change must come from the "outside."

Speaking to supporters in Sarasota, Florida, Romney seized on the remark as an admission of failure, saying: "The president today threw in the white flag of surrender. He went from the president of change to the president who can't get change."

For all of the open fretting among Republicans, several party leaders say Romney still has an opportunity to win over voters who are ready to reject Obama.

"Romney has not made the sale yet with the 5 or 10 percent that are undecided, and he very well could," said Mike DeWine, Ohio's attorney general. "It's a very doable thing for Romney to win Ohio and very doable for him to win the race."

As Romney headed to an evening fund-raiser in West Palm Beach, Florida, a reporter asked if he would be campaigning more extensively.

"Ha, ha. We're in the stretch, aren't we?" Romney said before promptly changing the subject and pointing to the sky. "Look at those clouds. It's beautiful. Look at those things."

Title: North Korea Launches Missile Over Japan, Renewing Tensions in the Region

Article:

President Trump stated Tuesday that "all options are on the table" following North Korea's launch of a missile over Japan, an action that immediately escalated tensions in the region after the regime seemed to de-escalate its threats against the U.S. and its allies just days prior.

In a written statement released by the White House, Trump said, "The world has received North Korea’s latest message loud and clear: this regime has signaled its contempt for its neighbors, for all members of the United Nations, and for minimum standards of acceptable international behavior."

The statement continued, "Threatening and destabilizing actions only increase the North Korean regime’s isolation in the region and among all nations of the world. All options are on the table."

In a first, North Korea on Tuesday fired a midrange ballistic missile designed to carry a nuclear payload that flew over U.S. ally Japan and splashed into the northern Pacific Ocean. The distance and type of missile test seemed designed to show that North Korea can back up a threat to target the U.S. territory of Guam, if it chooses to do so, while also establishing a potentially dangerous precedent that could see future missiles flying over Japan.

The White House said that Trump spoke Monday with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe about the "grave" North Korean threat. "President Trump and Prime Minister Abe committed to increasing pressure on North Korea, and doing their utmost to convince the international community to do the same," the statement said.

Any new test worries Washington and its allies because it presumably puts the North a step closer toward its goal of an arsenal of nuclear missiles that can reliably target the United States. Tuesday's test, however, looks especially aggressive to Washington, Seoul, and Tokyo.

The Pentagon told reporters that it was investigating the launch over Japan, adding: "North American Aerospace Defense Command determined the missile launch from North Korea did not pose a threat to North America." U.S. officials said the Japanese military did not attempt to intercept the missile.

South Korea's air force responded to North Korea's missile launch over Japan by conducting a live-fire drill involving powerful bombs, officials said early Tuesday. Four F-15 fighters dropped eight MK-84 bombs that accurately hit targets at a military field near South Korea's eastern coast, Seoul's presidential spokesman Park Su-hyun said. Each bomb has an explosive yield of a ton, according to the country's air force.

Tuesday's launch comes days after the North fired what was assessed as three short-range ballistic missiles into the sea and a month after its second test of an intercontinental ballistic missile, which analysts say could reach deep into the U.S. mainland when perfected.

Trump responded earlier this month by threatening Kim Jong Un's regime with "fire and fury," touching off an escalating war of words. Kim eventually walked back threats to attack the U.S. territory of Guam, temporarily easing tensions -- until the latest round of provocations.

Title: White House Refuses to Comment on President's Involvement in Justice Department's National Security Leaks Investigation

Article:

As the U.S. Justice Department investigates recent high-level national security leaks from the White House, a top adviser to President Obama, David Plouffe, refused to confirm whether the president will answer investigators' questions during an appearance on Fox News Sunday. The investigation, led by two career attorneys at the Justice Department, is focused on determining who leaked classified national security information to a New York Times reporter, resulting in a series of recent stories.

The leaks included details of a top-secret "kill list," a list of targets for drone strikes assembled by the president's national security team, as well as information on a U.S. cyberattack on Iranian infrastructure and confirmation that American intelligence agencies had a mole inside al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

Some congressional Republicans and political pundits have speculated that the leaks were authorized by the White House to aid President Obama's re-election campaign by bringing his national security record back into the spotlight. However, the veracity of this theory remains unclear.

Sen. Joe Lieberman, Connecticut independent, expressed concern over the leaks, stating, "In my opinion, an enormous amount of damage has been done to our national security." He further noted that the disclosure of cyberwarfare against Iran could lead to a retaliatory strike.

Many on Capitol Hill, including Sen. Lieberman, believe the administration should appoint independent prosecutors to investigate the matter, rather than relying on investigators who report directly to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. The White House has thus far rejected these calls.

Despite being pressed on the question, Mr. Plouffe would not confirm whether the president would agree to one-on-one interviews with the two investigators, as former President George W. Bush did during the probe into the public disclosure of former CIA operative Valerie Plame's identity. During that scandal almost a decade ago, Mr. Bush also instructed his entire staff to come forward with any information they had about the source of the leak, which turned out to be State Department official Richard Armitage.

Sen. Lieberman and others are now urging the administration to follow the Bush administration's playbook. "I think the administration ought to do everything it can to eliminate any appearance that people in the administration leaked this highly classified information for political or other personal purposes," Mr. Lieberman said. "If I were advising [the president], I'd say he should sit down and talk to the investigators."

Title: Political Polarization in the United States: A Deepening Divide

Article:

A recent correspondence between a Democrat and a Republican within an extended family has shed light on the deepening political polarization in the United States. The Democrat, in expressing concerns about the upcoming political season, noted that the family, consisting of around 50 or 60 members, has only a few known Republicans, suggesting a significant political imbalance.

Evidence of this polarization can be found in various studies, such as the Pew Research Center's 2014 report based on interviews with 10,000 adults. The report reveals that the number of Americans expressing consistently conservative or liberal opinions has doubled over the past two decades, from 10 percent to 21 percent. The report also shows that ideological overlap has diminished, with 92 percent of Republicans being to the right of the median Democrat, and 94 percent of Democrats being to the left of the median Republican.

The report further indicates that many in the political center stay on the edges of the political process, while the most ideological make their voices heard. Two-thirds of consistent conservatives and half of liberals say most of their close friends share their political views. This finding, the report states, is "shocking."

The divide between the two major political parties is not a new phenomenon, and its causes remain unclear. Some suggest that partisan news media and the internet have contributed to this polarization. The divide, according to National Journal's Ron Brownstein, is a "durable standoff" between a diverse, younger, urbanized, more secular Democratic coalition and a predominantly white, older, non-urban, and more religious Republican coalition.

The consequences of this political polarization are far-reaching, with personal attacks becoming vicious and unrestrained, and legislators voting along party lines. The divide is not going away, and it is unclear how to start dealing with the problem.

In personal relationships, it is natural to seek reinforcement by getting together with those who think as we do, even though we make token exceptions to read a few columnists from the other side to stimulate different perspectives. However, the deepening political polarization in the United States raises concerns about the future of the nation's political discourse and the potential consequences of the next presidential term, particularly in relation to Supreme Court appointments.

Title: U.S. and China Intensify Trade War, Trump and Xi to Meet Amid Global Market Volatility

Article:

The trade war between the United States and China has escalated, with both countries imposing higher tariffs on each other's goods. U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Monday that he would meet Chinese President Xi Jinping next month at the G20 summit in Japan.

China announced earlier that it would impose tariffs on a range of U.S. goods, including frozen vegetables and liquefied natural gas. This move followed the U.S.'s decision last week to increase its own tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports.

The U.S. Trade Representative's office later stated that it planned to hold a public hearing next month on the possibility of imposing duties of up to 25% on a further $300 billion worth of imports from China. Cellphones and laptops would be included in this list, but pharmaceuticals would be excluded, the office said.

The prospect of a no-holds-barred dispute between the world's two largest economies has rattled investors, leading to a sharp selloff on equities markets in the past week. A gauge of global stocks shed a further 1.9% on Monday, its biggest one-day drop in more than five months. China's yuan currency fell to its lowest level since December, and oil futures slumped.

Trump said he would talk to Xi at the G20 summit and expressed optimism about the meeting, stating, "Maybe something will happen. We're going to be meeting, as you know, at the G20 in Japan and that'll be, I think, probably a very fruitful meeting."

Speaking at a White House dinner gathering later, Trump said it should be clear in "three or four weeks" if a U.S. trade delegation's trip to Beijing two weeks ago was successful. "I have a feeling it's going to be very successful," Trump said.

China's top diplomat, State Councilor Wang Yi, said during a trip to Russia that China-U.S. talks were not a "one-way street" and needed to be conducted on the basis of equality. "Both countries' negotiating teams have the ability and wisdom to resolve each other's reasonable demands, and in the end, reach a mutually beneficial, win-win agreement," he said.

The comment period on the planned new tranche of U.S. duties, which covers 3,805 product categories, is much shorter than in previous rounds and could potentially leave Trump in a position to trigger those tariffs by the time he meets Xi.

U.S. farmers are among those most affected by the trade war, with soybean sales to China plummeting, and U.S. soybean futures hitting their lowest level in a decade. Trump said on Monday his administration was planning to provide about $15 billion to help farmers whose products might be targeted.

Farmers, who are a core political constituency for Trump's Republicans heading into the 2020 presidential and congressional elections, are growing increasingly frustrated with the protracted trade talks and the failure to reach an agreement. "What that means for soybean growers is that we're losing," said Davie Stephens, president of the American Soybean Association, in a statement.

China also announced on Monday that it planned to set import tariffs ranging from 5% to 25% on 5,140 U.S. products on a $60 billion target list. These tariffs are set to take effect on June 1. China's finance ministry stated, "China's adjustment on additional tariffs is a response to U.S. unilateralism and protectionism."

In the middle of the negotiations last week, Trump increased tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25% from 10%. The move affected 5,700 categories of Chinese products, including internet modems and routers. Sources have said talks stalled after China tried to delete commitments from a draft agreement that its laws would be changed to enact new policies on issues from intellectual property protection to forced technology transfers.

Beijing stated on Monday that it would never surrender to external pressure. Its state media kept up a steady drumbeat of strongly worded commentary, reiterating that the door to talks was always open but vowing that China would defend its national interests and dignity. State television said in a commentary that the effect of the U.S. tariffs on the Chinese economy was "totally controllable."

Trump has said he is in no rush to finalize a deal with China. He again defended the move to hike U.S. tariffs and said there was no reason why American consumers would pay the costs. Economists and industry consultants, however, maintain that it is U.S. businesses that will pay the costs and likely pass them on to consumers.

U.S. tariffs last year triggered retaliation by China, which imposed 25% levies on $50 billion worth of U.S. products including soybeans, beef, and pork, and lower tariffs on a list of $60 billion in goods. Goldman Sachs economists said in a research note that new evidence showed the costs of Washington's tariffs on China last year had fallen entirely on U.S. businesses and households, with no clear reduction in prices charged by Chinese exporters. They said the effects of the tariffs had spilled over noticeably to the prices charged by U.S. producers competing with goods affected by the levies.

Title: Sen. Doug Jones Announces Vote to Convict President Trump on Both Articles of Impeachment

Article:

Sen. Doug Jones (D-Ala.), considered one of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats running in November, announced on Wednesday that he will vote to convict President Donald J. Trump on both articles of impeachment.

In a statement, Jones, who has been undecided on his voting decision for weeks, stated, "After many sleepless nights, I have reluctantly concluded that the evidence is sufficient to convict the President for both abuse of power and obstruction of Congress."

The Senate is set to vote on the two House-passed articles of impeachment: abuse of power over the delayed Ukraine aid and obstructing Congress's investigations into those actions. The votes are scheduled to take place on the same day as Jones's announcement.

Jones had previously expressed his indecision, telling reporters on Monday that he was "getting there" but still wanted to review notes and consult with colleagues. He sparked speculation last month that he could split his votes when he told USA Today that he had "concerns" about the House manager's second article of impeachment, which deals with alleged obstruction of Congress.

On Wednesday, Jones acknowledged that the second article "gave me even more pause," adding that he "struggled to understand" the House's strategy. However, after careful consideration of the evidence, the public disclosures, the legal precedents, and the trial, I believe the President deliberately and unconstitutionally obstructed Congress by refusing to cooperate with the investigation in any way," Jones said.

Jones also stated that Trump's actions "demonstrate a belief that he is above the law" and, if left unchecked, would risk guaranteeing that no future whistleblower or witness would ever come forward and no future President would be subject to Congressional oversight.

On the first article, abuse of power, Jones said he was "deeply troubled" by the arguments from Trump's legal team. "The President’s actions placed his personal interests well above the national interests and threatened the security of the United States, our allies in Europe, and our ally Ukraine. His actions were more than simply inappropriate. They were an abuse of power," Jones said.

Title: Biden's Claim of Lack of Oversight in Coronavirus Relief Effort Disputed

Article:

During a virtual rally in Wisconsin on Wednesday, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden claimed that President Trump was implementing the coronavirus relief effort with "no oversight, no IGs [Inspectors General], no accountability." However, several different methods of oversight for the coronavirus relief effort were created by the CARES Act.

The most significant oversight mechanism is the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee, established by Section 15010 of the CARES Act. The committee's responsibilities include auditing the economic relief funds to prevent waste and abuse and ensuring the money is efficiently distributed. The CARES Act outlines the membership of the committee, which includes the inspectors general of several departments, as well as the inspectors general of the Small Business Administration and Tax Administration.

The CARES Act also established the special inspector general for pandemic recovery, a position tasked with conducting audits and investigations of the making, purchase, management, and sale of loans, loan guarantees, and other investments made by the Secretary of the Treasury under any program established by the Secretary under the Act. The position is currently vacant, with President Trump having nominated his senior associate counsel, Brian Miller.

Furthermore, the CARES Act established the Congressional Oversight Commission, tasked with overseeing the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve's lending practices to create transparency about how the money is being used and determine the economic impact of the loans. The commission is made up of five members, with each party leader in the House and Senate appointing one member, and the leaders of each chamber picking a fifth member with consultation from the minority party leaders.

President Trump's meddling with the inspectors general on the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee and his choice for a special inspector general have earned him criticism. Additionally, he has stated he disagrees with elements of the CARES Act oversight provisions, issuing a statement detailing which sections he would ignore. However, it is inaccurate to claim, as Biden did, that there is "no oversight, no IGs [Inspectors General], no accountability" in the coronavirus economic relief effort. Biden's campaign did not respond to a request for comment.

Title: Bipartisan Immigration Bill Dismissed by White House as Non-Starter

Article:

The White House has dismissed a bipartisan immigration bill brokered by a group of lawmakers as a non-starter just hours before it is expected to be formally introduced in the Senate. The bill, to be introduced by Arizona Republican Sen. John McCain and Delaware Democratic Sen. Chris Coons on Monday, aims to grant eventual citizenship to young undocumented immigrants who have been in the country since 2013 and came to the US as children. However, it does not address all of President Trump's stated immigration priorities, such as ending family-based immigration categories or the diversity visa program.

The bill does not immediately authorize the $30 billion that Trump is seeking to build the border wall, instead greenlighting a study of border security needs. The bill also seeks to address the number of undocumented immigrants staying in the US by increasing the number of resources for the immigration courts, where cases can take years to finish.

The bill is a companion to a piece of House legislation that has 54 co-sponsors split evenly by party. A White House official rebuffed the effort, telling CNN that it takes "a lot of effort" to write up a bill worse than the Graham-Durbin immigration bill, but somehow "this one is worse."

Trump tweeted about the latest immigration efforts on Monday, writing, "Any deal on DACA that does not include STRONG border security and the desperately needed WALL is a total waste of time. March 5th is rapidly approaching and the Dems seem not to care about DACA. Make a deal!"

Delaware Democratic Sen. Chris Coons defended the bill in a conference call with reporters on Monday, calling it a "strong starting place" and a "fresh start" if other talks about immigration do not result in a compromise.

The White House has been aware of the legislation introduced by Texas Republican Rep. Will Hurd and California Democrat Rep. Pete Aguilar for weeks, with officials being informed while it was being drafted and with chief of staff John Kelly and legislative director Marc Short being briefed on the bill in meetings with members of Congress, including Hurd and Aguilar. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus, of which Aguilar is a key member, has been especially supportive of the bill as a compromise, as have moderate Republicans.

The bill would create a "smart wall" where the Department of Homeland Security would gain "operational control" of the border by the end of 2020 through "technology, physical barriers, levees, tools, and other devices." On family-based migration, the bill does not make explicit reference to sponsoring relatives, but the bill authors say that existing law would prohibit parents of these individuals who came to the US illegally to apply for a visa to come back without returning to their home country for at least 10 years before applying, and the bill does nothing to erase that requirement.

Sen. Coons said that Sen. McCain approached him about being a co-sponsor, saying that McCain is deeply concerned about the lack of future certainty for the military because of a budget impasse and the lack of a broader deal on immigration issues, and wanted to find a partner to introduce the Hurd-Aguilar bill in the Senate as part of that effort.

Sen. Coons also had some harsh words for the President, saying that despite the White House saying his proposal is the only one that can move forward, "I'm sorry, that's not how the Senate works." He rejected White House criticism of his proposal and said the "worst" thing would be failing to act or only doing a one-year stopgap.

Sen. McCain said in a statement the new bill has "broad support." The Senate is expected to turn to a floor debate on immigration soon, and Sen. Coons has been part of a group of bipartisan lawmakers that have been meeting for weeks to try to find a compromise that could pass the vote with more than the 60 votes needed to advance legislation, which would require members of both parties. Sen. McCain has been recuperating from cancer treatments but is a veteran of efforts to pass immigration reform.

"While reaching a deal can not come soon enough for America's service members, the current political reality demands bipartisan cooperation to address the impending expiration of the DACA program and secure the southern border," Sen. McCain said in the statement.

Title: 2016 U.S. Presidential Election Forecast: State-by-State Analysis and Key Factors

Article:

The 2016 U.S. Presidential Election is rapidly approaching, and the race between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump is tightening. Here's a breakdown of the latest forecasts, focusing on the Electoral College votes, state-by-state analysis, and key factors that could influence the outcome.

### How the Forecast has Changed

The forecasts will be updated daily until November 8, providing a clear picture of the candidates' chances of winning. The probability of a candidate's victory is determined by simulating the election 20,000 times, which produces a distribution of possible outcomes for each state.

### Who's Ahead in Each State and by How Much

The following table shows the expected margins of victory for each state, with the closer dot to the center line indicating a tighter race, and the wider bar indicating less certainty about the outcome.

| Pennsylvania           | 2.3% (Clinton)            |

### How Much Each State Matters

Two measures help capture how important a state and its voters will be in determining the next president: "Tipping-point chance" is the probability that a state will provide the decisive vote in the Electoral College. "Voter power index" is the relative likelihood that an individual voter in a state will determine the Electoral College winner.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Same-Sex Marriage Cases in Federal and California Challenges

Article:

The Supreme Court's decision last week to review two cases concerning same-sex marriage, Windsor v. United States and Hollingsworth v. Perry, has set the stage for a constitutional battle over the issue. The cases, which involve the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and California's Proposition 8, have both sides trying to interpret the court's decision and its implications for the legal battles ahead.

On Friday, the Supreme Court announced it will review Windsor v. United States, a case involving the 1996 federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), and Hollingsworth v. Perry, a challenge to Proposition 8, the California voter-passed measure that ended gay marriage in the state in 2008. Four of the nine justices had to agree for a case to be heard.

Gay rights activists expressed cautious confidence that they can win both cases. James Esseks, litigation director of the American Civil Liberties Union Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender & AIDS Project, said, "This is it — the Supreme Court marriage moment that the ACLU has been working towards for years. These cases are poised not just to take down DOMA and Prop 8, but to be the next building blocks for LGBT equality more broadly."

Traditional-values groups are also heartened that the marriage issue will finally be heard, noting that gay marriages are still not recognized in more than 80 percent of the states. John Eastman, chairman of the National Organization for Marriage, which opposes gay marriage, said, "Taking the case sends 'a strong signal that the justices are concerned with the rogue rulings that have come out of San Francisco, at both the trial court and appellate levels.' Had the Supreme Court agreed with [the rulings], it could have simply declined to accept the cases and let the decisions stand."

Supreme Court oral arguments are expected to be held in late winter or early spring, with decisions issued by summer. The high court proceedings are likely to take on new urgency given the activity in states such as Washington, where voters last month rejected an initiative to overturn the state's gay marriage law. Same-sex couples will also be able to marry in Maine on Dec. 29 and in Maryland on Jan. 1.

The federal case was brought by the ACLU and other lawyers on behalf of Edith Windsor, a New York woman who married her longtime companion, Thea Spyer, in Canada in 2007. When Ms. Spyer died a few years later, their marriage was not recognized by the federal government because of DOMA, and Ms. Windsor, now 83, was forced to pay nearly $370,000 in federal estate taxes.

The Proposition 8 case asks whether the U.S. Constitution prohibits the people of California from defining marriage as the union of one man and one woman in their state. The American Foundation for Equal Rights (AFER) sued to overturn Proposition 8 on behalf of two same-sex couples. "This case is about the fundamental constitutional right of all Americans to marry the person they love," said Theodore B. Olson, AFER's lead co-counsel with David Boies. The Supreme Court's decision to grant review in this case "illustrates the national significance of marriage equality, and brings us closer to the day when every American will be able to equally enjoy the fundamental freedom to marry."

Andy Pugno, general counsel for ProtectMarriage.com, the organization that put Proposition 8 on the ballot, said, "Arguing this case before the Supreme Court finally gives us a chance at a fair hearing, something that hasn't been afforded to the people since we began this fight."

Title: Republican Governors Shift Focus Away from Tax Cuts and Medicaid Expansion

Article:

In the United States, several Republican governors, who were elected in 2010 and are now in their second term, are deviating from traditional Republican orthodoxy by focusing on issues other than tax cuts and Medicaid expansion.

In Wisconsin, Governor Scott Walker, known for his conservative policies such as ending public-employee collective bargaining, is not pursuing a so-called right-to-work bill, which would further limit unions, as vigorously as he did in the past. Walker is also downplaying suggestions he made a year ago to deeply slash the income tax.

In Ohio, Governor John Kasich, another potential presidential candidate, is proposing to raise taxes on energy drilling companies to fund an income tax cut, despite opposition from a Tea Party faction in the General Assembly. Governor Rick Snyder of Michigan is advocating for higher gasoline taxes to improve roads, an idea that is unpopular among his conservative supporters.

The prospect of sweeping new tax cuts seems to have diminished, partly because incumbents have already enacted cuts in their first term, but also due to the cautionary example of Kansas. In Kansas, Governor Sam Brownback pushed for large business and income tax cuts in 2012 and 2013, promising that the loss of revenue would be made up by a business boom. Instead, revenues plummeted, the state faces a significant budget shortfall, and a backlash nearly cost Brownback, a Republican, re-election.

In Florida, Governor Rick Scott, who was sworn in on Tuesday, has outlined an agenda that includes spending billions more on schools, the environment, and transportation, a stark contrast to the $3.3 billion in education cuts during his first term and his rejection of billions in federal aid for high-speed rail.

In Arizona, the newly elected Republican governor, Doug Ducey, did not mention his campaign pledges to cut income taxes each year in his inauguration speech on Tuesday. This omission was not surprising, given that the state faces a substantial and growing budget deficit.

Several Republican governors, including Bill Haslam of Tennessee and those in Wyoming and North Carolina, have announced their support for some form of Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act, arguing that it is fiscally smart to accept the billions of dollars in federal aid.

Title: Hillary Clinton Affirms No Contact from FBI in Email Investigation

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner in the 2016 presidential race, stated on Sunday that she has not been contacted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) in the ongoing investigation regarding her use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State.

During an interview on NBC's Meet the Press, Clinton told moderator Chuck Todd, "No, no, they haven't." When asked if FBI agents had reached out to her. Clinton added, "But, you know, back in August, we made clear that I'm happy to answer any questions that anybody might have. And I stand by that."

Clinton expressed no concern that the investigation may not be concluded by the time the Democratic National Convention takes place in July. "No, I'm not," she said when asked about her apprehensions. "Because I do not think anything inappropriate was done. And so I have to let them decide how to resolve their security inquiry, but I'm not at all worried about it."

Clinton reiterated that sending emails from a private server while serving as Secretary of State was a mistake. "So let me just say again, I sent emails to government employees on their government accounts," Clinton said. "I had every reason to believe they were in the government system. It was a matter of convenience. I've said repeatedly, it was not the best choice. It was a mistake. But I think that anybody who's actually looked at this has concluded that I have now put out all of my emails. Go and ask others for their emails. Ask everybody else who's in public office. I'm the one who's done it, and I did it because I thought it was the right thing to do."

Regarding the possibility of debating her Democratic rival, Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Clinton expressed confidence but did not commit to a specific date. "I'm not the one negotiating it, that's going on between our campaigns," Clinton said.

Sanders has been pressing Clinton to debate. Sanders, a Brooklyn native, believes he has a chance to win New York, while Clinton, a New York resident and former U.S. senator from the state, expects to carry the Empire State. Sanders also expressed confidence that there will be a debate before the primary, stating on ABC's This Week on Sunday that he is "confident" there will be a debate before the primary.

Title: Cellphone Video Shows Alleged Police Misconduct in Minnesota Incident

Article:

A cellphone video capturing an alleged instance of police misconduct has surfaced this week, featuring a black man identified as 28-year-old Christopher Lollie. The incident occurred in a public space in downtown St. Paul, Minnesota, where Lollie was waiting to pick up his young children from New Horizon Academy.

In the video, a female police officer approaches Lollie and asks him to identify himself. Lollie, who had been sitting in the public area for 10 minutes, protests that he is not required to provide his name as he had not broken any laws.

"The problem is I'm black," Lollie interrupts. "It really is, because I'm not sitting there with a group of people. I'm sitting there by myself, not causing a problem."

A second officer then approaches the two, and attempts to touch Lollie. "I've got to go get my kids," Lollie says, growing upset. "Please don't touch me."

"You're going to go to jail then," the second officer replies. "I'm not your brother. Put your hands behind your back, otherwise it's going to get ugly."

Shortly thereafter, the phone gets knocked out of Lollie's hands as the cops cuff him. One can then hear the sound of a taser charging and Lollie's screams as the cops tase him.

According to the police report, two officers, Michael Johnson and Bruce Schmidt, were called to the First National Bank Building "on a report of an uncooperative male refusing to leave." The identity of the female officer involved in the incident has not been disclosed.

Lollie, who had been attending New Horizon for about 9 months at the time, said his children were not present during the incident as their mother had not arrived yet. However, Lollie's children's classmates and teacher witnessed the event, he said. "The teacher actually gave me a witness statement, stating that 'he was calm, he was not doing anything wrong, he was talking to them, and they just started assaulting him,'" he said.

Since then, Lollie said he fought the charges and, due to the teacher's statement and the footage from the building's security cameras, all charges against him were dropped as of July 31.

Lollie stated that he did not want to post the video until the charges were dropped. "It hurts, it really does," he said. "Because no matter what -- I could be the nicest guy in the world, talk with respect, I can be working, taking care of my kids, doing everything the model citizen is supposed to do -- and I still get that type of treatment."

Title: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver Defends Employee's Freedom of Speech Amidst China-NBA Tensions

Article:

TOKYO (AP) — NBA Commissioner Adam Silver has stated that the league is not apologizing for Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey's tweet supporting anti-government protesters in Hong Kong, despite China's state broadcaster canceling plans to show two preseason games later this week.

Speaking Tuesday at a news conference in Tokyo before a preseason game between the Rockets and NBA champion Toronto Raptors, Silver emphasized that Morey, as an employee of the Houston Rockets, has the right to freedom of expression.

"Daryl Morey, as general manager of the Houston Rockets, enjoys that right as one of our employees," Silver said. "What I also tried to suggest is that I understand there are consequences from his freedom of speech and we will have to live with those consequences."

Among those consequences, China's state broadcaster, CCTV, announced it would not show the games between the Los Angeles Lakers and Brooklyn Nets, which were scheduled to take place Thursday in Shanghai and Saturday in Shenzhen. Basketball is popular in China, and the two teams, particularly due to LeBron James' stardom for the Lakers and Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba's co-founder Joe Tsai's ownership of the Nets, would have likely been a significant television draw.

"We are strongly dissatisfied and oppose Adam Silver's claim to support Morey's right to freedom of expression," CCTV said in a statement. "We believe that any remarks that challenge national sovereignty and social stability are not within the scope of freedom of speech."

The broadcaster is also reviewing all its cooperation and exchanges involving the NBA, according to a statement posted to CCTV Sports' official social media account.

The NBA is not the first major corporation to face criticism from China over political differences. Mercedes-Benz, Delta Air Lines, hotel operator Marriott, fashion brand Zara, and others have also encountered conflicts with China in recent years.

Silver is scheduled to visit Shanghai on Wednesday and hopes to meet with officials and some of the league's business partners there in an effort to find common ground. He expressed hope that Chinese officials and fans would consider the totality of the three-decade-plus relationship between the league and their country and acknowledge political differences between the countries.

"I'm sympathetic to our interests here and our partners that are upset," Silver said. "I don't think it's inconsistent on one hand to be sympathetic to them and at the same time stand by our principles."

Silver also stated that the NBA did not expect CCTV to cancel plans to show the Lakers-Nets games. "But if those are the consequences of us adhering to our values, I still feel it's very, very important to adhere to those values," Silver said.

The rift between China and the NBA began late last week when Morey tweeted a now-deleted image that read: "Fight for Freedom. Stand with Hong Kong," in reference to months of pro-democracy demonstrations in the semiautonomous Chinese territory that has been mired in escalating violence between protesters and law enforcement.

Efforts were made to defuse the impact; Rockets owner Tilman Fertitta stated that Morey does not speak for the Rockets, and Morey returned to Twitter on Monday in an attempt to clarify his message. However, damage was clearly done: At least one Chinese sporting goods company said it was no longer cooperating with the Rockets, NBA streaming partner Tencent—which has a $1.5 billion contract with the league over the next five seasons—said it would not show Rockets games, and a sports news website in China said it was no longer covering the team.

Further complicating the matter is the fact that China's best-known basketball player, Hall of Famer Yao Ming, spent his NBA career with the Rockets. Yao is now the president of the Chinese Basketball Association, which has suspended its relationship with the Rockets as part of the response to Morey's tweet. The CBA also canceled plans for Houston and Dallas G League affiliates to play preseason games in China later this month.

"I'm hoping that together Yao Ming and I can find an accommodation," Silver said. "But he is extremely hot at the moment, and I understand it."

A ceremonial NBA Cares event for an educational center in Shanghai with the Nets was canceled Tuesday, though the Nets participated in other events as scheduled. The Lakers were arriving in Shanghai Tuesday. Silver stated that NBA Cares would still honor its larger mission surrounding that event, including providing a gift of new computers.

"How can it be possible to carry out exchanges and cooperation with China without knowing China's public opinion?" Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Geng Shuang said Tuesday. "NBA's cooperation with China has been going on for quite a long time, so for what should be said and what should be done, they know best."

Silver also released a statement before his news conference, stating that "those who question our motivation" should know that the NBA's stance is about more than business. Many U.S. lawmakers have called for the league to take action—some even suggesting the games in China should be canceled by the NBA.

"We are not apologizing for Daryl exercising his freedom of expression," Silver said. "I regret—again, having communicated directly with many friends in China—that so many people are upset, including millions and millions of our fans. At the end of the day, we come with basketball as an opportunity to sell dreams, sell hopes...that we are causing disruption in people's lives and that we are causing disharmony, that's something I regret."

Title: Controversial Remarks by Obamacare Architect Jonathan Gruber Raise Questions for Democrats Ahead of Supreme Court Review

Article:

In the aftermath of controversial remarks made by Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor Jonathan Gruber, who was a key architect of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), Democrats are facing questions about his role in their defense strategy as they prepare for another Supreme Court review of the health care law.

Gruber's comments, which surfaced recently, have been criticized as suggesting that the health care bill was intentionally written in a complex manner to avoid being labeled a tax by the Congressional Budget Office and to pass through Congress more easily. In 2012, Gruber stated, "Lack of transparency is a huge political advantage...[and] that was really, really critical to get the thing to pass."

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who, as speaker in 2009, posted an Obamacare "myth buster" citing Gruber, distanced herself from him this week, stating, "I don't know who he is...He didn't help write our bill." However, she added that Gruber's comments were a year old and he had recanted them.

Gruber's comments about the health care law's subsidies have also caused controversy. In legal briefs submitted last year to a federal district court in Virginia, Obama administration attorneys cited Gruber in a case defending their ability to pay subsidies to enrollees regardless of whether they are part of state-run or federally run health care exchanges.

The Supreme Court decided this month to take up the case, King v. Burwell, after the challengers lost to the administration in the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Neither the Justice Department nor the White House responded to questions about Gruber and his role in their legal strategy.

Sam Kazman, general counsel for the Competitive Enterprise Institute, which is funding the administration's opponents in the King case, said Gruber's 2012 remarks about subsidies bolster their own arguments. Gruber at the time stated that subsidies would flow only to states that set up their own exchanges, which would mean consumers in most states wouldn't be eligible for subsidies, potentially puncturing a big hole in Obamacare.

In a parallel case before the D.C. Circuit, the administration tried to downplay Gruber in its latest court filings. On Nov. 3, the Justice Department stated in a footnote that "post-enactment statements by a non-legislator are entitled to no weight."

Gruber has made hundreds of thousands of dollars off Obamacare, serving as a consultant to the Department of Health and Human Services and to states that used health care grant money to pay him for his services.

Timothy Jost, a law professor at Washington and Lee University who closely tracks the health care law, stated, "This whole thing just puzzles me...He wasn't a legislator. He didn't write the bill. He didn't vote on the bill."

Title: Trump Administration's Proposed Rule on Short-Term Health Insurance Plans to Increase Coverage and Reduce Costs for Taxpayers, According to Urban Institute Study

Article:

The Trump administration's proposed rule to make it easier for Americans to access short-term, limited duration (STLD) health insurance plans, which are exempt from the Affordable Care Act's regulations, could increase the number of insured Americans by 1.7 million while reducing costs to taxpayers, according to a study by the Urban Institute.

On February 20, the Trump administration released a proposed rule that would repeal an October 2016 regulation that restricted the availability of STLD plans. The proposed rule would allow these plans to last up to a year and permit guaranteed renewal of enrollment beyond that.

Congressional Democrats have criticized the Trump administration's move, arguing that the availability of affordable plans outside of the ACA's risk pool could deprive the exchanges of essential revenues from healthy enrollees and increase premiums for those who remain.

However, the Urban Institute's study demonstrates that the trade-off associated with the policy would be small. According to the report, 7.4 million on the exchanges eligible for tax credits would see no change in premiums. Furthermore, 4.2 million would enroll in STLD plans, whose premiums would be far below those for plans currently available on the exchanges.

While there are roughly similar numbers of winners and losers, the scale of benefits far exceeds the costs. The report also estimates that Trump's proposal would reduce the number of uninsured Americans by 1.7 million, a finding the report buries by grouping those enrolled in STLD plans together with the truly uninsured.

In terms of the net fiscal impact of STLD deregulation, the Urban Institute finds that the reform would slightly reduce federal spending on health care for the nonelderly by $686 million, or 0.2 percent. These empirical findings suggest that the deregulation of STLD plans overall substantially reduces the cost of health insurance, covers more people, and slightly reduces the burden on taxpayers.

Title: Trump Administration Lifts Ban on Lawsuits Against Foreign Companies Over Confiscated Cuban Properties

Article:

The Trump administration will allow lawsuits in U.S. courts for the first time against foreign companies that use properties confiscated by the Cuban government since Fidel Castro's revolution six decades ago. The policy shift, to be announced on Wednesday, could expose U.S., European, and Canadian companies to legal action and potentially harm Cuba's efforts to attract foreign investment.

The decision, explained by a senior U.S. official on Tuesday, is another sign of Washington's efforts to punish Havana over its support for Venezuela's socialist president, Nicolas Maduro. President Donald Trump's national security adviser, John Bolton, will detail the administration's decision in a speech in Miami and announce new sanctions on Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua, countries he has branded a "troika of tyranny."

It is unclear whether such property claims will be acceptable in U.S. courts, and the European Union has already warned it could lodge a challenge with the World Trade Organization. The complete lifting of the ban could allow billions of dollars in legal claims to move forward in U.S. courts and likely antagonize Canada and Europe, whose companies have significant business holdings in Cuba.

The Cuban government did not immediately respond to a request for comment, but the country's National Assembly, meeting over the weekend, declared the Helms-Burton Act "illegitimate, unenforceable, and without legal effect." Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel criticized the United States for attempting to "activate the hateful Helms-Burton Law," which he said aims to return Cuba to a state of being a "slave nation of another empire."

U.S.-Cuban relations have deteriorated since Trump became president in early 2017. A six-decade U.S. economic embargo on Cuba has remained officially intact. The Trump administration's decision follows threats by top aides to take actions against Cuba to force it to abandon Maduro, something Havana has insisted it will not do.

The administration will also begin full enforcement of Helms-Burton's Title IV, which requires the denial of U.S. visas to those involved in "trafficking" confiscated properties in Cuba. Among the foreign companies heavily invested in Cuba are Canadian mining firm Sherritt International Corp and Spain's Melia Hotels International SA. U.S. companies, including airlines and cruise companies, have forged business deals in Cuba since the easing of restrictions under former President Barack Obama.

Defending the decision, the U.S. official said allowing lawsuits would cause only a "bump" in the business world but send a message of U.S. resolve against Havana. The administration is considering a range of options, including sanctions against senior Cuban military and intelligence officials over their role in Venezuela and the tightening of limits on U.S. trade with the island.

Title: House Republicans, Senate Democrats Reach Budget Agreement, Face Backlash from Conservatives

Article:

A bipartisan budget agreement negotiated between House Republicans and Senate Democrats on Wednesday has faced criticism from tea party groups and fiscal conservatives, prompting an unusually strong response from House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican. The deal, which was struck a day earlier by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Republican, and Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray, Washington Democrat, has been met with mixed reviews, with some industries and interests emerging as winners, while others have been labeled as losers.

The deficit-cutting deal, which includes some sweeteners for defense contractors and oil drillers, has been criticized for raising taxes in the form of higher fees, failing to restrain entitlement programs, and permitting new spending in the short term in exchange for vague promises of long-term cuts.

Rep. Jim Jordan, Ohio Republican, stated that Republicans sacrificed their biggest point of leverage - the tough "sequester" spending cuts that were already in force - in the rush to get a short-term deal that did not address the long-term costs of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.

The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the bulk of the plan's deficit reduction would come in the final three years of the deal, while the new spending would happen over the next two years. The estimate followed news that the U.S. government ran a $135.2 billion budget deficit through the first two months of the year - well short of the $226.8 billion deficit the nation had built up by this time a year ago.

The Ryan-Murray agreement increases spending in 2014 to $1.012 trillion and in 2015 to $1.014 trillion and restores more than $60 billion in sequester spending cuts. The new spending is offset in part by lowering the cost-of-living adjustment for military retirees, requiring higher pension contributions from recently hired federal employees, and raising fees on travelers collected by the Transportation Security Administration.

Industries and interests that emerged as winners in the final deal included the Pentagon and the defense industry, where much of the defense-related sequester cuts were restored, and the energy industry, which won expanded rights for joint drilling along the U.S.-Mexico border and in the Gulf of Mexico.

Industries and interests that emerged as losers in the final deal were quick to make their unhappiness known. The National Treasury Employees Union launched a pre-emptive strike against the proposal, saying federal employees had suffered enough under pay freezes and furloughs. The National Nurses United took issue with the cuts aimed at federal workers, especially nurses working in Veterans Affairs hospitals.

Many liberal lawmakers said the federal budget should not be balanced on the backs of federal workers and that the bill could have trouble passing if it does not extend unemployment insurance for the 1.3 million Americans who are set to get kicked off the rolls before the end of the year.

Despite conservative unhappiness and tepid reviews from many House Democrats, the proposal could be voted on in the House as early as Thursday, and Mr. Ryan said Wednesday on CNN that he is confident he has the votes to pass the bill. Mr. Boehner used unusually pointed language in hitting back at conservative opponents of the deal, charging that critics opposed the agreement even before knowing what was in it.

Title: Suspect in New York and New Jersey Bombings Captured in Shootout with Police

Article:

Authorities have apprehended Ahmad Khan Rahami, the primary person of interest in the Saturday night blast in New York's Chelsea neighborhood and the explosions in New Jersey's Seaside Park on Saturday morning and a foiled bomb attack Sunday night near a train station in Elizabeth, NJ. The capture occurred after a gun battle with police that was initiated when officers found Rahami, a 28-year-old naturalized U.S. citizen, sleeping in the doorway of a bar in Linden, NJ.

The manhunt for Rahami began Monday morning as part of a dragnet launched by officials in search of the suspect. A bar owner in Linden spotted a man sleeping in his doorway and called the police. An officer confronted the man around 10:45 a.m., and soon recognized him as Rahami, officials said. Rahami pulled out a gun and shot the officer, identified by the Linden mayor's office as Angel Padilla, in the abdomen. Padilla was wearing a bulletproof vest.

A second police officer, identified as Investigator Pete Hammer, had a bullet graze his head. Both officers were expected to recover. Rahami was shot at least once in the leg and was eventually brought down and captured alive, Union County Prosecutor Grace Park said. He was taken to University Hospital in Newark where he underwent surgery.

Rahami was charged late Monday in Union County with five counts of attempted murder of a police officer. He was being held on $5.2 million bail and remained at a hospital. It was not known if Rahami had an attorney, as messages left with phone numbers listed for family members by the Associated Press were not returned. Federal charges in the bombings have yet to be filed.

Linden, the city where Rahami was captured, is about four miles from Elizabeth, where Rahami was last known to have lived. The FBI conducted a raid at his apartment, located above a fried chicken restaurant, on Monday morning. Elizabeth is also the city where investigators discovered five suspicious devices, one of which exploded while a bomb squad robot tried to disarm it, near a train station on Sunday night.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio noted during a Monday news conference that authorities were not currently searching for any other suspects. The assistant director of the FBI's field office in New York, William Sweeney Jr., said "there is no indication that there's a cell" in the area.

Following the Chelsea explosion, which injured 29 people, on West 23rd Street at 8:30 p.m. on Saturday, police found a second, unexploded device four blocks away. The device was described as a pressure cooker with wires and a phone attached. The contraption, which bore a resemblance to the bomb used in the 2013 Boston Marathon attack, was placed in a plastic bag.

Authorities found Rahami's fingerprint on the unexploded bomb discovered on West 27th Street. Authorities were still searching for two people who removed that bomb from a duffle bag after it had allegedly been placed on the street by Rahami. The pair placed the device in a plastic bag and then walked off with the duffel bag. Police said the individuals were only considered witnesses.

The Chelsea bombing came 11 hours after a pipe bomb exploded about 80 miles south in a New Jersey garbage can near the route of a charity 5K race. That explosion occurred in Seaside Park, a borough about 60 miles from Elizabeth. No one was injured in that blast. Runners were slated to be near the location of the explosion when it went off, but the race was delayed after an unattended backpack was discovered.

Authorities said the New York and New Jersey bombs used flip phones as detonators. Several media outlets also reported the New York bombs contained shrapnel consisting of ball bearings and BBs. Local and federal officials said Rahami had not been on law enforcement's radar before the explosions, and the FBI said they had no knowledge of Rahami receiving any weapons or explosives training overseas.

Title: Bernie Sanders and Michael Bloomberg Clash Over Campaign Financing During CNN Town Hall

Article:

During a CNN town hall on Tuesday night, Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders criticized fellow candidate Michael Bloomberg's wealth and his decision not to contest in the early primary states, while declining to indicate whether he would accept financial support from Bloomberg in the general election.

CNN's Anderson Cooper introduced the topic, stating, "Tomorrow night, for the first time, you'll be on a debate stage with the former mayor of New York, Michael Bloomberg, perhaps you've heard this. Two polls out today show that he's your closest competition." Cooper then asked Sanders if he considered Bloomberg the biggest threat to his nomination.

Sanders responded, "This is what I do know and this I feel very strongly about. You know, Mr. Bloomberg has every right in the world to run for president of the United States. He's an American citizen. But I don't think he has the right to buy this election... I think it's a bit obscene that we have somebody who, by the way, chose not to contest in Iowa, in Nevada, in South Carolina, in New Hampshire where all of the candidates – we did town meetings, we were talking to thousands and thousands of people, working hard – he said, 'I don't have to do that. I'm worth $60 billion. I have more wealth than the bottom 125 million Americans. I'll buy the presidency.'"

Later in the town hall, an audience member asked Sanders if he would accept help from billionaires like Bloomberg if nominated, to which Sanders declined to answer the question multiple times.

Sanders differentiated his campaign financing from Bloomberg's, stating that he has received more campaign contributions, 7 million, from more Americans, 1.5 million, than any candidate in the history of the United States. He added that his average contribution is $18.50 and that his campaign is building the strongest grassroots movement in the modern history of the country.

Cooper pressed Sanders on the issue, asking if he would accept money from Bloomberg if he did not win the nomination. Sanders responded that he would support the democratic nominee vigorously, but did not commit to accepting financial support from Bloomberg.

Cooper followed up, asking if Sanders would accept the money or not if Bloomberg offered it. Sanders responded that he had already stated his position, which is that if Bloomberg wins, he will support the democratic nominee. Cooper then asked if Sanders was unsure if he would take the money or not, to which Sanders refused to answer, and Cooper concluded the discussion.

Title: House Republicans Propose Plan to Address Potential Obamacare Subsidy Crisis

Article:

House Republicans have outlined a plan to maintain the current level of subsidies for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) for all beneficiaries, regardless of their state of residence. The plan, which is still in development, allows states to opt out of Obamacare starting in 2016, with the option to receive block grants to manage their residents' health insurance as they see fit.

The block grants and subsidies, including those for states that remain in Obamacare, will expire in 2017, necessitating the replacement of the law by the next president and Congress. The Supreme Court is currently considering a case that could rule on the legality of the subsidies, with a decision expected as early as Thursday.

Republicans in the House have been working to finalize a plan in response to the potential Supreme Court ruling. Representative Charles W. Boustany Jr. (Louisiana Republican) described the plan as a "good start." Senate Republicans are also discussing their own plans, including extending subsidies through 2017 and allowing states to opt out of Obamacare if the subsidies are discontinued.

The GOP-led Congress has been critical of the Affordable Care Act, with some members advocating for the repeal of its insurance mandates on individuals and employers. The House proposal, which has not been finalized, would repeal these mandates, a move that is likely to be met with opposition from supporters of Obamacare who argue that the mandates are crucial for balancing risk pools and keeping premiums manageable.

The House plan would use a budget process known as "reconciliation" to pass the legislation, allowing it to bypass a filibuster in the Senate and pass with a simple majority. However, the president could still veto the plan. Some lawmakers have expressed reservations about extending the subsidies beyond the current year, fearing it sends the wrong message to voters after years of efforts to repeal the entire law.

The Supreme Court case, known as King v. Burwell, challenges the legality of providing subsidies in states that did not establish their own health insurance exchanges. The administration argues that the subsidies were intended to cover all residents, while opponents claim they were meant to exclude states that did not set up their own exchanges. More than 6 million Americans could lose subsidies if the court rules against the administration.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry Addresses Allegations of Secret Iranian Uranium Enrichment Facility

Article:

U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry has stated that a potential nuclear deal with Iran could be jeopardized if recent allegations from the Iranian dissident group, National Coalition of Resistance of Iran (NCRI), regarding a secret uranium enrichment operation at a facility near Tehran prove to be true.

During a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing on Wednesday, Mr. Kerry revealed that U.S. officials were aware of the site prior to this week, but it has not been identified as a nuclear facility. He stated, "It is a facility that we are well aware of, which is on a list of facilities we have. I’m not going to go into greater detail."

Mr. Kerry added, "But these things are obviously going to have to be resolved as we go forward."

The NCRI claimed on Tuesday that the underground facility, known as "Lavizan-3," has been used for clandestine nuclear research since 2008 and for uranium enrichment with advanced IR-2m and IR-4 centrifuge machines. The veracity of the NCRI's claim was not immediately verifiable, and the group has a controversial history in Washington. However, the group is known for having deep sources inside Iran's nuclear community and is credited with making game-changing revelations about Tehran's activities in the past.

Notably, during the early 2000s, similar NCRI claims exposed the existence of Iran's Natanz uranium enrichment facility and the Arak heavy-water plutonium facility, two operations that have been at the center of international scrutiny and distrust of Tehran since then.

Rep. Brad Sherman (D-California) noted to Mr. Kerry on Wednesday that "the MEK sometimes gives us accurate information." Mr. Sherman added, "They are the ones that told the world about the Iranian nuclear program. They now say that there’s a secret facility at Lavazza 3."

Title: South Korea's Response to Coronavirus Outshines China's: Transparency, Testing, and Civil Society

Article:

South Korea's approach to managing the coronavirus outbreak has been hailed as a success story, contrasting with China's response, which has been criticized for denial, cover-ups, and missteps. The South Korean government, in collaboration with its civil society, has implemented a strategy focusing on education, transparency, and mobilizing citizens, without resorting to China's tactics of mass home detention, forced labor, or censorship.

South Korea's most effective weapon against the virus has been rapid and extensive testing. The country is currently testing 15,000 people daily, according to government figures, with 210,000 South Koreans tested since January 3, compared to approximately 6,500 tests completed in the United States by Tuesday morning. South Korea's testing has resulted in a reported 7,513 confirmed cases and 54 deaths, a mortality rate of 0.71 percent.

The number of daily confirmed cases has been steadily declining, from 686 on March 2 to just 131 on Tuesday, according to government figures. The government has deployed 53 drive-through sample collection stations, allowing drivers to get tested without physical contact with anyone.

President Moon Jae-in stated on March 1 that the government is waging an "all-out response" after raising the crisis alert to the highest level. South Korea's civil society has voluntarily pitched in, with major events canceled, church services moved online, and citizens avoiding the city of Daegu, where the majority of cases are, without turning the entire city into a prison.

Some of South Korea's measures have been controversial, such as tracking confirmed coronavirus patients using GPS and creating a live map of their locations without their names. However, this approach seems less invasive than the use of surveillance drones to take people's temperatures and spray disinfectant, as is being done in several parts of China.

To stop the export of the virus, South Korea has implemented a three-step detection system at Incheon International Airport, with extra screening measures for passengers headed to the United States. Seoul aims to give other countries confidence in doing business with South Korea and admitting South Koreans. The focus is on transparency and openness, not Beijing's pattern of distortion and distraction.

The World Health Organization's joint mission report with China credited Beijing for mobilizing government agencies and devoting scientific attention to the problem. However, the report also noted that the Chinese people, not their government, deserve much of the credit for the country's exceptional containment measures.

Imagine if Beijing had practiced openness, transparency, and public education seven or eight weeks earlier. The epidemic might never have become as severe as it is now. While China's draconian police-state measures may work, only if one ignores the massive suffering they cause.

South Korea's response is stronger because it is open to criticism and examination. This openness is likely to improve South Korea's economic situation faster, along with its public health. The approach is also working politically for President Moon Jae-in. Trump might want to consider this before stating that the coronavirus will "just go away," as he did on Tuesday.

Democracies strike a balance between personal liberty and government responsibility. South Korea's values are not what make them vulnerable; they are what make them strong. The only thing they have to do is live up to them.

Title: FBI Interview Summaries Suggest Attempt at Email Classification Deal Between State Department and Clinton Aides

Article:

Documents released by the FBI as part of interview summaries surrounding the Clinton emails case suggest an attempt at a deal between Patrick Kennedy, a senior aide to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, and the Bureau, whereby classified emails on Clinton's unsecured bathroom server would have their status altered in Clinton's favor in exchange for more favorable treatment of FBI officials in overseas postings at embassies.

According to a report by The Weekly Standard's Stephen Hayes, a senior FBI official in the international operations division described conversations with Kennedy about the classification of emails. The official stated that his section of the FBI had attempted to contact Kennedy repeatedly over several months in the spring of 2015, but Kennedy did not return the calls.

In the late spring or early summer of 2015, the FBI official reported to work to find a note indicating that Kennedy had called. According to the FBI summary, Kennedy wanted help. The FBI official spoke with Kennedy and Kennedy raised the possibility of keeping at least one Clinton email from public disclosure by obtaining a "B9" exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, a rarely used exemption that refers to "geological and geophysical information and data."

One email in particular concerned Kennedy, and according to the FBI summary, providing a B9 exemption "would allow him to archive the document in the basement of the Department of State never to be seen again." The FBI official told Kennedy that he would look into the email if Kennedy would authorize a pending request for additional FBI personnel in Iraq.

A summary of an interview with the section chief of the FBI records management division provides further evidence of Kennedy's attempts to have the classification of some sensitive emails changed. The FBI records official, whose job includes making determinations on classification, told investigators that he was approached by his colleague in international operations after the initial discussion with Kennedy. The FBI records official says that his colleague "pressed" him to declassify an email "in exchange for a quid pro quo," according to the interview summary. "In exchange for making the email unclassified, State would reciprocate by allowing the FBI to place more agents in countries where they are presently forbidden." The request was denied.

The FBI has "explained" these events by saying that the bargained-for exchange never took place, and the FBI agent with whom Kennedy was communicating has since retired. State Department spokesman Mark Toner made the absurd claim that these conversations were a "normal part of the classification process" — as though it's "normal" to reclassify documents that are part of an investigation into criminal misuse of state secrets in favor of the governing party's presidential nominee.

This isn't acceptable, to be charitable. This communication took place amid Hillary's denials that any classified material was sent or received on her email, which her former employees still working at State — including Kennedy — knew to be a lie. And rather than give the public the truth, which wouldn't come out until much later, after she had won the Democrat nomination, Kennedy was working to remedy her false denials by making a lie true.

Furthermore, he was offering essentially a bribe to the FBI in order to procure more favorable field on which the Clinton email investigation would play out.
