This isn't some ho-hum bureaucratic deal-making at work — or if it is, it illuminates precisely how like the Third World the corruption in Washington has become.

Consider what would happen if the middle manager or legal counsel at XYZ Corporation, whose CEO is under FBI investigation, were to offer perks and valuables to FBI agents individually or collectively as a quid pro quo for a reframing of the investigation. We all know how that would go — the charges would pile up, the offender in question would be quickly dismissed, the corporation would be dragged through the mud, and the CEO would be accused of directing the attempted bribe.

In this case, there is no evidence Hillary Clinton was behind Kennedy's offers — but we also don't know how hard investigators have looked. After all, this horse-trading didn't happen when Hillary was wrapping up her affairs at State in 2012; it happened last year when the FBI investigation was ramping up. One assumes Kennedy understood the stakes at hand, and one assumes he's smart enough to know how best to butter his own bread as a Clintonite.

And given Kennedy's role as the Clintons' fixer at State, you would expect that he would be the primary individual put to the squeeze in any investigation of the email scandal. Kennedy, after all, was involved in the questionable political hiring of Clinton IT tech Bryan Pagliano to a nonpolitical State Department job; Pagliano was the man who set up Hillary's private server and ended up getting immunity in the investigation.

But yes — Toner and the rest of the Democrat stooges disguised as federal bureaucrats are correct. For those of us rubes in the hinterlands, this might seem a flagrant example of an out-of-control government, but for our betters inside the Beltway, it's a Tuesday. And they wonder why we increasingly recoil from consent to be governed by them.

Title: Raheem Kassam and Laura Loomer Discuss Social Media Censorship at CPAC

Article:

Raheem Kassam, a former editor for Breitbart and a fellow at the Claremont Institute, discussed the Left's campaign to silence conservative voices on social media at the 46th annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC). Kassam's temporary Facebook ban this week, which he believes was an attempt to intimidate him, has gained attention, with Donald Trump Jr. tweeting in support.

Kassam, the author of "No Go Zones: How Sharia Law Is Coming to a Neighborhood Near You," sees the social-media crackdown on conservatives as evidence that the Left is frightened. "If the other side wasn't afraid, they wouldn't be coming down so heavy-handed on people," Kassam said in an interview near Radio Row at CPAC.

Kassam anticipates that if President Trump is re-elected next year, there will be serious legislation about this issue, potentially in the form of a Digital Bill of Rights. The suppression of online free speech has become apparent, with instances such as Instagram (owned by Facebook) deleting a post by Donald Trump Jr. in February.

Anti-conservative censorship online has escalated, with major social media platforms targeting prominent conservatives for censorship. In 2016, Twitter banned Stacy McCain's account without providing a reason, and since then, the Left's online suppression of dissent has increased.

Laura Loomer, a Trump supporter who was banned from Twitter in November after criticizing newly elected Democrat Rep. Ilhan Omar, discussed her role in a recent investigation of Omar at a CPAC press conference. Loomer asserted that pressure from the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR), which has connections to Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood, was responsible for Twitter's banning her.

Loomer also shared a brief video interview with Donald Trump Jr. at CPAC, which she posted to her Instagram account. In the interview, Trump Jr. responded to Loomer's question about taking action against social-media censorship by saying, "It's time."

If Kassam's analysis is correct, the recent campaign of online censorship may signal that leftists in Big Tech are acting out of fear that they are losing the Internet battle against Trump's supporters. The stakes in this issue could not be higher, as the suppression of free speech online has significant implications for the 2020 presidential campaign and the future of political discourse.

Title: Kentucky Senate Candidates Dodge Questions in Debate, Raising Questions About Political Calculus

Article:

In the first and only debate for the marquee Kentucky race for the U.S. Senate, incumbent Republican Mitch McConnell and his Democratic challenger, Alison Lundergan Grimes, each evaded a high-profile question from the moderator. The question about their evasions is: What is the political calculus behind it, and will it hurt them?

The debate's focus on evasion began with Ms. Grimes, the Kentucky Secretary of State, who, in an interview with The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., refused to answer a question about whether she voted for President Obama four times.

Senator McConnell, who is unpopular in Kentucky, has equated Grimes with the president. In the newspaper interview, she danced around the simple question, saying the election is not about the president but about jobs, and that she was a delegate in 2008 for Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Grimes was criticized from both the left and the right, and the left-leaning host of NBC's "Meet the Press," Chuck Todd, said she "disqualified herself."

On Monday, Grimes provided a more detailed response, explaining that, as secretary of state in charge of elections, she has to stand up for the right to a secret ballot. "If I, as chief election official, don't stand up for that right, who in Kentucky will?" she asked KET television moderator Bill Goodman.

In the past, Grimes has said she voted for Mrs. Clinton in the 2008 primary. The downside of revealing her vote now is that her words can be used in a McConnell ad against her.

"Grimes apparently has made the calculation that it's better to not answer the question than it is to answer it and have the words 'I voted for Obama' used against her in a seven-figure television ad buy," said Courier-Journal political reporter Joseph Gerth in an email.

Some argue that Grimes' evasion is not significant, as her voting for Mr. Obama is assumed. "Sometimes candidates get a question where there is no winning answer, and they are better off just letting it ride," says Stephen Voss, a political scientist at the University of Kentucky in Lexington.

Similar evasion was observed in Senator McConnell's response to a question about climate change, a relevant issue in a state that relies on the coal industry for electricity and jobs. In the past, the senator has remarked, "I'm not a scientist," so he cannot delve into climate change's causes.

When asked on Monday whether he stands by his "not a scientist" position and whether he believes in discussing climate change, the senator brushed past the question.

"There are a bunch of scientists who feel that this is a problem," he answered. However, the main thing to understand is that his job is "to fight for coal jobs in our state, and this administration has destroyed 7,000 of them," he added.

McConnell's political calculus is similar to Grimes's. He "has decided that not answering whether climate change is man-made is better than siding against the fossil fuel industry that has contributed millions to his political committees, or siding with climate-change deniers," says Mr. Gerth.

Some observers think this deflection doesn't matter much, either. The reason is that the two candidates are both pro-coal, so "this isn't a voting issue," says Al Cross, director of the Institute for Rural Journalism and Community at the University of Kentucky in Lexington.

"The whole question of climate gets ignored because they're both embracing coal," Mr. Cross explains.

Title: Obama's Israel Visit: A Trust-Building Trip Amidst Tension and Peace Process

Article:

President Barack Obama landed in Israel this morning, marking his first visit to the country as president. During a welcoming ceremony at Tel Aviv airport, Obama stated, "I see this visit as an opportunity to reaffirm the unbreakable bond between our nations, to restate America's unwavering commitment to Israel's security, and to speak directly to the people of Israel and to your neighbors."

NPR's Larry Abramson, who is at the airport, reported that Obama was welcomed by Israeli President Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The leaders reaffirmed the "unbreakable alliance" between the countries, according to Larry.

Obama is currently on a tour of Israel's Iron Dome, the country's missile defense system, which the United States has helped fund. Later today, he will head to Jerusalem, and tomorrow, he will cross into Ramallah in the West Bank.

The New York Times reports that Obama does not arrive in the region with grand plans to revive stalled peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. Instead, the president is seeking to make a connection with the Israeli people, many of whom view him with a jaundiced eye after four years in which he sparred with Mr. Netanyahu over issues like Iran and the Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

The highlight of the trip will be a speech Obama will deliver to students at the Jerusalem International Convention Center on Thursday. The Washington Post reports the president is expected to reassure Israel of the United States' commitment to its security as Israel "seeks to counter threats from Iran and protect its people in the midst of civil war in neighboring Syria."

Larry described this as a "trust-building visit." He said, "Even though both sides insist there are no problems between the two countries, the fact is there has been some tension."

President Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu recently concluded a 45-minute press conference where they addressed the peace process, Iran, and Syria. During the press conference, President Obama was asked by NBC's Chuck Todd why peace talks stalled during his first term. Obama responded, "I did not promise to bring peace to the Middle East; instead, I said I would start on the process immediately."

Netanyahu was asked directly whether Israel and the United States believed that Iran was a year away from producing a nuclear weapon. Netanyahu said the countries "share information and we share the same assessment on the schedule."

President Obama stated that "each country has to make its own decision" when it comes to war. However, he believed that on the question of Iran, there was "still time to solve this diplomatically."

On Syria, President Obama defended the United States, saying it has done a lot to try to bring the conflict to a resolution. "I have made clear the use of chemical weapons is a game changer," Obama said. His team, he added, is currently trying to assess whether the Syrian government has used those weapons.

"Israel will have no greater friend than the United States," President Obama said during an appearance with Israeli President Shimon Peres. Peres, for his part, told Obama that his vision of peace for the region can be accomplished. He said he believed Obama when he said, "peace is not only a wish but a possibility."

Obama and Peres met at Peres' presidential home and discussed the Arab Spring, Iran, and the peace process. They opened their meeting with a planting ceremony. Obama brought Peres a magnolia tree from the White House garden. "This is the work of generations," Obama said about peace. He framed that quote with a story from the Talmud about Honi and the carob tree. The tree yields carobs 70 years after it's planted. So what's the point of planting one, if you may never eat its fruits? Honi asks a man. The man tells him that when he came into the world, his father and grandfathers had planted carob trees for him to enjoy. The man said he was planting carob trees for his children and grandchildren.

Title: Senate Foreign Relations Committee Approves Pompeo's Nomination for Secretary of State

Article:

Mike Pompeo, the current CIA director, won a favorable vote on Monday from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, paving the way for his confirmation as secretary of state as early as this week. The unexpected support came after Senator Rand Paul, who had previously been opposed to Pompeo, changed his stance following personal appeals from President Donald Trump.

Senator Paul's surprising change of heart on Pompeo came after multiple conversations with Trump and assurances that the nominee views the war in Iraq as a mistake and wants to wind down the U.S. presence in Afghanistan. In a statement, Paul stated, "President Trump believes that Iraq was a mistake, that regime change has destabilized the region, and that we must end our involvement with Afghanistan. Having received assurances from President Trump and Director Pompeo that he agrees with the president on these important issues, I have decided to support his nomination to be our next Secretary of State."

Trump praised Paul after the libertarian's change of heart on Pompeo, according to a pool report, saying Paul "never let me down." The final vote count on Pompeo's nomination in the committee was 11-9, with Senator Chris Coons (D-Del.) agreeing to vote "present" to expedite the nominee's progress to the floor.

Senator Paul's change of position on Pompeo, whom he had indicated he would oppose as recently as last Thursday, came minutes before the nominee's scheduled vote in the committee. Foreign Relations Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) appealed to potential Pompeo supporters by observing that the nominee, a veteran House Republican, has forged a notably close bond with Trump.

Pompeo is expected to win confirmation from the full Senate later this week with unified GOP support and backing from a handful of vulnerable Democrats. Among the Democrats who have announced their support for Pompeo are Senators Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Joe Donnelly (D-Ind.), and Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.).

Activists on the left who have pushed Democrats to oppose Pompeo, citing his past statements regarding Islamic leaders and other politically volatile stances, lauded the committee's minority for staying united in opposition. Elizabeth Beavers, foreign policy manager at the liberal group Indivisible, said in a statement, "We were glad to see Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hold firm and say that an Islamophobic, anti-woman, climate change-denying, pro-torture war hawk is an unacceptable choice to serve as our country’s secretary of state."

Title: U.S. Military Bases Increase Security Levels Due to Terror Threats

Article:

The U.S. Department of Defense has increased the security conditions at military bases across the country to "Force Protection Bravo" due to growing concerns about terror threats, officials confirmed to CNN on Friday. This level is the third-highest threat level on a five-tier scale used by the Department of Defense.

The announcement was not a response to a specific threat but rather a result of several recent incidents, U.S. military officials stated. One such incident involved a jihadist linked to the Garland attack tweeting the name and address of a U.S. military officer connected to the military's Syrian rebel training program.

The tweet, published on an account connected to British-born jihadist Junaid Hussain, was sent out a few days before the attack on a cartoon exhibit and appeared to encourage an attack on the address. Hussain is believed to have been messaging with Elton Simpson, one of the two attackers of the Texas event, and had been urging Simpson to take action.

This followed the publishing of the names and addresses of about 100 military members on ISIS-connected accounts several weeks ago. FBI Director James Comey stated on Thursday that there are thousands of ISIS followers online in the U.S.

"We have a general concern, obviously, that ISIL is focusing on the uniformed military and law enforcement," Comey told reporters on Thursday.

The order to upgrade the threat level was signed by Admiral William Gortney, head of the U.S. Northern Command, which oversees all U.S. military installations in the continental U.S. The security order affects 3,200 sites, including bases, National Guard facilities, recruiting stations, and health clinics, a Pentagon official said.

Captain Jeff Davis, spokesman for the U.S. Northern Command, or NORTHCOM, stated, "We have the same concern about the potential threat posed by violent homegrown extremists." The change in threat level status could mean more checks of vehicles entering bases and more thorough identity checks of all personnel.

The order to raise the force protection level to Bravo also applies to all National Guard installations, recruiting stations, and ROTC detachments. However, a U.S. military official acknowledges it will be difficult for the ROTC detachments to do much more than security awareness.

In addition, security was recently raised at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio, in response to a perceived threat to the base security. The threat was never deemed credible, but it came after another security concern at a base in Delaware used by Vice President Joe Biden when he flies home.

On Friday, Wright-Patterson announced that the Air Force museum, which is part of the base, was canceling a planned Friday night concert and was stopping tours that were regularly offered until further notice. The base said this was "due to elevated security measures."

Since NORTHCOM was established in October 2002, the threat level has reached Bravo on four occasions: Feb. 9, 2003, amid concerns al Qaeda was planning attacks on American targets; Dec. 21, 2003, when officials were concerned about attacks during the holiday season; May 1, 2011, in the aftermath of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden; and the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. It reached "Delta," its highest level, on Sept. 11, 2001, Pentagon officials told CNN at the time.

Title: Photographer Ellen Shub's Work and the Alteration of a Historical Photograph at the National Archives

Article:

Last month, photographer Ellen Shub passed away at the age of seventy-three near Boston. Known for her work as a chronicler of social protest, Shub's photographs, published in alternative and movement media, served as a historical record of protests and demonstrations throughout the years.

In 1975, Shub captured a photograph of a woman holding a placard that read "No more back room back alley abortions." In 1981, at a Boston rally for the Equal Rights Amendment, she photographed a woman with a sign that read "59c" – the amount of money a woman made for every dollar earned by a man. In 2004, during the Republican National Convention in New York, Shub took a picture of a protester with a large sign that read "Dissent is the highest form of patriotism – Thomas Jefferson." In 2014, at a rally in Boston, she photographed a young man holding a sign that said "# Icantbreathe."

Shub's intention in taking such text-centric pictures was to create a historical record. Her medium was photographs published in alternative media, including gay and lesbian newspapers, feminist newspapers, and city weeklies. These papers served as amendments to the historical narrative, providing a record of what was also said, also written, and also seen.

Recently, the Washington Post reported that the National Archives had altered a photograph from the 2017 Women's March on Washington. The word "Trump" was blurred on a sign that originally read "God Hates Trump." In other signs in the same picture, the words "vagina" and "pussy" were removed.

In response to the Post's initial inquiry, the Archives offered two arguments and one excuse. The excuse was that the altered photograph was not part of a current exhibition at the Archives, tracing a hundred years of the suffragist movement, but merely a display that advertised the show. The arguments were that the words referring to female anatomy may strike visitors as "inappropriate" and, separately, that the Archives are a "non-partisan, non-political federal agency."

The altered photograph, from the 2017 Women's March on Washington, on display at the National Archives Research Center, on January 17th. Photograph by Salwan Georges / The Washington Post / Getty

The Post and others who picked up the story noted that the director of the Archives, David S. Ferriero, was appointed by Obama. This is an important point, as it provides a measure of how far we, as a society, have drifted under President Donald Trump. By the third anniversary of his inauguration, an organization created for the purpose of creating a historical record—and headed by someone who is not a Trump appointee—has falsified the historical record.

Hannah Arendt, in her 1967 essay on truth and politics, warned of the danger of trying to create politics in the absence of shared reality. She wrote, "Facts and events are infinitely more fragile things than axioms, discoveries, theories—even the most wildly speculative ones—produced by the human mind; they occur in the field of the ever-changing affairs of men, in whose flux there is nothing more permanent than the admittedly relative permanence of the human mind's structure." In the case of the National Archives and the Women's March, a swift media reaction was probably instrumental in correcting the record—if that is actually the outcome of whatever remedies the Archives has selected. However, Arendt warns us that history lost, even if only temporarily, is still, indeed, memory lost.

Title: Ecuador Delays Decision on Edward Snowden's Asylum Request for Up to Two Months

Article:

The former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden remains in transit at a Moscow airport, according to Russian officials, as Ecuador announced that it could take up to two months to approve Snowden's political asylum bid. Ecuador's foreign minister, Ricardo Patino, stated that the decision process could take as long as it took for the approval of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange's asylum, who has been residing in Ecuador's embassy in London for over a year.

Snowden is wanted by the US government for leaking top-secret information on US surveillance programs to The Guardian, The Washington Post, and a Hong Kong-based newspaper. The US revoked his passport, but he managed to flee Hong Kong on Sunday. Ecuador denies granting Snowden special travel documents, according to Reuters.

Initially, Snowden was expected to leave Russia on Monday on a flight to Cuba, but he did not board the plane. Some speculate that Snowden has already left the Moscow airport and is making his way toward Ecuador's embassy there.

Ecuador has faced criticism for offering Snowden asylum, with some calling for the US to cut off aid to the country. National security analyst Aaron Cohen told Fox News that the US has given millions of dollars in aid to Ecuador over the past five years and may potentially be harboring someone responsible for one of the most massive intelligence leaks in history.

Ecuador has received $144.4 million in US aid over the past five years, according to Fox. Some speculate that Ecuador is taking its time considering the asylum application in order to come across as seriously weighing the legal implications of Snowden's asylum request, while others point to the media attention Ecuador garners while the decision is pending.

Ecuador's embassy official Efraín Baus stated that Snowden's application will be reviewed responsibly, as are the many other asylum applications that Ecuador receives each year. Ecuador does have an extradition agreement with the United States, but makes exceptions for political crimes, according to The ███.

Steve Striffler, a Latin America specialist at the University of New Orleans, wrote on CNN that Ecuador's President Rafael Correa is not offering Snowden asylum for political points but is instead taking a principled stance. Correa's openness to individuals like Assange and Snowden, as well as his decision to close a US military base in Ecuador, is part of an effort to deepen Ecuadorian sovereignty while strengthening Latin America's ability to limit the influence of the United States in the region.

However, Ecuador has faced criticism for its apparent irony in supporting freedom of information while deterring expression at home. The country recently passed a media law that contains provisions to clamp down on criticism by the press, according to Reporters without Borders. Correa has called reporters there "rabid dogs" and "assassins with ink," according to the Monitor.

There could be some immediate political and economic consequences for Ecuador if it does indeed grant Snowden asylum, as well. The renewal of preferential treatment for trading certain products including roses and tuna is on the table, reports The New York Times. Michael Shifter of the Inter-American Dialogue told the Times, "The risks are enormous… It would bring the United States down very hard on him." Others, however, say preferential treatment was already at risk of not being renewed.

Title: ABC News Allegedly Suppressed Jeffrey Epstein Story, Sparking Trust Issues in Media

Article:

A video released this week has raised questions about the integrity of ABC News, as anchor Amy Robach was caught on tape discussing how the network allegedly suppressed a story that could have exposed Jeffrey Epstein, a billionaire who was later convicted of sexually abusing underage girls.

In the recording, Robach expressed frustration over the network's decision not to air her interview with Virginia Roberts, a woman who had alleged that Epstein had sexually abused her. Robach stated, "I've had this interview with Virginia Roberts... We would not put it on the air. I was told, 'Who's Jeffrey Epstein? No one knows who that is. This is a stupid story.' Then the palace found out we had her whole allegations about Prince Andrew and threatened us a million different ways... And then Alan Dershowitz was also implicated in it because of the planes."

Epstein, a wealthy money manager with close ties to many top establishment figures, was indicted for his alleged crimes in 2007. However, with the help of high-profile lawyers, he negotiated a 13-month sentence with former U.S. Attorney and later Trump Labor Secretary Alex Acosta.

The Epstein case highlights the growing divide between society's elites and the general public. If the super-wealthy and super-connected can get away with sexually abusing young girls with minimal punishment, the system is clearly broken.

After the footage was released, Robach issued a statement, saying her past comments were "a private moment of frustration." ABC claimed they did not run the interview because they "could not obtain sufficient corroborating evidence to meet ABC's editorial standards about her allegations."

However, ABC's claims of a lack of "corroborating evidence" are difficult to accept, given that the same network ran uncorroborated reports about Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh at the time, peddled by now-disgraced Democratic activist and lawyer Michael Avenatti. The discrepancy in treatment suggests bias.

There is one further explanation for the disparate treatment: politically partisan bias. Avenatti's claims were made against Kavanaugh, a Republican. The claims against Epstein potentially implicated former President Bill Clinton. ABC's lead news anchor is George Stephanopoulos, Bill Clinton's former staffer.

CBS News, MSNBC, and CNN responded to the Robach video by largely ignoring it. ABC, in addition to their clearly bogus statement, responded by searching for the whistleblower who released the video. Reports indicate that ABC found the whistleblower was working at CBS, and CBS followed up by firing the whistleblower.

Taken together, we have all three major U.S. television broadcast networks implicated to some degree in covering for alleged rapists. This, along with similar allegations against NBC News and journalist Ronan Farrow regarding their handling of the Harvey Weinstein case, has led to a significant loss of trust in the news media. A recent Gallup poll found that 69% of Americans have lost trust in the news media over the past decade. Based on these recent events, that number may now be closer to 100%.

Title: Trump Expresses Optimism Over North Korea's Nuclear Disarmament Following Historic Summit

Article:

President Donald Trump, following his historic summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, expressed optimism that the North Korean leader will begin the process of dismantling his country's nuclear program "virtually immediately." The summit took place in Singapore, and the two leaders signed a document stating Pyongyang would work toward "complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula."

In an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, Trump stated, "I just think that we are now going to start the process of denuclearization of North Korea, and I believe that he's going back and will start it virtually immediately – and he's already indicated that, and you look at what he's done."

The historic agreement came after the two leaders held several meetings throughout the day. When asked by a reporter if Kim agreed to denuclearize, Trump responded, "We are starting that process very quickly."

Trump also stated at a press conference that he will be ending joint military exercises between the United States and South Korea. He added that Kim agreed to destroy a "major" missile testing site, but did not offer specific details.

The joint declaration states that the U.S. has committed to providing "security guarantees" to Pyongyang. The extent of these guarantees remains unclear.

Whether the unpredictable North Korean leader will follow through on his commitments remains unclear, but Trump sounded optimistic as he left the summit. He told "Hannity" the two of them "got along from the beginning" and Kim understood the need to dismantle his nuclear program.

The summit, which almost didn't happen, represented a remarkable turnaround from the tension between Washington and Pyongyang last summer when Trump and Kim exchanged a war of words, with the American president warning the dictator of "fire and fury."

Trump told Fox News, though, that "without the rhetoric we wouldn't have been here."

"So I think the rhetoric, I hated to do it, sometimes I felt foolish doing it, but we had no choice," he said.

As for what happens next, Trump insisted, "I think he's gone back to get this done. He wants to get it done."

During a gaggle later in the day with reporters on Air Force One, Trump said he trusts Kim but the U.S. would have to "check" to ensure denuclearization occurs.

"We're going to have to check him. And we will check him very strongly. But he has a plan total and complete," Trump said. "He's got a total plan. It will get done."

When asked whether he had any concerns about Kim, the president insisted Kim "wants to get it done." He added, "And we should all want that to happen."

Title: GOP Presidential Candidate Ben Carson Defends Flat Tax Plan, Discusses Foreign Policy and Controversial Remarks

Article:

GOP presidential candidate Ben Carson defended his flat tax plan on Fox News Sunday, stating that it is "condescending" to suggest that poor people cannot pay taxes. The 63-year-old Carson, who grew up poor in Detroit before becoming a pioneering pediatric neurosurgeon at Johns Hopkins University, argued for the proportional tax, which he likened to the biblical concept of tithing.

Under Carson's plan, individuals making $10 billion a year would pay $1 billion in taxes, while those making as little as $100 would pay $1. "That's pretty darn fair if you ask me," Carson said. He countered criticisms that a flat tax rate would disproportionately burden low- and middle-income families, stating that his numbers are closer to 10-15 percent.

Carson proposed cutting out loopholes and increasing revenue through other means, such as utilizing America's energy resources, revamping corporate taxes, and bringing in overseas money through a tax holiday. He estimated that these measures would generate $2 trillion in revenue.

In addition to discussing his tax plan, Carson was asked about his foreign policy views. When asked about a statement on his website that "all options" should remain open for dealing with Russia, Carson confirmed that this would include military action, but emphasized that it would not be his first option. He also stated that he would handle Ukraine differently than President Barack Obama has, citing Ukraine's promise of defense against Russian invasion in exchange for giving up its nuclear weapons.

Carson also addressed two controversial statements he has made in the past. In a 2014 interview with Breitbart.com, Carson suggested that Americans feel intimidated by their own government due to potential IRS audits and job interference. He also compared Obamacare to slavery in a 2013 speech, stating that it fundamentally changes the relationship between the people and the government.

Regarding his statement last week that, as president, he would not have to enforce "judicial law," Carson clarified on Sunday that the president or executive branch is obligated to carry out the laws of the land, as provided by the legislative branch according to the Constitution.

Title: 18 Democratic Attorneys General Sue Trump Administration Over ObamaCare Payments

Article:

A group of 18 Democratic attorneys general, along with the District of Columbia, have filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration following the White House's decision to end payments to health insurers under the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare). The lawsuit was filed in a federal court in California. The states involved in the lawsuit are California, Connecticut, Delaware, Kentucky, Illinois, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont, Virginia, and Washington.

The states argue that President Trump's decision to halt the payments constitutes an attempt to undermine the health and well-being of the country. They are seeking a court order to compel the Trump administration to make the next payment to insurers, scheduled for October 18. In a separate court case, the Justice Department notified a federal appeals court in Washington on Friday that the payment "would not occur."

A federal judge has found that Congress never properly approved the payments. The subsidies have continued under Obama and Trump until now, despite prior Trump threats to block them. The money goes to companies for lowering out-of-pocket costs like co-payments and deductibles for low- and middle-income customers. It will cost about $7 billion this year.

Congressional Democrats have vowed to press for a bipartisan deal to restore the money by the end of the year. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi criticized Trump's move to end the payments, calling it a "spiteful act of vast, pointless sabotage leveled at working families and the middle class in every corner of America."

President Trump, in response, told conservative activists at the Values Voter Summit that his move would pressure Democrats to negotiate major changes in the law. He also reiterated his belief that his move would ultimately be "just as effective" and "maybe even better" than repealing ObamaCare.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer told reporters that Trump's "threats and bullying are not going to work." He expressed optimism about forcing money for the cost-sharing reductions into a massive spending bill Congress is expected to approve late this year.

Democrats believe they would have little difficulty reaching a bipartisan deal, citing support for the payments by some Republicans and polls showing the public would blame the GOP for any failure. Some Republicans privately agree. Maryland Sen. Chris Van Hollen, who heads Senate Democrats' campaign committee, said, "Now, President Trump has his fingerprints all over the knife."

Sens. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) and Patty Murray (D-Wash.) have been seeking a deal that would reinstate the payments for two years. In exchange, Republicans want "meaningful flexibility for states" to offer lower-cost insurance policies with less coverage than Obama's law mandates.

Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), who leads the conservative House Freedom Caucus, said he is willing to back the payments if they are "part of a transition from Obamacare to something else" with greater state flexibility than Alexander and Murray are discussing. Another conservative leader, Rep. Mark Walker (R-N.C.), said the payments should be revived "under no circumstance."

Some GOP leaders have expressed openness to continuing the payments, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who has said he wants them accompanied by significant changes. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady (R-Texas) said this summer that the payments should be continued, citing their impact on premiums. Moderates like Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) said halting the payments would make insurance costs "unaffordable for some people." Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) tweeted that the cuts "will mean more uninsured in my district."

Title: Senate Leaders Negotiate Government Reopening and Debt Ceiling Extension, but Deal Remains Elusive

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and his Republican counterpart, Sen. Mitch McConnell, have initiated discussions on a potential deal to end the two-week-long government shutdown and provide the Treasury Department with sufficient borrowing authority to avoid a potential default this month. However, the specifics of the agreement are still under negotiation, and all sides have cautioned that the deal is not finalized.

The proposed agreement includes funding the government for several months and granting President Obama the necessary authority to raise the debt ceiling into the next year. The House and Senate would then appoint negotiators to work towards a broader budget deal in the interim.

However, the exact dates for the debt and spending extensions, as well as additional provisions such as delays or restrictions on the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), are still under negotiation, according to aides.

Even if Reid and McConnell reach an agreement, it remains unclear whether the deal can pass through the GOP-controlled House, where some conservatives have expressed skepticism.

Rep. Tim Huelskamp, a Kansas Republican, stated, "When you're giving 98, 99 percent of Obamacare, I don't see how that would ever pass over here, if indeed it passes the Senate."

The mere prospect of a deal that would provide the government with more borrowing room sent the stock markets higher on Monday.

President Obama had initially invited the top party leaders to the White House for talks on Monday afternoon, but he later canceled the meeting, stating it was more appropriate for Reid and McConnell to continue their negotiations.

For his part, the president visited a local food bank, Martha's Table, where some furloughed federal workers were volunteering. President Obama said "some progress" had been made, but he cautioned, "We'll see if the progress is real."

The Treasury Department has stated it will run out of borrowing room on Thursday, leaving it with only cash on hand to pay bills. This cash could last a couple of weeks, or it could be exhausted almost immediately, according to analysts.

The deal's details, particularly regarding the length of the stopgap funding bill, the amount of borrowing authority to be granted, and the potential changes to Obamacare, are still under negotiation.

Sen. Susan M. Collins, a Maine Republican, had proposed delaying a tax on medical devices, a move that has bipartisan support. However, Democratic leaders and the White House have resisted changes to President Obama's Affordable Care Act, leaving Republicans to search for another concession on this subject, which is what sparked the conservative revolt against the spending resolution and debt ceiling in the first place.

The White House has been adamant that the government should reopen and the debt ceiling should be raised without any conditions, repeatedly comparing Republican demands on Obamacare to hostage-taking and terrorism.

House Republicans remain a significant hurdle, and conservatives have expressed reservations about the Senate deal. Rep. Charles W. Boustany Jr., a Louisiana Republican, stated, "I think we'll have a hard time with our conference, with a number of members, because of the lack of Obamacare features in that."

Both party leaders in both houses are discussing strategy, such as which chamber should move first and how many House Democrats would be needed to pass the deal there.

Title: Analysis of American Identity and Politics in the 21st Century

Article:

The aftermath of the September 11, 2001, attacks marked a period of national unity and shared identity among Americans. However, as the years passed, this unity seemed to dissipate, giving way to a fragmented society characterized by identity politics.

In the article, the author suggests that the unity experienced in 2001 was a response to the attacks, which the author refers to as a "powers of darkness." The author argues that this unity was a manifestation of the American identity, and that it took effort to bring about. The author notes that previous events, such as the Vietnam War, Watergate, and the Clinton years, had created deep national divisions.

The author contrasts the unity of 2001 with the current state of American society, where group identity is the primary focus. The author states that identity politics is the new brand of politics, with each constituency asserting its demands over the needs and rights of others. The author notes that while there have always been divisions in American society, the current indisposition to cut slack for anyone besides oneself is the main and most frightening feature of today's politics.

The author expresses concern over the current generation of collegians, who may have a provisional regard for free speech and other freedoms. The author also notes the elimination of Confederate monuments, the war on free trade, and the secularization of society as examples of the linkage between identity politics and the erosion of American ideals.

The author concludes by stating that the American ideal of freedom to pursue legitimate interests is turning off people who view themselves and their group as uniquely deserving or put-upon. The author is writing a book about moral restoration in the 21st century.

Title: Did the Republican National Convention Provide Mitt Romney a Poll Bounce?

Article:

The Republican National Convention appears to have provided Mitt Romney with a poll bounce, although the magnitude of the increase is small. The exact extent of the post-convention boost is subject to interpretation, depending on the specific polling data analyzed.

According to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday, Romney experienced an overall improvement in his image among voters but no significant change in the number of voters who intend to cast their ballots for him. The poll showed Romney steadily improving in likeability and other positive-image features.

Rasmussen Reports' data showed a six-point swing in Romney's favor following the Republican National Convention. Prior to the convention, Romney trailed President Barack Obama by two points, but now holds a four-point lead. This poll also showed Romney surging ahead by two points in 11 key swing states.

Gallup published data prior to the Tampa convention indicating that the GOP had slightly bolstered its image compared to 2008, while Democrats' favorability has declined by double-digits over the same period. This information is relevant as it informs partisan sample breakdowns as pollsters attempt to measure the composition of the 2012 electorate and predict the election's outcome.

Additionally, Rasmussen Report's data showed that the number of Americans who consider themselves Republicans jumped nearly three points in August, with 37.6% of Americans identifying as Republicans. This is the largest number of Republicans ever recorded by Rasmussen Report since monthly tracking began in November 2002.

An update to the article mentions a snap poll of Florida voters that seems to bode well for Romney. However, it is important to note that holiday weekend polling is notoriously unreliable.

Overall, while the exact impact of the Republican National Convention on Mitt Romney's poll numbers is subject to interpretation, it is clear that the convention helped Romney's image among voters.

Title: Sanders and Buttigieg Address Abortion Rights in Presidential Campaign

Article:

During a town hall event on MSNBC, Senator Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate, stated that being pro-choice is an essential part of being a Democrat. This response contrasts with Sanders' stance in 2017, when he campaigned for Heath Mello, a mayoral candidate in Omaha, Nebraska, who was labeled "anti-abortion" for supporting a bill requiring doctors to inform women of their ultrasound rights.

In 2017, a piece in Salon argued that Sanders' endorsement of Mello indicated that he views reproductive rights as negotiable. However, Sanders' support for Mello does not necessarily reflect a pro-life worldview.

During a Fox News town hall, another Democratic presidential candidate, Pete Buttigieg, was asked if he would support more moderate platform language to include pro-life Democratic voters. Buttigieg did not provide a direct answer, instead focusing on the importance of personal autonomy and the woman's right to make decisions about her own body.

Pro-life Democrats have repeatedly asked presidential candidates if there is room for them in the party, and their responses have been largely negative. At least Sanders has been forthcoming in his response, telling pro-life Democrats not to waste their time.

Title: Obama Campaign Outspends Romney Campaign in June, but Faces Challenges in Polls and Favorability Ratings

Article:

President Barack Obama's re-election campaign outspent Mitt Romney's campaign 2 to 1 in June, according to campaign reports filed with the Federal Election Commission. The Obama campaign spent $70.8 million, including about $38 million on television advertising, while Romney and the Republican National Committee spent $38.8 million, including about $11 million on television advertising.

Despite the significant spending, the Obama campaign and the Democratic National Committee have less cash on hand than Romney and the Republicans, according to polls that show a head-to-head race. The first round of polls after President Obama's Bain attacks against Mitt Romney has not been favorable for the White House. In the new New York Times/CBS poll, Romney holds a 47 to 46 percent lead, and Obama is stuck at 47 percent in recent polls by Fox News and NPR.

Voters appear to be processing the worsening economic news belatedly, and their pessimism shows. In the CBS/NYT poll, Obama's job approval dropped to 44 percent, with only 39 percent approving of his economic performance - down five points from April. For the first time since January, more voters now think the economy is getting worse. Nearly two-thirds of voters now place some blame on the president for the weak economic conditions, with 34 percent giving him "significant" responsibility, and an outright 52 percent majority of independents believe Obama will "never improve" the economy.

Another red flag for Team Obama is the president's crumbling favorability ratings, a troubling departure from his previous strength. In the CBS/NYT poll, Obama is underwater on the favorability question, generally his strong suit, by double digits. More Americans are developing a poor overall perception of Obama the man, independent from their misgivings about his leadership. Obama's favorability with independents is 28/52, with Romney actually above water at 32/31.

The media should be asking whether Obama's Bain attacks are hurting Obama rather than how much they are hurting Romney. Another related nugget, reported by the Weekly Standard over the weekend, is that the Obama campaign spent nearly $93,000 to rent a large arena for his big May re-elect kickoff event in Columbus, but ended up with thousands of empty seats. Hyped expectations, disappointing results, huge expenditures, and resulting deficits - these are not numbers that victories are made of.

Title: International Sanctions on Iran Lifted After Compliance with Nuclear Deal

Article:

International sanctions on Iran have been lifted following the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) confirmation that Tehran has complied with a nuclear deal aimed at preventing it from developing nuclear weapons. The EU foreign policy chief, Federica Mogherini, stated that the deal would contribute to improved regional and international peace and security.

The landmark deal between Iran and world powers was agreed upon last July. The lifting of sanctions will unfreeze billions of dollars of assets and allow Iran's oil to be sold internationally. The IAEA confirmed that its inspectors had verified that Iran had taken the necessary steps, including drastically reducing its number of centrifuges and dismantling a heavy-water reactor near the town of Arak, both of which could be used in creating nuclear weapons.

Iran has maintained that its nuclear program is peaceful, but some US Republicans and other opponents of the deal argue that it does not do enough to ensure the country cannot develop a nuclear bomb. US Secretary of State John Kerry has ordered that US nuclear-related economic sanctions against Iran be lifted.

Speaking in Vienna, Mr. Kerry said Iran had "undertaken significant steps" that many people "doubted would ever come to pass." He added, "I thank God for this blessing and bow to the greatness of the patient nation of Iran."

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani tweeted, "Today, as a result of the actions taken since last July, the threat of a nuclear weapon has been reduced." US Secretary of State John Kerry stated, "Today, as a result of the actions taken since last July, the United States, our friends and allies in the Middle East, in the entire world are safer because the threat of a nuclear weapon has been reduced."

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated, "Even after signing the nuclear deal, Iran has not relinquished its ambition to obtain nuclear weapons, and continues to act to destabilize the Middle East and spread terror throughout the world while violating its international commitments." US Republican House Speaker Paul Ryan stated, "Today, the Obama administration will begin lifting economic sanctions on the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism."

British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond stated, "Years of patient and persistent diplomacy, and difficult technical work, have borne fruit as we now implement the deal." Earlier on Saturday, it emerged that Iran had released Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian and three other Iranian-American prisoners in an apparent prisoner swap with the United States.

President Barack Obama will provide more details of the releases later, Mr. Kerry said. A fifth American, Matthew Trevithick, was also released on Saturday. The IAEA has installed a device at the Natanz plant to monitor Iran's uranium enrichment activities in real time, in order to verify that uranium enrichment levels are kept at up to 3.67% as agreed in the deal with world powers. The organization's head, Yukiya Amano, is to visit Tehran on Sunday for meetings with President Rouhani and other officials.

In July 2015, Iran agreed to a landmark nuclear deal with six world powers to limit its sensitive nuclear activities for more than a decade in return for the lifting of crippling sanctions. The US is confident the agreement will prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. Iran says it has the right to nuclear energy and stresses that its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes only. The sanctions have cost Iran more than $160bn in oil revenue since 2012 alone. Once they are lifted, the country will be able to resume selling oil on international markets and using the global financial system for trade. Iran has the fourth-largest oil reserves in the world, and the energy industry is braced for lower prices. Iran will also be able to access more than $100bn in assets frozen overseas.

Title: Biden Suggests AOC and Progressive Democrats Don't Represent Future of Democratic Party

Article:

In an interview with Axios, which will air this weekend on HBO, former Vice President Joe Biden has criticized the rise of progressive Democrats and the label of "Democratic socialists," suggesting that they do not represent the future of the Democratic Party.

During the interview, Biden disputed the notion that the Democratic Party has moved leftward following Hillary Clinton's loss to President Donald Trump in 2016. He claimed that the media's portrayal of the Democratic voter base as more liberal and left-leaning is inaccurate.

When asked about the rise of progressive Democrats and the "Democratic socialist" wing of the party, Biden demurred, stating, "You guys got it all wrong about what happened. It’s just bad judgment. You all thought that what happened was the party moved extremely to the left after Hillary. AOC was a new party. She’s a bright, wonderful person. But where’s the party? Come on, man."

Biden also suggested that Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) appeal to a narrow segment of voters who are more vocal but do not represent the Democratic base as a whole. He stated, "The party’s not there. The party’s not there at all," referring to where Warren and Sanders fall on the political spectrum. Biden reportedly added that he believes both Warren and Sanders have misread Democratic voters and are appealing to the wrong segment of primary voters.

Biden's comments are not new, as he has long maintained that he is a more moderate choice for the Democratic nominee. However, this is a significant development in that Biden has mentioned Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez by name, calling out the up-and-coming "Democratic socialist" wing of the party directly, and suggesting that members of the "squad" and their allies are a small segment of a larger Democratic party and not the future of the Democratic party as Ocasio-Cortez and her Justice Democrats insist.

Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez seem to be presiding over a static element of the Democratic Party, and both Sanders and Warren are vying for the same group of potential primary voters—mostly young, white, highly educated voters in urban centers. However, until now, most of the candidates targeting the middle—Biden and South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg, included—have resisted the urge to suggest the progressive left isn't part of the party.

The good news for Biden is that his newfound opposition to a leftward moving party may play well with voters in early primary states like Iowa, South Carolina, and Nevada, where progressive ideas, like Medicare for All, don't seem to be resonating with voters.

Title: Obama Urges House to Approve Comprehensive Immigration Reform

Article:

President Barack Obama has called on House lawmakers to approve comprehensive immigration reform, stating that the current system is "not fair." In a speech on Thursday, he expressed his belief that it is the right time to address the issue and urged lawmakers to "go get it done."

The president's call comes as the legislative calendar is short for him to get his priorities acted on this year, following a 16-day government shutdown. House Republican leaders have indicated they still intend to hold an immigration debate this year, but they do not plan to take up the comprehensive reform plan approved by the Senate.

The Senate bill, which grants a pathway to citizenship for an estimated 11 million illegal immigrants, is supported by President Obama, who believes it would be beneficial for the economy and the country. He urged Republican leaders to disregard the politics of the issue and take action.

"I'm not running for office again; I just believe this is the right thing to do," Mr. Obama said. "What we can't do is just sweep the problem under the rug one more time. Let's not delay, and let's do it in a bipartisan fashion."

Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, has expressed opposition to the president's wishes, with his spokesman, Brendan Buck, stating that the House will not consider "any massive, Obamacare-style legislation that no one understands." Instead, the House is committed to a "common sense, step-by-step approach" to immigration reform.

The spokesman added that the House is working towards a reform that would boost the economy and that they hope the president will work with them, not against them, as they pursue this approach.

Title: MIT Media Lab Director Resigns Amid Epstein Donation Scandal

Article:

In an email sent on Saturday to MIT's provost, Joi Ito, the director of the Media Lab, announced his resignation as director, professor, and employee of the Institute, effective immediately. The resignation follows an article in The New Yorker detailing the Media Lab's efforts to conceal its relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, a convicted sex offender.

The internal emails, shared with The New York Times by a former Media Lab employee, reveal the handling of donations made and solicited by Epstein over the years, including a $2 million gift from Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. In an email from October 2014, six years after Epstein's conviction, Ito wrote that the gift from Gates was "directed by Jeffrey Epstein." A development official at the Media Lab, Peter Cohen, wrote in a subsequent email, "For gift recording purposes, we will not be mentioning Jeffrey’s name as the impetus for this gift."

In a statement, a spokesperson for Gates stated that Epstein was introduced to Gates as a person interested in increasing philanthropy. The statement further clarified that Epstein did not direct any programmatic or personal grant-making for Gates and that any claim to the contrary is false.

Gates, one of the world's richest men and most generous philanthropists, is among several powerful individuals facing scrutiny for their connections to Epstein. This list includes President Trump, former President Bill Clinton, Britain's Prince Andrew, high-profile scientists, business executives, and financiers such as Leslie Wexner, the CEO of L Brands, and Leon Black, the founder of Apollo Global Management. R. Alexander Acosta, a former federal prosecutor involved in the 2008 plea agreement with Epstein, stepped down as labor secretary after the deal was heavily criticized.

Title: COVID-19 Patients Face Mental Health Risks Due to Hospital Isolation

Article:

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has filled hospitals with critically ill patients, has led to another challenge for some survivors: mental health issues. The stress, loneliness, and fear experienced by patients, often magnified by invasive treatment procedures, place them at a high risk for disorders such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), according to some medical experts.

Loneliness, a combination of thinking, feeling, and behaving, can affect everyone during a pandemic, as many people maintain physical distance from each other. Ami Rokach, a clinical psychologist and psychology teacher at York University in Toronto, states that loneliness can have a significant impact on psychological and physical health.

However, there are some indications that people's resilience and increased use of communication technology may be helping to lessen the broader impact of the pandemic on loneliness, according to Martina Luchetti, an assistant professor at Florida State University College of Medicine. While further research is needed, Luchetti's recent study found that distancing measures did not increase loneliness in the general public as expected.

For COVID-19 patients, the situation is different. With the exception of giving birth, many hospitals do not allow adults to bring a support person due to fears of infection and a limited supply of personal protective equipment. Martha A.Q. Curley, a professor of pediatric nursing at the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing, describes the situation as "heart-wrenching" to watch, as people who have lived together for decades cannot be with their loved ones when they are ill, transition through the illness, or when they die.

Some COVID-19 survivors may experience PTSD, which can last for years without treatment. Anthony King, a professor of psychiatry and psychology at the University of Michigan, explains that most people feel anxiety with the uncertainty of COVID-19, but some experience PTSD due to trauma and a "threat to life or threat to physical integrity."

The chance that someone may experience PTSD may be exacerbated by patient isolation while fighting the disease. Long-term studies of past serious outbreaks found PTSD is much higher in patients than in the general population. In one study, one-fourth of 90 SARS patients had PTSD 30 months after the outbreak, and 15.6% had a depressive disorder.

Research has shown that many Intensive Care Unit (ICU) survivors experience trauma, particularly with procedures like intubation. Curley also points out that reports of post-intensive care syndrome are growing after patients with COVID-19 are discharged, which can be further complicated by the fact that family members do not know what the patient went through.

Four doctors argue in a New England Journal of Medicine perspective piece that new guidelines should enable more regular telecommunication between isolated patients and their families. Curley suggests steps can be taken to safely allow a family member into the ICU with a COVID-19 patient. Family facilitators can help with the careful screening, preparation, and support needed to undertake this goal, she says.

"We need to think of ways to make this happen. It will be different within each system, it will be different with each patient, but we ought to not just create a rule that families are not allowed," Curley adds.

In conclusion, isolated and faced with uncertainty and fear, some COVID-19 patients are at risk for trauma that experts say should be screened for and addressed at all stages of healthcare.

Title: AP Declares Hillary Clinton Winner of Democratic Primaries; Sanders Accuses Media of Rushing Judgment

Article:

The Associated Press has declared former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton the winner of Tuesday's Democratic presidential primaries, citing her acquisition of the 2,383 delegates required to clinch the party's nomination. The announcement was made before the primaries began, with superdelegates tipping the scale in Clinton's favor.

Clinton, in a speech to supporters, expressed gratitude for the support and urged voters to cast their ballots in the six states holding primaries on Tuesday, including California, the largest. "We're going to come out of the primary even stronger to take on Donald Trump," she said.

Senator Bernie Sanders' campaign, however, has accused the media of prematurely declaring Clinton the winner. Michael Briggs, Sanders' spokesperson, stated, "It is wrong to count the votes of superdelegates before they actually vote at the convention this summer. Secretary Clinton does not have and will not have the requisite number of pledged delegates to secure the nomination."

Sanders' campaign has vowed to spend the time until the convention, on July 25, attempting to convince superdelegates that he is the stronger candidate. Despite the apparent shift in momentum, Sanders' influence on the Democratic Party remains significant, particularly on economic issues and the Israel-Palestine conflict.

Sanders has advocated for changes in the Democratic Party's platform, including explicit references to the Israeli occupation of Palestinian lands and recognition of a Palestinian state. He has also appointed pro-Palestinian representatives to the platform committee, including those who support the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement, which aims to delegitimize the Jewish state.

The potential changes in the party's platform have sparked controversy, with pro-Israel Democrats expressing concern that such changes would be met with resistance. However, recent data from the Pew Research Center suggests a shift in sympathies among liberal Democrats, with a majority now sympathizing with the Palestinians for the first time in a decade.

This division could lead to a contentious fight at the Democratic National Convention over the party's stance on the Israel-Palestine conflict. Even without such a fight, the growing divide among Democrats could indicate a potential shift in the party's support towards greater sympathy for Palestinians and potentially less support for Israel in the future.

Title: Wildfires in Australia's East Coast Trapped Residents, Caused Fatalities and Destroyed Properties

Article:

Wildfires burning across Australia's two most populous states, Victoria and New South Wales, trapped residents of the seaside town of Mallacoota in apocalyptic conditions on Tuesday, December 31, 2019. The fires, which are feared to have destroyed many properties and caused fatalities, have been a devastating part of Australia's fire season that started early due to an unusually warm and dry winter.

About 4,000 residents in Mallacoota, located in Victoria state, fled towards the water Tuesday morning as winds pushed an emergency-level wildfire towards their homes. The smoke-filled sky shrouded the town in darkness before turning an unnerving shade of bright red.

As of Tuesday, approximately 5 million hectares (12.35 million acres) of land have burned nationwide over the past few months, with 12 people confirmed dead and more than 1,000 homes destroyed. Nearly 100 fires were burning across the state of New South Wales, which is home to Sydney.

New South Wales state Rural Fire Services Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons described this wildfire season as the worst on record and painted a bleak long-term picture. "We've seen extraordinary fire behavior," he said Tuesday. "What we really need is meaningful rain, and we haven't got anything in the forecast at the moment that says we're going to get drought-breaking or fire-quenching rainfall."

The wildfire crisis has reignited debate about whether Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative government has taken enough action on climate change. Australia is the world's largest exporter of coal and liquefied natural gas.

Morrison, who has been criticized as a climate change skeptic, conceded earlier this month that "climate change, along with many other factors," has contributed to the wildfires. The prime minister faced criticism for going on a family vacation to Hawaii in December during the crisis. He eventually cut his trip short and publicly apologized.

Late Tuesday, Mallacoota was saved by changes of wind direction, but authorities said "numerous" homes were lost. Residents returning home were urged to boil tap water before drinking it. Forest Fire Management Victoria said the wildfires had put heavy demands on tap water that is affecting the supply of water.

Stranded residents and vacationers were reported to be sleeping in cars on New Year's Eve, while gas stations and surf clubs transformed into evacuation areas. Victoria state Premier Daniel Andrews had earlier announced plans to evacuate the trapped people by sea. There were grave fears for four missing people. "We can't confirm their whereabouts," Andrews told reporters Tuesday.

Andrews has requested assistance from 70 firefighters from the United States and Canada, while Australia's military sent air and sea reinforcements. Victoria Emergency Services Commissioner Andrew Crisp confirmed "significant" property losses across the region. More than 115 communities across Victoria remained under emergency warnings Tuesday night.

Some communities canceled New Year's fireworks celebrations, but Sydney's popular display over its iconic harbor controversially went ahead in front of more than a million revelers. The city was granted an exemption to a total fireworks ban in place there and elsewhere to prevent new wildfires.

Fire conditions in Victoria and New South Wales worsened after oppressive heat Monday mixed with strong winds and lightning. Police in New South Wales said Tuesday that two men—a 63-year-old father and 29-year-old son—died in a house in the wildfire-ravaged southeast town of Cobargo, and a 72-year-old man remained missing.

"They were obviously trying to do their best with the fire as it came through in the early hours of the morning," New South Wales Police Deputy Commissioner Gary Worboys said. "The other person that we are trying to get to, we think that person was trying to defend their property in the early hours of the morning."

On Monday, a firefighter was killed when extreme winds flipped his truck. Samuel McPaul, 28, was the third volunteer firefighter in New South Wales to have died in the past two weeks. He was an expectant father.

More than 130 fires remain burning across New South Wales, with five at an emergency level. Authorities warned that power would be out for 24 hours along the fire-ravaged south coast of the state.

Title: Vice Presidential Debate: Biden and Ryan Prepare for a Substantive Showdown

Article:

As the vice presidential debate between Vice President Joe Biden and Representative Paul Ryan approaches, anticipation mounts for the highly anticipated event taking place tonight in Danville, Kentucky. The debate, which will likely be widely watched, serves as an important table-setter ahead of the second presidential debate on Tuesday in New York.

The pressure is particularly intense on Vice President Joe Biden, following President Barack Obama's lackluster performance in last week's presidential debate, which moved Republican nominee Mitt Romney into a national polling lead. Republicans have been eagerly anticipating this confrontation for months, believing that Ryan, the Republican ticket's No. 2, has the intellectual firepower to make gaffe-prone Biden appear foolish.

Democrats, on the other hand, believe Biden will come well-prepared and be able to expose what they see as the duplicity of the Romney-Ryan ticket, which has appeared to shift positions in recent days on issues such as abortion, education, and tax policy.

The vice presidential debates are often quickly forgotten, but this one will likely be widely watched and at the very least serve as an important table-setter in advance of the second presidential debate. "It will be very substantive, with probably two of the most substantive vice presidential candidates we've ever had," says David Carney, a Republican consultant. "I think Biden's performance, in an ironic way, will put more pressure on [President] Obama for the next debate."

Four years ago, the vice presidential debate between Biden and Republican Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska actually drew higher TV ratings than any of that year's presidential debates. This one also will draw considerable attention.

Biden's task tonight is different from what it was four years ago. Then, he essentially ignored Palin in favor of attacking Arizona Sen. John McCain, the GOP nominee. This time, he'll still want to concentrate most of his fire on the other party's presidential candidate, but he will doubtless also use Ryan as a target. As the House Budget Committee chairman, Ryan is the architect of a spending plan that Democrats warn would gut domestic programs and threaten entitlements such as Medicare.

"Where Gov. Romney muddied the water, I think the vice president will try to clarify it," says Jared Bernstein, who served as an economic adviser to Biden in the White House. "He's going to link the political agendas and the policy agendas so the electorate has a much better understanding than they did from the first debate."

Since his selection as running mate, Ryan has served as the loyal soldier, shying away from some of the implications of his own budget and declaring that Romney sets the policy for the ticket. But if Democrats accuse the Republicans of duplicity, Republicans counter that Democrats have mismanaged the economy and do not have a record worth running on and so are relying on scare tactics.

The vice presidential debate will be a strong contrast between Paul Ryan's actuarial style and Joe Biden's storytelling, tell-it-like-it-is campaign style. Ryan, who was born two years before Biden was first elected to the Senate, needs to show he has some "gravitas," says David Yepsen, director of a public policy institute at Southern Illinois University Carbondale. Republicans from Romney on down have tried to downplay expectations for Ryan's performance in recent days, pointing out that he has not engaged in a campaign debate since he first ran for Congress 14 years ago.

Ted Kaufman, a longtime Biden aide who succeeded him in the Senate after his ascension to the vice presidency, says Ryan will be ready. "Ryan will do a good job," Kaufman says. "Anyone who has been a member of Congress for 14 years knows how to present their positions well and how to challenge the positions of the other side."

Title: Russian Forces Allegedly Involved in Eastern Ukraine Offensive, Escalating Tensions

Article:

Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko convened an emergency security meeting today as pro-Russia rebels launched a new offensive in eastern Ukraine. The escalation comes amid mounting evidence of direct Russian military involvement in the conflict.

The town of Novoazovsk, previously unaffected by the violence, was shelled hours after a landmark meeting between the Russian and Ukrainian presidents on Tuesday. Pro-Russian rebels reportedly drove Ukrainian forces out of the town on Wednesday, with some Ukrainian soldiers in full retreat and refusing to fight. Associated Press reporters were barred by separatists from entering Novoazovsk today.

The new southeastern front raises concerns that the separatists may be attempting to create a land link between Russia and the annexed Crimea Peninsula. If successful, it could give them or Russia control over the entire Sea of Azov and the gas and mineral riches believed to be contained within. Ukraine has already lost approximately half its coastline, several major ports, and significant Black Sea mineral rights following Russia's annexation of Crimea in March.

In Mariupol, a city of 450,000 about 30 kilometers (20 miles) to the west, a brigade of Ukrainian forces arrived at the airport Wednesday afternoon, while deep trenches were dug on the city's edge a day earlier.

The BBC reports that the incursion could serve as a means to divert Ukrainian troops from Luhansk and Donetsk, where they have made headway against pro-Russian separatists in recent months.

Ukraine accused Russia this week of sending heavy weaponry into southern Ukraine to aid pro-Russian rebels. National security spokesman Col. Andriy Lysenko stated that Russian soldiers crossed as far as 30 miles beyond the border in armored personnel carriers and a truck this week.

The prime minister of the self-declared Donetsk People’s Republic acknowledged today that there are Russian servicemen fighting alongside pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine. Alexander Zakharchenko claimed there are between 3,000 and 4,000 Russian volunteers fighting with the rebels, with some being retired Russian military personnel.

Accusations of direct Russian involvement in Ukraine have prompted Western governments to impose sanctions against Russia, despite Moscow's repeated denials. Russia refers to the crisis in Ukraine as a national issue that must be resolved internally.

The Obama administration this week accused Russia of moving artillery and air defenses to aid pro-Russia separatists in Ukraine. "These incursions indicate a Russian-directed counteroffensive is likely underway," said Jen Psaki, the State Department spokeswoman. Psaki criticized Russia's "unwillingness to tell the truth" about its military's role in Ukrainian territory.

International leaders, including those from France, Germany, and NATO officials, have expressed alarm. "I think there's a shift here that we may be witnessing, very recently, from largely covert, ambiguous, deniable support to what appears increasingly to be flat-out, overt and obvious [support], and with the only form of ambiguity being that the Russians... claim it is not happening," a NATO diplomat told reporters in Brussels on the condition of anonymity.

NATO officials are expected to give a briefing today on the situation in Ukraine. French President François Hollande stated this week that if Russian soldiers are in Ukraine, "it would be intolerable and unacceptable." German Chancellor Angela Merkel called Russian President Vladimir Putin for clarification on the Kremlin's involvement.

"The latest reports of the presence of Russian soldiers on Ukrainian territory must be explained," Merkel spokesman Steffen Seibert said of the call. "She [Merkel] emphasized Russia's major responsibility for de-escalation and watching over its own frontiers."

A report by the UN found that the death toll in eastern Ukraine over the past month grew to at least 36 people killed each day. An estimated 2,200 people have died since the conflict began in April, according to the UN.

Title: Poll Results and the Tight Presidential Race Between Obama and Romney

Article:

A recent poll indicates that 57 percent of likely voters believe America is in decline, with a significant plurality believing the country has worsened over the past years. Despite this, the race between President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, remains tied.

The poll, as reported by Chris Stirewalt, digital politics editor for ███, shows that Obama is upside down on his overall job approval and lags on his handling of the economy, the number one issue this year by 12 points. By an almost 20-point margin, respondents said they would rather the federal government leave them alone than lend them a hand.

When asked whether it was fair to say Obama wants to make Americans more dependent on the government, 53 percent said yes, and only 44 percent said no. This is a dire slate for any incumbent Democrat, particularly bad for one whose major liabilities relate to spending too much and intervening too much while failing to revive the consistently crummy economy.

The race's tightness is surprising given the poll results, as Obama's major liabilities are well-defined. The effort to define Romney has been nearly as successful, with the central emphasis of the Obama campaign being to make Romney an unacceptable alternative.

The poll reveals that 10 percent of respondents are undecided or have rejected the major party choices. This group strongly disapproves of the president's performance but doesn't seem very pleased with the GOP nominee either. While Obama suffers a 12-point deficit on personal favorability among these voters, Romney's rating stands at a whopping negative 28 points.

Every re-election campaign is about the electorate answering two questions: Do we want to keep the guy we have, and is the person running to replace him a plausible pick?
