As we prepare for the two-week convention kick-off for the fall campaign, it is clear that Obama has failed the first question. With 74 days until the election, there isn't a way for the president to turn public sentiment in favor of his administration.

The president and his team have focused on personal attacks on Romney for nearly five months. As Vice President Joe Biden often says, "Don't compare us to the almighty, compare us to the alternative." The central emphasis of the Obama campaign has been to make Romney an unacceptable alternative. But given all of the slashing and bashing so far, Romney is still hanging on.

Respondents in the poll were 6 points less inclined to believe Romney wanted to make the rich richer but neglect everyone else – a charge that is the ethos of the Obama campaign – than they were the Republican charge that Obama is seeking greater government dependency.

The other big knock on Romney is that he is more interested in political expedience than principle. While nearly 60 percent said Romney would "say and do just about anything to get elected," Obama scored just as poorly.

The danger for the president is that he has succeeded in his goal of stoking resentment against Romney, but he has also made himself into a very typical politician in the eyes of the electorate. This creates a scenario in which fed-up moderates and independents declare a pox on the houses of both candidates and sit out the election.

Obama has been seeking this kind of base-versus-base election and his long, negative campaign has helped shove people into their respective camps sooner than usual. The president's team believes that the power of incumbency combined with a superior turnout operation will allow them to win a narrow victory.

However, the alarming sign for the blue team is this: The president has failed to close the voter intensity gap for month after month. Romney supporters lead Obama supporters 64 percent to 54 percent on the question of whether it is "extremely important" for their candidate to win. In a tie race, that would mean victory for Romney.

The president is trying to ring as many alarms for Democrats as he can. Talking about abortion is a risk for Democrats, who have seen public sentiment move away from their support for elective abortions. But Obama needs to get his voters marching. Maybe not the way they were in 2008, but enough not to get badly out-hustled.

For Romney, the next week is all about reintroducing himself to a crabby and skeptical electorate. The first step came with his selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate, helping cast Romney as a serious man and a serious fiscal conservative. The effort continues today in a Wall Street Journal op-ed in which Romney told the story of his 25-year career as a corporate turnaround artist. He explained how he could use the same skills to remake the federal government, thereby stimulating the lagging economy. And it will continue through the next week and through his acceptance speech in Tampa on Thursday. The message will be the same one we always expected from Romney: competency, accomplishment, and steadiness. It's not sexy, but it's certainly a plausible presidential pedigree. Obama failed to land the kill shot on Romney before this final phase of the campaign begins. If he wants to win, Romney needs to make the most of the next week.

Title: Philippines Impounds North Korean Freighter in Response to Global Sanctions Over Nuclear Test and Missile Launch

Article:

The Philippine government has impounded a North Korean freighter, the Jin Teng, in Subic Bay and plans to deport its crew, according to the official Philippines News Agency. This action comes in response to North Korea's recent nuclear test and missile launch, and the subsequent global community's imposition of new sanctions.

The United Nations Security Council voted this week to impose an array of new sanctions in response to what it called "violation and flagrant disregard" of previous resolutions. The vote was unanimous, including from longtime North Korean foes such as the United States and Japan, as well as Russia and China, who have been less adversarial to the regime.

Resolution 2270 mandates that other countries "should inspect cargo within or transiting through their territory—including airports, sea ports, and free trade zones—that was destined for or originating from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea." It also makes special mention of calling out any "evasion of sanctions" by various parties.

The Jin Teng is one of 31 vessels operated by Ocean Maritime Management, which is named in the U.N. resolution as being "subject to the asset freeze." Documents show that all 21 of the Sierra Leone-flagged ship's crew are North Korean nationals.

The freighter arrived Thursday in Subic Bay from Indonesia with a load of palm kernels, according to state news. Coast guardsmen also found minor safety violations like faulty emergency light bulbs, a lack of fire hoses, corroded air vents, and inadequate accommodations for crew, according to Philippines Coast Guard spokesman Armand Balilo.

A team from the United Nations may also inspect the Jin Teng, according to Quezon. Regardless, the Philippine government will report its findings to that world body.

Such actions—this ship seizure, specifically, and stronger sanctions, generally—seem to have done little to deter North Korea's muscle flexing, bellicose talk, and nuclear ambitions.

North Korea has continued and, if anything, escalated its threat to potentially deploy a nuclear weapon. On Friday, state news agency KCNA reported that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said his country's "nuclear warheads need to be ready for use at any time."

This rhetoric came out a day after the news agency reported tests of a new multiple-launch rocket system. The extent to which these tests refer to a launch of "short-range projectiles" chronicled one day earlier by the South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff is unclear.

Pyongyang has long boasted about its nuclear ambitions, as long as countries like South Korea and the United States have sought to derail them. The issue has only furthered the isolation of North Korea, a communist, closed-off state led for decades by the authoritarian Kim, his late father, and his grandfather.

A chief concern is not only that Pyongyang will develop effective nuclear warheads but that they'll pair them with missiles that can strike targets around East Asia and perhaps beyond. North Korea has even repeatedly threatened to attack the United States, including saying last August that it would do so "with tremendous muscle." A state television report in 2015 mentioned that such strikes could reach the American mainland.

There are strong doubts North Korea currently has the technology to mate a nuclear warhead to a missile that could travel 5,000 miles and hit the U.S. West Coast. However, much is still unknown about Pyongyang's military potential, and there's no disputing its bravado.

One anti-nuclear advocate thinks a lot of the talk is intended for internal consumption, to help Kim consolidate power, and is not proof of his military's abilities. "To me, right now, it's a lot of bluster," said Philip Yun, executive director of the Ploughshares Fund, a group that calls for nuclear disarmament. "For them to deliver on a threat, they have to have intent and they have to have capability. And quite frankly, I do not think they have both."

Title: Former President Obama's Speaking Fees Under Scrutiny as Climate Change Address Fee Remains Unclear

Article:

Former President Barack Obama's speaking engagements have come under scrutiny as the fee for his upcoming climate change address in Milan remains undisclosed. The organization hosting the May 8-11 Italian summit, Seeds & Chips, and Obama's team have declined to reveal the amount he is being paid for the event.

While a publication estimated the total cost for all 3,500 tickets to the event on food innovation and climate change at a potential $3.2 million, this figure is believed to be the total cost for the tickets, not Obama's speaking fee. The Express replaced an earlier story with an updated one that made no mention of any speaking fee, and representatives for Obama did not respond to Fox News' request for comment. Michela Gelati, a spokesperson for Seeds & Chips, told Fox News that they did not have the information.

The secrecy surrounding Obama's potential payday comes after he raised eyebrows by signing on for two lucrative speaking engagements that seemed to contradict his image as a champion of the 99%. In late April, it was reported that Obama would receive $400,000 for a talk on healthcare at a Wall Street conference run by Cantor Fitzgerald, a big Wall Street firm.

Eric Schultz, a spokesman for Obama, defended the former president, stating, "With regard to this or any speech involving Wall Street sponsors, I'd just point out that in 2008 Barack Obama raised more money from Wall Street than any candidate in history -- and still went on to successfully pass and implement the toughest reforms on Wall Street since FDR."

Obama's spokesman added that the former president will continue to give the occasional speech but will devote much of his time to writing his book and "focusing his post-presidency work on training and elevating a new generation of political leaders in America."

Less than a week after news broke about his planned speech at the Cantor Fitzgerald conference, The New York Post reported that Obama was paid another $400,000 for his appearance at the A&E Networks advertising upfront at The Pierre Hotel in New York City.

While Obama's speaking fees may be nothing new for a former president, he has also come under scrutiny for allegedly using his tax-exempt Obama Foundation as a money generator. Critics warn that the operation is starting to look like the controversial Clinton Foundation, which took in tens of millions of dollars and sparked "pay-to-play" accusations. In an apparent effort to avoid such comparisons, Obama said in January that he would not accept contributions from for-profit entities, federal lobbyists, or foreign nationals or agents while in office.

It is not uncommon for former presidents to earn significant speaking fees after leaving the Oval Office. Harry Truman refused to give speeches for money and called the practice exploitative, but that did not stop Gerald Ford, who was the first president known to take advantage of the speaking circuit after leaving office in 1977, earning as much as $40,000 per speech. Bill Clinton, who normally charges between $250,000 and $500,000 per engagement, was paid a whopping $750,000 to give a talk in Hong Kong in 2011, while his successor, George W. Bush, has reportedly made somewhere between $20 million and $35 million in speaking fees since he left office in 2009. Shortly after leaving office in 1989, Ronald Reagan was paid around $2 million to go on a speaking tour of Japan.

Title: Harry Reid Plans 2016 Reelection Bid Amidst Republican Anticipation

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) has announced his intention to run for reelection in 2016, three years ahead of the scheduled election. This announcement comes as Republicans eagerly anticipate the November 2016 elections, marking the end of President Barack Obama's tenure.

Reid, a controversial figure among Republicans due to his inflammatory rhetoric and hardball tactics during the government shutdown, is reportedly preparing for a potential onslaught from the GOP. In an interview last week, the 73-year-old senator confirmed his plans to run for a sixth term.

The senator is reportedly ramping up his campaign organization and seeking commitments from aides to stay with him through 2016. He is also spending more time fundraising, traveling to locations such as New York and Southern California. If GOP Governor Brian Sandoval of Nevada is reelected next year, he will be in the middle of a second term in 2016, potentially positioning him as a rival for Reid's Senate seat.

Reid warned a potential GOP opponent, stating, "If he wants to run midterm, let him. I would remind him and everybody else that doesn't work very well. Anytime anyone who is a governor leaves midterm, it just doesn't work very well."

Reid's polarizing nature has increased due to his pugnacious stance during the shutdown fight. His strategy has been successful in keeping Democrats together, a challenging task given the political climate. Removing him from his position as the powerful majority leader has become a leading Republican campaign pitch in the run-up to the 2014 midterms, two years before he will be the top GOP target in the country during his own race.

Whether Reid is merely posturing to avoid being viewed as a lame duck remains to be seen. He could ultimately change his mind and decide not to run for a sixth term. Alternatively, his decision could be influenced by changes in the political landscape, such as a potential Republican takeover of the Senate in 2014 or the loss of his majority leader title, which he has held for over six years.

Reid is optimistic about Democrats' prospects in 2014, even believing the party may gain seats next year. He attributes the Republicans' handling of the government shutdown as a factor in the GOP's weakening position.

When asked if he was bluffing about running in 2016, Reid responded, "I guarantee you that I haven't spent all that money [just] to show strength during the shutdown. To have a campaign operation that I have is not easy."

Thanks to August fundraising swings in Nevada's Lake Tahoe and Las Vegas, as well as Southern California, Reid's campaign and political action committee account raised over $600,000 in the third quarter, surpassing the $407,000 he raised during a similar period in 2010. At a similar point in the last cycle, Reid had raised $5.6 million, compared to the $5.5 million he has raised so far this cycle.

Despite the potential for an even stronger GOP target in 2016 than in 2010, when Reid managed to secure a victory despite suffering low approval ratings and a national Republican effort to oust him, Reid is expected to remain a significant target for the GOP. Reid has been criticized for his constant derision of the Republican party, using words like "extreme" and "anarchists" to describe conservative Republicans in the House and Senate. He has also been vocal in his criticism of the GOP's relentless drive to dismantle Obamacare.

Reid's tactics during the shutdown fight have further solidified his status as a thorn in the side of the GOP. Reid has publicly disclosed private conversations he had with House Speaker John Boehner to make the case that the Ohio Republican had backed off an earlier agreement to pass a government funding bill with no policy restrictions attached. After Boehner publicly demanded killing federal dollars for health coverage of lawmakers and their staff, a series of private emails between top Reid and Boehner aides were leaked to the media, detailing Boehner's secret maneuvering for those very same subsidies.

Not only has Reid ridiculed the GOP strategy to tie Obamacare to the shutdown fight, but he has also refused to schedule votes on House GOP bills to fund popular agencies and programs one at a time. Additionally, despite Boehner's demands, Reid refuses to negotiate with Republicans until they agree to pass a Senate bill to keep the government open until mid-November.

These actions have driven Republicans to frustration, with Rep. Tom Rooney (R-FL) stating, "He's the most uncompromising politician I've encountered in the past five years. He's the guy more than anybody that thwarts progress." When asked about some of his rhetoric, Reid seemed to acknowledge his reputation for gaffes but was unapologetic about his tough talk.

Title: U.S. Economy Adds 288,000 Jobs in April, Unemployment Rate Drops to 6.3%

Article:

The U.S. economy added 288,000 jobs in April, marking the strongest month for job growth in two years, according to the Department of Labor. This figure surpassed economists' forecasts, causing stocks to rise following the news, although they have since fallen back. The unemployment rate decreased to 6.3%, down from 6.7% in March.

The severe winter had previously hindered various economic statistics, including the housing market, retail sales, and manufacturing. The jobs numbers for February and March were revised higher on Friday, indicating that the economy has moved past the winter lull.

However, the unemployment rate, derived from a survey of households, paints a more discouraging picture. This data shows a decrease in the number of Americans joining the labor force and a decline in the number of people reporting employment. These trends led to the unemployment rate's decrease to 6.3%, its lowest level since September 2008.

A Department of Labor spokesperson noted that the drop in participation is not due to discouraged workers leaving the labor force, but rather to fewer young people entering the job market for the first time and more seniors retiring and staying that way. Participation also decreased among the prime working-age population, which is a concerning sign, according to Diane Swonk, chief economist for Mesirow Financial.

Economists advise against drawing overly optimistic conclusions from a single month of data. They emphasize that the big picture remains the same. The employment data can fluctuate from month to month, and while this month's report is above expectations, it is still consistent with the recent trends in the labor market.

The jobs recovery has been ongoing for four years, and long-term unemployment remains elevated, with 3.5 million people out of a job for six months or more. Economists estimate it could take at least another two years until the job market returns to its pre-recession health, when the unemployment rate was around 4% to 5%.

The positive aspect of the recovery is that it is now broad-based across many industries. For instance, professional and business services is one of the strongest sectors for job growth, adding 75,000 jobs in April and over 660,000 jobs over the past 12 months. Many of these jobs are likely to be office jobs paying mid- to high-level wages.

Retail, restaurants and bars—traditionally low-wage industries—have also experienced strong job growth, and blue-collar industries like manufacturing and construction are on the upswing. The only major sector that continues to cut jobs is the federal government, which has reduced 83,000 positions over the past 12 months.

Title: Sen. Dianne Feinstein Discusses Potential Hillary Clinton Presidency and Foreign Policy Expertise

Article:

In a recent interview on CNN's "State of the Union," Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) discussed the potential presidency of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and her foreign policy expertise. While not issuing a formal endorsement, Feinstein expressed her belief that a Clinton presidency would result in a top foreign policy expert in the White House.

When asked about the recent comments by Karl Rove regarding Clinton's health, Feinstein called Rove's questioning of Clinton's cognitive abilities a "pathetic" attempt to sway voters against the most talked-about Democratic Party candidate for 2016.

When Candy Crowley, the interviewer, pressed on the legitimacy of Rove's underlying question about Clinton's health, Feinstein responded, according to Mediaite, "That she has sustained brain damage? That's legitimate?... In my view, she's in the prime of her political life. She has all the elements of a good leader, plus the fact—and this is not to be underestimated—she is enormously attractive to people. She carries the torch for women, who are the majority of votes in this country, very strongly and holds it very high. I think people respond to her."

Feinstein then referenced Clinton's upcoming book as a means of highlighting her foreign policy background. "I think the book will likely carry a good bit of her thinking on various big issues, certainly foreign policy, certainly the Secretary of State, and we would have someone in the White House who would have a real background in foreign policy," Feinstein said, according to Mediaite.

"I think that's critical at this point in the world with Russia expanding, with Africa becoming real problems from a terror point of view, and on and on and on," she added. The specifics of Clinton's book and its contents were not discussed in the interview.

Title: Testimony of Fiona Hill and Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman: U.S.-Ukraine Relations and Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

In March 2019, the situation at the U.S. embassy in Ukraine and U.S.-Ukraine relations underwent significant changes. The priorities of security, economy, and justice, as well as U.S. support for Ukrainian democratic resistance to Russian aggression, were overshadowed by a political agenda promoted by former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani and a group of officials with a direct channel to the White House.

During a hearing, Fiona Hill, a former National Security Council (NSC) senior director for Europe and Russia, stated that some members of the committee seemed to believe that Russia and its security services did not conduct a campaign against the U.S. in 2016, and that Ukraine may have been responsible for the attack. Hill emphasized that this narrative was a fictional one, perpetrated and propagated by the Russian security services.

Hill also mentioned that the hold on the security assistance may have been lifted, but there were still unfulfilled demands, such as a meeting with the president in the Oval Office. She added that this situation might still persist.

Regarding Rudy Giuliani's actions, Hill stated that his remarks were explosive and incendiary, and that he was pushing forward issues and ideas that would likely cause problems for the U.S. She also mentioned a confrontation with Ambassador Sondland and expressed her irritation with him for not coordinating effectively.

Hill was asked about the accusations against Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, who served as a National Security Council (NSC) expert on Ukraine. In response, Hill stated that she and her colleagues felt it was deeply unfair to suggest that Vindman, as an immigrant, was not loyal to America.

During the hearing, Hill also discussed a conversation with Ambassador Sondland, in which he proposed a deal involving a meeting with the president in exchange for Ukraine announcing investigations into 2016 and Burisma. Hill cut off the deal when she realized that Burisma was a code for the Bidens, as Giuliani was promoting this narrative publicly.

When asked if her boss, Ambassador John Bolton, described Giuliani as a "hand grenade," Hill confirmed that he did. She explained that Bolton meant that Giuliani's actions and the narrative he was promoting would backfire.

The hearing concluded with Hill's statement that it was time for the ongoing impeachment inquiry to end, and she thanked the committee for their service. During the hearing, Hill was given the opportunity to respond, and she emphasized that all witnesses who testified under a legal obligation also felt a moral obligation to do so, and that they came as fact witnesses to ensure the American people could make informed choices in the 2020 presidential election without fear.

Title: YouTube Investing Mid-Six-Figure Sum in TYT's Digital-First Local News Online Course

Article:

Google-owned YouTube is investing a significant sum, reported to be in the mid-six-figures range, in The Young Turks (TYT) to launch an online course called TYT Academy. The course focuses on the creation of digital-first local news. This investment is part of YouTube's $25 million commitment to news efforts, which is part of the $300 million Google News Initiative announced in 2018.

As one of YouTube's most successful publishers with 4.6 million subscribers on its main account and millions of followers across its affiliated channels, TYT is a logical fit for this type of investment. The new class features a two-track video series, with each containing eight videos. Users will take short quizzes along the way, and must pass a final exam after completing each track to earn a TYT Academy certificate.

The first track covers journalism tactics and responsibilities, while the second track focuses on best practices for online video production across multiple online platforms, not just YouTube. For now, the course is in a trial period, with TYT planning to expand the program more broadly after first testing it with 10-15 people. The goal of the class is to engage everyday people in digital media so that they can help report on their local communities.

While TYT takes a strong progressive position as an outlet, Steven Oh, TYT’s Chief Business Officer and the creator of TYT Academy, told ███ on a phone call that TYT is "not interested in cranking out journalists who share our political viewpoint whatsoever."

Facebook has also invested in online news courses from publishers. In December, ███ reported that Facebook would be funding an online deepfakes course for newsrooms by Reuters. The videos for this course, which have been online for about two months, appear to be nonpartisan, but it's notable that YouTube is investing in a course from TYT, which has a progressive bent. Facebook has said that it will include partisan publishers like Breitbart in its news tab, but has not necessarily paid Breitbart. The company has not released a list of all of the publishers who are being paid.

Title: Idaho Wedding Chapel Owners Face Legal Action for Refusing to Perform Same-sex Weddings

Article:

Two Christian ministers, Donald and Evelyn Knapp, who own the Hitching Post Wedding Chapel in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, are facing potential legal action for refusing to perform same-sex weddings, according to a lawsuit filed in federal court on Friday. The Alliance Defending Freedom, a legal organization, is representing the Knapps.

The lawsuit states that the wedding chapel is registered with the state as a "religious corporation" limited to performing "one-man-one-woman marriages as defined by the Holy Bible." However, the chapel is also registered as a for-profit business, not as a church or place of worship. City officials argue that this means the owners must comply with a local nondiscrimination ordinance, which prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation and applies to housing, employment, and public accommodation.

City Attorney Warren Wilson reportedly told The Spokesman-Review in May that the Hitching Post Wedding Chapel would likely be required to follow the ordinance. He also told television station KXLY that any wedding chapel that turns away a gay couple would in theory be violating the law, potentially facing a misdemeanor citation.

According to the lawsuit, Wilson confirmed that even ordained ministers would be required to perform same-sex weddings if they refused. If they refused, Wilson reportedly told the ministers that they could be fined up to $1,000 and sentenced to up to 180 days in jail.

Until last week, gay marriage was not legal in Idaho. However, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit issued an order on May 13 allowing same-sex marriages to commence in Idaho on Oct. 15. Two days later, the Hitching Post received a telephone call inquiring about a same-sex wedding ceremony, which they declined, putting them in violation of the law. City officials did not respond to requests for an interview or to requests from local news outlets.

"The government should not force ordained ministers to act contrary to their faith under threat of jail time and criminal fines," said Jeremy Tedesco, the ADF attorney representing the Knapps. "The city is on seriously flawed legal ground, and our lawsuit intends to ensure that this couple's freedom to adhere to their own faith as pastors is protected, just as the First Amendment intended."

Alliance Defending Freedom also filed a temporary restraining order to stop the city from enforcing the ordinance. "The Knapps are in fear that if they exercise their First Amendment rights they will be cited, prosecuted, and sent to jail," Tedesco said.

The lawsuit comes at a time when similar incidents are occurring across the country, with the city of Houston issuing subpoenas demanding that five Christian pastors turn over sermons dealing with homosexuality and gender identity.

"Government officials are making clear they will use their government power to punish those who oppose the advances of homosexual activists," said Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council. "Americans are witnesses to the reality that redefining marriage is less about the marriage altar and more about fundamentally altering the freedoms of the other 98 percent of Americans."

The incidents in Houston and Coeur d'Alene are the latest examples of a disturbing trend in the culture war, with direct attacks on clergy. "Government officials are making clear they will use their government power to punish those who oppose the advances of homosexual activists," Perkins said. "No one should be discriminated against, but have you noticed that any time a city passes a 'nondiscrimination' ordinance, it's the Christians who wind up being discriminated against?"

Title: Nancy Reagan, Wife of 40th President Ronald Reagan, Passes Away at 94

Article:

Nancy Reagan, the wife of the 40th President of the United States, Ronald Reagan, has passed away at the age of 94, according to TMZ. Known as Mrs. Ronald Reagan, she was a close confidant and played a significant role in her husband's career and presidency.

When Ronald Reagan died in 2004, an ABC News report stated that "their love story has always been a part of the presidential story." The New York Times described Mrs. Reagan as a "fierce guardian of her husband's image, sometimes at the expense of her own."

Reagan biographer Craig Shirley wrote in his book Last Act: The Final Years and Enduring Legacy of Ronald Reagan, "They were best friends and soul mates, and his letters over the years left no doubt as to the depth of their mutual love." Shirley once said in an interview, "Mrs. Reagan was a balm to him, and he hated being on the road without her. His diaries recount on several occasions how much he missed her when she was traveling."

The world may not have had the man who won the Cold War if it was not for the driving force of Nancy in his life. Michael Deaver, a Ronald Reagan aide, once said, "Without Nancy, there would have been no Governor Reagan, no President Reagan."

Ronald and Nancy Reagan met in 1949 when Ronald was the head of the Screen Actors Guild. They married three years later, and their bond was deep and a driving force behind Ronald Reagan's relentless and successful political career.

When Ronald Reagan was diagnosed with Alzheimer's in 1994, Nancy became his primary caretaker until his death in 2004. Throughout that time, she remained a guardian of his legacy.

Today, the nation mourns the loss of Nancy Reagan, a true example of integrity and grace. Politicians and public figures, including Marco Rubio, Mark R. Levin, John McCain, Rep. David Schweikert, Governor Walker, Ted Cruz, Mitt Romney, Donald J. Trump, Jim Webb, Nikki Haley, Reince Priebus, Lindsey Graham, Senator John Thune, Jon Huntsman, Hugh Hewitt, and Steve Forbes, have expressed their condolences and shared their memories of Nancy Reagan on social media.

Nancy Reagan's passing serves as a timely reminder of how toxic our politics have become, as stated by Jon Huntsman. Her life and legacy will continue to inspire Americans for generations to come.

Title: White House and Presidential Candidates Face Criticism Over Pay Equity

Article:

In a demonstration of equal pay for women on Tuesday, President Barack Obama declared the day as National Equal Pay Day, symbolizing the number of days a woman needs to work in a year to earn as much as her male counterpart did in the previous year. The President stated that on average, full-time working women earn 78 cents for every dollar earned by men, with women of color facing a more significant disparity.

However, an analysis of White House salaries from last July revealed a 13% pay gap between male and female staffers, with female staffers earning less on average. During her time in the U.S. Senate, Hillary Clinton, a leading presidential contender, also faced criticism for paying women in her office 72 cents for each dollar paid to men, according to an analysis by the Washington Free Beacon. The report found a gender gap of 28% between the median annual salary for female staffers and men between 2002 and 2008.

Supporters of Clinton argue that she was a consistent advocate for equal-pay legislation in the Senate and was an original sponsor of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act, signed by President Obama in 2009 to expand workers' rights to take pay discrimination cases to court.

Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz stated Tuesday that Democrats are "proud to fight for equal pay every single day." In 2009, women at the White House were paid on average $72,700, while male staffers were paid $82,000. By 2014, women staffers earned $78,400, compared to the average male salaries of $88,600. White House aides have stated that men and women staffers who hold the same job description are paid the same, but there are more men in higher-paying jobs.

The Democratic National Committee (DNC) attacked GOP presidential candidates on Tuesday over their pay-equity policies, criticizing former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, former Texas Gov. Rick Perry, Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, and others for either downplaying the importance of the issue or enacting policies that were said to be unfavorable to female workers.

In Congress, Democrats are offering the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would allow employees to share information about their pay and file lawsuits against an employer. On the Republican side, a coalition of four senators, led by Sen. Deb Fischer of Nebraska, has offered an amendment to the bill that would prohibit retaliation against employees for discussing salaries and provide grants to states to create industry-led partnerships to address disparities of opportunity.

Title: House Approves Strict Syrian and Iraqi Refugee Background Check Bill

Article:

The United States House of Representatives passed a bill on Thursday that aims to block Syrian and Iraqi refugees from entering the country unless they pass stringent background checks. The bill received near unanimous support from Republicans, with 47 Democrats also voting in favor, despite a last-minute effort by the Obama administration to persuade House Democrats to oppose the Republican-written bill.

With 289 "yes" votes, the bill secured a veto-proof majority for the measure, marking a significant loss for the White House, which has expressed concerns about the bill's potential impact on the refugee resettlement process. The vote was a rebuke of President Barack Obama by House Democrats who felt that the administration failed to make a compelling case for why they should vote against the Republican-authored bill, given the political implications of doing so.

New York Democrat Rep. Sean Patrick Maloney stated, "I think a lot of us went in with open minds and really wanted to understand the administration's position on this. It is offensive to me that we would stigmatize refugees...but if you read the bill, what you find is that you have a pretty simple certification process sitting on top of an existing and extensive screening process that most of us believe works pretty well."

The bill, known as the American Security Against Foreign Enemies Act, requires the FBI, Homeland Security Department, and the director of national intelligence to certify to Congress that any refugee from Syria or Iraq is "not a threat to the security of the United States" before being allowed to settle in the United States. President Obama has proposed allowing 10,000 Syrian refugees to enter the country this year, as part of the Western response to the wave of refugees fleeing Syria's bloody civil war and Islamic State-related violence.

The measure faces an uncertain future in the Senate, with Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) stating that the Syria bill will not make it to Obama's desk. Senators are likely to attempt to attach the measure as a rider to the government spending bill that Congress has to address in December.

Conservative House Republicans have signaled they will not vote to support December's so-called omnibus bill unless it includes beefed-up provisions for vetting Syrian refugees. Meanwhile, House Democrats are calling for a budget bill free of all contentious policy riders.

The final vote was 289-137, with House Democratic leaders urging their colleagues to oppose the legislation but not formally whipping votes. Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) made an informal whip count Wednesday night to gauge where the caucus stands.

The White House dispatched Chief of Staff Denis McDonough and Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson to Capitol Hill to speak with Democrats just hours before the House vote. However, their presentation did not receive wide support in the room, with multiple sources stating that the administration officials' "in the weeds" presentation did not sway many Democrats.

Rep. Scott Peters (D-Calif.), who voted for the bill, said he was not swayed by Johnson's pitch to Democrats that the Homeland Security Department doesn't have time to certify refugees. "If you look at the bill, it's hard to see how it's as awful as the administration is portraying it as," Peters said.

Rep. Gerry Connolly (D-Va.) stated that White House officials did not make an effective pitch during the meeting with Democrats, urging them to drop their opposition to the Republican bill. "It's one more assurance that those coming into the country are screened," Connolly said of the GOP-sponsored measure. "That seems to me not an imprudent measure under the circumstances."

Title: John Kasich's 2016 Presidential Campaign: A Look Back

Article:

John Kasich's 2016 presidential campaign, while not particularly successful, was a replay of former Utah Governor Jon Huntsman's unsuccessful 2012 bid for the Republican nomination, as both shared a campaign architect, the GOP strategist John Weaver. Despite a strategy that may have been more effective for Kasich than for Huntsman, it was not enough to secure the nomination or even come close.

Initially, Kasich's strategy seemed plausible, as he placed second to Donald Trump in New Hampshire, the nation's first primary and second nominating contest. However, with a significant focus on New Hampshire, Kasich lacked infrastructure for the rest of the campaign and was insignificant in the South Carolina primary. By the time the campaign reached his home state, Kasich was effectively out of the running. He won only Ohio, and closed out the campaign with fewer delegates than Senator Marco Rubio, who dropped out on March 15.

Kasich's pitch to voters was that, amid a field of volatile and unpredictable characters like Trump and radicals like Ted Cruz, he was an old-style conservative who could also win swing states like Ohio. His policy theme, if one could be discerned, was his advocacy for a balanced-budget amendment, a vague promise tied to his work on balancing the national budget while in the U.S. House in the 1990s. The extent of his involvement in that work was a subject of debate.

However, some of Kasich's other policy stances were at odds with much of the Republican Party. As governor, he accepted Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act, a move that was criticized by conservatives. He justified his decision by invoking faith, stating, "When you die and get to the meeting with St. Peter, he’s probably not going to ask you much about what you did about keeping government small. But he is going to ask you what you did for the poor. You better have a good answer."

Many of Kasich's former colleagues viewed his image as a soft, cuddly, friendly politician with skepticism, recalling a more irritable, angry Kasich. The problem was that Republican primary voters in 2016 did not want a sane, rational nominee; they wanted a Trump.

Title: Obama Administration Faces Challenge in Meeting 21 Million Obamacare Enrollment Target for 2016

Article:

President Obama's administration is facing a significant challenge in enrolling more than 21 million Americans in Obamacare exchange plans next year, as per budget projections, marking the next major test for the health care law. As of June, the Department of Health and Human Services reported 9.9 million customers who have bought plans through the federal HealthCare.gov portal and a handful of state-run exchanges.

This figure places the administration ahead of its own estimates for 2015 but is less than half of what the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projected for 2016, indicating the work that officials have ahead as the next round of enrollment begins in less than two months. Industry analysts view the CBO's estimate for next year as "overly optimistic" and a "stretch," suggesting it will take more time for the law to attract that many people onto the Web-based markets.

Open enrollment for the third go-around of Obamacare's exchanges begins on November 1, and the administration is counting on winning over millions of customers who did not sign up in the first two years but could be pressured by the increasing pain of the "individual mandate" tax assessed on those who forgo health insurance.

The tax during the first year was $95 or 1% of income above the filing threshold—a relatively minor bite. This year, the penalty will be $325 or 2% of income, and by 2016 it will be $695 or 2.5% of income.

"The substantial increase in penalties under the individual mandate next year is a big wild card," said Larry Levitt, a senior vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, a nonpartisan health policy organization. "We're in uncharted territory here about how effective these bigger penalties will be in nudging people to get insured."

The individual mandate was included in the Affordable Care Act of 2010 to ensure enough healthy Americans signed up, spreading out the costs for higher-risk customers. A divided U.S. Supreme Court upheld the mandate in 2012 as an appropriate use of Congress' taxing power.

However, congressional Republicans are still intent on scrapping the health care law, and may use a fast-track budget procedure known as "reconciliation" to take a swing at it. GOP leaders say they may not be able to eviscerate the law through the budget, but they plan to repeal the individual mandate.

Even as it struggles to meet the 2016 enrollment projection, the Obama administration is on track on other measures, including a CBO estimate that 17 million fewer people lack insurance this year because of the health care law. Under political duress, the White House let customers transition to compliant plans to keep President Obama's notorious promise that people who like their plans can keep them under his law.

The Health and Human Services has begun to set its own, more modest goals for exchange enrollment, ignoring CBO's guess of 12 million for 2015 and setting the mark at 9.1 million enrollees. So far, it's besting its less ambitious goal. The agency says it is doing its own evaluation of the marketplace and will likely announce its enrollment targets for 2016 before signups begin in November.

"At this point, the Congressional Budget Office's projected enrollment total for 2016 seems overly optimistic," Mr. Levitt said. "Enrollment may reach that level eventually, but I doubt it will happen by next year."

Title: Republican Opposition to Obama's Cuba Policy Threatens Normalization Efforts

Article:

President Barack Obama's plan to normalize relations with Cuba has faced opposition from Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill, potentially hindering the new relationship with the communist country. Just hours after Obama announced a prisoner swap with the Cuban government for two Americans, Republicans began discussing ways to prevent changes to the U.S.-Cuba relationship.

Republicans have proposed measures such as denying Obama funds to reopen an embassy in Havana, stalling the nomination of a potential ambassador, voting down a bill to open up travel more widely, and ignoring requests from the White House to lift a decades-old embargo. With Republicans set to control the Senate next year, they would be in a strong position to implement some of these plans. However, even if they cannot fully stop Obama, who has some authority to act without Congress, the dispute will provide another opportunity for the president's Hill rivals, including 2016 likely hopefuls Sens. Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, to question his use of executive action—a theme Republicans had already planned to take on next year regarding Obama's moves on immigration and Obamacare.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) stated on Twitter Wednesday, "I will do all in my power to block the use of funds to open an embassy in Cuba. Normalizing relations with Cuba is a bad idea at a bad time."

In a White House address on Wednesday, Obama announced that he would direct Secretary of State John Kerry to review Cuba's place on a list of state sponsors of terrorism, reestablish an embassy in Havana, and ease travel restrictions. Obama also stated that the U.S. would increase remittance levels, expand commercial sales, and exports.

"We will end an outdated approach that for decades has failed to advance our interests," Obama said. "Neither the American nor the Cuban people are well-served by a rigid policy that is rooted in events that took place before most of us were born."

Republicans will control the Senate starting in January, giving them the power to block presidential nominations. Already, a number of influential Republicans vocal on foreign affairs, including Graham, Sens. John McCain (R-Ariz.), Rubio (R-Fla.), and Cruz have stated their staunch opposition to Obama's plans.

Obama also called on Congress to pursue legislation that would lift the 50-year embargo against goods and travel to Cuba. However, Speaker John Boehner stated he would not allow any Cuban-U.S. relations to be revisited in the House.

Incoming Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said he would defer the upper chamber's response to Cuba policy changes to Rubio, who criticized Obama for threatening U.S. national security concerns.

Some Republicans have already cast doubt on the Obama administration's legal authority to roll back some travel restrictions and allow increased numbers of Cuban cigars to be brought into the U.S. Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) stated that action by Obama "may be in direct violation of Helms-Burton that specifically states that all political prisoners must be released and free and fair elections must be held before establishing a diplomatic relationship."

The incoming chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Tennessee Republican Bob Corker, gave few details on Wednesday on what his panel would do to halt any of Obama's proposals.

"The new U.S. policy announced by the administration is no doubt sweeping, and as of now, there is no real understanding as to what changes the Cuban government is prepared to make," he said. "We will be closely examining the implications of these major policy changes in the next Congress."

Meanwhile, Democrats were mixed in their response to Obama's plans. Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.), the current chair of the Foreign Relations Committee, was highly critical of Obama's proposals. However, House Minority Nancy Pelosi hailed Obama's "new chapter."

"It is clear that policy of isolating Cuba is serving neither the interests of the American people nor the democratic aspirations of the Cubans," Pelosi said. "We must acknowledge our policy towards Cuba is a relic of a bygone era that weakens our leadership in the Americas and has not advanced freedom and prosperity in Cuba."

Title: The Impact of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) on Federal Budget: A Long-term Perspective

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, has been a subject of debate among politicians regarding its impact on the federal budget. Democrats argue it will lead to savings, while Republicans claim it could lead to increased deficits.

Initially, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated that the Affordable Care Act, passed in March 2010, would reduce deficits by over $100 billion in the first decade and significantly more in the second decade, equating to half a percent of economic growth. This could potentially mean reducing deficits by more than $1 trillion.

However, the CBO's estimate assumes the law will be implemented exactly as written, which may not be sustainable over a long period. The CBO itself noted that the ACA would "put into effect a number of policies that might be difficult to sustain over a long period of time."

Several changes have already been made to the law, and more are being proposed. For example, there is a push to repeal Obamacare's tax on medical devices, expected to raise about $30 billion over the next decade. There is also concern that Congress may struggle to adhere to various cost-containment provisions in the law.

If lawmakers continue to make changes, the potential deficit reduction could be compromised. For instance, if they phase out key provisions intended to restrain spending growth in Medicare and do not implement a policy to slow the growth of health insurance subsidies, deficits could increase.

The Government Accountability Office conducted a long-range simulation that included these and other assumptions about the broader budget. In such a scenario, deficits would increase by 0.7% of GDP over the next 75 years, primarily due to increased spending on Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program, and subsidies offered on the health insurance exchanges.

The impact of Obamacare on the federal budget remains uncertain, as it is a complex law with various components that phase in and out over time. The growth in national health spending, of which federal spending is a significant part, has fallen to a record low rate. Part of this slowing is attributed directly or indirectly to the ACA, but the exact extent is unclear.

The growth rate is expected to rise in the next few years as more people become insured under Obamacare. It remains to be seen whether the new health insurance exchanges will attract a diverse pool of enrollees and generate enough competition to fulfill the law's promise of providing affordable health care for most Americans.

Joshua Gordon, policy director of the Concord Coalition, a deficit watchdog group, is optimistic about Obamacare's long-term impact on the country's fiscal outlook due to the changes hospitals, doctors, and insurance companies are already making to slow cost growth. However, he expresses concern about the potential for Congress to interfere and disrupt these efforts.

Gordon stated, "Underneath this surface fight over Obamacare, there's a huge amount of change and consensus on different ways to slow down health care costs and shift to a value-based health care system." The uncertainty lies in the potential for Congress to disrupt this progress.

Title: McConnell Calls for Roy Moore to Step Aside Amid Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has called for GOP Senate candidate Roy Moore to "step aside" following sexual misconduct allegations against him. During a tax reform press conference in Louisville, Ky., McConnell stated, "I think he should step aside."

The Washington Post published a story last week detailing allegations that Moore pursued relationships with teenage girls, including an account from Leigh Corfman, who said she had a sexual encounter with Moore in 1979 when she was 14 years old and he was 32. The report also included accounts from three other women who said Moore attempted to court them around that time, when they were between 16 and 18 years old.

Moore, in a tweet on Monday, said McConnell is the person who should step aside. "He has failed conservatives and must be replaced," Moore said, using the hashtag “ DrainTheSwamp.”

If Moore withdraws from the Senate race, Republicans are stuck with his name remaining on the ballot. The deadline for the party to remove Moore's name from the ballot passed in October, though Republicans could mount a write-in challenge. Republicans have also floated trying to move back the December special election date.

McConnell said Monday that the party is exploring a write-in bid, though he declined to say specifically who would be the candidate. When asked if Sen. Luther Strange (R-Ala.), who Moore defeated in the GOP primary runoff, would be the write-in candidate, McConnell added, "We'll see."

Moore has denied wrongdoing and threatened to sue The Washington Post, arguing the story is politically motivated and aimed at damaging him ahead of the December special election.

Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) and Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) have also called on Moore to step aside, with Collins stating, "I believe the individuals speaking out against Roy Moore spoke with courage and truth, proving he is unfit to serve in the United States Senate and he should not run for office."

Republicans are increasingly retreating from the Alabama Senate candidate, with Alabama Republicans publicly defending Moore and warning that if he left the race it would hand the Senate seat to Democratic candidate Doug Jones. Despite the blowback nationally from Republican officials and lawmakers, Moore is using the backlash in his fundraising appeals, saying that "establishment Republicans are colluding with the Obama-Clinton Machine."

Title: U.S. Foreign Policy and Terrorism: A Political Analysis of the 2016 Presidential Debate and Paris Attacks

Article:

In the aftermath of the Paris attacks in 2015, where over 100 people were killed by ISIS-related terrorists, former President Barack Obama stated that ISIS was "contained." This statement sparked controversy, as some liberals argued that the attacks in Paris demonstrated the success of Obama's approach, as ISIS was forced to resort to such attacks to gain attention.

During the 2016 Democratic debate, candidates discussed foreign policy and terrorism. Bernie Sanders reiterated his belief that global warming is the greatest threat to humanity and the root cause of terrorism in the Middle East. Martin O'Malley expressed his intention to bring 60,000 Syrian refugees into the U.S., despite some refugees being involved in the Paris attacks. The White House Deputy National Security Advisor confirmed that the refugee importation plan would proceed as planned.

The Republican Party is traditionally less successful in domestic policy elections, but excels in foreign policy. The American public appears to favor a President who is willing to take decisive action against terrorists without being overly idealistic. The Democratic Party has been criticized for being naive and delusional in their approach to foreign policy.

Hillary Clinton, a Democratic candidate, has faced criticism for her foreign policy proposals. John Podhoretz noted that her policy solutions are a jumble of contradictory statements. She stated that ISIS must be "rooted out" and implicitly criticized Obama for containing ISIS, while also stating that it cannot be an American fight. She emphasized the importance of American leadership, but also downplayed the U.S.'s responsibility in the fight against ISIS.

In a surprising turn, Clinton suggested that Syria's dictator, Bashar al-Assad, should take the lead in the fight against ISIS, despite his role in the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of his own people and the refugee crisis in Europe.

The Republican Party's focus on foreign policy and their willingness to take decisive action against terrorists has been well-received by the American public. The Democratic Party's approach to foreign policy, particularly in regards to ISIS, has been criticized for being naive and delusional. The debate over the best approach to terrorism and foreign policy continues to be a contentious issue in the 2016 U.S. Presidential election.

Title: Historic Milestone: 100 Women in U.S. Congress for the First Time

Article:

Tuesday's midterm elections marked a significant milestone in American politics as the number of women in Congress will reach 100 for the first time in the nation's history. This milestone, however, highlights the fact that more than 80% of the country's federal legislators are still men.

The increase in female representation will be approximately 1%, with women making some gains but not significantly altering the gender imbalance. The low number of women with political power in Washington is a concern, as it is far lower than in most advanced democracies.

According to Debbie Walsh, director of the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University, women tend to enter politics because they want to solve a problem or address a policy issue, while men often run for political careers. This difference in motivation may contribute to the gender imbalance in Congress, as women who want to make a difference may look elsewhere when Congress fails to serve as a place for solutions.

Other factors contributing to the gender imbalance include the challenges of raising vast sums of money, entering politics later in life, and the incumbent advantage that preserves the status quo. It is important to note that when women do run, they win in similar numbers as men, and women in Congress tend to function as consensus builders.

There have been several firsts for women in this election cycle. The Senate will have its first female combat veteran, Joni Ernst, who will join a small group of women veterans now serving in the House. Ernst is also the first woman from Iowa to be elected to Congress.

Another notable first is Mia Love, the first black woman ever elected to Congress as a member of the Republican Party. Love, a 38-year-old Haitian-American convert to Mormonism, ran for office in Utah as a champion of conservative self-reliance.

The story of women in American politics is one of persistent and very-slowly-eroding inequality. To break this pattern, more women need to run on both parties. Each victory is a sign to other women that politics is a field where they can succeed, and, as it happens, success for women would give the entire country, Democrats and Republicans, a real reason to celebrate.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Book Recounts 2016 Election Moments, Including Debate Encounter with Donald Trump

Article:

In her new book, "What Happened," former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recounts her experiences during the 2016 election, including a controversial debate moment with Donald Trump. Clinton describes an uncomfortable encounter during a debate where Trump followed her closely, invading her personal space.

Clinton writes, "We were on a small stage, and no matter where I walked, he followed me closely, staring at me, making faces. It was incredibly uncomfortable. He was literally breathing down my neck. My skin crawled."

The book discusses Clinton's decision to remain calm and continue with the debate rather than confronting Trump directly. Clinton states, "I kept my cool, aided by a lifetime of dealing with difficult men trying to throw me off."

The book has received criticism for its focus on Clinton's personal experiences and perceived obsession with sexism. In the book, Clinton references a speech by David Foster Wallace, "This Is Water," to discuss the challenges of recognizing sexism, particularly in politics.

Clinton's book tour has sparked debate about her focus on her own experiences rather than the Democratic Party's future. The book offers insights into Clinton's perspective on various issues, including government's role in solving problems and the importance of the White House as a symbol of the nation. However, the book's intended insights are not the ones that have received the most attention.

The book has been met with mixed reviews, with some praising Clinton's candidness and others criticizing her focus on personal experiences rather than the broader political landscape. The book serves as a recollection of the 2016 election, offering a unique perspective on one of the most contentious and closely watched elections in American history.

Title: CBS Debate Moderator Elaine Quijano Criticized for Perceived Bias in Vice Presidential Debate

Article:

The vice presidential debate on Tuesday, October 4, at Longwood University was marked by a perceived bias from moderator Elaine Quijano, according to conservative critics. The debate, which was moderated by Quijano, the CBS News anchor, was compared to a "Groundhog Day" scenario, with the moderator asking tough questions primarily to the Republican candidate, Vice Presidential nominee Mike Pence, while allowing Democratic nominee Senator Tim Kaine to interrupt at will.

Quijano started the debate by asking Kaine about the public's perception of Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton's trustworthiness. However, she reserved most of her tough questions for Pence, asking him eight questions compared to just one for Kaine.

The New York Times acknowledged Quijano's bias, stating, "Elaine Quijano, the moderator, helped Mr. Kaine along, opening one question with a recitation of Mr. Trump’s statements." However, the Times later deleted that quote and eliminated any reference to the moderator in the story.

Conservatives, including Michael Barbaro of The New York Times and Chris Cillizza of The Washington Post, praised Pence's performance, with Cillizza listing Pence among the debate's "winners." Even MSNBC's Chris Matthews, known for his pro-Democratic leanings, described Pence as "eloquent," "excellent," and "looking like a grown-up."

The debate's bias was also evident in the social media comments from left-leaning outlets such as Fusion, which posted over 30 tweets pushing Kaine or attacking Trump/Pence, while only giving 10 tweets to Pence's message.

Quijano's performance was compared to that of NBC's Lester Holt, who moderated the first presidential debate, and CNN's Jake Tapper, who will moderate the next debate, on October 9. Tapper, who is also a CNN anchor, admitted that Pence had won the debate, but questioned whether the media coverage would shift in the following days.

Despite the perceived bias, Quijano did have some moments of fairness, such as when she asked Kaine to allow Pence to speak when they were both talking over each other. However, the total number of interruptions during the debate is expected to be a topic of discussion in the coming days.

The third and final debate between the vice presidential candidates will take place on October 9, with CNN's Anderson Cooper joining Quijano as a moderator. Expect to hear "I Got You Babe" coming from your clock radio.

Title: Minimum Wage Increase: CBO Report and Its Implications

Article:

The debate over increasing the minimum wage has gained significant attention, with proponents arguing that it is a viable solution to address low-wage worker issues, income inequality, and poverty. The policy is attractive due to its off-budget mechanism, which allows the government to distribute funds down the income scale without creating a politically vulnerable welfare program or incurring new debt.

Recently, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released an analysis concluding that a phased-in $10.10 minimum wage, as proposed by President Obama, would have a modest but real disemployment effect. The CBO projected that at $10.10, the minimum wage would reduce employment between a trivial amount and 1 million jobs by the end of 2016, with a best estimate of 500,000 jobs lost relative to a scenario with no increase.

Conservatives, who oppose any minimum wage increase, were elated with the CBO's findings, using it to support their claim that a $10.10 minimum wage is a job killer. However, the report's impact is large enough to command attention without inviting a ton of second-guessing, making it challenging for Democrats to spin away the findings.

Economist Austin Frakt offers a wise perspective on the minimum wage: if increasing the minimum wage entailed no downside, there would be no reason not to set it at an infinity-jillion dollars. Similarly, if establishing a minimum wage entailed no upside, the only reasonable argument would be to set it at $0.00. If the minimum wage entails both, then it should be set somewhere in between.

While there may be concerns about the disemployment effect, the case for a $10.10 minimum wage is strong. According to the CBO, a $10.10 minimum wage would lift about twice as many people out of poverty (900,000) as it would leave without a job, and increase wages for nearly 20 times more people (16.5 million) than that.

Moreover, a higher minimum wage could mitigate some of the consequences of Obamacare that conservatives find distressing. People who earn higher wages are less likely to quit their jobs, and when wages increase, they slide up the Affordable Care Act's means-tested benefit scale. In states that have expanded their Medicaid programs, a higher minimum wage would draw a significant number of new eligibles into the exchanges, creating savings for the federal government. In states that have refused to expand Medicaid, a higher minimum wage would pull people out of the coverage gap and make them eligible for tax credits on the exchanges, albeit at a cost to the federal government.

While it is possible to increase the minimum wage beyond the point at which the costs outstrip the benefits, $10.10 is not that point. Conservatives, by contrast, overwhelmingly oppose having a minimum wage altogether, ignoring ancillary benefits such as those related to Obamacare and unemployment compensation.

In conclusion, the minimum wage debate is complex, with valid arguments on both sides. However, the CBO report's findings do not necessarily disprove the benefits of increasing the minimum wage, and ancillary benefits such as those related to Obamacare and unemployment compensation should be considered. The argument for a $10.10 minimum wage is strong, and the counterargument, while present, is not without its own inconsistencies.

Title: Obama Proposes Community College Initiative, Tax Credits, and New Policies

Article:

In his State of the Union address, President Barack Obama proposed a $60 billion initiative over a decade to fund community college education, along with a series of new tax credits aimed at the middle class. The proposals include a $500 tax credit for families with two working spouses, a $2,500 annual subsidy for college expenses, and a tripling of an existing tax break for college costs, up to $3,000.

The President emphasized the need to reconsider the approach towards child care, stating, "It's time we stop treating child care as a side issue, or as a women's issue, and treat it like the national economic priority that it is for all of us."

In foreign policy matters, Obama expressed a desire to shift the United States' approach towards Cuba, stating that the current strategy has been ineffective. He also expressed support for engaging in diplomatic talks with Iran to prevent nuclear weapon development and opposed new sanctions before these talks have concluded.

The President also called for legislation to strengthen protections against cyberattacks, citing recent high-profile cyberattacks, such as the one against Sony Pictures, which his administration attributed to North Korea. He emphasized the need for such legislation to protect the nation and its economy from foreign cyber threats.

"No foreign nation, no hacker should be able to shut down our networks, steal our trade secrets or invade the privacy of American families, especially our kids," Obama said. "If we don't act, we'll leave our nation and our economy vulnerable. If we do, we can continue to protect the technologies that have unleashed untold opportunities for people around the globe."

Title: U.S. Reaffirms Justification for Syria Strikes, Threatens Further Action

Article:

In a statement at the United Nations on Friday, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley reiterated the Trump administration's position on the U.S.'s missile strikes on a Syrian airbase earlier this week in response to a chemical weapons attack that resulted in the deaths of dozens of civilians, including children.

Haley stated, "We are prepared to do more, but we hope that won't be necessary." She echoed President Trump's call for "all civilized nations to stop the horrors taking place in Syria and demand a political solution."

Haley also argued that the responsibility for Syria's use of chemical weapons extends not only to President Bashar Assad, but to his allies in Iran and Russia. She suggested that Russia, entrusted with ensuring the removal of such weapons from Syria, may be knowingly allowing chemical weapons to remain in the war-torn country, or may be incompetent in its efforts to remove them.

Russia, in response, has condemned the U.S. missile strikes and has promised to further bolster Syria's anti-aircraft defenses.

At an earlier meeting this week, Haley had hinted at the possibility of a unilateral U.S. strike against Syria, warning that "when the international community fails in its duty to act collectively, there are times when states are compelled to take their own action." She reiterated this sentiment, stating, "The indiscriminate use of chemical weapons against innocent civilians is one of those times."

The article does not provide specific details on what additional action the U.S. might be considering.

Title: Traditional Conservative Newspaper Endorsements of Hillary Clinton Spark Backlash and Subscription Losses

Article:

Over the past month, several traditionally conservative newspapers in the United States have endorsed Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, prompting backlash and subscription losses. The Cincinnati Enquirer, which hadn't endorsed a Democrat in nearly a century, and The Arizona Republic, which had only backed Republican presidential candidates in its 126-year history, have faced angry letters, subscription cancellations, and, in the case of The Arizona Republic, a death threat.

The Arizona Republic, in a scathing editorial this week, portrayed Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump as unqualified and not a true conservative. The Enquirer's editors acknowledged that breaking with a century-long tradition could lead to an uproar. Peter Bhatia, Enquirer editor, stated that the decision to endorse Clinton was an important part of the conversation when considering the paper's legacy and the potential backlash from readers. Since the endorsement last week, the paper has received angry letters and subscription cancellations "in the triple digits."

The backlash, presumably from ardent Trump supporters, is not surprising, according to analysts. Trump has made anti-media sentiment a central theme of his campaign, and the billionaire businessman can dismiss Clinton endorsements as proof that the establishment, which includes top news outlets, is against him.

The Enquirer was aware that its Clinton endorsement could strengthen Trump's support, but felt obligated to make a statement about the presidential race. At least a dozen major American newspapers have endorsed Clinton, but none has backed Trump. Libertarian Gary Johnson has secured at least four major endorsements, including those of the Richmond Times-Dispatch and the New Hampshire Union Leader.

In addition to The Arizona Republic and the Cincinnati Enquirer, the Dallas Morning News and USA Today have also broken decades of precedent in their presidential endorsement decisions. USA Today, in its 34-year history, had never endorsed any presidential candidate, and it still technically didn't in Thursday's editorial calling Trump "unfit for the presidency." It urged readers to vote, whether for Clinton or a third party, or in down-ballot races— "just not for Donald Trump."

The Morning News, which hadn't endorsed a Democrat since World War II, was more explicit, urging readers this month to back Clinton. "Clinton has made mistakes and displayed bad judgment, but her errors are plainly in a different universe," the Morning News editorial board wrote. "Trump's values are hostile to conservatism."

Since the Sept. 7 editorial, the paper is reporting a drop in subscriptions. In Arizona, Republic editors have lost subscribers and received at least one death threat, though this hasn't caused them to rethink their decision. "We know we're doing the right thing," Phil Boas, director of the paper's editorial page, told The New York Times.

While endorsements clearly are having an impact on newspaper subscriptions, there are questions about how much they affect the presidential race itself. Analysts say endorsements, in a broad context, do little to change the trajectory of a race, though they may play a role in pulling some voters away from long-shot third-party candidates.

"Newspaper editorials might also have an impact on those thinking of voting Libertarian or Green," said David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois University and formerly a top reporter and editor at Iowa's Des Moines Register. "A lot of thoughtful voters are thinking about those options now, and a newspaper editorial might encourage them to stick with one of the candidates who actually has a chance of winning rather than casting a protest vote."

Title: Democrats Push for Gun Purchases Ban by Terror Suspects, Face Opposition from Republicans and NRA

Article:

Congressional Democrats are attempting to garner support for an initiative to prevent gun purchases by terror suspects, capitalizing on the same public concerns about security that contributed to the Republican's House victory. The Democratic push, led by Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), is likely to face opposition from the National Rifle Association (NRA) and congressional gun-rights advocates, primarily Republicans, who have historically thwarted firearms restrictions.

If Republicans, who control Congress, block votes on the proposal, Democrats hope to gain political capital by appealing to voters' anger. In a statement released Friday, Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) stated, "By leaving this terrorist loophole open, Republicans are leaving every community in America vulnerable to attacks by terrorists armed with assault rifles and explosives purchased legally, in broad daylight."

Senator Feinstein's bill aims to compile a list of known and suspected terrorists, likely drawing from existing government databases. Federally licensed gun dealers would be prohibited from selling firearms to individuals on this list if government officials believed they intended to use the weapons for terrorism.

Currently, gun dealers are prohibited from selling to 10 categories of people, including convicted criminals or those with severe mental illness. However, people on the government's terror watch lists, including those barred from air travel, are not automatically disqualified from purchasing weapons from gun dealers. The FBI is notified when a background check for the purchase of firearms or explosives generates a match with the watch list, and agents often use this information to intensify surveillance on suspects.

Between 2004 and 2014, individuals on one terror watch list underwent background checks to buy guns 2,233 times and were allowed to make the purchase 91 percent of the time, according to a March report by the Government Accountability Office, an investigative agency of Congress.

NRA spokeswoman Jennifer Baker noted that there have been numerous instances of innocent people mistakenly added to terror lists. She also accused Democrats of exploiting heightened public alarm following last week's attacks in Paris, which claimed at least 130 lives and for which the Islamic State, which has also threatened the U.S., has claimed responsibility.

Feinstein's measure mirrors legislation proposed by the late Sen. Frank Lautenberg (D-N.J.) over the last decade and by Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) for a long time. None of these measures has ever received a vote. Feinstein introduced her bill in February, but last week's mass killings in Paris have injected new life into terrorism and public safety as top-tier political issues.

Just Thursday, Republicans took advantage of voters' security concerns and pushed legislation through the House preventing Syrian and Iraqi refugees from entering the U.S. until the administration tightens restrictions on their entry. Forty-seven Democrats voted for the bill, disregarding a veto threat by President Barack Obama, who said the current screening system is strong and accused Republicans of playing on panicked voters.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) did not respond directly when asked Thursday if he favored barring people on terror lists from buying guns. "We are just beginning this process of reassessing all of our security stances," he said.

Donald Stewart, spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), said McConnell has not stated whether he would be open to a vote on Feinstein's bill. However, opposition from Republicans and some Democrats to curbing firearms runs deep, and such legislation would require support from 60 of the 100 senators. Democrats could not attain that margin even when they had a Senate majority in the months after the 2012 massacre of 20 first-graders and six adults in Newtown, Connecticut.

Though the Senate had showdown votes on gun curbs in early 2013, it did not revisit the issue as the 2014 elections approached, and Reid opted to protect vulnerable Democrats from potentially angering constituents. The GOP-run House has held no votes on major gun control measures since the Newtown killings.

In addition to Feinstein's bill, a measure by Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) would bar gun sales to foreigners in the U.S. from the 38 countries from which visitors need not have visas.

Title: GOP Lawmakers and Benghazi: Unanswered Questions and Allegations of a Cover-up

Article:

Senator John McCain, a prominent Republican lawmaker, has been vocal in his pursuit of answers regarding the 2012 Benghazi attack, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans. In a recent interview on Meet the Press with David Gregory, McCain expressed his belief that there are still unanswered questions about the incident and suggested a cover-up of information related to the deaths of the four Americans.

During the interview, McCain questioned Gregory about the importance of the Benghazi incident, asking if he cared that four Americans had died. Gregory responded by asking for clarification on the nature of the cover-up McCain was referring to.

The crux of the interview centered on a list of questions that McCain believes have not been answered, including what actions the president took and whom he spoke to on the night of the attack, why individuals evacuated from the consulate the following day were not interviewed immediately, and why the president continued to claim uncertainty about whether the attack was a terrorist attack for two weeks during the 2012 campaign.
