McCain also questioned whether the president's statements during the campaign were an attempt to maintain the narrative that Al-Qaeda had been decimated and that the situation in that part of the world was stable. McCain stated that the lack of answers to these questions is a fact, and that reaching conclusions would require receiving the answers.

It is unclear from the provided text whether Gregory responded further to McCain's questions or provided his own perspective on the matter. The transcript of the interview was obtained from NewsBusters.

Title: James Comey's Book Raises Questions About Credibility as Witness in Russia Investigation

Article:

In the wake of his dismissal by President Trump last year, former FBI Director James Comey has become a key witness for Special Counsel Robert Mueller in the ongoing investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election. Comey's written accounts of his interactions with Trump, including the president's requests for loyalty and for the FBI to drop its investigation of former national security adviser Michael Flynn, form the core of Mueller's inquiry into potential obstruction of justice.

The release of Comey's book, "A Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership," has sparked a new crisis for the White House and raised questions about Comey's credibility as a witness against the president. The book, in which Comey compares Trump to the Mafia bosses he once prosecuted, has been met with criticism from the Republican National Committee, which launched an offensive against the book, challenging Comey's credibility.

The Republican National Committee's website features a critical section titled "Lyin' Comey," which includes tweets from Trump and comments from lawmakers questioning Comey's handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server when she was Secretary of State. Former FBI assistant director Ron Hosko suggested that the book may open the door to criticism that Comey wrote the dramatic account merely to enrich himself.

In an interview with ███, Comey characterized the book project as "an obligation to try to drive a healthy conversation" about leadership and ethics. He stated that the good he hopes to come out of the book is to offer a vision to people, especially young people, about what ethical leadership is.

In the book, Comey defended the timing of the book's publication in the midst of the Russia inquiry and before the release of a Justice Department inspector general's examination into the FBI's handling of the Clinton email investigation, which Comey oversaw. Comey told ███ he did not consult Mueller about the timing of the book's publication.

Patrick Cotter, a former federal prosecutor, said that although there is less risk in limiting a witness's public statement about an ongoing case, Comey's story has been the subject of a full, public Senate Intelligence Committee hearing. Cotter stated that unless there are glaring inconsistencies in Comey's testimony, what he told the special counsel, and in his book, he does not see a problem. Cotter added that any argument related to a financial incentive could fall flat.

Cotter concluded by stating, "In a perfect world, you would put witnesses in a cryogenic chamber and only let them out when it's time to testify. That's not the world we live in."

Title: Gina Haspel Confirmed as First Female Director of CIA, Splitting Senate Along Party Lines

Article:

Gina Haspel, a veteran spy and career operations officer, has been confirmed as the first female director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) following a 54-45 vote in the Senate. The confirmation vote, which saw six Democrats join Republicans, was the closest for a CIA nominee in the nearly seven decades that a Senate nod has been required.

Haspel, 61, is a native of Kentucky but grew up around the world as the daughter of an Air Force serviceman. She has spent nearly all of her 33-year CIA career in undercover positions, working in Africa, Europe, and classified locations globally. Haspel was tapped as deputy director of the CIA last year and served under former CIA director Mike Pompeo until President Donald Trump moved him to secretary of state.

Haspel was backed by many in the CIA rank-and-file and was robustly supported by senior intelligence officials, including six former CIA directors and three former national intelligence directors. National Intelligence Director Dan Coats said Haspel has integrity and both frontline and executive intelligence expertise.

Opponents argued that it was not right to promote someone who supervised a covert detention site in Thailand where terror suspects were waterboarded, an interrogation technique that simulates drowning. They said the U.S. needed to slam closed what was one of the CIA's darkest chapters that tainted America's image with allies abroad.

Several senators said Haspel was not forthcoming in answering questions about her role in the torture program or the CIA's decision to destroy video-taped evidence of the sessions. They also had questions about her rejection of the now-banned techniques.

Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said in a floor speech that Haspel "offered up almost the classic Washington non-apology." He asked how the Senate could take seriously Haspel's "conversion on torture?"

Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said the world was watching the confirmation vote, which he called a "referendum on torture." He said the so-called "enhanced interrogation techniques" the CIA used at black sites, including slamming detainees against walls and confining them in coffin-shaped boxes, amounted to "government-sanctioned torture."

Haspel has vowed never to restart such a program and says her "strong moral compass" would prevent her from carrying out any presidential order she found objectionable. That was enough to coax some senators into the "yes" column. However, Leahy said he still questioned her judgment and lamented that she has never publicly condemned torture as "immoral."

He wondered aloud what Haspel would do if she's asked to do something that goes against America's core values. "Should we trust that she will have the moral compass to stand up and say 'No?'" he asked. "Based on what we've seen, I do not."

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., said the nomination was not just about Haspel, but the U.S. grappling with its past mistakes. "The bottom line is this: No one has ever been held accountable for the torture program and I do not believe those who were intimately involved in it deserve to lead the agency," Feinstein said before casting her vote against Haspel.

Since Trump nominated Haspel, her confirmation has been clouded by debate over the CIA's former interrogation program. A protester in the Senate visitor gallery briefly disrupted speeches ahead of the vote with shouts against the CIA.

Three Republicans opposed her: Sen. John McCain of Arizona, who is battling cancer and did not vote; Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky; and Sen. Jeff Flake of Arizona. Six Democrats, however, were heartened by her pledge to never restart harsh interrogation programs, even if Trump requested. They said they voted for Haspel because they thought her experience was essential in confronting today's threats from U.S. adversaries like Russia, North Korea, China, and Iran.

Among Democrats supporting Haspel were several up for re-election this fall in states where Trump is popular, including Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Sen. Joe Donnelly of Indiana, and Sen. Bill Nelson in Florida. Also voting yes were Sen. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia, the ranking member of the intelligence committee.

"This has not been an easy decision," Warner said, adding that he'd met and talked with Haspel many times in the past several weeks. He said he's convinced that Haspel could and would stand up to Trump, who has voiced support for waterboarding and has said "torture works."

After the vote, human rights groups quickly issued statements denouncing the confirmation and the now-defunct program. "The Senate has now rewarded that atrocious conduct by promoting someone that reportedly administered it to lead one of the government's most powerful agencies," said Daphne Eviatar at Amnesty International USA.

Title: Fed Rate Hike in June Unlikely After Weak May Jobs Report

Article:

The Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike in June has been put on hold following a disappointing May jobs report, which showed a significant drop in job creation compared to economists' expectations. The U.S. Department of Labor reported that only 38,000 jobs were created in May, the lowest number since September 2010.

The Federal Reserve, led by Chairwoman Janet Yellen, had been signaling that an interest rate hike could occur in the coming months, potentially as early as June, if the job market and economy continued to perform well. However, the weak jobs report has led to a reevaluation of the Fed's plans.

Steven Ricchiuto, chief economist at MSUSA, described the jobs report as "horrible," while Chris Gaffney, president of world markets at EverBank, called it "very weak." Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, referred to the jobs number as a "bombshell."

The weak jobs report has led to a significant decrease in the likelihood of a June rate hike. According to futures markets tracked by the CME Group, the odds of a June hike have plummeted to about 4%, down from 19% before the data was released.

"This is the weakest number of workers added in almost six years," Gaffney said via email. After the disappointing jobs report was released, the chances of a July hike also decreased, from close to 60% to 34%.

The market reaction was swift. Stocks dipped as investors became concerned about a potential slowdown in job creation, which is negative for the economy. Bond yields fell, and investors piled back into U.S. government bonds as the threat of an imminent Fed rate hike faded. The U.S. dollar weakened as the Fed's rate-hike timetable was pushed back.

While the unemployment rate did tick down to 4.7%, this decrease is mainly due to "another big drop in the labor force," according to Paul Ashworth, chief U.S. economist at Capital Economics. Yellen is scheduled to speak on Monday, and Wall Street will be closely listening for more insight on the Fed's thinking.

"Yellen should provide more insight on the Fed's thinking Monday," Ashworth said via email.

Title: Facebook Removes Pages Linked to Russian Activity, Stirring Controversy Among Political Activists

Article:

Facebook has removed 32 pages from its platform, citing "coordinated inauthentic behavior" that may be linked to Russia. Among the pages removed was an event page for a counter-protest to a white nationalist march in Washington D.C., organized by Black Lives Matter DC. The removal of the page has caused concern among organizers, who fear it may suggest they are linked to Russian election meddling.

Organizers of the "No Unite the Right 2 - DC" protest told The Associated Press that they have set up a new event page, as the initial page was being organized before the first page was created. However, they fear the damage has already been done. "Our participation may take a hit because people are trying to find out what's legit and what's not," said organizer April Goggans. "We've had to 'prove we exist.'"

Facebook stated that administrators of a page called "Resisters" were connected with those from other legitimate pages that helped drum up support for the protest. "These legitimate Pages unwittingly helped build interest in 'No Unite Right 2 – DC' and posted information about transportation, materials, and locations so people could get to the protests," Facebook said in a statement.

Andrew Batcher, an organizer for the Shut It Down DC coalition, said the event page created by "Resisters" was taken over and controlled by "a lot of real people doing real work." Batcher told The Associated Press that he has not seen any evidence that any administrator for the "Resisters' page was a "bad actor."

Lawmakers on Capitol Hill have linked the 32 pages in question to Russia, with a spokesman for Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley stating that Facebook had informed his office "that a limited group of Russian actors has attempted to spread disinformation using its platform and that the affected groups are affiliated with the political left."

The New York Times reported that Facebook also detected coordinated activity around the #AbolishICE campaign, a left-wing movement to abolish Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The issue highlights a broader difficulty social media sites now have in identifying Russian actors. While the intelligence community has concluded that Russia meddled in the election through online activities, Russia's meddling has not been limited to pro-Trump activities, especially this election cycle.

The issue points to a broader difficulty social media sites now have in identifying Russian actors. While the intelligence community has concluded that Russia meddled in the election through online activities, Russia's meddling has not been limited to pro-Trump activities, especially this election cycle.

Meanwhile, with the president still playing clean-up after appearing to initially accept Vladimir Putin's denial of election meddling during their summit last month, the administration is making clear they accept the prior U.S. intelligence findings and take the threat seriously. At a White House press briefing last Thursday, officials warned that a disinformation campaign from Moscow is ongoing.

Title: Republican Representative Cole Advocates for Bipartisan Tax Deal with Obama

Article:

Republican Representative Tom Cole of Oklahoma has urged his colleagues to vote to extend the Bush tax rates for all but the highest earners before the end of the year, suggesting that such a move would not violate the anti-tax pledge by Grover Norquist and would strengthen the Republican position in the ongoing tax debate.

In a private session on Tuesday, Cole argued that this move would not violate the anti-tax pledge and that he is not alone in his stance within Republican circles. He made his case during a meeting of the House GOP whip team earlier in the day.

Cole's position is notable given his reputation as a staunch Republican, having served as chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee and holding other official posts within the party. He suggested that such a bipartisan deal could provide cover for other Republicans looking to avoid the fiscal cliff and secure tax cuts for most taxpayers before the end of the year.

"I think we ought to take the 98 percent deal right now," Cole said, referring to freezing income tax rates for all but the top 2 percent of earners. "It doesn't mean I agree with raising the top 2. I don't."

Instead, Cole proposed that Republicans should fight the president over tax rates for the top earners after everyone else is taken care of. This approach, he argued, would remove the president's argument that Republicans are holding up tax cuts for all but the top earners.

"Some people think that's our leverage in the debate. It's the Democrats' leverage in the debate," Cole said.

Cole indicated that he is likely to support his leadership when a package is put on the floor, but he also suggested that there are other lawmakers in his camp, as well as others who have been willing to listen. He was adamant that his approach would not violate the Norquist pledge, as Republicans would be voting to lower taxes for most people and doing nothing—which would result in an increase—for the rest.

"I don't see that as a violation of my pledge," he said.

Title: Supreme Court's Conservative Majority Leans on Textualism in Close Cases

Article:

WASHINGTON – The Supreme Court has been leaning on a conservative interpretation of statutes, known as textualism, in closely divided cases this term. The justices have settled challenges involving the rights of workers, immigrants, prisoners, and patent owners by meticulously defining the meaning of words such as "for," "shall," "any," and "other," along with "satisfy" and "salesman."

Justices Neil Gorsuch, Clarence Thomas, and Samuel Alito have authored a series of 5-4 decisions that rely on textualism, a philosophy championed by the late Justice Antonin Scalia. President Trump, who appointed Gorsuch as Scalia's successor, had promised to select justices who would adhere to this approach.

Paul Clement, a former U.S. solicitor general who has argued more than 90 cases at the Supreme Court, noted, "The terms of the debate have shifted. You don't want to walk into the court without a textualist argument."

Last week, Gorsuch refused to read into the National Labor Relations Act any rules for handling legal disputes under the Federal Arbitration Act. In his opinion for the court, Gorsuch held that employers can insist that workers settle labor disputes individually through arbitration.

In a dissent led by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the liberal justices argued that the NLRA guarantees workers the right to unionize, bargain collectively, and "engage in other concerted activities for the purpose of collective bargaining or other mutual aid or protection." The judicial dispute boiled down to the word "other" – Gorsuch declaring it must be related to union membership or collective bargaining, while Ginsburg contended the law "speaks more embracively."

In another 5-4 decision written by Gorsuch last month, the court ruled that an administrative board created to review patents cannot pick and choose which parts of a patent to review. The law passed by Congress, according to Gorsuch, is "both mandatory and comprehensive."

In dissent, Ginsburg called Gorsuch's conclusion a "wooden reading" of a law that Justice Stephen Breyer described as "technical, unclear, and constitutes a minor procedural part of a larger administrative scheme."

In February, Gorsuch's 5-4 opinion for the court held that under federal law, prisoners who win civil rights suits must pay up to 25% of their award "to satisfy" attorneys' fees. Lower court judges cannot limit a prisoner's contribution, the court said.

In dissent, Justice Sonia Sotomayor argued that the law allows judges to limit the amount prisoners must pay. The phrase "to satisfy" does not necessarily mean in full, she said, citing other contexts ranging from credit card payments to college course credits.

Supreme Court experts say Gorsuch's addition has merely returned the court to Scalia's brand of textualism. Irving Gornstein, executive director of the Supreme Court Institute at Georgetown University Law Center, stated, "The court is no more textualist than it was when Scalia was on the court. The only thing that has changed is that one textualist has been replaced by another."

However, Jeffrey Fisher, co-director of the Stanford Law School Supreme Court Litigation Clinic, said, "Gorsuch seems to be trying to put some fresh wind in the sails of textualism. And it seems he’s having some success."

Justices Samuel Alito and Clarence Thomas also stuck to the letter of the law in recent 5-4 rulings. Alito ruled that illegal immigrants can be detained indefinitely while their cases are reviewed, rather than given intermittent bail hearings.

In a second case involving workers' rights, Thomas's 5-4 ruling found that service advisers at car dealerships can be excluded from the Fair Labor Standards Act's wage and hour protections because their duties are akin to salesmen and partsmen, who are specifically excluded.

Elizabeth Wydra, president of the liberal Constitutional Accountability Center, said, "There’s going to be a battle about what is actual textualism. And the liberals aren’t giving up that fight."

Title: President Trump Signs Executive Order to Address Social Media and Big Technology Companies

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced his intention to sign an executive order on Thursday, aiming to regulate social media and big technology companies. The move follows a fact-check on a tweet by the president regarding mail-in voting by Twitter.

The president is invoking section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a provision that aims to protect free speech by shielding providers from liability for the content they host. The section states, "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider."

The executive order seeks to add regulations to section 230, limiting the liability protections for companies that editorialize or censor content or speech. The president also plans to instruct the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to monitor reported political bias. President Trump has criticized Twitter for fact-checking his tweet about mail-in voting, while alleging that the platform has not previously addressed propaganda from the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).

The White House tweeted, "Today, I am signing an executive order to protect and uphold the free speech and rights of the American people." Bloomberg QuickTake reported that Trump described social media companies as currently receiving an "unprecedented liability shield."

Attorney General Bill Barr has partnered with President Trump in this effort. Barr contends that the new order does not repeal section 230, but rather an accountability measure to ensure the law is interpreted correctly. Section 230 has faced criticism from both Republicans and Democrats, who argue that the law allows social media companies to avoid the responsibility to ensure truth is present online.

The executive order is expected to be challenged in court on its constitutionality.

Title: Cautious Optimism Surrounds Immigration Overhaul Amidst Stalled Legislation

Article:

A broad immigration overhaul, which includes a 13-year path to citizenship for the estimated 11 million immigrants residing in the United States illegally and stricter border security measures, has passed the Senate with bipartisan support in June. However, this legislation has largely stalled in the Republican-controlled House, where Speaker John Boehner has rejected negotiations with the Senate over its comprehensive bill.

Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, a key negotiator of the Senate bill, expressed cautious optimism, stating, "This is obviously a long, hard road, but I think since August, the number on the other side vehemently opposed has stayed the same, the number who think it should go forward has grown, and numbers in the wide middle are less opposed than they used to be. But that doesn't guarantee an outcome one way or another."

Republican Party leaders, backed by business groups, have emphasized the necessity of an overhaul to repair their political position with Latino and other immigrant voters. Former Chief of Staff to Speaker Boehner, Barry Jackson, is now consulting for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which supports an overhaul that expands high-technology visas and guest worker programs.

Immigration is less of a concern during midterm elections, when immigrants are less likely to vote, and House members in safe districts are somewhat insulated from the influence of more moderate swing voters. The biggest threats to Republicans often come from primary challenges by more conservative candidates who argue that changing the immigration status of those in the country illegally amounts to amnesty for lawbreakers.

Representative John Carter, Republican of Texas and one of the Gang of Eight House members who attempted to forge a bipartisan overhaul, told Capitol Hill newspaper Roll Call that an election year is not the time to press forward, stating, "Immigration is a very, very contentious issue."

Title: President Obama's Hawaiian Vacation: A Detailed Account of the 16-Day Retreat

Article:

During his 16-day Hawaiian vacation, President Barack Obama took a few visible actions related to official business. The vacation, which ended on January 4, was filled with leisure activities such as golf, dining at high-end restaurants, snorkeling, and a private visit to a zoo.

The president reportedly received daily presidential briefings, including the "threat matrix" - secret guidance culled from intelligence agencies about global hotspots. He also issued a statement about the ailing former first lady Barbara Bush, participated in a conference call about Sudan, signed a few bills, called senators about a contentious bill, and received updates on terrorist attacks in Russia.

The cost of the vacation, including the rental of a beach house in Kailua, Hawaii, which typically rents for $3,500 per day, and the travel on Air Force One, has been estimated to cost taxpayers around $4 million. This estimate includes the rental of at least seven homes in the area, according to watchdog.org.

The president played golf with New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, his teenage son Max, and White House aide Marvin Nicholson at the Marine Corps base at Kaneohe Klipper Golf Course. He also engaged in eight gym workouts, two family hikes, two beach trips, and a visit to Hanauma Bay Nature Preserve, where they snorkeled with parrotfish and green sea turtles. The preserve was closed to the public during the Obamas' visit.

The first couple has met with U.S. troops once but have not attended church services, even for Christmas. Reporters and photographers covering the president's vacation have been kept at a distance, but were allowed to observe the president during his New Year's Eve shopping center outing and his golf outing on Thursday.

President Obama well knows that the decisions will get tougher when he returns to Washington next week.

Title: Washington D.C. Prepares for Second Unite the Right Rally as Businesses and Transportation Services Take Stance

Article:

In anticipation of the second Unite the Right rally scheduled for Sunday in Washington D.C., white supremacists and white nationalists may face challenges in finding transportation and dining options. The rally marks the one-year anniversary of the violent white supremacist events in Charlottesville, Virginia.

On Saturday, police in Charlottesville blocked off streets and mobilized hundreds of officers downtown as a precaution. A group of 20 Antifa protestors marched through downtown Charlottesville, holding a flag that read "Antifascist action."

In preparation for the rally near the White House, ride-sharing companies Uber and Lyft have informed drivers they have the right to refuse service to passengers who harass or threaten them. The Restaurant Association of Metropolitan Washington has also provided a toolkit to restaurateurs, informing them of their legal rights to refuse service to white nationalists and other political fringe groups.

Rally organizer, Jason Kessler, obtained a permit for Lafayette Park across from the White House, expecting 400 supporters to show up. The first "Unite The Right" rally in Charlottesville on Aug. 12, 2017, resulted in violent clashes between white supremacists and counter-protesters, with one person being killed when a white supremacist drove into a crowd of counter-protesters.

Uber has reminded its drivers in the Washington region of community guidelines and their right to refuse service to disrespectful or threatening passengers. Several restaurant owners have stated they are threatening to refuse service to those participating in the rally or planning to close altogether.

Airbnb has also threatened to ban users who participate in the rally. Ellen Kassoff Gray, owner of Equinox restaurant near the White House, and several other restaurant owners have stated they would refuse service to those who espouse hate.

Twitter has suspended numerous accounts associated with the Proud Boys, a controversial right-wing group, for violating Twitter's policy against "violent extremist groups." A number of non-verified accounts for various Proud Boys chapters were also suspended.

Title: President Trump Hosts "Celebration of America" as Eagles Disinvitation Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, President Donald Trump disinvited the Philadelphia Eagles, the Super Bowl LII champions, from a White House event on Tuesday. Instead, the White House is hosting a "Celebration of America" event.

The White House decision to disinvite the team marked the end of speculation over whether the Eagles would visit the White House in some capacity. The team reportedly wanted to send a small group of players.

"We will proudly be playing the National Anthem and other wonderful music celebrating our Country today at 3 P.M. The White House, with the United States Marine Band and the United States Army Chorus. Honoring America! NFL, no escaping to Locker Rooms!" Trump tweeted early Tuesday.

Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney criticized Trump, calling him "not a true patriot" and a "fragile egomaniac" over the move.

"Disinviting them from the White House only proves that our president is not a true patriot, but a fragile egomaniac obsessed with crowd size and afraid of the embarrassment of throwing a party to which no one wants to attend," Kenney said in a statement.

Last month, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell announced the league would fine teams and league personnel who do not "stand and show respect for the flag and the anthem." Goodell said the league unanimously agreed to the vote, though San Francisco 49ers owner Jed York abstained. The new overhaul does allow players to remain in the locker room for the anthem.

Trump has praised the new policy, but his Eagles decision -- and swipe Tuesday at those who stay in the locker room -- reflects ongoing tension between his White House and players protesting police violence by sitting out the national anthem.

Trump also used his Twitter account Tuesday to note past events the White House has held with other championship teams.

"We have had many Championship teams recently at the White House including the Chicago Cubs, Houston Astros, Pittsburgh Penguins, New England Patriots, Alabama and Clemson National Champions, and many others. National Anthem & more great music today at 3:00 P.M.," Trump tweeted, adding minutes later that "@NASCAR and Champion @MartinTruex_Jr were recently at the White House. It was a great day for a great sport!"

Title: House of Representatives to File Lawsuit for Release of Fast and Furious Documents

Article:

The United States House of Representatives is expected to file a lawsuit in the coming weeks to compel the Justice Department to release additional documents related to the Fast and Furious gun-tracking operation. The decision follows a resolution passed by the Republican-led House on Thursday, which found Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress for failing to provide further documents to congressional investigators.

Speaker of the House, John Boehner (R-Ohio), stated on CBS's "Face the Nation" that "The American people have a right to know what happened." The criminal contempt resolution opens the door for the House to call on the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia to bring the case before a grand jury. However, Deputy Attorney General James Cole informed Boehner in a letter on Friday that the agency would not prosecute, stating that Holder's failure to release the documents does not constitute a crime.

The second, civil contempt resolution grants the House the ability to ask a court to compel the Justice Department to hand over the documents. President Obama has already asserted executive privilege over the documents in question.

The investigation into the Fast and Furious operation, led by Republican Rep. Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, has spanned 16 months. The non-defunct Operation Fast and Furious was run out of an Arizona field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), which is under the Justice Department.

The operation involved putting roughly 2,000 assault guns into the hands of arms dealers, then allowing the guns to cross the U.S.-Mexico border with the expectation they would resurface at crime scenes and lead agents to organizers of Mexican drug cartels. Two of the weapons were found at the site of the 2010 shooting death of U.S. Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

Recently, Rep. Issa has focused on a February 2011 letter from the Justice Department to Congress that falsely stated ATF made "every effort" to interdict the illegally purchased guns and stop them from going into Mexico. White House Chief of Staff Jack Lew described the Justice Department's decision not to prosecute Holder as based on a Reagan administration memo and characterized the House's continued efforts as "political" and a "fishing expedition."

Title: Clapper Criticizes Trump's Openness to Foreign Opposition Research, Cites Double Standard in Dossier Case

Article:

Following the release of George Stephanopoulos' exclusive interview with President Donald Trump, former Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, appeared on Anderson Cooper 360 to discuss the president's comments regarding his willingness to listen to foreign opposition research. During the interview, Clapper and Cooper focused on Trump's statement that he would be open to receiving such information if it were presented to him.

"It's certainly interesting. I've run out of adjectives to describe a reaction to this. Incredible, amazing, stunning, and disturbing that the president would advocate for this use of accepting information provided by a foreign country, notably a foreign adversary," Clapper told Cooper. "And, in doing so, completely overlooking the fact that this could, will be, probably would be, disinformation. In other words, completely phony. And to endorse that, and in doing so endorse, undercut the FBI, and its director, it's just incredible. I can't get over the duplicity of it."

Clapper also addressed the double standard he perceived in the handling of the infamous dossier, compiled by a former British spy, during the 2016 election. "Here's all this criticism about the infamous dossier and you can't use it because it's not valid. You can't accept it. That's, and in this case, okay. And we're looking in the future here. We're not talking about the past," Clapper added.

Clapper argued that opposition research is a common practice in every campaign during every election, and candidates have the right to conduct such research. However, he emphasized that the government has an obligation to independently verify the information in such documents, especially when it comes to obtaining FISA warrants based on the information.

"Journalists" at BuzzFeed and The Washington Post were criticized by Clapper for not independently verifying the information in the dossier, and for accepting it as fact because it was damaging evidence against Trump. Clapper suggested that there were political motives in not vetting Steele's information.

According to Cooper, this is Trump's "clarion call" for information from foreign countries, particularly Russia, in the upcoming 2020 election. "They're [Russia] going to repeat what they did in 2016. They're going to repeat it in 2020," Clapper said. "And now, what President Trump has done, is encourage them to do so. Again, it's just, it's just stunning."

Title: Planned Parenthood Affiliates Return $80 Million in PPP Loans Due to Ineligibility

Article:

Thirty-seven Planned Parenthood affiliates have returned a total of $80 million in loans received from the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) after the Small Business Administration (SBA) determined that they were not eligible for the coronavirus stimulus payouts. The SBA is reaching out to each involved affiliate to explain that affiliates of larger organizations with more than 500 employees are not eligible for PPP distributions.

The Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PFFA) alone has over 600 employees, making it ineligible for PPP distributions. For instance, a Planned Parenthood affiliate in Metropolitan Washington (PPMW) will receive a letter stating that although it self-certified that it was eligible for a $1,328,000 PPP loan, it will need to return the money.

In August 2020, PPMW's president and CEO, Laura Meyers, promised not to accept federal funds from the Trump administration after the White House banned Planned Parenthood clinics from making abortion referrals to continue receiving federal funds. However, PPMW requested funds from the Trump administration just months later.

The SBA warned of "severe penalties" for incorrect or false eligibility certifications by PPP recipients. Incorrect eligibility certifications could result in criminal or civil sanctions if the SBA determines borrowers made knowingly false statements. The SBA letter explained that PPFA affiliates were covered by the PPP affiliate rules, as PPFA's bylaws require a certification by the PPFA board, and each affiliate is governed by written bylaws that conform to PPFA policies.

The largest single government loan was a $7.5 million allotment to the Planned Parenthood of Orange and San Bernardino Counties in California. One Planned Parenthood affiliate received a loan but declined it.

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), who serves as chairman of the Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship, called for an immediate investigation on Tuesday evening. Rubio stated that there is no ambiguity in the legislation that passed or public record around its passage that organizations such as Planned Parenthood, whose parent organization has close to half a billion dollars in assets, is not eligible for the Paycheck Protection Program.

In January 2020, Planned Parenthood reported a record-high number of abortions and government funding for 2018-2019. Planned Parenthood claimed that abortion constituted just a small percentage – 4 percent in 2018-2019 – of its services, and that federal funds did not go directly to abortions.

Ninety-eight percent of PPP loans have been less than $1 million, with an average loan of $118,000. Canceled or returned funds can be used during future PPP rounds.

Republicans have resisted reported efforts from some Democrats to push abortion-related spending amid the pandemic. In March 2020, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) was reported to have tried to include federal funding for abortion in the coronavirus stimulus bill.

Title: Alabama Senate Passes Near-Total Abortion Ban, Sending Measure to Governor's Desk

Article:

The Alabama Senate on Tuesday evening passed a legislation that effectively bans nearly all abortions in the state, sending the measure to Governor Kay Ivey's (R) desk for signing into law. The bill, which passed by a 25-6 margin, would ban abortions in virtually all instances, including for victims of rape and incest, and would only permit the procedure if necessary to save a mother's life.

Anyone performing an abortion could be punished by 10 to 99 years in prison, but no criminal charges would be filed against a person undergoing the procedure. The legislation was tabled last week due to a shouting match that erupted on the Senate floor after an exception for cases of rape and incest was removed from the bill.

State Rep. Terri Collins (R), who sponsored the bill, told The Washington Post she empathized with survivors of rape and incest but that the exceptions were specifically left out so that the law would be strong enough to force a federal court battle.

The bill's proponents hope the legislation, along with abortion restrictions in other states, will set up a Supreme Court battle that will see the overturning of the landmark Roe v. Wade decision that legalized abortion.

As of now, sixteen states have passed or are currently considering abortion bans once a fetal heartbeat is detected about six weeks into pregnancy. Four states have approved so-called heartbeat abortion laws. However, Alabama's is without a doubt the most restrictive abortion law in the country.

State Sen. Vivian Figures (D) told The Washington Post before the bill was considered, "If I were them, I would be making plans to leave Alabama. Who is going to stay in a state like this?"

The pro-abortion rights group NARAL Pro-Choice America swiftly condemned Tuesday's vote and expressed concern that the current makeup of the Supreme Court puts Roe v. Wade at risk after the Senate confirmed President Trump's two nominees.

"Alabama just passed a law that is a total ban on abortion, criminalizing the act and punishing women and doctors. Anti-choice Republicans no longer even pretend to respect the law or the women that it protects. When this dangerous and demeaning law passed, Republicans stood up and applauded, while women wept," NARAL Pro-Choice America President Ilyse Hogue said in a statement.

When women stood up in record numbers to fight Brett Kavanaugh's nomination, propelled by his alarming record and Trump's promise to nominate jurists committed to criminalizing abortion and punishing women, we were told we were 'hysterical' because Roe was settled law. Not six months later, we are battling measures where the stated goal is exactly that: outlawing abortion," she added, referring to the newest Supreme Court justice, Brett Kavanaugh.

Title: Traveling to Damascus Offers Insight into Syrian Conflict's Impact on a Muslim Shrine

Article:

In the Syrian capital of Damascus, the ongoing civil war has left many residents with a profound sense of hope for the preservation of the city's historical sites, particularly the Muslim shrine of Sayida Zeinab. This shrine, dedicated to the granddaughter of the Prophet Muhammad, remains a beacon of hope and unity for the city's residents, despite the ongoing conflict.

A local doctor, who requested anonymity, spoke of his deep affection for Sayida Zeinab, stating, "We love Sayida Zeinab. We like Sayida Zeinab. We respect Sayida Zeinab." The doctor, who has worked in the area for 25 years, offered to guide visitors to the shrine, which is located in a Shiite neighborhood and is surrounded by guards due to fears of potential destruction by Sunni extremist rebels.

The doctor explained that the shrine is significant to all Muslims, though the Shiite sect maintains the shrine. He expressed concern that Sunni extremist rebels, who allegedly hold Wahhabi beliefs, may target the shrine due to their opposition to shrines and their austere interpretation of Islam.

The Syrian government, led by President Bashar Assad, has consistently portrayed the rebels as foreign terrorists. While not all Sunni rebel groups oppose Shiites, it is clear that some are extremist Sunnis, and this fear has led Shiites and other minority groups to align with Assad's regime.

The area surrounding the shrine is heavily contested, with ongoing fighting nearby. Despite this, the doctor stated that he has never missed a day of work at the nearby hospital.

Upon reaching the shrine, visitors are greeted by a series of military checkpoints and a golden dome, which stands out amidst the battle-scarred city. Inside the courtyard, walls adorned with elaborate blue tiles display messages of support for Assad's government.

Inside the shrine, pilgrims can pay their respects at Sayida Zeinab's tomb. One young mother, with a baby in her arms, shared her reasons for supporting the government: "Because I saw by my own eyes, because I saw by my own eyes how the army saved us and the rebels want to kill us."

The guards of the shrine include men from Lebanon, who are allies of Assad and members of the Lebanese Shiite group Hezbollah. They believe Syria has become the battleground for a proxy war between Shiite Iran and Sunni Arabs, including the rulers of Saudi Arabia. Local men, such as a former sheep dealer who joined a volunteer defense force, also serve as guards.

Inside the golden dome, visitors find a room adorned with mirrored tiles, reflecting the brilliance of the space. The doctor who guided the visit expressed a desire for a revolution that would bring about positive change, but not at the cost of the country's destruction.

In Syria's elections, Assad has always been the only candidate, making it a yes-no referendum on his rule. The challenge for Syria's rebels is to present a plausible alternative—a new system of government in which terrified Syrians might believe.

Title: Afghan Immigrant Ahmad Khan Rahami Arrested in Connection with New York and New Jersey Bombings

Article:

An Afghan immigrant, Ahmad Khan Rahami, wanted in connection with bombings that occurred in New York City and a New Jersey shore town was captured Monday following a gun battle with police. Rahami, a 28-year-old naturalized U.S. citizen from Afghanistan, underwent surgery for a gunshot wound to his leg, and two officers were wounded but not critically in the shootout.

The arrest took place just hours after police issued a bulletin and photo of Rahami, who lived with his Muslim family in an apartment in Elizabeth, New Jersey, above a fried-chicken restaurant owned by his father. U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara, the chief federal prosecutor in New York, stated that New Jersey officials will likely bring charges against Rahami for the police officers' shooting, while federal authorities consider their own charges.

On Saturday night, a shrapnel-packed pressure-cooker bomb similar to those used in the Boston Marathon attack exploded in New York's Chelsea section, wounding 29 people, none seriously. An unexploded pressure-cooker bomb was found blocks away. Earlier that day, a pipe bomb exploded in Seaside Park, New Jersey, before a charity race to benefit Marines. No one was injured. Then on Sunday night, five explosive devices were discovered in a trash can at an Elizabeth train station. Investigators are still gathering evidence and have not publicly tied Rahami to those bombs.

With Rahami's arrest, officials stated they have no indication of more bombs or suspects to find, though they cautioned that they are still working to understand Rahami's connections. His motive remains unclear, according to New York Police Commissioner James O'Neill. William Sweeney Jr., the FBI's assistant director in New York, said there are no indications Rahami was on law enforcement's radar at the time of the bombings.

As for how investigators zeroed in on Rahami as a suspect, three law enforcement officials stated that clues included a fingerprint lifted from one of the New York sites and "clear as day" surveillance video from the bombing scene that helped identify Rahami. The officials spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the case.

Five people were pulled over Sunday night in a vehicle associated with Rahami, but were questioned and released. The law enforcement officials stated at least one of Rahami's relatives was in the car, which appeared headed toward Kennedy Airport in New York after coming from New Jersey.

Linden Mayor Derek Armstead stated the break in the case came late Monday morning, when the owner of a bar reported someone asleep in his doorway. A police officer went to investigate and recognized the man as Rahami, police and the mayor said. Rahami pulled a gun and shot the officer - who was wearing a bulletproof vest - in the torso, and more officers joined in a gun battle that spilled into the street, police Capt. James Sarnicki said.

The Council on American-Islamic Relations, a national Muslim advocacy group, welcomed Rahami's arrest. The organization and the Afghan Embassy in Washington condemned the bombings. Around the time Rahami was captured, President Barack Obama was in New York on a previously scheduled visit for a meeting of the U.N. General Assembly. He called on Americans to show the world "we will never give in to fear."

Rahami lived with his family on a busy street a few miles from the Newark airport. An AP reporter went to the building that houses the family's restaurant and home, but it was cordoned off. Rahami's father, Mohammad, and two of Rahami's brothers sued the city of Elizabeth in 2011 after it passed an ordinance requiring their restaurant, First American Fried Chicken, to close early because of complaints from neighbors that it was a late-night nuisance. The Rahamis charged in the lawsuit that they were targeted by neighbors because they are Muslims. The lawsuit was terminated in 2012 after Mohammad Rahami pleaded guilty to blocking police from enforcing the restrictions on the restaurant.

Ryan McCann, of Elizabeth, stated that he often ate at the restaurant and recently began seeing the younger Rahami working there more. "He's always in there. He's a very friendly guy, that's what's so scary. It's hard when it's home," McCann said.

On Sunday, a federal law enforcement official stated the Chelsea bomb contained a residue of Tannerite, an explosive often used for target practice that can be picked up in many sporting goods stores. One of the five devices found at the Elizabeth train station exploded while a bomb squad robot tried to disarm it. No one was hurt.

Luck and some scavengers played a role in the investigation: Two homeless men grabbed a backpack left on a trash can near the Elizabeth train station, only to discover it contained several apparent pipe bombs. They quickly reported the find to police, said Elizabeth Mayor Christian Bollwage.

On Saturday, two men walking down a street in New York saw a suitcase on a sidewalk, opened it, discarded the pressure cooker they found inside, and walked off with the bag. Later that evening, after the blast in Chelsea, state troopers found the unexploded device.

Title: West Virginia Governor Invites Virginia Counties to Secede Amidst Political Differences

Article:

In a proposal dubbed "Vexit," West Virginia's Republican Governor Jim Justice has extended an invitation to Virginia counties discontent with their liberal state government in Richmond to secede and join West Virginia. The invitation was made during a press conference with Liberty University President Jerry Falwell, Jr. at a community college in Martinsburg, West Virginia on Tuesday.

"If you're not happy where you're at, come on down," Justice said. "If you're not truly happy where you are, we stand with open arms to take you from Virginia or anywhere you may be. We stand strongly behind the Second Amendment, and we stand strongly for the unborn."

The proposal comes after Virginia Democrats regained full control of the government in Richmond last fall, leading to changes in gun laws and abortion restrictions. Since taking office this month, the new government has dismantled laws protecting gun rights and is reportedly proposing to repeal the state's right-to-work law, which would force workers to join a union and pay dues.

Thousands of gun owners concerned about their freedom gathered for a rally on the Capitol grounds in Richmond on January 20th to lobby against the proposed legislation. Fearing the loss of their freedoms, citizens have flooded city council meetings all over the state, resulting in 91 of Virginia's 95 counties declaring themselves Second Amendment Sanctuaries.

The idea of Virginia counties seceding to another state is not new, as West Virginia became a state in 1863 by seceding from Virginia, which had seceded from the United States.

When asked for a reaction to West Virginia's proposal that Virginia counties join their state, Virginia Democrat Governor Ralph Northam's office responded, "It sounds like it's an election year in West Virginia." Virginia Senate Majority Leader Dick Saslaw (D) described the secession proposal as "preposterous," suggesting West Virginia should focus on fixing its high poverty rate.

Minority leader in the House of Delegates, Todd Gilbert, told reporters that many Virginians are not happy with the Democrat agenda, but Republicans are not retreating from the political fray in Richmond. However, he did seem to appreciate West Virginia's offer.

"We're nowhere near done fighting for our values here in the Commonwealth," Gilbert said. "Democrats have been in power for less than two months and they're already raising taxes, working to let violent felons out of jail early, and punishing law-abiding gun owners. We think Virginians will have a significant case of buyer's remorse very soon. That being said, it's always nice to have options."

However, concern by Virginia conservatives over the leftist tilt of their state government is not going away. Jerry Falwell, Jr. stated, "What's happening in Virginia right now is a tragedy in the making. Democrat leaders in Richmond, through their elitism and radicalism, have left a nearly unrecognizable state in their wake, and they are using their power to strip away the God-given rights held by every person in the state, despite their due protections under the US Constitution."

It remains unclear whether the proposal for Virginia counties to secede and join West Virginia will become a reality. Lawyers consulted by Falwell reportedly stated that secession would be a difficult process, requiring petition drives, referendums, and the consent of Congress and both states. For their part, lawmakers in West Virginia have already introduced formal resolutions inviting parts of Virginia to join their state.

Title: Seismic Activity in North Korea Determined as Natural Event, Not Nuclear Test

Article:

South Korean and Chinese monitors have concluded that the seismic activity in North Korea on Saturday was a natural event and not a nuclear test. The Korea Meteorological Administration reported a magnitude 3.0 earthquake in North Hamgyeong Province, an area where North Korea conducted its sixth and most powerful nuclear test on Sept. 3.

The seismic activity occurred in Kilju, near the site of the previous nuclear test. However, the Korea Meteorological Administration and China's Earthquake Networks Center, as well as officials with The Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization, have assessed the activity as natural.

An official from South Korea's weather agency stated, "The quake is presumed to have occurred naturally," according to South Korea's Yonhap news agency. They added, "A sound wave, which is usually generated in the event of an artificial earthquake, was not detected."

The seismic activity was reported against a backdrop of growing tension over North Korea's nuclear and missile intentions. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has vowed to take the "highest-level" action in response to President Trump's threat to "totally destroy" North Korea over its nuclear and missile programs.

North Korean Foreign Minister Ri Yong-ho said in New York on Thursday that Pyongyang may consider its most powerful test of a hydrogen bomb over the Pacific Ocean. "This could probably mean the strongest hydrogen bomb test over the Pacific Ocean," he told reporters in response to a question about what action the North Korean regime might take against the U.S.

Meanwhile, China announced on Saturday that it will limit exports of petroleum products to North Korea starting in October under the terms of the latest U.N. sanctions passed in response to North Korea's sixth nuclear test.

Title: Senate Democrats Distance Themselves from Obama in Midterm Campaign Strategy

Article:

In the lead-up to the midterm elections, the White House and Senate Democrats are devising a comprehensive campaign strategy to navigate the unpopularity of President Barack Obama in several competitive states. According to a source speaking with nearly every incumbent and aspiring Democratic Senate candidate, only a handful of candidates expressed a desire for Obama to campaign with them.

Alaska Sen. Mark Begich stated, "I don't care to have him campaign for me. I'd rather he come up to see where his policies aren't working. He's wrong on ANWR, we've had struggles to try to get our permits done down in the southeast for our timber industry. I want to show him how important the military is in Fairbanks."

The president's unpopularity could potentially cost Democrats the Senate, as vulnerable incumbents require the full resources of the White House to maintain the majority. To mitigate this, the White House and party leadership are exploring strategies to deploy Obama and his team in a manner that minimizes complications for Democrats in states like Colorado, Georgia, or Kentucky, where his polls are unfavorable.

President Obama has committed to half a dozen Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee fundraisers for 2014, with the first two expected in the coming weeks in New York and the Washington suburbs. He is also planning to attend fundraisers for the Senate Majority PAC. Vice President Joe Biden, first lady Michelle Obama, and former President Bill Clinton will take the lead in campaigning, while Obama remains distant.

In an interview, Sen. Mark Pryor of Arkansas, who is trying to defend his seat, downplayed the role any surrogate would play in his campaign, despite Clinton's involvement in fundraising. "I don't get people to come and campaign for me very often," Pryor said. "To me, in Arkansas, people don't vote for you because somebody else says vote for you."

Vice President Biden was a previously unreported attendee in an Oval Office meeting last week with Obama, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, DSCC Chairman Michael Bennet, and DSCC Executive Director Guy Cecil. The White House is also reportedly debating how and where to deploy Michelle Obama.

In 2012, many of Michelle Obama's events on behalf of the president's reelection were focused on voter registration, and she could help promote turnout and energize the Democratic base without endangering candidates by a close connection to the president, particularly in states like New Orleans, where local turnout could make the difference for Sen. Mary Landrieu.

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), the Senate majority whip, reported that Obama told Senate Democrats at a meeting at Nationals Park last week that he understands his health care law will be used as the "No. 1 attack tool" on Democrats by the Koch Brothers. Obama also acknowledged that his popularity may be lower in some states, stating, "I can help many of you, even in states where I'm not popular with everyone. I can still help, and I'm willing to do everything I can."

The president is still likely to campaign at some point later this year, although decisions regarding his travel schedule have yet to be made. He has a busy travel schedule in February and March focused on international affairs, including a California summit with the king of Jordan, trips to Mexico, Saudi Arabia, and Vatican City, where he'll meet Pope Francis.

Title: US Officials Believe Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752 Was Likely Shot Down by Iranian Missile

Article:

U.S. officials believe that Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752 was likely shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile, according to multiple reports on Thursday. The incident occurred shortly after Iran fired a barrage of ballistic missiles at U.S. and coalition forces in Iraq in response to a U.S. drone strike that killed Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani, former head of the IRGC Quds Force.

Defense officials told Newsweek and others that the plane was probably shot down by accident, as Iran's surface-to-air missile systems were likely active at the time of the crash early Wednesday. The plane, which was made by Boeing, crashed outside the Iranian capital of Tehran, killing all 176 people on board.

U.S. officials told Newsweek, Reuters, and other outlets that the incident was likely an accident, as anti-aircraft systems were likely active at the time of the crash. CBS News reported that U.S. intelligence detected anti-aircraft radars turning on before the crash and that satellites detected two infrared blips, thought to be SA-15 missiles, that were quickly followed by another blip, the suspected aircraft explosion. CNN confirmed CBS and Newsweek's reporting, and U.S. officials told The Associated Press that it was "highly likely" that the aircraft was downed by an Iranian anti-aircraft missile.

President Donald Trump said on Thursday that he did not believe that the passenger jet went down as a result of a mechanical error. "It was flying in a pretty rough neighborhood," the president said. "Someone could have made a mistake." Trump added, "I have a feeling that — it's just some very terrible, something very terrible happened, very devastating."

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Thursday afternoon that Canada also had intelligence and evidence from multiple sources indicating "that the plane was shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile." He added that "this may well have been unintentional" and expressed a desire for a full investigation.

Images appearing to show Tor missile fragments, said to have been found outside Tehran, have been circulating on social media. A video making the rounds appears to show the moment a missile struck the Ukrainian aircraft. Iran has denied responsibility, with Iranian media, citing state officials, arguing that the missile theory is "scientifically impossible" and "illogical" because several domestic and foreign flights were in Iran at the same altitude of 8,000 feet.

Ukrainian investigators are considering several possibilities, including the plane being shot down, an engine explosion due to a technical malfunction, a terrorist attack on the flight, or even a collision with an unmanned aerial vehicle. Oleksiy Danylov, the secretary of Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council, wrote on Facebook earlier Thursday that Ukrainian investigators were considering several possibilities.

Title: "Church Security Expert Warns of Increasing Attacks on Houses of Worship Following Charleston Massacre"

Article:

On September 15, 1999, a gunman entered Wedgwood Baptist Church in Fort Worth, Texas, and opened fire, killing multiple individuals. Since then, Carl Chinn, a statistic compiler, has documented over 1,000 violent attacks on churches, synagogues, and other houses of worship, with more than 150 such incidents occurring this year.

Chinn, who began compiling these statistics in 1999, has identified the attack on Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, as the worst attack on an assembled congregation in American history. Tim Miller, a nationally recognized expert in church security, shares Chinn's concerns, stating that violence directed against churches has been growing over the past decade and fears the Charleston massacre could be the beginning of a series of similar incidents.

Miller, a retired Marine, former Secret Service agent, police officer, and counter-intelligence officer, leads a team that includes former Homeland Security agents, FBI agents, and special-ops personnel. He shifted his focus to church and non-profit security three years ago, recognizing that the same threats previously experienced overseas are now present in the United States.

Churches are considered soft targets, and Miller believes the Charleston massacre should serve as a wake-up call. He expressed concern that the suffering experienced in such incidents is unimaginable. Miller's team helps churches prepare for potential violence while maintaining a welcoming environment for those seeking solace.

The challenge lies in balancing the need for security with the welcoming nature of houses of worship. As the Old Testament Book of Nehemiah suggests, "We prayed to our God and posted a guard."

Title: U.S. Navy to Proceed with Review of SEAL Eddie Gallagher's Status Despite Presidential Support

Article:

The U.S. Navy announced on Thursday that it will move forward with an administrative review board hearing to consider the potential expulsion of Special Operations Chief Eddie Gallagher from the Navy SEALs, despite President Donald Trump's support. Gallagher and three supervising officers were informed of the hearing, scheduled for December 2.

In a tweet earlier Thursday, President Trump stated, "The Navy will NOT be taking away Warfighter and Navy Seal Eddie Gallagher's Trident Pin." He also added, "This case was handled very badly from the beginning. Get back to business!" The Trident Pin is a symbol of membership in the SEALs.

In July, Gallagher was acquitted of murdering a wounded Islamic State militant in Iraq in 2017, but he was convicted on the single charge of posing with the body of the dead prisoner. Last week, Trump restored Gallagher's rank after he had been demoted to petty officer first class. However, the president did not pardon Gallagher for his offense.

In a statement issued late Thursday, Rear Adm. Charlie Brown, Chief of Information, said, "The Navy follows the lawful orders of the President. We will do so in case of an order to stop the administrative review of SOC Gallagher's professional qualification. We are aware of the President's tweet and are awaiting further guidance."

The White House did not respond to an NPR request for comment on the tweet.

Gallagher's lawyers claim that Navy brass is seeking to expel him from the SEALs in retaliation for Trump's reversal of his demotion. They have filed a complaint with the Navy Inspector General, alleging that Naval Special Warfare Commander Rear Adm. Collin Green is defying the president.

"How can Admiral Green credibly preach about preserving good order and discipline while publicly flouting the orders of the commander in chief?" Gallagher's attorney Timothy Parlatore said, as quoted by the Associated Press.

If a review board decision goes against Gallagher, he can then appeal to the Navy's Personnel Command.

Title: Vatican Concludes Doctrinal Assessment of Leadership Conference of Women Religious

Article:

The Vatican has announced an end to the doctrinal overhaul of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious (LCWR), marking the conclusion of a five-year process that began in 2012. The Vatican's announcement on Thursday signifies a perceived shift towards a more merciful church under Pope Francis, as reported by NPR's Sylvia Poggioli.

During their annual visit to Rome, LCWR leaders met with Pope Francis, a meeting described by David Gibson of Religion News Service as another indicator of the thaw in relations. Both parties agreed to maintain silence towards the media for the next month, and the joint statement and final report issued Thursday seemed to represent a quiet and merciful end to the contentious period between the women religious and the Vatican.

The Rev. James Martin, SJ., editor at large of the Jesuit magazine America, stated in a Facebook post that the LCWR agreed to implement some changes, mainly regarding speakers and liturgies at its annual conventions. However, overall, the operations of the LCWR remain intact.

Joshua J. McElwee, writing in the National Catholic Reporter, described the news as bringing an end to an especially contentious period between the women religious and the Vatican. The investigation of the LCWR, which began in 2012 under Cardinal William Levada, the previous head of the Vatican's theological watchdog, was initiated due to concerns that the umbrella group representing most American nuns had strayed from church doctrine and adopted "radical feminist" views. The investigation called for a five-year doctrinal overhaul of the group.

Sister Simone Campbell, head of the Catholic social justice lobby Network, told NPR at the time that the investigation came "like a sock in the stomach." A separate Vatican investigation into U.S. nuns ended last December with the Vatican expressing appreciation for the dedicated work of nuns in education, health, and among the poor.

Title: Obama's 2014 Remarks on Asylum Seekers Resemble Trump's New Regulations

Article:

In a recent development, the Democrats have criticized President Donald Trump for new asylum regulations aimed at addressing the escalating humanitarian crisis at the southern border. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) described the regulations, which mandate migrants to claim asylum in the first safe country they reach, not their preferred country, as "illegal" and "cruel."

However, a 2014 video featuring former President Barack Obama sheds light on the evolution of the Democrats' stance on asylum issues. In the video, Obama stated that poverty and crime are not valid reasons for granting asylum. He explained that under U.S. law, refugees are admitted based on specific criteria, and asylum status is not typically granted due to economic need or dangerous living conditions.

Obama further clarified that the U.S. asylum-request pipeline may not be equipped to handle a large-scale humanitarian asylum crisis. He emphasized that accommodating a large number of additional migrants would not necessarily be feasible.

The context of Obama's comments is traced back to a meeting at the White House in 2014 with Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez, Guatemalan President Otto Perez Molina, and El Salvadorian President Salvador Sanchez Ceren. The meeting was held to discuss a migrant crisis that was affecting Central America, Mexico, and the U.S., particularly the surge of unaccompanied migrant children that overwhelmed U.S. immigration resources.

Title: Actor Mehcad Brooks Features in Center for Reproductive Rights' Video Celebrating 40th Anniversary of Roe v. Wade

Article:

The Center for Reproductive Rights, an organization advocating for the legalization of abortion through legal means, has released a video to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the landmark Supreme Court case Roe v. Wade. The video features actor Mehcad Brooks, known for his roles in USA Network's "Necessary Roughness" and HBO's "True Blood."

The video's release has sparked debate, with some arguing that the involvement of men in the abortion debate is unnecessary, while others view the video as a celebration of the procedure. The video's message has been interpreted as suggesting that men can disregard their responsibilities as fathers due to the availability of abortion.

The Center for Reproductive Rights' choice of Mehcad Brooks for the video has raised questions, given the organization's history and the controversial views of Margaret Sanger, the founder of Planned Parenthood, who was an advocate for birth control and abortion. Sanger's writings have been criticized for expressing racist views, including a belief in the need to limit the reproduction of certain racial groups.

The video has also sparked discussion about the high rate of abortions in the black community. According to data from the Guttmacher Institute and the U.S. Census, black women make up 13% of the female population in the United States, yet they account for 30% of the abortions performed.

The video has been met with criticism for its tone, with some viewing it as glorifying and belittling the serious nature of abortion, a medical procedure with potential lifelong psychological consequences. The Center for Reproductive Rights and Mehcad Brooks have not commented on these criticisms.

The debate surrounding the video will continue tonight, with the issue being discussed on Fox News' "Hannity" at 9:40 pm EST.

Title: SBA Anticipates Imminent Exhaustion of Paycheck Protection Program Funds

Article:

The United States Small Business Administration (SBA) has announced that the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), a relief initiative aimed at supporting small businesses financially impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, may run out of funds as early as Wednesday. As of April 15, 1.3 million loans have been approved, totaling nearly $300 billion.

According to reports, the $349 billion allocated to the PPP program is nearing depletion. This development was first reported by Jennifer Jacobs on Twitter, stating that sources indicate the SBA expects to exhaust the funds imminently, possibly even this afternoon.

The Senate originally legislated $350 billion for the small business sector, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has advocated for additional funding since last week. However, Senate Democrats have blocked this effort. Senate Republicans have proposed a clean bill to legislate an additional $250 billion to the program.

In a tweet on April 13, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer expressed concern over the delay in funding, stating, "Small businesses in rural areas should have access to funds even if they're not customers of larger banks. Small banks & funds should be able to provide this help NOW. Small businesses shouldn’t have to wait while well-connected banks dole out $$ to favored clients."

Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Minority Leader Schumer have accused the Republican party of causing the funding delay, while the GOP has countered that the hold-up was orchestrated by Democrats. Pelosi, in a tweet on April 15, stated, "The Paycheck Protection Program is a crucial tool for protecting workers across the country – yet serious flaws are keeping far too many small businesses from receiving the resources they need. The @ SenateGOP must stop blocking commonsense solutions that put # FamiliesFirst."

The lack of additional funding for the PPP program could result in further economic distress for small businesses, emphasizing the need for Congress to collaborate and swiftly legislate additional funds to support this vital program.

Title: Fact-Checking President Obama's Affordable Care Act Insurance Pledge

Article:

President Obama's pledge that individuals could keep their insurance policies under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has been a subject of controversy in recent weeks, with numerous stories about policy cancellations across the country. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals that the issue is more complex than it appears.

First, it is crucial to understand that the ACA grandfathered all individual policies that were in place at the time the law was enacted. This means that plans that were active at the time President Obama was advocating for the bill could still be offered, even if they did not meet all the ACA's standards.

The policies being terminated due to non-compliance with the ACA's minimal standards were all plans introduced after the passage of the ACA. Insurers introduced these plans knowing they would not meet the standards that would take effect in 2014. Insurers may not have informed their clients at the time they sold these plans that they would not be available after 2014 because they had designed a plan that did not comply with the ACA.

If insurers did not inform their clients that the new plans would only be available for a short period, the blame would seem to rest with the insurance companies, not the ACA. President Obama did not promise people that he would keep insurers from developing new plans that do not comply with the ACA's provisions.

In addition to the new plans that did not comply with the ACA's terms, there have been complaints that the grandfathering was too strict. For example, insurers can only raise their premiums or deductibles by a small amount above the rate of medical inflation. As a result, many of the plans in existence at the time of the ACA are losing their grandfathered status.

In this case, it is wrong to view insurers as passive actors who are being forced to stop offering plans because of the ACA. The price increases charged by insurers are not events outside of the insurers' control. If an insurer offers a plan with many committed buyers, it would presumably be able to structure its changes in ways that are consistent with the ACA. If it decides not to do so, this is presumably because the insurer has decided that it is not interested in continuing to offer the plan.

As a practical matter, there are many plans that insurers will opt to drop for market reasons that may or may not have anything to do with the ACA. It's hard to see how this could be viewed as a violation of President Obama's pledge. After all, insurers change and drop plans all the time. Did people who heard Obama's pledge understand it to mean that insurers would no longer have this option once the ACA passed?

If Obama's pledge was understood as ensuring that every plan that was in existence in 2010 would remain in existence, then it would imply a complete federal takeover of the insurance industry. This would require the government to tell insurers that they must continue to offer plans even if they are losing money on them and even if the plans had lost most of their customers. This would at the least be a strange policy. It would be surprising if many people thought this was the meaning of President Obama's pledge.

Finally, there will be many plans that insurers will stop offering in large part because of the changed market conditions created by the ACA. For example, last week the Washington Post highlighted a plan for the "hardest to insure" that was being cancelled by Pathmark Blue Cross of Pennsylvania. This plan is likely being cancelled because it is unable to compete with the insurance being offered through the exchanges. The exchanges charge everyone the same rate regardless of their pre-existing health conditions. A plan that is especially designed for people who have serious health conditions would almost certainly charge a far higher rate. If these high-priced plans no longer exist because they can not compete with the exchanges, would this mean that President Obama had broken his pledge?

On closer inspection, the claim that President Obama lied in saying that people could keep their insurance looks like another Fox News special. In the only way that the pledge could be interpreted as being meaningful, the pledge is true. The ACA does not eliminate plans that were in existence at the time the bill was approved.

If we want to play Fox News, President Obama also promised people they could keep their doctor. Since 2010, tens of thousands of doctors have retired or even died. Guess the pledge that people could keep their doctor was yet another lie from the Obama administration.

Title: Vice President Pence to Meet with Mexican Officials Amidst Tariff Tensions

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence is set to meet with top Mexican officials on Wednesday, as the Trump administration and Mexico engage in negotiations to avoid the implementation of proposed tariffs on Mexican goods. The tariffs, which could escalate to 25 percent by October, were announced by President Trump last week in response to increasing levels of illegal migration.

Trump stated during a press conference in London on Tuesday that the tariffs are likely to be imposed as scheduled, casting doubt on a quick resolution during the meeting at the White House. Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard is leading the Mexican delegation, with U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also expected to attend.

Ebrard told reporters on Tuesday that the delegation has been preparing for the meeting, which was quickly convened with Pompeo over the weekend. "What Mexico must do and we are doing is to prepare," said Ebrard. "We have our strategy on how to coexist with what sometimes can be unpredictable."

The Trump administration has been vague about the specific steps Mexico would need to take to prevent the tariffs from taking effect, adding to the confusion surrounding the situation. White House trade adviser Peter Navarro, who has advocated for the tariffs, suggested they may not need to take effect at all.
