Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan told ███ in an interview that the administration wants to see Mexico help create a "vast reduction" in illegal crossings by tightening security on its border with Guatemala, expanding intelligence sharing with U.S. law enforcement agencies, and cracking down on migrants crossing its northern border with the U.S.

The economic and diplomatic tensions could slow or halt progress toward the president's North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) revision, which Pence has previously vowed would be approved by this summer. The trade pact was signed by the leaders of all three countries last year but must still be ratified by their legislatures. The U.S. and Mexican governments have both started the formal legislative process, but consideration could be delayed with the tariffs in place.

The private sector added just 27,000 jobs in May, according to a key study, a sign the president's multifront trade war is beginning to have an effect. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said Tuesday the central bank is "closely monitoring" the situation and indicated it could respond by slashing interest rates in order to prevent widespread damage.

Mexico recently became the U.S.'s largest trading partner. Last year, the U.S. imported $346.5 billion in goods from Mexico, according to the U.S. trade representative. Automakers, agricultural companies, and retailers are expected to be hit hardest by the duties, which will be paid for by U.S. importers, who often pass along the cost to consumers.

Title: Boehner Criticizes Obama's Budget Proposal, Citing Lack of Bipartisan Effort

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has criticized the budget President Barack Obama is set to unveil, stating that it takes no steps towards finding common ground with Republicans, despite the president's offer to cut federal entitlement spending.

In a press release, Boehner expressed his disapproval, stating, "If the president believes these modest entitlement savings are needed to help shore up these programs, there's no reason they should be held hostage for more tax hikes. That's no way to lead and move the country forward."

The president's proposal, as described to CNN and other news outlets by senior Obama administration officials, includes changes to Social Security and Medicare, similar to an offer Obama made to Boehner during the fiscal cliff negotiations in December. This would include a cut of $400 billion to Medicare over a decade.

Boehner responded, "The president and I were not able to reach an agreement late last year because his offers never lived up to his rhetoric. Despite talk about so-called balance, the president's last offer was significantly skewed in favor of higher taxes and included only modest entitlement savings. He said he could go no further toward the middle, and that's why his last offer was rejected."

The reported entitlement program changes have also received criticism from left-leaning groups who argue the changes would hurt vulnerable individuals.

Obama's budget also includes tax increases, which Republicans say is a non-starter since taxes were increased on wealthy individuals as part of the final fiscal cliff deal.

"In the end, the president got his tax hikes on the wealthy with no corresponding spending cuts," Boehner wrote. "At some point we need to solve our spending problem, and what the president has offered would leave us with a budget that never balances. In reality, he's moved in the wrong direction, routinely taking off the table entitlement reforms he's previously told me he could support."

Boehner suggested further that Obama's so-called charm offensive was to little avail on budget matters. "When the president visited the Capitol last month, House Republicans stated a desire to find common ground and urged him not to make savings we agree upon conditional on another round of tax increases. If reports are accurate, the president has not heeded that call," Boehner said.

Republicans have roundly criticized Obama for missing the February deadline for submitting his budget proposal. The proposal could be released next week, White House officials have said.

The Republican-led House has previously passed a proposal drafted by Budget Chairman Paul Ryan. It was a budget not warmly received by the Democratic Senate or the White House.

Title: Trump-Erdogan Meeting Fails to Resolve NATO Ally Dispute Over Air Defense Systems

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan failed to reach an agreement during their meeting at the White House on Wednesday, November 13, regarding Turkey's decision to accept delivery of a Russian air defense system that has strained relations between the two NATO allies.

The Turkish president stated he might consider using the U.S.-made Patriot system in addition to the Russian S-400 system. Trump said they would continue working on the issue. Trump acknowledged the S-400 acquisition as creating "very serious challenges" for the U.S., expressing hope for resolving the situation.

The dispute over the competing air defense systems is a significant source of tension between the two countries. Turkey has also faced criticism for its incursion into Syria last month, targeting Kurdish forces that fought alongside the U.S. against the Islamic State. Additionally, Turkey has been criticized for repressing political opponents, journalists, and others.

In response to the Turkish military offensive against U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in northeastern Syria, Erdogan stated, "We're just fighting terrorists, period. If you don't fight back, you will have to pay a very hefty price."

The leaders' news conference, following a meeting with Republican lawmakers at the White House, provided Trump an opportunity to counter the first public hearings in the House impeachment inquiry. Trump stated he did not watch a minute of the televised hearings, which he called a "hoax."

Republicans and Democrats in Congress expressed disapproval of Trump's meeting with Erdogan. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) described the meeting as "mindboggling" and "appalling" after the invasion of Syria. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) stated that significant concerns remain regarding both the S-400 and the attack on the Kurds, who "have risked a lot to stand with America" and battle the Islamic State.

During the news conference, Trump jokingly suggested that Erdogan should only call on a friendly Turkish reporter. When Erdogan called on a female Turkish reporter, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) was overheard whispering to someone seated next to him, "She's the only reporter left over there" in Turkey.

Two Democratic senators have introduced legislation denouncing Turkey's targeting of journalists, political opponents, dissidents, minorities, and others. They claim the Turkish government has imprisoned over 80,000 Turkish citizens, closed more than 1,500 non-governmental organizations on terrorism-related grounds, and dismissed or suspended more than 130,000 civil servants from their jobs.

Title: New York Financial Regulator Proposes Cybersecurity Measures to Protect Against Potential "Armageddon-Type" Attacks

Article:

Ben Lawsky, head of New York's Department of Financial Services (DFS), has expressed concerns about the potential for a large-scale cyber attack on Wall Street firms that could have far-reaching effects on the broader economy. In a speech at Columbia Law School on Wednesday, Lawsky stated, "We are concerned that within the next decade, or perhaps sooner, we will experience an Armageddon-type cyber event that causes a significant disruption in the financial system for a period of time."

In response, Lawsky is considering new regulations to compel banks and insurance companies regulated by DFS to enhance their cybersecurity measures. DFS has regulatory oversight over numerous New York-licensed banks and insurance companies, including Goldman Sachs, MetLife, and Barclays.

To prevent a catastrophic cyber attack, Lawsky plans to incorporate cybersecurity into the grades DFS assigns to the banks and insurance companies it regulates. Financial firms "care deeply" about their grades because they can impact their ability to pay dividends or acquire other companies, Lawsky said.

Lawsky also suggested implementing multifactor authentication systems for employees of DFS-regulated financial firms, stating that single-step passwords are outdated. Additionally, he may require banks and insurance companies licensed by DFS to secure guarantees from third-party vendors that their security meets certain standards.

Lawsky's call for enhanced cybersecurity follows a report last week by Moscow-based security firm Kaspersky Lab, which warned of a group of international cybercriminals who have stolen up to $1 billion from 100 banks across 30 countries by infiltrating their internal systems.

In his speech, Lawsky also addressed the issue of money laundering, proposing new regulations to improve detection of suspicious transactions. He suggested random audits for DFS-licensed banks to assess their effectiveness in flagging such transactions. Lawsky may also require bank executives to certify that their money transaction monitoring is up to par to better protect against terrorism and other crimes.

Lawsky's office has discovered that some banks do not take the monitoring of financial transactions seriously, as evidenced by the recent controversy surrounding British bank Standard Chartered, which was accused by Lawsky of ignoring money laundering. In August, the bank agreed to settle its dispute with DFS by paying $300 million and cutting off dealings with certain customers flagged for their suspicious transactions.

Lawsky stated that DFS caught Standard Chartered by comparing the company's flagging of suspicious transactions with its own system for finding suspicious activity. "We basically ran the company's transactions through our own filtering system and compared the results," Lawsky said, noting that regulators typically rely on self-reporting from the firms they oversee.

"What regulators have not done is actively tested the effectiveness of the filtering systems banks are using," Lawsky said. "That needs to change."

Title: Democrats and Republicans Prepare for 2018 Midterm Elections

Article:

The 2018 midterm elections are expected to be crucial in determining the party in power for the subsequent election cycles. The outcome remains uncertain, with tight polling in numerous states leaving the question unanswered until Election Day in November. However, one fact is clear: Democrats face an uphill battle due to the 33 Senate seats up for grabs, with Democrats currently holding 22 of them, while Republicans hold just eight. Independents hold the remaining two seats.

In response to this challenging situation, Democrats are reportedly enlisting high-profile figures for support. Former President Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, are among those being called in to assist. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, admitted last week that Democratic Senate candidates welcome the support of Obama and the Clintons.

According to Hollen, Clinton has already been reaching out to campaigns. The twice-failed presidential candidate started "Onward Together" last year, an organization focused on electing Democrats nationwide. Hollen stated, "I think she's going to continue to reach out to candidates and let them know that she's ready to help in any way that she can. These are really conversations that go on between Secretary Clinton or President Obama and the particular campaign."

In the House of Representatives, every seat is up for grabs during each election cycle. If Democrats aim to regain control of the House, they have significant work ahead, as Republicans currently hold a 42-seat majority.

However, in California, the situation appears chaotic for Democrats running for the House. The New York Times reports that national Democrats are pouring millions of dollars into congressional races to prevent a self-inflicted disaster that could jeopardize their chances of taking control of the House. The issue stems from the large number of Democrats running in important primaries, causing national party leaders to fear losing seats or being less competitive compared to the more organized Republicans.

Title: Senate Republicans Tasked with Proposing Obamacare Replacement, Despite Resistance

Article:

President Donald Trump has assigned three Republican senators the task of developing a replacement for the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, if the courts rule against it. This move is seen as a prudent contingency plan, but Republican senators, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have expressed reluctance to take up this assignment.

The Senate is expected to wait for a potential deal between the White House and Democrats on health care before addressing the issue, according to Republican strategists. This strategy is based on the assumption that it is more advantageous for the party to focus on criticizing Democratic proposals rather than presenting their own health care plan.

However, this strategy may not be effective, as many Republicans running for office in 2020 have already expressed a desire to replace Obamacare. The Republican administration is also advocating for the abolition of the health law in court. Democrats can easily accuse Republicans of seeking to eliminate a health law relied upon by millions of Americans.

If the lawsuit against Obamacare fails, it is unlikely that a conservative health care plan could pass through a Democratic-controlled House. Additionally, there is limited chance that a conservative plan could serve as the basis for a bipartisan compromise. This was a similar situation during the Obama administration, when Republicans chose not to settle on a health care plan due to concerns about enacting legislation they had no way to pass.

The key innovation of Obamacare was the centralization of health insurance regulation in Washington, D.C., which led to a decrease in choice and an increase in costs. Republicans tasked with replacing Obamacare should work to undo this centralization, according to the article.

One proposed solution is for the federal government to remove many of Obamacare's regulations and redirect the money currently flowing to Obamacare's exchanges and Medicaid expansions to state governments. State governments would then determine how to spend the money to meet their residents' health care needs.

Under this proposal, states could use a portion of the Obamacare money to buy insurance for able-bodied Medicaid recipients above the poverty line, while prioritizing those who are disabled, below the poverty line, or both. States could also allow Medicaid recipients to use a share of the Obamacare money to buy insurance on the private market.

Republican officeholders are encouraged to contribute their ideas to modify this basic template or propose a wholly different idea. The article concludes that it is important for Republicans not to simply hold off the next Democrat-led lurch to the left for a few years, and for conservatives not to let them. President Trump's challenge to his party is seen as a welcome one.

Title: Senate to Vote on Federal Reserve Audit Legislation in 2015

Article:

After years of being blocked by former Democratic leader Harry Reid, the Senate will finally have a chance next year to vote on legislation to audit the Federal Reserve's decision-making. The push for a full audit of the country's central bank has been led by Sen. Rand Paul and others, and has the backing of the new Republican majority leader, Sen. Mitch McConnell.

Despite overwhelming support in the House, where the legislation has passed twice, the bill is not a sure thing in the Senate. The Federal Reserve itself is pushing back against the audit, with Chairwoman Janet L. Yellen stating earlier this month that the Fed remains opposed to stricter oversight of its monetary policy decisions.

For supporters in Congress, the fight is a matter of constitutional prerogatives and good governance. They argue that the Federal Reserve oversaw trillions of dollars of stimulus during the 2009 Recovery Act, while the Act's spending and tax cuts totaled $800 billion.

In the House, legislation calling for an audit has passed twice, including most recently in September on a 333-92 vote. All but one Republican, and more than half of the Democrats in the chamber, voted for the legislation. However, former Democratic leader Harry Reid refused to give the bill floor time in the Senate, bottling it up in both 2012 and 2014.

With the GOP netting nine seats in November's elections, delivering control over the floor schedule to Sen. Mitch McConnell and undercutting Mr. Reid's power, the change in Senate leadership presents the best opportunity yet to get a stand-alone vote on "Audit the Fed." However, Norm Singleton, vice president of policy at Campaign for Liberty, cautions that it is not a "slam dunk."

"This is popular with 75 percent of the American people, but it's not popular among Wall Street; it's not popular among banks; it's not popular among foreign central banks," Mr. Singleton said. "These hold a fair amount of sway among both parties, so just to say that a change in party necessarily means we'll be able to move Audit the Fed - it's better odds now than we've had before, but it's not a slam dunk."

Sen. Paul's spokesman, Sergio Gor, confirmed that they will make sure the bill is available for the new Congress. "It will be among the first pieces of legislation to be introduced as soon as the new Congress convenes in January," Mr. Gor said. "Transparency at the Federal Reserve remains a top priority for Senator Rand Paul."

Congress established the Federal Reserve nearly a century ago. The system, which consists of a board of governors and 12 regional banks, acts as lender of last resort to the country's banking system, and it is charged with fighting inflation and promoting economic growth and employment. The interest rates it sets have a direct impact on the rates that banks charge consumers.

The audit legislation would grant the Government Accountability Office, Congress's chief investigative arm, the power to retroactively review the Fed's decision-making, particularly on monetary policy. Ms. Yellen and her defenders argue that giving the GAO audit powers could amount to having their decisions scrutinized almost in real time, which they say could influence the closed-door deliberations by the Fed.

Title: Trump Tweets Criticism of Adam Schiff, Democrats Plan to Release Counter-Memo on FBI Surveillance Allegations

Article:

President Donald Trump has tweeted criticism of Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat from California, in a series of tweets on Monday morning. Trump accused Schiff of being a "big liar and leaker" in Washington, and claimed that Schiff illegally leaks confidential information from closed committee hearings.

In response, Schiff tweeted, "Mr. President, I see you've had a busy morning of 'Executive Time.' Instead of tweeting false smears, the American people would appreciate it if you turned off the TV and helped solve the funding crisis, protected Dreamers or... really anything else."

Trump did not provide evidence that Schiff has illegally leaked confidential information. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment Monday morning.

Democrats plan to offer a motion at a Monday business meeting to release their counter-memo to the Republican memo, which alleges that the FBI improperly used information paid for in part by Hillary Clinton's campaign to obtain a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant for then-Trump campaign foreign policy adviser Carter Page. Trump has said the memo "totally vindicates" him in the Russia probe.

Last week, Republicans blocked a Democratic attempt to release their memo at the same time as the memo spearheaded by Chairman Devin Nunes of California. Republicans have since said they would vote to release the Democratic memo, drafted by Schiff.

In a separate tweet, Trump praised Nunes, calling him a "man of tremendous courage and grit" and suggesting that he may be recognized as a "Great American Hero" for his actions.

The four-page GOP memo, which was declassified and released last Friday, has sparked a political firestorm, with Democrats accusing the Republicans of cherry-picking information to support their narrative of FBI surveillance abuses. The Democrats' counter-memo is expected to rebut the Republican document. If approved by the committee, the matter would be sent to Trump, who would have five days to object to its release.

Title: Trump Defends Steel Tariffs, Faces Criticism from Allies and China

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended his decision to impose tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, stating that "trade wars are good and easy to win." The tariffs, which will be 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum, have been met with criticism from manufacturers and trade partners in China and Europe. The formal order is expected to be signed next week.

In a tweet on Friday, Trump said, "When a country (USA) is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win." The details of the planned action, including any product or country exemptions, have not been disclosed.

The planned tariffs, justified on the basis of cut-price metal imports hurting American producers and national security, have raised the prospect of tit-for-tat curbs on American exports and higher prices for domestic users. While the practical impact may yet turn out to be limited, the political environment for global trade has taken a turn for the worse.

The response in China, the world's largest steel producer, has been muted. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying merely said in Beijing that China urges the U.S. to follow trade rules. Industry insiders, however, have been less restrained. Wen Xianjun, vice chairman of the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association, said the U.S. measures "overturn the international trade order."

U.S. allies, seeing their industries threatened, have responded with bafflement and dismay. Some also panned the idea that metal imports pose a threat to national security. Japan's Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko said, "Steel and aluminum imports from Japan, which is an ally, do not affect U.S. national security at all."

The European Union has vowed to "react firmly" with World Trade Organization-compliant countermeasures, while Canada, the biggest foreign supplier of steel to the U.S., said the measures were unacceptable. Australian Trade Minister Steve Ciobo called the move "disappointing" and said his country is seeking an exemption.

The tariffs could potentially level the unfair playing field that has persisted for years, making it easier for American companies to expand and hire workers, according to Trump. However, U.S. companies that use aluminum for manufacturing and packaging, such as beer brewer MillerCoors and candymaker Hershey Co., have said operations would be hurt by the tariffs.

The impact of the step hinges in part on which nations will be affected, and until the final scope of the tariffs and the response from global trading partners is known, it's hard to say it's the start of a tit-for-tat trade war. The move risks provoking retaliation, particularly from Beijing, which has already launched a probe into U.S. imports of sorghum and is studying whether to restrict shipments of U.S. soybeans.

Title: Senator Marco Rubio Warns of Potential ISIS Attack on U.S. Homeland

Article:

Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) has issued a chilling assessment suggesting that the jihadist ISIS insurgents, currently dominating parts of Iraq, will eventually launch attacks on the United States. Rubio, a member of the Senate's Foreign Relations and Select Intelligence Committees, believes that President Barack Obama's use of military force to protect American diplomats and military personnel in Iraq is not sufficient.

In his statement, Rubio warns that if decisive action against ISIS is not taken now, it will not only be Iraqis and Syrians who suffer, but Americans as well, due to a potential terrorist attack on the U.S. homeland or on U.S. personnel overseas. Rubio draws a parallel to the Clinton administration's handling of al-Qaeda in the 1990s, stating that terrorist groups, once established, use safe havens to launch attacks on the United States and its interests.

Rubio asserts that ISIS, with thousands of foreign fighters, many from the West, will not rest after taking the Kurdish capital of Irbil or Baghdad. He asserts that ISIS's expansionist ideology will lead it to attack U.S. allies in the region and eventually Europe and the United States.

Senator Rubio calls for an increase in military and humanitarian assistance to the Iraqi government, as well as the Kurdistan Regional Government. His warning echoes that of Senate Intelligence Committee chair Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), who has also expressed concern about ISIS's recruitment of fighters in Western countries and the potential threat they pose to European and American cities.

Feinstein has called for a broader military campaign against ISIS, stating, "It takes an army to defeat an army, and I believe that we either confront [ISIS] now or we will be forced to deal with an even stronger enemy in the future." She concludes, "Inaction is no longer an option."

Title: Clinton Accuses Trump of Inviting Alt-Right Movement, Ties Campaign to Racist Ideology

Article:

In a speech in Reno, Nevada on Thursday, Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton accused Republican nominee Donald Trump of inviting the "alt-right" movement into the political landscape. Clinton described the alt-right as an emerging racist ideology, characterized by anti-Semitic, white supremacist, anti-Muslim, anti-immigrant, and anti-women views.

The alt-right, primarily an online movement, uses websites, chat boards, social media, and memes to disseminate its ideology. The Star of David image that Trump was criticized for retweeting was reportedly first posted on an alt-right message board. The movement's members are predominantly young, white men who identify as champions of their own demographic, with their greatest points of unity lying in what they are against: multiculturalism, immigration, feminism, and political correctness.

Nicole Hemmer, a University of Virginia professor and author of a forthcoming book on the right, explained on NPR's Morning Edition that the alt-right views political correctness as the greatest threat to their liberty. They believe that saying racist or anti-Semitic things is not an act of hate, but an act of freedom.

The alt-right movement differs from traditional conservatism in several ways. Its origins can be traced to many conservatives' opposition to the policies of President George W. Bush, particularly the U.S. invasion of Iraq (alt-righters are strictly isolationist). They are also suspicious of free markets, a key tenet of conservatism, as they believe that business interests can often be in conflict with their higher ideals—those of cultural preservation and homogeneity.

Two self-proclaimed leaders of the alt-right movement, Allum Bokhari and Milo Yiannopoulos of Breitbart, have outlined a manifesto of sorts for the group's beliefs and alliances. They claim that "beltway conservatives" despise alt-right adherents more than Democrats or progressive liberals. Instead, they see themselves as "natural conservatives," with an "instinctive wariness of the foreign and the unfamiliar."

Last week, Trump announced that Stephen Bannon, chairman of Breitbart News Network, which Bannon has called "the platform for the alt-right," would be his campaign's new chief executive. Hemmer stated that by putting Breitbart at the forefront of his campaign, Trump has elevated the alt-right. However, Hemmer suspects that Trump—and the majority of his supporters—do not pledge allegiance to the alt-right movement. Instead, they see Trump as a means to spread their ideas.

Clinton is expected to continue drawing a link between Trump and the alt-right in the minds of voters, reminding them that whatever the new moderate face of Trump might be, there are the things he has said and the implications of those statements, as well as the people he has brought into his campaign.

Title: Federal Health Care Exchange Enrollment Reaches 100 as of October 2, According to House Oversight Committee Documents

Article:

According to documents provided to the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, 100 Americans had successfully enrolled in the federal health care exchange by October 2. The documents, which were posted online Thursday, also indicate that the six enrolled individuals were issued policies from five different insurance companies.

The notes from a "war room" meeting at the Center for Consumer Information and Insurance, which is part of the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, underscore the beleaguered debut of the online marketplace. The documents show that Healthcare Service Corporation had two enrollments, while approximately 100 enrollments had taken place since the launch of the federal exchange by the next meeting held that afternoon.

Joanne Peters, a Health and Human Services spokeswoman, stated that the department declined to release the number of Americans who have been able to successfully enroll in the exchange. "We will release enrollment statistics on a monthly basis after coordinating information from different sources such as paper, online, and call centers, verifying with insurers and collecting data from states," Peters said.

Peters reiterated that a slow start does not mean that the exchange will not boast a healthy roll call by the deadline to enroll. "We have always anticipated that the pace of enrollment will increase throughout the enrollment period," Peters said. Citing the quiet pace at which Massachusetts residents registered for that state's health program, the spokeswoman remained confident that enrollment totals would tick up as more people learned about the exchange.

HHS remains focused on providing accurate enrollment totals and cannot yet give those figures due to collection issues. "We have had more than 20 million visitors to the Marketplace, showing an overwhelming interest in Americans learning more about their options for affordable health care," Peters said.

Title: Republican Presidential Aspirants Criticize Hillary Clinton at New Hampshire GOP Summit

Article:

In the New Hampshire city of Nashua, the Republican presidential candidates gathered for a two-day summit over the weekend, with Hillary Clinton, the Democratic frontrunner, being the main topic of discussion. Kentucky Senator Rand Paul delivered the strongest criticism of Clinton, focusing on her handling of the situation in Libya, particularly the 2012 attack on the U.S. Embassy in Benghazi.

"I think her dereliction of duty, her not doing her job, should forever preclude her from holding high office," Paul said.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker suggested that Clinton's shopping habits may have left her out of touch with the average American. "I doubt the presumptive nominee for the other party has ever been to Kohl's before," he said.

Hillary Clinton is scheduled to visit New Hampshire on Monday and Tuesday, but for the weekend, the political world's focus was on the Republicans in Nashua. The Republican candidates primarily attacked Clinton and President Obama, while calling for a freer economy and stronger foreign policy.

Florida Senator Marco Rubio managed to weave a compelling narrative, tying his Cuban immigrant parents' pursuit of the American dream to his efforts to save it for his daughters. Rubio positioned 2016 as a "referendum on our national identity," saying that his children and their generation would be "the first to inherit a diminished country from their parents."

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush attempted to assuage primary voters concerned about a potential Clinton-Bush general election, stating, "I don't see any coronation coming my way, trust me."

The field's policy differences were on display, with Paul taking on his own party over Libya, advocating that the United States should never have waded into the conflict there in the first place. South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham and Texas Senator Ted Cruz, in particular, advocated a more muscular role in the Middle East.

Former Hewlett-Packard executive Carly Fiorina's speech was devoid of substance but managed to catch attention with her allusion to the Monica Lewinsky scandal and a rebuke of a Dallas businesswoman's comment that only men should be elected President.

The candidates' stage presence varied, with Bobby Jindal being considered the most forgettable speaker, while Donald Trump managed to both insult the audience and win their applause with his comments about running for president.

Overall, the Republican candidates used the summit to criticize Hillary Clinton, attack President Obama, and present their visions for a stronger economy and foreign policy.

Title: Justice Department Declines to Investigate Trump-Zelensky Call, Citing Lack of Evidence for Quid Pro Quo or Campaign Finance Violation

Article:

The Department of Justice (DOJ) has announced that it will not investigate the July phone call between President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, which prompted a formal impeachment inquiry into allegations of a quid pro quo scheme. In a statement on Wednesday, DOJ spokesperson Kerri Kupec stated, "Relying on established procedures set forth in the Justice Manual, the Department's Criminal Division reviewed the official record of the call and determined, based on the facts and applicable law, that there was no campaign finance violation and that no further action was warranted."

During the call, Trump repeatedly asked Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden's son, Hunter Biden, over allegations that the former vice president used his position to help a Ukrainian energy company avoid a corruption probe soon after Hunter was appointed to its board of directors. On Tuesday, Trump admitted that he temporarily withheld military aid from Ukraine that was intended to help the country ward off Russian aggression, prompting suspicion of a quid pro quo scheme. If a quid pro quo deal was struck, it may constitute a campaign finance law violation since a foreign national, Zelensky, would have been providing Trump's campaign assistance in the form of opposition research on his chief political rival, Joe Biden.

The White House on Wednesday released a partial transcript of the call, which revealed Trump did in fact ask Zelensky to help Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani investigate Biden's influence in firing a Ukrainian prosecutor. The whistleblower complaint from an anonymous member of the intelligence community was submitted to the Director of National Intelligence's inspector general and subsequently sent to the DOJ in August.

An Office of Legal Counsel opinion released by the DOJ on Wednesday said the whistleblower complaint was not an "urgent concern" and challenged the idea that the complaint must be sent to the congressional intelligence committees. However, Senate Republicans on Tuesday unanimously approved a non-binding measure proposed by Democrats calling on the Trump administration to turn the complaint over to Congress.

Title: President-elect Trump Steps Down from Business Empire to Focus on Presidency, Announces Cabinet Picks and Job Creation Efforts

Article:

President-elect Donald Trump has announced his decision to step down from his multi-million dollar business empire to focus on his role as the nation's new commander in chief. In a tweet before dawn on Wednesday, Trump stated, "I will be leaving my great business in total to fully focus on running the country in order to make America great again."

Trump explained that he felt it was important, as president, to avoid any conflict of interest with his various businesses. The news comes as the Trump transition continues, with more cabinet picks, a Twitter firestorm, and a significant win on job creation.

Among the latest cabinet selections are Steven Mnuchin for treasury secretary, who, if confirmed by the Senate, will play a key role in shaping Trump's tax policy. Wilbur Ross, a Wall Street financier, was chosen to lead the Commerce Department. Elaine Chao, who served as labor secretary under George W. Bush and is the wife of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky), was announced as the secretary of transportation.

Robert Johnson, the founder of BET, was offered a post but declined, stating that, as an entrepreneur, he did not want to enter government bureaucracy. Johnson also said he has never considered Trump to be a racist or anti-African-American.

The biggest question at present is who will be selected for the position of secretary of state. Trump has been meeting with potential candidates for this role, with Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn) commenting, "The secretary of state's role is so important to a president. He needs to choose someone that he is very comfortable with."

Trump also had an elegant dinner with Mitt Romney on Tuesday, despite Romney's criticism during the campaign. Romney has since praised Trump for his victory in the election and his "message of inclusion."

General David Petraeus, former CIA director, is also under consideration for the top diplomat position.

Trump caused a Twitter storm on Tuesday with a tweet stating, "Nobody should be allowed to burn the American flag -- if they do, there must be consequences, perhaps loss of citizenship or a year in jail." The Supreme Court has ruled that flag burning is constitutionally protected speech.

In addition to job creation efforts, Trump is also making progress on other key campaign promises, such as repealing the Affordable Care Act, fixing the immigration system, and strengthening the economy by cutting taxes and government regulations and bringing back jobs. The air conditioning company Carrier Corp. has reached a deal with the president-elect to keep nearly 1,000 jobs in Indiana, fulfilling a campaign promise.

Title: Federal Court Unseals Fusion GPS Bank Records, Reveals Details of Payments and Projects

Article:

A federal court in Washington, D.C., unsealed documents in a lawsuit over Fusion GPS's bank records on Tuesday, providing new details of payments made last year to the opposition research firm that commissioned the infamous Trump dossier. The documents also shed light on requests made by the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence about payments that Fusion GPS made to journalists.

The records, unsealed in response to a ruling made last week by Richard Leon, a federal judge in the district court in Washington, D.C., reveal transactions between two law firms that Fusion GPS worked with last year on two Russia-related projects.

Perkins Coie, the law firm that represented the Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee (DNC), paid Fusion GPS a total of $1,024,408 between May 24, 2016, and Dec. 28, 2016, according to the records. The largest payment was made just before the election, with Perkins Coie making a $365,275 payment to Fusion GPS on Oct. 28, 2016. A payment made to Fusion in late-December is later than previously thought.

The transaction list does not show payments that Fusion made to Christopher Steele, the former British spy who wrote the dossier. Fusion reportedly paid Steele a total of $168,000 for his work, which lasted from June 2016 until the election.

The records show that Fusion was also paid $523,651 by the law firm BakerHostetler between March 7, 2016, and Oct. 31, 2016. Fusion worked for BakerHostetler to investigate Bill Browder, a London-based banker who helped push through the Magnitsky Act, a sanctions law vehemently opposed by the Kremlin.

BakerHostetler represented Prevezon Holdings and its owner, a Russian businessman named Denis Katsyv. Katsyv and Prevezon sought to limit the impact of the Magnitsky sanctions.

Glenn Simpson, a former Wall Street Journal reporter and Fusion GPS founding partner, compiled the research for the anti-Browder project. He worked closely with Natalia Veselnitskaya, the Russian lawyer who also showed up at the infamous Trump Tower meeting held on June 9, 2016. Simpson's research ended up in the Trump Tower meeting in the form of a four-page memo carried by Veselnitskaya. She also shared Simpson's work with Yuri Chaika, the prosecutor general of Russia.

Simpson testified this week that he did not know that Veselnitskaya provided the Browder information to Chaika or to Donald Trump Jr., the Trump campaign's point-man in the Trump Tower meeting. Simpson also stated that he did not know that Veselnitskaya had visited Trump Tower until it was reported in the press earlier this year.

The unsealed documents also reveal details of the House committee's requests for records related to Fusion's payments to journalists. The document shows that the committee sought records related to "five Fusion payments to research and Russia expert [name redacted]" and the production of three additional payments. The committee also seeks records "related to Fusion's payments to journalists who have reported on Russia issues relevant to its investigation."

In a memo filed Tuesday, lawyers for the House panel stated they are seeking transactions related to nine payments made to "three individual journalists...each of whom have reported on and/or been quoted in articles regarding topics related to the Committee's investigation, some of which were published as recently as October 2017." The names of the journalists are redacted in the filing.

It is not clear from the requests whether Fusion GPS paid active journalists for their work. The firm is known to employ a stable of former reporters. Simpson and his two founding partners, Peter Fritsch and Thomas Catan, worked together at The Wall Street Journal.

The unsealed filings show that Fusion argued against releasing records related to payments to journalists. In a Nov. 3 declaration, Fritsch argued that "transactions between Fusion GPS and certain journalists...are not pertinent to work related to Russia or Donald Trump." And in a Nov. 2 email to the Intel committee's legal team, Levy argued that "records related to payments to the journalists and 'individuals' are protected by the First Amendment and confidentiality, and they are not pertinent."

Title: Justice Department Drops Charges Against John Edwards

Article:

The Justice Department has decided not to retry former Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards following a federal judge's declaration of a mistrial in his corruption case two weeks ago. The department filed an "order for dismissal" on Wednesday in the U.S. District Court in North Carolina, dismissing the remaining five counts against Edwards on which the jury had been deadlocked.

Assistant Attorney General Lanny Breuer defended the department's decision to prosecute the case, stating, "We knew that this case -- like all campaign finance cases -- would be challenging. But it is our duty to bring hard cases when we believe that the facts and the law support charging a candidate for high office with a crime."

The jurors could not reach a unanimous verdict on five of the six counts of the indictment, and the government respects their judgment, according to Breuer. Edwards was already found not guilty on one other count.

Edwards' attorneys, Abbe Lowell, Allison Van Laningham, and Alan Duncan, welcomed the decision in a joint written statement. They asserted that while Edwards had admitted to his sins, he did not violate any campaign law nor did he imagine that any campaign laws could apply.

Judge Catherine Eagles declared a mistrial two weeks ago after the jury was unable to reach a verdict on most of the counts alleging Edwards accepted illegal campaign contributions. Prosecutors had tried to prove that hush money sent to his mistress by wealthy donors during the 2008 presidential campaign constituted illegal donations. Edwards' lawyers, however, claimed the money was meant to hide his affair from his wife Elizabeth, who has since died of cancer, and not from voters.

Edwards stated after the trial that while he does not believe he did anything illegal, "I did an awful, awful lot that was wrong."

Title: Republican Senator Jeff Sessions Accuses Obama Administration of Failing to Enforce Century-Old Immigration Law

Article:

Republican Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, the top Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, has accused the Obama administration of failing to enforce a century-old law meant to prevent immigrants from taking root in the United States to live on government welfare. The administration reported that no one was cited for this violation last year.

Sessions stated that "virtually no one" is being examined before they enter the country to determine if they will immediately begin to depend on government welfare. He emphasized that any immigration reform package "has got to end that."

Last week, Sessions presented new statistics from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) that he described as a startling trend. DHS reported that relatively few immigrants are being turned away on the grounds that they are likely to become a "public charge" - individuals who depend on welfare programs - despite a 100-year-old law that is supposed to prevent this.

The department, citing "data entry quality," reported that it did not have complete information on how many immigrants became public charges. However, DHS conducted a case-by-case review for the bulk of fiscal 2012, and found just one instance where this claim was leveled at an immigrant. "However, the charge was later withdrawn," DHS reported.

Further, DHS reported that only a tiny fraction of people are rejected on these grounds when seeking entry under a program that allows admission for 90 days for travelers from certain countries. Between fiscal 2005 and most of fiscal 2012, a total of 9,796 were denied - a fraction of a percent of those admitted. State Department figures for visa applications showed a similar trend, with just 0.068 percent of visa applications denied on these grounds in fiscal 2011.

Sessions has been vocal about this issue for months. He and other Republican senators earlier wrote to the departments of Homeland Security and State arguing that a bedrock principle of immigration law is that "those who seek citizenship in this country ought to be financially self-sufficient."

The senator suggests the immigration system has produced a lopsided result in which high-skill immigrants are turned away while those who end up absorbing more taxpayer dollars than they contribute stay.

Recent studies show welfare spending on immigrant-headed households is relatively high. A Center for Immigration Studies report found that 36 percent of these households were using "at least one major welfare program" in 2010 - compared with 23 percent of other households.

Sessions' office states that the number of non-citizens on food stamps has increased significantly in recent years. The conservative Heritage Foundation claims low-skill immigrant households take in roughly $20,000 more in government benefits every year than they pay in taxes.

Sessions suggests the government is fueling this trend. He previously criticized long-running U.S. Department of Agriculture radio "novelas" that depicted people being pressured into going on food stamps. The ads were later discontinued. The senator is also drawing attention to the WelcomeToUSA.gov site that provides information on a host of taxpayer assistance programs for immigrants, including Medicare, food stamps, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, and others.

Title: Treasury Lifts Sanctions on Three Russian Companies Tied to Oleg Deripaska, Maintains Sanctions on Oligarch

Article:

The U.S. Treasury Department announced on Wednesday that it will remove sanctions imposed on three Russian companies, United Co. Rusal PLC, EN+ Group PLC, and JSC EuroSibEnergo, due to their ownership or control by Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska. The companies were placed on the U.S. sanctions list in April.

The Treasury Department stated that the companies agreed to a sweeping deal centered on severing Deripaska's ties with them, resulting in their removal from the blacklist. The removals, expected to take place in 30 days, are based on a change in factual circumstances "in line with longstanding U.S. sanctions precedent" that "is not intended to significantly alter U.S. foreign policy."

The Treasury Department had issued licenses at least six times since April, allowing the companies to continue operating while they worked with the U.S. government to reach a satisfactory divestment plan. The deal would be a binding agreement between the companies and the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), the Treasury's sanctions office.

The agreement requires Deripaska to reduce his ownership stake in EN+ from 70% to 44.95%, and he is prohibited from increasing his stake. In reducing his stake, Deripaska won't receive cash for his shares nor from future dividends issued by the companies, according to the agreement.

EN+ is "the linchpin" underlying the sanctions designations on all three companies, as Deripaska has virtually no direct ownership in Rusal and none at all in EuroSibEnergo. The agreement also requires sweeping governance changes, including limiting Deripaska's voting rights in EN+, creating a 12-person board mostly independent of him, and committing him to severing his ability to control the company.

EN+ will continue to control Rusal through a 56.88% stake, and it will retain the right to nominate the chief executive. EN+ also will use that majority control to create a 14-person board, most of whom will have no ties to Deripaska. Rusal's current chairman will step down, with the new chair held by one of the new directors. EuroSibEnergo, which is wholly owned by EN+, will provide the Treasury with monthly certifications they are not acting on behalf of Deripaska.

The companies will face severe consequences if they fail to comply with the agreement, including being put back on the sanctions list, according to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. "OFAC maintains the ability under the terms of the agreement to have unprecedented levels of transparency into operations," he said.

David Murray, a vice president at consulting firm Financial Integrity Network who previously served as the director of Treasury's illicit finance office, commented that the deal provides a roadmap for other companies to pursue sanctions removal if they're not actively involved in illicit conduct. "What we have is an outline of expectations that OFAC may have for other companies targeted solely because they're owned or controlled by someone on the sanctions list," Mr. Murray said.

Aluminum prices, which fell to a 16-month low before the sanctions announcement was made Wednesday, could head lower once the sanctions are lifted. Some analysts had predicted aluminum prices would rise again in 2019, based in part on the sanctions against Rusal, the world's second-largest aluminum producer. "If (the sanctions) had not been solved, at least half of Rusal's production would have had to shut down," said Lloyd O' Carroll, an independent analyst for the metals industry. "That's not happening now."

Title: Town Hall Debate Format Presents Challenges for President Obama

Article:

The town hall-style debate, popularized by former President Bill Clinton in 1992, is set to feature President Barack Obama and former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney in the upcoming presidential debate. However, the town hall format presents a distinct disadvantage for President Obama, according to Chris Arterton, a professor of political management at George Washington University.

Democratic partisans are expecting more passion from President Obama, perhaps not as intense as the vice presidential debate, but more than he displayed in the first presidential debate. The challenge lies in the fact that the town hall format requires the president to engage Romney in a more confrontational manner while simultaneously responding to the person asking the question.

Alan Schroeder, a journalism professor at Northeastern University, agrees that it will be a balancing act for the president. The town hall format is more conversational, with a greater emphasis on dialogue with the questioner. Candidates are known for dodging questions and delivering rehearsed political soliloquies, but ignoring a working mother of two from Red Hook would not be an option in a town hall setting.

In a town hall debate, responsiveness to the question is a key measurement, according to Schroeder. Candidates also need to navigate the physical space and adapt to the different format, which includes being seated and moving around more freely.

In 1992, Clinton's town hall performance was marked by his engagement with the audience, walking around more freely, and being more responsive. This year, both Romney and Obama need to directly engage the citizen asking the question and respond in a way that showcases their understanding of grassroots politics.

However, the town hall debate format has become more controlled since the days of Bush-Clinton, with no more random questions. Candidates now have to write their questions on a piece of paper, and the moderator chooses the question, with the questioner not allowed to depart from their written question or follow up. This has led to debates being less spontaneous, as seen in the 2008 town hall debate between Obama and GOP nominee Sen. John McCain, which Schroeder described as one of the dullest presidential debates in history.

The tussle over control of the format is ongoing, with CNN anchor Candy Crowley, who will moderate the debate, raising hackles on both sides for suggesting she may take a more active role in the questioning. As the debate approaches, President Obama may need to change his tactics while still maintaining a consistent image. In 2000, Vice President Al Gore changed his style from debate to debate, according to Arterton, and people struggled to get a fix on who he was.

Title: Tucker Carlson Criticizes Mainstream Media and Political Violence in Interview

Article:

In a recent interview with ███ News, Fox News host Tucker Carlson criticized the mainstream media for allegedly being "water carriers for the Democratic Party." The criticism comes amidst a series of protests, some of which have turned violent, targeting political figures, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

Last Friday, an angry protester confronted McConnell and his wife, Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao, at a restaurant in Kentucky. The protester demanded they leave the establishment and the country, and later followed McConnell to his car, throwing his to-go box out the door.

Carlson, in his interview, accused the mainstream media of mirroring the Democratic Party's political objectives and presenting news in line with the party's talking points. He also suggested that the Democratic Party is not in control of its "crazy people on the street" who are committing acts of violence.

When asked about alleged violence on the political Right, Carlson stated that while there are extremists on all sides, there are currently no groups of conservatives engaging in the same level of disruptive behavior as those on the Left, such as screaming at Democratic lawmakers in restaurants, on airplanes, or in airports, or smashing Starbucks windows and blocking traffic.

Carlson's comments come as part of a broader discussion on the country's heated politics, which he addresses in his new book, "Ship of Fools: How a Selfish Ruling Class is Bringing America to the Brink of Revolution."

Title: Leaked GOP Proposal Offers Detailed Look at Obamacare Replacement Plan

Article:

In a significant development, a leaked draft proposal has provided the most comprehensive and specific glimpse to date at the long-awaited Obamacare replacement plan from the Republican Party. The document, while not a finalized piece of legislation, offers a roadmap for the GOP's approach to overhauling the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare.

The leaked proposal eliminates many of the market-distorting provisions contained within the ACA, such as the individual mandate to purchase insurance, and subsidies that reduce the incentives for those outside the labor force to remain there. Instead, the plan would establish tax credits based on age, not income, to help uninsured patients afford private insurance plans.

The plan also scales back or eliminates some of the ACA's most burdensome tax provisions, including the Medicare surtax on wages and self-employment income. It eliminates federal Medicaid expansion by 2020, but preserves capped payments to states based on the number of enrollees in states that expanded Medicaid already.

The plan also includes grants to states that would allow them to experiment with programs designed to increase coverage rates or reduce premiums. This approach, according to conservative healthcare wonk Avik Roy, represents a departure from the ACA's federally-driven mandate bonanza and could help create a wider array of available coverage, including cheaper options, and stabilize the risk pools that the ACA is ruining.

However, the plan also includes elements that appear to partially mimic or tweak the ACA's existing provisions. For instance, the proposal still prohibits insurers from denying coverage to people with pre-existing conditions, so long as those people have maintained continuous coverage. This, according to Roy, strongly incentivizes consumers to obtain coverage without imposing an individual mandate tax, which is repealed under this plan.

The draft GOP plan also faces criticism for its approach to tax credits, with some arguing that the proposed amounts are flawed. The proposal also entails critical reforms to Medicaid (through a form of flexible block-granting) and Health Savings Accounts (HSAs), and pumps billions into a modernized version of high-risk pools.

Overall, the GOP plan represents a significant shift from the ACA, with the core of the troubled law being removed and replaced with a system that massively curtails burdensome federal mandates and taxes, and offers more flexibility and discretion to the states. However, it's important to note that the eventual legislative language is likely to be different from the draft document, and debates, negotiations, and legislative mark-ups are expected to iron out the disputes and details.

In related news, some of the nation's most vulnerable Senate Democrats are reportedly avoiding town hall meetings, according to a report by ABC News. This development comes as media chatter about town hall meetings on healthcare is all the rage these days. Conservatives are encouraged to attend these events and make phone calls to their members' offices to help stiffen GOP spines in the face of intense, and sometimes coordinated, liberal opposition.

Title: Young People Favor Same-sex Marriage, but Marriage Rates Decline Among Straight Couples

Article:

David Frum, a well-known commentator, has highlighted a shift in public opinion regarding same-sex marriage, stating that 80% of Americans under 30 support it. However, he poses a larger question about the future of marriage in general. Frum suggests that children born to single parents face longer odds in life compared to those born to married parents.

The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments this week in two same-sex marriage cases. Regardless of the court's decision, the widespread support among young people for same-sex marriage seems inevitable. However, Frum notes that while young straight Americans support marriage for same-sex couples, they are increasingly opting against marriage for themselves.

According to the U.S. Census Bureau, nearly half of American children, 48%, are now born to unmarried women. This trend is particularly prevalent among women without college degrees and of all races, as unwed motherhood has become the norm.

Frum refers to this trend as the "crisis of the American family." He argues that children born to single parents face more challenges in life, including lower chances of college completion, increased likelihood of prison involvement, and less likelihood of forming marriages themselves.

A new study by ThirdWay.org suggests that the impacts of single parenthood are particularly intense for boys, with less significant effects on girls. However, Frum emphasizes that these are not absolute rules, as there are always exceptions.

The root of this issue, Frum suggests, is the decline of male wages relative to female wages. He cites a quote from Michael Greenstone, an MIT economist, who states, "I think the greatest, most astonishing fact that I am aware of in social science right now is that women have been able to hear the labor market screaming out 'You need more education' and have been able to respond to that, and men have not."

Frum also references a quote from Harvard's Christopher Jencks, a left-leaning academic, who states, "Single-parent families tend to emerge in places where the men already are a mess."

The article discusses the need to address the single-parenthood problem, suggesting that men without a college education need to be made less of a "mess." Frum argues that the decline of mass-production industries has put pressure on the roles and incomes of working-class and middle-class men. The expansion of government and service industries has opened new opportunities for women, of which working-class and middle-class men seem less able to avail themselves.

The article concludes by stating that it's important to note that men in full-time work continue to earn more than women in full-time work. However, it also acknowledges a widening divergence between the family patterns of the college-educated top one-third and those of the non-college-educated bottom two-thirds. Frum suggests that the family life of the bottom two-thirds is the family policy challenge of the 21st century, and the debate over same-sex marriage is no longer the pressing issue it once was. Instead, the focus should shift to ensuring that the next generation of American children enjoys the more equal chances and wider opportunities from a more universal commitment to marriage.

Title: Romney's Wife Reveals Vice Presidential Search Includes Female Candidates

Article:

Mitt Romney's wife, Ann Romney, has disclosed a significant detail about her husband's vice presidential search, revealing that he is considering a female candidate. In an interview with CBS News, Ann Romney stated, "We've been looking at that, and I love that option as well." She added that there are several individuals under consideration for the position.

During the interview, Ann Romney also expressed her belief that President Obama and the Democrats will "do everything they can to destroy Mitt." She warned Mr. Obama, saying, "Not when I'm next to him, you better not." Mitt Romney did not comment on this characterization of Mr. Obama's strategy during the joint interview.

The Romneys gave a rare joint interview while spending time with their family at their lakeside estate in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire. The interview was conducted during a week-long holiday, a break from the campaign trail, and a chance for Romney to contemplate his campaign strategy before the pre-convention push.

Speculation is high about whom Romney will choose as his running mate, with several names circulating in Republican circles. These include Ohio Sen. Rob Portman, former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty, Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte, South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley, New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez, and former eBay CEO Meg Whitman.

Ann Romney also outlined her requirements for a running mate, stating that the person should be "someone that obviously can do the job but will be able to carry through with some of the other responsibilities." She added that the person should be someone who will have her husband's support, someone he will enjoy being around, and someone who shares a similar personality type.

Four years ago, Sen. John McCain selected then-Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, a little-known conservative, to be the first female on a Republican presidential ticket. The selection led to questions about Palin's readiness to be president and criticism of an inadequate vetting process. This year, Romney has stated that preparedness to be president is his top requirement for a vice president.

The Romneys' vice presidential search is ongoing, with the self-imposed deadline for picking a running mate "before the convention" approaching. The Romneys' campaign has not provided further details about the status of the search.

Title: Understanding the Rise of Mass Incarceration in America: A Look at the National Research Council Report

Article:

The United States is witnessing a growing movement towards reducing mass incarceration. Both the federal government and state governments are scrutinizing the number of individuals they send to prison and the lengths of their sentences. However, the question remains: how did the U.S. prison population grow so significantly over the past 40 years?

A National Research Council report from 2014 debunked two common misconceptions about the causes of the increase, offering two primary reasons: increased efficiency in prosecution and lengthened prison sentences.

The report found that the rise in incarceration could not be attributed to crime rates increasing. Crime rates have varied over the past forty years, and do not seem to have a substantial impact on the prison population, regardless of the direction of crime rates. The report also found no evidence that harsher prison sentences deter crime.

It was not due to better policing leading to more arrests
Policing has evolved significantly since the beginning of the mass-incarceration era, and most of these changes have been designed to make policing more effective. This implies that police are better at apprehending criminals today than they were thirty years ago.

However, the NRC report showed that since 1980, the ratio of arrests per crime—in other words, the proportion of crimes that police were able to find and arrest suspects for—stayed relatively constant. Based on the arrest-to-crime ratio, the authors wrote, "no increase in policing effectiveness occurred from 1980 to 2010 that might explain higher rates of incarceration."

It was because people who got arrested were more likely to go to jail
While the arrest-to-crime ratio is a rough measure of police effectiveness, the prison-to-arrest ratio is a rough measure of the efficiency of the prosecution and court process. The NRC report found that prosecution has become more efficient, and this was a significant reason for the explosion of the incarcerated population.

Why are people who get arrested more likely to end up in prison now than they were thirty years ago? Part of it is that more crimes now require a prison sentence than in 1980, so more of the people who are found guilty of crimes end up having to go to prison for them (rather than getting probation or a fine).

Part of it is also that most people who get convicted of crimes these days never even go to trial—they just plead guilty in exchange for a shorter prison sentence. This makes it much easier for prosecutors to move cases through the courts. Of course, efficiency is not necessarily the same as effectiveness—in theory, the point of prosecution should be to determine whether the person committed a crime or not, not to convict and sentence as many people as possible.

But whatever the merits of the way prosecution works, the authors concluded it was a big reason for the rise of mass incarceration. In fact, during the 1980s, it was the biggest reason, before being overtaken by the last and most important factor.

It was because people who went to prison served more time
The biggest reason the prison population exploded, especially after 1990: more people were in prison for longer periods of time. This is also largely due to changes in sentencing policy. States and the federal government added lots of new mandatory minimum sentences in the 1980s and 1990s, which forced people convicted of a given crime to serve a certain number of years in jail.

One particularly harsh kind of mandatory minimum sentence was imposed as "three-strikes" laws, which forced a criminal convicted of his third felony to serve a long prison sentence (between 25 years and a life sentence). States and the federal government also passed "truth-in-sentencing" laws, particularly in the late 1980s and early 1990s, which forced inmates to serve a large amount of their prison sentences (typically 85 percent) before being eligible for parole.

Ultimately, the NRC report's authors said, the common denominator in both of the big causes of mass incarceration—more prisoners per arrest, and longer sentences per prisoner—is the harsher sentencing policies of the 1980s and 1990s. That means that sentencing reform policies that some state governments have been pursuing, and that members of Congress in both parties have proposed, are a good place to start when it comes to reducing mass incarceration—even if they are not a panacea.

Title: Politicians Distance Themselves from Cliven Bundy's Controversial Racial Remarks

Article:

Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy's recent comments about the welfare of African Americans during slavery have sparked a wave of criticism and distancing from politicians, particularly those in the Republican party. Bundy's remarks, which were reported by The New York Times, have been echoed by other conservative figures such as Ted Nugent and Phil Robertson.

In an interview with reporters, Bundy questioned whether African Americans were better off as slaves or on government subsidies. "They abort their young children, they put their young men in jail, because they never learned how to pick cotton," Bundy said. He later added, "And I've often wondered, are they better off as slaves, picking cotton and having a family life and doing things, or are they better off under government subsidy? They didn't get no more freedom. They got less freedom."

Bundy, who gained notoriety for his much-publicized land dispute with the federal government, defended his comments as idle thoughts. In an interview with "The Peter Schiff Show," he said, "In my mind I'm wondering, are they better off being slaves, in that sense, or better off being slaves to the United States government, in the sense of the subsidies? I'm wondering. That's what. And the statement was right. I am wondering."

Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, a potential 2016 presidential GOP contender, was among those who distanced themselves from the controversy. "His remarks on race are offensive and I wholeheartedly disagree with him," Paul said in a statement. Republican Sen. Dean Heller of Nevada also condemned Bundy's comments.

The Republican National Committee called Bundy's comments "completely beyond the pale" and "100% wrong on race." Mark Anthony Neal, an African-American studies professor at Duke University, suggested that Bundy's comments represent a cultural tension in some segments of America. "We are looking at some of the 'last white men standing,'" Neal said, referring to demographic shifts that show minorities now represent more than half of the nation's population born in 2010 and 2011, according to the most recent census data.

Political experts say that Bundy's comments, along with those of Nugent and Robertson, speak to a politically active fringe element in America. Andra Gillespie, an associate professor of political science at Emory University, said, "What this reflects is that there are groups of people who have not been accepted by politically correct circles and have never learned to frame their comments in a palatable fashion. They take pride in that."

The comments have put politicians who have previously embraced figures like Bundy, Nugent, and Robertson in an awkward position. For instance, Texas Attorney General Greg Abbott, the Republican nominee for governor, took heat for allowing Ted Nugent to appear at a campaign event this year. Abbott's campaign said it did not endorse Nugent's comments. Other potential presidential candidates, including Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and the state's governor, Rick Perry, also distanced themselves from Nugent's remarks.

Title: White House Invokes Executive Privilege Over 'Fast and Furious' Documents in Congressional Contempt Vote

Article:

The ongoing dispute between the Obama administration and the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee over the 'Fast and Furious' operation has escalated, with reports indicating that the White House is asserting executive privilege over documents subpoenaed by the committee. The development comes just before a committee hearing, where lawmakers are expected to vote on whether to cite Attorney General Eric Holder for contempt of Congress for failing to turn over the documents.

The hearing, which is to be webcast here, is scheduled to take place amidst the news that the committee will proceed with the Republican majority's plan to cite Holder for contempt. The 'Fast and Furious' operation came to public attention following the December 2010 death of a U.S. Border Patrol agent, Brian Terry. Two guns connected to the botched gun-trafficking operation were found near Terry's body, sparking two congressional probes and an ongoing investigation by the Justice Department's inspector general.

During a hearing on June 7, Holder faced questioning from Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) and other Republican lawmakers. Issa asked Holder if his department was aware of the tactics used in the flawed gunrunning operation, and Republicans accused him of not being forthcoming and not complying with subpoenas.

As of the time of this report, the committee has not yet voted on the contempt citation. Members are still arguing along partisan lines, with Republicans advocating for and Democrats opposing the contempt citation of Holder. If the committee does vote to hold Holder in contempt, the contempt citation would then go to the full House. The Associated Press reports that if the matter does progress to a federal case against Holder, past examples suggest it may not get that far.

The lawmakers are still in session, and no vote has been cast as of yet. Committee members are still giving their opening statements, with Republicans stating that the Obama administration has been resisting efforts to obtain information about 'Fast and Furious,' and Democrats arguing that the administration has cooperated fully.

At the start of the hearing, Issa stated that the committee did not set out to hold Holder in contempt, but rather to "get the information the committee needs to complete its work." He described the assertion of executive privilege as "untimely" and "not spoken of last night" during negotiations between committee staffers and Justice Department officials.

Title: Republican Greg Gianforte Wins Montana Congressional Race Amid Assault Allegation

Article:

Republican Greg Gianforte has been declared the winner in the Montana congressional race, defeating Democrat Rob Quist despite an election-eve altercation with a journalist that led to a misdemeanor assault charge. The Associated Press called the race for Gianforte more than 2½ hours after polls closed at 8 p.m. MDT, with 83 percent of precincts counted.

Gianforte led Quist by a margin of 50.3 percent to 43.9 percent, with Libertarian Mark Wicks receiving 5.8 percent of the vote. In his victory speech, Gianforte stated, "Tonight, Montanans are sending a wake-up call to the Washington DC establishment."

The day before the election, Gianforte was charged with misdemeanor assault after allegedly body-slamming a reporter from Britain's Guardian newspaper. The incident occurred when the reporter asked Gianforte about the Congressional Budget Office's analysis of the GOP's healthcare bill. Three newspapers in the state rescinded their endorsements of Gianforte in response to the incident.

Gianforte apologized to the reporter, Ben Jacobs, during his victory speech, stating, "That is not the person that I am and it is not the way that I will lead in this state." House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have both expressed disapproval of Gianforte's behavior, but have stopped short of calling for him to step down or be barred from the GOP conference.

The victory gives Republicans a 239-193 majority in the House. The party is eager to capitalize on the wave of anti-Trump sentiment among progressive activists, but the Gianforte incident could cause headaches for GOP lawmakers. Democrats are now 0 for 2 in special election races, having also lost the April special election in the 5th Congressional District in Kansas.

Looking ahead, both parties will turn their attention to the June 20 special election in Georgia's 6th Congressional District, where Democrat Jon Ossoff and Republican Karen Handel are in a tight race. The outcome of this race will be closely watched as a potential indicator of the political climate in the lead-up to the 2018 midterm elections.

Title: The Importance of Political Discussion at Thanksgiving: A Call for Conservative Families to Engage

Article:

As the holiday season approaches, numerous media outlets have been advising against discussing politics at the Thanksgiving dinner table. However, some argue that this is a missed opportunity for conservative families to engage with their liberal relatives, particularly those who have moved to coastal cities or attend college.

In many American families, Thanksgiving is a time to reflect on shared values and bond over generations. This year, even Bernie Sanders is reportedly preparing his progressive followers on how to navigate political discussions with family members.

For conservative families, the Thanksgiving table can serve as a unique opportunity to engage with relatives who may hold different political views, especially those who have moved to liberal strongholds or are currently attending college. These individuals may not often encounter conservative viewpoints, making the family dinner table a valuable platform for open dialogue.

The term "bubble" is not used here in hyperbole, but rather to represent the closed-off mindset of American progressivism in coastal cities and on college campuses. In places like New York City, where the labor movement is seen as too centrist and avowed Socialists are a political force, conservative viewpoints may be scarce. On college campuses, students may be exposed to an unparalleled and unmitigated rage of the American left, where "cancel culture" and groupthink overshadow academic debate.

Conservative families are encouraged to use this opportunity to share their perspectives, discuss the reasons for their political beliefs, and engage in open dialogue.
