This can include sharing personal stories, discussing the role of religion in their lives, and explaining the benefits of their political ideologies.

Furthermore, families are encouraged to discuss the economy, the role of law enforcement, and the presidency. While it is expected that political differences may lead to heated discussions, it is essential to remember that these opportunities for open dialogue are rare and valuable.

In conclusion, the Thanksgiving dinner table can serve as a unique platform for conservative families to engage with their liberal relatives and share their perspectives. By discussing their personal stories, the role of religion, the economy, law enforcement, and the presidency, conservative families can help their relatives understand their viewpoints and foster open dialogue.

Title: TV Newsrooms Adapt to Trump Presidency, Anticipate Unprecedented Coverage

Article:

Following Donald Trump's election as the 45th President of the United States, newsrooms across the country are reevaluating their coverage strategies to accommodate the unpredictable nature of the incoming administration.

"This changes everything," says Phil Griffin, president of MSNBC. "We left the studio at 4 a.m., and we knew there was a whole other world of storylines and changes that are going to happen."

Major TV news operations were bracing for a ratings decline as the historic and contentious election wound down. CNN had its highest online traffic ever on Election Day, and the election was a distinct revenue driver for its parent company, Time Warner, this year. However, the company was warning as early as summer that its ratings would drop next year.

The unexpected victory of Trump, who defied most polls, has left TV networks to quickly reassess their coverage plans and story ideas. "There are so many different threads that we'll pursue that we didn't imagine three days ago," Griffin says. "It's an amazing story about what's going on in this country."

The first 100 days of any presidency are typically exciting, particularly when a new party takes over in Washington, D.C. The transition, with politicians jockeying for key Cabinet positions, is a horse race of its own kind. However, Trump, the inexperienced politician suddenly leading the federal government, adds multiple and substantive layers to the story.

"You've got a more dynamic transition in place," says Chris Isham, CBS News' Washington bureau chief. "He's not a predictable Republican, not in the way of previous administrations."

Gauging Trump's comfort level with the press, already underway, has been as challenging as pinning down his stance on issues. Reporters who have known him for years speak of his accessibility and willingness to banter. Yet he's also sought political advantage in bashing the mainstream media.

"Let's see how much access he grants," says Chris Ariens, editor of TVNewser. "He's not the candidate anymore. He's not going to be calling into Fox and Friends."

One of the first major interviews Trump granted after the election was to 60 Minutes, which will air Sunday. Jeff Fager, executive producer of 60 Minutes, said the show had planned on pursuing an interview with the president-elect regardless of the election outcome, but because so much of Trump's governing philosophy and policy specifics are unknown, it heightens the urgency.

"It's not about good TV. It's about how we can help people better understand," Fager says. "There's a lot to talk about. Hopefully, we'll get some details."

In an interview clip released early by CBS, Trump says he's willing to retain some key provisions of the Affordable Care Act, including prohibiting insurers from denying coverage to patients with pre-existing conditions.

There has already been plenty of hand-wringing in American newsrooms about the failure to properly assess the impact of Trump's voters and the issues that drove them so eagerly to the voting booths. Coverage planning for Trump's presidency must entail deep-diving into these issues to hold him accountable for some of his outlandish proposals, Fager says.

"There are so many layers that make this interesting," he says. "He's tapped into the dissatisfied voters. That's an important part of this. How is he going to address the issues they care about? How is he going to build a wall?"

Beyond issues, scrutinizing Trump's governing styles and tendencies—not as a career politician, but honed on the fly based on his experience as a real estate developer and TV personality—will also be a rich source of stories.

"He's a businessman who's a negotiator," Fager says. "There's a lot of stories that could be generated in (covering) someone who's got a totally different perspective on how to get things done."

While no news executives may admit it publicly, the possibility of Trump's gaffes and unfiltered diatribes, frequently evident during his campaign, remains an intriguing variable, says Mark Feldstein, a broadcast journalism professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, and a former journalist at NBC.

"Media critics are always attacking TV for ideological bias," he says. "But the real bias is toward conflict, controversy, and excitement because that's what increases revenue. Whether you love or hate him, he is going to bring controversy."

Title: Trump Softens Stance on Immigration, Courts Non-White Vote Amidst Controversial Remarks

Article:

In a recent shift in his campaign strategy, Republican nominee Donald Trump has softened his stance on immigration, a signature issue of his campaign, as he attempts to appeal to non-white voters. This change in approach comes as polls show Trump trailing Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, particularly among likely non-white voters.

Last summer, Trump proposed a controversial plan to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, with Mexico paying for it. His stance on immigration has been notoriously hardline, with unclear proposals regarding the estimated 11 million undocumented migrants currently residing in the U.S. He has suggested a "deportation force" to remove them.

On Saturday, following a meeting with his Hispanic advisory council, reports emerged that Trump was softening his stance. On Sunday, newly appointed campaign manager Kellyanne Conway seemed to waffle on whether Trump was still committed to deportation. In an interview with Fox News, Trump himself denied that he was "flip-flopping." To buy more time to refine his stance, the campaign postponed a speech Trump was due to give on Thursday.

On Wednesday, Trump stated that immigrants not in the U.S. legally would not receive citizenship, but also appeared to offer a path forward and contradict his previous promises of deporting undocumented migrants.

"They'll pay back taxes, they have to pay taxes, there's no amnesty, as such, there's no amnesty, but we will work with them," Trump said in a town hall with Fox News anchor Sean Hannity. The next day, he met with African American and Latino activists at Trump Tower in New York.

Such apparent moderation on immigration comes as Trump tries to aggressively court Hispanic and African American voters. A Quinnipiac University poll released on Thursday gives Clinton a 62-point lead over Trump among likely non-white voters.

In a speech in Akron, Ohio, on August 22, Trump made controversial remarks about crime in American inner cities, stating that they are "safer than living in some of our inner cities that are run by the Democrats." This statement, at best, offers a broad-brush portrait of America's cities and, at worst, uses offensive language towards the very voters Trump is trying to reach.

Trump also claimed that crime is at "levels that nobody's seen." Based on the context and past statements about crime statistics, we can assume he means crime is at record heights. However, this bleak picture of crime-ridden American streets, more dangerous than parts of the world where the U.S. is engaged in military action, such as Afghanistan and Iraq, runs counter to a trend of declining crime that has persisted for more than a quarter of a century.

Trump also claimed to employ "so many, so many" African Americans in his various businesses. However, a June analysis by the Associated Press found "few if any" black executives in the upper echelon of Trump's organization.

Trump has recently increased his outreach to African American voters, but he delivers his speeches before largely white audiences. A recent NBC/Wall Street Journal poll showed Trump receiving the support of only 1% of African American voters.

In a speech in Dimondale, Michigan, on August 19, Trump repeated an eye-popping statistic: that more than half of young black men and women are unemployed. The latest figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) put the unemployment rate among 16- to 19-year-old black Americans at 25.7%, adjusted seasonally. So how did he get to 58%?

The campaign's economic adviser, David Malpass, told ABC News it began with BLS data from 2015 and broke out the numbers for 16- to 24-year-old African Americans. As part of its calculation, the campaign included labor force participants and those outside the labor force, including people who have no job or are not looking for one, such as students and retirees. These are sectors of the population the federal government does not count as unemployed.

The campaign then divided the larger number by the population of the 16-to-24 age group to reach 58.5%, ABC reported. Economists have said it is statistically misleading to include segments of the population that are actively not seeking employment.

Title: Biden's Third Presidential Bid: Unity Candidate or Divisive Figure?

Article:

Joe Biden, who has previously run for president in 1988 and 2008, is set to officially announce his third presidential campaign this week. According to RealClearPolitics, he leads in 36 out of 37 polls for the 2020 Democratic nomination contest and is also ahead in Iowa and California, where his opponent, Kamala Harris, is from.

However, Biden's candidacy is facing a significant challenge: the question of his ability to unite the Democratic Party across ideological and demographic lines. His long political career, which includes his two terms as vice-president under Barack Obama, initially positioned him as a bridge between the Clinton-Obama era and a more progressive future.

Recent months, however, have seen a resurgence of criticism over Biden's association with some of the less defensible political and policy trends of the past, particularly those that are unpopular among minority and feminist constituencies. Allegations of inappropriate behavior towards women have further fueled doubts about Biden.

Despite this, Biden's standing among Democratic voters remains strong. Morning Consult's tracking poll of Democrats currently gives him a 75/15 approval ratio. He is also the top second-choice candidate for those who favor Kamala Harris, Beto O'Rourke, or Bernie Sanders.

However, it remains to be seen if this support will hold, especially as his rivals begin to attack him more directly. If Biden chooses to distinguish himself from more progressive candidates as a moderate, he could risk falling between stools, as some have suggested. Alternatively, he could restore his "unity candidate" persona by clearly establishing himself as the most, or even the only, electable opponent for Donald Trump.

The feasibility of an all-electability rationale for Biden may depend on the assumption that Biden has a unique ability to appeal to white working-class swing voters in the Rust Belt states that Barack Obama won and Hillary Clinton lost. However, it is still early for general-election trial heats to have any significance, and partisan polarization may eventually erase any differences among Democrats.

Title: Volker Testimony Undercuts Specific Allegations Against Biden in Trump Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

Republican lawmakers are increasingly relying on the closed-door testimony of senior diplomat Kurt Volker in their defense of President Donald Trump against allegations of impropriety in the House impeachment inquiry. According to Volker's account, Trump never engaged in an improper "quid pro quo" when he pressured Ukraine's new president to investigate allegations against Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.

Rep. Jim Jordan, one of Trump's staunchest allies, stated that Ambassador Volker's testimony is the definitive account of the events in question. Trump himself thanked Volker for his testimony in a tweet on Wednesday.

However, Volker's testimony contradicts the specific allegations against Biden that Trump and his allies have been promoting for months. Volker testified that no evidence was brought forward to support the allegations, and he considered them self-serving and not credible.

Biden has publicly recounted how, as the Obama administration's point man on Ukraine in 2016, he pressured Ukraine's leadership to fire the prosecutor general, Viktor Shokin. Biden even threatened to withhold nearly $1 billion in U.S. aid if Shokin was not removed.

Volker testified that Biden's push for Shokin's firing was justified, as Shokin was not pursuing corruption cases and had a reputation for not doing his job. The ousted ambassador to Ukraine, Marie Yovanovitch, also testified that Shokin had a "notorious reputation" for "not doing his job."

In March, Shokin's successor, Yuriy Lutsenko, unleashed a series of explosive allegations about Shokin's firing. Lutsenko alleged that Biden pushed for Shokin's firing to protect his son and derail the Ukrainian investigation of Burisma, the major gas company where Biden's son, Hunter, served on the board.

Volker testified that Lutsenko's allegations against Biden were self-serving and made up to save his job and prevent investigations into himself for potential corruption. Lutsenko's allegations have never been directly or fully debunked, according to Volker.

In May, after Zelenskiy was elected Ukraine's new president and after the allegations against Biden began to attract more media attention, Lutsenko seemed to back away from his initial claims, telling Bloomberg News, "Hunter Biden did not violate any Ukrainian laws, and at least as of now, we do not see any wrongdoing."

Title: House Judiciary Committee Releases 658-Page Report on Impeachment Case Against President Trump

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee has released a 658-page report detailing the impeachment case against President Donald Trump, alleging two impeachable offenses: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress during its investigation. The report states, "President Trump has placed his personal, political interests above our national security, our free and fair elections, and our systems of checks and balances."

The Democrats argue that Trump's actions constitute impeachable offenses, even if they are not explicitly outlined in the articles of impeachment. The report states, "While there is no need for a crime to be proven in order for impeachment to be warranted, here, President Trump's scheme or course of conduct also encompassed other offenses, both constitutional and criminal in character."

The report accuses Trump of abusing power, which it claims constitutes the constitutional offense of "Bribery." It also alleges multiple federal crimes. The Democrats argue that Trump has betrayed the national interest, the people of the nation, and should not be permitted to be above the law.

Republicans have pushed back, with Ranking Member Doug Collins (R-GA) criticizing the Democrats for "pursuing impeachment first and building a case second" based on hearsay and assumptions. The minority argues that "not one of the criminal accusations leveled at the president over the past year—including bribery, extortion, collusion/conspiracy with foreign enemies, or obstruction of justice—has found a place in the articles."

The Republicans also claim that the actions taken by the Democrats during the impeachment process are "unprecedented, unjustifiable, and will only dilute the significance of the dire recourse that is impeachment." The full House is expected to vote on the articles of impeachment this week.

Title: Missing Wisconsin Girl Jayme Closs Found After 88 Days; Suspect Arrested

Article:

A 13-year-old Wisconsin girl, Jayme Closs, who had been missing since her parents were found dead in their home three months ago, has been located. Jayme escaped from a remote house on Thursday and was found by a woman walking her dog. The girl was taken into police custody after the woman contacted authorities. She was reunited with her family on Friday following interviews with investigators.

Investigators identified the suspect as Jake Thomas Patterson, a 21-year-old man, and announced kidnapping and murder charges on Friday. Police stated that Patterson had planned his actions and took steps to avoid detection.

Patterson was apprehended near the house from which Jayme escaped, and his arrest was facilitated by a description of his vehicle provided by Jayme. Authorities believe Patterson was searching for the girl when he was taken into custody.

Barron County Sheriff Chris Fitzgerald stated that investigators were still working to understand Jayme's experiences and the reasons for Patterson's apparent determination to abduct her. "The will of a kid to survive – it's unthinkable," said Fitzgerald, who expressed emotion after 88 days of searching for the teenager.

Investigators found no evidence of a relationship between Patterson and Jayme's family, nor any social media contact between them. Patterson had a connection to Jayme's hometown, Barron, but the details of this connection were not disclosed. Patterson had altered his appearance before the October attack and abduction, shaving his head to avoid leaving hair behind.

Investigators questioned Patterson, who is unemployed and has no local or Wisconsin criminal history, on Friday morning. The house where Jayme had most recently been held was searched.

It remains unclear if Jayme had been in the same house for the entire three months of her disappearance or if she was abused by her captor during that time. The local district attorney's office plans to issue a criminal complaint next week.

Jayme's aunt, Sue Allard, expressed her joy upon learning of the news on Thursday night. "Praise the Lord," Allard said, between sobs. "It's the news we've been waiting on for three months. I can't wait to get my arms around her. I just can't wait."

Police confirmed that no additional suspects were being sought, and no one else was found in the residence from which Jayme escaped. "It is an incredible day," said Justin Tolomeo, FBI special agent in charge of Milwaukee.

Patterson is scheduled to make his first court appearance on Monday.

Title: U.S. Withdraws from Arms Trade Treaty, Citing Sovereignty and Domestic Gun Rights

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Friday that the United States would withdraw as a signatory to the Arms Trade Treaty, a global agreement aimed at regulating the international sale of conventional weapons. The treaty, which was approved by the United Nations General Assembly in 2013 but never ratified by the U.S. Congress, has been a point of contention between gun rights advocates and supporters of stricter arms regulations.

In a speech before the National Rifle Association (NRA) in Indianapolis, Trump stated, "We will never surrender American sovereignty to anyone." The NRA, a key backer of Trump's 2016 campaign, was a leading opponent of the treaty, arguing it could impinge on the rights of American gun owners.

The Arms Trade Treaty has been ratified by 101 countries, including member states of the European Union, but not by the United States. The treaty seeks to regulate the international sale of conventional weapons, with the goal of ensuring that weapons are not sold to countries involved in civil conflict or to regimes that the U.S. does not support.

Thomas Countryman, a former assistant secretary of state who was the lead U.S. negotiator for the treaty, stated that the treaty has no impact on Second Amendment rights of U.S. citizens. He also noted that the U.S. has for decades had strict arms-export laws in place.

Rachel Stohl, managing director of the conventional defense program at the Stimson Center, a Washington think tank, criticized the decision as a "retreat from global leadership" that would "undermine international peace and security, increase irresponsible and illegal sales of conventional weapons, and harm the American economy."

The decision to withdraw from the Arms Trade Treaty follows Trump's announcement in February that the U.S. would withdraw from the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which Washington alleged Moscow has violated by deploying multiple battalions of a prohibited cruise missile.

During his third visit as president to an NRA annual convention, Trump pledged his support for gun rights, touted the strength of the U.S. economy, and criticized the recently completed Mueller investigation. Trump also warned the crowd that "far-left radicals in Congress" want to take their guns, stating, "that will never happen as long as I'm president, not even close."

The president received a rousing reception from NRA members, despite criticism from some hard-line gun-rights advocates of his record on guns. The only major action Trump had taken on guns since being elected was to ban bump stocks, devices used in the September 2017 Las Vegas massacre that make semiautomatic rifles fire like machine guns. Meanwhile, Trump has not signed into law any major pro-gun legislation.

Title: Death Threats and Racial Slurs Target Senator Tim Scott, While Pelosi's Controversial Remark Goes Unreported by Major Broadcasters

Article:

A New York Times report published on Tuesday detailed recent death threats and racial slurs directed at Republican Senator Tim Scott, the only black Republican in the Senate. The major broadcast networks, ABC, CBS, and NBC, did not report on this incident, instead choosing to focus on other topics.

According to the New York Times article, written by Catie Edmondson, Senator Scott shared two audio recordings of the threatening and racist calls with the newspaper. The calls contained profanity, racial slurs, and one caller threatened to put Senator Scott "in his crosshairs."

Senator Scott attributed the media's portrayal of his police reform legislation as the reason for the negative characterization of him and his colleagues. In his interview with The Times, he stated, "It's interesting that we are on the right side of the police reform conversation, yet we're on the wrong side according to the people, based on the way that we are characterized in the national press."

In a separate incident, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) generated outrage with her comments on CBS News Radio, where she stated, "But so far, they were trying to get away with murder, actually, the murder of George Floyd." The Republican Party was not involved in the killing of George Floyd.

Pelosi's comment was made in response to a question about the possibility of compromise on police reform, and there was no fact-check about her statement in the broadcast networks' coverage.

The major broadcast networks also did not report on the official rollout of Scott's Justice Act, as previously noted by ███. Additionally, they did not cover the outrage generated by Pelosi's controversial comment made to their own West Coast correspondent, Steve Futterman.

Title: Living Room Conversation: A Bipartisan Dialogue on Immigration

Article:

Rremida Shkoza, an Albanian-born US citizen and real estate broker, participated in a Living Room Conversation, a bipartisan forum for peaceful dialogue on immigration. The event, which took place in New York, brought together three Democrats and three Republicans, with the focus on immigration.

Shkoza, a refugee who fled communist Albania in 1991, initially questioned the participation of a Republican immigrant in the conversation. However, she was pleasantly surprised to find common ground with Sue Googe, a Republican co-host and fellow real estate professional, as well as other participants.

During the conversation, each participant shared their personal experiences with immigration. Shkoza emphasized her refugee status and the xenophobia she faced as a child in Italy. The other participants, including Julia Song, a Brazilian immigrant and Republican, and Mario Benavente, an active local conservative politician, shared their experiences with immigration in the United States.

The participants agreed on the need for comprehensive immigration reform and the importance of treating migrants and refugees humanely. They acknowledged the need to balance democratic values with the need to help others, and the need to address issues such as racism, xenophobia, and homelessness in the United States.

Policy differences emerged, with some participants discussing the impact of Trump's tax cuts and immigration policies on the economy and average Americans. Shkoza and other participants suggested that investing more in working-class Americans might improve the economy and reduce xenophobia.

Despite these policy differences, the conversation ended on a hopeful note, with participants finding common ground on the importance of humanizing immigrants and assisting them to the extent possible. Shkoza left the conversation with a newfound appreciation for the open-mindedness of Republicans and a renewed hope for the future of the United States.

Title: Federal Law Enforcement Officers in Portland Detain Protesters in Unmarked Vehicles

Article:

Federal law enforcement officers in Portland, Oregon, have been using unmarked vehicles to detain protesters since at least July 14, according to reports from Oregon Public Broadcasting (OPB). Personal accounts and multiple videos posted online show the officers driving up to people, detaining individuals with no explanation of why they are being arrested, and driving off.

The tactic appears to be another escalation in federal force deployed on Portland city streets, as federal officials and President Donald Trump have said they plan to "quell" nightly protests outside the federal courthouse and Multnomah County Justice Center that have lasted for more than six weeks.

Federal officers have charged at least 13 people with crimes related to the protests so far, while others have been arrested and released, including Donavan L. Pettibone and Mark P. O'Shea. They also left one demonstrator hospitalized with skull fractures after shooting him in the face with so-called "less lethal" munitions on July 11.

Officers from the U.S. Marshals Special Operations Group and Customs and Border Protection's BORTAC have been sent to Portland to protect federal property during the recent protests against racism and police brutality. However, interviews conducted by OPB show officers are also detaining people on Portland streets who aren't near federal property, nor is it clear that all of the people being arrested have engaged in criminal activity.

Demonstrators like O'Shea and Pettibone said they think they were targeted by federal officers for simply wearing black clothing in the area of the demonstration. Pettibone did not escape the federal officers. "I am basically tossed into the van," Pettibone said. "And I had my beanie pulled over my face so I couldn't see and they held my hands over my head."

Pettibone and O'Shea both said they couldn't think of anything they might have done to end up targeted by law enforcement. They attend protests regularly but they said they aren't "instigators." They don't spray paint buildings, shine laser pointers at officers or do anything else other than attend protests, which law enforcement have regularly deemed "unlawful assemblies."

Mayor Ted Wheeler and other local officials have said they didn't ask for help from federal law enforcement and have asked them to leave. "A number of people have asked if I know DHS leadership is in town, and if I'm going to meet with them. We're aware that they're here. We wish they weren't," Wheeler tweeted Thursday. Democratic Gov. Kate Brown called Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf's visit "political theater from President Trump" and said he "is looking for a confrontation in Oregon in the hopes of winning political points in Ohio or Iowa."

Since when does a Cabinet official, representing the president, come to a city and not even try to meet the mayor? Since 2017, of course. Brown is right. This is dumbshow for dummies. But it's also a terrible look into that of which this administration is capable, and for which this administration seems to be softening the ground.

Wolf is certainly on board. He put out a release that reads like Eisenhower's exhortation before the ships left for Normandy. "This siege can end if state and local officials decide to take appropriate action instead of refusing to enforce the law. DHS will not abdicate its solemn duty to protect federal facilities and those within them. Again, I reiterate the Department's offer to assist local and state leaders to bring an end to the violence perpetuated by anarchists," said Acting Secretary Chad Wolf.

Two more dirty words on the side of a building, and Wolf might be calling in air strikes. Also on Thursday, press secretary Kaleigh McEnany took a moment out of her briefing to call Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot a "renegade mayor" because Lightfoot refuses to ask for the National Guard to come into her city. (To her credit, Lightfoot snapped right back.) The White House is on record several times as trying to delegitimize Muriel Bowser as mayor of Washington, D.C.

Portland may be a dumbshow for dummies, but it also looks like a dress rehearsal. This is not an "authoritarian impulse." This is authoritarian government—straight, no chaser. And this administration has a powerful thirst for it. It will do anything if it thinks it can get away with it in order to benefit a president who wants to bring the Republic down on his head.

We need a Truth and Reconciliation Commission now, before the dress rehearsal becomes a road show.

Title: Romney Labels Individual Mandate in Health Care Law as a Tax

Article:

In an interview with CBS News on Wednesday, former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney declared that the individual mandate in President Barack Obama's health care law is a tax. This statement comes just days after Romney's campaign had previously rejected this characterization.

During the interview, Romney stated, "While I agreed with the dissent, that's taken over by the fact that the majority of the court said it's a tax, and therefore it is a tax. They have spoken."

He further added, "They concluded it was a tax. That's what it is, and the American people know that President Obama has broken the pledge he made. He said he wouldn't raise taxes on middle-income Americans. Not only did he raise the $500 billion that was already in the bill, it's now clear that his mandate, as described by the Supreme Court, is a tax."

On Monday, Romney's presidential campaign stated that the health care mandate should be considered a penalty and not a tax. This statement by Eric Fehrnstrom, the campaign's spokesman, contradicted the general stance of leading Republicans in Congress and elsewhere, who have been accusing the president of imposing a new tax.

"The governor disagreed with the ruling of the court," Mr. Fehrnstrom said Monday on MSNBC's "The Daily Rundown." "He agreed with the dissent written by Justice Scalia, which very clearly stated that the mandate was not a tax."

The characterization of the mandate is a sensitive issue for the Romney campaign, given Romney's past support for universal health care in Massachusetts when he was governor there. While Romney has pledged to repeal what conservatives call Obamacare, he had previously avoided labeling the mandate as a tax, possibly because his Massachusetts plan included a similar mandate.

Romney made his comments while vacationing in New Hampshire.

Title: Unforced Errors in Politics: Clinton's Email Controversy and the GOP's Iran Letter

Article:

In the world of sports, an unforced error refers to a mistake made by a player that doesn't involve the opposition. In politics, this concept also applies, with unforced errors potentially having more significant consequences than a simple misplay in a game. Recently, two major unforced errors have been committed by both sides of the political spectrum, demonstrating a lack of strategy and, at its core, poor decision-making.

Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, encountered a setback due to her use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State. While the former First Lady may have rationalized her decision given the Whitewater investigation that led to her husband's impeachment proceedings, the questionable nature of this choice remains. For someone who served in high office, it is questionable why one would not have an official government account to transact business while having a separate email account for personal business.

In a similar vein, the open letter signed by 47 Republican Senators to the Iranian leadership can be seen as another unforced error. While the letter was intended as a lesson in constitutional government, the tone and approach it took were perceived as arrogant and an attempt to sabotage any deal reached between the U.S. and Iran. The letter made its signatories, particularly its author, U.S. Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, appear as spiteful meddlers in foreign policy.

While senators have the constitutional (and thus, legal) power to approve a treaty and can outlast an occupant of the White House due to their six-year terms, their own majority may be short-lived, with another third of the Senate seats coming up for election in just a year and a half, and GOP senators having to defend more than their fair share.

Blind arrogance of power, whether in terms of email management and deciding what to release or openly flaunting senatorial power and prestige to a foreign nation, often backfires on those wielding the power. In this age of political polarization, should we really be surprised by these, and future, unforced errors? Not really, because these errors are due to the partisan nature of the players, and it is the game of politics that ultimately suffers.

Title: DOJ Establishes Task Force to Combat Violent Anti-Government Extremism

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has announced the formation of a task force aimed at curbing "violent anti-government extremists of all persuasions." The announcement was made in a June 26 memo to all heads of department components and U.S. attorneys, shared publicly by Department of Justice (DOJ) spokesperson Kerri Kupec.

In the memo, Barr wrote that the aim of the task force is to lead DOJ efforts to investigate and prosecute those who commit violent acts, prevent extremist violence before it happens, and "ultimately eliminate it as a threat to public safety and the rule of law."

Protests in the wake of the police-custody death of George Floyd, who died on May 25 after a Minneapolis officer restrained him by kneeling on his neck, have largely been peaceful. However, at times, the protests have descended into scenes of looting, arson, and violence.

Barr noted attacks on police officers and other government officials, destruction of public and private property, and threats to innocent bystanders. Clashes with protesters in Seattle several weeks ago led police to abandon a precinct and prompted the establishment of a so-called "autonomous zone." While largely peaceful, the zone has also been the site of acts of violence, including a recent shooting.

Nearby property owners and businesses on June 24 filed a federal lawsuit against the city of Seattle for its tolerance of the zone, saying officials had been complicit in depriving them of their rights to their property.

Barr said extremist groups targeted by the new initiative seek to deny constitutional rights to others and resort to methods that are illegal. "Although these extremists profess a variety of ideologies, they are united in their opposition to the core constitutional values of a democratic society governed by law," Barr wrote in the memo, adding that the DOJ has obtained information suggesting that some extremists intend to sow more chaos.

"We have evidence that anti-government violent extremists—including those who support the ‘ Boogaloo,’ those who self-identify as Antifa, and others—will pose continuing threats of lawlessness," Barr wrote, adding that some of those who in recent weeks have undercut public order and tried to "become a law unto themselves" through violent acts may be supported by "foreign entities seeking to sow chaos and disorder."

The task force will provide training and resources to local law enforcement in an effort to arrest perpetrators of violence. It will also work closely with the FBI to "develop detailed information about violent anti-government extremist individuals, networks, and movements—and will share that information as appropriate with federal, state, and local law enforcement, especially in places where these extremists pose a threat."

Barr's announcement came on the same day President Donald Trump signed an executive order protecting American monuments, memorials, and statues from being destroyed. "I just had the privilege of signing a very strong Executive Order protecting American Monuments, Memorials, and Statues—and combatting recent Criminal Violence," Trump wrote in a tweet. "Long prison terms for these lawless acts against our Great Country!"

Title: Former Texas Governor Rick Perry Suspends 2016 GOP Presidential Campaign

Article:

Former Texas Governor Rick Perry has announced the suspension of his campaign to secure the 2016 Republican presidential nomination during a speech at the Eagle Forum in St. Louis on Friday afternoon. Perry, who served as governor for 14 years, faced difficulties in fundraising and gaining traction in a crowded and experienced field.

In his speech, Perry attributed his decision to God's guidance, stating, "That is why today I am suspending my campaign for the presidency of the United States." He acknowledged the strength of the current Republican candidates, expressing confidence in the party's future as long as it remains connected to the grassroots and the cause of conservatism.

Suspending a campaign, in most cases, is equivalent to dropping out of the race. Candidates typically cite technical fundraising issues as the reason for such a move. Perry's decision comes less than a week before the second debate of the primary season.

This marks Perry's second failed presidential campaign, following his 2012 bid, which was labeled one of the biggest campaign failures in modern political history. In his 2012 campaign, Perry managed to raise funds but failed to convert that into votes, ultimately withdrawing just before the South Carolina primary. This time around, Perry faced a crowded field of current and former governors with extensive experience and fundraising abilities, and he never found a niche. Reports emerged last week that he had stopped paying staffers, and some of his team had left to join other political campaigns.

Michael Dennehy, a Perry supporter and strategist in New Hampshire, expressed regret over Perry's decision, stating, "It's a shame that a man with the most successful executive experience and the one who can best relate to middle-class America will not be on the ballot as we choose the Republican nominee."

Perry was relegated to the second tier in last month's first presidential debate in Ohio, and he was expected to remain in the second tier for the upcoming debate at the Reagan Presidential Library. Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union, noted that Perry struggled to rebound after being excluded from the opening prime-time debate.

Perry remains under indictment in Texas on corruption charges, with prosecutors alleging that he attempted to use the state budget to force a local prosecutor out of office. His departure leaves four candidates in the second-tier race: Former Sen. Rick Santorum, former New York Gov. George Pataki, Sen. Lindsey Graham, and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal. The main stage features 11 candidates: Businessman Donald Trump, retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina, Govs. Chris Christie of New Jersey, John Kasich of Ohio, and Scott Walker of Wisconsin, former Govs. Jeb Bush of Florida and Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, and Sens. Rand Paul, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio.

In his prepared remarks, Perry expressed optimism about the future, stating, "As I approach the next chapter in life, I do so with the love of my life by my side, Anita Perry. We have our house in the country, we have two beautiful children and two adorable grandchildren, four dogs, and the best sunset from our front porch that you could ever imagine."

Title: ZOA Defends Stephen Bannon Against ADL's Allegations of Anti-Semitism

Article:

The Zionist Organization of America (ZOA) has released a statement in defense of Stephen Bannon, President-elect Donald Trump's appointee as chief strategist, against allegations of anti-Semitism made by the Anti-Defamation League (ADL). In the statement, ZOA President Morton A. Klein criticized ADL President Jonathan Greenblatt for engaging in "character assassination" against Bannon and Breitbart Media, the media company Bannon presided over.

According to the ZOA, Bannon and Breitbart have been fair-minded towards Israel and the Jewish people, and the allegations of anti-Semitism are "Orwellian." The ZOA's statement cites several examples of Bannon and Breitbart's efforts to combat anti-Semitism, including their work to address anti-Semitic rallies at CUNY, their reporting on the Palestinian Authority's defamation of Israel, and their coverage of anti-Semitic incidents on college campuses.

The ZOA also criticized ADL for not speaking out against anti-Israel advisors in Hillary Clinton's campaign, specifically George Soros, who is known for his criticism of Israel. The ZOA concluded by expressing support for Bannon's appointment and urging ADL to withdraw and apologize for their allegations against Bannon and Breitbart Media.

It is unclear whether Trump's pro-Israel advisors, including Newt Gingrich, Rudy Giuliani, Mike Pence, Mike Huckabee, Sheldon Adelson, Jared Kushner, David Friedman, and Jason Greenblatt, would allow an anti-Semite to work with them or whether Trump's Orthodox Jewish daughter Ivanka, whose children attend an Orthodox day school, would allow an anti-Semite to work with her father. The statement also questions why ADL and other Bannon critics did not speak out against anti-Israel advisors in Hillary Clinton's campaign.

Title: Attorney General Directs Prosecutors to Pursue Most Serious Charges, Reversing Obama-Era Policies

Article:

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has directed federal prosecutors to pursue the most serious charges possible against the vast majority of suspects, marking a significant reversal of Obama-era policies that is expected to result in more people being sent to prison for longer terms.

In a memo sent Thursday night to U.S. attorneys and made public early on Friday, Sessions wrote, "This policy affirms our responsibility to enforce the law, is moral and just, and produces consistency."

The move represents a clear undoing of Obama administration criminal justice policies that aimed to ease overcrowding in federal prisons and contributed to a national rethinking of how drug criminals were prosecuted and sentenced. Critics argue that the change will subject more lower-level offenders to unfairly harsh mandatory minimum sentences.

Sessions contends a spike in violence in some big cities and the nation's opioid epidemic show the need for a return to tougher tactics. In remarks prepared for a Thursday speech in Charleston, West Virginia, Sessions stated, "Drug trafficking is an inherently violent business... If you want to collect a drug debt, you can’t, and don’t, file a lawsuit in court. You collect it by the barrel of a gun."

The policy memo instructs prosecutors to "charge and pursue the most serious, readily provable offense" - a move more likely to trigger mandatory minimum sentences. The memo concedes there will be cases in which "good judgment" will warrant a prosecutor to veer from that rule, but any exceptions will need to be approved by top supervisors, and the reasons must be documented.

The directive rescinds guidance by Sessions' Democratic predecessor, Eric Holder, who told prosecutors they could in some cases leave drug quantities out of charging documents to avoid triggering long sentences. Holder's 2013 initiative, known as Smart on Crime, was aimed at encouraging shorter sentences for nonviolent drug offenders and preserving justice department resources for more serious and violent criminals.

The Obama policy shift coincided with U.S. Sentencing Commission changes that made tens of thousands of federal drug prisoners eligible for early release, and an Obama administration clemency initiative that freed convicts deemed deserving of a second chance. Combined, these changes led to a steep decline in a federal prison population that now stands at just under 190,000, down from nearly 220,000 in 2013. Nearly half of those inmates are in custody for drug crimes, records show.

Obama administration officials cited that decline and a drop in the overall number of drug prosecutions as evidence that policies were working as intended. They argued prosecutors were getting pickier about the cases they were bringing and were seeking mandatory minimum sentences less often.

However, some prosecutors felt constrained by the Holder directive and expressed concern that they'd lose plea bargaining leverage – and a key inducement for cooperation – without the ability to more freely pursue harsher punishments. Sessions and other justice department officials argue Holder's approach sidestepped federal laws that impose such sentences and created inconsistency across the country in the way defendants are punished. Even while in the Senate, Sessions repeatedly asserted that eliminating mandatory minimums weakened the ability of law enforcement to protect the public.

Advocates for the previous policy argue the change will revive the worst aspects of the drug war. "It looks like we're going to fill the prisons back up after finally getting the federal prison population down," said Kevin Ring, president of Families Against Mandatory Minimums. "But the social and human costs will be much higher."

Title: Vehicle Ramming Incident at NSA Headquarters in Ft. Meade: Two Perpetrators, One Dead, One Severely Injured

A vehicle attempted to ram the gates at the National Security Agency (NSA) headquarters in Ft. Meade, Maryland, on Monday morning, leading to a confrontation with security forces that ended with shots being fired. At least one uniformed guard was injured and transported in an ambulance.

According to BBC News, helicopter footage showed two cars, one a police vehicle and the other a black vehicle with no insignia, in a junction near the security gates. The cars appear to have collided, and debris is scattered across the intersection. A white cloth is visible beside the black vehicle.

Local emergency responders are handling the incident, with local agencies providing support, according to the BBC. The NSA has not provided an official comment.

The UK Mirror reports two people were injured during the incident, one of whom was the uniformed man described being placed in an ambulance by the BBC. Ynet News reports the man who tried to ram the gates was shot dead by security forces. CBS News confirms one fatality occurred during the incident, along with two injuries.

CBS News reports that two women were in the vehicle attempting to ram the NSA gates, and that at least one woman is dead, with the other taken to Shock Trauma for treatment. The CBS report also claims authorities found "cocaine and a weapon" in the car involved in the incident, and that there is currently no armed shooter at large.

The gender of the individuals attacking the NSA headquarters is disputed in various reports. NBC News claims the two people in the car were "men disguised as women," not women. The NBC report notes that drugs were found in the vehicle, coinciding with CBS. CNN is also reporting that the attackers were two men.

Further updates note the car was stolen, and there is not yet any indication of an organized terrorist attempt, but rather, one anonymous official described the attack as a "local criminal matter" to NBC.

This is not the first recent report of trouble at NSA headquarters. Earlier this month, the FBI arrested a man for firing shots at the building, as part of a shooting spree that lasted several weeks, including shots fired at a service truck, which injured one of the passengers with shattered glass.

Update 12:30PM EST: ABC News reports that one of the perpetrators was shot dead on the scene, while the other is "severely injured" and probably will not survive. The injuries of the security officer are said to be "non-life-threatening." Some reports have suggested the officer was struck by one of the vehicles involved in the crash – two damaged SUVs can be seen in helicopter footage – rather than being hit by gunfire.

CBS News in Baltimore reports the FBI will take over investigation of the incident from the NSA's security force. There are still said to be no links to organized terrorism.

Update 4:45PM EST: The Associated Press reports that the vehicle used to ram the NSA gates was stolen from a hotel.

Title: American Photojournalist Luke Somers Killed in Failed Rescue Attempt in Yemen

Article:

American photojournalist Luke Somers was killed during a failed rescue attempt in Yemen, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel announced Saturday. Somers had been held by al-Qaeda militants since his abduction in Yemen's capital, Sanaa, in September 2013.

Hagel, speaking from Kabul where he made a surprise visit Saturday, confirmed the British-born hostage's death following an unsuccessful raid by U.S. and Yemeni special forces to free him.

In a statement, Hagel described Somers' death as murder at the hands of terrorists, stating there were "compelling reasons to believe Mr. Somers' life was in imminent danger."

Lucy Somers, Somers' sister, learned of her brother's death from the FBI. "We ask that all of Luke's family members be allowed to mourn in peace," she told the Associated Press.

A second hostage, South African Pierre Korkie, a teacher abducted in Yemen in May 2013 with his wife, was also killed in the failed raid. Yolande Korkie had previously been released by al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula militants.

During the rescue operation, helicopters swept in and dropped U.S. commandos about a mile from the village where Somers was being held, according to a senior Defense Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak publicly. U.S. warplanes flew overhead for protection but did not fire weapons. The commandos, from teams based in the Middle East, killed all of the al-Qaeda-linked terrorists. No U.S. forces were wounded, the official said.

President Obama authorized the rescue attempt due to information the U.S. had that Somers' life was in immediate danger, including a video released by his terrorist captors this week that announced the journalist would be killed within 72 hours.

U.S. officials believe the militants shot the two men during a firefight, and that both were alive when American forces pulled them from a building on the group's compound and got them aboard aircraft, where medical teams operated on them during a short flight to the USS Makin Island, a Navy ship in the region. Korkie is believed to have died during the flight, while American Somers died on the ship, according to senior U.S. officials who spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the information had yet to be approved for release.

Those who knew Somers, who was born in Britain but spent much of his life in America, remembered the photographer as a person drawn to new experiences. "He really wanted to understand the world," said Shawn Gillen, an English professor and chairman of Beloit College's journalism program. Somers earned a bachelor's degree in creative writing while attending Beloit College in Wisconsin from 2004 to 2007. "He'd want to be in places where world events were happening."

At a news conference in Bahrain on Saturday, Yemen's national security chief, Maj. Gen. Ali al-Ahmadi, said the militants had planned to kill Somers on Saturday. "Al-Qaeda promised to conduct the execution (of Somers) today so there was an attempt to save them, but unfortunately, they shot the hostage before or during the attack," al-Ahmadi said.

At the same time, Pierre Korkie was set to be released Sunday, according to Gift of Givers, the aid group that negotiated his wife's freedom. "The psychological and emotional devastation to Yolande and her family will be compounded by the knowledge that Pierre was to be released by al-Qaeda," the group said in a statement.

In a YouTube video released Wednesday, Somers, 33, said his "life is in danger." The video featured an al-Qaeda official and a brief message from Somers—dressed in a purple shirt and with a shaved head—at the end. Pentagon press secretary Rear Adm. John Kirby said Thursday a U.S. raid last month attempted to free Somers, but he turned out not to be at the site. Before her brother's death, Lucy Somers released an online video describing him as a romantic who "always believes the best in people." She ended with the plea: "Please let him live."

Title: Nine Members of Mormon Community Killed in Drug Cartel Attack in Mexico

Article:

Nine individuals, including three women and six children, were killed in a violent attack in northern Mexico on Monday. The victims were members of a Mormon community of dual U.S.-Mexican citizens. The attack occurred on a highway in the border state of Sonora, an area known for its contention among organized crime groups.

According to Mexico's minister for public security, the incident transpired in broad daylight. The attack began when one vehicle stopped due to a flat tire, and assailants attacked the stranded car, killing the driver and four children, including 6-month-old twins. The attackers then set the car on fire.

Two other cars were attacked nearby, resulting in the deaths of two women and two children. A family member described a chaotic scene where a child was shot while attempting to flee. It is believed that at least eight survivors remain, including as many as seven children who reportedly managed to escape. Some of the surviving children sustained serious injuries, including a 9-month-old who was shot in the chest and a 4-year-old who was shot in the back. A 13-year-old reportedly walked 14 miles to the family's home to seek help after hiding his wounded siblings in the brush.

The Mormon community targeted in the attack is a farming community that moved south of the border nearly a century ago to practice polygamy after a dispute with the church over the practice. The U.S. President, Donald J. Trump, tweeted about the incident, expressing his condolences and offering potential U.S. involvement in addressing the issue. However, the specifics of any potential U.S. intervention have not been detailed.

Title: World Mourns and Celebrates the Life of Evangelist Billy Graham

Article:

The world is remembering and mourning the passing of evangelist Billy Graham, who dedicated his life to spreading the gospel of Christ through various communication technologies, a renowned evangelistic organization, and an eloquence that moved many to accept Jesus.

Dana Robert, a Boston University religion professor, praised Graham's evangelical zeal, comparing it to that of the Apostle Paul 1,800 years earlier. She attended one of Graham's crusades in her native Baton Rouge in 1970 and described him as a man who lived a good life and could say, as Paul did in his letter to Timothy, "I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith."

Larry Ross, Graham's longtime spokesman, said the evangelist showed courage and faith throughout his long physical decline. "He was faithful to the end," he said. "He showed how to finish well."

News of Graham's death spread globally, from missionaries' huts in Africa to back-country Bible Belt churches to mighty Southern Baptist temples. His life was recalled by Protestants, Catholics, Muslims, and Jews; by those who attended one of his crusades, or dozens; by those who only saw him on TV or heard him on the radio; by those who knew him mostly as a pastor to presidents.

Randall Balmer, a Dartmouth College expert on evangelical Christianity, described Graham as "the most prominent religious celebrity of the 20th Century," a period that included popes John XXIII and John Paul II, the 14th Dalai Lama, Mother Teresa, and Norman Vincent Peale. Balmer estimated that, even if the audiences for his many broadcasts are not counted, Graham preached to more people in person than anyone in history.

Those with the strongest impressions of Graham saw him at his final big public events. Craig Allen, 74, of Finksburg, MD, heard Graham's last major sermon, delivered in Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore in July 2006. Michael Freeland, 59, of Metairie, LA, who lost most of his real estate business after Hurricane Katrina the previous year, attended with his wife and two sons. He said Graham's presence after the storm, especially after announcing his retirement the previous year, "meant a lot to us." He was old, he'd lost his wife. You could see his frailty. But once he started to preach, you could feel an energy. That was the Holy Spirit. That was him doing something he was passionate about."

Maggie Rousseau and her husband, Bill, drove 14 hours from Savannah, GA, to see Graham for the first time in New York City in June 2005. Given the evangelist's health, they knew it would be the last. "There was just something about him," Maggie said. "I don't know what it was, but you believed him. On the crusades, on TV, he spoke, and you listened."

However, some argued that Graham's impact has already diminished. Balmer reported that, several years ago, when he asked one of his classes at Dartmouth if they knew who Billy Graham was, only 25% raised a hand. Robert described him as essentially a phenomenon of the Greatest and Boomer generations. "When I was young, the whole family watched him on television, like Walter Cronkite. When he came to town, everyone went to the crusade," she recalled. "But I don't think the Millennials even know who he was."

Title: U.S. Faces Tough Decisions as Covid-19 Death Toll Rises and Economy Suffers

Article:

The United States has reported 2,231 Covid-19 deaths on May 7, bringing the total number of deaths in the country to 75,662, and over 270,000 worldwide. The economic impact has been significant, with the U.S. Gross Domestic Product (GDP) expected to see its first drop in six years in the second quarter of 2020, according to the U.S. Congressional Budget Office. Since March, 33.5 million people have filed for unemployment, and businesses large and small are closing, leading to the loss of millions of jobs.

The debate over reopening the economy versus maintaining strict social distancing measures to control the spread of Covid-19 has become a contentious issue. President Trump has advocated for reopening the country, stating, "We can't keep our country closed. We have to open our country." However, the choice may not be as stark as it seems.

The objective of social distancing is to "flatten the curve," slowing the spread of the virus to prevent hospitals from being overwhelmed and to allow for public health measures like widespread testing and contact tracing. If these measures had been implemented effectively, the lockdown could have been less stringent, and the economic costs could have been reduced.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo made a poignant point during a briefing, asking, "How much is a human life worth?" He stated, "To me, I say the cost of a human life, a human life is priceless. Period."

The federal government has largely abandoned its own standards for when states should lift their shelter-in-place orders. A researcher at the respected Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security told Congress last week that no state looked epidemiologically ready to return to normal.

Despite this, 31 states have decided to ease restrictions, with Texas allowing restaurants, movie theaters, and barber shops to reopen at 25% capacity, while acknowledging that Covid-19 cases will likely increase as a result. Georgia has lifted its stay-at-home order and reopened businesses like tattoo parlors and bowling alleys, while California, which initially took early action, is opening some southern beaches.

The information available about the virus, its impact on the national economy, and what people will contribute to the economy even if states end official restrictions is incomplete and sometimes contradictory. Given this uncertainty, it remains to be seen who will choose to travel or visit crowded places in the near future.

The question of the value of a human life is a complex one, and it is a question that society has historically been willing to incur costs to save lives and improve public welfare. However, the trade-offs clearly have limits, and the decision to prioritize the economy over public health during a pandemic is a difficult one that requires careful consideration and balanced decision-making.

Title: Trump Suggests Softening Stance on Illegal Immigration, Emphasizes Deportation of Criminals and Reform of Sanctuary Cities

Article:

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump reiterated his stance on illegal immigration during a town hall with Fox News host Sean Hannity on Wednesday, stating that there would be "no amnesty" for undocumented immigrants but suggesting a willingness to "work with them." This is the latest in a series of recent interviews where Trump has indicated a potential softening of his previous pledge to deport 11 million illegal immigrants in the U.S.

During the town hall on Tuesday, Trump expressed openness to "softening" laws dealing with illegal immigrants. On Wednesday, Trump clarified that there would be "no citizenship" for those who are in the country illegally. He proposed that these individuals would pay back taxes and work towards legal status, but not receive amnesty in the traditional sense.

Trump also addressed the challenges of deporting long-term residents who have built families in the U.S. He emphasized the need to focus on deporting criminals while acknowledging the emotional impact of separating families who have lived in the country for decades.

In addition, Trump criticized sanctuary cities for protecting criminals, claiming that police are increasingly frustrated due to the inability to enforce immigration laws in these jurisdictions. He called for the elimination of sanctuary cities, arguing that they protect criminals and hinder law enforcement efforts.

Trump is expected to announce a decision on his stance regarding illegal immigration "very soon." According to the Associated Press, he will unveil his new immigration policy during a speech in Phoenix next week at the Hyatt Regency. The speech is expected to cover policy matters, as confirmed by Arizona Republican Party Chairman Robert Graham and two unnamed officials with knowledge of Trump's campaign plans.

Title: Pennsylvania, Idaho, Nebraska, and Oregon Hold Primary Elections on Tuesday

Article:

Tuesday will see primary elections in several states, including Pennsylvania, Idaho, Nebraska, and Oregon. The elections will help settle the chaotic congressional landscape in Pennsylvania, which has undergone redrawn districts following a court fight just three months ago.

In Pennsylvania, primary voters will decide the fate of President Donald Trump's pick for U.S. Senate, as well as the nominees for 18 House districts due to the new court-ordered redrawn congressional district maps. This is the highest number of candidates running in Pennsylvania's House districts since 1984, when the state had 23 seats in the House.

Five of Pennsylvania's 13 GOP House members have quit or are not running again, creating seven House vacancies, the most in Pennsylvania since 1976. The 7th District, abandoned by moderate Charlie Dent, is one of these vacancies. Hillary Clinton received more votes than Trump in this district, which was reunified with Democratic-leaning cities in the east and cut out some of Republican-leaning central Pennsylvania. Six Democrats are running in this district.

Ten Democrats are running in suburban Philadelphia's 5th District, where Rep. Patrick Meehan resigned last month amid sexual harassment allegations and where Clinton also beat Trump.

In the Pennsylvania Republican Senate primary, Rep. Lou Barletta is heavily favored to become the Republican challenger for Democratic Sen. Bob Casey, who is seeking a third term in November. Barletta was a Trump supporter before the 2016 presidential nomination and has Trump's early support in the Senate race.

Last week, Trump urged GOP Senate primary voters to support Rep. Jim Renacci in the Ohio Senate primary and oppose former coal company executive Don Blankenship in West Virginia. Renacci won, and Blankenship lost. Ohio, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia are all seen as key to the 2018 Senate election landscape as states where Trump won in 2016 and Democratic senators are seeking re-election this year.

In Nebraska, Tuesday's Democratic primary in the 2nd Congressional District, dominated by Omaha and its suburbs, features moderate former Rep. Brad Ashford fighting for his old seat and Kara Eastman, a children's nonprofit administrator, running to Ashford's left. Ashford, a former Republican, served one term in Congress as a Democrat before losing to Republican Don Bacon in 2016.

In Idaho, the primary goes a long way to determining the general election, as Republican Gov. C.L. "Butch" Otter is not seeking re-election after three terms. Lt. Gov. Brad Little is seeking the GOP nomination, with Otter's endorsement, while Tommy Ahlquist, an emergency room doctor turned developer, hopes his outsider status carries him as it did Indiana businessman Mike Braun in last week's GOP Senate primary.

In Oregon, ten Republicans are vying for the nomination for governor—the most in more than a century. The interest among candidates belies the uphill climb for the party in the Democratic-leaning state. Businessman Sam Carpenter, state Rep. Knute Buehler, and retired Navy pilot Greg Wooldridge have emerged as leaders in fundraising and GOP straw polls. However, Democratic Gov. Kate Brown remains the favorite to win in November. Brown became governor in 2015 upon the resignation of Gov. John Kitzhaber following an ethics scandal, and she won a special election in 2016.

Oregon is among eight states where Democrats control the governorship and both houses of the state legislature. Voters who identify as Democrats also outnumber their Republican counterparts by more than 9 percentage points.

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows in August, Missing Wall Street Projections

Article:

The U.S. economy added 130,000 jobs in August, falling short of Wall Street's expectations, as trade uncertainty and slowing global growth cast a shadow over the economic outlook. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.7%, near a 50-year low, while the labor force participation rate was little changed at 63.2%. Average hourly earnings rose 3.2% over the past year to $28.11, slightly higher than projected at 3.1%.

Economists anticipated employers to add 158,000 jobs, in line with average growth this year but significantly below the 2018 average of 223,000. The June and July jobs numbers were revised down by a combined 20,000, according to the Labor Department's report released on Friday.

Employment in the federal government increased in the last full month of summer, primarily due to the hiring of temporary workers for the 2020 census. Excluding these employees, August payrolls grew by 105,000 jobs. Notable gains also occurred in the health care sector, which added 24,000 jobs, and the finance industry, which grew by 15,000.

The lower-than-expected growth comes amid concerns that the current economic expansion in the U.S., which has reached a record length, is beginning to slow and may be followed by a recession within two years. Industries on the front line of the U.S.-China trade war continued to report losses.

Tony Bedikian, managing director at Citizens Bank, commented, "The on-again, off-again U.S.-China trade talks continue to roil markets and, in some ways, are mirroring the on-again, off-again Brexit debate. Both issues are providing market participants with more theater than substance while the U.S. consumer tunes them out, keeps spending, and keeps the U.S. economic fundamentals on track."

The jobs report is likely to give the Federal Reserve justification to lower short-term interest rates by a modest 25 basis points, rather than making a deeper cut, when policymakers meet in mid-September. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is scheduled to discuss the economic outlook in a speech later Friday in Zurich.

Title: California Imposes Indefinite 'Stay At Home' Order as Coronavirus Cases Surge

Article:

California Governor Gavin Newsom has issued an indefinite 'Stay At Home' order for the state's 40 million residents in response to the growing novel coronavirus epidemic. The order, announced late Thursday, is the most extensive directive issued by any state so far in the United States.

The order requires residents to stay at home, with exceptions only for essential travel. The move follows similar restrictions imposed earlier this week for the San Francisco Bay Area.

During a late-evening news conference in Sacramento, Newsom stated, "This order goes into force and effect this evening, and we are confident that the people of the state of California will abide by it, will do the right thing."

Newsom, a Democrat who took office just over a year ago, said Californians would "step up as they have over the last number of weeks to protect themselves, to protect their families, and to protect the broader community in this great state and the world we reside in."

The duration of the order is undetermined. After the announcement, California Republican Rep. Kevin McCarthy, the House minority leader, tweeted, "I hope Governor Newsom consulted with a lot of experts before he decided to shut down 12% of the nation's population."

The order includes several exemptions, according to Newsom. "We're going to keep the grocery stores open," he said. "We're going to make sure that you're getting critical medical supplies. You can still take your kids outside, practicing common sense and social distancing. You can still walk your dog."

Essential travel includes trips to grocery stores, gas stations, farmers markets, food banks, convenience stores, takeout and delivery restaurants, banks, and laundromats, according to the Los Angeles Times. The directive also exempts critical infrastructure such as food and agriculture, health care, transportation, energy, and financial services, the newspaper said.

California, along with Washington and New York, is among the states hardest-hit by the burgeoning U.S. outbreak. The state has over 1,000 confirmed cases of the potentially fatal respiratory infection, with 19 deaths from COVID-19.

Earlier, Newsom stated that an official projection estimates that up to 56% of the state's residents could become infected by the virus—a figure that would equate to more than 22 million people. However, he said at the news conference, "The point of the stay-at-home order is to make those numbers moot."

According to the latest figures from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the total number of cases in the U.S. has surpassed 10,000. However, officials believe that due to the small number of tests for the virus so far due to a lack of test kits, the number of infections is thought to be significantly higher.

A tally of worldwide coronavirus statistics maintained by Johns Hopkins University shows the global total of reported cases is nearly 250,000, with more than 10,000 deaths.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Mixed Legacy on National Security Issues

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder, who announced his resignation on Thursday, leaves office with a mixed record on national security issues, according to legal experts. Holder, who took office in 2009, was determined to distance the Justice Department from past practices, but his decisions have drawn scrutiny and disappointed some who felt he did not go far enough in protecting civil liberties.

One of Holder's most controversial decisions was his plan to prosecute the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks and other alleged co-conspirators in a New York courtroom rather than through the Guantanamo Bay military commission process. The Obama administration's eventual decision to walk away from the proposal was a stinging defeat for Holder.

During his tenure, Holder oversaw hundreds of terrorism-fighting successes, including the prosecutions of plots to explode a bomb in Times Square and on a Detroit-bound airliner. However, the department also authorized targeted drone strikes against Americans abroad, subpoenaed journalists' telephone records in leak investigations, and defended in court the government's bulk collection of millions of Americans' telephone records.

Jonathan Hafetz, a Seton Hall University law professor and former senior lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union, said Holder had been "too supportive of executive power and insufficiently protective of civil liberties." Stephen Vladeck, an American University law school professor, credited Holder for overseeing a large number of terrorism prosecutions but noted that the visible successes did not tell the whole story.

When Holder took over, he quickly signaled a new direction from the previous Republican administration. During Senate hearings on his nomination, Holder defined waterboarding as torture and announced an investigation into CIA interrogation methods of terrorist detainees. The inquiry ended without criminal charges.

Holder pushed a shift away from the military commission system the Bush administration enacted to prosecute suspected terrorists at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba. In November 2009, he said the Justice Department would prosecute five detainees, including professed Sept. 11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, in federal court in New York and seek the death penalty.

Critics, mostly Republicans, argued the federal courts were ill-equipped for such a trial and expressed alarm that terrorists would be brought to American soil. The White House in 2011 shelved the idea, which was seen as a step toward closing the Guantanamo detention facility.

Despite that defeat, Holder remained firm in supporting civilian courts for suspected terrorists, and his Justice Department has won many convictions before American juries. He has said his position was vindicated by the fact that, in the years since the Guantanamo proposal was spiked, Osama bin Laden's son-in-law was captured, convicted in New York, and given a life sentence. The military commission case against Mohammed remains stalled in Guantanamo by pretrial wrangling.

Holder's successor will face many of the same policy questions, including how to close Guantanamo and what to do with the detainees, how to handle potential foreign fighters trying to join extremist groups in Syria, and whether there is a vehicle for bringing former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden out of asylum in Russia and into a U.S. courtroom.

Either way, said Vladeck, it's challenging from the outside to fully assess Holder's national security record. "The public's perspective, I think, may be very different from the attorney general's perspective. He knows all the things that never made the front pages."

Title: U.S. Officials Provide Contrasting Views on Safety of Iraqi Christians

Article:

Two senior U.S. officials have provided contrasting assessments on the safety of Iraqi Christians, with one asserting that they face terror and extortion in northern Iraq, while the other maintains they are largely immune from politically motivated violence.

Last September, Hallam Ferguson, a senior Trump appointee at the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), told a government commission that militias aligned with Iran terrorize families who have returned to northern Iraq, extort local businesses, and openly pledge allegiance to Iran. Ferguson stated that in some towns, the number of Christians who have returned after the defeat of the Islamic State has reached only 1 to 2% due to persecution by these militias.

On the same day, Michael Rubin, a Middle East expert at the American Enterprise Institute, completed a sworn declaration at the request of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for use in its efforts to deport Iraqis. Rubin argued that Iraq is now a more stable country with an increasingly professional government, and Iraqi Christians could count on the state's protection.

Government lawyers have submitted Rubin's statement, along with similar declarations by two other experts, to courts during immigration hearings. The assessments by Rubin and the other experts can have significant consequences, as the administration has sought to deport hundreds of Iraqis, many of them Christians, who immigrated to the U.S. years ago. To stay in the U.S., many of the Iraqis have to prove that if they are deported, they are most likely to be tortured by, or with the tacit permission of, the Iraqi government.

President Donald Trump said in a January speech in Michigan that he would grant an "extension" to Iraqi Christians facing deportation, but DHS' effort to deport the Iraqis is ongoing, lawyers said. In approving one Iraqi Christian's deportation late last year, an immigration judge wrote that he found the experts' declarations "persuasive" and was convinced that the Iraqi government has cracked down on abuses by the majority-Shiite Muslim militias that helped defeat the Islamic State but have not disbanded since its demise.

In an emailed response to questions, Rubin said that he does not agree with the Trump administration's policy of deporting the Iraqis, but that he had been asked for an informed assessment and not his political opinion. Rubin plans to update his statement to address recent unrest in Iraq, where there have been widespread demonstrations and the killing of hundreds of mostly unarmed protesters.

The two other experts who took similar positions as Rubin, Denise Natali and Douglas Ollivant, did not respond to requests for comment. Natali is now a senior State Department official.

The State Department, USAID, DHS, and the White House did not respond to requests for comment, and the Iraqi Embassy in Washington did not offer a response either.
