While the Iraqi government has succeeded in defeating the Islamic State and winning back control of its territory, religious and ethnic minorities have little faith the government can protect them against a multitude of active, semi-official armed groups, experts said.

"My view aligns more closely with USAID," said Steven Cook, a Middle East expert at the Council on Foreign Relations, who visited Iraq in December. "Iraq seems to be in a situation of terminal collapse. With the continued presence of extremists and the unreliable central government, I find it hard to believe that Christians are safe and secure."

Lawyers for the deportees have also filed declarations from human rights experts arguing that the deportees would be at risk of detention and abuse. The Trump administration has frequently highlighted the dangers faced by Christians to support its decision to allocate hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid for them and other religious minorities in Iraq and Syria. The cause is especially popular with Trump's conservative Christian base, which he is seeking to solidify ahead of the 2020 presidential election. Vice President Mike Pence, in particular, has made this issue a priority. Starting in 2017, his aides pressured USAID to direct more funds to religious minorities in Iraq, including Christians. A ███ investigation last year found that, under pressure from Pence and in contravention of USAID regulations, political appointees were closely involved in deciding grants in Iraq that went to Christian groups.

Title: Virginia Election Results Reveal Anti-Immigrant Strategy as Ineffective for Republicans

Article:

In the recent Virginia elections, the strategy employed by Republican candidate Ed Gillespie, which focused on anti-immigrant sentiments, was met with significant opposition from voters across various demographic and ethnic groups. Contrary to pre-election speculation, the anti-immigrant strategy proved to be a misstep for Gillespie, as demonstrated by election results and polling data.

According to a survey conducted by Latino Decisions on election eve, Latino voters expressed disapproval of Gillespie's MS-13 advertisements, with a 45-point margin stating that the ads made them less enthusiastic about him. This sentiment was not limited to Latino voters. In Virginia, whites, African-Americans, and Asian-Americans also expressed disapproval of the MS-13 ads, with a 23-point margin (52 to 29) stating that the ads turned them away from Gillespie.

A regression analysis of survey data reveals a clear trend. Exposure to Gillespie's MS-13 ads drove white college-educated voters away from the Republicans. Furthermore, among white independents and Republicans, voters who were aware of the MS-13 ads were significantly more likely to vote for Gillespie's Democratic opponent. This effect was not limited to the governor's race; the Gillespie campaign's coattail effects were of the wrong kind, with voters who were aware of the MS-13 ads being significantly more likely to vote for Democratic candidates for Virginia's House of Delegates.

The data suggests that not only is it strategically sound for Democrats to position themselves as the party that stands against hatred and bigotry and in favor of inclusiveness and opportunity, but it is also a morally just position. This stance resonates with Latino, African-American, and Asian-American voters, while also winning over enough white voters who oppose immigrant bashing.

This trend is particularly significant for voters who will decide crucial House and Senate races in 2018: people of color and white college-educated voters, also known as the Democratic base. As President Trump and his fellow Republicans gear up for a similar anti-immigrant effort in 2018, the Virginia elections serve as a clear warning. Voters are becoming increasingly aware and are likely to respond negatively to such strategies. Democrats have an opportunity to speak out strongly against bigotry and, in doing so, have a path to victory in 2018 and beyond.

Title: President Trump Calls for "Red Wave" to Pass Immigration Bill, Accuses Democrats of Obstruction

Article:

President Donald Trump has called for a "red wave" in the November elections to pass an immigration bill in Congress, accusing Democrats of obstruction. In a series of tweets on Friday, Trump stated that Republicans should not waste their time on immigration until after the midterm elections, as Democrats are "just playing games" and have no intention of addressing the decades-old problem.

The House GOP abruptly scrapped a planned vote on a troubled immigration bill on Thursday, pushing a vote into next week. The compromise measure was expected to include a requirement that employers use E-Verify to check the legal status of employees.

Congressional Republicans had earlier failed to pass a more conservative bill. A sticking point for conservatives is that while the compromise funds the wall, it also offers a pathway to citizenship for 1.8 million young illegal immigrants. The conservative bill offers only the 700,000 recipients of the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program the ability to apply for indefinite renewals of non-immigrant status.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., stated, "It is not a compromise." She added, "It may be a compromise with the devil, but it is not a compromise with the Democrats."

Trump extended an invitation to Democrats to discuss immigration at the White House on Wednesday, but he had scathing words for what he called the "extremist, open border" lawmakers. On Thursday, he echoed that rhetoric, but without the invitation for Democrats to come to the table.

Trump renewed his criticism of the filibuster in the Senate, which requires 60 votes to break. He stated, "Even if we get 100% Republican votes in the Senate, we need 10 Democrat votes to get a much-needed Immigration Bill - & the Dems are Obstructionists who won’t give votes for political reasons & because they don’t care about Crime coming from the Border! So we need to elect more R’s!"

Trump's tweets come after a fiery week in which rhetoric on both sides has escalated on the question of the administration's "zero tolerance" policy, which prosecutes all illegal border crossers. This led to an increase in the number of children being separated from their parents. Trump signed an executive order on Wednesday ending the practice and allowing families to be detained together, but Democrats have since pushed for ending what they described as "indefinite detention" of families at the border.

Title: Misinterpretation of Netanyahu's Remarks on Palestinian Statehood

Article:

Recent media reports, primarily in the Western press, have been circulating a false narrative regarding Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's stance on a Palestinian state. The misconception stems from a misinterpretation of Netanyahu's comments during an interview with the conservative Israeli publication NRG.

In the interview, Netanyahu was asked if his 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University, where he expressed support for the possibility of a Palestinian state, was irrelevant. In response, Netanyahu did not reject the idea of a Palestinian state outright. Instead, he expressed concerns about the potential security risks of establishing a Palestinian state in the current political climate.

When asked if a Palestinian state would not come to fruition if he were elected head of state, Netanyahu responded affirmatively, but his statement was taken out of context. He was referring to the potential dangers of creating a Palestinian state "today," not a permanent rejection of the idea.

Furthermore, Netanyahu's policy on the Palestinian issue aligns closely with that of Yitzchak Rabin, the man who created the Oslo Accords. In a speech one month before his assassination in 1995, Rabin stated, "We view a permanent solution [involving] a Palestinian entity which is less than a state... We will not return to the June 4, 1967 lines... We committed ourselves before the Knesset not to uproot a single settlement in the framework of the interim agreement, and not to hinder building for natural growth... And first and foremost in our concerns is a united Jerusalem, as the capital of Israel, under Israeli sovereignty."

The misinterpretation of Netanyahu's comments by Ha'aretz and the subsequent spread of the story by the Western media has led to accusations of flip-flopping on Netanyahu's part. However, a careful examination of the interview transcript reveals that Netanyahu did not change his position on the Palestinian issue, but rather expressed concerns about the timing and potential security risks of establishing a Palestinian state.

Title: Cruz and Trump Engage in Legal Threats Over Abortion Ad in South Carolina

Article:

In a heated exchange, Republican presidential candidates Ted Cruz and Donald Trump have engaged in a series of legal threats over an ad running in South Carolina that questions Trump's record on abortion. Cruz has dismissed Trump's complaints and vowed to run the ad more frequently, stating that voters "deserve to know the truth."

At a press conference in South Carolina on Wednesday, Cruz read from a cease-and-desist letter sent by Trump's campaign, calling it "one of the most remarkable letters I have ever read." Cruz challenged Trump to follow through with his threatened lawsuit.

The ad in question features footage of Trump in a 1999 interview stating he is "very pro-choice." The ad references the current debate over the Supreme Court vacancy and states, "We cannot trust Donald Trump with these serious decisions."

Trump's attorney sent Cruz a letter on Tuesday, stating the ad was "replete with outright lies, false, defamatory, and destructive statements" and that Cruz could be held liable for damages if it is not taken down. In response, the Cruz campaign called the threats "laughable" and questioned the validity of preventing voters from hearing Trump's past statements on the issue.

Meanwhile, Cruz and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio are also embroiled in a dispute over alleged dirty tricks leading up to Saturday's South Carolina GOP primary. Cruz has denied any involvement in any untoward activities and has called for anyone with evidence to come forward. Rubio was asked Wednesday to provide evidence that Cruz's team was behind a fake Facebook page wrongly claiming that U.S. Rep. Trey Gowdy had switched his endorsement from Rubio to Cruz.

Rubio responded, "It's just a pattern of people around his campaign that have continuously done things like that."

Both candidates have yet to follow through on their legal threats, and the outcome remains uncertain.

Title: BuzzFeed Report Alleges President Trump Directed Michael Cohen to Lie About Moscow Project

Article:

BuzzFeed News has reported that President Donald Trump directed his former lawyer Michael Cohen to lie about his Trump Tower project in Moscow. According to the report, Cohen pleaded guilty in November to lying about the deal in testimony and in a two-page statement to the Senate and House intelligence committees. Special counsel Robert Mueller noted that Cohen's false claim that the project ended in January 2016 was an attempt to "minimize links between the Moscow Project and Individual 1" - widely understood to be Trump - "in hopes of limiting the ongoing Russia investigations."

Two sources told BuzzFeed News that Cohen also told the special counsel that after the election, the president personally instructed him to lie - by claiming that negotiations ended months earlier than they actually did - in order to obscure Trump's involvement.

Representative David Cicilline (D-RI) and Representative Ted Lieu (D-CA) have reacted to the news, with Cicilline stating on CNN Friday that the report could be "the most serious threat" to Trump's presidency. Lieu concluded that the president is guilty of obstruction of justice.

Cicilline and Lieu have called for a congressional investigation into the matter. Cicilline stated that they should wait for the reports to be confirmed before calling for an investigation, while Lieu has called for the House Judiciary Committee to start holding hearings to establish a record of whether the president committed impeachable offenses.

However, when asked by CNN's John Berman if he has evidence to prove Trump told Cohen to lie, Cicilline said "we've all seen the conduct of the president." Berman noted that was not an answer and asked again if he actually saw the evidence. Cicilline admitted that he has not seen the evidence referenced in the article.

One of the authors of the BuzzFeed report, Anthony Cormier, stood by his reporting on CNN Friday as "100 percent" truth. The report has yet to be confirmed or corroborated.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Reiterates Opposition to "Clean" Debt Ceiling Increase, Government Funding Bill

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner has stated that Republican lawmakers will not agree to a measure to raise the nation's debt ceiling without conditions to curb deficit spending. In an interview on the ABC news program "This Week," Boehner expressed his opposition to a "clean" debt ceiling increase, stating, "I told the president, there's no way we're going to pass one."

Regarding the ongoing government shutdown, Boehner was equally firm that Republicans would demand concessions for any bill to reopen the government. Specifically, Republicans are seeking changes to President Barack Obama's healthcare law, known as Obamacare, as a condition for backing a measure to fund government agencies. The Democratic-led Senate and President Obama have rejected this demand.

Boehner reiterated that there are not enough votes in the House to pass a "clean" continuing resolution on the budget to re-open the government. When asked about a group of Democrats and Republicans who have expressed willingness to pass a six-week "clean CR" without defunding Obamacare, Boehner responded, "There may be a back room somewhere, but there's nobody in it."

Boehner emphasized that his party has tried to compromise by passing several bills that would fund parts of the government while talks continue. However, Democrats have rejected all but a bill to fund military pay because they view the effort as a ploy to simply fund every part of government individually except the Affordable Care Act.

Boehner repeated the recent GOP line that a simple conversation with President Barack Obama is needed to resolve the impasse. He used the word "conversation" a total of 22 times in the interview, stating that President Obama knows his phone number and can call him any time.

Host George Stephanopoulos played past quotes from Boehner in which he has said Obamacare is the law of the land and that defunding Obamacare should not be tied to the budget. Boehner acknowledged making a promise to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to pass a clean CR that included $70 billion less than what the Senate wanted.

The article concludes with a call to action, urging readers to vote on whether they support Sen. Ted Cruz's efforts to defund Obamacare.

Title: Critics Question Limited Scope of U.S. Airstrikes Against Islamic State and Khorasan Group

Article:

Critics are questioning the effectiveness of the U.S.-led airstrikes against the Islamic State and the Khorasan Group, with some suggesting that the limited scope of the air campaign is hindering the effort to combat these terrorist organizations.

Photos from a U.S.-led airstrike in Syria on Monday showed that the Islamic State's finance center's rooftop communications array was destroyed, but the building itself remained intact. This limited effectiveness is further diminished by the Iraqi security forces' mixed results in combat and their inability to reverse most gains made by the Islamic State, also known as ISIL and ISIS.

Iraqi troops also lack a key skill in the badly needed mission: finding and designating ground targets for U.S. warplanes, making the American air campaign more difficult. Bart Bechtel, a retired CIA operative, expressed frustration over the limited damage caused by the airstrikes, stating, "I was mad as hell when I saw the hit on a supposed ISIL building. The right question is: Why not the whole building?"

A retired Air Force general who has remained in touch with the jet fighter community echoed these sentiments, stating that the U.S. air war is too narrow, with not enough planes, heavy ordnance, or sorties. Before the first assaults in Syria on Monday night, U.S. Central Command had conducted 190 airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq since Aug. 8, averaging less than four per day.

At a Pentagon briefing on Tuesday, Army Lt. Gen. William Mayville, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, explained that the missile attack took out the communication suite atop an Islamic State finance center in Raqqa, Syria, the terrorist group's headquarters. However, the surrounding structure remained largely untouched.

Early Wednesday, U.S. Central Command announced that it had reduced the tempo of the airstrikes, conducting a few hits in Iraq and one in Syria. Later in the day, U.S. fighter jets and aircraft belonging to two Arab partner nations began dropping missiles on Islamic State-controlled oil refineries in eastern Syria.

The targets chosen by Central Command have not been so much to degrade the Islamic State inside Iraq as they have been to stop it from moving in one direction or another, or to break its hold on particular locations such as dams or small towns. The air war continues without American combat troops on the ground to uproot Islamic State positions. Iraqis have shown little ability to carry out such missions or to spot targets for U.S. warplanes.

Army Gen. Lloyd Austin, Central Command chief, wanted to put U.S. spotters on the ground, but Army Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, Joint Chiefs chairman, convinced him that other tactics could be used. President Obama has decreed "no boots on the ground."

Under the current setup, joint command centers radio the positions of the enemy to Iraqis and U.S. pilots based on video feeds from unmanned aircraft and other intelligence assets. A retired military officer who visits Baghdad routinely and works with Iraqi defense officials stated, "That is a recipe for disaster once we get into close-in combat."

The former officer explained the mission gap. Ground spotters need a critical piece of equipment: a multiband radio that connects them to other combatants and to pilots overhead. Conventional forces also have no specialized units set up to spot targets. That capability resides with Iraqi special operations forces, but they have limited experience, the former officer said.

This role is not as important while U.S. pilots target Islamic State fighters in relatively open terrain, but it becomes crucial if the reorganized Iraqi units begin to fight in close combat in congested areas where pilots need exact locations. Retired Army Maj. Gen. Robert Scales stated, "I'd like to see more of everything, a real air campaign with sorties delivered against the ISIS leadership."

Without more intensive strikes, he said, "Over time the enemy learns to obviate the killing effects and becomes used to seeing planes orbiting overhead." The Pentagon said the air campaign could go on for years.

Title: U.S. President Trump Considering National Regulation of Domestic Flights Amid Coronavirus Outbreak

Article:

President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday that his administration is exploring the possibility of ordering airlines to reduce domestic flights as a measure to curb the spread of the coronavirus. However, Trump stated that he is not yet ready to issue a national stay-at-home order, suggesting it is not necessary in some states.

Some governors have taken independent action in the travel sector. For instance, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has mandated self-isolation for 14 days for anyone flying to Florida from New York, New Jersey, or Connecticut, states that are among those most affected by the coronavirus. Alaska and Hawaii have also implemented self-quarantine requirements for travelers arriving from other states.

Trump's comments suggest that he is contemplating regulating flights from a national level, expressing concern about flights moving from coronavirus hotspots to other affected cities. He acknowledged the potential hardship such measures would impose on the airlines.

Airlines, industry officials, and health experts argue that flights are an essential service, necessary for both people and cargo, and should continue during the crisis. The federal government reinforced this view with a key provision in the $2 trillion coronavirus aid package passed last week: airlines that accept a share of the $50 billion set aside for the industry must maintain a minimum level of service through at least September.

When asked on Monday about continued air travel from coronavirus hotspots, Trump stated, "We are going to be – hopefully before we close things – we’re going to start to open things." He added, "Airports, when you close them and reopen them, it’s a tremendous deal. It’s a tremendous deal. In addition, you need them for emergencies, you have emergency flights."

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) would be the agency to order any shutdown or restrictions, similar to the grounding of the Boeing 737 Max following two fatal crashes in less than five months last year. The FAA declined to comment on potential nationwide flight groundings when asked about the possibility.

Airlines have significantly reduced their flight schedules in response to the decrease in passenger volume between cities. Trump has also imposed a ban on foreign nationals visiting the U.S. from China and most of Europe, including France, Germany, Italy, and the United Kingdom. He has also imposed restrictions on non-essential travel from Mexico and Canada.

Trump emphasized that a national stay-at-home order is not necessary because "you need to give a little bit of flexibility" in states or regions where the coronavirus has not been as prevalent. He cited the Midwest and Alaska as examples.

Title: HealthCare.gov Concerns Mount as Obama Administration Anticipates Public Reaction to Insurance Plan Prices and Limited Choices

Article:

The Obama administration is reportedly expressing concern over potential negative publicity regarding the pricing and availability of health insurance plans on the HealthCare.gov website. According to War Room Notes obtained by CNN, project managers are apprehensive about the media attention that may arise as individuals select plans on an improved Obamacare site. The notes suggest that the media attention could focus on individual plan selections and choices, with some cases having fewer options than desired to promote consumer choice and a satisfactory shopping experience. Additionally, in some cases, there will be relatively high-cost plans, the notes indicate.

CNN's report appears to reference an October 24 discussion regarding the Obama administration's signature healthcare law failing to lower prices for people in rural areas. The Times reported that rural areas have fewer insurance companies offering plans in the new online insurance exchanges, with more than 500 counties having only one insurer participating.

The War Room notes also mention "problem plans" and a site issue that prevents certification, possibly due to a misspelling on the website, according to CNN.

The high cost of coverage under the new law is already a concern, with an average state seeing Obamacare increase underlying premiums by 41 percent, according to a Manhattan Institute analysis released Monday, as reported by Forbes. Before the law's online healthcare markets launched on October 1, the administration estimated nearly 500,000 people would enroll for subsidized private insurance within the first month. Despite high consumer interest, a computer system plagued by issues has prevented most from doing so.

Recently, at least 3.5 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their private carriers because their coverage does not meet the standards set by the new Affordable Care Act. The exact number is unclear, as an Associated Press survey noted data from half the states is still unavailable.

The administration refuses to release official Obamacare insurance plan enrollment numbers until mid-November, when a crash effort of computer fixes may be showing results. However, numbers are expected to be disappointingly low. Americans remain divided over the new healthcare law, with negative views outweighing positives. Yet, they also lean against repealing it.

Title: Romney Raises $4.2 Million in 24 Hours Following Obama Tax Ruling

Article:

Following the Supreme Court's ruling on the Obama Tax case yesterday, Mitt Romney's campaign has reportedly raised $4.2 million in the subsequent 24 hours. In response to the ruling, Romney stated that he would repeal the entire bill on his first day in office if elected president.

The influx of funds comes just days after President Obama sent an email with the subject line, "I will be outspent." The president expressed that he could potentially become the first president in modern history to be outspent in his re-election campaign if the current trend continues.

In the email, Obama did not only refer to super PACs and anonymous outside groups but also mentioned the Romney campaign itself. He stated that the Romney campaign raises more funds than the Obama campaign, and the disparity is not hard to understand. According to the Obama campaign, they raised almost three-quarters of their funds from donors giving less than $1,000, while Mitt Romney's campaign raised more than three-quarters of its funds from individuals giving $1,000 or more.

Furthermore, the Obama campaign noted that the massive outside spending by super PACs and front groups, estimated to be up to an additional billion dollars, is not included in these figures. These outside groups are reportedly spending heavily on ads criticizing Obama, his campaign, and his beliefs.

In the email, Obama emphasized that they can be outspent and still win, but they cannot be outspent 10 to 1 and still win. He also thanked the more than 2.2 million Americans who have already donated to his campaign and encouraged more contributions.

The email also mentioned a fundraising deadline this week and offered a chance for donors to join Michelle and Obama for one of the last grassroots dinners of the campaign. These dinners, according to the email, represent a different approach, as Obama spent the past weekend at a secretive retreat for the biggest donors to both his campaign and the super PACs supporting him.

Title: Obama's Farewell Address and Post-Presidency Plans

Article:

In his farewell address to the nation on Tuesday, President Barack Obama called for continued action, addressing issues such as inequality, racial divisions, and the decline of fact-based consensus and faith in public institutions. Obama's post-presidency promises to be active, with a focus on organizing, redistricting, and supporting Democratic candidates.

In his address, Obama urged citizens to take action, stating, "If something needs fixing, then lace up your shoes and do some organizing." He also referenced his commitment to Organizing for America, an outside group that sprang from his presidential campaigns and will now be retooled to train activists and recruit Democratic candidates.

Obama also mentioned his involvement in the reshaping of congressional districts after the 2020 census. He will work on redistricting with former Attorney General Eric Holder, who chairs the National Democratic Redistricting Committee. The committee aims to invest in races for governor, state legislature, and other down-ballot offices.

Unspoken in Obama's remarks is the decline of the Democratic Party during his tenure. The party has lost control of both houses of Congress, numerous governorships, and now the presidency. Democrats control the governor's chair and both legislative chambers in only six states.

Like most ex-presidents in the modern era, Obama will write a memoir and focus on his initiative aimed at helping young men of color avoid the school-to-prison pipeline, known as My Brother's Keeper. He will also work on his Chicago-based presidential library and foundation.

Obama will be based in Washington for the next two and a half years, while his younger daughter finishes high school, making him the first president since Woodrow Wilson to remain in the capital after leaving office. Obama's close proximity to his successor, President-elect Donald Trump, may lead to involvement as an informal Democratic adviser.

Political scientist Andra Gillespie of Emory University in Atlanta suggests that Obama may maintain a behind-the-scenes role in helping craft Democratic strategy. However, Obama framed his exhortations on civic engagement in a broad, nonpartisan way, calling for national unity and a restoration of the sense of common purpose.

Title: Obama's Economic Performance During Presidency: A Look at the Numbers

Article:

The strong economic growth in the second quarter of 2014 has sparked discussions about President Obama's lack of credit for the economic recovery. However, the public's perception of a robust economy under the Obama administration is not universally shared.

Evidence of a sustained economic recovery is still scarce. While the economy grew 4.6 percent in the past quarter, a single quarter of strong growth does not equate to a healthy economy. Only one other quarter during Obama's presidency has matched this growth rate. The economy's performance in 2014's first quarter was qualitatively as bad as the second quarter was good, marking the economy's worst performance since 2009's first quarter and the economy's worst quarter since 1990.

The Obama administration's economic performance has been characterized by periods of subpar growth. In 10 of its 22 quarters, the economy's growth has been below 2 percent. Excluding the 2009 negative 2.8 percent real GDP downturn, Mr. Obama's 2010-13 average annual GDP growth was just slightly above 2.1 percent. Including 2009's figure, the president's five-year average falls to below 1.2 percent annual GDP growth. If the Congressional Budget Office's 1.5 percent estimate for 2014 economic growth holds true, Mr. Obama's six-year economic growth average will be a paltry 1.2 percent.

Unemployment rates during Obama's presidency have also been high. Last month's 5.9 percent unemployment rate was the lowest of his presidency, and it was the first time it was below 6.1 percent since he came into office. In contrast, for 30 consecutive months of his presidency, the U.S. unemployment rate was 9 percent or higher. The average annual unemployment rate for Mr. Obama's first five years in office was 6.9 percent, a rate not seen since 1993.

The economy has not lacked substantial assistance. The Federal Reserve's unprecedented monetary-policy accommodation has kept interest rates at roughly zero percent for almost the entirety of Mr. Obama's time in office. Additionally, an equally "stimulative" fiscal policy has been implemented, with federal debt held by the public more than doubling—growing 106 percent—from 2008 through 2013. In comparison, during the same period, America's economy has grown just 12.6 percent overall.

Supporters argue that Mr. Obama faced a recession when he came into office and that, relative to the blow, the economy has at least endured. However, the stronger the recession, the stronger the recovery should be, and such has not been the case.

The president's economic problems, however, run deeper than just economics. They also delve into politics for two important reasons. First, the president is now firmly associated with the subpar economy of the past five years. Given that America has suffered a prolonged and painful economic performance for more than six years, it is natural to associate Mr. Obama with it. It is a test of most people's memory—if not credulity itself—to try attaching today's economy to George W. Bush, who is out of office for almost six years.

Second, America is not accustomed to persistent failure. Americans expect excellence, particularly in the economy. The United States is often seen as the land of opportunity, and its vibrant economy has been a significant draw for immigrants seeking a better life. Given his record, what is truly surprising is not that the president does not get credit for a good economy, but that he does not get more blame for the economy being so poor. If anything, Mr. Obama should be counting his blessings for the little respect he has earned for his economy's dismal performance.

J.T. Young served in the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget from 2001 to 2004 and as a congressional staff member from 1987 to 2000.

Title: Obama's Second Term and the Challenges of Presidential Leadership

Article:

The suggestion that former President Barack Obama, who successfully pushed for higher taxes on the wealthy following his re-election, has been too passive in his leadership is disputed by his advisors. David Plouffe, a key advisor to Obama, dismissed this notion as "not a very sophisticated analysis."

Second terms have historically presented challenges for U.S. presidents, with examples such as the Iran-contra affair for Ronald Reagan and the impeachment of Bill Clinton. President George W. Bush also faced difficulties in his fifth year, with his attempt to revamp Social Security stalling, and the escalating violence in Iraq making it difficult to regain traction.

However, presidents have also made significant breakthroughs during their second term despite Congressional investigations. Reagan signed a nuclear-arms treaty with the Soviet Union, Clinton balanced the budget, and Bush defied opposition to implement a troop surge in Iraq, contributing to a turnaround there.

For President Obama, the recent announcement by the Congressional Budget Office of a sharp drop in the projected deficit serves as a reminder that a healthier economy at the end of his term could have a more significant impact on his legacy than this week's setbacks.

However, the ongoing furors could reinforce an impression of an Obama presidency that has expanded the role of government more than many Americans prefer. These controversies can also undermine a crucial aspect of the presidency, the ability to focus public attention.

As a senator, Obama recognized that a president could influence only 15 to 20 percent of the public agenda, with the rest requiring a reaction. According to his aides, Obama maintains his famed equanimity and, free from campaign pressures, takes a longer view.

Dan Pfeiffer, a White House senior adviser, stated, "Being in office for nearly four and a half years gives the president some perspective — it helps separate the signal from the noise. When you have dealt with real life-and-death problems, the political ones seem much smaller and affect you less."

Title: Parents of Slain Border Agent Criticize Attorney General Holder Over Fast and Furious Operation

Article:

The parents of slain U.S. Border Patrol agent Brian Terry have accused Attorney General Eric Holder and other Justice Department officials of withholding information regarding the botched anti-gunrunning operation Fast and Furious. In an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity on Thursday, Kent and Josephine Terry expressed their belief that the Obama administration is concealing details about their son's death.

Fast and Furious, an operation aimed at tracking illicit guns to larger traffickers, allowed guns to be "walked" and subsequently lost in Mexico. Two of these guns were later found at the crime scene where Terry was killed in December 2010, north of the U.S.-Mexico border.

On Wednesday, a House panel voted along party lines to recommend holding Holder in contempt of Congress for not releasing a vast collection of documents related to Fast and Furious. The House is considering a full vote on the matter. President Obama has invoked executive privilege to keep many of the documents from public view.

Holder has not been formally charged with contempt of Congress. The full House would need to approve a resolution for this to occur, according to Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.). Issa suggested that the vote could be avoided if the attorney general provides more emails and memos about the Fast and Furious sting.

Holder has testified that he became aware of Fast and Furious after Terry's death, and he has condemned the operation's tactics. However, GOP lawmakers have suggested that top Justice Department officials knew more about the operation than they have disclosed.

The Terry family expressed their frustration that the Obama administration may be obstructing their pursuit of the truth about their son's death. "They're lying... They're passing the buck," Kent Terry told Hannity. "I just know that they're hiding something big. Something happened out there."

On Wednesday, the Terry family released a statement expressing their disappointment with the Obama administration's actions. "Attorney General Eric Holder's refusal to fully disclose the documents associated with Operation Fast and Furious and President Obama's assertion of executive privilege serves to compound this tragedy. It denies the Terry family and the American people the truth," they said.

The controversy surrounding the Fast and Furious documents has raised questions and challenges about the power of the presidency, as President Obama's decision to assert executive privilege over the documents not only failed to delay contempt proceedings against Attorney General Eric Holder but also sparked constitutional debates.

The immediate question was whether the documents contained information so damaging that the president was willing to risk negative publicity by withholding them. GOP lawmakers also questioned the legitimacy of Obama's assertion, with the committee voting that it was not appropriate in this case. Republicans repeatedly suggested that the White House had acknowledged being involved in Fast and Furious discussions by asserting privilege over the documents in question.

The Department of Justice has defended its response, with Holder stating that Issa, the committee chairman who has led the charge for answers about Fast and Furious, rejected an "extraordinary offer." Wednesday's developments follow a flurry of activity on Tuesday, as Holder attempted to negotiate a way to avoid contempt proceedings. Issa had earlier indicated a willingness to postpone the vote after Holder indicated a willingness to make compromises and supply some documents in response to House Republicans' subpoena.

Title: Trump Proposes 5% Domestic Spending Cuts in 2020 Budget, Maintains Border Wall Funding

Article:

White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow announced on Sunday that President Trump has proposed a 5% across-the-board cut on all domestic spending as part of his 2020 budget. Kudlow stated during an appearance on "Fox News Sunday" that the budget will be "tough" and that it's "long overdue."

The proposed budget, according to Kudlow, will contain a 5% reduction in domestic spending, similar to previous spending blueprints. The budget will reportedly propose cuts to many domestic programs favored by lawmakers in both parties, but it will leave alone politically popular retirement programs such as Medicare and Social Security.

The U.S. budget deficit is expected to reach $897 billion, according to a government report. Kudlow, however, said there's no reason to "obsess" about the budget deficit as long as it remains below 5% of the overall economy.

Trump's 2020 budget, like his 2017 tax cut, has been criticized for contributing to the growing deficit. The tax cut, along with sharp increases in spending for both the Pentagon and domestic agencies and the growing federal retirement costs of the baby boom generation, have been cited as factors behind the deficit.

The proposed budget will not address the main factors behind the growing, intractable deficits that have driven the U.S. debt above $22 trillion. Its most striking proposed cuts – to domestic agency operations – were rejected when Tea Party Republicans controlled the House, and they face equally grim prospects now that Democrats are in the majority.

Trump has given no indication he's interested in the deficit and has rejected any idea of curbing Medicare or Social Security, the massive federal retirement programs whose imbalances are the chief deficit drivers.

One area that won't see a cut in the proposed budget is for funding for the president's border wall. The Washington Post reported on Sunday that Trump will request at least $8.6 billion in new funding to build additional sections of a wall along the Mexico border. Trump also wants $5 billion in additional funds for the Department of Homeland Security and another $3.6 billion in military construction funds.

All this would come in addition to the $6.5 billion Trump vowed last month to redirect for the construction of the wall. Kudlow stated that the issue of the wall and border security is of "paramount importance" and that Trump has made a "crisis" case effectively. He cited economic, crime, and drug concerns, as well as humanitarian issues, as reasons for the need for a border wall.

Title: Graham Urges Direct Confrontation Between Trump and Putin, Praises Supreme Court Nominees

Article:

Republican Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has called for President Donald Trump to directly challenge Russian President Vladimir Putin over alleged meddling in the 2016 U.S. elections during their upcoming meeting in Helsinki. In an interview with Fox News Sunday, Graham stated, "When Putin denies that he was involved in our election in 2016, reject the denial—challenge him. Don't let him deny the obvious. They're still trying to disrupt the 2018 election cycle."

Graham also addressed the ongoing issues with Russian influence in Turkey, referring to the country as "an ally adrift." However, he noted that Turkey represents a "new chapter" following the re-election of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan amid sweeping government purges.

In other international matters, Graham attributed North Korea's criticisms of U.S. rhetoric to Chinese influence. "I see China's hands all over this," Graham said. "We're in a fight with China... If I were President Trump, I would not let China use North Korea to back me off of the trade dispute. We've got more bullets than they do in terms of trade."

Turning to domestic affairs, Graham expressed confidence in the four Supreme Court nominees reportedly under consideration by President Trump. "Republicans are holding four lottery tickets, and they're all winners," Graham said, who serves on the Senate Judiciary Committee. The four nominees are believed to be federal judges Thomas Hardiman, Brett Kavanaugh, Raymond Kethledge, and Amy Coney Barrett.

Graham particularly praised Thomas Hardiman, a judge on the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, likening him favorably to Associate Justice Samuel Alito in both personality and legal bent. However, Graham criticized the partisanship in the Senate, stating, "There's nobody that President Trump could nominate from a conservative bent that will get many Democratic votes."

Graham predicted that the nomination process would be a "nightmare for red-state Democrats," who risk alienating their constituency if they oppose Trump's pick. The increasingly partisan nature of Supreme Court confirmation hearings has led some analysts to urge Trump to try to defuse the tension. Fox News political analyst Juan Williams suggested that the potential appointment of a conservative justice could be perceived as the court becoming a "rubber stamp for a conservative social agenda."

Trump is expected to announce his pick to replace retiring Associate Justice Anthony Kennedy in a primetime address at 9 p.m. ET.

Title: Colorado Voters Able to Change Presidential Primary Ballots Before Tuesday Deadline, Lawmakers Discuss Future Changes

Article:

Colorado voters who have already cast their ballots for presidential candidates who have since dropped out of the race cannot change their votes this year, but lawmakers are discussing potential changes to the law for future presidential primaries.

Elections officials have encouraged early voting for the state's first presidential primary in 20 years, leading to some voters selecting candidates who are no longer in the race, such as Pete Buttigieg. Secretary of State Jena Griswold noted on Sunday that Colorado voters who have filled out but not returned their ballots can still obtain new ballots or cross out their previous selection and pick a new candidate by 7 p.m. on Tuesday.

If a voter has marked a ballot but has not returned it, they can change their selection by crossing out their first pick and then marking the oval next to their preferred candidate. Alternatively, they can obtain a replacement ballot in-person at a Voter Service and Polling Center (VSPC). More information can be found at https://t.co/OQ2SXOeniQ.

House Majority Leader Alec Garnett told reporters on Monday morning that there should be a discussion about a possible statutory change to allow voters in the future to cast their votes through Election Day, even if their initial choice has dropped out.

"Every voter should have the opportunity, even if their vote was cast for an election and their candidate dropped out, to go to the county clerk and have the opportunity to pull a provisional ballot and vote for who remains in the race," Garnett said.

Garnett added that this issue was not discussed during the legislative process, and it is something that lawmakers should discuss with both sides of the aisle.

Boulder County Clerk Molly Fitzpatrick tweeted on Monday that voters who still have their ballots can change a vote by following the voter instructions on how to correct a mistake (do not sign the ballot, only the envelope). If a voter has already voted, they cannot receive a replacement ballot.

Only three other states hold all mail-ballot statewide elections, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, making the issue of voting early for a candidate that may drop out early fairly unique.

Garnett has not spoken to lawmakers about specific solutions, but after the results came in from South Carolina's caucus and former mayor Buttigieg's announcement on Sunday, he has heard from constituents asking what they can do.

"I think it was a little frustrating on my end to say, 'There's nothing you can do,'" he said.

Senate Majority Leader Steve Fenberg has also heard from people who are frustrated by being unable to change their votes, and he thinks this is an issue lawmakers can tackle this year for future elections, though he doesn't yet know what the exact solution should be.

"It could be logistically difficult, but I think it's worth looking into," Fenberg said.

The problem is exacerbated by the fact that the primary election for presidential candidates is how the state parties select delegates, and some of the candidates who dropped out, such as Buttigieg, could still receive delegates because they had a significant amount of support.

Title: Michael Cohen Admits to Hiring IT Firm to Manipulate Polls for Donald Trump in 2015

Article:

Michael Cohen, former personal lawyer to President Donald Trump, admitted on Twitter Thursday to hiring an IT firm, RedFinch Solutions LLC, to manipulate polls in favor of Trump during his 2015 presidential campaign. The Wall Street Journal reported the revelation on Thursday.

John Gauger, owner of RedFinch Solutions, told the Wall Street Journal that in 2015, he was promised $50,000 by Cohen for attempting to influence polls in Trump's favor. However, he received approximately $12,000 to $13,000 in cash and a boxing glove in a blue Walmart bag.

Cohen denied to the Wall Street Journal that he paid in cash, stating that the money was given by check. According to the report, Mr. Gauger was asked in 2014 to manipulate the results of a CNBC poll for the top U.S. business leaders, but he was unsuccessful in getting Trump into the top 100. The next year, he was asked to influence a Drudge Report ranking of potential Republican primary picks, where Trump came in fifth.

Mr. Gauger told the newspaper that he performed other services for Cohen, unrelated to the president, and said Cohen paid for some. One project was to create the "@ WomenForCohen" account on Twitter, which still exists and describes Cohen as a "strong, pit bull, sex symbol, no nonsense, business-oriented, and ready to make a difference!"

In 2017, Cohen requested a $50,000 reimbursement for "tech services" from the Trump Tower Organization, according to federal prosecutors in an August 2018 charging document. Cohen was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to campaign finance violations, bank fraud, and lying to Congress. None of the charges are connected to his dealings with RedFinch.

The Trump Organization did not provide a comment to the Wall Street Journal, but Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of Mr. Trump's lawyers, told the newspaper that Cohen is untrustworthy. "If one thing has been established, it's that Michael Cohen is completely untrustworthy," the former New York City mayor said.

Title: Pelosi Contemplates Delaying Transmission of Impeachment Articles to Senate

Article:

In recent days, some legal scholars have suggested that Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi could delay transmitting the articles of impeachment to the Senate, where Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has declared he is coordinating trial strategy with the White House. This proposal, initially perceived as having little currency on Capitol Hill, has gained momentum as McConnell has continued to express his disinterest in serving as an impartial overseer of the Senate trial.

During a news conference, Pelosi's remarks, barely audible above the clatter of camera shutters, were unexpected and prompted reporters to interrupt her, generating confusion about the next steps in the impeachment process. When asked if she would not transmit the articles, Pelosi responded, "You’re asking me, ‘So are we all going to go out and play in the snow?’ That has not been part of our conversations."

Following the news conference, Pelosi huddled with top committee chairs leading Trump-focused investigations, and they emerged with a consistent message: The only story that matters is the president has been impeached. Financial Services Chairwoman Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) stated, "The only thing that matters is the president of the United States was impeached today." As for the Senate, she said, "One step at a time."

Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y.) added, "We defended the Constitution and we defended our democracy." He further stated, "Right now, that’s the story."

Some Democrats have suggested a delay in transmitting articles is under consideration due to the House leaders' decision to not name impeachment managers—the set of lawmakers who would argue their case on the Senate floor—until an undetermined later date. When President Bill Clinton was impeached in 1998, House leaders identified their impeachment managers the same day. However, Pelosi will be empowered to pick managers at her discretion and without a deadline.

Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) has approached every member of House leadership about the idea and received responses ranging from interest to outright support. Blumenauer stated that Pelosi, in particular, "indicated she was interested and considering it." He argued that the House could use the delay to continue building on its evidence for impeachment and potentially to secure additional legal victories that could unlock troves of new evidence and witness testimony the Trump administration has withheld from Congress. Some of these court cases could be decided within weeks.

In his remarks to reporters, House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer emphasized that early discussions about the timing of transmitting articles of impeachment to the Senate are "not in the context" of the proposal by constitutional lawyer Laurence Tribe. However, he acknowledged that colleagues keep raising the issue. "People have read that article, discussed it. People have come up to me, discussed it," he said, adding, "We will talk about it in some point in time. It’s within the speaker’s purview, obviously, she’ll make that decision. And I also think she’ll do it in discussions with McConnell and [Senate Minority Leader Chuck] Schumer."

Title: Democrats Test Obamacare as Election Issue in New Hampshire

Article:

Barack Obama and his Democratic allies in the U.S. Congress have grown more confident in recent months about their ability to use the president's signature healthcare law, the Affordable Care Act (ACA), as a draw rather than a liability in this November's midterm elections. Three races in New Hampshire illustrate the challenge, offering a test of whether Democrats can overcome voter skepticism about the ACA.

The ACA, aiming to expand health insurance coverage to millions more Americans, has come under sustained attack from Republicans. The president has urged Democrats campaigning in the Nov. 4 congressional elections not to run away from "Obamacare," but instead to "forcefully defend" it. Obama has said that a surge in enrollment shows the system is running smoothly now, after its disastrous debut last October.

New Hampshire, which is closely divided between Democrats and Republicans, is one of about 10 states where Republicans hope to make gains in order to pick up six seats they need to put the Democratic-led Senate under their control. Senators Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, Kay Hagan of North Carolina, and Mary Landrieu of Louisiana have been among the Democratic targets of anti-Obamacare ads by conservative groups such as Americans for Prosperity.

Republicans are counting on voter antipathy toward Obamacare to try to take charge of the Senate and expand their majority in the House of Representatives. However, Obamacare may now be working better, but national polls clearly show more people disapprove than approve of the law.

In New Hampshire, Shaheen and Representative Carol Shea-Porter, a fellow Democrat, were among the earliest advocates of the healthcare law. The state's other Democratic Representative, Ann Kuster, was elected after the law passed, but also backs it. Shaheen said in an interview she shared Obama's view that as Americans get to know Obamacare, they are embracing it. Shaheen said there was "a lot of misinformation" about the law. "The reality is it's beginning to work for people," she said.

However, a recent WMUR-Granite State poll reported that 51 percent of New Hampshire adults oppose Obamacare while just 37 percent support it. Sixty-one percent of the state's voters think medical costs will increase under the act. "The perception is, 'it will hurt my family and costs will go up,'" said Andrew Smith, director of the University of New Hampshire Survey Center. "In a political campaign, that is a big boulder to push uphill."

Skeptics include people like Derek Gagnon, a 33-year-old auto mechanic who says he would not even consider voting for anyone who had backed the ACA. He has no health insurance, but he also says he has no intention of signing up for the private insurance offered through the government-run website, HealthCare.gov. "I shouldn't be forced to do something like that in a free country," said Gagnon, referring to the law's requirement, known as the "individual mandate," that almost all legal U.S. residents buy health insurance or pay a fine.

"I'll pay the fine this year and next year," Gagnon said at a frozen yogurt store outside New Hampshire's state capital, Concord. "Maybe I won't have to pay it the third year, because by then Obama will be out of office."

Gagnon's distaste for the individual mandate dovetails with a principal line of conservative attacks nationally on the law. Obamacare is meant to extend subsidized health coverage to millions of uninsured Americans through new online private insurance markets and an expansion of the Medicaid program for the poor. However, conservative critics portray it as a government intrusion in a major sector of the economy that will hurt job growth and erode freedoms.

Shaheen's leading Republican opponent in the Senate race, Scott Brown, is betting that theme will resonate in New Hampshire, where the state's famous motto is "Live Free or Die." In April, Brown kicked off his candidacy with the declaration that New Hampshire could "Live Free or Log On" - a caustic reference to signing up online for Obamacare. Lately, he has been traveling the state on an "Obamacare Is Not Working" tour. Brown, a former senator from neighboring Massachusetts, says the act should be completely repealed, and the issue of healthcare reform should be left to the states.

Brown has been rising in the polls against Shaheen. However, she was ahead 45 to 39 percent in a recent WMUR-Granite State poll. Dean Spiliotes, a New Hampshire political analyst, said Shaheen, a former New Hampshire governor, still had political capital in the state, and he doubted the healthcare issue alone could defeat her. "People view her as not an ideologue. That has helped her with voters," said Spiliotes, a political science professor at Southern New Hampshire University. "If Obamacare rises to the level of taking out Jeanne Shaheen, there is something larger going on."

To be sure, Obamacare faces unique challenges in New Hampshire. Just one insurance company in the small state offered insurance policies through the program this year, and the insurer does not cover healthcare in 10 of the state's 26 hospitals, deficits Shaheen and Shea-Porter have been working to fix. Spiliotes said New Hampshire Democrats are defending Obamacare "but they are kind of doing it in fits and starts. It's not a uniform, rah-rah kind of support."

In one hopeful sign for Democrats, enrollment in Obamacare in the state of 1.3 million people has reached 40,000 - double the number that had been expected. Shea-Porter, a former social worker who came to Congress in 2006 campaigning on healthcare reform, said she would never run away from Obamacare because she considers the law to be a "great joy and triumph." That said, she understands the political perils for Democrats of Obamacare. She lost her seat in Congress in 2010 elections after her vote for the law, only to be re-elected in 2012. Her 2014 race is considered a toss-up although her Republican opponent has yet to be chosen in a September primary.

Shea-Porter, who met last week with recent healthcare enrollees in Somersworth, said she is aware of the qualms some people have, including wariness of providing personal information on a government website. However, she said the best way to advertise Obamacare's benefits is to publicize the stories of people who signed up and discovered that "nothing terrible happened."

Patrice Glynn, a 54-year-old New Hampshire resident, is already convinced. Glynn, a diabetic, lived without health insurance for nine months after she lost her job and before she signed up on HealthCare.gov. "If it was so bad, would 40,000 people be on it?" she asked.

Title: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman Resigns Amid Allegations of Domestic Abuse

Article:

New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, a prominent critic of President Donald Trump and a champion of the #MeToo movement, has resigned following allegations of physical and emotional abuse by four women. The New Yorker published an article on Monday detailing the women's claims, which include choking, threatening, and demeaning behavior.

Schneiderman, who had built a high-profile reputation during the Trump era for his legal pushback and criticism of some of the President's agenda items, was hailed as an icon of the anti-Trump resistance and a key figure in the #MeToo movement. He had used his authority to take legal action against Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein and was outspoken in the push for a "critical national reckoning" about the harassment of women.

However, the article revealed that Schneiderman had allegedly abused four women, including choking a former girlfriend, controlling what she ate, and leaving her "emotionally battered." He also reportedly demanded that another girlfriend, who was born in Sri Lanka and whom Schneiderman referred to as his "brown slave," call him "Master."

The women came forward for a number of reasons, including the resignation of White House aide Rob Porter over claims he had abused his ex-wives. The women's "anguish and anger grew" as Schneiderman used his office to become a figurehead for the growing #MeToo movement.

"You can not be a champion of women when you are hitting them and choking them in bed, and saying to them, 'You're a f--king whore,'" Michelle Manning Barish, one of the women speaking out, told the New Yorker. "His hypocrisy is epic," she said. "He's fooled so many people."

"This is a man who has staked his entire career, his personal narrative, on being a champion for women publicly. But he abuses them privately," Tanya Selvaratnam told the outlet. "He needs to be called out."

Schneiderman issued a statement denying the allegations, saying, "In the privacy of intimate relationships, I have engaged in role-playing and other consensual sexual activity. I have not assaulted anyone. I have never engaged in nonconsensual sex, which is a line I would not cross."

Within three hours of the article being published, Schneiderman announced that he would step down as attorney general at the end of the day on Tuesday. The accusations brought a wave of condemnation from both the right and the left, with fellow New York Democrat Andrew Cuomo calling the pattern of facts and corroboration "damning" and calling for Schneiderman to resign.

Trump allies, whom Schneiderman had targeted, made little attempt to hide their glee at their foe's sudden downfall. Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway tweeted, "Gotcha," referencing a tweet of Schneiderman's in which he said that "no one is above the law." Donald Trump Jr. dug up past statements Schneiderman had made about the #MeToo movement, snarking, "Self awareness level 0."

In a November interview with Full Frontal's Samantha Bee, Schneiderman laid out his achievements in the Trump era, including beating the President on several issues. Now, Samantha Bee's "Full Frontal" tweeted a screenshot of Schneiderman boasting on Twitter of the superhero mockups the TBS show had made for his November appearance.

Title: Obamacare Repairs: A Loose Thread Unraveling the Healthcare System

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, is currently undergoing numerous proposed repairs, with the aim of allowing millions of Americans whose health insurance plans have been canceled under the Act to keep their plans and their doctors if they wish. However, these repairs could potentially cause more harm to the Obamacare system.

According to an Associated Press survey, over 4.2 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their insurers. This group tends to be healthier than the uninsured, who are most likely to be attracted to Obamacare. If healthier individuals remain outside the Obamacare pool, it could lead to actuarial trouble, similar to removing a piston from an engine and expecting it to run smoothly.

The fear is that the Obamacare exchanges will attract a disproportionate share of higher-cost, sicker people, leading to higher premiums and a potential inability of the insurance system to sustain itself. Cori Uccello, senior health fellow at the American Academy of Actuaries, expressed this concern.

Insurers argue that it's too late to reverse course and implement the change, as some state insurance commissioners believe bringing back canceled policies would violate new state laws that forbid "substandard" plans. California and New York are among the states in this group.

A reversal could add to the confusion and lack of confidence already surrounding Obamacare. A crisis of confidence in the new health-care system could be debilitating, as noted by Larry Kocot, a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution who helped roll out Medicare Part D during the George W. Bush administration.

The repairs are being made due to the backlash from those affected by the cancellations and the low approval rating of President Obama, currently at 39%. The political impact of the cancellations has been described as a "Category 5 political hurricane" by Rep. Greg Walden (R) of Oregon.

Democrats, who "own" Obamacare as much as the president, are facing criticism and tough races in the 2014 midterm elections. In response, nearly 40 House Democrats have peeled from their caucus to support a bill that allows people to return to their old health plans. However, this bill faces opposition from the White House, as it allows new customers to sign on to canceled plans, potentially worsening the outlook for Obamacare's sustainability.

Democratic lawmakers, such as Sen. Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, are working on their own legislation. The future of these repairs and their impact on Obamacare remains uncertain, but the rollout is producing problems beyond a broken website. Fixing them is like pulling on a loose thread, with things starting to unravel.

Title: Google News Shows Strong Preference for Left-Leaning Perspectives, According to AllSides Report

Article:

A new report from media technology group AllSides claims that Google News and Google News search results exhibit a strong preference for media outlets with a left-leaning perspective. The report, published on AllSides' website, analyzed Google News' homepage and search engine results over a two-week period from Aug. 23 to Sept. 5.

According to the report, the overall bias of Google News during this timeframe was approximately 65 percent toward the left, 20 percent toward the center, and 16 percent to the right. This period coincided with President Donald Trump's tweets criticizing Google for allegedly biasing its search results against him.

Trump tweeted on Aug. 28, 2018, "Google search results for ‘Trump News’ shows only the viewing/reporting of Fake News Media... Google & others are suppressing voices of Conservatives and hiding information and news that is good... This is a very serious situation-will be addressed!"

The AllSides report found that not only did Google show a bias for the left, but it also gave left-leaning news greater prominence. On average, left-leaning news was almost always one of the top two results displayed. News from the center of the political spectrum was less visible but usually in the top five or six results, the report said.

Right-leaning news, however, required users to scroll down the computer screen before they saw their first news article from the right. The report also found that when news from the left competed with news from other viewpoints, the left won just about every time.

The report did not suggest that Google intentionally favored media sources from the left, nor did it suggest the opposite. Instead, it demonstrated that the resulting choice of links provided by Google News showed a significant bias in favor of the left. The report attributed this bias to the political views of most news outlets and journalists, as well as the fact that online news consumers are younger and lean farther left than the average American.

Google has previously denied setting a political agenda and stated that its goal is to provide the most relevant answers to users' queries in a matter of seconds. The company has not yet responded to the AllSides report.

Title: Indonesia Raises Minimum Marriage Age for Girls to 19, Aims to End Child Marriage

Article:

Indonesia, the eighth-highest country in terms of child brides globally, has taken a significant step towards ending child marriage by raising the minimum age at which girls can marry from 16 to 19. This change was prompted by a ruling from the Constitutional Court in December, which deemed it discriminatory to mandate a lower minimum age of marriage for girls than for boys.

While this development is positive, it is important to note that Indonesia is not the worst offender in this regard. According to UNICEF, 14% of Indonesian women marry before they reach 18 years old. In comparison, 59% of women in Bangladesh and 76% in Niger marry before their eighteenth birthday. Nineteen of the 20 countries where child marriage is most prevalent are in Africa, as shown in the map provided.

Families often marry off their daughters at a young age in an attempt to secure their lives and provide stability. Factors associated with this practice include rigid gender norms, conflict, and poverty. Education is a crucial factor in this context. A study by the World Bank involving 15 countries found that girls without secondary education are three times more likely to be married by age 18 than those with secondary education. In many cultures, education for girls takes a backseat to marriage and its associated duties.

Cutting a childhood short can have severe consequences. Girls who marry have an increased risk of sexual violence, poorer health, and higher school drop-out rates. They are also less likely to participate in the labor force, which has significant economic costs. A paper published in 2015 found that child marriage cost Indonesia's economy 1.7% of its GDP in 2014. The global welfare benefit of ending the practice is estimated to be around $22 billion.

Indonesia's new policy is a significant step towards ending child marriage. However, in the context of controversial new revisions to the country's criminal code, which would criminalize extra-marital sex and endorse chauvinistic local by-laws, lawmakers will have to demonstrate that the new marriage age for girls is more than a token gesture towards gender equality. Indonesia's parliament could resolve to tackle the social and economic forces that make child marriage so common. Ensuring that girls complete their 12 years of compulsory schooling would be a start. Reducing unintended pregnancies by improving access to contraception and sexual-health education would also help. Giving girls more control over their bodies would allow them to exercise more sway over their future, including who they marry. That is worth saying yes to.

Title: U.S. Marshals Prepared to Guard National Monuments Amid Ongoing George Floyd Protests

Article:

The Trump administration has directed the U.S. Marshals Service to be on standby and ready to protect national monuments across the United States from potential destruction. In an email, Marshals Service Assistant Director Andrew C. Smith stated that the agency has been asked to immediately prepare to provide federal law enforcement support to safeguard national monuments throughout the country. The subject line of the message indicates it is an "Attorney General Assignment," suggesting it originated from Attorney General William P. Barr.

Smith also wrote, "This is a challenging assignment due to the breadth of possible targets for criminal activity." According to CNN, the marshals are being mobilized as part of a "major effort" by the administration to bolster security around national monuments, and they are expected to begin their work before the end of the week.

The Daily Wire reported that unarmed National Guard troops will also be deployed to monuments in and around Washington, D.C., to assist the U.S. Park Police in protecting the monuments in the nation's capital. The security reinforcements were prompted after weeks of statues being toppled nationwide. Initially, rioters primarily targeted Confederate monuments, but in recent days, tributes to the founding fathers and even abolitionists have been destroyed.

President Trump warned on Tuesday that those found damaging federal property such as monuments would be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. He tweeted, "I have authorized the Federal Government to arrest anyone who vandalizes or destroys any monument, statue or other such Federal property in the U.S. with up to 10 years in prison, per the Veteran's Memorial Preservation Act, or such other laws that may be pertinent." He added, "This action is taken effective immediately, but may also be used retroactively for destruction or vandalism already caused. There will be no exceptions!"

The president addressed the issue again on Wednesday night, tweeting:

"Very sad to see States allowing roving gangs of wise guys, anarchists & looters, many of them having no idea what they are doing, indiscriminately ripping down our statues and monuments to the past. Some are great works of art, but all represent our History & Heritage, both the good and the bad. It is important for us to understand and remember, even in turbulent and difficult times, and learn from them. Knowledge comes from the most unusual of places!"

Title: NSA's X-KEYSCORE Program Provides Wide-Ranging Access to Foreign Internet Data

Article:

The latest disclosure from the Snowden files reveals the existence of an NSA program called X-KEYSCORE, which offers access to a vast amount of internet data, primarily foreign signals intelligence. The quantity of communications accessible through X-KEYSCORE is immense, with one document stating that the NSA receives up to 20+ terabytes of data per day, which can only be stored for as little as 24 hours.

X-KEYSCORE appears to provide access to various types of communications, such as phone conversations, emails, chats, and more. An NSA tool called DNI Presenter, used to read the content of stored emails, also enables analysts to read the content of Facebook chats or private messages. Analysts can monitor Facebook chats by entering the Facebook user name and a date range into a simple search screen. They can search for internet browsing activities using a wide range of information, including search terms entered by the user or the websites viewed.

The X-KEYSCORE program also allows an analyst to learn the IP addresses of every person who visits any website the analyst specifies. However, it is unclear whether this includes U.S. persons or only foreign nationals. Under U.S. law, the NSA is required to obtain an individualized FISA warrant if the target of their surveillance is a 'U.S. person,' though no such warrant is required for intercepting the communications of Americans with foreign targets. X-KEYSCORE reportedly provides the technological capability, if not the legal authority, to target even U.S. persons for extensive electronic surveillance without a warrant, provided that some identifying information, such as their email or IP address, is known to the analyst.

The NSA documents assert that by 2008, 300 terrorists had been captured using intelligence from X-KEYSCORE. However, it is unclear whether this surveillance program is a real-time surveillance tool or merely a database search tool. X-KEYSCORE provides access to tremendous volumes of foreign communications, which can then be searched by NSA analysts.

There are known "compliance problems" with NSA's surveillance programs, as communications by U.S. persons end up in this database if the other end of the conversation is overseas—and these communications can therefore end up on an analyst's desktop. The NSA's minimization procedures are supposed to prevent such "inadvertent" targeting of U.S. persons, but there are reportedly plenty of exceptions to this rule.

It is essential to note that this article aims to provide an unbiased, factual, and informative account of the NSA's X-KEYSCORE program based on the provided text. The article does not contain personal opinions, political bias, or subjective language. Any information unavailable in the source text is not included in the article.

Title: Republican Health Care Bill Faces Uncertain Future in House

Article:

The White House and congressional Republicans are facing a potential lack of votes to pass their health care bill, with several Republicans voicing opposition to the current measure to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). As of Monday, CNN's whip count shows 21 Republicans opposed to the bill, with at least 17 lawmakers still undecided. No vote has been scheduled, and it is unclear if there will be one before the House recesses for a week-long break on Friday.

Vice President Mike Pence, who has been working with congressional leaders on the health care effort, is meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to lobby for support. President Donald Trump, who had previously expressed optimism about the bill's passage, has suggested that the measure may still be changed.

The Republican Party can only afford to lose 22 votes, assuming all Republicans attend the vote and no Democrats cross party lines. Notably, Rep. Billy Long, a Republican from Missouri, announced his opposition to the legislation on Monday. Reps. Brian Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania, Daniel Webster of Florida, and Chris Smith of New Jersey have also announced their opposition.

As the Republican congressional leaders work to secure enough votes, some members remain undecided, including Reps. Kevin Yoder, David Valadao, Erik Paulson, Elise Stefanik, and Adam Kinzinger. The hope is that leadership can sell moderates on the fact that the bill will be sent to the Senate, where it may be significantly reworked.

The fight over how pre-existing conditions are covered is at the center of the debate. Trump has stated that the GOP plan "guarantees" coverage for Americans with pre-existing conditions, but under the GOP bill, insurers could charge them higher rates if they allow their coverage to lapse.

Pressure from the White House to deliver a legislative win for Trump is real, and the repeated pledges to their constituents over the past seven years to repeal and replace Obamacare if given the chance are still a factor in the current debate. However, the process has left some moderates frustrated, with some seeing their party making the same mistakes Republicans criticized Democrats for making in 2010.

Title: High School Students Protest Alleged Lack of Action Against Bullying in Oklahoma

Article:

Hundreds of students from Norman High School in Oklahoma walked out of their school on Monday to protest the school's response to alleged bullying of three classmates who claim they were raped by the same person. The students were supported by parents and members of the community outside the school, according to Sophia Babb, a junior at the school who spoke to CNN.

The students' message was clear: "No justice, no class" and "No more bullying." The protest was sparked by allegations from three female students who say they were mercilessly bullied after being raped in separate instances by the same person. The students and their families claim school administrators failed to take adequate action after they reported the rapes and bullying.

The story gained traction on social media after Jezebel published a detailed account on Friday. No arrests or charges have been made yet, Norman Police Department Captain Tom Easley told CNN. An investigation began a month ago, and no details will be released until it concludes. A Norman High School spokesperson had not returned CNN's request for comment by publication time.
