In a letter to the school community, Norman Public Schools Superintendent Joe Siano encouraged parents to discuss alternatives to the walkout, such as wearing stickers and ribbons provided by the school "in symbolic support." He also announced the school was expanding a task force to study the implementation of a "targeted, research-based sexual assault curriculum for students." The school will continue to respond quickly to reports of sexual assault and bullying, according to Siano.

The three teens told Jezebel that they stopped attending classes and left school voluntarily after the teasing became unbearable. Friends of the teens started a Facebook page, YES ALL Daughters, two weeks ago to show support for them. The page drew nearly 10,000 likes in two weeks. With the help of their mothers and relatives, they organized Monday's protest.

"After hearing the story, we felt compelled to help the kids do something," said Stacie Wright, whose niece started the Facebook page.

The group posted a list of "Protest Do's and Don'ts" on its Facebook page to ensure a peaceful event. The list included guidelines such as "Be Peaceful, Law-Abiding Citizens that do not disturb local businesses" and "Do Not Respond to any negativity."

The Daily Oklahoman reported the crowd of protesters on Monday was in the hundreds. However, organizers estimated that 1,500 attended the protest outside the school, which has an enrollment of about 1,800 students.

"It shows that students won't put up with this harassment and bullying," Babb said. "We stand in solidarity with all victims and we want to show that we support them."

Title: Ryan's Speech at the Republican National Convention: Analysis of Content and Delivery

Article:

Republican vice-presidential candidate Paul Ryan delivered a speech at the Republican National Convention in Tampa on Wednesday that received applause from the audience. The speech was critically analyzed for its content, with mixed reviews on its delivery and clarity.

Ryan, in his speech, critically assessed the Obama administration's economic policies, particularly the Obama Economy and Obamacare. He also addressed the common Democratic attacks on Medicare reform, often referred to as "Mediscare." However, the economic growth solutions presented in the speech were reportedly unclear, with some stating that Ryan's use of the term "tax fairness" was surprising, as it is a term frequently used by President Obama and other liberal Democrats.

The speech did not mention specific tax cut proposals, such as the 20% across-the-board supply-side reduction in marginal tax rates or the 25% corporate tax rate reduction, which have been proposed by Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate. Instead, the speech focused on the issue of debt to an extent that some found it disconnected from the concerns of the unemployed or underemployed.

Critics argue that when Republicans focus on debt and deficits, they often lose elections, while running on growth, limited government, lower spending, lower tax rates, and deregulation tends to result in victories. The growth issue, according to some, was not clearly addressed in Ryan's speech, leading to confusion.

The article concludes by stating that the specifics of Mitt Romney's growth policies will likely be clarified during his speech on Thursday night. The author expresses a desire for clearer emphasis on economic growth in the Republican platform.

Title: Narendra Modi: From Humble Beginnings to India's Likely Prime Minister

Article:

Narendra Modi, the current Chief Minister of Gujarat, is poised to become India's next Prime Minister following the conclusion of the country's parliamentary elections on Friday. Modi, who has been praised for the strong economic growth in Gujarat, has been a controversial figure due to religious riots that occurred in 2002 during his tenure as Chief Minister.

Modi, the son of a tea vendor, rose through the ranks of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist organization, and is closely allied with the group. He is married but did not acknowledge his wife's existence until April, when he filed his nomination papers.

Modi has been Chief Minister of Gujarat for 13 years and during his tenure, he made it one of India's best-performing states economically. He is known for his self-discipline, austerity, and decisiveness. According to NPR's Julie McCarthy, Modi is seen by many as a "pro-business go-getter."

Gujarat's economy has nearly tripled in size under Modi's stewardship, and he has a reputation for rooting out corruption, stimulating investment, and slashing through bureaucratic red tape and outdated regulations. Gujarat is one of the few places in India where there is an uninterrupted electricity and water supply, and its roads are the envy of Indians from other states.

However, not everyone has benefited from the state's economic progress. Half of all children younger than 5 suffer from malnutrition, and two-thirds of rural households lack toilets. Additionally, Gujarat's entrepreneurial tradition long predates Modi, but as one businessman told Julie, Modi made the government machinery accountable.

The biggest reservation many Indians have about Modi is the massive anti-Muslim violence that broke out under his watch in 2002. Hundreds of Muslims were killed in violence that followed the burning of a train compartment carrying Hindu pilgrims; 59 of those pilgrims died. Some of Modi's close aides were found guilty of taking part in the violence that ensued.

Modi has never publicly addressed the violence until late last year, when he published a long blog post saying the violence shook him deeply. However, his comments fell short of an apology sought by many victims of the riots. Those riots still make many Muslims and other minorities wary of Modi.

The Indian government's own data show urban Muslims in Gujarat are worse off than Muslims in the rest of the country. However, government figures also show that Gujarat is one of the top states in the country for Muslim employment.

Modi is also criticized as vindictive and abrasive, and he is capable of holding grudges for years and intolerant of dissent. According to Reuters, "Modi displays all the signs of becoming an Indian Putin."

Following the 2002 Gujarat riots, Modi was denied a visa to travel to the U.S. However, it's nearly certain he would be granted one if he becomes prime minister and applies for a visa. Indeed, Modi met with the U.S. envoy to India in February and has also met with European officials. If Modi becomes prime minister of the world's largest democracy, he would not be isolated in the West or the international community.

Title: Hurricane Sandy Affects Presidential Campaign Schedules as East Coast Braces for Storm

Article:

The eastern third of the United States is bracing for the impact of Hurricane Sandy, with a 42 percent chance of experiencing tropical storm-force winds in the coming days. The storm has disrupted the campaign schedules of both President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney.

President Obama has canceled campaign events in Northern Virginia on Monday and in Colorado Springs, Colo., on Tuesday, according to a statement by press secretary Jay Carney late Saturday evening. Obama will continue to receive regular briefings on the storm and expects his team to continue preparations as state and local partners do the same.

Mitt Romney has canceled all events scheduled for Virginia on Sunday and has decided to campaign in Ohio on Monday morning instead.

Hurricane Sandy currently sits off the coast of Florida, with tropical storm watches and warnings in effect in the Carolinas. Federal officials warn that the East Coast from South Carolina on up should prepare for heavy rains and winds, and inland areas could see up to 2 feet or more of snow. Tropical storm conditions off the coast of North Carolina are expected to soon move northward. The National Hurricane Center projects landfall around Delaware and New Jersey sometime late Monday or early Tuesday.

Federal Emergency Management Agency Administrator Craig Fugate emphasized that the storm will affect a large geographic area and not just coastal areas. He warned of potential flooding in the Ohio Valley and Appalachian regions. FEMA and other federal partners are already sending teams and resources into potentially impacted areas to support state and local preparedness efforts.

Vice President Joe Biden is set to appear in Ohio on Tuesday, and additional changes to Obama's schedule may be announced. Obama will leave Washington for Florida on Sunday afternoon before the brunt of the storm hits the D.C. metro area, and he will hold an event in Youngstown, Ohio, before returning to Washington to monitor the storm.

Both White House and campaign officials downplayed the storm's potential effect on turnout in swing states as well as the optics of campaigning during a looming disaster.

Title: US President Trump Cancels Planned Veterans Day Parade in Washington DC Over High Costs

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has announced the cancellation of a planned Veterans Day military parade in Washington D.C. due to the high costs associated with staging the event. The estimated cost of the parade was reported to be around $90 million (£71m), more than three times the original estimate.

In a tweet, Mr. Trump stated that local politicians had requested a "ridiculously high" figure for the parade. He added that he might organize an event in Washington D.C. next year and will instead attend parades in France and at Maryland's Andrews Air Force Base.

The Washington parade was initially scheduled for November 11, the centenary of the end of World War One. Paris will hold its long-planned parade on the same day, while the event at the Maryland air force base is scheduled for a "different date," according to the president.

The budget director had initially estimated costs of between $10 million and $30 million when the White House announced its request in February. However, a U.S. official later provided a new estimate of $92 million.

Initially, the plan was to avoid using tanks to prevent damage to the roads of the nation's capital. The District of Columbia Council, Washington's legislative body, was critical of the plan when it was announced, voicing displeasure on Twitter.

Members of the Democratic party were similarly sceptical, with congressman Jim McGovern declaring it "an absurd waste of money" on Twitter and saying Mr. Trump "acts more like a dictator than a president."

The Pentagon had stated that the military would march from the White House to the Capitol, and the parade would feature a "heavy air component at the end." The focus was set to be the work of U.S. military veterans through the ages, starting with the American revolution.

It is worth noting that Donald Trump cancelled planned military exercises with South Korea in June after his meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, citing the need to "save a fortune." The U.S. had a military parade in 1991 following the end of its successful campaign to force Saddam Hussein's troops out of Kuwait.

Washington Mayor Muriel Bowser responded to the cancellation, emulating the president's Twitter tone. A Pentagon spokesperson, Col Rob Manning, said in a statement that the Department of Defense and the White House "have now agreed to explore opportunities in 2019."

Title: House Passes GOP-Authored Bill to Repeal Unpopular Obamacare Provisions, Faces Uncertain Future in Senate

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives has passed a bill, known as the Restoring Americans' Healthcare Freedom Reconciliation Act, which aims to repeal unpopular provisions of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The bill, which defunds Planned Parenthood for one year, was passed with a vote of 240-189. However, the bill's future in the Senate is uncertain, as vocal conservatives have expressed concerns that the bill does not go far enough in repealing Obamacare.

The bill, if enacted, would repeal Obamacare's insurance mandates on individuals and employers, as well as taxes on medical device sales and the "Cadillac tax" on generous health plans. The bill was passed using the budget reconciliation process, which allows it to bypass a filibuster in the Senate and be passed with a simple majority.

President Obama can still veto the bill, but Republican leaders are hoping to demonstrate their ability to dismantle Obamacare with a simple Senate majority and a GOP president in 2017. Majority Whip Steve Scalise, a Louisiana Republican, stated, "Let's get this bill to the president's desk and let him make a decision. Is he going to finally stand up for American workers and sign this bill? Or is he going to continue to support a law that's destroying jobs and destroying health care in this country?"

Democrats criticized the bill, with Rep. Louise Slaughter, a New York Democrat, stating, "I don't know why the American public is not outraged over the fact that none of their business is taken care of, but over and over and over again we talk about taking health care away from people."

The bill's path through the Senate will be challenging, as it must win the approval of the chamber's parliamentarian, who will rule on which provisions meet reconciliation's arcane rules. A provision that would repeal Obamacare's Medicare spending board was already removed from the bill due to the parliamentarian's likely ruling that it would be out of order.

A trio of Senate Republicans, including two 2016 presidential hopefuls, have stated that the legislation "simply isn't good enough" and does not fulfill repeated promises to repeal the entire law. The bill passed with the support of Republican votes, with only seven GOP members rejecting it and one Democrat, Rep. Collin Peterson of Minnesota, voting "yes," though he has been opposed to Obamacare in the past.

The bill's passage comes as House Speaker John A. Boehner is set to be replaced by Rep. Paul Ryan, who won the support of the House's three main factions and swayed a majority of the House Freedom Caucus, a coalition of hard-line conservatives who pushed Mr. Boehner out of office. Mr. Ryan is putting himself at odds with the Heritage Foundation on the reconciliation bill, and Friday's vote appeared to split the Freedom Caucus itself.

Title: DHS Ammunition Purchases Under Scrutiny: Republican Lawmakers Question Department's Bullet Buys

Article:

In a hearing on Thursday, Republican Rep. Jason Chaffetz of Utah questioned the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) over its ammunition purchases, stating that the department is using roughly 1,000 rounds of ammunition more per person than the U.S. Army. Chaffetz, who chairs one of the House oversight subcommittees, noted that the DHS currently has more than 260 million rounds in stock, with over 103 million rounds purchased in 2012 and 116 million used the same year, among approximately 70,000 agents.

Comparing these figures with the small-arms purchases procured by the U.S. Army, Chaffetz noted that the DHS is churning through between 1,300 and 1,600 rounds per officer, while the U.S. Army goes through roughly 350 rounds per soldier. Nick Nayak, the chief procurement officer for the Department of Homeland Security, did not challenge Chaffetz's numbers but sought to counter what he described as several misconceptions about the bullet buys.

Despite reports that the department was trying to buy up to 1.6 billion rounds over five years, Nayak clarified that the number is closer to 750 million. He also stated that the department, on average, buys roughly 100 million rounds per year. Nayak further countered claims that the department is stockpiling ammo, stating that such claims are "simply not true." He also denied that the purchases are contributing to broader ammunition shortages in the U.S.

While Democrats likened concerns about the purchases to conspiracy theories, Republicans raised concerns about the sheer cost of the ammunition. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, stated, "This is not about conspiracy theories, this is about good government." Rep. Darrell Issa, R-Calif., who chairs the full Oversight and Government Reform Committee, suggested that rounds may be being stockpiled, then either "disposed of," passed to non-federal agencies, or shot "indiscriminately." If that is the case, he said, "then shame on you." The department has long stated that it needs the bullets for agents in training and on duty, and buys in bulk to save money.

Title: Romney Accuses Obama Administration of Misunderstanding Threat of Radical Islam, Sharpens Attack on Libya and Egypt Incidents

Article:

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, is set to deliver a major foreign-policy speech at the Virginia Military Institute on Monday, where he will accuse the Obama administration of fundamentally misunderstanding the threat of radical Islam. The speech, which was delayed for nearly a month, will also sharpen Romney's attack on the way President Obama handled the assault on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya.

According to excerpts, Romney will say that President Obama's initial reaction was to blame an Internet video mocking Islam, and only belatedly to acknowledge "the deliberate work of terrorists who use violence to impose their dark ideology on others."

Romney will argue that Obama's response to the attacks is emblematic of his overall approach to foreign affairs, which Romney said he will change by asserting more American influence. He will propose using foreign aid to pressure Egypt to protect democracy, building the Syrian opposition, and restarting negotiations toward a two-state solution for the Israelis and Palestinians.

The Obama campaign has criticized Romney's foreign policy credentials, stating that he has not demonstrated his ability to handle foreign policy. Jen Psaki, an Obama campaign spokeswoman, said, "We're not going to be lectured by someone who has been an unmitigated disaster on foreign policy every time he's dipped his toe in the foreign policy waters."

The economy has dominated the presidential race, but Iran's nuclear program and the September 11 attacks on the American Embassy in Cairo and the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, have thrust foreign affairs into the headlines. The Obama administration initially said the attacks were sparked by a video mocking the Prophet Muhammad, but have since acknowledged that the attack in Benghazi was orchestrated by terrorist elements linked to al Qaeda.

The Romney campaign has not specified how his foreign policy would differ from Obama's, and this question has been a point of contention throughout the campaign. Romney's advisers, however, have stated that he starts from a completely different philosophy that begins with the belief that the fight against terrorism cannot be conducted surgically.

Romney chose VMI, in Lexington, Va., to deliver the speech because it was the alma mater of George C. Marshall, who, as secretary of state and secretary of defense, helped craft the foreign policy that guided Republicans and Democrats after World War II. The presidential race has seen a series of ups and downs over the past week, with Romney's strong debate performance and the release of unemployment numbers benefiting Obama, while the Obama campaign announced they collected $181 million in donations in September. The campaigns have exchanged rhetorical blows over their contrasting economic messages, with both sides airing television ads criticizing each other's tax plans.

Title: Trump's Embrace of American Health Care Act: A Betrayal of Promises Made to the American People

Article:

Donald Trump's endorsement of the American Health Care Act, authored by Paul Ryan and other House Republicans in collaboration with establishment-minded members of his administration, represents a significant departure from his clear and repeated promises to the American people.

While it was likely that Trump would break some of his promises, the extent of his shift towards more centrist positions on health care and retirement security is a crucial aspect that cannot be overlooked. Trump ran and won on a platform that included promises to cover everyone, avoid Medicaid cuts, and boost funding for opioid abuse treatment. However, the American Health Care Act, which he is now lobbying Congress to pass, does none of those things.

In May 2015, Trump told the conservative Daily Signal, "I'm not going to cut Social Security like every other Republican and I'm not going to cut Medicare or Medicaid." He reiterated these promises throughout his campaign, stating, "I am going to take care of everybody" and "Everybody's going to be taken care of much better than they're taken care of now."

The centerpiece of the Trump-endorsed American Health Care Act is a $600 billion tax cut. While families with incomes below $208,500 per year will see their taxes fall by an average of $0 per year, receiving none of that money, members of the top 0.1 percent of the income distribution—households with an annual income of more than $3.75 million—will see their taxes fall by an average of $165,090 per year.

The American Health Care Act's tax cuts come at a cost, with an estimated 6 to 15 million people losing insurance, according to various analyses. The administration's current strategy is to deny these projections and claim that nobody will lose coverage. However, this is contradicted by the bill's requirement for offsetting long-term spending cuts to enact the tax cuts under budget reconciliation rules.

The bill shifts $370 billion in Medicaid costs onto state governments, some of which will likely respond by throwing people off the program. The American Health Care Act also drastically reduces federal subsidies to help people pay for insurance, meaning many people will drop out.

While the American Health Care Act specifically advantages and disadvantages certain groups of people relative to the ACA, it will particularly harm older Americans and residents of rural areas where the cost of health insurance is inherently higher due to reduced competition.

Trump's betrayal of his health care promises is not only a departure from his campaign promises but also a specific harm to the people who voted for him the most. As Nate Cohn writes for the New York Times, Trump will be specifically harming his own voter base. It remains to be seen whether Trump voters will care about this, but it is unlikely that Trump made these promises without considering their popularity.

Title: Trump's Hydroxychloroquine Use and Pelosi's Comment Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Donald Trump's admission on Monday that he has been taking hydroxychloroquine, a drug he has long advocated for in the fight against COVID-19, has sparked a flurry of questions and controversy. Some speculate whether Trump was lying about his use of the drug, while others question the medical reasoning behind its prescription. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has cautioned against using hydroxychloroquine outside of hospitals, and the drug has been linked to deaths.

The news did not seem to alarm Trump's supporters, but a comment from Speaker Nancy Pelosi did. In an interview with CNN on Monday night, Pelosi expressed concern about the president's use of the drug, particularly given his age and weight. "He's our president, and I would rather he not be taking something that has not been approved by the scientists, especially in his age group and in his, shall we say, weight group—morbidly obese," Pelosi said.

The reaction to Pelosi's comment, regardless of political affiliation, was varied. Some found the comment humorous, while others took offense at what they perceived as a "fat-shaming" of the president. Trump supporters, in particular, took umbrage at Pelosi's comment, with some accusing her of "fat-shaming" and violating the rules of body positivity.

However, Pelosi's comment was not the first time the president has been criticized for his comments about weight and appearance. Throughout his public career, Trump has been accused of making derogatory and insensitive comments about women, immigrants, the media, and people with disabilities.

Some Trump supporters, emboldened by Pelosi's comment, took the opportunity to make their own fat-shaming remarks about others, including public figures such as Lizzo, Stacey Abrams, and unnamed individuals.

The earnestness with which these comments were made suggests that they were not intended as jokes. In response, S.E. Cupp, the host of "S.E. Cupp Unfiltered" on CNN, tweeted, "The president has referred to women over the course of his public career as 'dogs,' 'pigs,' 'fat,' 'ugly,''slobs,' 'lowlifes,' and 'horseface'; he has bragged about grabbing women by the genitals, and has been accused by no fewer than 25 women of sexual misconduct."

Cupp's tweet sparked a debate about the rules of decency and the hypocrisy of those who are offended by Pelosi's comment but remain silent or even support the president's own history of offensive remarks. The debate continues as to whether Pelosi's comment was inappropriate or a valid concern for the president's health.

Title: Senate Republicans Face Challenges in Delivering on Obamacare Premium Reduction Promises

Article:

Senate Republicans are grappling with finding ways to reduce health insurance premiums as part of their efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The options for reducing premiums are limited, with the primary methods being offering larger subsidies, allowing insurers to offer skimpier coverage, or permitting insurers to charge more to those with pre-existing conditions and older individuals.

Republicans argue that Obamacare's insurance regulations are responsible for making coverage expensive, and premiums would decrease if these rules are rolled back. However, they have yet to develop a comprehensive plan to achieve this goal while preserving consumer protections.

Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) expressed concern that reducing premiums could come at the expense of those with pre-existing conditions or by significantly reducing benefits. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) acknowledged the complexity of reducing premiums but emphasized the importance of making health care affordable for families.

Analysts suggest that Republicans may achieve their goal for younger, healthier consumers, but at the cost of eliminating popular consumer protections like the ban on insurers charging more for coverage to those with pre-existing conditions. This could leave millions of people unable to afford the increased premiums associated with conditions such as heart disease, rheumatoid arthritis, or cancer.

The Congressional Budget Office's report on the House repeal plan has made the Senate Republicans' task more difficult. The analysis concluded that allowing states to opt out of Obamacare's pre-existing condition requirement would destabilize markets and in some cases, drive premiums upward for older, sicker people.

Some Republicans, such as Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.), advocate for preserving the pre-existing condition policy, while others, like Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.), argue that Obamacare's pre-existing condition policy is the "biggest reason" premiums have increased.

Republicans have proposed allowing insurers to sell more basic policies without certain benefits, such as maternity coverage, mental health, or prescription drug benefits. However, they may face challenges in implementing these changes due to the complex rules governing the fast-track process being used to avoid a Democratic filibuster.

Some Republicans also support allowing insurers to charge older people higher premiums, although Republican leaders appear to have been deterred by the backlash faced by House Republicans when they raised the idea. Ultimately, the GOP drive to reduce premiums could result in an increase in the number of uninsured Americans.

Premiums vary across the country but have generally been on the rise. This year, benchmark Obamacare policies in 17 major cities rose an average of 9 percent, according to the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation. That's up from 2 percent in 2016.

Lawmakers can influence market conditions to make premiums fall, but they do not control how insurers set rates. Sen. Mike Rounds (R-S.D.), a former insurance executive, emphasized the need to recognize how to bring actual costs down and transfer them to the insurance industry.

Ultimately, the success of the GOP's efforts to reduce premiums will be judged by the extent to which they achieve this goal. When asked about the possibility of achieving this goal, Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.), the Senate's No. 3 Republican, responded, "That is the goal."

Title: President Trump Delivers Expletive-Laden Speech at CPAC, Accuses Mueller's Team and Clinton Aide

Article:

In a two-hour speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on Saturday, President Donald Trump accused FBI Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team of attempting to "take him out with 'bullshit'" and criticized a top Clinton aide for not having "recovered from getting his a-- kicked."

Trump, in his speech, alleged that his opponents were moving away from the narrative of Russian collusion as Mueller prepares to file his report on the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. He stated that the report was being produced "by people who weren't elected."

The President also commented on the recently revealed book proposal by his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, stating, "Cohen's newly revealed book proposal blows up his testimony: Totally discredited!"

Trump's remarks come just days after Cohen testified to a House committee, where he partially refuted some of the claims surrounding theories about the Trump campaign's alleged collusion with Moscow, including denying that he traveled to Prague in 2016 and saying he has no knowledge of any compromising material Russia may have on Trump.

In his speech, Trump pointed to alleged hypocrisy from Democrats who, he said, wanted to fire former FBI Director James Comey, only to change their tune when Trump fired him in 2017. He singled out Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and former Hillary Clinton campaign chair John Podesta.

"Podesta, I believe that day, because he still hasn't gotten over getting his a-- kicked, I believe that day called for his resignation," he said. "Podesta, the great genius of campaigns."

He went on to say he told First Lady Melania Trump that the move would be popular.

"And I fire a bad cop, I fire a dirty cop, and all of a sudden the Democrats say 'How dare he fire him? How dare he do this?'" he said. "That's where we are. In this swamp of Washington, D.C., but you know what? We are winning, and they're not."

The President's speech also touched on various other topics, including media bias, his "Never Trump" opponents within the GOP, and Democratic policies like the Green New Deal. He jokingly encouraged the Green New Deal, apparently sensing that the policy may be unpopular and lead to his re-election.

He also used anecdotes to promote his policies at home and abroad, particularly pulling back troops from the Middle East. He spoke at length about a Christmas visit to Iraq, where he was told to kill the lights on Air Force One as it came into land.

"We spent $7 trillion, and we can't land a plane with the lights on," he said.

As Trump spoke, the crowd appeared to be highly engaged, with audience members standing on chairs and craning their necks to get a glimpse as the Rolling Stones' "Time Is On My Side" blared through the speakers, indicating the president's imminent arrival.

Title: Former NSA Officials Express Confusion Over Nunes' Claims of Surveillance on Trump Transition Team

Article:

A group of former top National Security Agency (NSA) officials gathered on Friday prior to an academic conference in Washington, discussing the ongoing investigation by the House Intelligence Committee into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election. The conversation centered around Representative Devin Nunes (R-CA), the committee's chairman, and his recent claims that President Trump's transition team had been subject to surveillance by U.S. intelligence.

The Nunes-led panel has been investigating Russian interference in the election, and his claims, made public this week, have caused a stir, as there has been a consistent lack of evidence to support President Trump's allegation that he was wiretapped by his predecessor, President Barack Obama. The former NSA leaders found Nunes' claims vague and inconsistent, and they were unsure about the type of surveillance he was referring to.

James A. Lewis, a senior vice president at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) and former State Department official, witnessed the discussion and stated, "They were scratching their heads trying to figure out what was going on."

The confusion surrounding Nunes' actions has raised concerns about the credibility of the Intelligence Committee's investigation, with Democrats questioning his motives. Critics have called for an independent commission or select committee to take over the Russia investigation. Nunes, however, maintains that he is fulfilling his responsibilities as intelligence panel chief.

Nunes' dispute began on Wednesday when he held a press conference to announce that a source had revealed "dozens of reports" showing that unnamed U.S. intelligence agencies had collected information about Trump or members of his transition team as part of their "normal foreign surveillance." This collection was legal, said Nunes, and it was not confirmation that Trump's tweets claiming he was wiretapped by Mr. Obama were true.

Since then, Nunes has walked back some of his original implications. He does not have the documents in question in his possession, though he has requested them from the NSA. He is unsure whether Trump officials were part of the conversations collected by U.S. intelligence, or whether their names were simply mentioned by two foreign persons under U.S. surveillance.

On Friday, Nunes declined to say how many Trump-related names had been "unmasked" in the documents he is discussing. "I don't know that yet," he said, stating that he was waiting for the NSA to provide copies of the documents for his full perusal.

Presumably, the Intelligence Committee chairman is referring to reports or other summaries of emails or phone conversations obtained by the NSA under Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA). This law allows the NSA to listen in on foreign targets. If the foreign target happens to contact a U.S. citizen, the NSA can still spy on the communications. That's called "incidental collection." However, the agency must mask the name of the American. The name can be unmasked for compelling intelligence reasons.

The specific details of who was being surveilled and why remain unclear. James Lewis of CSIS notes, "What we don't know is who was talking to whom. It could have been a Russian under surveillance talking to an American – Ambassador Sergey Kislyak talking to former Trump National Security Advisor Michael Flynn, for instance. Or it could have been foreigners simply talking about an American."

The reasons for unmasking the names would also remain a question. Perhaps they were integral to the intelligence value of the conversation, as it would be indicative if someone were speaking of an important Trump associate. On Friday, Nunes said he could not figure out why the names he's seen were not hidden, but he added that all of it appeared to be "legal surveillance" as well as "valuable intelligence."

Without more details, it's unclear whether Nunes has uncovered a situation that's troubling or not. However, by raising the charge, he's increased the political temperature of his own panel's work. The top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA), has said that Nunes' actions have raised "profound doubt" about the panel's ability to conduct an impartial investigation of Russian meddling. Nunes didn't brief the committee on his findings until he'd been to the White House and held two press conferences, Representative Schiff said.

On Friday, the situation became further inflamed when Nunes canceled a public hearing scheduled to feature former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper, among others. In its place, the panel will hold a closed hearing with FBI director James Comey and NSA chief Adm. Mike Rogers, who testified publicly earlier in the week. "It's necessary to get both of them back down here before we can move onto other interviews," Nunes said.

Title: Trump Attempts to Pivot Campaign Strategy as Election Nears, Faces Challenges in Winning Over Voters

Article:

In a bid to revitalize his struggling campaign, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has made significant changes to his campaign staff and strategy. Stephen Bannon, an executive from Breitbart News, has been brought on as a key advisor, effectively demoting Paul Manafort who subsequently resigned.

In a surprising admission, Trump acknowledged that he has said the "wrong thing" at certain points during his presidential campaign and expressed regret for these statements. The move comes as Trump is facing significant challenges in the polls, with poor showings in swing states, red states, and blue states.

The New York Times reported that Trump is even struggling to maintain support among his core demographic, white men. This development, coupled with the ongoing concerns about Trump's capacity to be president, has led some political analysts to predict a landslide victory for the Democrats.

If the Democrats win, they could capture the White House by a substantial margin, secure control of the Senate for the first time since 2010, and potentially take over a majority of the House of Representatives, although the odds of this last scenario remain low. The Republican party is reportedly feeling the pressure, with good reason.

Pivoting to a "New Trump," as some are calling it, will not be an easy task. It is challenging for any candidate at this stage of the campaign, and it will be particularly difficult for Donald Trump. Shaking up his campaign team, which he has done before, will not be enough to turn the tide.

Social scientists have cautioned against "game change" accounts of presidential campaigns, and the most significant challenge Trump currently faces is the overwhelming evidence from aggregate poll numbers that point to problems for the Republican ticket. While there are always a few polls that suggest the race might be tightening, a broader look at the data indicates that Trump is consistently struggling in almost every part of the country, including very red states like Utah.

My colleague at Princeton, Sam Wang, has shown that when all the polls are combined, Trump does not stand much of a chance of winning. Currently, Clinton is running 5.8 percentage points above President Obama's standing versus the 2012 GOP candidate Mitt Romney at the same point in the campaign four years ago.

Despite speculation that Trump would pivot to a more appealing message for the wider audience of general election voters, he has consistently failed to stay the course. Occasionally, he gives carefully calibrated speeches using a teleprompter, but then immediately reverts to his more extreme messages.

Trump has shown no interest in backing away from the provocative style that brought him to the forefront. His advisers have not been able to push him in a different direction, and as he slips in the polls, his instincts seem to be to double down on this kind of behavior.

Trump's efforts to reach out to new constituencies, such as African-American voters, will not be easy. In recent days, Trump has made attempts to appeal to African-American voters by criticizing Democrats for failing to deliver on their promises to the community. However, these kinds of speeches will do little to sway a part of the American electorate whose support for Trump registers a stunningly low level of 1 percent.

African-Americans will not start turning to Trump after the kinds of statements he has made over the course of his campaign, including his slow response to calls to dissociate himself from white supremacist supporters. Nor will the GOP as a whole easily reverse its disadvantage with African-American voters unless it works to reverse the damage caused by the party's positions on key issues like voting rights, economic inequality, and police violence.

As the summer comes to a close, we are pretty late into the election game. While there have been moments in US history, such as Hubert Humphrey's surge in the fall of 1968, when candidates have been able to rapidly gain ground on their opponents (of course, Humphrey still lost the election), these comebacks do not happen too often. Given the chaotic and underdeveloped state of Trump's campaign field operation in the swing states, it will be extremely difficult for him to achieve anything of this sort.

The three presidential debates, which begin in late September, offer an opportunity to change the direction of the race. The possibility of some kind of crisis or data dump creates room for campaigns to shift course. Most often, however, there is no October Surprise.

Fundamentally changing the direction of the campaign will be extremely hard for the GOP. The recent comments and new campaign staff will not be enough. Republicans might conclude that they will be better off focusing on the Senate and House races than placing too much hope in the idea that the man at the top of the ticket has a big trick up his sleeve.

Title: Trump's Tweets Spark Controversy: A Closer Look at the President's Remarks to Congresswomen

Article:

In a series of tweets on Sunday, President Donald Trump directed criticism towards four freshman Democratic representatives, including Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (N.Y.), Ilhan Omar (Minn.), Rashida Tlaib (Mich.), and Ayanna Pressley (Mass.). The tweets, which some have interpreted as racist, have sparked a national conversation about the nature of the comments and their implications.

Trump's tweets, in essence, suggested that the four representatives should return to the countries from which they originated. However, three of the four representatives were born in the United States, and the fourth, Ilhan Omar, was born in Somalia and is a naturalized U.S. citizen, according to the New York Times.

The sentiment expressed in Trump's tweets has been widely criticized as racist. Merriam-Webster defines racism as "a belief that race is the primary determinant of human traits and capacities and that racial differences produce an inherent superiority of a particular race." The president's comments are seen as targeting non-white women and suggesting that they are not truly American or that their views are not welcome in the country.

Furthermore, the comments have been criticized as anti-American, as they contradict the long-held notion that America is a melting pot, a place where people from diverse backgrounds come together to create a stronger, more vibrant society. The idea of America as a melting pot suggests that the diversity of its people is a strength, not a weakness, and that the country is improved by the unique experiences and perspectives brought by its inhabitants.

Trump's comments have been met with condemnation from both sides of the political aisle, with many arguing that the president's words are not only racist but also divisive and harmful to the fabric of American society. The president's remarks have been compared to past instances of racism and xenophobia in American history, and some have called for a more unified response from political leaders to address the issue.

In the past, President Trump has been criticized for his rhetoric and comments regarding race and diversity. During his campaign, he painted a dark picture of America, deriding so-called political correctness and suggesting that if he was not elected, it would mark the end of the American experiment. In his inauguration speech, Trump painted a dystopian version of the America he was to lead, describing it as a place plagued by poverty, crime, and a failing education system.

Trump's slogan, "Make America Great Again," has been interpreted by some as a call to return to a time when America was supposedly better, a time when white people and men supposedly held more power and influence. This interpretation has been criticized as racist and anti-American, as it suggests that America was better off before the diversity that exists today.

In contrast, former President Barack Obama, in a speech in March 2008, spoke of the importance of diversity and the need to work together to create a more just and equal America. Obama's words, in many ways, represent the antithesis of Trump's rhetoric and serve as a reminder of the ideals that America was founded upon: a place where people from diverse backgrounds come together to create a more perfect union.

In conclusion, President Trump's tweets directed at the four freshman Democratic representatives have sparked a national conversation about race, diversity, and the nature of America. The comments have been widely criticized as racist and anti-American, and have been compared to past instances of racism and xenophobia in American history. The president's words serve as a reminder of the importance of diversity and the need to work together to create a more just and equal society, a society that truly embodies the ideals of the melting pot.

Title: China's Interest in Iraq's Oil Fields: Implications and Perspectives

Article:

The China National Petroleum Corporation has expressed interest in acquiring a 60 percent stake in the West Qurna I oil field, a potential divestment from Exxon Mobil due to the latter's oil interests in Iraqi Kurdistan. Despite initial resistance, Exxon Mobil has yet to make a definitive decision. In March, the Chinese company expressed openness to forming a partnership with Exxon Mobil for the oil field.

The potential Chinese investment in Iraq's oil sector could have positive implications for global oil prices and geopolitical stability. If the United States invasion and occupation of Iraq resulted in increased Iraqi oil production, much of it pumped by Chinese workers, it has shielded the world economy from a potential spike in oil prices due to Western sanctions on Iranian oil exports.

With the boom in American domestic oil production from new shale fields, the United States' dependence on Middle Eastern oil has declined, making access to Iraqi fields less vital. However, China's interest in Iraq could help stabilize the country as it faces a growing sectarian conflict.

David Goldwyn, former State Department coordinator for international energy affairs in the first Obama administration, stated, "Our interest is the oil gets produced and Iraq makes money, so this is a big plus. Geopolitically it develops close links between China and Iraq, although China did not get into it for the politics. Now that they are there, they have a great stake in assuring the continuity of the regime that facilitates their investment."

China's growing economy relies heavily on oil imports, with Iraq being one of several countries it invests in to meet its energy needs. China recently became the world's biggest oil importer, and with its consumption growing, it is investing heavily in oil and gas fields worldwide. Over 50 percent of its oil imports come from the Middle East, even as imports from Iran have been reduced in recent years.

The Iraqi government depends on oil revenues to finance its military and social programs. Iraq, currently OPEC's second-largest oil producer after Saudi Arabia, estimates that its oil fields, pipelines, and refineries need $30 billion in annual investments to reach production targets that will make it one of the world's premier energy powers for decades to come.

The revenue that investment would produce could either help alleviate tensions between Kurds, Shiites, and Sunnis or exacerbate those tensions as competing factions vie for control of the oil resources. The article does not provide specific information on the potential impact of Chinese investment on Iraq's internal conflicts.

Title: Presidential Persuasion: The Challenges Facing Obama in Rallying Public Support for U.S.-Led Airstrikes in Syria

Article:

President Barack Obama's upcoming media blitz, including interviews on six television networks and a primetime Oval Office address, is not expected to garner significant public support for U.S.-led airstrikes in Syria, according to an analysis by George C. Edwards III, university distinguished professor of political science and Jordan chair at Texas A&M University.

The belief in the dominant president who moves the country and the government through strong leadership has deep roots in American political culture. However, history shows that even great communicators typically fail to move the public to support their initiatives.

Presidents such as Bill Clinton, "the great explainer," could not win public backing for his economic stimulus bill or his cornerstone proposal for reforming the health-care system. Nor did the public support his 1999 bombing in the Balkans.

Similarly, Ronald Reagan faced opposition when he took office, with the public moving against increased defense spending, and he never achieved even plurality support for his high-priority policy of aiding the Contras in Nicaragua. Reagan could not convince the public to support limiting domestic policy expenditures or environmental regulations. Rescuing Americans in Grenada was an easier sell.

World War II posed the greatest crisis of the twentieth century. Franklin D. Roosevelt, the century's supreme politician, was continually frustrated in his efforts to convince Americans to rearm and aid their allies against Adolf Hitler's onslaught. It took events in Europe and then Pearl Harbor, not a fireside chat, to change voters' minds.

These presidents were not stymied in their efforts to persuade the public because they avoided engaging the public, framed their positions ineffectively, or articulated their views in unappealing terms. They failed because of the nature of public opinion and the president's communication environment.

The president faces strong competition for the public's attention, and most people are not attentive to him. Barely a tenth of the population watched Obama's 2013 State of the Union address. Moreover, many people who do pay attention miss the president's points, and the less people know, the more confidence they have in their pre-existing beliefs and resist factual information. A desire to avoid risk and distrust of government make people wary of policy initiatives, especially when they are complex and their consequences are uncertain, as is the case with virtually every proposal for a major shift in public policy and undoubtedly is the case of military action against Syria.

What's more, the opposition gets to have its say. Committed, well-organized, and well-funded opponents can undermine the White House's efforts to write its own narrative and place the president's performance in a favorable light. Republicans are not accepting the White House view that attacking Syria will weaken Assad and deter his use of chemical weapons. Then there's partisanship, which is especially likely to bias perceptions, interpretations, and responses to the president. Most people seek out information confirming their opinions and ignore or reject arguments that contradict their predispositions.

The deep polarization of today's politics only exacerbates these tendencies. One might think opinion about military action against Syria would be fluid because the issue is relatively new. The president would be wise to couch his presentation in terms of a unique situation posing a grave threat to the nation's security rather than the general international responsibilities of a humane superpower. The latter frame activates opinions that counsel against taking action.

Nevertheless, the president is unlikely to change many opinions. Those least likely to change are Republicans, the core constituency of the House majority. Although one wing of the GOP favors a more aggressive foreign policy, few Republican voters trust the president. And even those inclined to hear his argument will note the relative lack of international support for U.S. action. Meanwhile, a range of partisan leaders they do trust is signaling that opposing a strike is the wiser course.

The president might have better luck with his fellow Democrats. Many will remain opposed to attacking Syria because of their deep opposition to violence in international relations. A few others, and it will be at most a few, may be moved by their general predisposition to support their party's leader. This calculation explains why administration officials have fanned out to liberal outfits such as MSNBC and the Center for American Progress in recent days.

But barring dramatic events in Syria itself, the world will not change on Tuesday. Partisan politics will not stop at the water's edge, and the president is unlikely to substantially increase public support for military action against Syria. It's not because, as you'll hear often in the days ahead, he's a pale shadow of great presidents of yore; it's just the way American politics really works.

Title: FISA-Gate Scandal: A Comparative Analysis with Watergate and Iran-Contra Affairs

Article:

The FISA-Gate scandal, unfolding in the present day, shares similarities with the Watergate and Iran-Contra affairs of the past, as it involves allegations of government officials using intelligence agencies for political purposes. The scandal centers around members of the Obama administration's Department of Justice seeking court approval for the surveillance of Carter Page, a Trump campaign associate, based on an unverified dossier that originated from a Hillary Clinton campaign-funded opposition research.

In the Watergate scandal of 1972-74, Democratic politicians and a tenacious media uncovered the Nixon administration's attempts to manipulate the CIA and FBI to cover up a minor, though illegal, political break-in. In the Iran-Contra affair of 1985-87, the media and liberal activists exposed wrongdoing by some rogue members of the Reagan government, warning of government overreach and the use of the "Deep State" to subvert the law for political purposes.

The FISA-Gate scandal, however, presents a unique twist. Unlike the Watergate and Iran-Contra scandals, the media and liberal civil libertarians are now opposing the disclosure of public documents, siding with those in the government who sought surveillance to facilitate the efforts of a political campaign. This time around, the press is not after a hated Nixon administration or a conservative Reagan team; instead, the roles are reversed.

Barack Obama, a progressive constitutional lawyer who expressed distrust of the secretive "Deep State," is accused of weaponizing the IRS and surveilling Associated Press communications and a Fox News journalist for reporting unfavorable news based on supposed leaks. This contrasts with the past stereotypes of right-wing authoritarians subverting the Department of Justice and its agencies.

The FISA-Gate scandal is still unfolding, and its full extent remains to be seen. However, the potential for it to surpass the Watergate and Iran-Contra scandals lies in the fact that our defense against government wrongdoing—the press—is defending such actions, not uncovering them. Liberal and progressive voices are excusing, not airing, the excesses of the DOJ and FBI.

Victor Davis Hanson, a classicist and historian at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, is the author of "The Second World Wars: How the First Global Conflict Was Fought and Won" (Basic Books, 2017).

Title: Potential U.S. Strike on Syria: Implications and Concerns

Article:

The potential military action by the United States against Syria, despite strong opposition from various countries and influential political and religious leaders, including the Pope, has raised concerns about the potential consequences. The strike could result in more innocent casualties and escalate the conflict, potentially spreading it beyond Syria's borders.

The conflict in Syria is not a struggle for democracy, but an armed conflict between the government and opposition in a multi-religious country. The number of democracy advocates in Syria is limited, while there are numerous Qaeda fighters and extremists engaged in the conflict. The U.S. State Department has designated Al Nusra Front and the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, fighting with the opposition, as terrorist organizations. This internal conflict, fueled by foreign weapons supplied to the opposition, is one of the bloodiest in the world.

Concerns have been raised about mercenaries from Arab countries fighting in Syria, as well as hundreds of militants from Western countries and even Russia. There is a fear that these individuals, having gained experience in Syria, might return to their home countries, posing a potential threat. This is a concern, as extremists who fought in Libya moved on to Mali, posing a threat to global security.

From the outset, Russia has advocated for peaceful dialogue, enabling Syrians to develop a compromise plan for their future. Russia is not supporting the Syrian government, but international law. The preservation of law and order in today's complex and turbulent world is seen as one of the few ways to prevent international relations from sliding into chaos. The law is the law, and it must be followed, regardless of personal opinions.

Under current international law, force is permitted only in self-defense or by the decision of the United Nations Security Council. Any action outside of these parameters would be unacceptable under the United Nations Charter and would constitute an act of aggression.

While there is no doubt that poison gas was used in Syria, there is reason to believe it was used not by the Syrian Army, but by opposition forces, to provoke intervention by their powerful foreign patrons, who would be siding with the fundamentalists. Reports of militants preparing another attack, this time against Israel, cannot be ignored.

Title: House Republicans Abandon Health Care Bill, Democrats Celebrate

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, House Republicans have decided to abandon their high-stakes health care bill after failing to secure enough support from within their own party. The move leaves the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, intact.

Democrats immediately celebrated the development, taking to social media and holding press conferences to express relief for the American public. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi told reporters, "Today is a great day for our country. It's a victory. What happened on the floor is a victory for the American people."

Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez said in a statement, "In the words of my friend Joe Biden: This is a BFD."

The failure to uphold their campaign promise to repeal and replace Obamacare is expected to embolden and amplify the Democratic party, both in Congress and at the grassroots level.

Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-California, told CNN the bill's downfall was due not only to Republican intra-party disagreement, but also to the liberal movement that's been pushing back against the new Republican government since President Donald Trump's first day.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said Friday that the health care disaster sets a poor precedent for Republicans in the new Congress, adding that they're unlikely to have much luck with the president's budget plan.

Democrats are now entering what will likely be an ugly fight over Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch. The Democrats were already planning to filibuster, but Republicans can still get around that by lowering the threshold needed to end a filibuster from 60 votes to a simple majority.

Whether the health care bill fiasco will have a real impact on the Gorsuch nomination is unclear, but it could give Democrats some momentum as they head into the week.

Speaker Paul Ryan acknowledged the Republican setback in a sobering press conference. "I will not sugarcoat this," he said. "This is a disappointing day for us. Doing big things is hard."

Republicans are already fretting about next year's midterm elections, with one senior GOP official telling CNN, "2018 will be tough."

Rep. Ben Ray Lujan, chairman of the House Democratic campaign arm, is already forecasting which Republicans they could start targeting over the debacle. He told reporters there were 15 Republicans from competitive districts who voted to advance the bill in various committees during the legislative process.

Rep. Jim McGovern, D-Massachusetts, told CNN now is a time for House Republicans "to reflect and be a little bit humble."

"If they want to do something constructive, they'll work with us to find ways to improve the Affordable Care Act," he said. "If they want to play politics and go down the same road again or drop their hands and do nothing, I think that's unfortunate because we have to wait for the Democrats to take over."

Title: President Trump's Response to White Supremacist Terrorism in Charlottesville Falls Short

Article:

President Donald Trump's response to the white supremacist violence in Charlottesville has been criticized for its vagueness and equivocation. During his presidential campaign, Trump often condemned Islamic terrorism, but his response to the events in Charlottesville has been met with criticism for failing to label the violence as an act of terrorism.

The president's initial statement, which condemned "violence on many sides," has been widely criticized as insufficient. The subsequent expansion of the statement, which was not made by the president himself but by an anonymous White House aide, has not been enough to quell the criticism.

While President Trump is correct in acknowledging that there has been violence on both sides during the current season of protests, his denunciation of hatred and bigotry in Charlottesville fell short. It is important that he join other Republican leaders in labeling the violence as an act of terrorism conducted under the auspices of a white-supremacist movement that has embraced terrorism and political violence.

The president's advisor Steve Bannon has been linked to the white-supremacist movement, having boasted of turning the website Breitbart into a platform for the so-called alt-right. Trump-aligned alt-right elements have also taken a more than indulgent attitude toward white-supremacist groups.

Republicans, for the most part, have denounced the white-supremacist violence after Charlottesville. However, the white supremacists and their allies have taken the president's "both sides do it" stance as tacit indulgence, as the closest thing to a public embrace that realpolitik will allow.

The president should treat the Charlottesville white supremacists with the same specificity with which he denounces other political adversaries. The car attack on the counter-protesters has all the hallmarks of a terrorist attack, similar to those seen in other cities around the world.

The violence in Charlottesville is not only a specific act of violence but also a broader cause that should be repudiated. The rally in question was advertised as a project to "Unite the Right." However, the idea of unity with white-supremacist groups, who are characterized by their hatred, bigotry, and racism, is rejected.

The events in Charlottesville are a reminder that armed brawls between white-supremacist groups and their left-wing equivalents are an ordinary part of American politics. Responsible parties on both sides can at the very least be honest about what is happening and unequivocal in their condemnation of it. The president has a special responsibility to set an example, and it is urged that he live up to it.
